title: Analysis of Thermal Disturbance in Vertically Stacked Phase-Change Memory Using Multiphysics Simulation
authors: Yechan Kim, Namwook Hur, Hyesoo Kim, Hongsik Jeong, Joonki Suh, Yongwoo Kwon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Vertically stacked phase-change memory (PCM) architectures represent a promising strategy for realizing high device density; however, they remain susceptible to thermal disturbance (TD), manifested as heat-induced crosstalk between neighboring cells during switching operations. In this study, thermal effects in 3-D PCM arrays are systematically investigated using a multiphysics simulation framework, where our electrothermal and phase-field models are implemented within a commercial finite element solver. By quantitatively analyzing the effects of intercell spacing and cell dimensions, we identify geometrical regimes where TD can be suppressed without sacrificing memory density. Furthermore, we demonstrate that engineering the cell architecture to enhance thermal boundary resistance (TBR), for example, by incorporating recessed heater structures, significantly mitigates heat transfer to adjacent cells and enables lower reset energy operation. Simulation results further reveal the tradeoffs among heater thickness, interlayer dielectric (ILD) thickness, and device endurance over repeated programming cycles. These insights guide the design of stackable PCM cells for robust, energy-efficient, and scalable memory integration.

title: A 12-bit 10GS/s Pre-Sampling Pipelined ADC With Split-Capacitor-Based Parasitic Compensation Technique
authors: Yu Liu, Mingliang Chen, Yupeng Shen, Yao Yang, Xubin Chen, Jiarui Liu, Zhiyu Wang, Faxin Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: Pre-sampling multiplying digital-to-analog converters (MDACs) feature high speed and energy efficiency. However, the parasitic capacitance between the sampling capacitor and the reference capacitor in the pre-sampling MDAC can induce gain and intercept errors in the pipeline stage, which significantly degrades the linearity of the entire pipelined ADC. This work presents a pre-sampling MDAC with parasitic compensation using a split-capacitor technique in the analog domain, combined with an intercept calibration method to correct the gain and intercept errors. Employing this technique, a 12-bit pre-sampling pipelined ADC fabricated in a 28nm CMOS process consumes 495mW at a 10GS/s sampling rate, achieving a signal-to-noise-and-distortion ratio (SNDR) of 50.8dB and a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 60.7dB with a Nyquist input signal.

title: Distributed Fuzzy Voltage Security Restoration of Multi-Source Heterogeneous Microgrid Clusters With Performance Monitoring and Nodes Isolation
authors: Fabin Cheng, Jingang Lai, Zhigang Zeng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems
abstract: The growing integration of massive multi-source heterogeneous distributed generation (DG) into power grids and the emergence of cluster-collaboration-based generation modes have highlighted significant challenges in effectively controlling microgrid clusters (MGCs). This paper develops an interval type-2 (IT2) Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model for the secondary control layer of MGCs with additive disturbances, designed to capture the dynamics of heterogeneous DG under non-cyber attacks. By adopting the constrained-tightening-based prescribed performance control strategy, the proposed low-computation distributed fuzzy secondary control protocol achieves voltage cooperative restoration for MGCs subject to additive disturbances. Notably, this protocol eliminates reliance on the dynamics of upper-level DG for lower-level communication networks while the efficient multi-layer communication structure is employed to facilitate cluster collaboration. Subsequently, the MGC security detection-isolation-deferred switching framework under distributed cyber attacks is established. The proposed method based on performance monitoring for security detection, node isolation, and performance recovery, demonstrating that multi-source heterogeneous DGs can be reconnected to the MGC through deferred switching. This approach enhances the feasibility of the design while maintaining MGC performance standards. Finally, a standard IEEE 33-node distribution model is employed to validate the proposed control protocol's effectiveness via the OPAL-RT real-time simulation platform.

title: Lyapunov-based Nonlinear Model Predictive Control of Input-Delayed Functional Electrical Stimulation: Investigative Simulations and Experiments
authors: K. Lambeth, Z. Sun, A. Iyer, V. Ganesh, N. Sharma
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Control Systems
abstract: Existing closed-loop controllers for functional electrical stimulation are prone to exceeding subject-specific stimulation limits, thereby limiting performance and also accelerating stimulation-induced muscle fatigue. In view of these challenges, this paper develops a Lyapunov-based model predictive control method to control knee flexion and extension during input-delayed stimulation. The method incorporates a contractive constraint under an electromechanical delay (EMD) compensation control law that achieves system stability despite an unknown constant input delay, bounded control constraints, and imperfectly estimated model parameters. A Lyapunov stability analysis proves that the Lyapunov constraint renders the closed-loop error ultimately bounded, and gain conditions are provided to guarantee recursive feasibility. LMPC's performance is explored in simulation and experiments and compared against an analytical proportional derivative-dynamic surface controller (PD-DSC) and a proportional-derivative-delay compensation (PD-DC) controller. In simulation, LMPC improved tracking root-mean-square error by 75.57% and 71.71%, on average, compared to PD-DSC and PD-DC, respectively. We observed that incorporating a slackening term often improved LMPC's tracking performance, although strict enforcement of the Lyapunov constraint was superior when there was greater EMD estimation error. Additionally, unlike PD-DSC and PD-DC, LMPC was not destabilized when EMD was overestimated or underestimated, nor did it violate input constraints. In knee extension experiments, LMPC respected input constraints, which PD-DSC did not. The LMPC was also validated in overground walking experiments to test its ability to produce both knee flexion and extension in participants with and without spinal cord injury.

title: Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM): A Systematic Review of Observability Regimes, Methods, and Evaluation Paradigms
authors: Esdras B. Silva, Hiago G. Almeida, Gabriel A. Silva, Ruhan P. P. Souza, Cristiano M. Agulhari, Marcelo F. Castoldi, Alessandro Goedtel, Wesley A. Souza
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents a systematic review of Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM), analyzing its scientific, methodological, and infrastructural evolution over more than three decades. Rather than being a taxonomic survey, the review develops a system-level synthesis in which NILM is conceptualized as an observability-conditioned cyber-physical inference problem. In this formulation, sensing regimes, physical observability ceilings, abstraction mechanisms, and deployment contexts jointly delimit the admissible inference space and condition achievable performance. A corpus of 2,908 publications indexed in the Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus was analyzed in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) protocol and interpreted through an integrated bibliometric and qualitative analytical framework structured under the Theory-Context-Characteristics-Methodology (TCCM) perspective. The literature is organized into methodological regimes including deterministic low-frequency formulations, probabilistic and optimization-based models, and abstraction-driven deep learning architectures. The analysis indicates that reported performance gains are primarily conditioned by sensing infrastructures and observability structures rather than by algorithmic refinement in isolation. Heterogeneity in sensing configurations and evaluation protocols limits cross-study comparability and deployment transferability. A structural gap is identified between abstraction-driven performance gains and the progressive attenuation of explicit physical interpretability, with implications for validation transparency, physical coherence, and operational robustness. Interpretability is therefore examined as an evaluation-layer property emerging from the interaction between observability regimes, abstraction depth, and deployment constraints. The review concludes that sustainable progress in NILM requires regime-aware design and evaluation paradigms that integrate performance, generalization, physical coherence, and interpretability within deployment-constrained operational environments.

title: Harmonic Cancellation in Multi-Electrolyzer P2H Plants Via Phasor-Modulated Production Scheduling
authors: Yangjun Zeng, Yiwei Qiu, Li Jiang, Jie Zhu, Yi Zhou, Jiarong Li, Shi Chen, Buxiang Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Thyristor rectifiers (TRs) are cost-effective power supplies for hydrogen electrolyzers (ELZs) but introduce harmonic distortion that may violate grid codes. This letter proposes a self-governing harmonic mitigation strategy through coordinated operation of multiple ELZs in large power-to-hydrogen (P2H) plants. First, the harmonic model of TR-powered ELZs is derived, revealing a natural harmonic cancellation mechanism among them. Based on this, a system-level operation scheme based on phasor modulation is developed and integrated into plant scheduling. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed method reduces harmonic currents by 21.2%–39.7% and ensures grid-code compliance, with only a 0.25% loss in hydrogen output, while increasing total revenue by over 21% compared to production-oriented strategies.

title: GDNConv: A Novel Graph Deformation Network for Robust Representation Learning on Noisy Graph Structures
authors: Vinay Santhosh Chitla, Hemantha Kumar Kalluri, Satya Krishna Nunna, Mahesh Kumar Morampudi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Graph Neural Networks have emerged as powerful tools for analyzing graph-structured data. However, their performance often varies across datasets due to challenges such as noisy edges, sparse connectivity, and over-smoothing in deep layers. To address these limitations, Graph Deformation Network Convolution (GDNConv) is proposed as a novel graph convolution model that incorporates four key innovations: dynamic edge weight learning to filter noisy connections, graph attention deformation to prioritize relevant neighbors, multi-level aggregation to capture multi-scale patterns, and self-regularization to stabilize training. This proposed model demonstrates robustness and scalability, particularly for real-world applications involving complex and noisy graph structures, such as social networks and recommendation systems. It has ability to dynamically adapt graph topology during training and superior performance on both dense and sparse datasets highlight its potential as a versatile solution for graph-based learning tasks. Additionally, GDNConv’s computational efficiency and self-regularization mechanisms make it suitable for large-scale applications where resource constraints are a concern. The proposed model is evaluated on four benchmark datasets—Cora, CiteSeer, PubMed, and ogbn-arxiv—and compared with several state-of-the-art models, including Graph Convolutional Network, Graph Attention Network, and Graph Sample and Aggregate. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model consistently outperforms these baseline approaches, achieving improvements of 4.7% and 4.2% in both accuracy and F1 score.

title: Boundary-Aware Time–Frequency Sparse Coding for Low-Overhead IoT Time Series Analytics
authors: Zehui Mu, Dengao Li, Jumin Zhao, Hairong Jiang, Fanming Wu, Xupeng Niu, Qinghong Wang, Shan Xue
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Distributed IoT water quality monitoring systems are evolving toward greater density, broader coverage, and enhanced real-time performance. However, severe constraints on edge-node bandwidth, power consumption, and computational capability make high-accuracy prediction and reliable anomaly detection extremely challenging under intense noise and non-stationary conditions. Water quality time series are characterized by abrupt changes, complex time–frequency patterns, and dominant noise components. Conventional deep learning models applied to such data tend to over-smooth signals, exhibit limited sensitivity to transient features, and incur excessive communication overhead.To address these limitations, a boundary-aware time–frequency sparse learning codec termed BASM is proposed for resource-constrained environments. Preservation of abrupt boundaries and localized anomaly structures is enhanced through boundary-weighted wavelet sparse reconstruction, while prediction robustness in low-SNR regimes is achieved via sparsity-guided ESN. Additionally, a lightweight adaptive anomaly-triggered reporting mechanism is integrated, enabling substantial reduction in uplink traffic without compromising the integrity of anomaly information. Extensive evaluation on real-world datasets from the Yangtze River basin demonstrates that BASM maintains superior stability and accuracy in low-SNR conditions while significantly lowering both communication and computational costs. The framework establishes a new communication–computation co-design paradigm for efficient edge intelligence in IoT-based water quality monitoring.

title: Quantum-Powered Plasma Propulsion: A Sustainable Leap for Deep Space Exploration
authors: Shailesh Singh Thakur, R. Ahila, Haider Mohammed Abbas, A. Moulika, K.S. Bhuvaneshwari, R. Jayanthi, Uzok Jurakulov Tashkent
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Current propulsion methodologies employed during deep space exploration are usually short in their ability to enable manned interplanetary missions to be performed over a long period of time. Chemical rockets are very reliable in terms of launch performance; however, they are inefficient for long-range operation, as they consume a significant amount of propellant and have a low specific impulse. The current propulsion systems, including electric and plasma propulsion systems, as well as the Hall effect and VASIMR propulsion systems, have limitations in the form of plasma instabilities, energy loss, and a lack of high thrust scalability. The outcome of these inadequacies is the need for a propulsion paradigm that is sustainable and capable of producing increased efficiency, thrust density, and mission flexibility. To address this issue promptly, we introduce Quantum-Powered Plasma Propulsion (QPPP). This hybrid propulsion system integrates a blend of state-of-the-art plasma acceleration principles with quantum-capable sensing and control. It involves heating the plasma in a system, applying radio frequency to accelerate ions efficiently using superconducting magnetic nozzles, and accurately locating and in real-time the density, potential, and electromagnetic variations of the plasma. These measurements are fed into a quantum-assisted predictive control loop, in which quantum algorithms can compute the dynamics of the plasma within seconds, enabling sub-cycle optimal control of thrust and stability. Furthermore, the quantum hydrodynamic corrections, including the contribution of the Bohm potential and quantum pressure, are provided to achieve a perfect ion energy distribution and suppress turbulence, which is usually devastating to plasma thrusters. Analytical estimates based on scaled-down quantum magnetohydrodynamic models suggest that QPPP is capable of achieving a thrust and efficiency gain in the 20 to 40 per cent range compared to state-of-the-art plasma thrusters at the same power levels, and that specific impulse can increase to 20 times, thereby reducing propellant consumption and extending mission lifetimes. Finally, QPPP proposes an opportunity-based, transformational propulsion technology that will address the inefficiencies of existing systems in terms of sustainability, efficiency, and scalability, enabling reliable and high-performance exploration of deep space.

title: GenSQL: A Generative AI Framework for Natural Language to SQL Conversion
authors: Surajit Das, Swetha Gadde, M. Amarendhar Reddy, Mogulla Vijay Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to semantic parsing that transforms natural language queries into SQL statements using generative AI. Our system, GenSQL, uses a context-aware semantic parsing framework that responds to different database schemes while eliminating tag needings forming domain specific training. In contrast to previous approaches focusing on phrase based schema linking or heavily dependent on complex predefined encoders/genetive models, GenSQL illustrates how large generative models can capture user intent and outperform the syntactically correct SQL on schema aware translation. The system supports multiple input types including text face and speech recognition, and multiple inputs can support dynamic schema adaptation. GenSQL achieves a precision of $\mathbf{9 4 \%}$ incomplex analytical queries, surpassing recent methods by $\mathbf{7. 8 \%}$. Analysis of error cases reveals that GenSQL shines particularly in simplifying ambiguous natural language queries and queries that involve complex joins. With support for an array of data formats and the ability to handle unfamiliar schemas, this system is especially useful for non-technical users wanting to analyze different data sets without any SQL training.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Depok Single Window Application Reviews on Google Play Store Using Deep Learning
authors: Annisa Aulia Rahma, Amalia Zahra
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study aims to develop and optimize sentiment analysis of user reviews for the Depok Single Window (DSW) application available on the Google Play Store, using two machine learning models, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and IndoBERT. The DSW application, launched by the Depok City Government, provides various public service information accessible via mobile phones, and users can leave reviews about their experiences. Sentiment analysis of user reviews can provide insights into public perception of the application. This research utilizes a dataset of user reviews from the Google Play Store and applies a hybrid approach by using IndoBERT for textual embedding and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for sentiment classification into positive, negative, and neutral categories. Experimental results show that the IndoBERT-SVM model achieves excellent performance, with a test accuracy of 99.1%, macro-averaged precision of 99%, recall of 98%, and F1-score of 99%. At the class level, the model reaches an F1-score of 1.00 for negative sentiment, 0.97 for neutral sentiment, and 0.99 for positive sentiment. These results highlight the potential of combining language-specific pre-trained transformers with traditional machine learning classifiers. The findings are expected to assist application developers and the Depok City Government in understanding user sentiments, improving public service quality, and addressing key community concerns.

title: A Federated Learning-Based EEG Emotion Recognition Method Integrating Dual-View Frequency Domain and Spatiotemporal Features
authors: Pengwei Wang, Yufei Chen, Xuzhe Yan, Aobo Wu, Ziyang He
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is one of the practical, non-invasive tools for emotion recognition. However, the currently available automatic recognition algorithms are still limited due to the complexity of EEG data, user privacy and individual differences. To tackle this challenge, we propose a new EEG emotion recognition method based on dual-view frequency domain features, spatiotemporal features and a personalized few-shot federated learning mechanism. We first fuse DE and PSD features using self-attention to extract richer frequency-domain information. Secondly, we construct the dynamic graph convolutional neural network (DGCNN) and the Transformer encoder as the spatiotemporal feature extraction module to extract the complex spatial topology and the temporal dependencies between EEG channels. Finally, we propose a personalized few-shot federated learning framework to train the model, addressing data heterogeneity while protecting user data privacy. The proposed method achieves 91.89% and 88.63% accuracy on the DEAP and SEED datasets. Compared with the state-of-the-art methods, our method achieves excellent performance.

title: Comparative Study of Sequential Deep Learning Models for Sentiment Analysis of Swiggy and Zomato Reviews
authors: Yash Agrawal, Vandana Sharma, Geeta Sikka
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The online food delivery services is an emerging market in India. Food delivery applications are the medium to it that gives convenience to the user and provides comfort for selecting the meal from any listed restaurant and getting it delivered. The two most popular food delivery applications are Swiggy and Zomato. Users can rate the applications and give the textual feedback too. The user's feedback can be seen over the Google Play Store review section of both applications. The main idea behind the research is to analyze the sentiment of the user based on their textual reviews for the online food delivery service applications to get the insight for value add into user experience. These feedback are essential for organizational growth as well as knowing the consumer's attitude. These reviews of Google Play Store for Swiggy and Zomato have been taken into consideration for the research for sentiment analysis. The dataset comprised 5 lakhs reviews of each platform with 11 attributes. The data was further preprocessed and analyzed with the help of sequential deep learning techniques like RNN, LSTM, GRU with their bidirectional models. The study showed an analysis for performance of different models and found an insight that BiRNN performed well for Swiggy with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 5. 8 \%}$</tex> and Zomato with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex>.

title: Learning to Attack: Objective-Guided FDIA Generation for Smart Grids
authors: Xiao Yue, Guangzhi Qu, Lige Gan
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPSs), such as smart grids, effectively use modern sensors, computing mechanisms, and network technologies to integrate cyber and physical components. However, digital and network technologies in smart grids bring significant vulnerabilities that can be exploited by malicious attackers. In addition to discriminative models for attack detection tasks, generative models such as generative adversarial networks (GANs) are also exploited in the field of false data injection attack (FDIA) on smart grids. In this paper, we propose a novel objective-guided generative model for FDIA sample generation which is designed to support various objectives. Our approach employs a GAN to create FDIA samples, while the training process is guided by an extra pretrained GNN detector. From attackers’ perspectives, adversarial samples can be generated by our model to discover and exploit weaknesses in current detectors. From defenders’ perspectives, they can utilize the model to generate FDIA samples for further training and analysis without running expensive and time-consuming simulations that require domain expertise. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed model in generating high-quality FDIA samples based on various objectives.

title: A Novice Approach for Weather Forecasting by Using Hybrid Predictive Methodologies in ML
authors: Vikas Kamra, Yuvraj Singh, Nihursh Narayan
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Weather forecasting is a very crucial aspect in the contemporary civilization and it is being used in agriculture, transportation, renewable energy, and crisis management among other ways. Correct forecasting will help in informed decision-making, minimize the risks of the economy, as well as increase safety. Conventional forecasting methods which are mainly the products of the numerical weather prediction (NWP) models are founded on computer simulations and atmospheric science. Although helpful, the models also have drawbacks since they are very demanding in terms of processing, lack a good understanding of the physical process, and struggle to utilize large-scale observational data. The development of data-driven technologies has brought promising topical advances in terms of better predictions and efficiency in processing, adaptation to complex patterns, especially regarding Machine Learning (ML) in addition to Artificial Intelligence (AI). The paper will explore the significance of weather prediction, discusses the shortcomings and limitations of classic models of numerical weather prediction, and focuses on the newer machine learningbased systems as a supplementary and a transformative tool of enhancing forecasting reliability in the context of accelerating climate change.

title: A Bi-Level Game-Theoretic Optimization Model for Virtual Power Plants with Shared Energy Storage in Multi-Markets
authors: Tianru Wang, Liuchun Wu, Jie Wu, Xinrui Liu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: In response to the ongoing energy transition and the goals of carbon peaking and neutrality, virtual power plants (VPPs) must integrate shared energy storage and participate in multi-market operations to enhance economic efficiency. This paper proposes a dual-layer game-based optimization framework for VPPs under a shared energy storage leasing mechanism. The upper layer models cooperative interactions among VPPs, while the lower layer captures internal leader-follower decisions between operators and distributed resources. To address the model's high dimensionality and nonlinearity, an improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm is developed by introducing adaptive inertia weights and a chaotic disturbance mechanism to improve convergence and stability. Simulation studies demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances the overall economic performance of VPPs and effectively reduces energy storage investment costs, providing theoretical and practical guidance for low-carbon and efficient VPP operation.

title: Module Voltage Guided Global Maximum Power Point Tracking Algorithm
authors: Pankaj Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The partial shading in Photovoltaic (PV) arrays causes the single maximum power versus voltage (P-V) curve to transit into the multi maximum curve, this led to convergence issues with the traditional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms. Many partial shading centered maximum power point tracking algorithm are available in the literature, these are referred as global maximum power point tracking (GMPPT) methods. The number of peaks considered in these algorithms are less. In this paper, a new partial shading algorithm is proposed, the algorithm can handle a greater number of peaks on the P-V curve. The proposed algorithm is based on the module voltage guidance control. The region of operation on the P-V curve is verified by observing the module voltages. The algorithm is implemented on a boost converter connected to the terminals of a PV array, the array is having three modules connected in series. The model is simulated for two difference cases of three peaks.

title: A Stacked Ensemble Model for Multi-Crop Disease Classification Using Hybrid Feature Extraction and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Kunal Mishra, Reshmi Nayak, Arpita Ojha, Kedar Kumar Dora, Prabira Kumar Sethy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Ensuring food security and sustainable agricultural practices depends on early diagnosis of crop diseases. This paper presents a strong multi-crop disease classification system able to detect ten distinct conditions: Wheat Septoria, Wheat Rust, Sugarcane Fungal, Sugarcane Bacterial, Rice Fungal, Rice Bacterial, Maize Fungal, Maize Bacterial, Pest Attack, and Healthy leaves. Class imbalance was handled using the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) on 1,262 photos gathered from Kaggle and online sources. Feature extraction was done using a hybrid approach incorporating 283 features from statistical descriptors, Haralick texture features, Hu moments, Shannon entropy, and Gabor filters. Using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, several classifiers including Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), 1D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN 1D), and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) were assessed. Of them, RF, GBM, and CNN 1D performed best with accuracies higher than 95 %. A stacking ensemble model incorporating these three high-performing classifiers was created, hence improving classification performance to 96% accuracy, 95.98% precision, 96% recall, and 95.98% F1-score. For multi-crop disease identification, the suggested model shows good generalisation capacity and efficiently uses both handmade and deep features. This study offers a scalable and precise method for early identification and categorisation of several agricultural diseases, which can greatly help farmers and agronomists in carrying out timely intervention plans for better control of crop health.

title: Advancing Communication Flow in Enterprises Through Intelligent AI Applications
authors: Sarah Charisma Lakiang Akepogu, Vivek Veeraiah, Naim Shaikh, K. Akila, Ankur Gupta, Rohit Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: As companies go through digital transformation, it is getting more and harder for them to handle huge amounts of communication that are always changing and come through many channels. Traditional communication tools don't always have the intelligence and responsiveness needed to make decisions in real time, let people work together smoothly, and give people personalised experiences. The goal of this study is to suggest a business communication architecture that uses AI, NLP, machine learning, sentiment analysis, and automated feedback systems to improve the flow of information both inside and outside of the company. The capabilities of the framework include the automation of tedious communication activities, the improvement of message routing, the determination of what the sender intended, and the provision of intelligent, context-aware responses. Because it is able to adjust to changing circumstances and acquire knowledge from data in real time, the framework is capable of undergoing transformations. People are still trying to find out how the framework may assist the company in carrying out its functions more efficiently, improving its communication, and maintaining its concentration on the ultimate objective. The findings of this research may provide us with further knowledge about intelligent business systems since they explain how to improve communication models in order to make them more responsive, safe, and in accordance with the goals.

title: Maximizing Voltage Support Capability of DFIG-Based WT Considering Rotor-Side Limitations under Asymmetrical Faults
authors: Sen Zhang, Bin Hu, Lei Yang, Yuming Liao, Kaidong Lu, Dan Sun, Heng Nian
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: During asymmetrical faults, Doubly-Fed Induction Generators (DFIGs) need to inject dual-sequence currents to support the grid voltage. To further exploit the dual-sequence voltage support capability of the DFIG, this paper proposes a novel model aimed at maximizing this support subject to the rotor-side limitations. For a prescribed rotor current magnitude, the proposed model analytically derives the optimal injection angles for both the positive-and negative-sequence rotor current components. A key finding reveals that, in contrast to conventional grid tied converters, these optimal angles are functions not only of the grid impedance parameters but also of the DFIG’s intrinsic inductances. Experimental validation based on SimuNPS confirms that the proposed rotor current injection strategy significantly enhances the DFIG’s capacity for unbalanced voltage suppression, while strictly adhering to the rotor-side operational constraints.

title: Memory Replay and Knowledge Transfer for Fairness in Continual Learning on Imbalanced Data
authors: Ivana Nathania Wijaya, Hidayaturrahman
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The absence of memory and knowledge retention mechanisms in Supervised Contrastive Replay (SCR) results in severe forgetting, despite its potential for continual learning. This paper introduces SCR Enhanced, an improved architecture integrating knowledge distillation and memory replay to address these limitations. We systematically compare Vanilla, SCR Plain, and SCR Enhanced across three training regimes: scratch, pretrained with frozen layers, and full fine-tuning. Experiments on the imbalanced CIFAR-100 dataset show that SCR Enhanced with frozen pretrained features achieves the highest final accuracy of 21.61%, outperforming SCR Plain (8.99%) and Vanilla (8.83%). These findings highlight the importance of combining contrastive objectives with robust pretraining, replay, and distillation strategies to improve continual learning performance under real-world constraints.

title: Design of Low-Power XOR Based 16-Bit and 32-Bit CSA Using Reversible Logic
authors: Navya P Maraddi, Priyal S Guddad, Bhakti K Kadolkar, Suhas Shirol
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: In modern digital systems, efficient arithmetic operations are crucial for improving performance and reducing power use. Carry Select Adders (CSAs) are popular due to their speed, but conventional designs have high power consumption and larger area because of unnecessary logic. This paper shows the design and implementation of XOR-based 16-bit and 32-bit CSAs using reversible logic gates, created with Vivado. Unlike traditional methods that use Cadence-based workflows and irreversible gates, this new design uses reversible logic to cut down on power use, lower the gate count, and improve area efficiency. The XORbased structure removes unnecessary sum and carry logic while keeping speed advantages. Simulations in Vivado show that the reversible logic-based CSAs result in significant decreases in power consumption (up to 76%) compared to traditional 16-bit CSA designs. The results confirm that reversible logic is suitable for low-power, high-performance arithmetic designs and provides a scalable solution for energy-efficient computing platforms.

title: Federated Multimodal Deep Learning Framework for Robust and Privacy-Preserving Tuberculosis Detection
authors: Jayapratha Clement, Vasujadevi Midasala, Sivasangari A, Surendran R, Kalyani Gedela
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, driven by the airborne transmission of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which primarily affects the lungs and can become life-threatening if not diagnosed and treated early. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), approximately 10.6 million people contracted TB in 2022, and 1.3 million deaths were reported among HIV-negative individuals, with an additional 167,000 deaths among HIV-positive individuals, highlighting the ongoing global health burden. While a range of artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning-based systems have been developed for TB detection using chest X-rays, CT scans, or multimodal data, existing approaches often suffer from key limitations, including lack of interpretability, data privacy concerns, and generalization issues when applied across diverse populations or healthcare settings. To address these gaps, a novel privacy-preserving tuberculosis detection framework is proposed, leveraging federated learning integrated with a Vision Transformer (ViT) architecture enhanced by Grad-CAM for interpretability. This approach enables collaborative model training across distributed datasets without centralizing sensitive patient data, while also offering visual explanations for clinical validation. Experimental evaluation on publicly available chest X-ray datasets demonstrates significant performance, achieving an accuracy of 98% and F1-score of 0.98, indicating its robustness, transparency, and suitability for real-world deployment in resource-constrained and privacysensitive environments.

title: Wearables, Sensors, and Smart Dispensers: A Multimodal Approach to Improving Hospital Hygiene
authors: Frank Russow, Richard Meinhart, Thomas Mundt
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This paper presents the findings and technical developments of the DiSH-O-Klin project, which aims to improve hand hygiene compliance in hospitals through digital assistance systems. By combining wearable smart badges, sensor-equipped disinfectant dispensers, and gamification elements, healthcare workers are encouraged to perform hand disinfections more frequently and correctly. Initial field tests demonstrated a significant increase in disinfection rates and a reduction in hospital-acquired infections. However, challenges such as inaccurate user identification, lack of disinfection reminders, and staff concerns about surveillance were identified. To address these issues, the project explores alternative technologies including ultrasound and UWB-based positioning, biometric hand geometry recognition, and NFC wristbands. Furthermore, the integration of spatial risk modeling based on hospital layouts and privacy-preserving activity tracking is proposed. The paper outlines these enhancements and presents a framework for future hygiene-supporting systems in clinical environments.

title: Securing Encrypted 6G Traffic: An Edge-Optimized AI Framework for Attack Detection
authors: Daniel Esemezie, Iqra Batool, Mostafa M. Fouda, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Zubair Md Fadlullah
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In today’s networks, encryption is ubiquitous—protecting data privacy while simultaneously hindering security monitoring. This research introduces a privacy-preserving framework that achieves 99.2% accuracy in detecting brute-force attacks in encrypted 6G traffic without decryption. We compare supervised (CNN) and unsupervised (autoencoder) models operating exclusively on flow-level metadata such as packet timing, size distribution, and protocol behavior. The CNN classifier significantly outperforms the autoencoder and can be optimized (0.7MB) for edge deployment, enabling terabit-speed monitoring with sub-millisecond latency when distributed across 6G networks. Our approach resolves the security-privacy tension by maintaining encryption while effectively identifying malicious activities, making it ideal for future 6G environments where both privacy and computational efficiency are critical.

title: Harnessing Solar Energy Via Dye-Sensitized Solar Cell Using Saba Banana (Musa acuminata x balbisiana) Leaf
authors: Christian Rey G. Marino, Reena D. Samson, John Christian Y. Nicdao
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study shows the use of the extract of Saba banana (Musa acuminata × balbisiana) leaf to act as the natural dye sensitizer for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) with the purpose of harnessing renewable energy for the application of battery charging. This research involves extracting the natural dye from Saba banana leaves, utilizing a spectrophotometer to analyze the dye's light absorption, fabricating DSSCs, and testing their performance using a solar simulator. To evaluate the efficiency of the DSSC output, I-V characterization was done, which was then compared to the existing studies using other plant-based dyes. Eventually, the energy generated by the DSSC was used to charge a 18650 21700 lithium-ion battery (3.7 V, 2200 mAh). The results demonstrate the capability of the extract from Saba banana leaves as an efficient plant-based dye sensitizer for DSSCs, highlighting its potential as an economical and sustainable material for solar energy applications.

title: Leaf-Level Yellow Rust Severity Classification in Wheat Using Deep Hybrid Models
authors: Rohit Markan, Shikha Tuteja, Amarjeet Kaur, Ravinder Tonk, Sushil Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This paper proposes a CNN-Logistic Regression-based approach for the classification of wheat leaf yellow rust into ten specified grades of infection. The model is assessed on 10,070 images with a global accuracy of 92.45%. Performance metrics prove excellent precision, recall, and F1scores at all levels. The greatest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score, 97.73% was found in Grade 7, with precision of 97.85% and recall of 97.61%, and then Grade 1, Grade 2, and Grade 6 with F1-scores of 96.99%, 97.18%, and 97.31%, respectively. Even thinly populated classes, such as Grade 3 and Grade 10, had high F1scores of 92.59% and 91.74%, respectively. In support, Grade 7 was best represented with 1588 samples (0.16 proportion), and Grade 10 was worst represented with 434 samples (0.04 proportion). Notably, accuracy per class was uniform at 0.99 for all grades of infection. These findings demonstrate the flexibility of the framework, accuracy, and excellent generalization at each level of severity, and thus are a quality tool for automatic disease severity classification in precision farming.

title: Comparative Analysis of YOLO Algorithm Performance in Firearm Detection on Static Images
authors: I Gusti Ngurah Agus Rama Putra, I Putu Agus Eka Darma Udayana, Aniek Suryanti Kusuma
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Modern security systems require rapid and accurate threat identification, particularly in high risk environments such as military facilities, airports, and weapon storage areas. Computer Vision based firearm detection has become an effective approach due to its ability to operate automatically using deep learning algorithms. Although the YOLO family continues to evolve, comparative evaluations of the latest versions YOLOv8, YOLOv11, and YOLOv12 on the same static image dataset remain limited. This study analyzes the performance of these three models using metrics such as mAP, precision, recall, training time, inference time, and statistical testing. The experimental results show notable performance differences. YOLOv8 achieves the fastest training time (25.17 ± 0.11 minutes), followed by YOLOv11 (28.90 ± 0.21 minutes) and YOLOv12 (30.63 ± 0.24 minutes). For inference speed, YOLOv11 is the fastest in detecting long gun (0.58 ± 0.29 s) and short gun (0.68 ± 0.29 s) objects, while YOLOv8 shows moderate speed and YOLOv12 performs the slowest. In terms of detection accuracy, YOLOv8 provides the highest performance for long gun (88.00 ± 13.89%) and short gun (84.00 ± 5.29%), YOLOv11 reaches moderate accuracy, and YOLOv12 records the lowest and most variable results. Paired T-test results confirm significant differences in training time, with all p-values < 0.05, indicating that the three models differ statistically in computational efficiency. Meanwhile, no significant differences were found in detection speed or testing accuracy, as all p-values exceed 0.05 for both categories. Overall, YOLOv8 is the most suitable model when accuracy is the primary objective, while YOLOv11 is preferable for applications requiring faster inference. YOLOv12 provides the weakest performance and offers no clear advantage in this context.

title: AI-Driven Energy Forecasting for Real-Time Renewable Grid Integration
authors: Muntadher Muhssan Almusawi, Shubham Singh Chandel, G.B. Santhi, Ch. Anil Chowdary, D. Jebakumar Immanuel, Jumaboev Nurillo Khayrullo Ugli, M. Sabirova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: There are two aspects to the fact that the modern power grid must grapple with the massive growth of the renewable sources of the energy. Although it is both environmentally clean and economically efficient, the intermittent and unpredictable nature of wind and solar generation poses the most crucial implementation challenges, in the context of both providing grid stability and reliability and the grid efficiency in general. To address this issue, this paper suggests the Federated Edge-Enhanced Hybrid AI (FEEHAI) System, a new real-time forecasting and combination framework, which was created with intelligent, large, and privacy-sensitive renewable grid controls in mind. The consequence is that FEEHAI incorporates a decentralized yet synergistic distributed architecture of edge computing that has three fundamental capabilities (federated learning, multi-modal data fusion, and federated learning). The opportunity to process the data on the edge nodes located within the grid infrastructure and obtain a rapid response in real time is provided by the fact that there are edge nodes embedded within the grid infrastructure. At the same time, federated learning standards facilitate training on multi-model on decentralized devices where user and infrastructure privacy is maintained and enhance the performance levels of prediction. Such a system combines multiple non-homogeneous data, such as weather sensors, satellite data, and past pattern of electricity use, present telemetry of the grid depending on an aggregate of AI that included deep neural networks and spatiotemporal models. The simulation results are further extrapolated to the extent that: FEEHAI performs better than the older counter parts, which are centralized and not federated in the aspects of the precision of the prediction and responsiveness to highly volatile parts. Besides, the architecture accommodates the dynamic scaling on regional scale and also grid-layer-by-grid-layer scale within the micro grids and national transmission system. The proposed FEEHAI System will guarantee the attainment of resilience reasons, real-time renewable energy activities since; the proposed system will have the capacity of carrying out AI driven intelligence of the edge level infrastructure that will make the system sustainable as far as the data privacy and system nimbleness is concerned.

title: Environmental Efficiency Evaluation of the Power System Based on Two-Stage Network DEA Model
authors: Fan Cheng, Chen Wang, Ling Luo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Improving environmental efficiency in China’s power sector is crucial for achieving national carbon neutrality. Many earlier studies overlook the sequential nature of electricity supply and regional variation. This study fills these gaps by using a two-stage network DEA to separately assess generation and transmission for 29 provinces from 2014 to 2024, considering both desirable output and undesirable output. Results show that eastern coastal provinces, such as Guangdong, Jiangsu, and Beijing, consistently achieve the highest efficiency, while western and northeastern regions lag due to outdated infrastructure. Most provinces are more efficient at generation than transmission, highlighting the need for grid upgrades and loss reduction. These findings provide targeted policy insights for China’s low-carbon transition.

title: Optimization Analysis of Frequency Modulation Capability of Temperature Control Load in Time-Delay Environment
authors: Liwei Zhang, Hao Dong, Yulong Yang, Yuqing Wang, Xinxin Ge, Zhishang Duan
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Thermostatically Controlled Loads (TCLs), characterized by their thermal storage capabilities and millisecondlevel response speed, can serve as distributed frequency regulation resources to effectively address the shortage of regulation capacity in power systems. Considering both the aggregation characteristics of TCL clusters and the impact of frequent switching on equipment lifespan, this paper proposes a response frequency update (RFU) strategy based on a hierarchical heterogeneous control architecture. First, a frequency response model for TCLs is established, incorporating communication and response delays, and a dynamic response model analogous to the droop characteristics of conventional generators is constructed. Subsequently, a response control method for TCL participation in grid frequency regulation is proposed, aimed at enhancing power system frequency stability. The study also reveals the sensitivity of frequency dynamics to time delays, providing theoretical support for the coordinated control of distributed frequency regulation resources.

title: Noninvasive Hemoglobin Quantification via Neural Network Optimization for Spectral Partialities
authors: Tara R. Kim, Semin Kwon, Sang Mok Park
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Anemia affects approximately one-quarter of the global population. While its diagnosis typically relies on hemoglobin (Hgb) measurement through venous blood draws, such methods require access to clinical infrastructure and trained personnel, limiting accessibility in rural and resource-limited settings. In addition, invasive blood sampling can cause pain, infection risk, and iatrogenic blood loss. Although noninvasive technologies have been developed, they often require expensive and bulky equipment, and their performance can be affected by skin tone variability across diverse populations. To overcome these limitations, we present a mobile health (mHealth) technology utilizing neural network models to noninvasively estimate blood Hgb levels based solely on red-green-blue (RGB) color values from smartphone photos of peripheral tissue. The palpebral conjunctiva (inner eyelid) is selected as a sensing site due to its easy accessibility, uniform microvasculature, and absence of confounding skin pigments. By optimizing neural networks with varying spectral partialities, we demonstrate that the proposed method can reliably predict blood Hgb levels using only limited RGB input, eliminating the need for complex and costly optical components. This study highlights how machine learning-powered mHealth technology can reduce dependence on clinical laboratories and hardware complexity, offering accessible and scalable solutions in resource-limited and home settings.

title: Embodied Meta-Adaptation Engine for Multimodal Generative AI Dynamic Agents
authors: Varsha Shukla, Geoffrey G Parker
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Multimodal generative AI agents are increasingly deployed in dynamic real-world environments that demand constant contextual responsiveness, cross-domain generalization, and non-disruptive learning. However, current generative systems, predominantly reliant on static prompts, supervised fine-tuning, or reinforcement signals, struggle to adapt in real-time to implicit user cues, task drift, or failure patterns.This paper introduces the Embodied Meta-Adaptation Engine (EMAE), a novel architecture for generative agents that enables continuous, embodied learning through ambient, non-verbal feedback loops. Unlike traditional meta-learning models, EMAE does not require labeled data or formal rewards. Instead, it leverages environmental signals such as cursor behavior, document navigation flow, silent rejection patterns, or micro-interaction data to modulate reasoning strategies, switch generation styles, or reroute attention flows dynamically.The system is composed of four key components: (1) an adaptive controller, (2) a failure memory module, (3) a strategy-orchestration switchboard, and (4) a cross-modal integration layer. This architecture is designed to operate seamlessly across text, vision, audio, and tabular modalities. Through prototypes deployed in clinical documentation, legal contract summarization, and multilingual customer support, EMAE demonstrates increased user satisfaction, lower task latency, and higher error resilience without requiring retraining or explicit feedback.We present the full system design, cognitive architecture, experimental benchmarks, and commercial use case potential. EMAE represents a major shift in the paradigm of generative AI, from passively trained systems to actively adaptive agents.

title: Signal Reconstruction for Wave Excitation Force and Actuator Fault in Wave Energy Converters
authors: Zhiwei Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Signal reconstruction approaches for wave energy converters are investigated in this paper. A discrete-time estimator is first designed to reconstruct wave excitation force. Secondly, a discrete-time estimator is addressed to reconstruct additive actuator fault signal. It is noticed that an actuator fault signal may have adverse effect on the excitation force reconstruction. Motived by this, a novel dual-estimator design approach is proposed which enables a simultaneous reconstruction for both excitation force and actuator fault signal where the effect from the actuator fault on the reconstructed excitation force is avoided. The proposed reconstruction algorithms are validated by simulation studies in a point absorber wave energy converter.

title: Real-time Online Deceptive Evidence Detection Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Environment
authors: Junhao Pan, Bingyi Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In the application of Dempster-Shafer Theory (DST), the fusion of anti-deception evidence has always been a critical issue that needs to be addressed. Effectively detecting deceptive evidence has become an important and challenging task in the field of information fusion. Currently, research on this issue remains limited, and there is still ambiguity in distinguishing between deceptive and credible evidence. Moreover, existing methods often fail to handle dynamic data, cannot resist noise interference, and do not fully utilize information from historical data. This paper focuses on real-time online detection of deceptive evidence in dynamic scenarios. To address this, we propose a mathematical model to solve the problem of anti-deception evidence fusion under such conditions, and employ Deep Q-Networks (DQN) for online training and decision-making to enable real-time processing. Through comparative analysis of multiple numerical experiments, the effectiveness of the proposed method in real-time dynamic environment is validated.

title: Performance Evaluation and Decision Framework for Lightweight Cryptography in Resource-Constrained IoT Environments
authors: Saroj Kumar Rajak, Rachna Kumari, Sanjay Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) applications across domains such as healthcare, smart cities, industry, and agriculture has intensified the need for secure yet lightweight cryptographic mechanisms. Conventional algorithms are often unsuitable for resource-constrained devices due to high computational, memory, and energy demands. This study presents a systematic review and performance evaluation of 39 lightweight cryptographic algorithms (LWC) implemented on the ESP32 platform. Key decision criteria—including energy efficiency, latency, memory footprint, and implementation cost—are analyzed. A multi-criteria decision-making framework using the TOPSIS method ranks algorithms based on performance tradeoffs. Results identify XTEA, SPECK, and TEA as top-performing candidates. The proposed framework serves as a practical guide for selecting efficient and secure LWC solutions in constrained IoT environments.

title: Check-in Sequence Representation Learning for LBSNs with Embedding Spatio-Temporal-Semantic Contexts
authors: Ruizhi Wu, Renxiang Jia, Weiwei Xing
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Check-in data has been generated at an explosive rate in recent years due to the wide use of location-based social networks. To mine check-in data, a critical task is to learn a good check-in data representation since it is the foundation for downstream mining tasks such as location retrieval and recommendation. Established representation approaches tend to ignore the temporal information carried in check-in data, or treat spatial and temporal information separately. However, such strategy may be hard to reflect the reality. Beyond, the semantic information in check-in data is insufficiently exploited and enriched in existing approaches. In this paper, we propose a Space-Time-Semantic architecture for check-in sequence semantic representation, called STS, which spontaneously learns the spatiotemporal and semantic information carried in check-in data with a united framework. The basic idea is to learn check-in data representation as a bridge to connect location and time as a whole, by predicting the next check-in venue and time based on distributed vector representation and adaptive Hawkes process. Meanwhile, the semantics are directly embedded into the check-in distributed vector representation during the learning process. Extensive experiments on two real-world check-in data sets show that our proposed framework not only allows learning a good representation to capture the space and time information effectively but also has good performance of check-in data semantic enrichment.

title: IoT-Based Real-Time Monitoring System for Temperature-Sensitive Medicines
authors: Ebenezer Abishek B, Thomas Leonid. T, Abdul Azez I, Arunkumar P, Magesh M, M. Arul Selvan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Maintaining the quality of temperature-sensitive medicines during storage and transportation is crucial to ensuring their effectiveness. Traditional monitoring methods are often limited by the lack of real-time tracking and automation, which can lead to medicine degradation and financial losses. This paper proposes an IoT-based system using an ESP32 microcontroller, RFID technology, and temperature sensors to monitor and track pharmaceutical conditions in realtime. The system continuously measures and transmits temperature data to a cloud platform, enabling remote supervision and immediate corrective actions when deviations occur. RFID tags help track medicine packages at key checkpoints, ensuring compliance with pharmaceutical regulations. An automated alert system notifies stakeholders of any temperature variations through SMS, email, or mobile applications. By integrating real-time monitoring, automated tracking, and cloud-based data storage, this system enhances medicine safety, regulatory compliance, and supply chain efficiency.

title: Development of an Endfire Antenna Array Fed by a Rotman Lens for Multibeam Beamforming
authors: Aicha Gherbi, Idris Messaoudene, Massinissa Belazzoug, Choumeyssa Chennouf, Khalida Khodja, Boualem Hammache, Salem Titouni, Ali Mansoul
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper has presented the design and analysis of a compact beamforming antenna system based on a Rotman lens architecture tailored for wireless communication at 10 GHz. The proposed lens structure incorporates four beam ports, eight array ports, and three dummy ports, ensuring proper impedance matching and balanced power distribution. An Endfire antenna array is employed at the array ports to realize the radiation mechanism, enabling efficient control of the beam directions. Full-wave simulations confirm that the antenna achieves reflection coefficients below −10 dB at the operating frequency, validating the effectiveness of the feed network. The system successfully generates four directive beams oriented at approximately −11°, 11°,−49° and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+49 \circ$</tex>, covering a total scanning range close to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 49 \circ$</tex>. In addition, the proposed design achieves a peak realized gain of nearly 11.7 dBi, which confirms its ability to deliver high directivity and improved radiation efficiency. These results demonstrate that the integration of the Rotman lens with Endfire radiators provides a reliable and cost-effective beamforming solution, making it well-suited for modern wireless communication systems where compactness, angular coverage, and stable performance are essential.

title: Flexible Centralized-Decentralized Hybrid Control of Parallel Grid-Connected Converters With Reduced Current Sensors
authors: Midhu Das B., Arun Rahul S.
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Parallel operation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> grid-connected converters under a hybrid control framework combining centralized and decentralized modes with reduced sensing requirements is presented in this work. In centralized operation, grid-current sensing alone suffices to regulate total system power; however, individual module currents cannot be independently controlled. Decentralized operation enables flexible power sharing and independent regulation but demands per-unit phase-current measurements, increasing sensor count and complexity. To overcome this limitation, a reduced-sensor current-reconstruction method is proposed, wherein each converter's AC-side phase currents are obtained as the average of two independent estimates - one derived from the DC-link current and the other from a plant model driven by measured grid voltages. Estimation accuracy is further enhanced through adaptive selection that prioritizes the model-based estimate during sector transitions, where DC-link-based estimation becomes unreliable. This approach reduces sensing to a single DC-side current sensor per converter. The proposed hybrid control and estimation framework, scalable to any number of converter units, is modeled and validated in PLECS with digitally implemented control blocks emulating real-time execution on a Texas Instruments TMS320F28379D microcontroller.

title: Comparative analysis of active rectifiers for hydrogen electrolyzer applications
authors: Délcio Pedro, Rui Esteves Araújo
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: In this study, a comparison of five topologies of active AC/DC conversion chain rectifiers is performed. The purpose of this work is to investigate the implementation of these topologies in the context of an electrolyzer system. The main purpose is to help identify the eventual advantages of active rectifiers. The studies under consideration provide an appreciation of typical three-phase two-level PWM rectifiers and three-phase Vienna rectifiers with an additional stage based on buck DC-DC conversion, for electrolyzer application. The comparative analysis is based on the following metrics: the current ripple, the power factor, the total harmonic distortion, the active switch utilization ratio, and the complexity of the solution. A Simulink model corresponding to each topology was developed to obtain the performance values for the comparison. The procedure involved conducting a steady-state analysis of each topology through simulations to obtain the main waveforms and the values for each criterion. The scores for each technical solution were then calculated. The solution based on the Vienna 3-switch rectifier presented the best results overall.

title:
Adapting Multi-Objective Priorities Over a Fuel Cell Vehicle’s Lifetime Using Model Predictive Control
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Lukas Haubensak, Stephan Strahl, Jochen Braun, Ramon Costa-Castelló
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: As the demand for sustainable transportation solutions grows, an optimal energy management in heavy-duty fuel cell electric vehicles becomes increasingly important. This paper presents a novel model predictive control formulation for the energy management of multi-stack fuel cell systems. By integrating multi-objective optimization, lifetime adaptation, temperature dependency, and start-stop control, the proposed approach addresses the conflicting requirements of efficiency and durability. The simulation results span a Pareto surface in the three-dimensional objective space that shifts its position over the system’s lifetime. The proposed MPC formulation automatically adjusts operational conditions in response to this objective prioritization, as demonstrated through histograms. Additionally, the inter-stack power distribution is used to mitigate higher cell potentials and optimize overall efficiency. This paper motivates to focus operating strategies on minimizing stack degradation at begin of life, where the loss of active platinum surface area is most critical and emphasizes the necessity of adapting this prioritization throughout the system’s lifetime.

title: Energy-Efficient Post-CMOS Computing Using Non-CMOS Devices and AI-Driven Optimization Techniques
authors: Shamim Ahmad Khan, Mohammed Saleh Al Ansari, Kannan Ramakrishnan, Hassan Safi Ahmed, Mina Ismail Mahmoud, P Bhavani
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Modern computing has been possible through rapid scaling of the CMOS technology that is however confronted by fundamental limits in power, heat dissipation, leakage currents, complexity of fab at nanometer dimensions. The future post-CMOS device paradigms that help to address them are discussed in this paper: spintronics, memristors, neuromorphic processors, quantum architectures, photonic circuits and 2D materials. They incorporate non-volatility and in-memory computing, and parallelism to deliver low-power/high-performance alternatives. We also emphasize the emerging importance of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, not only to the power management optimizations, but also to direct the materials discovery and choice of fabrication processes of MOSFET and non-MOSFET devices. In comparative analysis, there are up to $95 \%$ power saving, 60 percent efficiency increase with hybrid energy harvesting and high thermal reduction by using AI-enhanced cooling. Taken together, these developments are indicative of future, borne-out-of-AI computing systems that promise to break CMOS bottlenecks, and facilitate practical AI, IoT, autonomous systems, and energy-aware data centre applications.

title: Ku-Band MIMO Array Antenna with Enhanced Mutual Coupling
authors: Ibrahim S. Mohamed, Mahmoud A. Abdalla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: In this paper 2x2 Multi-Input Multi-Output (MIMO) array antenna is introduced with low mutual coupling. The proposed MIMO antenna is utilized in the high-power applications since it is designed by using metallic rectangular waveguides (RWG) theory. The two RWG arrays are placed closely to be more compact in the integrated system applications with spacing $0.41 \lambda_{0}$. The radiation gain of each antenna in the MIMO array is 14 dB. The proposed MIMO array is linear and has good cross-polarization discrimination (XPD). The mutual coupling reduction has achieved 6 dB all over the bandwidth in in narrow spacing between the two arrays in the MIMO system. The radiation pattern performance of the proposed MIMO array not affected after applying the mutual coupling reduction.

title: Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy based State of Health Estimation for Lithium-ion Batteries Using Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Jingwei You, Cheng Xu, Kangli Wang, Kai Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Accurate estimation of lithium-ion battery state of health (SOH) is essential for ensuring the safety, reliability and lifespan of batteries in practical applications like electric vehicles and energy storage systems. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) has attracted increasing attention for battery SOH estimation, as it provides detailed insights into internal electrochemical processes over a wide frequency range. In this paper, a convolutional autoencoder (CAE) is employed to extract overcomplete features from EIS data. To capture temporal dependencies, obtained features from every five consecutive cycles are stacked into short sequences. These sequences are fed into a convolutional neural network (CNN) to estimate battery SOH. Extensive experiments are conducted on datasets from multiple cells operating at three different temperatures. Experimental results demonstrate the proposed CNN model, which incorporates temporal information, outperforms the baseline models by achieving lower root mean squared error (RMSE) and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) values as well as higher coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) scores.

title: Reliable Crowdsourcing Scheme Based on Blockchain
authors: Mengya Cai, Pengcheng Ma, Yuanxi Zhuang, Yuan Ji, Bowen Li, Lingyun Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Aiming at the centralization problem of crowd-sourcing model and the uneven competence level of participants, this paper proposes a crowdsourcing mechanism BRCS(Blockchain-based Reliable Crowdsourcing Scheme) based on blockchain technology and reputation system, which eliminates the dependence of crowdsourcing model on the central platform and solves the problems caused by the central platform. BRCS recruits third-party verifiers to be responsible for evaluating the quality of tasks completed by crowdsourcing workers, and uses peer prediction and logarithmic scoring rules to measure the honesty of verifier reports. On this basis, it establishes a reputation system, and proposes a worker and verifier selection mechanism based on reputation and reverse auction to encourage workers to submit high-quality task data and encourage verifiers to submit honest evaluation reports. Through theoretical analysis and simulation experiments, it has been proven that the model in this paper can screen out workers with good abilities to participate in crowdsourcing, and meets the properties of authenticity and individual rationality.

title: VXLAN-Based BGP EVPN Architecture for Dynamic and Flexible Workflow Deployment in Multi-Vendor Supercomputing Environments
authors: Ronal Kumar, Jun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of streaming work-flows in scientific supercomputing environments presents significant challenges for network scalability, resource orchestration, and overall system design. This paper introduces the use of a VXLAN-based BGP EVPN architecture for organizing large-scale supercomputing data center networks as software-defined networks (SDNs). The VXLAN-based BGP EVPN architecture offers flexibility and scalability for deploying and orchestrating streaming workflows with varying resource demands. We have prototyped a testbed of software-defined networks using this architecture to facilitate the development of network orchestration mechanisms capable of quickly adapting to the dynamic resource demands of streaming workflows. Our initial experimental results demonstrate the testbed’s potential to achieve high network throughput, scalable design, and balanced resource utilization in streaming workflow scenarios across multiple vendors. These findings suggest that our approach of constructing SDNs with a VXLAN-based BGP EVPN architecture has offered a viable solution to the evolving networking demands of modern supercomputing facilities.

title: Deep Learning-Based Classification of Banana Plant Leaf Diseases
authors: Narthana B, Achuoth Akol Achuoth Deng, Devika Sanil, Lekshmi R Chandran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Banana is among the most important food crops supporting the agricultural economy of tropical and subtropical regions. Nevertheless, several diseases are considered as threat to the productivity and quality of banana. The commonly used detection approaches based on manual detection is tedious, subjective, and not suitable for the large-scale agricultural disease detection. In this paper, we propose a deep learning model based automated classification system to classify different diseases of banana plants using image processing techniques. We use the CNNs to process the leaf images and to predict accurately the types of diseases. The approach consists of image preprocessing followed by feature extraction, then classification using proprietary and pretrained CNNs such as Custom CNN, InceptionV3, ResNet50 and EfficientNetB0. The developed system provides a scalable, precise, and fast resolution to detect diseases at an early stage, thereby facilitating in time intervention to reduce the crop damage. This research highlights the contribution of AI to improving agricultural diagnostics, with the aim of supporting food security.

title: Interval PCA Limitations in Sensor Fault Detection
authors: Anis El Maharat, Chouaib Chakour, Rosanna Verde
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a powerful tool for process monitoring and fault detection. Its traditional form assumes precise measurements, which is rarely the case in real systems. Interval PCA (IPCA), such as Symbolic Covariance PCA (SCPCA), Midpoint and Raddi PCA (MRPCA), and Complete Information PCA (CIPCA) approaches were introduced to extend PCA and incorporate measurement uncertainty. However, when a constant-width interval variable is considered to describe the uncertainty, these methods often fail to capture the full variability contained in interval representations. This paper examines the robustness of IPCA methods in the context of sensor fault detection and diagnosis (FDD), using a greenhouse prototype system as a case study. Robustness is evaluated through False Alarm Rate (FAR) analysis, based on squared prediction error (SPE) indices including, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S P E_{L}, S P E_{C}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S P E_{U}$</tex>, computed at the lower, center, and upper points of the interval data in the testing phase, respectively. The results show that IPCA models predict well the center of interval data but have difficulties with the lower and upper bounds. This makes them less robust and increases FAR. These outcomes highlight the limitations of current IPCA methods and underscore the need for more effective approaches that can effectively address uncertainty to enhance fault detection in real-world systems.

title: Enhanced Diabetes Prediction Using Ensemble Learning and SparsePCA Based Feature Reduction
authors: Sanjam Wadhwa, Lavdeep Singh, Rinkle Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Diabetes is a chronic metabolic disease where blood glucose levels are high and can damage various organs like heart, kidneys, eyes and nerves. Early and accurate diagnosis of diabetes is key to managing the progression and complications. In this study we conducted extensive analysis using machine learning approach to predict diabetes using a Kaggle dataset. The dataset is preprocessed by removing irrelevant features and scaling and Sparse Principal Component Analysis (Sparse PCA) for dimensionality reduction. After sorting, this study used multiple classification algorithms like Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost, AdaBoost, Support Vector Machine, Decision Tree. In order to improve performance, Optuna-based hyperparameter tuning for AdaBoost, LightGBM and CatBoostis also done. The best models were then stacked using a stacking classifier with logistic regression as the meta-learner. Finally, this study showed that stacked model performed better than individual models, hence ensemble learning is effective in medical diagnosis.

title: Modelling of Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine using Python Optimized Parameters in ANSYS for EV Applications
authors: Bhupendra Kumar Sahu, K. Chandrasekaran
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper deals with comparison of the optimized result of python and modelled ANSYS Platform for a V-shaped interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSM) design. The V-shaped magnet configuration offers enhanced reluctance torque contribution, and improved mechanical stability, making it highly suitable for electric vehicle, traction systems, renewable systems& other applications. Optimized design parameters are used for modelling both stator and rotor of an IPMSM. In this paper 18 design parameters have been optimized in python and with same design parameters are adopted in ANSYS platform for simulation to verify the better efficiency, rated torque, maximum rated torque, air gap flux density, maximum flux density and reduced core and copper losses for EVs & other Industrial applications.

title: A Legacy of Community in Conferences
authors: N/A
publish: Computer
abstract: Provides society information that may include news, reviews or technical notes that should be of interest to practitioners and researchers.
