title: Expert System for Computer Damage Diagnosis with Hybrid Natural Language Processing and Knowledge Base
authors: Gede Adhitya Bayu Pramana, Putu Sugiartawan, I Putu Agus Eka Darma Udayana
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Computers are important devices that support work and learning activities in educational laboratories. However, various types of damage, such as computers that cannot turn on, screens that do not display images, or systems that frequently restart, still often occur. The process of diagnosing such damage is generally done manually, which takes a long time and the results are not necessarily consistent. To overcome this, this study developed an expert system for diagnosing computer malfunctions that combines a Natural Language Processing (NLP) approach and a knowledge base with the Forward Chaining (FC) and Certainty Factor (CF) methods. The main objective of this study is to help users and IT staff diagnose computer malfunctions quickly and accurately, simply by entering complaints in natural language. The NLP module applies keyword matching enhanced with synonym expansion and TF-IDF–based weighting to extract relevant symptoms from free-text complaints. The KB consists of 25 symptoms, 15 fault types, and 30 rules structured in IF– THEN format. The reasoning process is carried out using the FC method to trace possible causes of damage, while the CF method is used to calculate the confidence level of the diagnosis results. The system was tested using computer symptom and damage data collected from the FKIK ICT unit. Tested using 30 real laboratory cases, the system achieved 85% accuracy and produced diagnoses up to 10× faster than manual troubleshooting. These results indicate that combining NLP and hybrid reasoning improves consistency and efficiency in IT helpdesk workflows. For further research, the system will be developed into an interactive AI chatbot with continuous learning capabilities using machine learning algorithms so that it can automatically adapt to new cases.

title: Fine-Tuning GPT-4o-Mini to Detect and Extract Teachers’ Opportunity-to-Respond Quotes in Noisy Classroom Transcripts
authors: Kemal Berk Kocabagli, Jessica Vitale, Shyamoli Sanghi, Alyssa Van Camp, Berk Coker
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Reliable measurement of high-leverage instructional practices, such as teachers’ opportunities to respond (OTRs), is critical for scalable, data-informed professional development. However, manually coding classroom audio is costly and infeasible at scale. In this study, we fine-tune a GPT-4o-mini model to jointly (i) classify whether each teacher talk turn in an automatic speech recognition (ASR) transcript contains OTRs and (ii) extract the specific quotes that instantiate those OTRs. Evaluated on noisy, in-the-wild transcripts from real classroom recordings, the fine-tuned model outperforms a zero-shot GPT-4o-mini baseline across four key metrics: turn-level classification (F1: 0.894), quote-level precision (0.831) and recall (0.804), detection of multiple OTRs within a single turn (F1: 0.776), and quote alignment, with 82.8% of extracted quotes exactly matching expert annotations. At the lesson-level, predicted OTR totals are highly correlated (r: 0.97) with ground truth, indicating consistent performance across varied teachers and contexts. These results show that accurate and cost-efficient detection of OTRs from classroom audio is feasible with current large language model technologies, laying a foundation for scalable feedback tools that support teachers’ professional growth.

title: Ensemble Learning for Robust Anomaly Detection in Banking Fraud
authors: Agung Nugroho, Muhtajuddin Danny, Ismasari Nawangsih
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Banking fraud detection is a challenge due to the increase in digital transactions and extreme data imbalances. The study compared several baseline models with ensemble methods to build a more reliable anomaly detection framework. Using a credit card transaction dataset, the results show that Random Forest performs best with an Accuracy of 0.9995 and an F1-Score of 0.8438, while Stacking Classifier achieves an F1-Score of 0.8021. Baseline models such as Logistic Regression and Gradient Boosting have high recall but low precision. These findings confirm that the ensemble method is more effective in maintaining the Precision and Recall balance in unbalanced banking fraud data.

title: Hybrid AI-Based Detection of High Impedance Faults Using Time-Frequency Features and Adaptive Thresholding in Distribution Systems
authors: Takudzwa Marshal Makumbirofa, Vipin Chandra Pal, Sheetla Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This study introduces a hybrid artificial intelligence-based approach that uses adaptive thresholding and time-frequency features to detect high impedance faults (HIFs) in electrical distribution networks. To capture minor fault features, the suggested method makes use of statistical feature extraction in both the time and frequency domains and signal processing techniques like the Discrete Wavelet Transform. These characteristics, which are utilized to train and evaluate classification models in MATLAB, include wavelet energy, crest factor, standard deviation, and root mean square. Preliminary fault screening is improved by integrating a novel adaptive thresholding approach. Ensemble learning techniques are used for the classification, and a wide range of metrics, such as the confusion matrix, ROC curve, feature significance plot, PCA-based clustering, and ensemble accuracy tracking, are used to assess performance. With notable true positive and true negative rates, few false alarms, and efficient feature reparability between fault and non-fault classes, the results show a high degree of accuracy. The suggested model makes a significant contribution to enhancing the dependability and security of power distribution systems since it has great generalization capabilities and practical applicability.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Machine Learning for Software Requirement Risk Classification
authors: Pathan Shaheen Khan, Chandan Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Software Requirement Risk Analysis is crucial for detecting potential failures early in the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC). Existing machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) methods provide promising results, but they often struggle with capturing complex dependencies in requirement data. This paper introduces a novel hybrid Quantum-Classical Machine Learning (QML) framework to improve the accuracy and reliability of requirement risk classification. The dataset was preprocessed using label encoding, Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE), ANOVA F-test (SelectKBest) for feature selection, and feature scaling to enable quantum circuit integration. Strongly entangling quantum circuits were implemented using the Qiskit framework to generate quantumenhanced features, which were fused with classical features. Four hybrid models-RF + QML, LGBM + QML, LR + QML, and Q-Kernel + MLP-were trained and evaluated. Experimental results show that the proposed Q-Kernel + MLP model achieved the best performance with $97.76 \%$ accuracy, $97.92 \%$ precision, $97.76 \%$ recall, and an F 1 -score of $97.77 \%$, outperforming classical baselines by up to $4 \%$. These findings highlight the potential of quantum-enhanced learning in software engineering, offering a scalable and robust solution for early risk detection and supporting more reliable project planning and software quality assurance.

title: Multi-Agent Orchestration Protocol for Generative AI Systems
authors: Varsha Shukla, Geoffrey Parker
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The growing use of large language models (LLMs) in industry demands new solutions for governance, compliance, and secure coordination across distributed AI agents. Existing agent frameworks lack built-in policy controls and assume a uniform environment, leading to risks from cross-border data flows and unmonitored information leakage. We propose a formal orchestration protocol that embeds jurisdictional rules, access controls, and auditability into every agent interaction. A central orchestrator decomposes complex requests into tasks, consults an Agent Registry (capturing each agent’s location, role, trust score, etc.) and a Policy Engine (enforcing laws like GDPR/HIPAA and security rules), and dynamically routes subtasks to eligible agents. Each agent has isolated memory shards and communicates a structured protocol with schema validation. A tamper-evident audit log captures every decision for post-hoc review. This ensures that sensitive data never crosses prohibited boundaries and every step is traceable. Unlike static LLM chains, our system constructs an on-the-fly task graph that adapts in real-time, enabling parallel execution and failover. Simulations show that this approach can reduce response latency while eliminating compliance violations. By combining policy-driven orchestration, memory isolation, and rigorous auditing, our protocol makes multi-agent AI workflows secure, compliant, and transparent in ways no existing framework has demonstrated.

title: α-aggregator SegLoss: A Novel Loss Function for Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Vivek C. Joshi, Mayuri A. Mehta
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Traditional loss functions encounter difficulties in effectively segmenting medical image, specifically when classes in dataset are imbalanced. Furthermore, many of these loss functions require extensive hyperparameter tuning, which limits their adaptability to different segmentation tasks and datasets. To overcome these limitations, this paper presents a novel loss function, named α-aggregator SegLoss, which dynamically sets the Tversky index over a range of α values. The performance of the proposed α-aggregator SegLoss is evaluated for segmenting White Blood Cell (WBC) from microscopic blood smear images using two popular deep learning-based segmentation architectures, U-Net and Deeplabv3+. The αaggregator SegLoss demonstrates significant performance improvements. It improves the validation Dice coefficient by 0.39 – 5.01% and IoU by 0.68 – 9.01% over the traditional loss functions using the U-Net architecture. It achieves 0.16 – 3.42% increase in the Dice coefficient and -0.18 – 4.65 % increase in IoU using DeepLabv3+ architecture. Moreover, the F1 score achieved with the proposed loss is 82.20% and 81.05% for U-Net and DeepLabv3+, respectively. These findings confirm the effectiveness and generalizability of α-aggregator SegLoss in tackling challenges in medical image segmentation.

title: FedROCK: A Federated Learning Framework with Region-Oriented Cultural Knowledge Distillation for Recommendations
authors: Ruizhi Wu, Renxiang Jia, Jiacheng Liu, Ying Zhou, Weiwei Xing
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Recommendation techniques have achieved notable advancements; however, conventional centralized learning paradigms and their heavy reliance on training datasets containing user-sensitive information pose substantial risks of privacy leakage and misuse. While federated learning presents a decentralized alternative to mitigate these concerns, it introduces ancillary challenges, including elevated communication overhead and performance degradation, particularly in terms of compromised model generalization capacity and diminished personalized recommendation performance at the client level. Furthermore, current recommendation models primarily focus on extracting users’ unique preferences while neglecting the critical influence of region-oriented cultural characteristics shaping collective user preferences, a factor integral to understanding behavioral patterns across distinct demographic groups. Motivated by the challenges, in this paper, we propose a Federated learning framework with Region-Oriented Cultural Knowledge distillation for recommendation applications, called FedROCK. FedROCK integrates region-oriented cultural knowledge through server-side aggregation and variational autoencoder (VAE)-based extraction, subsequently propagating this influence to client-side learning via parameter transmission mechanisms and layer knowledge distillation within the federated architecture. Meanwhile, to enhance client model personalization, we selectively synchronize only a subset of client model parameters during federated training. This dual mechanism—leveraging region-oriented cultural influence and adaptive client personalization—achieves an equilibrium between system-wide generalization and individually fine-grained recommendation precision. Extensive experiments on two real-world recommendation data sets demonstrate the excellence of the proposed FedROCK over the state-of-the-art methods.

title: AI-Powered Early Diagnosis for Autism Spectrum Disorder and Progress Monitoring
authors: Saravanan C, Ashwini M, Charnisha L, Gayathri P, Dhivya Shree S S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) affects millions of people worldwide, but is still diagnosed mostly on subjective criteria that require expert judgments and limited accessibility to specialists or early detection tools. Often, a late diagnosis translates into missed opportunities for effective interventions in developmental outcomes. Hence, the project describes Cure Path AI-enabled early diagnosis and monitoring of the progress of ASD. CurePath uses deep learning, eye-tracking analysis, sMRI anomaly detection, and federated learning to give precise, privacy-preserving assessments. In experimental validation, CurePath attained an accuracy of 92.3% in diagnosis, a sensitivity of 89% in detecting risk markers early, and a 70% reduction in diagnostic time. It also provides personalized therapy recommendations given genetic, behavioral, and familial data. Using explainable AI, the use ensures transparency whereby clinicians and caregivers understand the outputs of the system. Accessible via clinics, schools, and remote settings, it provides real-time insights to health care providers and actionable care suggestions for families. CurePath assists not only in speedy diagnosis but also invests in long-term developmental support through continuous, personalized monitoring and empowerment for better decisions, enhancing quality of life in children with ASD.

title: Space Data Centers Come of Age
authors: Thomas Coughlin
publish: Computer
abstract: Declining transportation costs enable more human activity in outer space. These activities require communication, data processing as well as memory and storage and this is driving the near-term development of data centers in space.

title: Decoupling Control of Multivariable Systems Using Eigenstructure Assignment
authors: Salima Djebrani
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic methodology for designing state-feedback control laws for linear multivariable systems using the eigenstructure assignment technique. Unlike the classical pole placement method, this approach allows for the simultaneous specification of both the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the closed-loop system, providing increased flexibility in achieving advanced control objectives such as input-output decoupling, robustness, and minimal interaction between subsystems. The proposed methodology is applied to a three-tank system, for which a control law is designed to ensure stability and decoupled dynamic behavior. The effectiveness of the approach is validated through numerical simulations.

title: Corrosion Classification With Synthetic and Real Images: A Comparative Study
authors: Salah Eddine AGAB, Nafaa NACEREDDINE
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: Accurate corrosion classification is essential for structural health monitoring and maintenance planning. This study investigates the effectiveness of combining synthetic and real corrosion images to train machine learning and deep learning models in this task. Two approaches are explored: the first combines hand-crafted techniques, namely the Lightweight Multi-Feature Descriptor (LMFD) applied on HSV images with Local Phase Quantization (LPQ); the second uses the ConvNeXt model applied directly to input images. Experimental results show that training exclusively with synthetic data yields suboptimal performance, with hand-crafted features achieving 70.75 % accuracy and ConvNeXt achieving 80.22 %. In contrast, adding real samples to the training set significantly improves performance: including 60 real images raises accuracy to 90.11 %, while including 600 real images increases it further to 95.05 %. These results suggest that synthetic data can complement real data effectively, enabling high-accuracy corrosion classification with limited real-world samples.

title: Benchmarking Few-Shot Learning Techniques for Steel Surface Defect Detection
authors: Rayen Ghali, Zhor Benhafid, Sid Ahmed Selouani
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Steel surface defect detection is crucial for industrial quality control, but acquiring sufficient labeled data for all types of defects remains a challenge. Few-Shot Learning (FSL) offers promising solutions by enabling models to learn from limited examples. This paper presents an investigation of recent FSL implementation strategies specifically applied to steel defect detection, with a focus on methods evaluated on the widely used NEU-DET dataset. We categorize and compare different approaches based on their pre-training and fine-tuning implementations like cross-domain transfer (CDT), in-domain self-supervised pre-training with full or novel-only fine-tuning (ISS-FFT, ISS-NFT), and in-domain supervised pre-training with novel-only fine-tuning (IS-NFT). Furthermore, we introduce and evaluate SSL-YOLO, a method integrating contrastive self-supervised pre-training with a YOLOv8 detector, across these implementation scenarios. This work aims to consolidate current strategies and provide insights into the landscape of few-shot steel defect detection, highlighting both specialized techniques and the performance achievable with effective methods like SSL-YOLO.

title: Digital Twin-Enabled Urban Management: Multi-Modal Data Fusion for Real-Time City Simulation and Prediction
authors: Rvs Praveen, Nandini Shirish Boob, Montater MuhsnHasan, Saloni Bansal, Lavish Kansal, B. Rajalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The growing complexity of modern urban environments demands advanced solutions for dynamic monitoring, simulation, and management. Digital Twin (DT) technology, when coupled with multi-modal data fusion, presents a transformative approach to real-time urban simulation and predictive analytics. This paper explores the integration of heterogeneous data sources-such as IoT sensor feeds, satellite imagery, social media streams, and traffic logsinto a unified digital twin framework for smart city governance. The proposed methodology employs machine learning algorithms and AI-driven fusion techniques to synchronize virtual representations with real-world conditions in near real-time. By enabling accurate city-scale modeling and forecasting, the framework supports informed decision-making in areas such as traffic control, environmental monitoring, public safety, and infrastructure maintenance. Experimental results from a pilot implementation demonstrate improvements in urban resilience, response time, and resource optimization. This study contributes to the advancement of intelligent urban systems by offering a scalable and adaptive model that enhances city situational awareness and operational efficiency through digital twin-enabled simulation.

title: Hybrid Energy System Based on Five-Level Reduced Switch Multilevel Inverter
authors: Het Bhalja, Amit V. Sant
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper introduces a grid-connected microgrid setup that uses a multilevel inverter (MLI) with five-level reduced-switch topology to link hybrid energy sources with the loads. In this paper, fuel cells and solar PV arrays with battery storage are used although the MLI input sources are selected based on their availability at the microgrid location. Here, in this topology each source will act as a separate dc source. Because of this arrangement, the inverter does not require the usual input capacitors or voltage-balancing circuits found in conventional MLI designs. The existing systems can also be converted into this MLI setup, so adding or upgrading it is simple. Power sharing among the various sources is achieved by varying the duration of each voltage level, allowing accurate and efficient energy management. An automated control algorithm coordinates the operation of the energy sources and storage units to regulate power flow. Depending on the availability of the energy sources and the required power, the microgrid can operate in different modes, which are discussed in detail. The simulation results and analysis show that the proposed configuration provides better power control to integrate multiple energy resources into microgrids.

title: Distributed Economic Optimization Scheduling Based on Neural Dynamics Optimization
authors: Jialu Cheng, Donghao Zhang, Xin Li, Dongxu Zhang, Bin Cheng, Linjiang Deng
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This paper studies the distributed economic optimization scheduling problem of the integrated energy system (IES) based on neural dynamics optimization. Firstly, for the IES containing four forms of energy, namely electricity, heat, gas and cold, this paper constructs the total cost function of the IES by using the output values of each device and the cost consumed, and proposes an IES optimization scheduling model. Secondly, in order to solve such problems, a distributed dynamic optimization algorithm based on neural networks is proposed to conduct economic scheduling analysis of the IES. This algorithm is based on the dynamic weight neural network model and can solve the problem of inseparable inequality constraints. This algorithm has the advantages of small computational burden, fast convergence speed and easy hardware implementation. Simulation results show that the proposed method can regard each agent (i.e., device) as a node and reach the global optimum by interacting information with neighboring nodes.

title: Remote Industrial Technician Training Through Real-Time XR Assistance
authors: P. K. Chidambaram, Hyba AbdulJaleel, Ruchi Chandrakar, D D D Suribabu, D. Jebakumar Immanuel, O. Sh. Gulyamova, Giyosiddinov Abdurakhim Nasritdin ugli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Development of the industrial techs in remote industries is quite important to grant efficiency and security under complex industrial cases. Conventional forms of remote training support environment has since been found not to add any value other than being stagnant general-purpose training, which is not aware of the real time variations in technician skill level and cognitive strain and training that happens to be considerate to variations of the environment. This unbending can lead to high levels of errors, extended classes and incompetence of the skills. Then, the remote guidance realization with the use of the experts and the visual instructions are more oriented on commercial XR-based training systems which do not suggest the possibility to monitor the physiology parameters, to fulfill the personalization. To eliminate these weaknesses, the paper is proposed to implement a pioneering AI-enhanced adaptive realtime Extended Reality (XR) training system that will include a contextual feed-back loop. The system is the initial to integrate wearable biometric sensors with both a system to constantly determine technician heart rate, skin conductance, and contact with the environment as well as AI algorithms capable of gauging cognitive load, emotional state and gauge the task performance of technicians in real time. Based on this information the contents of the XR instruction (visual overlays and auditory and haptic indicators) are provided dynamically according to the current capacity, stress and the rate at which the trainee is performing the skillsLong distance expert interface with real-time bio and haptic sensor feedforward makes the expert deliver his or her advice in a more explicit manner and experience unmatched sense of the situation and empathy. The 5G / 6G network with ultra-low latency and edges computing platform will provide a seamless interaction of both systems that is highly important as far as operational environments are concerned. Early testing will indicate that the human-AI adaptive training model has the capacity to reduce errors in training processes, reduce the time within which the trainees perform the training activity, and obtain large trust and satisfaction with the training process as compared to the conventional XR assistance gadgets. Personalization of the instruction and the real-time modulation of instruction through biometric and performance data provide transformative efficiency, scalability and security of the mammoth training needed in industry to unlock the potential of the technicians. The paper determines the capacity to form synergies among the AI potential, biometric sensors and XR technologies to transform the realm of distantly applied training modes, specifically in the industrial areas.

title: Automatic Generation of Operation Scenarios with Fixed Section Power for Stability Control Strategy Analysis
authors: Zhu Siting, Tian Ziying, Zhu Zexiang, Liu Qimeng, Fu Chao, Guan Lin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: In the offline analysis for formulating security and stability control strategies, the power of specific transmission sections is typically used as the primary input for control initiation and control quantity calculation. However, numerous power allocation schemes and operating modes satisfy the given section power conditions, and these predominantly rely on manual adjustments based on empirical experience, significantly compromising the efficiency and comprehensiveness of strategy development. This paper proposes an automatic generation method for fixed-section power operation scenario sets tailored for stability control strategy analysis and verification. First, the strongly correlated generator sets and DC converter stations are identified based on the section-node transfer impedance matrix, and the transfer sensitivity of active power output changes at each generator and DC converter station node to the section power is calculated. Subsequently, the feasible adjustment region for these strongly correlated units is determined and discretized into a state space. A tree search algorithm incorporating heuristic pruning is proposed to efficiently generate candidate operation scenario sets. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated using the IEEE 10-machine 39-bus system.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-Based Multimodal Liver Disease Detection
authors: Babitha Thummala, Vikram Yelgonda, Tejaswini Chilumarthi, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: In the past few years, early detection and diagnosis of liver diseases have been a research interest due to their increasing incidence and potential severity. The present paper presents a multimodal deep learning model that utilizes CT scan images, clinical diagnosis text, and laboratory test results to predict patients as having liver disease or normal. The model integrates disparate medical data sources to enhance diagnostic capability beyond what can be achieved using a single modality. The image modality uses a ResNet50 convolutional neural network to feature-embed liver CT scans. Clinical text inputs are handled using BERT, an advanced transformer-based language understanding model. Laboratory reports in the format of blood chemistries and liver function tests are represented using a Gradient Boosting Machine. These heterogeneous characteristics are then combined into an overall feature vector, normalized, and passed to the Gradient Boosting Classifier and trained through cross-validation and SMOTE to handle imbalance in data. A userfriendly we interface built with flask has been developed, enabling doctor to enter the patient data and obtain instant diagnostic predictions. The proposed model achieved an average accuracy of 94 % in predicting liver disease. This system highlights how combining multiple types of data can effectively support clinical decisions, offering a reliable, precise, and understandable method for diagnosing liver disease.

title: Research on Primary Frequency Regulation Strategy Based on Hybrid Energy Storage Technology
authors: Junhui Li, Yongqi Chen, Jun Dai, Hao Chen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To mitigate frequency fluctuations induced by the integration of photovoltaic power plants into the grid, this study introduces power system primary frequency control scheme utilizing a hybrid energy storage system that combines flywheels and lithium batteries. A coordinated control framework for photovoltaic and storage is designed, and a mathematical programming model is formulated to minimize the total absolute frequency error. The power distribution among different regulation resources is dynamically optimized using an enhanced Hierarchical Particle Swarm Optimization algorithm incorporating Time-Varying Acceleration Coefficients (HPSO-TVAC). Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to strategies employing lithium batteries alone or no energy storage, the proposed hybrid energy storage configuration strategy approach achieves a faster response speed and reduced frequency deviation under load variations, thereby significantly enhancing grid frequency stability. The findings confirm the efficacy and advantages of the proposed control strategy.

title: Comparative Analysis of the MPPT Techniques for Optimized Power Flow of Fuel Cell Integrated Boost Converter
authors: Brajesh Kumar Ravi, Rajdip Dey, Santanu Paul
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Fuel cells are emerging as a vital component of sustainable power systems due to their high efficiency, clean energy output, and reliable operation. However, their nonlinear voltage, current characteristics often prevent them from operating at peak efficiency without advanced control strategies. This paper presents a novel architecture in which two fuel cells of different power ratings are connected to a common load via independent circuit breakers. These circuit breakers enable selective activation of each fuel cell based on load demand, operational strategy, thus providing flexibility, fault tolerance, and energy prioritization. Once a fuel cell is activated through its respective circuit breaker, a Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm is applied to ensure the extraction of optimal power. Two different MPPT techniques are studied and applied, each independently controlling one of the fuel cell stack. The resulting power from each MPPT controlled fuel cell is then fed into a DC-DC boost converter, which steps up and regulates the output voltage to meet load or system bus requirements. Simulation-based analysis is conducted to evaluate the performance of this dual-fuel-cell system under varying load and input conditions. The Paper provides a comparative study of the output obtained by the Perturb & Observe (P&O) MPPT Technique and Incremental and Conductance (I&C) MPPT Technique. Results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed design in maximizing power extraction and enhancing operational reliability. This system is highly suitable for standalone or hybrid energy applications where reliability, adaptability, and efficiency are critical.

title: GHOST: Generating Hidden Obfuscated Samples from Benign Traffic to Evade SD-IoT Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Pankaj Dubey, Munesh Singh, Nitish Andola
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: SD-IoT integrates centralized control and network programmability, but this architectural centralization concentrates control-plane decision-making, creating a single point of failure that adversaries can exploit to bypass detection mechanisms and compromise overall network security. The adversarial attack samples are crafted from captured benign traffic using perturbation adversarial bounding (PAB), generative adversarial networks (GAN and WGAN-GP), and a hybrid PAB and WGAN-GP pipeline. These approaches produce realistic yet deceptive samples that preserve benign appearance while provoking misclassifications. We evaluate five widely used classifiers (CatBoost, XGBoost, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and MLP) under multiple testing scenarios and increasing adversarial volume. Results show that all techniques degrade detector performance, but WGAN-GP and the hybrid PAB & WGAN-GP are consistently most effective: evasion rates reach as high as 99.6-99.8% in adversarial-heavy tests and corresponding detection rates fall to single digits for several classifiers. Simpler GAN and PAB methods also reduce performance, though to a lesser extent. We further demonstrate that adversarial training on a balanced set substantially restores robustness.

title: Predictive Modeling of Grid Power Loss in EV Charging Systems Using Ensemble and Neural Networks
authors: B. Srinivasarao, Kanaka Raju Kalla, Trinadha Burle, D. Vijaya Kumar, Jayalaxmi Anem, Majji Durga Bhavani, Konna Akash, Ponnana Vedasri, Dokkana Sagar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into modern power grids presents growing challenges related to power loss, load balancing, and grid reliability. This study proposes a machine learning based framework for classifying power loss categories in EV charging networks, aimed at improving operational efficiency and supporting intelligent energy distribution. Four supervised learning models Random Forest, XGBoost, CatBoost, and a Feedforward Neural Network (FNN) are applied to predict the reduced power loss category based on key operational features. The dataset is preprocessed through normalization and correlation based feature selection. Models are evaluated using standard classification metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and $\mathbf{F 1}$-score. Among all models, the FNN achieved the highest performance with a classification accuracy of 91.00 percentage, followed by CatBoost and Random Forest. To enhance interpretability, SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) values are employed, identifying num power loss as the most influential feature driving model decisions. The analysis of training-validation curves confirms model generalization without overfitting. The proposed approach effectively combines predictive accuracy with model transparency, offering a scalable solution for real time power loss mitigation in EV charging grids. This work contributes to smart grid research by integrating interpretable AI into data driven decision making for sustainable energy infrastructure.

title: Robust Industrial Localization of Dot-Pattern Data Matrix Codes on Metallic Surfaces
authors: Chungang Han, Yipeng Liu, Jinyong Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Dot-pattern Data Matrix (DM) codes engraved or printed on metallic surfaces are widely deployed in industrial inspection and traceability pipelines. However, reliably localizing their dot structures remains challenging due to specular reflections, surface roughness, machining artifacts, and local damage. We propose a hybrid deepgeometric localization framework integrating YOLOv10-based dot detection with subpixel geometric refinement and projective grid reconstruction. First, YOLOv10 robustly detects dot candidates under severe illumination disturbances. A sub-pixel refinement module further enhances geometric precision by combining intensity-weighted centroid estimation and Taubin circle fitting. To suppress false detections arising from scratches or metallic noise, a geometric consistency filter based on inter-dot distance statistics and density clustering is applied. Subsequently, a RANSAC-based homography estimation aligns the detected dots with an ideal DM template for global grid reconstruction. Missing dots caused by reflections or damage are recovered using a reprojection-driven completion strategy. Experiments on real-world industrial metal datasets show that the proposed method significantly improves localization accuracy, grid completeness, and decoding robustness compared with deep-learning-only and geometry-only baselines.

title: A Frequency Regulation Control Strategy for Hybrid MTDC Power System Based on MPC
authors: Jialiang Wu, Xudong Huang, Pengyu Wang, Zhebo Zhang, Linbo Xu, Lihang Zhao, Qiang Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The technology of hybrid multi-terminal direct current (MTDC) transmission has received increasing attention, with the frequency regulation under the conditions of load variation and renewable energy fluctuation being a critical issue to be addressed. This paper presents a frequency regulation control strategy for a hybrid-MTDC system based on model predictive control (MPC) to enhance the frequency stability in the sending-end (SE) system. With the system prediction model, a disturbance observer is designed to observe and estimate the power disturbance in each system. Based on the objective function of the weighted minimum of local and interconnected receiving-end (RE) system frequency deviations, the optimization problem can be established and solved. By leveraging the rolling optimization and feedback correction mechanism, the optimal distribution of the output power of each converter station in the SE system can be achieved, and the influence of the frequency regulation process of the SE system on the frequency stability of the RE system is reduced. Finally, the simulations confirm the validity of the proposed strategy.

title: Performance Analysis of Target Motion Analysis System based on IMM with Maneuvering Point Detection
authors: Anila John, V Aparna, Sreekanth Raja, Eldho Joby, E Naseeba
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Passive localization of targets in maritime environment remains a significant challenge because the target dynamic parameters needs to be estimated from noisy bearing information alone. In the case of maneuvering targets, they have non linear motion and unobservable intent, which require adaptive target tracking. This paper presents a performance analysis of Target Motion Analysis(TMA) system, which employs Interactive Multiple Model (IMM) system to enhance tracking accuracy. The methodology integrates constant velocity and constant acceleration model with an adaptive framework that accounts for random target maneuver. By target maneuver detection and scaling of process noise with fudge factor, the system achieves improved robustness in complex environment.

title: Closed-form Analytical Expression for Moment of Inertia of Switched Reluctance Machine Rotors
authors: Samrat Das, G. Narayanan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The moment of inertia (J) of the rotor is a key performance metric, particularly for high-speed and precision position control applications, as it limits the maximum rate of speed rise for a given torque. Accurate knowledge of J is also essential for determining the frictional torque coefficient from the experimentally obtained mechanical time constant. This paper presents closed-form analytical expressions for estimating J of switched reluctance machine (SRM) rotors. Starting from first principles, the rotor is decomposed into two components: the yoke, modeled as an annular ring, and the poles, approximated as rectangular blocks for regular poles or trapezoidal blocks for tapered poles. The expressions are first validated on a 7.5 $\mathrm{kW}, 30,000~\mathrm{rpm}$ SRM rotor using computer-aided design (CAD) models. The influence of key dimensional parameters such as pole height, pole arc, and yoke width is demonstrated, with analytical predictions showing close agreement with CAD-derived values. Further validation on SRMs rated from $\mathrm{7~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}$ to $\mathrm{1 5 0~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}$ confirms the applicability of the method across a wide torque range. Additionally, the expression for tapered-pole rotors is derived and validated through CAD, extending the approach to more general geometries. The proposed expressions combine accuracy with computational efficiency, making them suitable for fast analytical design workflows.

title: Exploring the Electrical Behavior of AlGaN HEMTs: a Parametric Analysis on the Barrier Layer Composition
authors: Bilal Sanauddin Pirzada, Soheil Nouri, Samir El-Ghazaly
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This research investigates the trend of an AlGaN HEMT’s electrical performance as a function of the AIN composition in the barrier layer ranging from 20% to 60%. The percentage composition is fixed at 10% for the channel and other epitaxial layers. The parametric study revealed a linear increment in the device’s electrical performance for AIN compositions ranging from 20% to 35%. The increasing drain current highlights the dominance of consistently increasing polarization charges, which consequently increase the 2DEG density before carrier mobility experiences a steep degradation, after which its saturation is inevitable. Beyond a 35% AIN composition, the drain current saturates, highlighting an eventual tradeoff between consistently rising carrier density and an ultimate, severely degraded, saturated carrier mobility attributed to alloy scattering. The research also benchmarks the AlGaN HEMT against an AlGaN/GaN epitaxial device, examining the HEMT’s limitations in achieving comparable electrical performance.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Predictive Analytics for Loan Default and Repayment Behavior
authors: Gagandeep Kaur, Harinder Kaur, Gyana Ranjana Panigrahi, Nilesh Shelke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Predicting loan defaults is important to financial institutions for risk management and improving loaning policies. This research uses the LendingClub Loan Dataset comprising 2.26 million records with features such as credit score, debt income ratio, and loan amount, and applies a novel methodology for loan default and repayment behavior prediction with quantum-enhanced predictive analytics. The methodology uses embedded learning to disperse high-dimensional financial data into a low-dimensional quantum feature space. Coupled with a QML classifier, the framework demonstrated solid performance within a federated setting. The experimental findings indicate a ROC AUC of 0.897, surpassing classical machine learning baselines. The method preserves the data privacy through federated learning, thus applicable for sensitive financial contexts. This work demonstrates the ability of quantum analytics to enhance the predictive accuracy of loan defaults at scale.

title: Shunt Reactor Configuration for 220kV Offshore Wind Farms Based on Power Quality and Overvoltage
authors: Yuhe Fu, Lihang Zhao, Zhebo Zhang, Pengyu Wang, Linbo Xu, Qu Shen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The shunt reactor is an important component of offshore wind farms. This paper establishes a simulation model for the main circuit of a 220kV offshore wind farm. For different compensation degrees and compensation positions of shunt reactors, the THD, harmonic content, and voltage fluctuation rate of submarine cables are systematically analyzed. Meanwhile, the transient overvoltage characteristics under single-phase ground faults at the head and end of the cable are simulated. Based on the simulation results, different compensation schemes are comprehensively evaluated using the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), and the optimal compensation strategy is finally determined.

title: Adaptive and Secure Three-Level Steganography Scheme with Random Distribution and Parity Coding
authors: Sami Al-Mashaqbeh, Malik Qasaimeh, Raad Al-Qassas, Ayoub Alsarhan, Sami Alshammari, Nayef H. Alshammari, Rahaf R. Alshammari
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Data hiding has become crucial for ensuring information confidentiality in response to the increasing capabilities of modern decryption tools. This paper presents a novel steganographic approach based on Least Significant Bit manipulation to counter visual and statistical attacks. The proposed approach introduces a three-level steganography scheme that employs binary cover generation, Quick Response codes, and data embedding into Red, Green, and Blue image channels using parity coding and smoothing functions. Its key features include random data distribution across levels, adaptive pixel capacity, and the elimination of repetitive encryption processes. The approach achieves a maximum data hiding capacity of 9 bits per pixel while maintaining flexibility for varying secret message sizes. Experimental results examining standard test images demonstrate high robustness and imperceptibility, assessed through Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio, Structural Similarity Index Measure, and Mean Squared Error metrics. These findings emphasize the efficacy of the proposed approach for secure data hiding in digital images.

title: On-chip Processing Assisted TinyML for Heart Rate Monitoring Using Non-Contact Ballistocardiogram-Based Bed Sensor
authors: Quy Phuong Le, Truong Tien Vo, Dogeon Ha, Le The Anh Vi, Jae Sung Ahn, Byeongil Lee, Jaeyeop Choi, Junghwan Oh
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Heart rate monitoring (HRM) serves as a fundamental component of healthcare systems, providing essential insights into cardiovascular function and overall physiological status. Conventional HRM systems commonly rely on contact-based sensing modalities, such electrocardiogram (ECG) and photoplethysmogram (PPG) wearables, which require direct skin contact and complex wiring. This work presents a non-contact ballistocardiogram (NCBCG) bed sensor system integrated with tiny machine learning (TinyML) to provide on-chip processing for non-contact HRM. The proposed system incorporates a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) film sensor placed beneath the mattress, enabling comfortable, non-intrusive, and continuous monitoring. We design a TinyML model offers on-chip processing on a microcontroller unit (MCU), reducing dependency on cloud-based or external. Experimental findings demonstrate that the system achieves the accurate heart rate estimation, which is compliant with AAMI standard. These results highlight the feasibility and reliability for accurate heart rate estimation using embedded artificial intelligence. The work demonstrates potential for real-world applications in long-term remote healthcare and home-based monitoring.

title: TerseChain: A Stateless UTXO-Based Blockchain with Sharding Support_supp1-3662399.pdf
authors: Yi Sun
publish: N/A
abstract: Blockchain technology innovatively realizes data trusted verification and traceability through the chain structure. But meanwhile, the constant growth of blockchain causes a serious state bloat, becoming a critical challenge restricting the scalability of blockchain. The stateless blockchain, eliminating the necessity of storing the entire state by compressing it into a commitment, is a promising solution to address the state bloat problem. However, current stateless blockchains for unspent transaction output (UTXO) model suffer from poor performance and scalability. In this paper, we present TerseChain, a sharding stateless UTXO-based blockchain that can effectively balance storage, computation, and communication overhead. Specifically, TerseChain innovatively decouples the cross-shard transaction processing into local validation, global ordering, and parallel execution by stateless verification, improving scalability while guaranteeing security. More importantly, our enhanced algo rithms markedly increase the efficiency of stateless verification within each shard, necessitating only a constant overhead in storage. Through rigorous theoretical analysis and extensive experimental results, we demonstrate that TerseChain provides high processing capacity that scales favorably with the expansion of the network. TerseChain not only addresses the scalability issues of stateless blockchains but also provides a foundation for AI-enhanced blockchain scalability solutions.

title: Navigation Without Localization Using Stable Cycles
authors: Quentin Brateau, Loïck Degorre, Fabrice Le Bars, Luc Jaulin
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: Navigating autonomous robots in GNSS-denied environments, such as underwater, remains a fundamental challenge due to the lack of reliable localization. Classical approaches rely on exteroceptive sensors and complex state estimation pipelines, which are often computationally expensive, not-precise, and unsuitable for stealthy or resource-constrained platforms. In this article, we propose a novel, frugal navigation paradigm based on stable cycles, inspired by biological navigation strategies observed in migratory animals. Our method enables a robot to follow and stabilize a predefined cycle in the environment without requiring explicit state estimation. A timed automaton is used to generate control inputs that drive the robot along a discretized cycle, which is then stabilized in the world frame using sparse environmental measurements. We formally describe this cycle-based control framework, provide a proof of its stability, and validate the approach experimentally on a real robot. This work opens a new direction for low-cost, low-observability robotic navigation in unstructured and GNSS-denied environments.

title: Multistatic Tracking With the Precision Kalman Filter
authors: Steven V. Bordonaro, Tod E. Luginbuhl, Michael J. Walsh
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: This article presents a generalized, converted measurement Kalman filter for problems with a linear state equation and nonlinear measurement equation. This filter, called the precision Kalman filter (PKF), maps the measurements and their covariance matrices from measurement coordinates to state coordinates such that the converted measurements are unbiased and their covariance matrices are independent of the measurements. The filter’s performance is demonstrated on the multistatic sonar/radar tracking problems and is compared with that of the cubature Kalman filter (CKF) and another converted-measurement filter from the recent literature (called the CM2KF). These demonstrations show that the PKF has better overall performance than the CKF and CM2KF, particularly with respect to consistency.

title: DRL-Based Wireless-Powered UAVs Trajectories Planning for Fair Communication_supp1-3664292.pdf
authors: Xiaoyu Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: While unmanned aerial vehicle base stations (UAV-BSs) offer transformative potential for enhancing terrestrial networks, their deployment faces dual challenges of limited onboard energy and dynamic channel conditions that compromise long-term fair communication coverage. In this paper, we investigate the problem of Wireless-powered UAVs Trajectories planning for Fair communication (WUTF), that is, navigating multiple UAV-BSs powered by wireless charging towers (WCTs), to provide fair communication services for ground users. To address the problem, we first formulate the original optimization problem as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP), and propose a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) based trajectory planning algorithm. The proposed approach incorporates a novel reward function that balances multiple objectives and adopts a Centralized Training with Executed Decentralization (CTED) framework. Furthermore, a sequential policy update scheme is introduced to enhance multi-UAV coordination and reduce policy conflicts. Simulation results show that our proposed algorithm significantly improves the communication fairness, total throughput, and communication efficiency, as compared to state-of-the-art DRL-based methods up to $32.01\%$ on average.

title: Federated Learning in the Shuffle Model of Differential Privacy: A Communication-Efficient and Maliciously Secure Realization_supp1-3663543.pdf
authors: Yifeng Zheng
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a compelling privacy-friendly paradigm that allows multiple clients to jointly train a model by sharing only gradient updates instead of their local datasets. Since gradient updates may still expose sensitive information, a line of research has explored the use of local differential privacy (LDP) mechanisms to formally safeguard these updates. Under LDP, each client perturbs its gradients locally prior to sharing. However, LDP often leads to a significant degradation in model utility due to the addition of large noises. To enable a better balance between privacy and utility, an increasing trend is to leverage the shuffle model of differential privacy (DP) in FL, which introduces an intermediate shuffling operation on the perturbed gradients, enabling privacy amplification. Following this trend, we present <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math>${\sf Camel}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, a communication-efficient and maliciously secure FL framework operating under the shuffle model of DP. A key difference of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math>${\sf Camel}$</tex-math></inline-formula> from existing works is its new support for integrity checks on the shuffle computation, providing security against a malicious adversary. To achieve this, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math>${\sf Camel}$</tex-math></inline-formula> builds on a trending cryptographic technique called secret-shared shuffle, and augments it by our custom methods for system-wide communication optimization and lightweight server-side integrity verification. Furthermore, we provide a formal analysis of privacy loss by employing Rényi differential privacy (RDP) for the entire FL process, which allows a tighter privacy bound. Our comprehensive experimental results show that <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math>${\sf Camel}$</tex-math></inline-formula> outperforms current state-of-the-art approaches in achieving better privacy-utility trade-offs, while maintaining promising performance.

title: Hardware-Aware Neural Architecture Search for Encrypted Traffic Classification on Resource-Constrained Devices
authors: Adel Chehade, Edoardo Ragusa, Paolo Gastaldo, Rodolfo Zunino
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: This paper presents a hardware-efficient deep neural network (DNN), optimized through hardware-aware neural architecture search (HW-NAS); the DNN supports the classification of session-level encrypted traffic on resource-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) and edge devices. Thanks to HW-NAS, a 1D convolutional neural network (CNN) is tailored on the ISCX VPN-nonVPN dataset to meet strict memory and computational limits while achieving robust performance. The optimized model attains an accuracy of 96.60% with just 88.26K parameters, 10.08M floating-point operations (FLOPs), and a maximum tensor size of 20.12K. Compared to state-of-the-art (SOTA) models, it achieves reductions of up to 444-fold, 312-fold, and 15-fold in these metrics, respectively, significantly minimizing memory footprint and runtime requirements. The model also demonstrates versatility, achieving up to 99.86% across multiple VPN and traffic classification (TC) tasks; it further generalizes to external benchmarks with up to 99.98% accuracy on USTC-TFC and QUIC NetFlow. In addition, an in-depth approach to header-level preprocessing strategies confirms that the optimized model can provide notable performance across a wide range of configurations, even in scenarios with stricter privacy considerations. Likewise, a reduction in the length of sessions of up to 75% yields significant improvements in efficiency, while maintaining high accuracy with only a negligible drop of 1-2%. However, the importance of careful preprocessing and session length selection in the classification of raw traffic data is still present, as improper settings or aggressive reductions can bring about a 7% reduction in overall accuracy. The quantized architecture was deployed on STM32 microcontrollers and evaluated across input sizes; results confirm that the efficiency gains from shorter sessions translate to practical, low-latency embedded inference. These findings demonstrate the method’s practicality for encrypted traffic analysis in constrained IoT networks.

title: HRADP: A Heat-Recirculation-Aware Data Placement Approach for Energy-Efficient Cloud Data Centers
authors: Jie Li, Yuhui Deng, Zijie Zhong, Biqing Zeng, Yi Zhong, Geyong Min
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: With the proliferation of cloud computing, the exponential growth of data amount requires continuous expansion of storage capacity to meet the storage demand, consequently resulting in higher energy consumption in data centers. However, many of the conventional data placement strategies strive to save energy by optimizing the distribution of data requests, while overlooking the impact of heat recirculation among data nodes. To bridge this gap, we propose a heat-recirculation-aware data placement approach, termed HRADP, designed to optimize data placement in data centers while reducing energy consumption. First, based on the extent of heat recirculation, HRADP places data to the upper limit of the disk allowance for each data node. Second, during energy allocation, HRADP further eliminates disks with high current workloads to prevent localized hotspots. Finally, during request scheduling, HRADP selects dormant data nodes according to the request size, minimizing the startup energy consumption caused by data nodes waking up with small requests. We implement the HRADP approach on a data center simulation platform, CloudSim, and its performance with state-of-the-art, including the Energy-efficient and Thermal-aware Data Placement (ETDP) algorithm, Thermal-aware file assignment technique (TIGER), Storage and rack-sensitive replica placement algorithm (SRS), and Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS). The experimental results reveal that HRADP revamps the cooling supply temperature, total energy, and data throughput by averages of 0.08%-0.6%, 8.22%-53.03%, and 9.58%-64.59%, respectively.

title: Multi-Modal Environment Semantics Information Aided UAV Beam Alignment
authors: Lei Huang, Shengchun Huang, Dengke Guo, Dongtang Ma, Jun Xiong, Haitao Zhao, Jibo Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: In 6 G directional communications, high-frequency millimeter-wave (mmWave) and terahertz (THz) signals suffer from severe propagation loss and are highly susceptible to blockage, while the high mobility of the unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) further complicates link establishment. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel UAV beam alignment scheme that leverages multi-modal environment semantics information to improve beam alignment accuracy by integrating multi-modal semantics into highly dynamic UAV environments. Specifically, a dual-path feature extraction module that acquires visual semantics via target detection and positional semantics through GPS/INS fusion is presented. A neural network based on bidirectional cross-attention mechanism is designed to effectively fuse multi-modal environment semantics information to output the optimal beam. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvements in beam alignment accuracy through multi-modal fusion. Compared to existing vision-only and position-only schemes, the proposed scheme achieves increases in Top-1 accuracy of 16.25% and 74.66%, respectively.

title: Temporally-Similar Structure-Aware Spatiotemporal Fusion of Satellite Images
authors: Ryosuke Isono, Shunsuke Ono
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper proposes a spatiotemporal (ST) fusion framework robust against diverse noise for satellite images, named Temporally-Similar Structure-Aware ST fusion (TSSTF). ST fusion is a promising approach to address the trade-off between the spatial and temporal resolution of satellite images. In real-world scenarios, observed satellite images are severely degraded by noise due to measurement equipment and environmental factors. Therefore, some recent studies have focused on enhancing the robustness of ST fusion methods against noise. However, existing noise-robust ST fusion approaches often fail to capture fine spatial structure, leading to oversmoothing and artifacts. To address this issue, TSSTF introduces two key mechanisms: Temporally-Guided Total Variation (TGTV) and Temporally-Guided Edge Constraint (TGEC). TGTV is a weighted total variation-based regularization that promotes spatial piecewise smoothness while preserving structural details, guided by a reference high spatial resolution image acquired on a nearby date. TGEC enforces consistency in edge locations between two temporally adjacent images, while allowing for spectral variations. We formulate the ST fusion task as a constrained optimization problem incorporating TGTV and TGEC, and develop an efficient algorithm based on a preconditioned primal-dual splitting method. Experimental results demonstrate that TSSTF performs comparably to state-of-the-art methods in noise-free cases and outperforms them under noisy conditions.
