title: A Method for Identifying the Source of Second Traveling Wave Under Breakage Fault in Non-Bounded VSC-HVDC Grid with New Energy Access
authors: Xiangwen Chen, Yang Liu, Huixin Li, Yi Shen, Yinhong Li
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for identifying the source of the second traveling wave under breakage faults in the non-bounded VSC-HVDC grid with new energy access. Firstly, the line boundary structure of the non-bounded VSC-HVDC grid is introduced, and the voltage reflection coefficient of the line boundary is deduced. Then, the characteristics of the second voltage traveling wave at both ends of the line under breakage faults are explored based on the propagation process of the voltage traveling wave. It is found that for the unipolar breakage fault, the sign of the ratio of the second voltage traveling wave to the first voltage traveling wave can be used to identify the source of the second traveling wave, while for the bipolar breakage fault, there is no need to identify the source. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified in PSCAD/EMTDC. The results show that after applying the method, the sources of the second traveling wave can be accurately identified at both ends of the line in the non-bounded VSC-HVDC grid under various breakage faults.

title: Research on the Abnormality of Single-Phase Grounding of 66 kV System and the Abnormality of Coupling Voltage of the Same Tower Double-Loop Line
authors: Zhang XuYang, Wu HongZhang, Zhang PengQiao, Wang Yu, Wang XinYu, Deng LinJiang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: The article analyzes the single-phase grounding abnormality treatment of 66 kV system, summarizes the singlephase grounding characteristics and grounding line selection principles of 66 kV system, and conducts case analysis based on actual conditions. Modeling and analysis was carried out on the abnormal coupling voltage of the same tower double return line that exists during grounding. It was verified that the abnormal lines in the same tower double return line during single-phase grounding will have a greater impact on the voltage of the normal operating system, and provide technical exchange reference values for personnel in relevant fields.

title: Dynamic Music Recommender Based on User Mood and Affect Using Machine Learning
authors: Kunal, Himanshu Dubey, Bipin, Dinesh Singh Dhakar, Zahid Hussain Wani, D. Vetrithangam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Music has always been a part of human civilization since ancient times. It not only greatly influences human emotions, but it is also proven that it can influence cognitive function, physical health, and even social behaviour. These benefits as well as overall user experience can greatly be enhanced with the combination of music and artificial intelligence. The surge of music streaming platforms like Spotify, Gaana, You Tube Music, etc. ends up frequently overwhelming the users with its extensive music libraries, which in turn ends up complicating the process of choosing songs that actually match their current feelings and fit their vibe. Traditional music recommendation systems that are mostly dependent on content-based or collaborative filtering often struggling with a cold start and a lack of proper emotional context. To address such issues, this study presents a better dynamic music suggestion system that specifically generates a tailored song recommendation by recognizing the users emotions in real-time. This system uses certain methods such as machine learning and computer vision, to assess and thoroughly understand the user's facial expression, eventually detecting user's emotions as well by utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for feature extraction. The InceptionV3 architecture has been utilized to obtain and detect facial features, which is later on categorized using machine learning methods such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Logistic Regression. This system bridges emotional intelligence with personalized music experiences. The system recognizes the users emotions, and the recognized user's emotion is then associated with a thoughtfully designed music playlist provided through a hybrid recommendation method that merges the content-based filtering with emotion based sensitive context.

title: Improve Smart Surveillance Systems with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs): Integrate Fog Computing and IoT for Real-Time Threat Detection and Response
authors: S. Varalakshmi, Imad Shalout, Revathi R, V. Samuthira Pandi, Pacha Swathi, Shobana D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The growing interest in intelligent surveillance systems has been mainly driven by the necessity to guarantee public security, control sensitive areas, and detect threats in a proactive and timely manner. Traditional surveillance systems that depend on the centralized backend cloud processing are restricted by large lags, bandwidth and scalability. To address the issues above, we introduce an intelligent surveillance system by combining CNNs, Fog Computing, and IoT together to achieve the real-time threat detection and decision making at the network edge level. They CNNs achieve the state-of-theart performance in object detection, anomaly detection and face verification under the context of complex visual scenes, as a result of deep learning based hierarchical processing of features. They are however computationally expensive and require distributed processing power which cloud-only services are not good for in terms of latency. Fog Computing is introduced in this architecture as an intermediate layer between the IoT edge devices and the cloud to overcome such shortcomings. Fog nodes are placed close to data sources (surveillance cameras or sensors) for processing computationally intensive CNN inference locally to achieve low transmission delay, offload cloud and improve situational response time. Through it, a network of heterogeneous sensors can be easily connected, and data can be collected, synchronized, and remotely accessed. Integrated with CNNbased analytics, FCFWD leverages the distributed fog nodes and the continuous data streams from the IOT devices not only to facilitate context determination and intelligent threat recognition but also to enable immediate automatic event triggering and alert notifications to the appropriate agencies. The efficiency of the design is verified by simulation and prototype under a smart city scenario including public transport centers, governmental precincts and city road crossroads. Our evaluation demonstrates orders of magnitude improvement in response time, accuracy and energy over cloud dominated paradigms. The integrated system also contributes to data privacy by local sensitive analytics, and sends only like stats to cloud. This work presents a scalable, low-latency, and intelligent surveillance model that closes the AI vision systems and the distributed edge computing. In the end, this solution gives those behind the operation real-time situation monitoring and the ability to proactively manage security in high-stakes environments.

title: Fast Moving System Warning for Two Wheelers
authors: Nidhika Chauhan, Aryan, Brijesh Pradsad, Daksh Sehgal, Maish Bindra, Shubham Negi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Considering the cases of increased numbers of twowheelers accidents it can be concluded that a major reason could be lack of proper warning systems, hence the focus of this study is to propose a Fast Moving System Warning (FMSW) designed particularly for two-wheelers. The FMSW will help to reduce the risk of collision as it will warn the riders of the presence of super-speedy vehicles approaching in their blind spot. Radar and camera sensors are some of the advanced sensors which the technology utilizes to sense the movement of an approaching car and gauge its speed and direction relative to the two-wheeler. The FMSW initiates a series of warnings in the form of visual displays on the dashboard and verbal messages via integrated speakers or activators attached to the helmet of the rider, in the event of a potential collision. Furthermore, sophisticated algorithms facilitate the equipment to differentiate between harmless traffic and dangerous threats, ensuring that only a warning is issued when it is necessary, in order to prevent false alarms and the related inconvenience of distracting riders. Besides, the FMSW can be connected with safety systems that are already in use, e.g., traction control, ABS, to improve response strategies and reduce the extent of impact. Numerous tests and simulations confirm the effectiveness of the FMSW in awaring the riders and reducing the chance of an accident. All considered, the FMSW approach is a key event in terms of the security technology of two-wheeler, offering a preventive measure to the issues of a fast traffic scenario besides enhancing the overall experience of riding.

title: Design of Miniaturized 3.8-GHz Shorted Patch Antenna for Sub-6 GHz 5G Applications
authors: Thu-Trang Hoang, Dat Tran-Huy, Hoang Nguyen-Huy, Hung Tran-Huy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: This paper presents a method for miniaturization of a quarter-wavelength microstrip patch antenna. Theoretically, a shorted patch antenna provides a unidirectional beam operating in the TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1/2,0</inf> mode. To lower the operating band from 4.50 to 4.15 GHz, two slots are introduced along the side edges of the patch. Further miniaturization is achieved with the aid of a thin, shorted metallic strip in close proximity to the patch's radiating edge. Accordingly, the operating frequency significantly decreases to 3.8 GHz. The final antenna realization has small dimensions of 0.12 λ × 0.11 λ and operating bandwidth of about 40 MHz. It is also worth noting that the cross-polarization of the conventional shorted patch antenna is typically high at approximately -7.5 dB. Meanwhile, the proposed antenna with a more compact size can achieve lower cross-polarization level of about -12 dB.

title: Smart Glasses for the Blind: A Real-Time AI-Odriven Wearable System for Autonomous Navigation
authors: Priyanshi Sharma, Manju Sadasivan, M T Vasumathi, Akhila S Babu, K T Aroan Robert, Ashok Kumar T A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Blind individuals often face significant challenges in navigating their surroundings independently. Even with the sticks, they have a difficult time walking around on their own. They must always be accompanied either by trained dogs or people. They can't move around freely on their own, creating mobility issues for them. This paper introduces a comprehensive design and analysis of AI-based smart glasses which addresses the mentioned challenges. The model is designed to help a person who is blind/visually impaired. This model would assist a person to navigate and find objects in real time. This AI based smart glass is a tremendous help for blind people who are often frustrated because they have to be watched by others all the time. The proposed designed uses a Coral Edge TPU along with a Raspberry Pi Zero W to do efficient on-device processing to find obstacles, recognize traffic lights, and give vocal input through bone conduction speakers. A mathematical model is described that represents decision-making based on obstacle distance, classifying probability, and traffic light state. The paper also discusses the architecture, approach, and potential future enhancements to fault-free assistive navigation.

title: Design and Simulation of a Basic IoT Network Using MQTT and CoAP Protocols
authors: Jyoteesh Malhotra, Mohd Muddassir
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The proposed research demonstrates a combined experimental system that evaluates the strength, stability, and ability to detect anomalies in IoT communication protocols, specifically MQTT, CoAP, HTTP, and AMQP, within controlled network environments. The experiment utilises a hybrid simulation setup supported by MQTT publishing, CoAP server communications, and a CoAP-MQTT bridge to report real-time metrics such as latency, packet loss, jitter, and throughput. Isolation Forest is used for advanced anomaly detection, while statistical correlation and QoS scoring assess the efficiency of each protocol. To test resilience, experiments simulate network variability, introducing realistic conditions like variable bandwidth, packet delays, and loss profiles. Additionally, forecasting using time series decomposition, ARIMA, and LSTM models enables performance optimisation before issues arise. Insights into protocol behaviour are visualised through heatmaps, scatter plots, and stacked bar charts, providing actionable data. Results indicate that MQTT consistently outperforms in latency and anomaly detection.

title: A Gate Signal Feedback Method for Dynamic Delay Estimation and Dead Time Correction in Parallel GaN MOSFETs
authors: Pramod Kumar, Harish Sudhakaran Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Dynamic current balancing of parallel MOSFETs involves the accurate matching of gating signals, particularly in high-speed wide-bandgap devices such as GaN and SiC. While conventional methods rely on drain current feedback for synchronization of the gate pulses, they often suffer from limitations related to sensing bandwidth, sampling limitations of the dynamic part of the drain current, and increased system complexity. This paper proposes a novel gate-voltage-based feedback approach to detect and compensate for gate pulse mismatches without relying on drain current measurements. The concept is investigated through a comprehensive LTspice simulation study analyzing the impact of asynchronous gate signals on switching behavior and current imbalance. A MATLAB-based model is developed to process simulated gate voltage waveforms, determine the delay mismatch, and propose a corresponding dead time correction strategy for microcontroller implementation. Further, it also explores the trade-offs involved in the various methods of feedback. This simulation-driven study presents a promising direction for future low-cost, scalable current balancing strategies in paralleloperated power devices.

title: Effective Security Administration Interface in 6G Using Virtual and Immersive Reality
authors: Anmol Agarwal, Rakshesh P. Bhatt, Clifton Fernandes
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: 6G networks are anticipated to bring much innovation, and one key innovation is the idea that 6G will be more human-centric. Immersive environments such as the Metaverse are planned to be used more in 6G. While 6G will bring exciting innovation, the complexity of networks will increase, making security administration more difficult. In this paper, we propose a novel method to enable effective security administration in 6G using an avatar in an immersive environment like the Metaverse. We provide a procedure for secure access control, authentication, and registration of an avatar and a visual design of an immersive security administration application. The proposed solution is a secure and user-friendly method for an immersive and interactive security administration experience.

title: Post Quantum Secure Framework for IoT Based EV Battery Swapping Stations in Sustainable Transport Networks
authors: Ruchi Sharma, Mohd Khizar Syed, Sudhakar Ajmera, S. Sandhiya, Manoranjan Dash, A. Balakumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid advancement of quantum computing threatens the security of classical public-key cryptosystems widely used for secure communications in Internet of Things (IoT) and electric vehicle (EV) battery swapping networks. Existing methods, including traditional cryptography and some early post-quantum algorithms, often struggle with high latency, excessive energy consumption, and limited suitability for resource-constrained IoT devices, hindering their practical deployment. This paper proposes PostQ-SwapNet, a novel hybrid framework designed to secure IoT-based EV battery swapping stations against both classical and quantum cyber threats. The system integrates CRYSTALS-Kyber for quantum-resistant key exchange, Dilithium digital signatures for mutual authentication, AES-128 encryption for data confidentiality, and a BiLSTM-based anomaly detection module for real-time threat identification. Additionally, it leverages a private blockchain with smart contracts to ensure transaction immutability and traceability. The objective is to deliver a secure, efficient, and scalable solution compatible with current IoT hardware constraints. This framework reduces latency to $\mathbf{1 2 0 ~ m s}$, energy use to $\mathbf{1 5 ~ m J}$ and memory use to $\mathbf{2 5 6 ~ K B}$ and still maintains a strong level of security. Python and TensorFlow were used for coding the AI side of the project. The results affirm that PostQ-SwapNet effectively balances security and performance, making it a practical solution for future-proofing EV energy networks against quantum and conventional cyberattacks.

title: AG-MPBS: a Mobility-Aware Prediction and Behavior-Based Scheduling Framework for Air-Ground Unmanned Systems
authors: Tianhao Shao, Kaixing Zhao, Feng Liu, Lixin Yang, Bin Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: As unmanned systems such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs) play increasingly critical roles in urban sensing and emergency response, efficiently recruiting these autonomous devices for time-sensitive tasks becomes a vital challenge. This paper proposes MPBS (Mobility-aware Prediction and Behavior-based Scheduling), a scalable task recruitment framework that models each device as a recruitable "user." MPBS integrates three core modules: a behavior-aware KNN classifier, a time-varying Markov prediction model for forecasting device mobility, and a dynamic priority scheduling mechanism that aconsiders task urgency and base station performance. By combining behavioral classification with spatiotemporal prediction, MPBS adaptively assigns tasks to the most suitable devices in real time. Experimental evaluations on the real-world GeoLife dataset demonstrate that MPBS significantly improves task completion efficiency and resource utilization. The proposed framework provides a predictive, behavior-aware approach for intelligent and collaborative scheduling in unmanned systems.

title: A DC Bias Suppression Strategy of Three Phase DAB-LLC DC Converter
authors: Linjiang Deng, Fengxi Leng, Xinchi Yang, Chengchen Li, Jialu Cheng, Sihan Du
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Due to the variation in load power, the transient DC bias current caused by the voltage-time imbalance of the converter not only leads to transformer saturation but also increases the current stress of the devices. Based on the model predictive control characteristics, the DC bias is identified and eliminated, which further effectively improves the response speed of the transient process. In addition, the load current is estimated by using a state observer to save the cost of current sensors. Finally, the proposed strategy is further verified through simulation.

title: AI-Powered Plant Disease Detection System Using CNN for Precision Agriculture -Geospatial Data
authors: Deepa R, Senduru Srinivasulu, Sundara Rajulu Navaneethakrishnan, Janaki. E, Surendran R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Fast and accurate plant disease detection is essential for agricultural production and ecologically sustainable farming. The research paper defines GACN, a Geospatial data and AI-powered Crop disease detection Network. GACN uses spatial data analytics and CNNs to diagnose plant diseases more accurately, improving farming. The latest GACN development utilizes a curated dataset of over 50,000 annotated leaf photos. This collection covers fifteen crop kinds and twenty-five illnesses across many agroclimatic zones. GACN's F1-score is 95.2 %, recall 94.9 %, precision 95.5%, and classification accuracy 96.8%. Because of this, it can consistently locate ill individuals in the real world. The GACN develops disease risk maps that predict disease locations with an accuracy of over 92 %, using weather patterns, soil moisture data, and satellite-derived vegetation indicators (NDVI and LST). This multimodal technique enables early illness identification and localization prediction. Agronomists and farmers can use the system's decision support platform on their mobile devices for real-time warnings, regional treatment recommendations, and interactive maps and visualizations. Three Kenyan and Indian testing locations show the model's scalability and endurance. Additionally, it could cut crop losses by 38 %. The GACN has built data-driven, strong agricultural ecosystems using AI and geospatial intelligence.

title: Synthesis of Inverse Optimal Regulator for Uncertain Neutral Time-Delay Systems
authors: Hayate Sawato, Takuya Nakagawa, Koki Shibuya, Haruto Takahash, Tsuyoshi Matsuki, Hidetoshi Oya
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: In this paper, a design method of inverse optimal regulators for uncertain neutral time-delay systems is proposed. The proposed inverse optimal regulator minimizes a quadratic cost functional, i.e. the proposed control system is asymptotically stable and it has robustness for uncertainties. In this approach, Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional is utilized, and a new less conservative result comparing with existing results is derived. Furthermore, we show that sufficient conditions for the existence of the proposed optimal inverse regulator are reduced to solvability of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Finally, simple numerical examples are presented to demonstrate the usefulness of the proposed controller.

title: A Method for Medium and Long-term Power Generation Assessment of Offshore Wind Power Based on AE-GRU Considering Volatility and Extreme Weather Effects
authors: Jingkui Jiang, Cuiyun Luo, Hong Li, Wei Xu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Accurate assessment of medium and long-term power generation for offshore wind farms is crucial for investment decision-making and power grid planning. This paper presents an Alpha Evolution Algorithm-Gated Recurrent Unit (AE-GRU)-based method for medium and long-term power generation assessment of offshore wind power considering volatility and extreme weather effects. Firstly, high spatiotemporal resolution historical meteorological data from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts fifth-generation reanalysis (ERA5) is obtained, including basic parameters such as wind speed, wind direction, and temperature. Secondly, derivative features including wind energy density, monthly variation index, and extreme wind conditions are calculated based on ERA5 data. Finally, a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU)-based power generation assessment model optimized by Alpha Evolution (AE) Algorithm is constructed to fit the nonlinear mapping relationship between meteorological parameters and power generation, thereby achieving medium and long-term power generation assessment for offshore wind power. Case studies demonstrate that: (1) The proposed hybrid model improves assessment accuracy by 42.8% in terms of Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) compared to traditional methods, with notably enhanced adaptability to extreme weather conditions; (2) The model effectively captures seasonal variations and interannual fluctuation characteristics of power generation by comprehensively considering multidimensional meteorological features and their derivatives, reducing the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) to 29.49 GWh; (3) The introduction of deep learning and optimization algorithms further enhances the accuracy of medium and long-term power generation assessment for offshore wind power.

title: AI Augmented IoT Framework for Precision Coal Wagon Loading Using STM32 and Cloud Based Weight Control
authors: Subramanian. M, A Subbulakshmi, Shivani B S, Navin Athreya R, Adithya R, Chezhiyan M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Underloading or overloading is also common in coal wagon loading in India, which results in financial fines, wasted freight expenses and inefficiency. The current paper introduces an AI-enhanced IoT system that would automatize and optimize the process of coal loading in overlaying railways sidings. It combines an STM32F446RE microcontroller and a load cells collection consisting of Zemic H3-C3 with an HX711 ADC to measure weight accurately and an automated control system consisting of a conveyor belt. MQTT transmits real-time data to a cloud platform where it is monitored, anomalies are detected and operational insights are gained. An over-thecounter CNN model on the STM32 makes adaptive PID tuning and predictive fault detection possible, and can lead to better control accuracy across different loading conditions. Experimental trials proved an average loading efficiency of 99 % with less variance and throughput loss than manual techniques. The framework is cost-efficient, scalable, and smart in application to the Industry 4.0 practices and will be more reliable in coal logistics and use freight capacity more efficiently.

title: Simulating a ZPD-based Knowledge Tracing Model for Enhanced Adaptive Practicing
authors: Hongxin Yan, Raymond Morland, Fuhua Lin, Kinshuk, Cindy Ives
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Self-paced online learning demands strong self-regulation, a skill many learners lack, causing high attrition rates in this educational model. Learners need a means to assess their dynamic knowledge states to clearly understand their ability throughout the course learning. While knowledge tracing function in adaptive learning systems (ALS) helps, traditional models usually overlook the side information of metacognition and the consideration of learner control. To address these issues, our study introduces the Zone of Proximal Development-based Knowledge Tracing (ZPD-KT) model, a novel adaptive practicing framework for online STEM education. ZPD-KT integrates confidence-based assessment, dynamic ZPD, and traditional knowledge tracing principles to enable an AI-learner shared control approach. Through a large-scale simulation involving 8,000 synthetic learners, the ZPD-KT model was benchmarked against traditional Bayesian Knowledge Tracing (BKT). Initial results show a significant increase in the effectiveness of adaptive practice when traditional KT algorithms are augmented with ZPD. Furthermore, the study highlights the critical role of metacognitive signals (e.g., self-reported confidence) in refining KT beyond binary correctness metrics. For smart education ecosystems, ZPD-KT offers a scalable, ethically grounded solution that balances AI-driven personalization with learner autonomy, advocating for systems that prioritize pedagogical equity and adaptability in self-paced online learning environments.

title: A Systematic Evaluation of Non-IID Estimation Methods in Federated Learning
authors: Nafas Gul Saadat, Santhosh Kumar G
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) protects data privacy while enabling decentralized training across distributed clients. However, a primary challenge in FL is the presence of non-Independent and Identically Distributed (non-IID) data among clients. This data heterogeneity, common in real-world scenarios, can lead to several issues such as degraded global model performance, slow convergence, biased local updates, and increased consumption of computational resources and network bandwidth. Effectively addressing non-IID data across distributed clients requires an accurate estimation of its degree in their local datasets.Despite the variety of statistical methods used in the FL literature for non-IID degree estimation, different studies often adopt diverse approaches and assert their effectiveness without clear justification. This lack of explanation has resulted in no clear consensus on the most accurate and effective non-IID estimation method. This paper aims to bridge this critical gap by systematically comparing and evaluating several widely used non-IID estimation methods. We consider eight popular statistical methods used to estimate the degree of non-IIDness in client data within FL. We conducted extensive experiments on the CIFAR-10 dataset to evaluate each method based on its impact on global model performance, communication costs, and computation costs. The findings of this research are intended to guide future studies in selecting appropriate non-IID estimation methods and offer crucial insights into the efficiency of various estimation techniques. Furthermore, this work contributes to identifying the most effective and reliable non-IID estimation method for characterizing client data distributions.

title: SolarSalt: Phase-Change Sodium-Based Battery for 24/7 Renewable Energy Storage
authors: Jainish Roy, Kosimov Khusniddin Badriddinovich, K.S. Bhuvaneshwari, Saef Obidhusin, Diksha Thakur, Guma Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Conventional lithium-ion or high-temperature sodium batteries will not suffice for the growing demand for sustainable and efficient energy storage; research is expanding beyond these. SolarSalt achieves an energy density of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathbf{4 5 0} \text{Wh} / \text{kg}$</tex>, Coulombic efficiency above 98.5%, and a cycle life exceeding 2000 cycles at room temperature. Compared to lithium-ion batteries, it offers 40% lower kWh costs and improved safety, with no thermal runaway or dendrite formation. By also enhancing stability through HEA coating, which prevents corrosion and dendrite formation to improve the battery lifespan and efficiency, the coating is markedly beneficial. The innovation also offers a low-cost, high-density renewable energy storage alternative to provide uninterrupted power to solar and wind power systems at an appropriate power density. Other areas investigated are legal (such as intellectual property rights, safety certifications (UL, IEC, NFPA), environmental policies (EPA, REACH), and grid interconnection standards (IEEE 1547)). This paper proposes a blockchain-based energy certification system to provide transparency, compliance, and secure energy trading. Experimental results show that SolarSalt outperforms lithium-ion and conventional sodium batteries in terms of energy retention, safety, and cost-effectiveness. This research introduces a novel room-temperature, sodium-based SolarSalt battery that integrates liquid-solid phase change energy storage with HEA encapsulation and blockchain-enabled certification. The originality lies in uniting materials science, renewable energy storage, and digital compliance within a single scalable platform. This contribution advances both technical and regulatory dimensions of sustainable energy storage.

title: Analysis of Micro-Sized THz Graphene and Copper Antennas Implemented in 6G and Counterterrorism Armaments
authors: Gurjeevan Singh, Karmjit Singh Sandha, Ankush Kansal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The proposed research aims to utilize the combination of THz spectrum and graphene materials as a tool for detecting explosives to enhance counterterrorism efforts under THz spectroscopy & 6G technology's upcoming worldwide implementations. The current research work introduces the design of antennas that utilize graphene and copper to detect explosive materials in the THz region. A graphene-based terahertz antenna is compared to three other designs: one that uses a graphene patch and a copper ground, another that uses a graphene ground and a copper-based metallic patch, and one additional design incorporating a ground and a patch of copper. Detecting plastic explosives like SEMTEX requires all four designs to resonate at a frequency of 5.33 THz & with values of 96.29 % for radiation efficiency, -73.93 for return loss, 1.0004 for VSWR, and 6.92 for gain, the entire graphene antenna proposed here has outperformed over all other designs.

title: Hybrid Algorithm for CFAR Detection in Non-Homogeneous Environments
authors: Mohamed El Amine Bouchelaghem, Ahmed Assem Meddah, Nabila Nouar
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a hybrid Constant False Alarm Rate (H-CFAR) algorithm that not only guarantees good detection performances without altering the Probability of False Alarm (Pfa), but also is reliable in complex scenarios where traditional CFAR techniques often fail due to the presence of interfering targets and/or clutter variations. The proposed hybrid approach, which combines two CFAR processors using clutter estimates of both detectors in order to establish the decision rule, is an enhanced CFAR approach that dynamically adapts its threshold by analyzing surrounding cells while minimizing the effect of non-homogeneous elements. Detection Performances of (H-CFAR) are analyzed in both homogeneous and non-homogeneous environments under various assumptions such as: different clutter distributions and severe contamination by interfering targets. Simulations indicate that the proposed method offers improved detection performance and an enhanced robustness compared to conventional CFAR detectors, particularly in environments where clutter and interference are non-uniformly distributed.

title: Understanding the Effect of Measurement Noise in Fast Pulse-Based Impedance Spectroscopy
authors: Sneha Sundaresan, Krishna Pattipati, Balakumar Balasingam
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Accurate impedance estimation is essential for reliable battery diagnostics and modeling. Discrete Fourier transform (DFT)–based impedance estimation is widely adopted in electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) for battery characterization due to its simplicity and computational efficiency. However, the influence of measurement noise on such DFTbased impedance computation remains insufficiently understood. This paper develops a statistical framework that analytically quantifies how zero-mean Gaussian noise propagates through DFT-based impedance estimation. A closed-form expression for the bias of impedance estimates is derived, and a rectangular pulse excitation signal is employed to evaluate its performance for fast EIS applications under this framework. Simulation studies on a two time-constant RC model of the battery reveal that measurement noise and excitation design jointly influence estimation accuracy. For pulse excitation, bias amplification occurs near the high-frequency spectral zero-crossings, where the excitation spectrum approaches zero magnitude. By excluding a guard-band of impedance estimates surrounding these zerocrossings, the peak bias in both real and imaginary components is reduced by approximately 70% at 60 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Furthermore, increasing the pulse ON duration from 10 ms to 100 ms reduces the low-frequency bias by about 55%, strengthening the low-frequency signal content and improving the overall estimation accuracy.

title: Web-Based Flood Management System Enhancing Monitoring and Mitigation
authors: Uday Chavan, Tanmay Umtol, Aarti Karande
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Flood Management solutions are important to minimize the damage happening due to floods. This Paper tells us about the built project and guides us to making one as it had helped us track, control and monitor flood situations. The main part of the system is the web interface and GIS maps which brings us data to predict and take actions further. The main feature of our project is a flood warning system which uses an API to send alerts to affected areas. It also connects with a model control unit on the control panel to simulate and predict possible flood scenarios. The system provides water level updates, flood status reports, and flood levels which help in decision-making. Overall, this setup shows how different parts of the system work together and share information, making it possible to manage floods both before and after they happen. It highlights the potential of such a platform to improve preparedness and make response strategies more effective

title: Lyapunov-Based Reward Function Design for Reinforcement Learning Control of Grid-Connected Multilevel Inverters: A PUC5 Case Study
authors: Alamera Nouran Alquennah, Ahmed Kouzou, Tassneem Zamzam, Sertac Bayhan, Mohamed Trabelsi, Haitham Abu-Rub, Ali Ghrayeb
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper proposes a Lyapunov-based reward function design for Reinforcement Learning Control (RL-C) of a grid-connected 5-level Packed U Cell (PUC5) inverter. Unlike existing RL approaches that rely solely on tracking-error-based rewards, the proposed method integrates the Lyapunov stability condition directly into the reward formulation, ensuring stable learning and robust closed-loop performance. The control objectives are to regulate the flying capacitor voltage and inject a low total harmonic distortion (THD) grid current. The Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm is employed and trained in a MATLAB/Simulink environment under randomized operating conditions to enhance generalization. Simulation results demonstrate that the Lyapunov-based RL-C achieves stable operation with THD as low as 1.9 % and capacitor voltage error below 1 V across different current levels. Moreover, the trained agent exhibits strong adaptability to parameter variations and untrained operating points, confirming the proposed framework's robustness and suitability for real-time power electronics applications.

title: A Cloud-Based Generative AI Architecture for Integrated Multimodal Content Analysis and Automated Documentation
authors: Ashutosh Kumar Sinha, Divya Priya K, Nitika Nigam, Rahul Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: The world is generating unprecedented data and becoming increasingly available in unstructured formats such as text files, images, and audio files. This presents a challenge for intelligent systems geared towards information generation. Here, we present an innovative solution called Cloud-Based Generative AI System for Multi-Modal Content Analysis and Documentation. It enhances the capabilities of generative AI and cloud technologies for the automation of analysis and synthesis of inputs, such as PDF, DOCX, PPTX, TXT, MP3, and MP4. Transcription, audio content-based summarization, and document generation are achieved using LLMs, the speech-to-text model Whisper, and cloud computing infrastructure like AWS S3. Customizable topic inputs allow users to define their requirements and obtain fine-tuned results. Extensive testing on academic, business, and conversational corpora verifies its ability to generate accurate, abridged, and semantically correct summaries and Q&A reports even when the input does not contain structured context. The accuracy on all modalities shows its applicability in the real-world production pipelines of research, education, and enterprise.

title: FPGA-Based Real-Time Vehicle Monitoring System Using Licence Plate Detection
authors: Chandrakant R. Thakare, Sabarika Janani S, Goutham M. Narayanan, Sivasankaran K
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This paper presents an FPGA-based real-time vehicle monitoring system for automatic license-plate recognition, implemented on the Altera DE2-115 development board. A Sony Handy-cam video module captures a live 2592x1944 4:2:2 YCbCr stream, which is ingested via a Video-In Decoder and converted to full-resolution 4:4:4 YCbCr by a custom Chroma Re-sampler. License-plate localization is performed by a dedicated IP core that applies thresholding on Y, Cb, and Cr channels and executes two-pass connected-component labeling followed by a white-pixel-density filter to isolate the plate region. The cropped 320x240 plate image is written to on-chip SRAM through a burst-mode Video DMA, then up sampled to 640x480 RGB for VGA display. Character segmentation and recognition are extracted via secondary thresholding and labeling, normalized to 16x32 frames, and classified through a parallel template-matching engine. All pixel-level processing is offloaded to hardware IP blocks synthesized with Intel Quartus II and Platform Designer under Nios II soft-processor co-ordination. Experimental results demonstrate accurate plate detection and recognition at 30 fps with under 40% logic and 50% BRAM utilization, offering a low-power, low-cost solution for embedded intelligent-transportation application.

title: 2D Vibration-Damped Transfer of a 1DOF Overhead Traveling Crane Under Open-Loop Finite-Time Settling Control Using Half-Odd-Integer Trigonometric Functions with Two-Step Acceleration/Deceleration
authors: Shigeo Kotake
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: In this study, we present a method for generating a two-dimensional trajectory for a trolley that rapidly transports a suspended load under open-loop conditions with vibration control along various paths. This is achieved using a finite-time settling function composed of trigonometric functions with a period that divides the operation time by a half-odd integer for a 1DOF overhead crane moving on the XY horizontal plane. The trajectory for acceleration, deceleration, and curves is composed of a two-step vibration control acceleration/ deceleration operation. This consists of a first step of swinging up from a vibration control state and a second step of swinging down to the vibration control state, derived from the solution of a two-point boundary value problem of a linear 1DOF vibration system. Consequently, when the swing-up angle of the suspended load becomes large, the trajectory may deviate significantly due to the nonlinearity of the pendulum. Through simulations, we clarified how the swing-up angle of the suspended load affects the trajectory deviation when a twodimensional overhead crane transports a suspended load at various speeds with vibration control on a polygonal closed trajectory around an obstacle.

title: Soft Computing Solutions for Efficient Fault Detection in Transmission Lines
authors: Prema Daigavane, Shradha Umathe, Shrikant Chavate, Pranita Tembhurne
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Transmission lines are connected between generating points and the consumers. There is a large possibility of fault occurring in Transmission line. Fault occurs due to some weather conditions, equipment failure, human error, smoke of fire etc. due to which heavy current is being drawn from the supply. This heavy current damages insulation and other equipment. It is very important to clear these faults as soon as possible. To clear the fault, it is very important for us to know the location of the fault and the nature of that fault. Using Soft Computing tools, faults can be detected easily. This Research paper focuses on these advanced techniques which are helpful in determining faults and their location. The results obtained show the potential soft computing technology in improving fault detection in transmission line faults.

title: PPG To ECG Conversion Device
authors: Alister Moras, S Sridhar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper presents a detailed methodology for the development of a conversion system from Photoplethysmography (PPG) to electrocardiography (ECG), with the primary objective of improving healthcare monitoring. The methodology presents a series of steps to ensure the accuracy, reliability, and efficiency of the conversion process. The first step involves signal preprocessing, where collected PPG signals are subjected to techniques such as filtering and baseline correction to enhance signal quality. The feature extraction techniques are then employed to extract relevant information from the pre-processed signals. The core component of the methodology is the integration of a machine learning model, which learns the mapping between PPG and ECG signals. The Long-Short-Term Memory(LSTM) model is applied for the conversion of PPG signals to ECG signals. A Graphical User Interface(GUI) is created for user-friendly operation of our system. The functioning of the system is checked by measuring the real-time ECG reading and comparing them with the converted ECG output of the model. In the converted ECG signal we are able to visualize the peaks. This project aims to improve cardiac health monitoring by providing an alternative method of obtaining ECG signals through PPG measurements using an LSTM model.

title: Comparative Analysis of Optimization Algorithms for Deep Learning-Based Medical Image Classification
authors: Diksha Pandey, Gautam Kumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: This research examines and compares the performance of six distinct optimization methods used with CNN architecture in the context of binary classification of medical images. We pre-processed the images by converting them to grayscale and uniform dimensions to ensure uniformity in the training of the model. The six optimization methods (Adam, Adadelta, Nadam, and RMSprop, FTRL, and Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)) were used under the same conditions with the same CNN structure. The model was evaluated based on classification accuracy on the test datasets and confusion matrices to measure and analyze the performance of the methods in classifying the images into their respective categories and to which class each image was assigned. This allowed for a comparison of the optimization methods in terms of their influence on the learning of the model and the accuracy of the model prediction. The analysis of the results shows the difference in performance of the available optimization methods which would help to make an informed choice of the optimization methods to use in deep learning medical imaging.

title: IoT-Based Emergency Tracking System for Women Safety with Real-Time Location Alerts and Panic Button Activation
authors: Keshi Bhurawat, Shreya Bangde, Richa Khandelwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: In the era of increasing safety concerns, swift action during emergencies is important especially within cities. This paper presents an IoT system for personal tracking and alerts using the ESP32 microcontroller for design and implementation. For SMS alerts in real-time, the system integrates a GSM module (SIM800L) as well as a GPS module for purposes of location tracking. A panic button initiates the system into emergency mode. In this mode, the system sends a live location to the mobile number that is registered every minute. Concurrently, the system uses longitude and latitude to compute the distance to the closest hospital and police station using a mathematical equation that measures the great-circle distance between two points on the Earth's surface -the Haversine formula. An emergency contact for a person receives the locations that are identified via SMS, along with Google Maps links and distances. ThingSpeak IoT cloud also receives the GPS data. Data are logged into the cloud in the form of latitudes and longitudes of the user's current location. GSM/Wi-Fi communication, low-power microcontrollers, and geospatial mathematics combine to offer an affordable, compact solution for emergency response scenarios.

title: Fuzzy Logic Controller based Torque Ripple Minimization in Tesla Cybertruck’s PMSM Drive
authors: Ajumon Kurian, Vivek Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This article introduces a Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) combined with Direct Torque Control (DTC) and Space Vector Modulation (SVM) to enhance the performance of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSM), like the ones found in the Tesla Cybertruck. The FLC adjusts the load angle between the stator and rotor flux vectors in order to generate the required electromagnetic torque for propelling the vehicle. The method determines the reference stator flux by taking into account the load angle, changes in load angle, and stator flux magnitude, and makes adjustments to stator voltage based on stator flux difference. For electric vehicles like the Cybertruck, this method achieves reduced torque ripple, maintains a constant switching frequency, and enhances motor efficiency. Furthermore, the implementation remains straightforward, utilizing only one FLC with minimal computational requirements, making it suitable for real-time automotive applications. The control system was designed and tested in MATLAB/SIMULINK, proved to be effective for high-torque electric drives in the Cybertruck’s PMSM motor.

title: LSTM & Transfer Learning for Stock Market Bitcoin Price Prediction: An AI-Driven Channel Estimation and Prediction
authors: Lalit Verma, Chirag Sharma, Tanya Nagpal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Bitcoin, the most famous and priceless cryptocurrency in the modern financial products market, draws investors and opens new research avenues for scholars. Predicting Bitcoin values has been the subject of numerous studies employing a variety of machine learning prediction techniques. AI-driven channel estimation and prediction include important features extracted from a dataset that has a strong correlation with Bitcoin values to conduct the study. The model was then trained and tested using randomly selected data chunks. Unfitting outcomes caused by the random data selected for model training could reduce the price forecast accuracy. An effective training process for the prediction model is examined here. The suggested simple LSTM model, which predicts the cost of Bitcoin for the next five days, was then trained using this process. When the LSTM model is trained with a suitable data chunk, which has been determined, sustainable results for the prediction are obtained. Finally, the work culminates in future developments.

title: A Novel Soft Deep Learning Technique to Enhance Fashion Image Retrieval from Text Query
authors: Geeta Kasana, Sonal Kasana, Seema Wazarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The necessity for robust text-to-image retrieval systems has been brought a focus due to the increasing demand for intellectual fashion support in digital wardrobes. In order to maintain semantic fidelity, the current experimental work studies a novel wardrobe retrieval system that allows users to look for specific fashion items using natural language queries like “black top” or “red jacket”. The two experiments are carried out. In the first, the Contrastive Language-Image Pretraining (CLIP) model from OpenAI works by converting text and images into 512-dimensional vectors and figuring out how similar they are cosine-wise. Although CLIP’s high-dimensional embeddings are good at capturing semantic alignment, they come with a hefty processing cost and could contain duplicate or irrelevant characteristics. To get around these restrictions, the other experiment combines CLIP features with Rough Set Theory (RST). RST reduces dimensionality while maintaining semantic fidelity using entropy-based feature selection. Based on similarity scores, this hybrid CLIP+RST model divides retrieved images into three groups: lower, upper boundary region, and outside upper approximation. Regardless of its relevance, this classification allows for multi-perspective retrieval to meet various user search thrusts and sustainable computing.

title: Review of Deep Learning and Explainable AI Approaches for Skin Cancer Detection in Embedded Biomedical Systems
authors: Ritu Sharma, Animesh Kumar Agrawal
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The large number of skin cancer cases need early detection with accuracy to reduce mortality rate. Towards this different Artificial Intelligence (AI) models can be used to detect and predict with accuracy. This research investigates recent developments in Deep Learning (DL) and Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) for skin cancer diagnosis striking a balance between model accuracy and clinical interpretability. Well known DL models like ResNet50, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, EfficientNetB0, and hybrid architectures including HRNet-XGB are studied and compared. In order to create a reliable, interpretable AI system for early skin cancer diagnosis, this research suggests future paths including multimodal data integration, clinician-in-the-loop evaluation, and mobile-compatible deployments. A hybrid approach using Explainable AI (XAI) is proposed to derive more accurate diagnosis based on the models trained, thereby helping in early detection of skin cancer.

title: Machine Learning in Safety-Critical Applications: Beyond Traditional Worst-Case Design
authors: Rolf Ernst, Robin Hapka
publish: Computer
abstract: As semiconductor technology advances below 10 nm, the failure to capture the full range of system timing behaviors proposes a challenge for performance-demanding critical real-time applications such as neural networks. This article proposes a dual timing model for design, verification, and monitoring of real-time neural network systems.

title: Considering Safety Boundary Mapping and Safety-Economy Optimization of the Electricity-Hydrogen-Ammonia-Methanol Integrated Energy System
authors: Dandan Li, Zhige Li, Guoxian Luo, Xiqiao Lin, Huiling Qin, Chuye Hu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To address the challenges of safety domain characterization and Safety-Economy collaborative optimization caused by the strong coupling of multi-energy flows in the Electricity-Hydrogen-Ammonia-Methanol Integrated Energy System (EHAM-IES), this paper proposes a novel two-layer optimization method based on data-model fusion. In the lower layer, an improved vertex search algorithm is adopted to efficiently solve high-dimensional safety domains. In the upper layer, a Safety-Economy collaborative optimization model is established. To resolve the online computation bottleneck, an improved hybrid deep learning model is innovatively employed to achieve accurate mapping from operating states to safety domains. Subsequently, based on the rapidly computable safety domain indicators of the EHAM-IES obtained from the lower layer, the upper layer performs optimal operation for the Safety-Economy of the distribution network system, thus ensuring the safe and economical operation of the integrated energy system.

title: The Computational Kosmoplex: A Principia for Engineers in the Age of AI
authors: Christian Macedonia
publish: Computer
abstract: This article introduces the Codex Kosmoplex, a book containing the theoretical framework proposing that the physics of our reality operates as a recursive, 8D computational structure governed by discrete, well-recognized mathematical rules.

title: Synergistic Automation of Helpdesk Incident Management in Supply Chain Platforms via Contextual Vector Retrieval
authors: Hari Prasath Jothiswaran
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: A new method to automate helpdesk incident handling on a supply chain platform is proposed. We use a context vector retrieval-based technique to achieve high accuracy and timely resolution. The system uses a vector database with LLM. This LLM dynamically accesses new information rather than statically adapted. This project uses a RAG model specific to the logistics and procurement problems in the supply chain and not a general RAG. An examination of a real-life incident shows the extent to which resolution efficiency, throughput and cost efficiency have improved, offering insights for the best supporting interventions in complex logistics scenarios.

title: A Comprehensive Review on Multilevel PFC Rectifier Topologies for EV Applications
authors: Pothumahanty Sai Jyothi, Naresh Patnana
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: With the growing emphasis on high-efficiency and compact power conversion systems for electric vehicle (EV) charging and renewable energy integration, multilevel rectifiers (MLRs) have emerged as viable solutions for achieving power factor correction (PFC) and high-quality AC-DC conversion. This review paper provides a comprehensive comparative analysis of the Switched-Capacitor Multilevel Rectifier (SCMLR) against six established MLR topologies. The comparison is based on key performance indicators including switch count, passive component utilization, voltage gain, control complexity, modularity, and output power quality (THD, power factor). This review establishes SCMLR as a promising next-generation MLR topology for medium & highpower applications, particularly in the domains of EV fast charging and distributed power conversion.

title: A Prediction Method for Lithium Battery Charging and Discharging Curves based on the Battery Physical Model
authors: Wu Zhongben, Zhang Guogang, Wu Qirong, Lin Chuanqi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: In this paper, A physics-based model methodology for predicting lithium-ion battery charge/discharge profiles was proposed. Given the critical importance yet inherent challenges of charge/discharge curve prediction—such as the limited physical interpretability and high training complexity associated with neural network approaches—we adopt a physics-based battery modeling strategy. The PyBaMM battery modeling platform was employed in this study, integrated with optimization algorithms and regression techniques to formulate a prediction methodology that maintains high accuracy (0.25% MAPE as validated on experimental datasets) while operating at relatively low computational cost. This approach endows the prediction framework with greater physical interpretability compared to neural network methods, and at the same time effectively reduces the computational complexity in contrast to traditional physical model methods.

title: Blockchain-Federated Learning Framework for Secure and Privacy-Aware IoT-Enabled Wireless Sensor Networks in Smart Cities
authors: S. Vijayarangam, Shanker Aleti, N. Noor Alleema, P. Mano Paul, Meena Sachdeva, Bhagyashri Sunil Deshpande
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The ability to efficiently monitor, gather data from, and communicate across urban infrastructures is made possible by WSN, which are essential to Smart Cities. Problems with data quality, security, and decentralised learning arise from the vast amounts of sensor data. In response to these issues, it provides BlockFLA, a FL hybrid architecture that incorporates blockchain technology. Data cleansing, removal of unnecessary information, and normalisation are all part of the system's first data preparation procedure, which is designed to guarantee high-quality inputs. By eliminating the need to share raw data, FL enables distributed and decentralised model training among sensor nodes, protecting user privacy. Smart contracts on the blockchain can identify and punish bad actors automatically, making the network more trustworthy. Results from experiments demonstrate that BlockFLA improves resilience and dependability without sacrificing the communication efficiency that is typical of classic FL systems. Our experimental findings show that the suggested model outperforms similar frameworks, reaching an impressive accuracy rate of 97.53%. Finally, a safe, scalable, and effective way for smart data processing in Smart Cities is to combine FL with blockchain in WSNs. By improving distributed learning performance and fortifying urban sensor networks generally, BlockFLA is a game-changer.

title: A Review and Comparison of Virtual Impedance and Virtual Frame Method in Microgrid Systems
authors: J. Venumadhav, D. Rajababu, Dm Vinod Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Traditional microgrid control techniques are challenged to provide stable power sharing and frequency, especially in islanded mode. The primary issues are the inefficiency of traditional droop control methods in decoupling active and reactive power, as well as voltage regulation, caused by feeder impedance mismatches and low X/R ratios. Additionally, the absence of inherent inertia in inverter-based microgrids renders them highly sensitive to frequency fluctuations and transient disturbances. To overcome these issues, an overall solution is needed to enhance power decoupling, improve voltage control, and ensure a smooth transition between various microgrid operating modes. The Virtual Power Source (VPS)-based Virtual Impedance Control proves to be the best solution with a virtual power source combined with composite virtual impedance (negative resistance and inductance) to counteract impedance of feeder mismatches and realize accurate reactive power(Q) sharing and improved stability of the system. Incorporating this technique with the Virtual Frame Method also further improves voltage and frequency control, allowing seamless transitions in islanded modes. Virtual impedance control with VPS and the virtual frame method provides a better approach to overcoming the limitations of conventional microgrids, yielding stable, efficient, and strong microgrid operations. MATLAB-2024b Simulink programming is used to get voltage and frequency response for decentralised microgrid systems with the control strategy of the virtual impedance method and direct and quadrature voltage ($V_{d} \& V_{q}$) and frequency(f) response for the virtual frame method.

title: The Impact of Influencer Marketing on Brand Authenticity in Digital Campaigns
authors: Harshit Tiwari, Neha Sharma, G. Premananthan, S. Usha, Kuchkarov Bakhodir Abdullajonovich, Yogapriya J
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Influencer marketing has become an essential block of online campaigns with the rapid development of social media. Nevertheless, brands are facing the current challenge of influencer marketing: it must be authentic, and the audience should be genuinely interested, since traditional indicators of power - such as followers, likes, and shallow interest - cannot possibly differentiate between actual impact and artificially promoted popularity. A disconnect between influencers and the brand, fake communication via bots, and distrust in the content result in wasted marketing resources and, in most cases, the loss of brand loyalty. We suggest an AI-based Influencer Analytics framework as a possible solution that can be implemented using multi-source social media data, natural language processing, sentiment analysis, network analytics, and machine learning to determine and test the authenticity of influencers. The system includes posts and comments, patterns of interaction, and demographics of the audience. It applies sophisticated NLP algorithms to examine the relationship between the sentiment of a post or comment and brand values, as well as the engagement relevance of the post or comment. Graph analysis can be used to identify genuine follower groups and differentiate genuine from spurious interactions. At the same time, machine learning algorithms such as Random Forest and XGBoost can be used to evaluate campaign performance based on the determined Influencer Authenticity Index (IAI). This is a weight-based metric that considers credibility, depth of engagement, and consistency. It can automatically detect suspicious behaviour through its detection systems, thereby avoiding potential brand risk. The relevance of the suggested framework, as demonstrated by the positive outcomes of the simulation studies using real data found on Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube, lies in the fact that the actual influence of an influencer can be predicted at 87 per cent, which is considerably better than baselines that are based on superficial analysis of engagement indicators. The technology-based solution will help brands simplify influencer identification, enhance trustworthiness, and achieve the highest possible ROI by providing actionable, real-time data on an influencer's campaign credibility and effectiveness. Overall, the framework presents a data-driven, scalable process that turns influencer marketing into something objective rather than subjective, so that digital campaigns do not lose their authenticity and, on the contrary, offer new, even greater, levels of engagement.

title: Performance Analysis of Cluster-Based Routing Protocols under Propagation and Mobility Variants in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Ritika Kaushik, Akshika Jain, Gunjan, Mansi Jhamb, Ajay K Sharma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Energy-efficient routing protocols in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are important for extending the network lifetime because of the limited energy resources of sensor nodes. This paper presents a systematic analysis of several energy models, including the First-Order Radio Energy Model, the Free Space Path Loss Model, and the Two-Ray Ground Reflection Model. We have taken static and mobile sink scenarios where the static sink is placed at different locations, while the mobile sink moves with random and grid mobility. The key performance indicators of First Node Dead (FND) and Last Node Dead (LND) are analyzed for network stability and lifetime. The simulations consistently show that DCREA is superior to LEACH in all scenarios, in terms of both energy efficiency and network longevity. Performance improvements showed the greatest advantages for mobile sink scenarios and under truly representative propagation models like Two-Ray Ground Reflection. Most importantly, these results advocate DCREA as a valid contender for any real-world WSN applications that share a critical requirement on energy conservation under mobility of sink for a long-term lifetime.

title: Improved Plant Disease Recognition Using MobileNet and Regularization Techniques
authors: Deepika Kumar, Puneet Kumar, Nitika Bansal, Khushbu
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Plant health is one of the major agricultural concerns, as crops form the backbone of food security, economic stability, and environmental sustainability. Like humans, plants get affected by a suite of diseases caused by bacteria, fungi, or viruses. An adequate and timely diagnosis of disease can avoid massive crop losses and stimulate agricultural production. In the study, an advanced deep learning-based approach using leaf images of plants is suggested for disease detection. Architecturally, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based model is implemented since it is best suited for image classification, and also enables one to extract strong representation features. Moreover, Image augmentation techniques are employed to enlarge the dataset, to improve the robustness of the model, and to reduce the problem of data scarcity. Additionally, the different architectures and parameters were tested. From all the models tested, the one with the best results was the MobileNetV2 model, which applies transfer learning, L2 regularization, and dropout with LeakyReLU activation function. These methods helped reduce overfitting and improve generalization performance. The model, equipped with the capability of detecting several plant diseases with very high accuracy, would thus pave the way toward smart real-time plant health monitoring systems in precision agriculture.

title: Robust and Transparent IoT Anomaly Detection via Feature Selection and Explainable Machine Learning
authors: Sanzida Sultana Rupai, Tamim Hasan Saykat, Seendid Saleh Kabir, Md Abu Rafe Ruman, Apurbo Roy Chowdhury
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: Growing popularity of Internet of Things (IoT) and Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices has brought to the rise of major security issues as these systems that are interconnected are at risk. Anomaly detection plays an important role in safeguarding IoT networks against the diverse cyber threats, such as spoofing and data alteration attack. The proposed study introduces a complete model of machine learning of multi-class anomaly detection on the dataset WUSTL-EHMS-2020. This is done using a methodology that involves intensive preprocessing and feature selection of the data along Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) to overcome the imbalance in the classes. Several different classifiers have been tested, and XGBoost has performed the best as it reached an accuracy of 99.96%, F1-score 0.9998 and Cohen Kappa 0.9997. The model also has good computational performance, it took 3.7-second training and 0.068 seconds to infer a single sample. In order to improve transparency and trust in the selective decisions made by the model, explainable AI approaches like SHAP and permutation importance were used. The suggested idea has a very good trade-off between accuracy, interpretability and computational cost, which makes it highly applicable to implement in the drastically constrained IoT systems.

title: An Efficient IoT Security Prediction Framework
authors: Priyanshu Sinha, Shiv Prakash, Sudhanshu Kumar Jha, Tarun Kumar Gupta, Rajkumar Singh Rathore, Sohan Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is widely used in modern industrial applications due to its inherent capability of transferring data without human intervention. A Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) is the central part and plays an important role in IoT. These are widely used in complex applications in which various security attacks are encountered to prevent and countermeasure the problems in WSN, such as data processing, analysis, and efficient utilization of network resources. To ensure secure data processing, techniques are proposed to protect data privacy. Therefore, we propose a novel data-driven model using the benchmark NSL-KDD dataset based on a randomized tree, which improves the performance of WSNs. The performance analysis of the proposed model has been analyzed by using different metrics, e.g., RMSE, MSE, MAE, R-Squared, training time, model size, and prediction speed. The results obtained in the experiments depict that the proposed model effectively performs better than other contemporary models in the state of the art in case of different errors such as RMSE, MSE, MAE, R-Squared, etc.

title: Dispatch of Electricity-Hydrogen-Ammonia-Methanol Integrated Energy System Based on Constrained Diffusion Actor-Critic with Entropy Regulator
authors: Dandan Li, Xiqiao Lin, Juan Chen, Huiling Qin, Guoxian Luo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Hydrogen energy, distinguished by its operational flexibility, extended storage duration, and potential for producing high-value chemicals, is poised to underpin future power systems and enhance renewable energy integration. However, the large scale and complex variables of the Electricity-Hydrogen-Ammonia-Methanol Integrated Energy System (EHAM-IES) make traditional methods inapplicable. To address this issue, this study proposes an EHAM-IES dispatch method based on the Constrained Diffusion Actor-Critic with Entropy Regulator (CDACER). This method takes the inverse process of the diffusion model as a policy function—leveraging the model’s capability to fit multimodal distributions to enhance policy expressiveness. It also reconstructs the optimal dispatch model into a Constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP) and embeds Lagrange multipliers into the reward function (with constraints modeled as an opposing cost network) to improve the satisfaction of operational constraints. The method’s effectiveness is verified on the HRP-38 Bus Test System.
