title: Transfer learning with U-Swin transformer for adaptive ground roll attenuation in seismic records from Sabkha environments
authors: Ahmed Eleslambouly, Guibin Zhao, Fateh Bouchaala, Mohammed Y. Ali, Jun Matsushima
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Ground roll is a dominant coherent noise in land seismic data, characterized by low frequency, low velocity, and high amplitude. often overlaps with reflection arrivals, thereby reducing the reliability of seismic imaging and interpretation. Existing deep learning approaches exhibit inherent limitations in ground-roll attenuation, since Convolutional Neural Network-based models are constrained by local receptive fields, while standard Transformer architectures require large training datasets and incur substantial computational and memory costs due to their global self-attention mechanism. In this study, we propose a U-shaped Swin Transformer (U-Swin Transformer) for ground-roll attenuation. The proposed model replaces global self-attention with window-based self-attention, achieving linear computational complexity with respect to the input size and thereby significantly improving efficiency and scalability. Two near-surface field datasets acquired from the inland sabkha of Jayb Uwayyid (SJUW) in the Saudi Kingdom and the coastal sabkha of Abu Dhabi (CSAD) are used to evaluate the method under realistic geological conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed U-Swin Transformer effectively handles aliased ground roll and signal-noise overlap, which remain challenging for the U-shaped neural network (U-Net) and F-K filtering. Although the denoising performance of the U-Swin Transformer is comparable to that of the Vision Transformer (ViT) with similar mean absolute error, peak signal-to-noise ratio, and structural similarity index measure, it achieves this performance with significantly lower computational cost and GPU memory consumption. Furthermore, incorporating a transfer learning strategy enables efficient adaptation of the U-Swin Transformer across different sabkha seismic environments, substantially reducing training time compared to training the model from scratch.

title: Solving Multi-Depots Pickup and Delivery Problem Based on Heterogeneous Collaborative Multi-Attention Mechanism
authors: Yahui Lu, Anqi Li, Chunyan Song, Zhengping Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: As the complexity of logistics scenarios continues to increase, numerous new challenges have emerged. In multi-depots pickup and delivery path planning (MDPDP) scenario, these challenges include cross-depot resource coordination, spatio-temporal dependencies of pickup-delivery pairs, and generalization across problem scales. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning framework with a Heterogeneous Collaborative Multi-Attention (HCMA) mechanism. The HCMA framework has three key features. 1) HCMA comprises a three-level heterogeneous attention architecture: an inter-depot collaborative attention module for cross-depot resource allocation, a pickup-delivery pairing attention module that explicitly learns sequential and pairwise relationships between task nodes, and a global attention module to capture long-range node dependencies. 2) HCMA dynamically integrates real-time vehicle status with multi-type node features through attention weighting to balance vehicle resource utilization across depots. 3) HCMA adopts multi-start training and instance augmentation strategies to enhance generalization capability and obtain the global optimal solution. Extensive experiments conducted on random datasets, benchmark datasets, and a real-world Shenzhen logistics dataset demonstrate that the proposed HCMA method outperforms state-of-the-art heuristic algorithms and deep reinforcement learning baselines, while exhibiting superior generalization capability. The source code is publicly available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/CIA-SZU/LAQ</uri>

title: Flying in Clutter on Monocular RGB by Learning in 3D Radiance Fields with Domain Adaptation_supp1-3666383.mp4
authors: Fei Gao
publish: N/A
abstract: Modern autonomous navigation systems predominantly rely on lidar and depth cameras. However, a fundamental question remains: Can flying robots navigate in clutter using solely monocular RGB images? Given the prohibitive costs of real-world data collection, learning policies in simulation offers a promising path. Yet, deploying such policies directly in the physical world is hindered by the significant sim-to-real perception gap. Thus, we propose a framework that couples the photorealism of 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) environments with Adversarial Domain Adaptation. By training in high-fidelity simulation while explicitly minimizing feature discrepancy, our method ensures the policy relies on domain-invariant cues. Experimental results demonstrate that our policy achieves robust zero-shot transfer to the physical world, enabling safe and agile flight in unstructured environments with varying illumination.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Generalization for Pre-trained GNNs via Prompt Learning
authors: Zhenmeng Zuo, Changsheng Li, Mingkui Tan, Xing Gong, Ye Yuan, Guoren Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Graph out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization enables Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to perform robustly in applications when confronted with new environments not encountered during training. For better realization of OOD generalization, current methods are increasingly focused on designing more complex causal inference models training from scratch, without considering the potential of existing pre-trained models, increased computational complexity. In this paper, we propose an efficient framework (EGOG), which uses prompt learning for pre-trained GNNs to extract causal subgraphs from input graph data, for enhancing the generalization ability of the pre-trained GNNs. Specifically, we design a graph causal prompt module to enhance the generalization ability of the pre-trained GNNs. First, we use graph prompt learning with a causal features generator that enables pre-trained GNNs to decouple causal features from spurious features in graph nodes. Then, considering that the structure of graph is also affected by distribution shift, we further design a causal structure generator, which reuses the pre-trained GNNs to analyze graph’s structure, decoupling causal substructures from spurious substructures. This approach enhances the pre-trained GNN’s ability to decouple causal subgraph from both the node and structure perspectives. Meantime, we employ gradient reversal layers and information bottleneck to encourage our method to more accurately disentangle causal subgraph from spurious subgraph. Experiment results show that EGOG can be applied to pre-trained GNNs to enable generalization ability. Compared with the state-of-the-art baseline, EGOG shows an average relative improvement of 2.73% on two synthetic datasets while using only average 4.38% of the trainable parameters.

title: Dual Representations and $H_{\infty }$-Optimal Control of Partial Differential Equations
authors: Sachin Shivakumar, Amritam Das, Matthew Peet
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: We consider <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula>-optimal state-feedback control of the class of linear Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) which admit a Partial Integral Equation (PIE) representation. While linear matrix inequalities are commonly used for optimal control of Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs), the absence of a universal state-space representation and suitable dual form prevents such methods from being applied to optimal control of PDEs. Specifically, for ODEs, the controller synthesis problem is defined in state-space, and duality is used to resolve the bilinearity of that synthesis problem. Recently, the PIE representation was proposed as a universal state-space representation for linear PDE systems. In this paper, we show that any PDE system represented by a PIE admits a dual PIE with identical stability and I/O properties. This result allows us to reformulate the stabilizing and optimal state-feedback control problems as convex optimization over the cone of positive Partial Integral (PI) operators. Operator inversion formulae then allow us to construct feedback gains for the original PDE system. The results are verified through application to several canonical problems in optimal control of PDEs and indicate the resulting bounds on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> norm are not conservative.

title: IEEE Collabratec
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE BITS the Information Theory Magazine

title: Radiation Total Dose for PRIMA: Cold Exposure with Alpha Particles
authors: Elijah Kane, Chris Albert, Andrew Beyer, Charles Bradford, Pierre Echternach, Logan Foote, Jason Glenn, Henry LeDuc, Hien Nguyen, Thomas Stevenson, Brian Zhu, Jonas Zmuidzinas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The Probe far-Infrared Mission for Astrophysics (PRIMA) is a far-infrared (24– 261 μm wavelengths) probe class space observatory currently under Phase A study, which promises orders-of-magnitude improvement in mapping speed over its predecessors. PRIMA will field exquisitely sensitive (NEP < 0.1 aWHz−1/2) kilopixel arrays of kinetic inductance detectors (KIDs) for the Far-Infrared Enhanced Survey Spectrometer (FIRESS) instrument. PRIMA will orbit in space at the Sun Earth L2 point, where Planck found the energetic particle flux to be about 300/min/cm2 [1]. Thus, the possible effect of a high fluence of energetic particles on the detector sensitivity must be characterized. Previous work has suggested that bombardment of KIDs by ions can reduce the quasiparticle lifetime (Barends et. al. 2009 [2]), but the conditions of the experiment were not representative of a detector which is continuously held at sub-Kelvin temperatures in the energetic particle environment of L2 orbit. To better replicate the damage which would be produced by energetic particles in this environment, we developed a fully cryogenic irradiation experiment in which a stepper motor controls a screen which can block or reveal an alpha particle emitter. This setup can be used to irradiate aluminum KID arrays fabricated for FIRESS to well-controlled dose levels. In this work, we calculate the damage dose expected for a 5-year mission in L2 orbit, and we irradiate an array to approximately 62% of this level. Before and after irradiation, we measure the quasiparticle lifetimes, resonant frequencies, and quality factors of the detectors.

title: Breathing Space: Spatial Mapping of Breath and Cardiac Biofeedback for Affective State Representation and Coherence Training in Viscereality
authors: George Fejer, Till Holzapfel, Taru Hirvonen, Anestis Lalidis Mateo, Johannes Blum, Michael Gaebler, Bigna Lenggenhager
publish: Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Human-Computer Interaction in the Alps
abstract: None

title: Evolution of the CTMM model in the university context supported by AI_supp1-3666426.pdf
authors: Rene Fabian Zuniga
publish: N/A
abstract: This paper presents the evolution of the Computational Thinking Measuring Model (CTMM) within university contexts, integrating generative artificial intelligence tools as methodological support. It describes the gradual and reflective process of refining performance indicators, contextualizing them within engineering courses, and analyzing two new components: verification understood as the critical validation of responses provided by AI and ethics conceived as the reflection on the responsible use of these technologies in academic settings. The results demonstrate that the CTMM maintains its theoretical coherence and practical applicability, consolidating itself as a comprehensive instrument for evaluating computational thinking in higher education. The paper outlines the process of evolution and validation of the CTMM within university contexts, integrating generative artificial intelligence as a methodological tool to strengthen the assessment of computational thinking. The findings confirm the model’s relevance to engineering education and its capacity to promote reflective, ethical, and sustainable practices in the use of emerging technologies in educational environments.

title: Multi-Period Multi-Depot Vehicle Routing Problem for Mobile Center-based Last Mile Delivery
authors: Minseo Choi, Hyungjoo Cha, Taesu Cheong
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In response to the rapid growth of e-commerce and the resulting operational challenges in urban last mile logistics, this study introduces the Multi-period Multi-depot Vehicle Routing Problem with Mobile Center (MPMDVRP-MC). The proposed model jointly determines, over multiple periods, which candidate depot sites to activate for deploying mobile centers, how to assign customers to the activated sites, and how to construct capacity-feasible delivery routes, while allowing mobile centers to be opened, closed, and repositioned across days to respond to time-varying demand.We develop a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) formulation and a genetic algorithm-based heuristic tailored to this multi-period setting. Computational experiments on adapted Solomon benchmark instances [1] show that the heuristic matches or closely approximates MILP solutions on small instances and produces high-quality solutions on larger instances where the MILP frequently reaches the time limit or fails to prove optimality. Sensitivity analyses further reveal systematic trade-offs among travel, opening/operating, and repositioning costs, clarifying when the system behaves as a mobile, adaptive network versus a more static depot configuration. A case study using public parking-lot data from Seoul provides a proof-of-concept illustration of how repositioning can reduce travel costs under shifting demand patterns. Beyond cost efficiency, the mobile-center paradigm combined with light electric delivery modes has potential implications for reducing reliance on heavy vehicles in dense urban areas with fixed depot positions, which we discuss as a qualitative motivation.

title: In-Orbit Thruster Calibration Methods for Satellite Attitude Determination and Control
authors: Saidani Lyna Manel, Si-Mohammed Arezki Mohammed, Adnane Akram
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of in-orbit thruster calibration for satellite attitude determination by estimating the configuration matrix that relates commanded force vectors to the observed torque outputs with a linear model. The extracted matrix from Euler's dynamic equations, reflecting the actuator effectiveness, is of vital importance for ensuring accurate orientation and maneuverability of the spacecraft. A comparative study is conducted on five calibration approaches—Ordinary Least Squares (OLS), Weighted Least Squares (WLS), Instrumental Variables with Filtering (IVF), Gradient Descent (GD), and Recursive Least Squares (RLS). Each of them is tested for its performance in terms of estimation, accuracy as measured by the Frobenius norm of the residual error, computing efficiency, and running time both on ground and on-board computer (OBC). These approaches have been implemented and validated in the context of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite applications. Results indicate extreme trade-offs between speed and accuracy, where RLS is found to be a balanced option in both implementation. The findings provide actionable insights for selecting the most suitable estimation algorithm for satellite control systems under real-world constraints.

title: Dynamic Precision-Tunable Multiplier For Image Processing Applications
authors: Eleena Mohapatra, Titiksha Siva Priya K, P Narashimaraja
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Approximate multipliers enhance speed and energy efficiency by reducing area, power, and delay at the cost of minor computational inaccuracy. This study proposes an optimized 8-bit multiplier using 6:3 and 4:2 compressors to minimize partial products, integrating CSA techniques for reduced propagation delay. The design achieves significant hardware efficiency, with an error rate of 77.99%, an area footprint of 513.178 µm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and a power consumption of 76.5 µW, making it suitable for applications like image processing and low-power embedded systems. The reconfigurable compressor architecture allows scalability for higher-bit multipliers, with potential future improvements in adaptive error-tuning for optimized performance.

title: Innovative Hybrid Deep Learning for Precise Spatiotemporal Analysis of Oral Diseases
authors: Satyam Kumar, Deepjyoti Choudhury, Siddharth Kumar, Uddalak Chatterjee, Aakarsh Srivastava
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Oral disease is a serious problem that requires early and precise diagnosis for successful treatment and to avoid any serious complications. Examination of oral disease requires a lot of time, and it is solely dependent on the expertise of the examiner. To address this issue, this paper explores a novel computer assisted hybrid deep learning model that will assist in oral disease classification. A high-quality annotated oral image dataset, collected from publicly available medical databases, is used to train and test models. The deep learning hybrid models i.e. Inception v3 + GRU, DenseNet201 + GRU and InceptionResNetV2 + GRU are used for classification of oral diseases. The model uses the capability of CNNs to extract spatial feature and the learning ability of GRUs to achieve improved classification performance. The DenseNet201 + GRU model achieved an accuracy of 99.46%, and the model Inception v3 + GRU achieved an enhanced accuracy rate of 99.65%. The model InceptionResNetV2 + GRU performed with a maximum accuracy of 99.78<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>• These models have the capability of extracting complex sequential and spatial patterns in oral disease images, that creates a standard for computer aided oral disease detection. This paper proves the effectiveness by combining the capability of CNNs and GRUs for accurate, effective, and real time oral disease diagnosis that offers an effective computer aided tool for dental practitioners and healthcare professionals. This paper creates a hybrid model that provide correct and reliable diagnostics by early intervention and improved oral healthcare management.

title: Impact of Digital Human Resource Management on Organizational Efficiency from AI perspective
authors: Ayman Mustafa Al Armoti, Reema Al-Qaruty, Munther Balawi, Samer Abdel Hadi, Adnan Jawabri, Badriya Mohammed
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Digital Human resource management (DHRM) is the utilization of artificial intelligence (AI), Human resource information systems (HRIS), and digital technologies to make changes in HR practices and improve organizational efficiency. The current qualitative research examines the influence of DHRM in the UAE, using the insights gained from semi-structured interviews with 15 HR managers from public and private sector organizations, and is interpreted through a thematic assessment. The most significant conclusions can be found in the observed potential advantages, which include decreased recruitment complexity, improved staff interaction, data-based verdicts, and clear orientation direction. However, some disadvantages have also been identified, including concerns over data privacy, technological dependence, and implementation expenses. The given study provides a solid foundation for understanding the role of AI in HR transformation, with prospective practice and research implications (involving a more significant sample or mixed approaches). Nevertheless, the results demonstrate the potential of DHRM to streamline HR capacity and organizational performance despite specific contextual constraints.

title: Privacy-enhanced and Time-efficient Human Activity Recognition using Decentralized Federated Learning
authors: Arnab Chakraborty, Anwesha Mukherjee, Sanghita Bhattacharjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Conventional human activity recognition approaches have several limitations, including security and privacy issues related to user data and high response times due to remote storage and processing. To address these challenges of the existing approaches, this paper proposes a decentralized federated learning-based framework for human activity recognition. In the proposed framework, both the ring and mesh topologies are considered for collaboration among the participating nodes. To enhance the security and privacy of conventional federated learning, the proposed framework encrypts model weights during transmission among the collaborating nodes. We have used an Internet of Things (IoT)-edge-cloud paradigm, where smartphone sensors are used to collect data. The collected data are analyzed using the proposed framework, and the results show that ≥80% accuracy is achieved for our dataset and existing well-known datasets. The experimental results also demonstrate that the proposed framework has lower response time compared to the edge-cloud and cloud-only frameworks.

title: Perceiving Generative AI in Teacher Practice: A Design-Based Case Study in a Graduate Course
authors: Michael Pin-Chuan Lin, Fuhua Lin, Yu-Feng Lan, Jeeho Ryoo
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study presents a design-based case study examining how in-service teachers enrolled in a graduate educational technology course perceive and engage with Generative AI (GAI) tools, such as ChatGPT. As part of a structured course activity, participants incorporated GAI into lesson planning tasks and reflected on its pedagogical usefulness. Two participants completed a post-course survey consisting of Likert-scale and open-ended questions. Results indicate that both educators recognized benefits such as enhanced creativity and planning efficiency, while also expressing concerns about information reliability, ethical boundaries, and over-reliance. The findings highlight variability in teacher engagement based on prior AI experience and emphasize the need for scaffolding, critical reflection, and ethical guidance in AI integration. The study underscores the importance of providing early orientation, scaffolded design tasks, and space for structured dialogue around ethics and pedagogical judgment when integrating GAI in teacher education. Situated within the broader discourse on AI in education, this case study contributes to the literature by offering a context-specific account of how educators explore and make sense of GAI during authentic planning tasks. Design recommendations are proposed for future course iterations and for supporting professional learning environments more broadly.

title: A Review on Disease Prediction in Plants and Fertilizer Recommendation Using CNN & LSTM
authors: Amit Kumar Jaiswal, Syed Hauider Abbas, Binod Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Soil-borne or foliar diseases are frequently observed that affect agricultural productivity potentially causing severe economic loss and issues related to the food security. We survey the current research trends, datasets, evaluation metrics, challenges, and potential future directions in this area. Early disease diagnosis and fertilizer recommendation have been promising tasks due to Deep learning techniques like Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM). This paper provides a comprehensive overview of recent methods using CNN with LSTM for plant disease prediction and fertilizer recommendation. The deep learning algorithm used in research to develop a Deep Learning Model for the classification of Healthy leaf images Early Blight and Late Blight disease of Plant (Potato) and foliar diseases in Apple.

title: Multilevel Inverters for Electric Vehicle Applications: Recent Trends and Technological Advancements
authors: J.N. Bhanutej, P.S. Raghavendra, S. Sanjana, K.Tara Sing, M. Pranay, Sundeep Siddula, Neelima Kalahasthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) are transforming world by reducing the greenhouse gas emissions by a lot, make us less dependent on fossil fuels. Power electronics are an important part of how EVs work. It controls how energy flows from the battery to the motor. In this context Inverters will play significant role to turn the DC power that batteries store into AC power which traction motors can use. Some of the challenges that classic twolevel inverters have to contend with are high switching losses, thermal stress, and limited voltage scalability. Multilevel inverters (MLIs) are a very promising technique to get reduce these difficulties. MLIs provides many advantages, including as better output waveform quality, lower Total Harmonic Distortion (THD), the ability to handle higher voltages, and better overall efficiency. All of these things are necessary for small, reliable, and strong EV power trains. This article explain about depth of alternative MLI topologies that work well for EVs, such as Neutral-Point Clamped(NPC), Flying Capacitor, and Cascaded H-bridge(CHB)designs. The study focused on recent advances in control and modulation techniques, how they could be employed in Electric Vehicle (EV) systems, and the increasing use of widebandgap semiconductor devices like Silicon Carbide (SiC) and Gallium Nitride (GaN). Lastly, Deals about the various issues that need to be fixed right away and offers some ideas for future growth.

title: Wi-Flow: Multimodal Human Action Recognition Based on Dynamic Features in WiFi CSI and Optical Flow
authors: Zheng Zhang, Junxing Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In the domain of spatial computing, WiFi devices present innovative solutions for human action recognition (HAR) and intelligent space applications due to their advantages of being contactless, device free, and minimizing privacy risks. However, HAR using channel state information (CSI) from commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) WiFi devices encounters several challenges that hinder accuracy, particularly in source and cross-domain scenarios. These challenges stem from the low resolution of COTS WiFi devices, which constrains the performance of deep feature extraction networks, environmental sensitivity induced by multipath effects, and the neglect of dynamic properties intrinsic to human action. To overcome these challenges, we propose a multimodal HAR framework named Wi-Flow. Our framework integrates the WiFi CSI based weighted phase-amplitude shift (WPAS) with pixel-level optical flow feature extracted from visual data. This fusion enables deep feature extraction and enhances the accuracy of action recognition. Using the complementary characteristics of the two modalities, Wi-Flow improves both the accuracy and the robustness of HAR. We evaluated our framework on a large-scale open source dataset collected from the real world, conducting both source-domain and cross-domain evaluations. Experimental results show that our framework achieves an action recognition accuracy that exceeds 96% and 90%, respectively.

title: Enhanced APT Attack Detection Using Convolutional Neural Networks and Deep Learning Models
authors: Ishu Sharma, Anirudh Khanna, Tanisha Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: One type of cyberattack known as Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) occurs when an unauthorized user enters a computer system without authorization and remains hidden for a long period of time. Instead of destroying the network system, they targeted extremely valuable and sensitive data to steal it. These threats are dangerous for banks, government security, and business information. This study is conducted to evaluate and comparative analysis of deep learning models to identify the best one for detecting APT attacks. Each model has different strengths, and combining them helps improve accuracy and detection. The models used for testing are LSTM, CNN,AE, and hybrid models, in which LSTMs excel at capturing long-term dependencies in data, CNNs are highly effective at analyzing spatial features, and AEs help detect anomalies by reconstructing input data. By combining these models, the system gains the strengths of all three, enhancing its ability to detect complex attack patterns. from which the AE + CNN + LSTM (hybrid) model performed best among all other models in all four metrics - Precision, Accuracy, F1-Score, and Recall. In conclude, AE + CNN + LSTM (hybrid) is the most suitable model for APT attack detection.

title: Edge Computing for Real-Time Process Optimisation in Factories
authors: Ramya M, R. Venkatasubramanian, Sumit Ramswami Punam, M. Sirin Kumari, R. Gunasundari, Karthikayen A, Saif Obayd Husayn
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The real-time optimization of the processes in the factories is critical today to overcome the challenges of the highly-speed processes, the massive volume of sensor data sent to the IoT, and to achieve very low latency of the traditional cloud-based analytics that in the vast majority of the cases is the cause of the delay in the fault detection, of the inefficient production effectiveness and the rising downtimes. Mechanical and electrical anomalies, as well as software errors, require prompt solutions; however, current centralised developments do not guarantee that time-sensitive interventions are taken at decentralised production lines. The study proposes an Edge-Integrated Hybrid Digital Twin (EI-HDT) solution to address these issues, which combines physics-based modelling of machines and processes via simulation with AI-based predictive analytics, etc., implemented on distributed edge nodes. The digital twin hybrid continuously mirrors the real-life processes, predicts the deviation, foresees the reduction of the equipment, and suggests the optimal behavior of control in real-time. This leads to the control policy implementation being a hybridized centralized-decentralized approach, where a central coordinator sets global goals, and localized decisions are made by edge nodes to achieve the goals without consultation among themselves. The federated learning FEDprox-based predictive models of heterogeneous edge devices are trained to minimize the model drift and to maintain constant the accuracy, adaptively combine models and 5G Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) in the delivery of control commands to the edge nodes and the actuators with a low degree of latency and accuracy. The system continually observes and categorizes faults as critical, moderate, and minor in severity, initiating the relevant proportionate correction actions to ensure production continuity. On heterogeneous devices, EI-HDT has been demonstrated to improve process efficiency (top 85 percent and fault response latency (by approximately 3 orders of magnitude) and predictive accuracy (high) when simulated and on experiment data. Solution can be extended and scaled and improves industry productivity, fault tolerance and Industry 4.0 and efficient channel to real-time optimization and processes in the modern smart factory.

title: Cardiovascular Disease Prediction Using SHAP-Based Feature Selection and PSO-Optimized XGBoost
authors: S. Ramchandra Reddy, G. Vishnu Murthy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is one of the essential reasons in the back of the mortality worldwide. Prevention and early diagnosis are the most effective approaches to control its development and onset. This study generates a robust, data-driven approach to enhance CVD prediction accuracy, emphasizing the synergistic benefits of Shapely Additive Explanations (SHAP)- based feature selection and Particle Swarm Optimization(PSO) enhanced XGBoost model for real-world clinical application. Our Methodology is based on extracting specific features from SHAP and PSO which is employed to optimize the Hyperparameters of the XGBoost classifier. This model outperforms various standard algorithms and methods for demonstrating a superior prediction accuracy. Our findings provide various applications and potential future directions of machine learning models integrated with SHAP for cardiovascular disease, including the discovery of significant biomarkers.

title: Comprehensive Review of Reactive Power Challenges in Distribution Systems and Advanced Mitigation Strategies
authors: Hussain Tak, Neeraj Gupta, Mairaj Ud Din Mufti
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The stability and voltage profile of transmission and distribution systems are examined in this paper in relation to the integration of renewable energy resources. To ascertain the maximum loadability limitations of both systems, we performed load flow analysis using the IEEE 14-bus model for the transmission system and the IEEE 33-bus model for the distribution system. The steady state and voltage at various load levels were analysed using the continuous load flow. By integrating PV model and wind turbine model into the transmission and distribution systems, detailed models of photovoltaic and wind turbine systems with the transmission and distribution were created. The system’s voltage status and voltage profile were improved by the active and reactive power transactions and contributions made possible by these renewable energy models. The load flow analysis was extended to systems. In order to evaluate the loadability limit and voltage stability, the continuation load flow analysis was extended to systems that were integrated with PV and wind turbine models. They show that since the system’s voltage profile is enhanced, the incorporation of renewable energy sources improves voltage stability. Additionally, we closely examined a number of reactive power mitigation techniques and addressed associated problems in transmission and distribution networks. Our thorough examination and analysis provide important new information about how well renewable energy sources may improve voltage profiles and maintain grid stability. Essentially, this increases the power system’s dependability while simultaneously fostering future resilience.

title: Accessible Communication through Object Detection: A Deep Learning Model for Differently Abled People
authors: Manish Chaudhary, Sandesh Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The importance of communication is irrevocable. It is crucial to establish connection between humans. Given the immense importance of communication- the differently abled people often find themselves at a disadvantage- especially the deaf and mute community. This can be attributed to the lack of proficiency - o0r even knowledge- of sign language. This barrier often leads to social isolation, limited opportunities, and dependency (on interpreters). Here, we present a solution to this problem by the means of a real-time computer vision system that can translate ISL - Indian Sign Language gestures into text or speech. It will enhance the accessibility for such people. Our proposed solution utilizes a normal/regular camera set-up along with AI based object-detection models- like YOLO and SSD- to recognize hand signs. This approach is completely contactless, cheaper, and easier to scale in real-world settingswhich makes it different from previous approaches. When we tested the system on our custom ISL dataset, it was able to recognize about 85.5 % of the alphabets in real time. This work contributes to more inclusive communication technology for the hearing and speech impaired, while also paving the way for future research in multilingual and continuous gesture recognition.

title: A Systematic Review of Artificial Intelligence Applications in Alzheimer’s Disease: Advances and Research Gaps in Latin America
authors: Carlos Sánchez, Bryan Vásquez-Pineda, Nicole Velasco-Molina, Rodrigo Pinto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease poses an increasing global public health challenge, with Latin America facing particular obstacles due to limited research and available resources. This systematic review examines the current state of artificial intelligence (AI) applications in the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of Alzheimer’s disease in Latin America, assessing scientific output, technological approaches, and geographic distribution. The findings indicate that Brazil leads regional research efforts, followed by Colombia and Mexico, with a predominance of techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and EEG, combined with machine learning models like convolutional neural networks and explainable AI. Despite progress, significant gaps remain in the integration of multimodal data, longitudinal studies, and the clinical implementation of AI tools. To improve Alzheimer’s care in the region, it is essential to increase research investment, promote regional collaboration, and strengthen technical capabilities. This review highlights the urgent need to bridge these gaps and foster innovation tailored to the demographic and healthcare context of Latin America.

title: Compact Three-Stage SIW Bandpass Filter Based on Circular CSRRs for 4.7 GHz Wireless Systems
authors: Sirine Aouine Chaieb, Sabri Beldi, Neila Kammoun, Ali Gharsallah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a compact bandpass filter in SIW (Substrate Integrated Waveguide) technology based on the integration of circular CSRR (Complementary Split Ring Resonator) resonators. The study deals successively with three configurations: a single-stage topology, followed by a two-stage version and finally a threestage architecture. The operating principle is based on the utilization of evanescent modes below the cut-off frequency of the waveguide, which allows the creation of a controlled bandwidth. The filter performance is optimized by adjusting the geometry and arrangement of the CSRR resonators, which reduces unwanted modes, improves selectivity, and increases out-of-band rejection. The design and simulation were carried out using CST Microwave Studio software. The results show that the three-stage configuration achieves a bandwidth of 630 MHz (at -3 dB), extending from 4.3 GHz to 4.93 GHz, which corresponds to a fractional bandwidth of 13.4%. At the center frequency of 4.7 GHz, the return loss reaches -20 dB, while the insertion loss remains below $-\mathbf{0. 3 8 ~ d B}$. Outside the passband, the out-of-band rejection exceeds -55 dB. Furthermore, the proposed filter exhibits a 22.95% frequency miniaturization compared to a reference SIW filter operating at 6.1 GHz, highlighting its efficiency in achieving compactness without compromising performance. These features make this filter ideal for various applications, such as wireless communication systems and short-range radars.

title: A Power Transformer Condition Assessment Method Based on Multi-Source Information Fusion
authors: Yang Lu, Xing Zheng, Xinxi Yu, Zhengyu Chen, Zhen Zhong
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Power transformers are among the most critical equipment in power grids, and their operational stability directly affects the overall security of the power system. To achieve accurate condition assessment of transformers and overcome the limitations of traditional methods in handling multi-source heterogeneous data, dynamic weight adjustment and assessment uncertainty, this paper proposes a systematic methodology for transformer condition evaluation. The method begins with preprocessing of multi-source monitoring data, followed by weight determination using an improved analytic hierarchy process, state mapping through nonlinear membership functions, and information fusion based on an enhanced evidence theory. Finally, alarm signals are incorporated to derive a comprehensive condition score. This results in a complete evaluation framework that follows a data-parameter-state-score pipeline. The proposed methodology provides a valuable reference for practical transformer condition assessment.

title: Edge AI based Real -Time Classification of Underwater Target in Images using YOLO Deep Learning Algorithm
authors: Jinka Venkata Aravind, Shanthi Prince
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Underwater naval mines are extremely hazardous to battleships and submarines. Therefore, naval forces around the world use mine countermeasures to protect their borders against such threats. One of the strategies employed in mine countermeasures is mine hunting, which requires a thorough search for all mines within a potentially hazardous region. This process is often segmented into four phases: detection, classification, identification, and disposal. In recent years, there has been growing interest in using underwater computer vision for inspection and monitoring purposes. In this paper, we conducted an experiment in a pool and collected a dataset of underwater naval mine-like target using an optical camera for classification. Here, we propose an Edge AI system, including an NVIDIA AGX Xavier device, for classifying custom underwater naval mine-like targets in images using the YOLOV5 deep learning object classification algorithm. We evaluated the model’s performance by analyzing the training loss, testing loss, and accuracy for 50 and 100 epochs. The results show that, for 100 epochs, the losses are minimal and the accuracy is >90%. Additionally, we analyzed the image processing time with the Edge AI device, averaging 216.7ms and 213.8ms for batches of 8 and 16 images.

title: The Influence of Space-Time Geometrical Channel Models on Spatial Data Focusing
authors: Michael D Odhiambo, Aggrey S Shitsukane
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: The influence of geometrically based single bounce circular channel model (GBSBCM) on spatial data focusing (SDF) is investigated in this work. SDF has been presented as a potential alternative to traditional power focusing techniques in wireless geocasting, as it achieves directionality by utilizing the transmitted data itself rather than relying on radiated energy. As such its beamwidth is defined as the data coverage region, i.e., the area within which data can be decoded as opposed to the classical half-power beamwidth used in power focusing schemes. Space-time channel models are constructed from the statistics of the space-time system field function for an arbitrary channel. This statistical characterization of the channel is subsequently expressed in terms of the space-time power spectral density of the given space-time system field function. The parameters characterized include time-of-arrival and the associated delay spread, angle-of-arrival and power of multipaths components. Using GBSBCM model, the spatial selectivity capability of SDF is analyzed. It is demonstrated that SDF performance is exclusively influenced by the corresponding scattering radius R, and that the corresponding BER increases with increasing R.

title: A Novel Distribution System State Estimation Framework for Non-Gaussian Measurement Noise
authors: Md Arif, Priyanka Yadav, Kapil Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a novel Distribution System State Estimation (DSSE) framework employing a Maximum Correntropy Criterion (MCC)-based state estimator implemented through Iteratively Reweighted Least Squares (IRLS), specifically designed to handle heavy-tailed and asymmetric measurement noise. The proposed approach utilizes hybrid measurements comprising voltage phasors from Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) and power injections from Remote Terminal Units (RTUs). A systematic Monte Carlo analysis on the IEEE 33-bus system is conducted to quantify the degradation of the conventional Weighted Least Squares (WLS) estimator under Gaussian, Laplace, Exponential, and Mixed Gaussian noise conditions. Results reveal that WLS error variance increases by 26 %, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 1 \%}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{6 4 \%}$</tex> under Laplace, Exponential, and Mixed Gaussian (10 % outlier) noise, respectively, highlighting the need for robust alternatives. Comparative evaluation shows that the proposed MCC-based DSSE achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 5. 1}-\text{4 1. 9 \%}$</tex> reduction in estimation error relative to WLS, with the largest improvement <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(41.9 \%)$</tex> under outlier-contaminated conditions. The method maintains computational tractability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathrm{2} \times$</tex> overhead), making it suitable for real-time deployment while substantially enhancing robustness against non-Gaussian measurement noise.

title: Variable Voltage Strategy for Minimum Current Operation in the Flux Weakeing Region of DI-WRIM Drive
authors: Cheshta Jain, Abhishek Shaw, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: The Double Inverter fed Wound Rotor Induction Machine (DI-WRIM) is a versatile topology offering independent control of stator and rotor currents for enhanced performance across a wide speed range. It is a common practice to operate at the rated voltage condition in the flux weakening region (FWR) of a drive. But this work shows that operating at the rated voltage in FWR, under light load conditions does not ensure minimum current operation. Instead, it results in higher current drawn for a given torque reference, reducing efficiency. A detailed theoretical analysis is provided, revealing that variable voltage operation in the FWR can achieve better current utilization under light loads. Simulation results support the analysis and confirm the limitations of fixed-voltage operation in FWR. This study emphasizes the importance of adapting voltage in the FWR to ensure optimal performance and highlights the need to revisit conventional assumptions about the rated voltage operation in FWR.

title: Adaptive Edge AI Orchestrator for Real Time Data Analysis and Process Control in Manufacturing Lines
authors: Jansirani D, Hasan Muhammed Alii, Jyotsna Dwivedi, Makhkamova Husnida Ruziboevna, M R Manikantha, S. Balambigai, O.T. Tojiboeva
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The Industry 4.0 has exposed the manufacturing and transportation lines to large volumes of sensor and machine data, which needs to be processed real time. Nevertheless, the legacy manufacturing models continue to be plagued by the major issues of latency, bandwidth limitations, and the dangers of transferring sensitive manufacturing information to centralized clouds. These restrictions inhibit fast detection of anomalies, responsive actions to the process variations and resource optimization within the factory floor. As such, manufacturers suffer unjustified downtimes, energy wastages, and high cost of operation. To overcome these issues, this paper presents the Adaptive Edge-AI Orchestrator (AEO)-a distributed, edge-intelligent platform that is intended to be used in smart manufacturing to do real-time analytics and dynamic process control. Each edge node presents AEO as modular and containerized microservices with which low-latency inference is made possible, as well as workflow optimization with reinforcement learning, and the deployment of AI modules with no interruptions to production. Most prominently, AEO presents a peer-to-peer collaborative learning framework that is decentralized, in which edge nodes share learned knowledge instead of raw data, which guarantees privacy of data, generalization of models and continuous learning. AEO can be used to coordinate nearly in real-time through 5G-enabled mesh connectivity, thus decreasing the time response to anomalies, improving the product quality, and decreasing energy usage. It is also designed in a modular manner that enables it to integrate easily into the existing manufacturing infrastructures. In general, it can be stated that AEO is a paradigm shift in intelligent manufacturing-adaptive control, scalability, and real-time decision-making are being made available at the edge.

title: Towards Efficient Power Control in Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles with Braking Energy Recovery
authors: Kumari Archana, Madhu Singh, Simanta Kumar Samal
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The increase in the amount of traffic on vehicles has contributed to more pollution, and this has made fuel cells gain more significance. Fuel cells are very efficient, noiseless and pollution-free. An inverter will be able to supply power to AC loads even when the conditions are low-light/cold. Nevertheless, to be able to provide the appropriate voltage that such applications use, stepping up has to be enabled to reach such voltages. The effective boosting of a voltage must start with a step-up converter that has a wide range of input voltage and low stress on components. This paper presents a converter topology to use in the application of an electric vehicle. The paper also explores the use of electric vehicle regenerative brakes and rechargeable batteries in increasing the range of vehicles and sudden high energy requirements.

title: IoT and AI for Real-Time Monitoring in Substation Automation
authors: R. Sivanand, D. Pravin Kumar, Kushvanth Chowdary Nagabhyru, Eswara Prasath Natarajan, Vamsee Pamisetty, Dhiraj Kapila
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Advancing substation automation to a complete transformation through the implementation of real-time data analytics and intelligent sensing technologies combined. The paper reports a novel substation architecture using the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) for in-time monitoring and predictive fault diagnosis. The architecture has the following five layers that communicate with each other: IoT based sensing, Edge Preprocessing, Secure Communication, AI based cloud analytics and Interactive visualization and alerting. Experiments carried out with a laboratory substation prototype showed an over 92 % match rate in detection of various fault types and alert generation within 2 s. IEC 61850 protocol integration makes it possible to work with the SCADA of today, and modular design allows users to deploy at scale across the Distributed Energy Environment. Results from this study reveal a promising pathway to the deployment of next-generation substation monitoring systems with improved performance and intelligence via integrating IoT and AI.

title: Twitter Sentiment Mining for Marketing Decision-Making in Blockchain-Based Digital Assets
authors: Janjhyam Venkata Naga Ramesh, Vivek Veeraiah, Debshree Bhattacharya, Vipin Jain, Sanjiv Kumar Jain, Ankur Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Marketers who want to connect with very active and emotion-driven communities are facing both opportunities and problems because blockchain-based digital assets are growing so quickly. This study examines the function of Twitter sentiment analysis in informing marketing strategies within the blockchain ecosystem. Tweets about digital assets were gathered, cleaned up, and sorted into positive, negative, and neutral feelings using NLP and machine learning. The results show that positive sentiment is mostly caused by new ideas, new uses, and excitement about events like NFT launches. On the other hand, negative sentiment is linked to scams, price swings, regulatory uncertainty, and a lack of trust. Charts showing how people's feelings are spread out and word clouds show the common themes that shape how people feel. The study focuses on the marketing effects of making changes to campaigns in real time, using influencers to reach out to people, building trust, and promoting events. This study adds to both academia and industry by showing how sentiment analysis can help marketers make decisions that are in line with what the community wants and lower risks.

title: UniRisk-PCa: A Federated Self-Training Multimodal Spatio-Radiomic Network for the Prediction of Prostate Cancer Risk
authors: Manish Chahar, D. Vetrithangam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: UniRisk-PCa, a novel prostate cancer risk prediction model combining Multiparametric Magnetic Resonance Imaging(mpMRI), radiomic features, clinical variables and genomic data into a federated learning framework with Self-Supervised Pretraining. Due to the scarcity of data, privacy issues, and multiinstitutional collaboration challenges, UniRisk-PCa extract detailed feature representations from unlabeled MRI data and combines complementary multimodal information for accurate risk classification. Comparative evaluation against baseline methods demonstrates superior performance, achieving an accuracy of 95.5%, precision of 95.0%, recall of 96.0%, F1-score of 95.5%, and an AUC of 0.96. The model exhibits balanced sensitivity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(96.2 \%)$</tex> and specificity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(94.8 \%)$</tex>, minimizing false positives and negatives critical for clinical decision-making. Interpretability techniques such as SHapley Additive exPlanations(SHAP) and Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping(Grad-CAM) explain feature importance and areas of images that influence the predictions so that the process remains transparent and interpretable by clinicians. The promising results confirm that UniRisk-PCa is a scalable, privacy-preserving, and clinically reliable tool for personalized prostate cancer diagnosis and prognosis. Future work will focus on prospective validation, inclusion of more modalities of data, and implementation in realworld clinical settings to improve early detection and patient management further.

title: Multiagent Reinforcement Learning for Coordinated Cyber Defense Against Advanced Persistent Threats
authors: Manjot Kaur Sidhu, Navjot Kaur, Gurleen Kaur, Om Prakash Aditya, Gurpartap Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) as in the case of APT28 attack network security through multistage attacks, including phishing, lateral movement, and data exfiltration, which are covert. This paper will hypothesize a multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) system to coordinate resilient cyber defense in dynamic network settings. The CybORG is a collaboration of autonomous agents that specialize in analysis of traffic, monitoring endpoints and coordinating response to optimize realtime defense strategy. The framework uses MultiAgent Proximal Policy Optimization (MAPPO) and centralized training and decentralized executions, which result in adaptive and scalable responses. The system is tested in a series of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 h o s t}$</tex> CybORG simulated on APT28inspired tactics (e.g., T1078, T1021) and evaluated against singleagent Deep QNetwork (DQN) and rulebased intrusion detection systems (IDS) such as Snort on five metrics: detection rate, false positive rate, compromised hosts, response time, and energy consumption. This shows that the results showed 92.3 percent detection rate, 25 percent decrease in compromised hosts, 30 percent quicker response time, and 15 percent lesser power consumption than baselines. The architecture of the framework is decentralized, and the 8bit communication protocols are efficient, which helps to improve the scalability of the framework and overcome the constraints of the static and centralized defenses. It is a pioneering work on MARL-based APT defense solution, which is demonstrated to be the most effective based on large-scale simulation, and can be applied to protect enterprise networks, IoT, and 6G systems. Future directions: Realworld dataset validation and hybrid defence strategies Future directions: The framework is a scalable solution to nextgeneration cybersecurity issues.

title: Analytical Model for the Early Detection of Undersea Seismic Activity – A Tsunami Precursor
authors: Girish Kumar Tiwari, Staley Arya
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Several studies have demonstrated that, before the abrupt release of seismic energy from the Earth’s crust, weak electromagnetic (EM) emissions in the ultra-low frequency (ULF) and very-low frequency (VLF) ranges are generated due to the compression and fracturing of rocks in tectonically active regions. Within the framework of marine seismology, such EM emissions can perturb the electrical properties of the marine environment, leading to subtle variations in the conductivity of seawater in proximity to the seabed that may serve as reliable earthquake precursors. In this work, a mathematical model is developed to quantitatively investigate the variations in seawater conductivity and salinity associated with seismic processes, with salinity evaluated using the Practical Salinity Scale (PSS-78). The proposed model will provide a framework for the early detection of seismic events with the potential to generate tsunamis, thereby contributing to improved hazard assessment and early-warning systems.

title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning Approaches for Stroke Classification Using Multi-Muscle Upper Limb EMG Features Across Functional Reaching Tasks
authors: Krishna B Raj, Mohamed Shahid P.A., Sanjay M, A. P. Sudheer, Shehadad Kammili, Sreejith Kalathummarath
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Stroke often results in upper limb motor impairments, necessitating reliable diagnostic tools for clinical and rehabilitation applications. This study presents a comprehensive framework for classifying stroke and healthy individuals using surface electromyography (sEMG) signals recorded from eight upper arm muscles during nine reaching tasks. A total of thirty seven features spanning time, frequency, statistical, and non-linear domains were extracted and ranked using statistical significance testing. Nine machine learning classifiers, including SVM, Random Forest, kNN, Logistic Regression, LDA, AdaBoost, RUSBoost, and Naïve Bayes were evaluated. Along with machine learning classifiers, a deep learning LSTM model was also assessed. Results showed that ensemble and non-linear classifiers outperformed linear models, with ensemble methods achieving 80% accuracy and AUC 0.88. Notably, the LSTM model achieved the highest performance with 90% accuracy, demonstrating its ability to capture temporal dependencies and inter-muscle coordination. These findings highlight the potential of sEMG-based classification, particularly deep learning, for objective stroke assessment and its integration into clinical decision support and rehabilitation systems.

title: Cyber Risk Prediction and Management Using Random Forest-Based Risk Scoring Models
authors: Baba Shaheer Gutappa, Usman Javed Butt, M. Ali Akber Dewan
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The increasing relevance and number of sophisticated cyber threats are creating the need for the development of intelligent and robust systems for risk prediction and management. The paper introduces an elaborate framework for cyber risk assessment and mitigation through Random Forest risk scoring models. In their research, the authors used a Random Forest classifier to train the model with past cyber incidents' data and system attributes. This approach enabled the model to effectively recognize and predict cyber risks. The system applies risk scores to the various system parts, which greatly simplifies the identification of vulnerabilities. Feature selection is executed to point out the attributes of the most influence on cyber risk and make the model more transparent and efficient. The system also introduces a dynamic risk management module to adapt to changing threat landscapes by keeping the model up to date with new data. Our experimental results demonstrate robust performance with 94.8% accuracy, 92.3% precision, and 93.7% recall, proving the system's effectiveness and reliability in real-world cybersecurity environments. The paper presents as follows: one of the priority points is the inclusion in the machine-learning-based scoring method for the quantification of cyber risks, a feature-optimized Random Forest classifier for risk prediction and a feedback-based mechanism of risk model updating. This framework grants organizations a mechanism for the early detection of risks, cybersecurity decision-making, and finally, the safety of the data.

title: Low-SAR MIMO Antenna with High-Isolation High-Efficiency for Smartphones
authors: Si-Xin Dong, Qing-Xin Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: In this article, a four-element MIMO antenna for metal frames is designed based on a loop antenna. The antenna exhibits a wide operational bandwidth, which can cover 3.23.8 GHz, with the isolation of each port higher than 20 dB. Measured results demonstrate that the antenna maintains a radiation efficiency over $70 \% \mathrm{Sub}-6 \mathrm{G}(3.4-3.6 \mathrm{GHz})$ frequency band. The antenna exhibits a measured normalized SAR value less than $1.14 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{kg}$ under single-port excitation and a low MIMO-SAR less than $0.2 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{kg}$ during multi-port operation. The proposed antenna achieves the characteristics of high isolation, high efficiency, and low SAR simultaneously.

title: Robust Normal-Gamma Distribution Based Kalman Filter For MEMS/UWB Indoor Localization in the NLOS Scenario
authors: Guangle Jia, Xingshi Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In this paper, a robust Kalman filter based on the Normal-Gamma (NG) distribution is proposed for loosely coupled MEMS/UWB indoor localization in the non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenario. The heavy-tailed distributed measurement noise, which is induced by the NLOS errors. The parameters of the proposed robust Kalman filter are inferred by the conjugate property of NG distribution without fixed-point iterations. Experiment demonstrates that the proposed method has smaller localization errors and faster operation speed than existing cutting-edge robust Kalman filters in the NLOS scenario.

title: Reconstructing CT Scan Images with SADNN: A Promising Approach for Medical Imaging
authors: Jarugumalla Dayanika, Sivadi Balakrishna
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: The goal of this study is to improve the quality of CT scan images for medical analysis. After resizing the images for uniformity, we converted them to grayscale for more straightforward processing. In reversible data hiding, increasing the capacity may lead to a decrease in the quality of the medical image, which is undesirable in clinical applications. To overcome this problem, filters are used to improve the image quality while reducing noise, and we use a neural network to reconstruct the images. The aim is to overcome the limitations of existing approaches by providing a comprehensive solution for a wide range of medical imaging requirements. The Sparse Autoencoder Deep Neural Network (SADNN) model autonomously recognizes critical visual patterns, effectively reduces noise, and improves image quality. SADNN introduces a promising methodology for improving image quality, providing valuable insights into healthcare decisions in the complex field of medical imaging. The proposed SADNN model has been evaluated using the BRATS CT dataset for performance metrics such as PSNR and SSIM. The proposed method achieves an impressive peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) of 64.31 dB and an outstanding structural similarity index (SSIM) value of 0.994, with a computational overhead of only 23.32 kb. These findings highlight the applicability of this method in the field of medical image restoration and enhancement.

title: Hybrid LSTM–Random Forest Model for Forecasting Lettuce Leaf Growth in Hydroponic Systems During the Rainy Season
authors: Ahmad Fauzi Zayandra, Deny Haryadi, Demi Adidrana
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Hydroponic lettuce cultivation in Indonesia suffers from unpredictable growth during the rainy season due to fluctuating temperature, humidity, pH, and nutrient levels, leading to inefficiencies and losses of yield. The classic approaches ARIMA and Prophet were unable to model nonlinear relationships, which for Prophet indicated MAE 1.475 and a lower RMSE 1.808 for identical 2024 NFT data. This research aims to merge LSTM and Random Forest in a hybrid model capable of providing precise and practical predictions for farmers. 344 daily values for data regarding months of Jan to May 2024 were prepared for training with time series creation, selection with a hole based on standard deviation values of less than 1.5, MinMax value normalization, and split data division based on seasons 1 to 3 for training and season 4 for validation. The hybrid model boasts LSTM for extracting temporal relationships and Random Forest for correcting nonlinear relationships for univariate and multivariate approaches. In several experiments based on differing data structures and other parameters, multivariate clearly outperformed others with MAE 1.256 and a lower RMSE 1.822 for 14.6 percent absolute improvement in MAE performance with 14.85 percent improvement in MAE values for identical data when compared with Prophet. This model clearly indicates major contributing factors for droughts in hydroponic systems for practical future creation of low-cost action rules for straightforward and immediate actions via existing IoT equipment for tropical hydroponic farming.

title: SolarPredict: A Lightweight Machine Learning Model for Hourly Rooftop Solar Energy Forecasting Using Weather and Temporal Features
authors: Ashutosh Kumar Tejaswi, Sweety Suman, Santosh Kumar, Prakash Sahu
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of rooftop solar energy is essential for grid stability and large-scale Rooftop Solar (RTS) integrations. Many existing approaches are computationally intensive, limiting their suitability for real-world deployment. To address this issue, SolarPredict is proposed as a lightweight and scalable framework that integrates weather and temporal features with multiyear RTS data to deliver precise hourly predictions. A broad benchmark of 19 machine and deep learning models was conducted, where CatBoost, trained on an optimized set of 13 features, stood out by achieving state-of-the-art precision (RMSE = 0.0389, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9631, nRMSE = 0.0417) while maintaining high efficiency. Compared to LightGBM, the next-best model, CatBoost offered over twice the inference speed and required less than half the storage size, making it ideal for edge devices and large-scale deployments. RNN-based deep learning models, including LSTM and GRU, were also assessed. While GRU performed the strongest among them (RMSE = 0.0585, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9179, nRMSE = 0.0662), it came with a significantly higher resource footprint. The proposed framework has been deployed as a responsive web application to support real-time forecasting. These results confirm the practicality of SolarPredict for RTS optimization and smart-grid applications.

title: Development of Secure-by-Design RISC-V Architectures with Embedded Hardware Roots-of-Trust for Next-Generation Smart Devices
authors: Dola Jyothi, M. Nagaraju Naik, S. Mallesh Narayan, K Subramanayam Chari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The ever-growing spread of smart devices in safety-critical areas like healthcare, industry, and defence has accentuated the demand for safe, dependable computing platforms. In this paper, we propose ANCHOR-RV, a novel secure-by-design RISC-V ISA that incorporates embedded hardware Roots of Trust (RoT) to overcome the shortcomings of traditional security models. In contrast to the current solutions based on fixed trust anchors and inflexible boot mechanisms, ANCHOR-RV proposes an amazingly flexible and dynamic security system comprised of a Context-Aware Trust Engine (CATE), a Nonlinear PUF-Enhanced Identity Vault, a Secure DMA Isolation Bubble (SDIB) and a Trust-Aware Boot Chain with Mutation (TAB-CM). In combination, these modules can offer real-time threat monitoring, per-device identity verification, secure peripheral isolation, and highstrength boot integrity, and are enhanced by a custom RISC-V ISA extension (RV-TISA) to support more secure firmware-software communication. ANCHOR-RV enables the self-configuration of intelligent devices to dynamically changing threat situations with a minimal power and space footprint, making it particularly useful for prototyping and simulation in low-resource environments. The architecture is prototyped and simulated with the FPGA to test its security robustness, performance and efficiency. The experimental data convincingly show that ANCHOR-RV can deliver significant improvements in trust flexibility and attack resistance, and that it is more efficient than traditional constant RoT deployments in dynamic environments. Mutation of the boot mechanism employed in the architecture and context-aware trust management provides a new defence against side-channel attacks, persistent threats, and boot-time attacks. The work will lay the foundation for future resilient RISC-V-based computing systems, enabling a flexible, extensible, and resilient next-generation smart device platform. The subsequent steps will include an ASIC implementation, optimisation of the machine learning models, and integration with real-world smart device platforms.

title: An Interpretable Sparse Fourier-Based Convolutional Neural Network (SpFFT-CNN) for Eccentricity Faults Classification
authors: Latifa Yusuf, Belaid Moa, T. Ilamparithi
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents an interpretable frequency-domain approach for fault classification in synchronous machines using a Sparse Fourier-based Convolutional Neural Network (SpFFT-CNN). The method extends a time-domain convolutional neural network by integrating learnable spectral weights that operate directly in the frequency domain. These weights adaptively emphasize the harmonic components that contribute most to class separation, allowing the network to identify discriminative frequency regions for different fault conditions. The model was applied to current signals containing healthy and eccentric faults under three preprocessing configurations: with DC (direct current) component, without DC, and without mean. The harmonic spectra learned in each case reveal consistent frequency patterns that remain stable across all the model variants, confirming that the network captures genuine spectral characteristics. The higher harmonics consistently define mixed eccentricity, the lower harmonics dominate dynamic eccentricity, and static eccentricity maintains an overlap that is more pronounced when DC is retained. The results demonstrate that the SpFFT-CNN not only achieves a perfect fault classification but also provides a transparent interpretation of the underlying frequency structure. This framework bridges signal-based analysis and deep learning by linking classification accuracy directly to harmonic interpretability.

title: A Delta-Operator-Based Decoupled Periodic Output Feedback Control for Multivariable Systems
authors: Ankita Kumari, Bijnan Bandyopadhyay, Deepak Fulwani
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents the delta operator formulation to establish a decoupled design framework for periodic output feedback (POF) control. The traditional POF-based shift operator becomes numerically ill-conditioned with decrease in sample time. This leads to reduction in closed-loop efficacy and loss of controllability or observability. To overcome these issues, the POF problem is reformulated in the delta domain, and a decoupling strategy is employed that improves the design of controllers for multivariable systems. The decoupled design POF method reduces the complexity by allowing each input to receive feedback from fewer outputs, resulting in fewer feedback loops than the direct design for multivariable systems, which ensures stability of the closed-loop system, and the delta operator maintains structural properties during fast sampling that ensure system matrices are well-conditioned and the stabilization of poles. The proposed method is validated through a numerical example and simulated results.

title: LanPerAct: A Framework for Language-Driven Perception and Robotic Manipulation
authors: Haoning Wu, Shaowu Wu, Youyuan Tu, Hao Zhou, Steve Drew, Xiaoguang Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Robotic manipulation necessitates comprehensive environmental perception and precise awareness of object pose estimation. Current systems predominantly rely on predefined motion primitives, exhibiting significant limitations in flexible interaction. The semantic reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models can provide robust task planning and decision-making support, while more accurate object pose estimation ensures execution precision and operational stability. In this study, we present LanPerAct, a Unified Framework for Language-Driven Perception and Robotic Manipulation. LanPerAct integrates large language models with pose-based grasping through a language-vision-action co-reasoning pipeline. Our approach first employs Deepseek to construct an end-to-end natural language instruction parser that generates structured task parameters. Subsequently, we utilize open-vocabulary object detection and instance segmentation to obtain object masks and corresponding point cloud data, followed by a two-stage point-matching algorithm for precise 6D pose estimation. Finally, the system executes zero-shot object grasping through generated code that interfaces with our multi-stage, multi-task pose-grasping framework, achieving both lightweight implementation and robust task execution. Experimental results in both simulated and real-world environments demonstrate the advanced effectiveness of our method, showcasing its capability for efficient and precise execution of natural language-guided manipulation tasks. We believe this research provides valuable insights for real-world robotic behavior development.

title: Real-Time Micro-Stress Detection for Remote Managers Using AI
authors: Neha Nahariya, Rohit Bajaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Stress is not a new phenomenon and it is a significantly influential factor that affects and affects people without any discrimination by their age, gender, color, or occupation everywhere all around the world. The research paper provides AI-based Machine Learning (ML) paradigm that will be able to identify micro-stress in telecommuters through the combination of behavioral, physiological, and a few environmental variables, and the significance of understanding stress in the current context, which is the stress that is ubiquitous, chronic, and multifaceted. The Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) are some of the ML techniques that have been employed to determine the impact of the potentially influential variables such as the workload, the frequency of communication, the quality of sleep, and the physical activity. The results indicate that XGBoost has the highest according with 92.3 percent with other models having lower accuracy in precision, recall, and F1-score. The approach that is suggested by applying ML and AI enables superior stress management functions that consequently enable individuals, teams and organizations to shield themselves against the adverse consequences of stress in their lives. The research might be used in the planning of digital health interventions, which are preventive and can establish a more productive and mentally healthier workplace.

title: An Ensemble Stacking Approach for Reliable Type 1 Diabetes Prediction
authors: Sudha D, S.M. Keerthana, T.N. Sudhahar, S. Thumilvannan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: For Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), individualized insulin dosage at mealtimes is essential for the best possible blood glucose management. Individual differences in metabolic reactions are not taken into consideration by current dosing regimens, which are frequently generic.
