In order to forecast individual insulin dosages, this study suggests an attention network-based model that makes use of meal data, continuous glucose monitoring (CGM), and personal health metrics. The model selectively focuses on important aspects impacting insulin requirements at each meal by integrating attention mechanisms. The strategy seeks to lower the risk of hypoglycemia while enhancing glycemic control. According to experimental results, insulin dosage accuracy and patientspecific optimization have significantly improved, providing a more flexible and customized therapy option for the control of diabetes type 1.

title: Development of a cost-effective and user-friendly skin potential acquisition module for emotion detection
authors: Anh Quang Tran, Duc-Tan Tran, Minh Giang Nguyen, Tran Huy Dang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: Emotion detection plays an essential role in various applications such as psychological assessment, human–computer interaction, and health monitoring. In this study, we propose a low-cost and real-time skin conductance acquisition system based on an Arduino Uno microcontroller and LabVIEW software for emotion detection. The designed circuit effectively amplifies and filters Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) signals with high signal-to-noise ratio. Experimental results show clear differences between relaxed and excited emotional states, confirming the sensitivity and reliability of the system in detecting sympathetic nervous activity. The combination of analog and digital filtering enhances signal quality, while the graphical interface allows convenient visualization and analysis. The proposed system achieves comparable performance to commercial GSR devices at a fraction of the cost, providing a feasible and scalable solution for biomedical, educational, and human–machine interaction applications.

title: Towards Reliable Microgrids: Investigation and Mitigation of Power Quality Disturbances
authors: Eamam Hasan Tanvir, Shady S. Refaat, Mostafa Farrag, Amira Mohammed
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV)-dominated microgrids are increasingly deployed to enhance sustainability and resilience, yet they face critical challenges in maintaining power quality under variable operating conditions. This study investigates the performance of a grid-forming inverter utilising frequency-active power (P-f) and voltage-reactive power (Q-V) droop control in both grid-connected and islanded modes. A detailed MATLAB/Simulink model is developed to analyze step-load variations and irradiance changes from 1000 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>. Results show that balanced three-phase voltages and currents are preserved with low total harmonic distortion, while frequency deviations remain confined to 49.5-50.0 Hz during large disturbances. Active and reactive power are effectively shared without requiring external coordination, and system voltage and frequency deviations remain within acceptable limits even under reduced irradiance. These findings demonstrate the robustness and ride-through capability of droop-controlled, grid-forming conversion for reliable operation of PV-rich microgrids.

title: A Low-Carbon Planning and Configuration Method for Electricity-Hydrogen-Methanol-Ammonia Multi-Energy System Considering Full Life-Cycle Assessment
authors: Dandan Li, Guoxian Luo, Huiling Qin, Zhige Li, Xiqiao Lin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: With China's commitment to carbon neutrality and the urgent need for global carbon emission reduction, the electricity-hydrogen-methanol-ammonia (EHMA) multi-energy system has emerged as a promising pathway for deep decarbonization. However, traditional planning methods often neglect life-cycle environmental impacts and the flexible interaction among multiple energy carriers, leading to suboptimal configurations. This paper proposes a low-carbon planning and configuration method for EHMA multi-energy systems considering full life-cycle assessment. First, a comprehensive life-cycle model is established, encompassing the manufacturing, operational, and disposal phases of all system components. Then, a multi-objective optimization framework integrating economic cost, life-cycle carbon emissions, and energy efficiency is constructed to determine the optimal equipment capacities and operational strategies. The method analyzes various system configurations and operational modes. Case studies of a southern industrial park demonstrate that the optimized configuration achieves 59.6% carbon emission reduction with 0.62 CNY/kWh levelized cost and 78% renewable penetration, while life-cycle assessment reveals operational emissions dominate at 78.5%, highlighting the importance of comprehensive life-cycle considerations in low-carbon planning.

title: Modulation Doping Techniques for AlGaAs/GaAs HEMTs: a Comparative Analysis
authors: Bilal Sanauddin Pirzada, Samir El-Ghazaly
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This research presents a comparative analysis of the continuous and the delta modulation doping techniques for an AlGaAs/GaAs HEMT, determining the optimum doping mechanism, the required doping density, and the thickness of the spacer layer. The analysis of the resultant I-V characteristics revealed that high-density, thin delta-doped layers yield enhanced electrical performance as compared to continuous doped layers with similar areal densities. This underscores the ability of delta-doped layers to move the dopant’s centroid closer to the heterojunction and create a channel with increased charge carrier density and enhanced electron mobility.

title: Intelligent Diagnosis Method for High-Voltage Transmission Line Short-Circuit Faults Based on Fault Feature Identification and Case-Based Reasoning
authors: Wei Dai, Shuqian Liu, Yang Gao, Xinghua Ma, Wei Li, Yuchen Jiang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: The diagnosis of short-circuit faults in high-voltage transmission lines is crucial for ensuring the security and stability of power grids. Addressing the challenges posed by short-lasting fault signals, limited effective data, and similarities between different fault features, this paper proposes an intelligent diagnosis method based on fault feature identification and Case-Based Reasoning (CBR). Firstly, to tackle the scarcity of real fault data, a simulation model of a high-voltage transmission system based on a Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) is established to generate fault data. Secondly, an intelligent feature extraction method integrating the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) with Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) is proposed. GWO is employed to adaptively optimize the penalty factor and mode number of VMD, enabling the optimal extraction of fault features, which are then quantified using Sample Entropy (SE). Finally, a historical case library is constructed based on SE feature vectors, and a retrieval mechanism using Euclidean distance-based similarity calculation is designed for the rapid and intelligent diagnosis of new faults. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average diagnostic accuracy of 98.46% for 11 types of short-circuit faults with a diagnosis time of only 0.14 seconds, outperforming comparative models like Extreme Learning Machine (ELM), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and BP Neural Network. Testing on 30 sets of real fault data still yielded an accuracy of 87%, validating the method's effectiveness and practicality in real-world scenarios.

title: LLM PhishGuard: A GPT-3.5–Driven Framework with Heuristics, VirusTotal Reputation, and OCR for SME Email Security
authors: Adil Khan, Suleiman Y. Yerima
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Phishing remains one of the most persistent threats in cybersecurity, frequently serving as a gateway for data breaches, ransomware, and financial fraud. While large enterprises rely on advanced filtering systems, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) often lack the resources or technical expertise to counter increasingly sophisticated phishing campaigns. These risks are amplified by social engineering, zero-day exploits, and hidden payloads. This paper introduces LLM PhishGuard—a lightweight, prompt-driven detection framework that combines OpenAI’s GPT-3.5 with practical heuristics and optional OCR. The system analyzes linguistic cues, domain reputation, SPF/DKIM indicators, domain age, and data extracted from suspicious URLs. Evaluated on a dataset of 59 emails drawn from real-world and corporate sources, PhishGuard achieved 95% accuracy and delivered structured, explainable outputs in downloadable JSON and PDF formats. It is the first lightweight framework to unify LLM reasoning, heuristics, and OCR in a modular, cost-effective design tailored for SME environments. Each message is processed in 5.3 seconds at a cost of approximately $0.002, offering a practical and scalable solution for resource-constrained organizations.

title: Enhancing Underwater Sonar Target Recognition using Non-linear Wavelet Transforms
authors: Andrew Christensen, Ananya Sen Gupta, Ivars Kirsteins
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: This work addresses a critical challenge of automatic target recognition in sonar by focusing on feature extraction and feature selection techniques. The inherent non-linear distortions prevalent in sonar echo returns, arising from complex acoustic scattering physics, waveguide propagation effects, and background clutter, severely limit the effectiveness of standard off-the-shelf machine learning classifiers applied to raw echo data. To overcome these limitations and extract highly informative target features, we propose using a non-linear feature extraction method to first separate the target signatures from the background distortions. Specifically, this method utilizes a cascade of wavelet filters combined with non-linear operators, yielding a set of features more amenable to linear classification. This non-linear wavelet transform is well-suited for sonar echo returns due to its highly localized time-frequency characteristics. Our method achieved a classification accuracy of 86.6% on a large sonar target dataset, representing a 13.9% improvement in performance compared to using only the raw sonar echoes. These results demonstrate the discriminatory power of the wavelet-based feature extraction techniques for challenging sonar ATR applications.

title: Multimodal Deepfake Detection: A Scalable AI Pipeline Combining Audio-Visual Analysis
authors: Deepjyoti Bhattacharya, Sangita Dutta, Indrajit Mondal, Debjyoti Ghosh, Avik Kumar Das, Sourav Bhattacharyya
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Deepfake generation has advanced to produce convincing synthetic audio and video, creating serious challenges for ensuring the credibility of digital content. This work proposes a scalable multimodal detection framework that leverages CNN-based transfer learning in combination with transformer-based fusion to capture spatial, temporal, and cross-modal inconsistencies. Video analysis incorporates face tracking, temporal dynamics, and artifact localization, while audio analysis employs Mel-Spectrogram features and pretrained embeddings. Additionally, speech–lip synchronization is evaluated to identify inconsistencies between phonemes and visemes. Experiments show that the system effectively distinguishes authentic content from manipulated variants (fake audio, fake video, or both), even under variations such as compression noise and resolution shifts. With applications in digital forensics, social media monitoring, and biometric verification, the proposed approach offers a robust defense against the growing sophistication of deepfake technologies.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for PCOS Detection Using MobileNetV2 and Clinical Features
authors: Mohanasundaram. V, Ramya K, Eswari K. E, Viswanathan. D, Tamizharasu. K, S. Hemalatha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Aim: PCOS Vision is a hybrid Deep learning techniques, particularly MobileNetV2, play a crucial role in accurately detecting Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) by analyzing clinical data and ultrasound images. Materials and Methods: The Model consisted of a Group 1(Control) Early identification of PCOS is critical to reducing complications, and machine learning (ML) offers a strong detection tool through advanced feature extraction. Various ML models, such as CNN, SVM, and Random Forest, have been extensively studied for PCOS diagnosis. Group 2 (Intervention) Deep learning algorithms, especially MobileNetV2, improve PCOS detection through the combination of clinical information with ultrasound images, resulting in improved diagnosis. Result: The PCOSVision model demonstrated high accuracy (94.8%), precision (93.5%), recall (95.2%), F1-score (94.3%), and AUC-ROC (0.96), highlighting the effectiveness combining ultrasound image analysis clinical data for accurate PCOS detection. Conclusion: The PCOS-Vision model, combining clinical information with MobileNetV2, shows great accuracy and efficiency, opening up AI-assisted diagnostic tools in gynecology with better patient outcomes.

title: Miniature Flexible Dualband Antenna for 5G NR Applications
authors: Z. Mordi, Z. Hamouda, M. Lagha
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This study introduces a compact and flexible printed monopole antenna using a coplanar waveguide (CPW) feed, optimized for dual-band 5G operation. The antenna operates efficiently over the frequency ranges of 3.95–5.39 GHz and 5.88–7.26 GHz, covering key 5G New Radio (NR) bands including N79 [4.4–5.0] GHz, N102 [5.925–6.425] GHz, and N104 [6.425–7.125] GHz. Its performance was analyzed using full-wave electromagnetic simulations, which indicate consistent radiation behavior and satisfactory gain levels. The simulated realized gains are 2.06 dBi at 4.6 GHz and 1.65 dBi at 6.5 GHz. Employing a CPW feed simplifies integration with planar circuits and supports efficient impedance matching and radiation performance. Thanks to its conformal structure and compact geometry, the developed antenna is a promising option for flexible, wearable, and compact 5G wireless platforms.

title: Direct hybridization of fuel cells with batteries for urban and suburban transport: a small-scale study
authors: Mengxi Wen, Stéphane Raël, François Lapicque, Caroline Bonnet, Melika Hinaje
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: A direct hybrid power source between fuel cells and batteries was proposed for a smaller and lighter electric vehicle, specifically designed for urban and suburban transport. By eliminating the DC/DC power converter, the system structure is simplified, its energy losses, weight and cost can also be reduced. The feasibility of this architecture was validated at a small scale by directly hybridizing a stack of five proton exchange membrane fuel cells and a single lithium-ion battery under a (sub)urban driving cycle. Power and energy contributions of the fuel cell stack and the battery were determined. A natural power sharing was observed: the fuel cell provided a regular power output with very small fluctuations, as it would be with power converters, while the battery flexibly responded to rapid transients, allowing the hybrid power source to meet the full power demand. Moreover, the fuel cell provided more power than the mean load demand, with the excess mainly recharging the battery. This confirms the appropriate sizing of the hybrid power source: when coupled, the fuel cell recharges the battery while continuously supplying power to the load.

title: Financial Performance Evaluation: Comparing Islamic and Conventional Banks Between 2013-2022
authors: Adnan Jawabri, Meera Albaloshi, Nael Sayedahmed, Mohammad Husam Odeh, Azza Mohamed, Mohammed Ghazal
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The study explores how the type of banking system used affects financial outcomes, drawing data from ten years between 2013 and 2022, from 40 different banks across multiple countries. This study was conducted considering the global environment where Islamic and Conventional Banking systems operate side by side, creating avenues for differing financial performances. Using a quantitative methodology, the research looks at the financial performance through Return on Assets (ROA) and Return on Equity (ROE). The results from two-sample T-test indicate a marked difference in both ROA and ROE, with Islamic Banks outperforming their conventional peers. Along with this, strong positive correlations between ROE and ROA were observed for Islamic Banks (ρ = 0.869) and Conventional Banks (ρ= 0. 784) showing the interrelation of these measures for profitability. These insights give implications for financial institutions and policymakers, showcasing the importance of understanding the operations of each banking model.

title: The End of Pretraining for Large Language Models: The Future of Agentic and AI Reasoning Beyond Peak Data
authors: Victor Kebande
publish: Computer
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has entered a transformative era, as traditional pretraining paradigms face the constraints of “peak data.” This article explores the implications of a “post-pretraining” era, where AI systems transcend static data dependency and evolve into agentic AI entities.

title: In Memoriam: George E. Smith (1930–2025) [Obituary]
authors: Bin Zhao
publish: IEEE Electron Devices Magazine
abstract: Recounts the career and contributions of George E. Smith.

title: On Informative State Vectors for Discrete Dynamic Estimation in Switched Systems Using the Model-Based Minimum Distance Method
authors: Koffi M.D. Motchon, Kevin Guelton
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: This technical note addresses the discrete dynamic estimation problem in switched linear systems using the model-based minimum distance method (MB-MDM). Prior work has shown that, for this method, the state vector must be sufficiently far from the origin to guarantee an accurate estimation of the discrete dynamic, thereby confirming inherent conflicts between discrete dynamic estimation and feedback control objectives in switched systems. To enhance the accuracy of the MB-MDM, this work focuses on characterizing the region of state vectors that enable exact discrete dynamic estimation, termed informative state vector (ISV). The contributions of this paper are twofold. Firstly, a necessary and sufficient condition based on linear matrix inequalities is derived to determine whether a state vector is informative, revealing that ISV must lie outside a specific ellipsoid. Based on this observation, an ellipsoid-based approach is then proposed to estimate the ISV region.

title: Tensorial Multi-view Clustering via Alternative Rank Minimization and Inter-view Alignment
authors: Zisen Kong, Dongxia Chang, Yiming Wang, Pengyuan Li, Yao Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Tensor-based multi-view clustering is a popular approach. It can enhance representation learning by exploring higher-order correlations among views. However, two key issues remain unsolved. First, minimizing the tensor rank is a complex multi-objective optimization problem, so finding a suitable optimization strategy is an open problem. Moreover, most tensor methods require two phases to obtain the consensus matrix, which usually leads to suboptimal performance. To address these issues, we propose a Tensorial Multi-view Clustering via Alternative Rank Minimization and Inter-view Alignment (ARIA), in which multiple low-rank matrices and the consistent matrix are jointly optimized in a unified framework. Specifically, we stack the representations obtained from different views into a higher-order tensor. Then, a non-convex alternative rank-minimizing regularization is introduced to achieve a tighter approximation of the rank function. Besides, we impose intra-view alignment constraints to establish a connection between inter-view and intra-view. Unlike the previous method, it is a one-step strategy to obtain the consensus representation. Notably, our approach requires only linear complexity, and thus it can be successfully applied in large-scale clustering tasks. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed method. The code for ARIA is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/zskong/ARIA</uri>.

title: Performance Degradation and Reliability of 4H-SiC MOSFETs at Extreme Low Temperatures
authors: Xinru Chen, Hang Xu, Yanghao Wang, Jianbin Guo, Changhao Wang, Qingqing Sun, David Wei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This study systematically investigates the cryogenic reliability of a 650 V silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFET for extreme-environment applications, using the 650 V silicon IGBT as a performance benchmark. Measurements and technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulations demonstrate that the SiC MOSFET experiences severe performance degradation below 200 K due to carrier freeze-out, which manifests as significant threshold voltage instability and pronounced C–V hysteresis. In stark contrast, the silicon IGBT maintains stable switching and robust gate integrity down to 150 K. These results define the low-temperature operational boundary and identify the carrier freeze-out mechanism as the root cause, providing essential guidance for the reliable application of wide bandgap (WBG) SiC devices in extreme cold environments.

title: RTCache: An Efficient Remapping Table Cache for NVM Wear-Leveling
authors: Hai Jin, Haobo Wang, Zhuohui Duan, Haikun Liu, Xiaofei Liao, Ruicong Chen, Hanfei Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: NVM provides a more generalized high-density memory media with DRAM-like performance and non-volatile nature to provide persistent data accesses to computing devices. Due to the poor write tolerance of NVM, wear-leveling strategies are essential in NVM. We find that the remapping table accesses become a neglected performance bottleneck when deploying wear-leveling strategies in NVM controllers, and contiguity-based CPU address mapping caching optimization strategies cannot be adapted due to the randomized mappings introduced by wear-leveling strategies. In this paper, we present RTCache, an efficient caching mechanism designed to accelerate access performance of the wear-leveling remapping table in NVM controllers. We propose a two-level mapping cache to enhance the cache utilization, consequently improving the cache hit ratio. Notably, RTCache incorporates a victim cache to improve the efficiency of RTCache for discretely accessed pages. Furthermore, RTCache adopts a cache-friendly remapping table memory structure, mitigating the challenges posed by access amplification due to RTCache misses. Experimental results show that RTCache can significantly improve the performance of NVM with wear-leveling strategies, and the negative impact on the system performance is reduced to an acceptable level.

title: Error Bounds for Radial Network Topology Learning from Quantized Measurements
authors: Samuel Talkington, Aditya Rangarajan, Pedro A. Alcântara, Line Roald, Daniel K. Molzahn, Daniel R. Fuhrmann
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: We probabilistically bound the error of a solution to a radial network topology learning problem where both connectivity and line parameters are estimated. In our model, data errors are introduced by the precision of the sensors, i.e., quantization. This produces a nonlinear measurement model that embeds the operation of the sensor communication network into the learning problem, expanding beyond the additive noise models typically seen in power system estimation algorithms. We show that the error of a learned radial network topology is proportional to the quantization bin width and grows sublinearly in the number of nodes, provided that the number of samples per node is logarithmic in the number of nodes.

title: Toward Realism: Sparse Matrix Statistics in the North American and Synthetic Electric Grid Models
authors: Sanjana Kunkolienkar, Farnaz Safdarian, Thomas J. Overbye
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: This letter uses sparse matrix statistics to highlight a structural gap between North American grid models and the synthetic cases commonly used in research. North American grids exhibit area-based modularity, characterized by dense intra-area links and limited inter-area connectivity. By contrast, synthetic grids often over-mesh across areas. Analysis shows that these surplus tie lines increase fills in the Jacobian factorization, which reduces realism and computational efficiency. The observations confirm that inter-area connectivity influences sparse matrix behavior. This work emphasizes the importance of incorporating modular structure into synthetic grid design.

title: Multimode Composite Continuum Robot: Coupled Static Modeling and Verification
authors: Jing Su, Hangxing Wei, Fuxin Du, Han Zeng, Changwei Yin, Rui Song, Yibin Li
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Hybrid continuum robots with concentric tubes and cable-driven mechanisms offer compactness and dexterity. However, they face limited adaptability and modeling challenges. This article proposes, for the first time, a multimode operation strategy for the composite continuum robot, enabling switching among high stiffness, high flexibility, and high precision modes. By adjusting the relative position between the concentric tube and the notched continuum, the robot achieves flexible transitions among these modes. A static model based on Euler–Bernoulli beam theory is established, where the bending moments from the concentric tube acting on the notched continuum segment are analytically integrated to reflect coupling effects. Algorithms are designed to achieve the mapping between the driving force and the shape, as well as the mapping relationship between the driving cable length and the robot shape. Based on the Kepler oval and the established static model, the inverse kinematics model of the robot is constructed. Simulations and experimental results show a modeling error of only 0.042 mm (0.084%), outperforming conventional models. The robot demonstrates convenient mode switching, showing performance characteristics, such as high stiffness, high flexibility, and high precision. This work contributes to improved modeling and control strategies for continuum robots.

title: Synchronous Vibration Suppression for Active Magnetic Bearing Systems With Induced Current and Stiffness Variation
authors: Qi Liu, Zhenzhong Su, Shouding Xu, Hao Jiang, Zhi Li
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: The synchronous vibration suppression controllers (SVSCs) based on active magnetic bearings (AMBs) can isolate the synchronous electromagnetic force to achieve synchronous vibration suppression. In this article, we address two key factors that have limited the conventional SVSCs: the induced current and the stiffness variation, which are addressed by induced current compensation and online stiffness measurement. First, the induced current under both open-loop and closed-loop conditions, as well as its effect on the AMB electromagnetic forces, is analyzed. Additionally, an online stiffness measurement method is introduced, which requires only adjusting the bias current without increasing the test weight or altering the speed, thereby ensuring practical applicability. Then, an optimized phase-shifted bandpass filter SVSC is implemented, whose parameters are dynamically tuned by the real-time values of the induced current and stiffness. Finally, experimental results at various speeds demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, achieving vibration reduction of at least 3.5 dB and up to 18 dB compared to conventional SVSCs.

title: Copyright Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)

title: A SPICE Simulation Study of Stacked Inverters and Transistors Type D Flip-Flop Designs with 16-nm CMOS Technology
authors: Md. Badhesha, J. Ajayan, Sandip Bhattacharya, Motla Sathwika, Mulstham Karthik Purnachander, Nagavelly Tarun Teja
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The D-Flip-Flop (DFF) is a critical block for integrated circuits (ICs) and application such as low-temperature infrared image sensors and sense amplifiers. Our research indicates that DFF exhibits a minimal percentage variation in power consumption and delay concerning temperature. This investigation has shown that temperature is a significant variable in the design and development of DFFs. Temperature variations can significantly change delay and power. As a result, the performance of the DFF is temperature dependent. In D-Latch Design with Stacked Inverters, at a temperature of $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the delay is 39.73 ps and 52.57 ps at $107^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. When the power supply was swept from 0.7 V to 1.2 V, and power consumption was increased by $87.1 \% / 89.2 \%$ at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / 107^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, respectively. In Stacked Transistor DFF, due to a change in temperature from $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $107^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the percentage of delay changes from $50.1 \%$ to $54.7 \%$. Almost every digital gadget, from basic microcontrollers and calculators to sophisticated computers and communication systems, uses DFFs.

title: Blockchain-Based Self-Sovereign Identity for Digital Security
authors: Namrata Mishra, P. K. Chidambaram, Hassan Mohamed Mahdi, A. Spandana, J. Karpagam, P Neelima, O. Sh. Gulyamova
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: SSI is a quickly appearing paradigm to secure and user-sovereign digital identity management. Nevertheless, existing implementations of SSI still have privacyprotection, interoperability, anti-fraud, and anti-cryptographic resiliency weaknesses. To tackle these issues, this paper presents a proposal of an AI-enhanced, blockchain-based protocol incorporating the use of Zero Knowledge Proofs (ZKP), Multiple Layer Decentralization (MLD) as well as quantumresistant cryptography. The framework uses AI to do dynamic Identity verification and real-time fraud detection, risk-based authentication and provides great advantage to traditional SSI models. The system proposed will utilize ZKPs to provide its users with privacy-preserving authentication so that one can confirm attributes but not reveal sensitive personal data. Multi-layer decentralized identity validation structure is developed to enhance the level of trust, reduce dependence on centralized authorities and enhances/supported interoperability across homogeneous systems. Ancillary, postquantum cryptographic schemes will also be incorporated to protect identities by mitigating the possible quantum computing attacks. Experimental evidence shows that our framework significantly enhances the accuracy of verification, the authentication latency and increases security in comparison to centralised and federated identity management solutions. The scheme is very flexible in financing sector, cross boundaries identity, e-governance portals and Web3 online portals. In the end, this study leads to an increment of a scaleable and privacy-sensitive digital identity system because it bridges existing security, usability and compliance gaps and opens pathways to robust and resilient SSI implementations into the future.

title: Predictive Modeling of BPSK Bit Recovery Using Machine Learning in Underwater Acoustic Communication
authors: Hussam Alraie, Abdullah Alraee, Mohammad Albaroudi, Raji Alahmad, Tayfun Nesimoglu
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Underwater Acoustic communication UWA poses a significant challenge to researchers due to the difficulties associated with wireless signal propagation in the aquatic environment. The most significant reason leading to an increased error rate and reduced accuracy of the communication system is signal attenuation. Machine learning algorithms can find an algebraic formula between data inputs and outputs by using simulation data or experimental data. The more data is used, the more accurate the algebraic relationship becomes. Simple threshold, Logistic regression, Support Vector Machine SVM and K-Nearest Neighbors KNN were used to predict the received bit in the Binary Phase Shift Keying BPSK digital modulation scheme. The methods were applied using the simulation environment of the Thorp formula for the underwater acoustic channel. The simulation results showed that machine learning algorithms outperformed the thresholding method, achieving an accuracy of 99.84% when using SVM.

title: Online state of charge estimation of supercapacitor considering uncertain bias compensation
authors: Luxiao Wang, Jiandong Duan, Haoran Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The state of charge(SOC) estimation accuracy of the methods based on equivalent circuit model will decrease due to the existence of uncertain bias such as model error, voltage and current measurement errors. In this paper, a SOC estimation method that considering uncertain bias compensation is proposed to improve the SOC estimation accuracy of supercapacitor(SC) under uncertain bias. The factors that cause estimation error and the impact of bias on estimation result are analyzed. A one-dimensional bias term is added as one of the states to the state space equation of SC for observation. Then, a bias-free Kalman filter(KF) and an uncertain bias estimator are built based on KF algorithm after the decomposition of the expanded estimation algorithm, the estimation results of the two estimators are added together to get the optimal estimation result. Thirdly, the sources of bias are analyzed, and the effectiveness of the proposed method is validated under various operating conditions.

title: Research on Collaborative Scheduling Strategy for Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Based on Spatiotemporal Demand Gradient
authors: Kong Lingda, Zhang Bo, Zhu Junyi, Fan Min, He Lianjie, Yang Honglei
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Addressing issues such as regional power grid overload, uneven resource allocation, and extended user waiting times caused by the spatiotemporal uncertainty and agglomeration of electric vehicle (EV) charging behavior, this paper proposes a collaborative scheduling and dynamic regulation strategy for charging stations based on spatiotemporal demand gradients. By designing the average simultaneous rate of adjacent stations and spatiotemporal demand gradient features, a short-term prediction method for the simultaneous rate of charging stations based on a hybrid model of K-means and LSTM-GCN is constructed. Furthermore, the Spatial Transfer Flag (STF) is combined with the Model Predictive Control (MPC) framework. This integration establishes a multi-objective rolling optimization model. The model uses forecast data to deploy regulation strategies in advance. Ultimately, it achieves collaborative regulation with three key goals, such as alleviate congestion, enhance revenue, and balance user costs. Experimental results show that the proposed strategy significantly reduces the congestion ratio in the experimental area by 43.6%. It achieves an effective balance between charging station revenue and user costs, verifying its effectiveness and practicality in complex scenarios.

title: Feasibility Study of a DC Networking and Transmission Scheme for Large-scale Wind Power Bases
authors: Decai Li, Shangjin Yang, Shicheng Liu, Xiaoli Zhang, Ruiwen Xu, Xiao Lei
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Wind power has undergone rapid development over the past decades. However, due to the remote locations of wind energy resources relative to load centers, centralized long-distance transmission technologies are essential. This paper presents a feasibility study of a novel DC networking scheme and corresponding control strategy for large-scale wind energy transmission. The proposed method achieves DC power aggregation by serially connecting the rectified outputs of individual wind turbines, which increases the DC transmission voltage. This approach is particularly suitable for large-scale wind power integration. Additionally, it significantly reduces equipment usage in both wind farms and the associated transmission systems, thereby lowering capital investment. To validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed scheme, a simulation model comprising four wind turbines has been studied. Simulation results indicate that the proposed system and control strategies ensures stable operation under a range of operating conditions.

title: Integration of Gaussian Plume Dispersion Modeling and UAV Monitoring for Power Plant Carbon Emission Inversion
authors: Xiran Wang, Xinyu Ouyang, Jiaming Wang, Zhihao Chen, Xiaocong Sun, Tianyu Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Accurate quantification of power plant carbon emissions is critical for low-carbon power systems. Existing methods lack integration of physical modeling with real-time inversion. To address limitations in existing monitoring methods, this paper integrates Gaussian plume inversion modeling with concentration monitoring based on unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) for independent emission quantification. The framework adapts dispersion theory to power plant point sources, derives carbon emission coefficients via inverse modeling, and deploys a custom UAV system for multi-altitude CO₂ sampling. Simulation results demonstrate consistent alignment with preset emission parameters. This method provides an effective tool for grid carbon management, enabling precise carbon allowance allocation and dispatch optimization.

title: Life Prediction of Hydrogen Fuel Cells Based on Particle Filter Optimized by Grey Wolf Optimizer
authors: Wang Han, Hongchuan Zhang, Shuangfei Xie, Yukun Hou, Zihua Lu, Kefan Zhao, JiaWang Xu, Zixiang Gao, Zhiguang Hua
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Predicting the remaining useful life (RUL) of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is critical for their stable operation and industrial application. However, due to the strong nonlinearity of the aging process and complex operating conditions, traditional life prediction methods struggle to balance prediction accuracy with computational real-time performance. To address the issues of particle degradation and lack of diversity in particle filters (PF) for PEMFC lifespan prediction, this paper proposes an aging prediction model based on a gray wolf optimization algorithm (GWO)-enhanced particle filter (GWO-PF). This model utilizes the hierarchical collaborative mechanism of GWO to optimize the initial particle set and resampling strategy of PF. Experimental results under different training set ratios (50%, 60%, 70%) using datasets from various operating conditions demonstrate that the GWO-PF model can accurately track aging trends under both steady-state and dynamic conditions, exhibiting good prediction accuracy and robustness. Compared to the traditional Least Squares Support Vector Machine (LSSVM) model, in steady-state conditions, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of GWO-PF is reduced by up to 25.26% compared to LSSVM, and the Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) is reduced by up to 35.16%. In quasi-dynamic conditions, the GWO-PF model achieves a maximum reduction of 20.90% in RMSE and a maximum reduction of 29.41% in MAPE.

title: A Practical Optimization Framework for Joint Sizing and Speed Planning of Electric Tractors
authors: Ricardo de Castro, Jorge Varela Barreras, Damián González Figueroa
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel optimization framework for joint sizing and speed planning of electric battery tractors. The framework aims to minimize the total cost of ownership, while accounting for power and energy constraints of the tractor across multiple farming tasks. These requirements are formulated as a nonlinear optimization problem, which is then used to determine the appropriate values for the tractor speed, nominal power, battery capacity, and charger size. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated using a 22-hectare farm case study.

title: Android Malware Classification based on Image Feature Extraction using CNN and LightGBM
authors: William Paul Gustav, Nurul Ilmi, Syifa Nurgaida Yutia
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The number of Android users has increased globally. It also increases the risk of cybercrime, one of which is malware attacks. This study aims to develop and evaluate an efficient and accurate Android malware classification using Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) based on the MalVis dataset containing 27,000 RGB malware image visualization from APK files. CNN is used to extract spatial and textural features from images, while LightGBM is used as a classifier to process the extracted features. This study evaluates the model performance based on the metrics of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The CNN–LightGBM hybrid model achieved 73.33% accuracy and 73.59% F1-Score on one benign and five malware classes. This hybrid approach shows clear improvement compared to the CNN softmax classifier with an accuracy of 60.67% and an F1-Score of 61.37%. While the overall accuracy indicates room for further optimization, the findings successfully demonstrate that integrating LightGBM as a classifier for CNN-extracted features provides a performance boost over end-to-end CNN architectures for malware classification.

title: Distributed Bias Equalization Double Layer Control Algorithm for Multi Flywheel Energy Storage Matrix After Primary Frequency Modulation
authors: Wendong Li, Bochao Huai, Fang Yan, Caiyun Wang, Rufei Ren, Yueyang Wang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the large-scale grid integration of intermittent renewable energy sources such as wind and solar power, the power system demands significantly enhanced response speed and regulation accuracy for primary frequency regulation. Multi-flywheel energy storage matrices have emerged as the mainstream auxiliary form due to their advantages of rapid response and extended cycle life. This paper investigates the distributed deviation balancing issue in multi-flywheel energy storage matrices following primary frequency regulation, focusing on global balancing and local safety coordination scenarios under a strongly connected communication topology. A control model for multi-flywheel energy storage arrays is constructed, integrating the multi-flywheel communication topology, SOC deviation sensing after primary frequency regulation, and distributed consensus logic. This model innovatively resolves the SOC deviation issue following primary frequency regulation, overcoming the limitations of traditional single-flywheel regulation or centralized deviation balancing frameworks. Adaptability to complex multi-flywheel matrix operation scenarios is enhanced by establishing a local limiting mechanism incorporating SOC upper/lower bounds, power rating constraints, and SOC rate-of-change limits. The effectiveness and efficiency of the model and algorithm are validated through proportional consensus convergence analysis and hierarchical architecture stability verification.

title: Hybrid Energy System Performance Enhancement by Implementing Artificial Bee Colony Optimization
authors: Hemant Sharma, Abinash Singh, Kamalkant Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The production of electricity from nonconventional energy sources including solar PV (SPV) & wind energy systems (WES) presents a sustainable and eco-friendly substitute for traditional power generation technologies. With the depletion of traditional energy resources and their adverse environmental impacts, RES (renewable energy sources) are increasingly essential for reliable electricity generation. However, factors like Lightning storms, system faults, & the challenges of delivering power to distant or hilly areas necessitate robust techniques. Hybrid Energy Systems (HES) integrates many sources of energy. It is a viable approach to ensure uninterrupted & reliable supply of power. This research focuses on designing a HES comprising SPV, WES, & diesel energy sources using MATLAB/Simulink. To enhance system reliability, a diesel engine generator (DEG) is connected with the solar-wind setup as a backup source. This study evaluates the feasibility and stability of the recommended system designed to support a $50-\mathrm{kW}$ load, of a mini-community. Optimizing the system is a crucial part of this research, aimed at maximizing performance and ensuring operational stability. To enhance the SPV system’s performance, the Proportional-Integral (PI) controller parameters are optimized via the Artificial Bee Colony Optimization (ABCO) algorithm. The SPV system is integrated with the WES & DEG to make a compatible HES.

title: AI and Big Data for Optimizing Indonesia’s Oil Trade Balance
authors: Jane Ivana, Kyla Aleitta, Khaylanissa Setiyo, Robertus Nugroho Perwiro Atmojo
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Indonesia's oil trade balance, which was in surplus in the late 1990s, has gradually moved into an extensive deficit. Crude oil exports fell drastically throughout time from USD 5.71 billion in 1996 to just USD 2.23 billion in 2024. Exports of crude oil have fluctuated although they are still less than imports. With a peak of USD 31.76 billion in 2012, imports of oil products increased from USD 2.08 billion in 1996 to USD 25.92 billion in 2024. This study forecasts trade values and identifies abnormalities using artificial intelligence (AI) and big data. Grid-searched ARIMA models and an automated data pipeline were used with the best models, ARIMA (0,2,1) for exports and ARIMA (2,2,1) for imports, showing short term corrections after sharp changes. Events like the 2008 oil price rise and COVID-19 decline in 2020 are the main causes of volatility, according to Z-score results of year-over-year analysis. This suggests that persistent instability is not the root source of volatility. The model's capacity to offer a more realistic long-term prognosis is demonstrated by the final projection, which predicts a major decrease in oil exports and a large trade imbalance by 2030 when compared to the Hybrid VAR-LSTM approach model. The results suggest opportunities to boost export recovery and reduce reliance on imports. Data-based routing and AI forecasting are applied for this. To increase energy security, recommendations include incorporating more detailed data such as including outside variables in forecasts as well as AI-assisted distribution and refining. To improve forecast accuracy even more, future studies might expand this framework by adding advanced deep learning architectures like Transformer models or bidirectional LSTMs.

title: Towards Smart Charging Strategies: Using Machine Learning to Predict EV Charging Pattern via Smart Grid
authors: Adli Naufal Irhaam Imran, Illani Mohd Nawi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: Electric Vehicles (EVs) are becoming significantly important in daily transportation system due to their potential in reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emission. However, their large-scale adoption presents significant challenges to power grids and public infrastructure. To address this, this study investigates the application of Ensemble Learning algorithms, specifically XGBoost and Random Forest, to analyze charging patterns using a comprehensive dataset from the City of Palo Alto, sourced from kaggle.com. While standard Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) approaches are powerful, Ensemble Learning has demonstrated superior predictive performance in this domain. Experimental results show that while raw data yielded below 10% accuracy, the proposed feature engineering approach achieved a Station Usage Prediction accuracy of 87.25% and an Energy Consumption Prediction R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9995. By refining these predictions, this study aims to develop smart scheduling algorithms that efficiently manage growing demand, ensuring the sustainable integration of EVs into existing infrastructure.

title: Microgrid Planning with Enhanced EV Hosting Using Marine Predators Optimization Algorithm
authors: Yasmeena, Shubh Lakshmi, Tarkeshwar Mahto, Somesh Vinayak Tewari, Veerakotlu Lella, Bhanu Prakash Darbha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The swift increase in the adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has necessitated the enhancement of campus microgrids’ hosting capacity to meet the rising demand for charging while ensuring system stability and efficiency are not compromised. This research introduces an innovative method utilizing the Marine Predators Algorithm (MPA) to optimize the hosting capacity for EVs within campus microgrids. The MPA, which draws inspiration from the hunting techniques of marine predators, provides a robust solution to the intricate and nonlinear challenges associated with load management, renewable energy integration, and overall grid performance. The proposed approach reduces power losses, enhances voltage stability, and guarantees system reliability by optimizing the distribution of distributed energy resources (DERs) and coordinating EV charging schedules. Simulation outcomes indicate that the MPA surpasses traditional optimization techniques in achieving greater hosting capacity while adhering to system constraints. This study underscores the promise of bio-inspired algorithms as a sustainable and efficient means to facilitate the integration of EVs into contemporary microgrids, thereby contributing to the development of smarter and more environmentally friendly energy systems.

title: Leveraging Deep Learning for High-Accuracy Eye Disease Detection and Severity Classification
authors: Sushil Bhardwaj, Sarabpreet Kaur, Shikha Tuteja, Ravinder Tonk, Rohit Markan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The abstract in the work presented a newly developed model that was the main goal to separate the eye diseases' kind of intensity just by pointing out the intensity of the symptoms. The evidence brought into the model shows the outstanding achievement of the model, with very stable results for all the classes that it is reaching high precision, recall, and F1 scores. As a matter of example, it got Symptom Intensity 1 at 97.01%, Symptom Intensity 2 at 97.07%, Symptom Intensity 3 at 97.09%, Symptom Intensity 4 at 97.16%, and Symptom Intensity 5 at 97.14%. There were 10,330 pictures in the dataset, and the model had an overall accuracy of 97.09%. This prototype is always capable of performing the tasks of accurately identifying and differentiating the symptoms of the condition, that the intensity. It was strongly supported by the very high accuracy of the classification tasks, as indicated by the support values, that the model is reliable and robust, as it reached 99% accuracy for all five symptom intensities. The model performs exceptionally well in terms of classification, as evidenced by the high precision and recall scores for each class, the nearly perfect F1 scores, the balanced number of 2010-2110 samples per class, and the support values being around 0.20. As a result, it is feasible to accomplish the diagnosis and cure of eye diseases at the level of precision needed by clinicians, thus the instrument becomes indispensable to them. The excellent accuracy, coupled with the model's even performance across different classes, highlights the potential of such a model to be implemented in real medical environments, thereby facilitating early detection, management, and promotion of the clinicians' decision-making process.

title: Stability Evaluation of Offshore Wind Power Transmission Systems Based on the Improved Multi-Infeed Short-Circuit Ratio
authors: Chenxu Wang, Jianing Liu, Junchao Ma, Lei Yang, Xinhai Niu, Jianyong Zhao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To support the large-scale development of offshore wind power in the mid-to-far sea and address the stability evaluation challenge of weak connection in long-distance AC submarine cables, this paper proposes an improved multi-infeed short-circuit ratio (MISCR) evaluation method that takes into account the voltage support capability of grid-forming (GFM) devices. Firstly, the equivalent transfer function model of a hybrid system is established, including the characteristics of GFM voltage sources and grid-following (GFL) current sources. Then, the improved MISCR evaluation method and its corresponding critical threshold are derived, respectively, which can analyze the capacity ratio of GFM and GFL sources on the system stability. Finally, simulation scenarios with different capacity ratios are constructed in Matlab/Simulink. The simulation results show that the proposed method can quantify the improvement effect of system stability as the capacity ratio of GFM and GFL sources increases, which can be used for configuration of GFM and GFL sources in the offshore wind farms.

title: Double-Integral Sliding-Mode Control for DAB Converters in V2V Energy Sharing
authors: Changjun Jin, Chao Wang, Yifan Liu, Hexuan Yin, Yisheng Fang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Although electric vehicles (EVs) have been vigorously promoted, the battery range issue has not been properly resolved. A feasible solution is to realize vehicle-tovehicle (V2V) energy mutual aid. However, the dual active bridge (DAB) Direct Current (DC) converter, as an intermediate converter, often suffers from unstable output voltage caused by unstable input voltage and sudden load change, making it difficult to operate with high efficiency. To this end, this paper proposes a voltage control strategy based on double integral sliding mode control, using the hyperbolic tangent function to suppress the chattering phenomenon of sliding mode control. First, a reduced-order model is derived based on the single-phase shift (SPS) power mechanism of DAB. Then, a double integral sliding surface including the first integral and the second integral is constructed, and the control law and stability analysis are derived. Finally, experimental verification shows that the proposed control strategy has better performance than the conventional sliding mode in terms of settling time, steady-state error, and robustness under parameter uncertainty.

title: Review of Microgrid Optimal Scheduling Research: Models, Methods and Prospects
authors: Zhan Zhang, Yiming Xu, Yuzhe Jin, Yongtao Yang, Xingjun Yue, Yusen Huo
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: As a key component of modern power system, the optimal scheduling of microgrid is very important to ensure energy efficiency, operation economy and system reliability. This paper aims to systematically sort out the research status and development trend of microgrid optimal scheduling. Firstly, this paper constructs a general mathematical model of optimal scheduling, and clarifies its core objective function and key constraints. On this basis, the core content of this paper focuses on solving the three core challenges of microgrid scheduling, namely uncertainty, multi-objective conflict and multi-agent coordination, and classifies and summarizes the corresponding advanced scheduling methodologies. Specifically, this paper deeply discusses the uncertainty processing technology from robust optimization to stochastic programming. The multiobjective optimization strategy for dealing with the conflict between economy, environmental protection and reliability is analyzed. The multi-agent cooperative scheduling framework based on game theory and market mechanism is systematically reviewed. At the same time, the article emphasizes the key role of methods from model predictive control (MPC) to reinforcement learning (RL) in achieving real-time decisionmaking. Finally, this paper summarizes the challenges faced in the current field, and looks forward to the important research directions in the future, such as data-driven and model fusion, digital twin and integrated energy microgrid.

title: Mid- to Long-Term Probabilistic Photovoltaic Power Forecasting Method for Plateau Regions Based on MTL-CNN-LSTM
authors: Dajun Si, Run Huang, Guangzeng You, Xinggang Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Addressing the complex forecasting challenges encountered in plateau regions, this study develops an advanced probabilistic prediction methodology for photovoltaic power systems over medium to extended time horizons. The research introduces an integrated computational framework combining Multi-Task Learning paradigms with hybrid CNN-LSTM architectures. The methodology employs MTL principles to facilitate knowledge transfer between interconnected prediction objectives, establishing photovoltaic output forecasting as the central task while incorporating solar irradiance estimation as a complementary objective to strengthen predictive capabilities. Probabilistic interval estimation is achieved through kernel density analysis to enhance forecasting reliability. Experimental validation conducted using operational data from a high-altitude photovoltaic installation in China's northwestern region during 2022-2023 reveals superior performance of the MTL-CNN-LSTM framework compared to conventional single-task CNN-LSTM approaches, demonstrating particular effectiveness in environments with significant solar radiation fluctuations. The investigation confirms that multi-task learning integration substantially improves model robustness, providing enhanced precision and dependability for photovoltaic power prediction in challenging mountainous terrain.

title: A Trajectory Planning Model for Autonomous Vehicles: Lane Change Manoeuvres Using Fuzzy Logic
authors: Ashu Nayak, Abdurakhimova Zulaykho Ikromjonkizi, N. Thangarasu, Ramee RiadHwsein, Neha Sharma, B Radha Krishna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) are critical in the automated Lane Change (LC) manoeuvre. The paper presents a developed hybrid lane-change planning model that incorporates fuzzy logic and polynomial trajectory generation. In contrast to current quintic-based approaches, which optimise only smoothness, the proposed model also employs adaptive fuzzy weighting to reduce both lateral jerk and the duration of lane changes, thereby maximising passenger comfort and vehicle stability during travel. A dual-objective goal modulates the trajectory's curvature based on dynamically varying Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) real-time communication data. The comparative simulation results indicate better performance than the traditional polynomial-only, Model Predictive Control (MPC), and Deep Q-Network (DQN) planners, with a minor trajectory deviation (I 0.2 m), lower lateral acceleration (I 0.18 g), and a stabilised yaw rate (I 5). The flexibility and accuracy of the proposed approach, as well as its usefulness in real-world autonomous driving in mixed traffic conditions, are emphasised.

title: AI-Based Traffic Prediction and Network Management: Enhancing Urban Mobility and Congestion Control through Machine Learning and Hybrid Algorithms
authors: Sripelli Jagadish, T. Sampath Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In this article, the author demonstrates AI-based forecasting and network management solutions to improve urban mobility and congestion. The combination of machine learning and bio-inspired algorithms is studied as a hybrid, and special attention is paid to combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The model proposed here uses real-time traffic information provided by the SUMO simulator to forecast congestion, optimal routing and to enhance the allocation of resources. The experimental outcomes show that the model predicts well (96.2%), 22% energy consumption, and the energy consumption of the model is lower than the baseline models (standalone LSTM and Random Forest). In addition to technical performance, the paper also addresses practical aspects of deployment such as scalability, costs of computation, and privacy issues in smart city setting. The paper identifies the contribution of AI-based solutions to the development of intelligent transportation systems (ITS) and outlines future directions including lightweight models, edge deployment, and hybrid bio-inspired reinforcement learning to provide real-world scalability and flexibility.

title: Automatic Defect Detection of Chain Link Fences Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Saksham Puri, Neha Gianchandani, Choudhury A. Rahman, Nan Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Chain link fences are used everywhere, whether it be for residential, commercial, or industrial use. These fences are used for security, safety, and boundary delineation. Once they are damaged, it is essential to replace or repair the fences as soon as possible to protect properties from unauthorized access. Typically, this process requires manual inspection to detect all damages and categorize them into specific categories, which is labor-intensive and prone to human error. In this paper, we propose an automated inspection process using anomaly detection techniques through computer vision, exploring various algorithms to address the task of detecting a variety of damages in chain link fences. Our approach includes evaluating several semantic segmentation models and analyzing the impact of design criteria such as edge detection, pre-processing, and post-processing. The results show that our proposed model utilizing the combination of IS-NET from Dichotomous Image Segmentation and Masked Autoencoder (MAE) outperforms the current approaches and effectively detects most of the defects in chain link fence images. This approach could significantly reduce human subjectivity, while minimizing the time, risk, cost, and safety aspects associated with manual inspection process.

title: Multi-varient Feature Extraction and its Late Fusion with VGG-16 based Deep Feature for Oral Cancer Detection via Multiple Classification
authors: Govind Narayan Patel, Jitesh Pradhan, B Ramachandra Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Early and accurate detection of oral cancer is essential for improving patient outcomes and enabling timely treatment. This study presents a robust classification framework that integrates handcrafted and deep learning-based features to enhance diagnostic accuracy in oral cancer detection. Handcrafted features including GLCM, DAISY, and RGB histograms are combined with deep features extracted from a pretrained VGG16 model to form a comprehensive hybrid feature vector. This vector is used to train a diverse set of models, including traditional machine learning classifiers (Random Forest, SVM, XGBoost, etc.), advanced neural architectures such as RNN variants (LSTM, GRU, Bi-LSTM, Bi-GRU), and recent deep learning models like TabNet and MLP-Mixer. Two public datasets containing clinical oral lesion images are utilized to validate the framework. The proposed approach demonstrates improved classification performance by leveraging both low-level and highlevel image representations. This work contributes to the development of intelligent and interpretable computer-aided diagnostic systems, offering potential support for early and automated oral cancer screening in real-world clinical settings.

title: Design of a Printed Yagi-Uda Antenna for Long-Range Applications in the 902-928 MHz ISM Band
authors: Ahmet Yigit Sasa, Sedat Kilinc, Mehmet Aytug Ormanci, B. Siddik Yarman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper discusses the design, fabrication, and experimental validation of a low-cost, printed Yagi-Uda antenna optimized for long-range telemetry in the $\mathbf{9 0 2 - 9 2 8 ~ M H z}$ ISM band. Using full-wave electromagnetic simulation, the element lengths and spacing were optimized to achieve a simulated peak gain of 8.65 dBi and an 11% fractional bandwidth covering $\mathbf{8 7 5 - 9 5 9 ~ M H z}$, with return loss better than -10 dB across the entire band. The antenna was constructed on standard FR-4 material via conventional PCB etching, resulting in a compact design suitable for integration into embedded wireless communication systems. Field trials conducted in a rural environment confirmed reliable bi-directional data reception over a distance of $\mathbf{2} \mathrm{km}$, demonstrating front-to-back ratios exceeding $\mathbf{2 0 ~ d B}$ at $\mathbf{9 0 0 ~ M H z}$ and stable performance under real-world conditions. These results establish the proposed printed Yagi-Uda antenna as an effective, easy-tofabricate solution for sub-GHz long-range telemetry in lowpower communication platforms and remote sensing applications.

title: Leveraging Data Analytics in NIDHI-TBI for Innovation-Driven Business Incubation
authors: Raminder Kaur Khattri, Vinay Kumar Jain, Prabh Deep Singh, Bhavna Sharma, Palki Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Technology Business Incubators (TBIs) is one of the analytical tools in encouraging creativity-driven entrepreneurship in India. This paper studies the role of TBIs which supports early stage technology startups by offering necessary facilities like infrastructure, market linkages and mentorship. This study highlights the contribution of NIDHI-TBIs regarding job creation, firm survival and commercializing ideas with the help of detailed analysis of incubators linked with elite Indian Institutions. Moreover, this research highlights the opportunity like limited industry-academia cooperation, funding limitations and the need for industry specific attention. Recommendations for a more integrated legislative framework, improved public-private partnerships and performance benchmarking to guide the incubation ecosystem throughout the report. This article emphasizes the strategic importance of TBIs in developing a flexible and innovation-driven entrepreneurial ecosystem in emerging economies such as India.

title: Comparative Analysis of Harmonic Injection Based Excitation Topologies in High Power Brushless Wound Field Synchronous Motors for EVs
authors: Surajit Saha, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: The Brushless Wound Field Synchronous Motor (BLWFSM) offers a promising alternative to Permanent Magnet (PM) machines for electric vehicle (EV) powertrains, particularly due to its cost-effectiveness and reduced reliance on rare-earth materials. This study focuses on improving the efficiency of a 50 kW BLWFSM by employing harmonic injection-based field excitation techniques. Multiple excitation topologies are investigated and compared, with emphasis on their impact on overall efficiency, torque capability and power density-critical parameters for high performance EV applications. Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations are performed using ANSYS Maxwell to evaluate and validate the performance of each topology.

title: Evaluation of AEAD Cryptographic Algorithms in an MQTT-Based IoT Tracking System
authors: Geva Almer Hariri, Favian Dewanta, Sri Astuti
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) technology has become widely utilized in various domains, including real-time location tracking systems that rely on sensor data and wireless communication. However, transmitting sensitive information over public networks raises serious security concerns. To address these issues, AEAD (Authenticated Encryption with Associated Data) algorithms such as AES-GCM, ChaCha20-Poly1305, and Ascon are implemented to ensure both data confidentiality and integrity. This study evaluates five main aspects which include encryption and decryption processing time, the efficiency of the encrypted payload size, the effectiveness of data obfuscation based on Wireshark packet capture analysis, avalanche effect strength, and memory utilization. The results show that ChaCha20-Poly1305 delivers the fastest performance, Ascon produces the smallest payload and requires the least memory, while AES-GCM offers the strongest avalanche effect with a balanced trade-off between speed and data size. All algorithms successfully obscure message contents, making them suitable for secure and efficient IoT-based tracking systems.

title: Enhancing Noise Immunity in Mixed-Signal Circuits for Biomedical Applications
authors: Parvindar Kaur Chhabda, R. Padmavathy, Hassan Mohamed, Pemmireddy Naga Surya Venkata Tejaswini, G. Ravivarman, B.N. Karimov, Mamasidikova Naima Tokhirjon kizi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The other important elements of biomedical applications are mixed-signal integrated circuits; these permit communication between analog signal-acquisition and digital processing on a chip. This monolithic integration was needed in such applications as ECG, EEG, and implantable telemonitoring due to the optimization of space and power consumption, and the quality of signals. The close range between the digital and analog domain is required to obtain a high SNR and the extremely large subsate noise can generally lower the signal integrity, and also lead to poor diagnosis or monitoring accuracy. Traditional types of fixed or statical isolation, such as fixed guard rings and substrate contact, have a disadvantage of being unable to accommodate dynamic noise, and have an area or power cost often. To reduce the constraints, the more advanced real-time adaptive substratebiasing isolation technique is proposed in this article. The plan exploits dynamical biased guard rings that have a frame maintenance by real-time substrate noise observation and in system machine learning predicting noise contributions based on circuit activity and environmental stimulus feed-back. This method is also useful since the massaging of isolation structures are anticipated in advance and therefore, it does not topographically increase any latency or overhead to whatsoever has been discussed on the reduction of periodic and transient substrate noise. As demonstrated using the simulation and the prototype performance, the specified approach would produce a significantly more desirable outcome when it comes to the noise suppression, relative to what the static schemes would present, perhaps by up to 35 per cent, judging by the signal-to-noise ratio. Moreover, the system has many opportunities of being produced with standard CMOS and possesses minimal extra-layout complexity, offering further procedures to apply the architecture to the following generation of medicine-related SoCs. One of the main breakthroughs of this adaptive isolation technique relates to the acquisition of signals, which should be reliable due to the ability to achieve reliance on real-time acquisition, in the circumstances when biology is vulnerable to noise.

title: CareerForge-AI: Graph Neural Network for Predicting Employee Performance and Personalized Career Paths
authors: Sabar Aritonang Rajagukguk
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Traditional human resource management systems fail to capture the dynamic nature of modern workplace relationships and evolving skill requirements, resulting in 47% annual turnover rates and significant skill gaps. This paper presents CareerForge-AI, a novel multi-dimensional graph neural network framework that models complex workplace ecosystems to predict employee performance trajectories and generate personalized career development pathways. Our framework combines Graph Attention Networks (GAT) with transformer architectures to process heterogeneous workplace data, including collaboration networks, skill dependencies, and career transitions. We evaluate CareerForge-AI on a comprehensive dataset from a mid-sized technology company with 178 employees over 24 months, comprising 8,544 performance records and 4,450 project assignments. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements: 87% accuracy in 6-month performance prediction, 91% precision in identifying at-risk employees, and 84% success rate in recommended career transitions. The framework reduces regrettable turnover by 40% and improves internal mobility by 35%. Our contributions include: (1) the first GNN-based architecture for holistic career development, (2) a novel temporal graph construction method capturing evolving workplace dynamics, (3) an explainable AI module providing actionable insights for HR professionals, and (4) built-in fairness mechanisms preventing bias amplification. This work advances intelligent human capital management systems and supports sustainable organizational development.

title: LungListener: Bootstrapping a Large-Scale Audio-Language Model for Lung Sound Classification and Analysis
authors: Zhenghan Liao, Guofeng Luo, Haolun Yan, Jiaru Wang, Shiyi Zhang, Jinzhun Wu, Rongshan Yu, Liang Xu, Longbiao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The prevalence of respiratory diseases is rising among the population, highlighting the need for greater attention to respiratory health. Lung sound classification is crucial for the diagnosis of respiratory diseases. Traditional lung sound classification methods often lack interpretability and typically focus solely on audio data, neglecting valuable metadata. To address this, we propose LungListener, a framework that bootstraps a large-scale audio-language model to integrate lung sound audio data and patient metadata for accurate lung sound classification. Specifically, we adapt the model to lung sound analysis by introducing joint reasoning over audio and metadata, and training it on a carefully constructed task-specific dataset, which significantly enhances its domain understanding. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to apply a large-scale audio-language model to lung sound classification, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the ICBHI respiratory sound database surpassing previous results by 0.28%. Additionally, we evaluate our framework on a dataset from Xiamen Maternal and Child Health Hospital, demonstrating good performance. Finally, we develop a home-based lung sound monitoring system, enabling users to conveniently monitor their respiratory health.

title: Facial Skin Disease Classification using EfficientNetV2B0 with Attention-Based BiGRU
authors: Nurul Ilmi, Siti Zahrotul Fajriyah, Erin Haryani, Ikram Mahesa Daratullah
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Currently, At present, facial skin diseases require early detection but due to limited number of dermatologists and many different kinds of skin diseases diagnosis process is difficult. Therefore, a classification method based on images is needed. In this study, the EfficientNetV2B0 model of Attention-Based BiGRU is proposed for facial skin disease classification. EfficientNetV2B0 is used to extract spatial features, with the BiGRU attention mechanism capturing sequential relationships between patches, indicating related lesion features. To ensure that this method remains stable and effective on smaller datasets, token reduction, channel projection, and SE blocks are used to strengthen this approach. In addition, these methods are all relatively simple and widely used, making them reliable in essence. The experimental results show that with five varieties of skin disease as indicators The proposed EfficientNetV2B0 model with Attention-Based BiGRU achieves 79% accuracy, which is better than the best baseline (ResNet50, 74%) and improved the EfficientNetV2B0 model itself (67%). The evaluation results show the integration of the CNN (EfficientNetV2B0) based on BiGRU and attention mechanism can significantly improve Facial Skin Disease Classification performance with the McNemar test (p < 0.05).

title: Design and Hardware Implementation of an H-Bridge DC-DC Converter for Power Supply Applications
authors: Kavin Mathalai, Linda Mary Zacharia, Nabivullah Syed, Farhan Ahmad Khan, Harish Sudhakaran Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Compared to the conventional buck-boost topologies such as the standard buck-boost converter, SEPIC, and cascaded designs, the H-bridge topology achieves higher efficiency due to its direct power transfer capability, and minimal number of reactive components. These features make it particularly well-suited for power supply applications requiring programmable output voltages and compact implementation.
