This paper presents the complete design, simulation, and hardware implementation of a DC-DC H-bridge power converter intended for regulated power supply applications. The converter is modeled and the performance is validated in MATLAB/Simulink, by including key non-idealities such as switch and passive component parasitics. A prototype was fabricated using discrete components, considering gate drive circuitry and isolated power supply requirements. Experimental results are presented to show the functionality of the converter and highlight various implementation challenges, such as inductor core saturation, which was mitigated by introducing an air gap. This work contributes a practical prototype and educational resource for understanding H-bridge power converter design and its advantages for power supply applications.

title: High-Speed, Low-Power ADC Design Leveraging Emerging Material Interfaces for Terahertz Signal Processing xApplications
authors: P Venkatapathi, B. Premalatha, K. Bharath Kumar, S Sudhakar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This work proposes a new high-speed, low-power analogue-to-digital converter (ADC) architecture, namely the Graphene-Plasmonic Interface Enabled Dual-Domain ADC (GPI-DDADC), specifically designed for terahertz (THz) signal processing applications. Even traditional ADCs are limited to high-frequency ranges in the THz range due to the inherent limitations of the charge-mode, including switching speed, heat dissipation, and silicon scaling. To address these issues, the proposed architecture relies on emerging material interfaces, combining graphene plasmonic modulators with opto-electronic quantisation layers of phase-change materials. This exotic hybrid system utilises graphene's ultrafast carrier mobility and Ge2Sb2Te5 (GST) refractive index tunability to achieve high-speed analogue-to-digital conversion with a low energy overhead. It presents a dual-domain quantisation method that jointly encodes signal data in the electrical and optical domains, thereby doubling bandwidth utilisation and reducing conversion latency. Moreover, ferroelectric nanomaterials are utilised at the memory level to achieve zero standby power through remanent polarisation, thereby replacing conventional CMOS latches. Simulation data show a maximum sampling rate of 200 GS/s, a power consumption of less than 30 mW, and an effective number of bits (ENOB) of up to 8, which is more than 40 per cent faster and 60 per cent more energy-efficient than state-of-the-art THz ADCs. The suggested GPI-DDADC architecture has the potential to enable miniaturised, low-power, high-resolution ADCs for 6G communication systems, high-frequency biomedical imaging, and next-generation radar systems. The work represents a paradigm shift away from silicon-based solutions towards hybrid electronic-photonic ADCs that leverage new material science to meet the requirements of next-generation ultra-broadband systems. This work reports system-level performance of the proposed GPI-DDADC architecture, achieving an effective sampling rate of 200 GS/s with on-chip power below 30 mW. The corresponding energy-per-conversion is approximately 150 fJ/sample when normalized to the full system rate. Monte-Carlo PVT simulations confirm an ENOB of 8 ± 0.12 bits, with measurable SNDR and SFDR improvements under dual-domain arbitration. All performance metrics and statistical confidence intervals are detailed in the Results section.

title: Prediction Method for Motor Main Insulation Breakdown Voltage Based on CHMM-GBDT Hybrid Model
authors: Yingqi Lu, Jiajin Wang, Xiaoyan Huang, Youtong Fang, Jian Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Breakdown voltage is a characteristic parameter characterizing the aging state of motor main insulation and is the direct cause affecting motor lifespan. To address the difficulty of online measurement of motor main insulation breakdown voltage, this paper proposes a hybrid model based on Continuous Hidden Markov Model (CHMM) and Gradient Boosting Decision Tree (GBDT), named CHMM-GBDT. This model captures the dynamic state evolution characteristics of the insulation aging process through CHMM. It integrates the dynamic state features with four non-destructive observable quantities—insulation resistance, insulation capacitance, dielectric loss tangent, and maximum discharge magnitude—to construct enhanced features. Based on these enhanced features, the breakdown voltage prediction model is built using GBDT. The results demonstrate that this hybrid model achieves high accuracy in predicting breakdown voltage.

title: A General Dynamic Channel Compression Framework for Feature Fusion in Self-Supervised Monocular Depth Estimation
authors: Ronghua Wu, Yuanyao Lu, Zhenzhao Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Depth estimation plays a vital role in various fields such as autonomous driving, 3D reconstruction, virtual reality, and robotics. Taking self-supervised monocular depth estimation as an example, existing methods commonly enhance multi-scale information transmission through dense cross-layer feature fusion techniques, such as skip connections and channel concatenation. However, these operations often lead to increased feature dimensionality and computational redundancy. Moreover, indiscriminate fusion of low- and high-level features tends to introduce noise, thereby degrading the edge sharpness and geometric consistency of the predicted depth maps. To address these issues, this paper proposes a general-purpose dynamic channel compression framework tailored for feature fusion. A task-oriented channel selection strategy is employed to reduce redundancy while preserving critical information. Specifically, the proposed framework includes a dynamic threshold generation network that determines sample-adaptive retention thresholds based on the distribution of channel-wise standard deviations. Furthermore, a probabilistic L0 gating mechanism is introduced, which relaxes the discrete channel selection problem into a continuous optimization via a hard shrinkage function. The design is attention-free and easily integrable into existing architectures. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that our method achieves a 10%–30% reduction in parameter count across multiple depth estimation models, with accuracy degradation of less than 1%.

title: Implicit Representation of Multispectral Images in Autonomous Driving
authors: Yiting Xu, Jiaxuan Shi, Xia Hua
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient method for hyperspectral image representation and compression specifically designed for autonomous driving applications. Our model incorporates two key innovations: the Fourier Implicit Enhancement Module and High-Frequency Residual Connection, which together enhance feature representation in the frequency domain. This approach effectively captures both structural characteristics and intensity information, enabling the decoder to reconstruct high-quality images with improved fidelity. Experimental evaluations on road spectral datasets spanning 400-1700nm wavelengths demonstrate superior performance compared to existing neural representation methods. Our approach achieves better results on standard image quality metrics including PSNR and MS-SSIM. Notably, the proposed method exhibits exceptional performance at low bit rates, making it particularly suitable for resource-constrained autonomous driving systems where bandwidth and storage limitations are significant concerns. The compression efficiency combined with high-fidelity spectral reconstruction capabilities addresses a critical need in autonomous driving applications, where accurate spectral information processing must be balanced with practical system constraints. Our results demonstrate that frequency domain enhancement provides an effective pathway for optimizing hyperspectral image compression while maintaining the detailed spectral information necessary for reliable autonomous driving perception.

title: Virtual Power Plant Optimal Scheduling Method Based on Temporal Fusion Transformer-Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient
authors: Jianying Sun, Liang Cheng, Huannian Jiao, Xiaoxuan Qi, Pengyang Duan, Zheng Dai
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Focusing on the complexity of real-time scheduling for Virtual Power Plants (VPPs) due to source-load volatility and rigorous security constraints, this study develops a novel optimal dispatch approach employing the Temporal Fusion Transformer-Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TFT-DDPG) algorithm. Initially, a holistic optimization framework is established with the goal of minimizing the overall operating expenditure. This framework integrates the operating constraints specific to diverse resources, including distributed generation units, energy storage systems (ESSs), and demand response programs. The VPP optimal dispatch challenge is subsequently recast as a Constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP). Subsequently, a hybrid intelligent solution algorithm integrating TFT and DDPG is proposed. This approach utilizes the TFT's strong ability to process multi-source time-series data and capture long-term correlations, significantly improving state perception for the scheduling agent. The DDPG, incorporating a Lagrangian dual function for constraint satisfaction, is used to optimize the continuous control actions. Furthermore, a new experience replay mechanism prioritizing temporal correlation is introduced to enhance training stability and efficiency. Case studies utilizing real operational data from a site in Qinghai, China, confirm that the proposed TFT-DDPG algorithm is capable of generating effective real-time scheduling decisions. This method offers a robust solution for securing the safe, economical, and operationally efficient management of VPPs in highly complex scenarios.

title: On Disturbance Observer-Based Control for DC-DC Boost Power Converters with Restricted Input
authors: German De La Cruz, Mizraim Martinez-Lopez, Marco Moran-Armenta, Javier Moreno-Valenzuela
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: In this work, a disturbance observer (DO) is proposed for the control of DC-DC boost converters. The DO is designed to ensure robustness against disturbances such as load variations and input voltage fluctuations. This article addresses the lack of DO designs specifically for input-constrained power boost converters by providing a framework that improves robustness. The stability of the DO integrated with a passivity-based controller, previously reported in the literature, is analyzed, and its performance is validated through real-time experiments. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed disturbance observer-based controller enhances disturbance rejection and improves voltage regulation compared to the controller without the proposed observer.

title: Analyzing Vulnerabilities in Academic Network Servers: A Foundation for AI-Driven Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Vikas Sharma, Puneet Chauhan, Tarun Kumar Vashishth, Sachin Kaushik, Priyanka Rana, Kajal Chaudhary
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Server systems in academic settings have increasingly been the focus of cyber threats due in part to legacy configurations and weak authentication policies, and weak cybersecurity infrastructure. Through a systematic process of vulnerability scanning, configuration audits and log analysis across several academic institutions, their findings revealed significant vulnerabilities, particularly relating to legacy software, SQL injection vectors, and misconfigured firewalls. Their results indicate that 57% of vulnerabilities discovered were high risk (CVSS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 8.0$</tex>) and that the two areas leading to the highest risk were weak access control and unpatched services. These findings provide a baseline for the subsequent implementation of an AI-based intrusion detection system that is tailored for the needs of academic institutions. Findings suggest that undertaking proactive vulnerability analysis is a critical first step prior to designing intelligent and adaptive network defence systems.

title: Discovering Proxy Systems to Test Critical AI Systems: A Metadata-Driven Software Similarity Approach
authors: Mark Kennedy, Joanna F. DeFranco, Phillip A. Laplante
publish: Computer
abstract: This article describes a practical approach for finding “software twins,” noncritical proxy systems that mirror critical artificial intelligence-enabled systems and can be safely abused during testing, even when proprietary source code cannot be accessed for direct comparison.

title: Leveraging Deep Progressive Reinforcement Learning and Feature Learning Techniques for Vietnamese Sign Language Recognition
authors: Doan-Tung Duong, Thi-Huong Nguyen, Nguyen Thi Thanh Tam, Van-Toi Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: We introduce a method based on Deep Progressive Reinforcement Learning to recognize isolated Vietnamese sign language. Our proposed method extracts information frames from our own RGB video dataset and utilize reinforcement learning based on the Asynchronous Advantage ActorCritic (A3C) model to model frame selection. We modify the original structure using 3D convolutional neural network (Conv3D) to adapt to video input and integrate Inflated 3D (I3D) and Separable 3D (S3D) convolutional networks into the model architecture to enhance recognition quality. The experimental results help us acquire insightful observations and better directions for solving sign language recognition problems.

title: Bird Sound Detection Using Convolution Neural Networks
authors: Deepa K, Mohankumar B, Jeyapriyadarshini S, Chadunduraa N, Sharmaatha N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Bird sound detection provides valuable insights into regional biodiversity, supporting the development of effective conservation strategies through monitoring of bird population densities, migration patterns, and overall biodiversity. Our methodology converts bird audio recordings into Mel spectrograms, which are then utilized as input for a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model. This deep learning approach enables the CNN to learn discriminative features from the spectrograms, leading to accurate classification of bird species calls. Our novel system, employing CNNs, achieves an accuracy rate on the training dataset and an 84% accuracy rate on the validation dataset. Implemented as a web-based interface, this model predicts the bird species from audio recordings, providing a scalable and powerful tool for ecological research and conservation efforts. This system enhances our understanding of avian biodiversity and supports targeted conservation initiatives. Furthermore, its adaptability allows for application in various ecological contexts, facilitating large-scale environmental monitoring. The integration of this technology can significantly advance our knowledge of avian populations and contribute to more effective biodiversity conservation strategies.

title: Leader Selection in Platooning of Autonomous Vehicles Using Machine Learning
authors: Patel Ayush Hiteshkumar, Modh Om Gaurangbhai, Darshan Patel, Sudha Anbalagan, Suganeshwari G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The rapid advancements of connected vehicles has made to present a novel approach of autonomous vehicle platooning systems with a platoon head. With the help of feature engineering, data preprocessing, and ensemble learning methods of machine learning methodologies, we were able to achieve effective and improved leadership scores for vehicles within the platoon. The paper utilizes Platoon Formation Simulator (PlaFoSim), which is a scalable Python based simulator, to obtain accurate freeway scenarios for platoon formation and also able to generate synthetic and robust dataset for the research work. The research work shows an increased performance using the generated datasets for vehicle traces and platoon traces, by further utilizing XG Boost and Random Forest models in combination under a Voting Regressor for better performance. By ensuring the optimum leader selection based on critical criteria such as platoon time, vehicle type, acceleration and communication range, our strategy improves autonomous vehicle platoon decision-making. This model improves the platoon formation with an appropriate leader selection that can be used in the real-world intelligent transportation systems.

title: Analysis of Blockchain with AI Integration for Autonomous Internet of Thing
authors: Pooja Yadav, Karan Bajaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Blockchain, and the Internet of Things (IoT) is increasingly being recognized as a productive framework for enhancing the availability, scalability, and efficiency of a range of domains. This study is a comparative review and analysis of a range of research wo exploring distinct areas of the integration of AI, Blockchain and IoT. The research discusses the implementation methods and optimizations used and the factors considered when utilizing the technology. The findings demonstrate that AI enables automation, decision making, and blockchain transaction anomaly detection. Blockchain's decentralized security model assures data integrity, while IoT functionality can help navigate some of the issues around real time data acquisition and communication. Additionally, the research concludes that scalability, interoperability, computation costs, and security remain considerable concerns to widespread adoption. This review identifies diverse feature extraction methodologies taken across a number of papers, including: cryptographic hashing, decentralized identity verification, statistical models to deep learning features. The performance results of each paper suggest that specific AI optimization strategies such as hybrid AI models, machine learning based frameworks for decision making, and cryptographic consensus mechanisms yield better performance in terms of security, processing time, and fraud reduction.

title: Cross-Modal Neural Networks for Real-Time Multisensory Information Fusion in Smart Healthcare
authors: Anushree Shrivastava, Umarova Nigorakhon Kholmatovna, S. Kannimuthu, Haydeer MohamadAbbas, Diksha Thakur, Thella Preethi Priyanka
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In the age of intelligent healthcare, fast multisensory information fusion at rates beyond real-time is crucial to perform accurate diagnosis, patient monitoring, and emergency response. However, traditional fusion techniques cannot handle heterogeneous medical data, real-time processing, or provide security to data. To integrate multimodal healthcare data that includes medical imaging, biosignals, environmental sensors, wearable data, this paper proposes an Adaptive Cross-Modal Neural Network (ACMNN), based on a new approach to building deep learning framework, a deep learning framework. To afford intermodal feature extraction and synchronization, a Latent Space Alignment (LSA) Module is designed to ensure feature matching and synchronization using a Hybrid TransformerCNN Fusion Framework with a Cross attention mechanism. A self-supervised contrastive learning module is integrated to increase robustness and to allow feature discrimination with little supervision. Moreover, to embed the privacy of medical data in the training algorithms, the model applies multi-agent reinforcement learning for dynamic decisions in general and blockchain integrated federated learning for private, decentralized training across multiple healthcare institutions. Deployment of the Edge AI on the 5G enabled devices achieves real-time processing as it decreases the latency and the resource consumption in the wearable devices. The proposal results experimentally prove its superiority as a diagnostic approach in terms of accuracy, and speed of computations, as well as its security. It enables the next generation of AI-driven healthcare systems capable of secure, real-time, and intelligent decision making for the benefits of patients as well as the operational efficiency of environments in which medical care is offered.

title: Real-Time XR Simulation for Emergency Medical Response Training
authors: Muntader Mhsnhasan, Dinesh Kumar Sahu, R. Venkatasubramanian, Veedhi Sravani Kumari, R. Nallakumar, Muhidinov Ayubbek Nuritdinovich, I.N. Aslanov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: EMR training requires a realistic, repeat, and scalable simulation that may adequately prepare the providers to practice in environment under high-stress variable environments, and in highly complex environment. The suggested solution is introduced as a new viable comprehensive solution in this paper and comprised of real-time Extended Reality (XR); that are an integration of Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR) and Mixed Reality (MR) to be implemented to provide life-like immersion simulations of the emergency medical response exercises. The research critique uses a critical critique of the current XR applications used with Emergency Medical Service (EMS) education, and the incidence of the current limitations, which include lack of physiological feedback, bad interactivity, and scales. As a response to the above-mentioned cases, we can offer an AI-based and multi-user real time XR simulation model, which can have its complexity accessed depending on trainee actions, as well as its ability to react to decision-making and indicators of real-time stresses (e.g., heart rate, eye-tracking, and the voice can be modulated). It is an embodiment of adaptive mechanism of what causes training in a group more realistic, or rather more individually-determined in diverse emergency setting; the high-tech framework is, thus, adapted to train a registered company of individuals and be better prepared to an emergency that seems to have involved great number of casualties. It will be powered by commodity hardware (e.g. XR headsets; standards-compliant AR-instance tablet customizable to some level) and will be developed as a standards-compliant modular architecture, in a manner that will simplify the task of updating, its possible customization of situations, and deploying it to other institutions. Along with technical viability, the solution is highly orientated on better decision-making, arousal inoculation, psychological preparedness, training expenses, risks and logistics compared to the utilization of simulation to train the conventional approach of training group-wise. The platform abreast with the changing requirements in the training of medical responders and act as an indicator on straight road to medical responder training: a novel medical responder training, that is immersive, evidence-based and repeatable to both urban and rural location.

title: GSP-SLAM: Dense Reconstruction of Visual SLAM Based on an Improved 3D Gaussian*
authors: Jiangyan Zou, Huiyan Zhang, Hao Sun, Xianqiang Yang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Visual Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) holds significant application value in fields such as robotics and augmented reality. However, its performance is often constrained by the scene representation method. This paper proposes a dense reconstruction approach based on an improved 3D Gaussian representation, aiming to address the challenges of initialization in textureless regions and the inefficiency of optimization in existing methods. This paper incorporates a progressive propagation strategy into the densification process of 3D Gaussians. By integrating scene geometric priors with block-matching techniques, it dynamically generates Gaussian distributions with precise positions and orientations, thereby significantly enhancing reconstruction quality. Compared with traditional splitting and cloning strategies, the proposed method effectively handles textureless regions in large-scale scenes and enables efficient structured map expansion. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves significant improvements in camera pose estimation, map reconstruction, and novel view synthesis.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Unified Load Forecasting and Optimal Dispatch in Smart Grids
authors: Hongbo Zhang, Caolu Shi, Yisheng Fang, Sihan Du
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: High renewable penetration and mass demand-side resources turn traditional grids into highly stochastic cyber-physical networks. “Predict first, optimize later” pipelines propagate forecasting errors into suboptimal decisions and cannot adapt to non-stationary loads. We propose a unified deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework that concurrently learns probabilistic load forecasts and computes multi-time-scale scheduling under operational constraints. A lightweight Transformer encoder outputs Gaussian load envelopes; the moments are embedded into the state vector of a constrained proximal-policy-optimization (PPO) agent that produces discrete-continuous hybrid actions for batteries, EV chargers and capacitor banks. The whole system is modeled as a constrained Markov decision process (CMDP) and trained by a Lagrangian-based PPO variant that guarantees zero constraint violation after finite updates. Simulations on the IEEE 33-bus active distribution network with one-year 5min metering data from the Danish Bornholm grid reduce the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4}$</tex>-h load-forecast MAPE from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 8}$</tex>% to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 1}$</tex>% and cut annual operational expenditure by 12.7% versus the best two-stage benchmark, while keeping voltage within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 5 \%$</tex> under all scenarios.

title: Confidence-Aware 3D Gaze Tracking and Assessment Metric
authors: Qiaojie Zheng, Jiucai Zhang, Xiaoli Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Knowing the level of confidence in appearance-based gaze tracking is critical for informing the downstream decision-making process. Due to the lack of gaze tracking confidence ground truth, most existing methods can only provide an approximated confidence by estimating prediction uncertainty associated with gaze tracking prediction. In this work, we proposed a confidence-aware gaze tracking framework based on heteroskedastic regression to more accurately estimate prediction uncertainty for better confidence awareness. In addition, we also introduced a novel assessment metric based on the causal relationship between eye feature degradation severity and confidence drop to judge the performance of confidence awareness. This metric provides a fairer assessment of confidence awareness than the existing metric that depends on a spurious correlation between prediction error and confidence. With experiments from two open source gaze tracking datasets, we have demonstrated the potential of the proposed confidence-aware gaze tracking structure.

title: Wideband Antipodal Vivaldi Antenna Integrated with GRIN Lens for High-Gain and Wide-Angle Dynamic Beam Scanning in Ka-Band
authors: Khalida Khodja, Imen Merabet, Aicha Gherbi, Idris Messaoudene, Massinissa Belazzoug, Salim Atia
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: In this work we present the design and performance analysis of a wideband antipodal Vivaldi antenna (AVA) integrated with a Gradient-Index (GRIN) dielectric lens for high- gain, wide-angle beam scanning at Ka-band frequencies. The antenna, fabricated on a Rogers RT/duroid 5880 substrate, is aligned at the center focal plane of a GRIN lens, enabling wave collimation and a notable enhancement in antennas directivity. The integration of the lens results in a notable gain improvement (from 7 dBi to 20 dBi) demonstrating a 13 dB enhancement. Furthermore, by laterally displacing the antenna element with respect to the lens center by an offset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{5 ~ m m}, \pm \mathbf{1 0 ~ m m}, \pm \mathbf{1 5 ~ m m}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{2 0 ~ m m}$</tex>, a continuous beam scanning range from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-58^{\circ}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+58^{\circ}$</tex> is achieved without the need for complex circuitry or phase shifters. The proposed configuration offers a compact, high-performance solution suitable for next-generation Ka-band covering applications in satellite links, imaging radar, and high-data-rate wireless systems.

title: On the Effective Fault-Ride Through Operation of Grid-Forming Inverters Under Asymmetrical Faults in Low-Inertia AC Microgrids
authors: Ahmed Kouzou, Muhammad F. Umar, Sertac Bayhan, Hussein Alnuweiri, Haitham Abu-Rub
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Grid-forming inverter-based resources (GFM-IBRs) are playing a key role in realizing 100 % renewable energy-based power grid due to their inherent advantages, such as virtual inertia emulation, frequency regulation, and voltage support. However, the fault-ride through (FRT) and stable operation in post-fault conditions, particularly under asymmetrical faults, is a major challenge. The unbalance between phases induces negative sequence current, and if not effectively controlled, it leads to double-line frequency oscillations in output of GFM-IBRs. Moreover, the limited fault-current capability of GFM-IBRs necessitates an overcurrent limiting mechanism to protect the power-electronic based switching devices. Thus, this paper presents a novel control framework that ensures robust operation of GFM-IBRs during asymmetrical and in post-fault conditions. The proposed control scheme incorporates a fault detection module (FDM) to identify the start and end of asymmetrical faults, and a modified virtual impedance-based overcurrent limiter that suppresses the negative sequence current and restricts the fault current within safe threshold. The effectiveness of the proposed control for GFM-IBRs is validated through various cases and benchmarked against the conventional current saturation-based overcurrent limiting approach.

title: Sequential Switching Strategy for DFIG Fault Ride-Through Considering Reactive Power Support
authors: Qishan Xu, Weijun Teng, Feng Zhang, Xin Sun, Junshui Hu, Yuming Liao, Heng Nian
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: As wind power integration continues to grow, maintaining the low-voltage ride-through (LVRT) capability of doubly-fed induction generator (DFIG) during grid voltage dips plays a crucial role in maintaining the grid’s stability and reliability. The electromagnetic transient process of a DFIG under three-phase short-circuit conditions is examined, and the rotor transiently induced electromotive force ( EMF ) is identified as the key factor leading to rotor overcurrent. By analyzing the coupling between stator flux linkage and rotor induced EMF, a feedforward compensation scheme is developed. In this method, the transient component of rotor control voltage derived from stator flux is implemented via the rotor side converter (RSC) to counteract transient EMF and minimize rotor current overshoot. In addition, considering timing constraints in the RSC control, a reactive power compensation target is superimposed during the fault period to provide effective voltage support at the grid connection point. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated using simulation studies carried out in MATLAB/Simulink.

title: Label Semantic and Sample Relationship Collaborative Learning for Domain Adaptation
authors: Zhen Wang, Shaohua Teng, Zefeng Zheng, Wei Zhang, Peipei Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Domain adaptation aims to transfer knowledge from the source domain to the target domain. However, transfer performance remains limited by two key issues: a) semantic relationships are often overlooked when exploring similarity between samples, and b) low-confidence pseudo-labels are not properly corrected, which affects subsequent iterations. To address these issues, we propose a method called Label Semantic and Sample Relationship Collaborative Learning (LSSRC), which consists of two core components: Composite Similarity Learning (CSL) and Consistent Neighborhood Pseudo-Label Refinement (CNPR). First, CSL measures the similarity between a sample and its neighbors by weighing feature similarity and semantic relevance, aiming to leverage class centers to rectify the learning of sample relationships. Second, CNPR introduces a correction strategy based on the semantic knowledge of target sample neighborhoods. It refines low-confidence pseudo-labels after each iteration, effectively reducing error accumulation. In addition, we introduce an Adaptive Neighborhood Reconstruction Embedding (ANRE) method to minimize reconstruction residuals when projected samples are represented by their neighbors, thereby enhancing the integration of cross-domain samples. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms existing advanced methods in terms of performance.

title: Design and Implementation of Smart Compiled PLC Based on Real-Time Operating System
authors: Xiaorui Hu, Minglei Bao, Feng Yue, Bei Dong, Shaowei Liu, Kai Wu, Wei Shang, Lin Ding, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Based on introduction and analysis of current commercial and open-source PLC solutions, a schema of smart compiled PLC based on RTOS (Real-Time Operating System) is proposed. In this schema, the PC-side configuration tool is introduced which is responsible for configuration of variable level and application development. Then runtime based on RTOS is discussed including basic function and the mechanism of task scheduler. After this, the workflow of overall schema is described to generate the final firmware binary file. Finally by using extra IoT(Internet of Things) modules, the PLC is can be extended as IoT terminal node or IoT gateway. At last, based on modular controller, some application demonstration is given to verify the effectiveness and performance of runtime, and the statistical and measurement results explained the effectiveness of the scheme, which is suitable for application with millisecond-level.

title: The resilience of social media users against Generative AI-based visual manipulation: A survey among Hungarian Facebook users
authors: Peter Banyasz, Laszlo Gulyas, Tamas Szadeczky, Kincso Boroka Banyasz-Vaczi
publish: Proceedings of the Central and Eastern European eDem and eGov Days 2025
abstract: None

title: GEM-AI: A Generative AI Driven Zero-Shot Method for Group Emotion Recognition
authors: Pasquale Molinaro, Giancarlo Fortino
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: In recent years, AI models have demonstrated a growing ability to interpret complex human behavior, including emotional states. While vision-language models (VLMs) have shown significant capabilities in this area, their application to group emotion recognition remains a challenging task. This challenge is compounded by the limitations of traditional evaluation metrics, which, due to their binary logic, fail to capture the nuanced semantic relationships between different emotional states. To address this evaluation gap, our work pioneers a systematic method for evaluating cohesive group emotion, moving beyond the simple aggregation of individual states. We achieve this within a zero-shot paradigm, establishing a lightweight baseline that eliminates the need for model fine-tuning. We present GEM-AI: a group-based Emotion recognition method, a novel group emotion detection framework based on semantic similarity. We apply this framework to a comparative study of several open-source VLMs, including LLaVA, MiniCPM, Deepseek-VL, and Qwen-VL, by reformulating precision, recall, and F1-score into “soft metrics” for a more semantically coherent assessment. Our results demonstrate that, when assessed with the GEM-AI framework, these models achieve high performance, reaching semantic accuracy of approximately 80%. This reveals a sophisticated comprehension of group emotion that is significantly underestimated by conventional metrics, which achieved only around 60% accuracy in our experiments.

title: Mapping-Guided Optimization Framework for Low-Sidelobe Sparse Antenna Arrays via Quadrant Amplitude Mapping
authors: Chunyang Teng, Yi Zhang, Shiyong Li, Zixiang Ye, Houjun Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Large‐aperture antenna arrays promise fine angular resolution, but their dense layouts usually lead to prohibitive cost and design complexity. Sparse arrays present a compelling alternative, yet their design typically depends on computationally intensive and numerically unstable optimization methods that are prone to local minima. In this paper, we first propose a deterministic and region-partitioning algorithm, referred to as Quadrant-Amplitude Mapping (QAM), which recursively divides the aperture into quadrants and directly maps a given amplitude taper to element positions. In 30 independent trials, QAM reduces the standard deviation of the peak SLL by 67.4% relative to conventional density-weighted mapping, effectively eliminating stochastic variability. Building on QAM, we further develop a mapping-guided sparse-array optimization framework that embeds position selection within the amplitude-weight refinement loop. Compared with direct position optimization, the proposed framework achieves 9.9 dB lower sidelobes within 60 minutes of computation, and outperforms the existing weight-first mapping approach by 4.97 dB after 20 iterations. The proposed strategy offers a fast and robust solution for designing low-sidelobe sparse arrays. Moreover, it can be extended to the design of arrays with arbitrary or non-uniform apertures, offering a cost-effective solution for next-generation high-resolution sensing systems.

title: Cost-Efficient Service Function Chain Deployment in Satellite Optical Networks
authors: Tianhao Liu, Xin Li, Yongjun Zhang, Chenyu Zhao, Xuhao Yan, Shanguo Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: With the development of on-board processing (OBP) and inter-satellite laser links (ISLL), satellite optical networks (SONs) can serve as a complement to terrestrial optical networks (TONs), providing computing and communication services for Internet of Things (IoT) users in remote areas. To improve flexibility in IoT service delivery, network function virtualization (NFV) has been integrated into the SON, where IoT services can be abstracted as service function chains (SFCs) comprising multiple sequential virtual network functions (VNFs). However, due to short satellite life, limited on-board resources, and diverse user demands, how to efficiently deploy SFCs in SONs still remains a great challenge. In this paper, we propose a cost-efficient SFC deployment (CE-SFCD) scheme to jointly optimize satellite battery life consumption, SFC latency, and resource consumption while guaranteeing a high SFC acceptance ratio during the process of SFC deployment. In CE-SFCD, the battery cost, latency cost, and resource cost are defined, and the SFC deployment problem is formulated as a multi-objective optimization problem. Considering the problem is NP-hard, heuristic algorithms are developed to realize the CE-SFCD scheme. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the flexibility and superiority of the CE-SFCD scheme in terms of SFC acceptance ratio, battery life consumption, latency, and resource utilization.

title: Prediction of Power Amplifier Performance at the Resonant Frequencies of Shielding Effectiveness in a Conductive Enclosure With an Aperture Under HEMP Exposure
authors: A. Kalantarnia, A. Mirzabeigi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: In this article, the performance of an RF power amplifier placed inside a conductive enclosure with an aperture is investigated under irradiation by a high-power electromagnetic pulse (HPEM). HPEM, due to its high amplitude and pulsed nature, can cause significant disruption in the operation of electronic systems. To evaluate the protective role of the enclosure, the shielding effectiveness (SE) against a modulated Gaussian wave is calculated using the finite difference delay modeling (FDDM) numerical method. The results indicate that at the enclosure’s resonant frequencies, SE sharply decreases and even becomes negative, revealing the resonant behavior of the structure. Subsequently, the TB232 PolyFET power amplifier, which uses a GP2441 GaAs transistor, is assessed under high-power microwave (HPM) irradiation with a sine burst waveform. By employing Thevenin-equivalent models at the gate and drain terminals, the impact of the interference wave on output power gain is analyzed. The results show that at resonant frequencies, electromagnetic interference (EMI) can reduce the amplifier gain by up to 30 dB. Moreover, increasing the input RF power reduces the detrimental effects of the interference. This study clearly highlights the influence of enclosure resonance and the amplifier’s nonlinear behavior on its susceptibility to HEMP disturbances.

title: Practical and Flexible Backdoor Attack against Deep Learning Models via Shell Code Injection_supp1-3662587.mp4
authors: Renshuai Tao
publish: N/A
abstract: Recently, backdoor attack, which aims to implant malicious logic into deep learning models (DLMs), has attracted so extensive research attention. Among them, the non-poisoning-based backdoor attack appears considerable development prospects owing to the posed threats against the DLMs-based artificial intelligence applications in cyberspace. However, previous non-poisoning- based backdoor attacks for DLMs are limited to the impractical attacking forms, resulting in certain weaknesses in both attacking complexity and attacking adaptability. To tackle the mentioned issues, this paper proposes a novel backdoor attack framework, namely the shell code injection (SCI), to perform backdoor attacks against DLMs with lower complexity and higher adaptability. Specifically, for alleviating the attacking complexity, we elaborate the logic-driven stealthy backdoor shell motivated by the biological behavior in nature, e.g., the camouflage and attack strategy of crabs. By introducing the trigger consistency verification and short-circuit code packaging strategies, the SCI misleads the victim models to output wrong predictions without training requirements according to the preset poisonous decision logic. For enhancing the attacking adaptability, we design the LLM-assisted adaptive attacking target code generation that consists of the model concept detection module and the attack target adjusting module. Since the attacking goals could be generated dynamically according to the aware victim model information and appointed attacker preset instructions, the SCI could achieve more flexible attacking performance. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate that the proposed backdoor attack framework appears awesome attacking ability (almost 100% ASR) under various settings. Additionally, we provide a case study on combining the cyber attack with SCI, which also exhibits certain space for imagination of new-type backdoor attacks.

title: Performance Evaluation of Advanced YOLOv10 and YOLOv11 Architectures for Object Detection in Autonomous Driving Scenarios
authors: Safa Teboulbi, Seifeddine Messaoud, Mohamed Ali Hajjaji, Mohamed Atri, Abdellatif Mtibaa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: Autonomous driving technologies are rapidly advancing, driven by the need for safer, more efficient, and intelligent transportation systems. A fundamental component of these systems is the perception module, which enables vehicles to understand and react to their surrounding environment. Object detection, in particular, is essential for identifying dynamic and static elements on the road, such as pedestrians, vehicles, traffic signs, and obstacles. In this work, we explore and enhance the capabilities of state-of-the-art deep learning-based object detectors within the YOLO (You Only Look Once) family, focusing on the latest versions: YOLOv10 and YOLOv11. We fine-tuned and optimized multiple variants of each model—namely, nano (n), small (s), medium (m), and large (l)—to improve detection accuracy and computational efficiency for real-time autonomous driving applications. The models were trained and evaluated on a diverse road object, and performance was measured using key metrics including precision, mean Average Precision (mAP), and Precision-Recall curves. Experimental results reveal that the fine-tuned YOLOv10n achieved a peak class-level precision of 1.00 at a specific confidence threshold (0.997), indicating that perfect precision was observed for certain classes under high-confidence conditions, while the overall mean precision and mAP metrics reflect more balanced model performance, while YOLOv11s attained the best result within its group with a precision of 0.91 at a threshold of 0.972. These findings demonstrate the potential of tailored YOLO architectures to meet the demanding requirements of real-world autonomous navigation systems.

title: 100 Gbps Radio Over Free Space Communication Using Space Diversity Reception Based on Photodetector Array
authors: Yunjie Yan, Joris Van Kerrebrouck, Nishant Singh, Mingxiang Yang, Yutong Liu, Shiyuan Zhao, Yiying Gu, Mingshan Zhao, Geert Morthier
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: With the rapid advancement of optical communication technology, radio over free space optical (RoFSO) communication has demonstrated considerable potential in communication applications due to its high bandwidth and low latency characteristics. A free space optical (FSO) receiver with high optical alignment robustness configured by a single optical lens is presented. The 10-element photodetector array (PDA) offers an expansive active detection area with a responsivity of 1.01 A/W at 1550 nm wavelength. In a 0.35 m FSO demonstration, the z-axis optical alignment tolerance on the condenser lens is evaluated to be as large as 65 μ m without crosstalk, demonstrating the robustness of the receiver design. The multiple output signals from the receiver are used in space diversity. A receiving rate of up to 100 Gbps (10×10 Gbps) NRZ with a bit error rate (BER) below 10<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{-12}$</tex-math></inline-formula> is demonstrated after 25km long distance single mode fiber (SMF) transmission. The system design and alignment tolerance without a mechanical beam tracking system are presented which verifies its feasibility in a high speed RoFSO communication system. It further demonstrates the potential for applications in space division multiplexing (SDM) systems.

title: Robot Grasp Detection With Category-Level 6-D Pose Estimation Based on 3-D Model Reconstruction
authors: Penglei Liu, Qieshi Zhang, Yu Liu, Jun Cheng
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Six-dimensional object pose estimation is essential for robot grasping, inspiring the development of various advanced methods in this field. The latest research on 6-D pose estimation mainly focuses on training a neural network for a specific object and estimating its pose through a 3-D model. However, 6-D pose estimation faces challenges such as the lack of 3-D models and variations in shape, color, and texture between similar objects, which significantly affect the accuracy and generalization of 6-D pose estimation algorithms. In addition, training neural network models requires substantial time and computational resources, leading to increased algorithmic costs. To address these issues, this article proposes a single-shot visual prompt-based 6-D pose estimation network (SVP6D), which can efficiently reconstruct 3-D models for novel objects from an RGB-D image and perform 6-D pose estimation. In addition, a hybrid attention-based visual prompting method (HAVP) is proposed, which reduces the training cost of the network by adjusting the input image to make it more suitable for the backbone. Experiments show HAVP reduces training costs while maintaining accuracy, and SVP6D achieves state-of-the-art performance. Moreover, the real-world experiments show that SVP6D achieves superior robotic grasping performance, with an average grasping success rate of 82.8% in different scenarios.

title: Color Manipulation and Fusion for Enhancement of Dark Underwater Images
authors: M. Kanagavel, M. Annapoopathi, S. Bama
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: This article introduces a new approach for the enhancement of dark underwater images. First, color manipulation is performed by transferring the information of predominant color channels to the weak color channels using the color transfer method followed by the gray world algorithm. Then three derived inputs such as two versions of gamma corrected images with different gamma values and the unsharp masking are obtained from the color manipulated image for blending their advantages using multiscale image fusion. The experimental results show that the proposed approach substantially removes the darkness and maintains the naturalness of the image.

title: Dynamic Anomaly Detection for Fire Alarm Fault Identification using a Fuzzy-CNN Based Approach
authors: Hemanand Chittapragada, Gangapuram Srikanth, Mohammad Rafeek Khan, P. Chandra Sekhar, C. V. Lakshmi Narayana, Ayushi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Fires pose a significant risk to human life and economic stability, rendering early detection essential. Conversely, FAS often encounter false alarms and malfunctions due to defective sensors, leading to hazardous delays or unnecessary responses. Due of their inflexible schedules, conventional maintenance procedures cannot accommodate the present condition of these systems. This study proposes an innovative method for FAF anomaly detection by integrating fuzzy logic with convolutional neural networks to address this issue. The method commences with the purification of a high-dimensional dataset by data preprocessing and the selection of features based on correlation. The subsequent phase involves developing a Fuzzy-CNN model that employs fuzzy logic to dynamically train the CNN weights, enhancing the model's adaptability and mistake detection capabilities. The experimental results indicate that the proposed model surpasses conventional classifiers in identifying FAF, with an impressive accuracy of 99.40%. The results indicate that the Fuzzy-CNN architecture is reliable and effective in identifying outliers in fire detection systems. This integrated strategy may yield enhancements in industrial safety and operational efficiency, along with a more responsive and precise method for monitoring FAS, potentially transforming fire safety system maintenance.

title: Analysis of No-Load Characteristics for Multi-Point Grounding Fault Locations in Three-Phase Transformer Cores
authors: Guofeng Yang, Boyang Liu, Zhenyang Zu, Yisheng Fang, Qiuchen Li, Nan Li
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Traditional diagnosis of transformer core multipoint grounding faults primarily relies on oil chromatography analysis, which is insensitive to early-stage electromagnetic characteristic changes. This paper investigates the potential clamping effect caused by multi-point grounding faults and its impact on no-load current characteristics. A 3D electromagnetic field simulation model of the transformer was established using the finite element method. Various scenarios of single and multi-point grounding faults at different core locations were systematically simulated. Results show that the fault location significantly influences the no-load current, with amplitude variation rates ranging between 2.7 % and 19.7 %. This circulating current causes a substantial increase in root mean square (RMS) value and waveform distortion of the noload current. The study provides theoretical and data support for using no-load current as a characteristic parameter in early online diagnosis of multi-point grounding faults.

title: SecureRag: Preventing Sensitive Information Leakage In Rag Pipelines
authors: Nidhi Mishra, Kanchan Rai, Dhruv Sharma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation is most commonly used to combine large language models with an external knowledge base in an attempt to ground them. This significantly improves the performance in terms of factual information, but sometimes these pipelines can also expose sensitive information if not handled properly. In this work, SecureRag a framework is presented which is designed to reduce the leakage of sensitive information in these systems. Synthetic datasets were created for six domains including legal, financial, healthcare, government, and e-commerce using Python Faker Library. To implement the SecureRag system, filtering layers were implemented that redacts confidential content before it reaches the large language model. The implementation began with regular expression based filters which were later enhanced with Microsoft Presidio based filters. The implementation was evaluated with multiple tests and large language models including MiniLm, Gemini Flash 2.5, BERT-QA. The RAG system was tested against various scenarios of adversarial attacks such as prompt injections, Base64-encoded data, and needle-in-the-haystack challenges. The results show that SecureRag can effectively prevent sensitive information leakage in RAG pipelines while keeping the retrieval performance intact, this offers a safer approach for RAG pipelines.

title: Design the Feedback and Health Monitoring for Rehabilitation Uses via Wearable IoT Integration in Virtual Reality (VR) Locations
authors: Vivek Justus, Ala'a Al-Shaikh, S. Varalakshmi, V. Samuthira Pandi, T Nagini, Shobana D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Rehabilitation therapy is particularly important in the treatment and recovery of people with physical injuries, neurological disorders, or post-surgical damage. Classical rehabilitation techniques, despite being clinically efficient, are challenged by high economic costs, the necessity of continual monitoring, and by a limited patient compliance. In order to overcome these issues, this work presents a new framework for real-time feedback and health monitoring during rehabilitation by means of Wearable Internet of Things (IoT) nodes embedded into Virtual Reality (VR) environments_ESCAPE_PUNCT, which is addressed to aforementioned problems. By combining immersive VR recordings with wearable health sensors, the proposed system improves patient motivation, and it makes personal treatment possible, as well as remote monitoring opportunity for healthcare providers. This system is primarily composed of a network of wearable IoT devices, monitoring physiological and biomechanical measurements, such as the heart rate, muscle activities, the alignment of the posture, and the joint angles. These points of data are sent in real-time to a cloud connected VR platform which a virtual therapist or customized exercise simulator uses to direct the patient in completion of rehabilitation exercises. The VR therapy is engaging and useful to patients and enables accurate adherence to exercises, with real-time visual, auditory, and haptic feedback. In addition, recorded data can be processed by machine learning algorithms to assess the patient's improvement or progression, and to tailor therapy and recovery forecasts. The use of VR in such a system makes it easy to create controlled, safe, and interactive environments that contain tasks similar to those seen in the real world. Patients may be gradually challenged according to their performance, and their adherence and improvement may be supervised at distanced. That decreases reliance on physical therapy centers and improves access, particularly for those in rural or underserved areas. And, the system is configured to identify abnormal readings, such as heart rate or posture anomalies, to issue alerts and avoid self-harm during unsupervised sessions. Simulation and prototype testing demonstrate a 35% improvement in patient compliance, 28% rehabilitation precision, and 40% decrease in supervision hours. The convergence of wearable IoT and VR typifies a strong cooperation and turns the traditional rehabilitation into a data-centric, interactive, and patient-oriented operation. This work proposes a scalable and modular design that can be adapted to a variety of rehab domains such as orthopedic rehabilitation, neurological rehab, post stroke therapy. Ultimately it provides an intelligent pathway to remote models of rehabilitative care, in the home, using real-time biofeedback and engaging interactivity to improve results and cost effectiveness.

title: Zero Trust Edge: An Explainable AI-Driven Energy- Aware IIoT Framework with Zero Trust Security for Sustainable Smart Grid
authors: Asthaa Jain, Arsalan Ahmed Alya, Er. Jai Parkash, Parveen Kaur, Aashdeep Singh, Kamal
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The increasing use of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) in smart grids has enabled sustainable energy optimization while exposing critical weaknesses in cybersecurity and energy efficiency. Conventional security models fail to address the energy limitations of IIoT edge devices, or instead utilize inflexible Zero Trust solutions, which cannot be easily explained and adapted to a particular situation. The work introduces ZeroTrustEdge, a new generation, modular security paradigm that combines the Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) with Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) and energy- aware robust access management to secure IIoT-enabled smart grids. As opposed to a more static security solution, ZeroTrustEdge is context-sensitive and can dynamically adapt security policy and ensures operational efficiency by monitoring the behavior of devices, context and energy states. Explainable AI models also make the decisions related to threat detection and access control clear and interpretable to the operator of the system, which would promote trust in automated defense. The results of experimental assessments of the simulated environments show that ZeroTrustEdge exceeds the conventional IIoT security models by enhancing the rate of detecting attacks by 26.4%, minimizing unnecessary energy consumption by 19.7%, and improving the explainability of the decisions made by 31%. ZeroTrustEdge creates a new paradigm addressing critical tradeoffs between resilience, transparency, and energy sustainability in future cyber- physical systems.

title: Leveraging Intelligent Digital Payment Systems for Tax Compliance Enhancement: Evidence from Indonesia's Motorized Tax Sector using SEM-PLS
authors: Suarni Norawati, Muhammad Luthfi Hamzah, Akmal Andri Yantama, M. Zacky, Diva Nazla Zaira
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Taxes constitute a vital source of government revenue, underpinning national development and the provision of essential public services. Nevertheless, ensuring tax compliance remains a persistent global challenge, with numerous countries grappling with administrative inefficiencies, inadequate enforcement, limited technological capacity, and declining public trust in tax institutions. These structural constraints hinder voluntary compliance and present significant governance concerns. In the Indonesian context, motorized taxpayer compliance continues to be an area of concern, particularly as regional governments strive to modernize tax administration through digital innovation and improved public communication. This study examines the combined effects of four key dimensions social media influence, penalty removal, tax sanctions, and payment digitalization on taxpayer compliance behavior. Guided by deterrence theory and digital government frameworks, the research employed a quantitative approach with data collected from 300 respondents using accidental sampling. The data were analyzed using Structural Equation Modeling with the Partial Least Squares (SEM-PLS) method. The results indicate that digital payment systems have a strong, statistically significant positive impact on compliance, highlighting the importance of user-friendly, accessible, and efficient tax payment platforms. In contrast, penalty removal policies exhibit a significant but negative influence, suggesting that leniency may unintentionally weaken tax discipline. Neither tax sanctions nor social media influence yielded a significant direct effect in this study. The findings offer practical insights for public sector decision-makers, digital system designers, and tax policy planners, emphasizing the need for a balanced approach that combines digital service expansion with effective psychological and regulatory strategies to enhance tax compliance in emerging economies.

title: Evaluating 2.5D Digital Twin Based Generation of Historical Women’s Jackets Using AI
authors: Zhiduan Yin, V.E. Kuzmichev
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study investigates the accuracy of AI-generated images of women’s jackets from the 1950s to the 2020s using a structure-driven evaluation framework based on the concept of a 2.5D digital twin. A dataset of twelve structural parameters was extracted from real garments, and two prompt strategies, non-parameterized and fully parameterized, were used to generate images via the Grok-3 model. Accuracy was assessed using a weighted relative error formula, designed to evaluate the precision of image generation under different strategies of structural input. Results show that including structural parameters in prompts improves generation accuracy from 84.7% to 92.4%. Further analysis identified key parameters for each decade, and simplified prompts containing only these features achieved a high average accuracy of 91.4%. These findings validate the feasibility of using minimal yet meaningful input for historically accurate fashion image generation. The proposed 2.5D digital twin framework provides a scalable and interpretable approach for AI-assisted fashion reconstruction and digital heritage applications.

title: Comparative Analysis of LSTM and 1D-CNN Models for Indonesian Sign Language (SIBI) Recognition Using MediaPipe Landmarks
authors: Ani Isnaeni, Rojali
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN1D) models for recognizing the Indonesian Sign Language System (SIBI), which serves as an essential communication tool for individuals with hearing impairments. The dataset comprises 11 SIBI gesture classes, each consisting of 100 samples, collected manually using OpenCV and processed with MediaPipe to extract 21 three-dimensional hand landmarks per frame. Data augmentation techniques, including horizontal flipping and brightness adjustment, were applied to enhance model generalization. Hyperparameter tuning was performed using GridSearchCV with 5-fold cross-validation. Experimental results indicate that LSTM outperformed CNN1D, achieving an accuracy of 98.41% compared to 87.73%, demonstrating its superior capability in modeling temporal dependencies in sequential gesture data. Horizontal flipping improved both models’ performance, whereas brightness adjustment adversely affected LSTM accuracy. The findings highlight LSTM’s potential for real-time, high-accuracy SIBI recognition systems, which could significantly reduce communication barriers for the deaf community in Indonesia.

title: Digital Twin engineering guided by MBSSE and Digital Thread
authors: Dalil Zeamari, Clarissa Gregory, Souad Rabah, Vincent Chapurlat
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The engineering of complex systems produces large volumes of heterogeneous data from multiple stakeholders. They are gathered throughout the system lifecycle, is organized within a Digital Thread, ensuring traceability and consistency. This data can be reused during the operational phase through a Digital Twin (DT), which serves purposes such as control, optimization, and maintenance. However, developing a DT remains costly, even though valuable models and data are already available in the Digital Thread. This highlights the need to capitalize on existing resources to improve efficiency. This work extends previous research in Digital Twin engineering by exploring the link between Digital Thread and Digital Twin. It proposes a methodology and case study based on systems engineering and Model-Based Systems Engineering to support coherent and reusable Digital Twin System design.

title: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning Algorithms for P2P Traffic Classification
authors: Ammar Mazri, Merouane Mehdi
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: The widespread proliferation of peer-to-peer (P2P) networks and the diverse applications utilized on the Internet, particularly among individuals via communication networks, occurs often without awareness of the associated risks and concerns. Consequently, the classification of network traffic has become a necessity, especially within institutional networks. Traditional traffic classification methods based on port numbers and payload inspection have become less effective due to the evolving nature of application systems and their increasing complexity. Therefore, it is evident that most researchers have turned to classification techniques based on Machine Learning due to the promising results they offer in this domain. In this research paper, we will present a study on various Machine Learning algorithms utilized in the classification of traffic, particularly concerning peer-to-peer (P2P) networks, along with a comparison and the challenges encountered in relation to previous research. Finally, we will provide an overview of the architecture specific to one of the P2P applications.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Inspired Ensemble Framework for Robust Facial Emotion Recognition
authors: Gayathri Soman, M.V. Judy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Facial emotion identification is at the forefront of affective computing, but finding balance between high accuracy and scalability remains challenging. A self-adaptive ensemble framework inspired by reinforcement learning is proposed in this work which is capable of dynamically assigning weight for multiple classifiers for robust facial emotion classification. Deep features take from facial images are used to train multiple base classifiers (Logistic Regression, Random forest and Naïve Bayes) in a distributed manner. The base model’s probabilistic outputs are then fused dynamically by a neural ensemble model that outputs weights for each classifier and is trained using a reinforcement inspired loss value which in cooperates an reward function that maximizes the excepted reward based on the correctness of the ensemble predictions. This approach improves accuracy and robustness by allowing the ensemble to dynamically emphasize the most reliable models. In contrast to the conventional fixed-weight ensembles, the results using the proposed method demonstrates the potential of integrating adaptive decision-level reinforcement learning inspired techniques with feature-level deep representations for next-generation emotion-aware computers. Utilizing the Extended Cohn-Kanade dataset (CK+) and Japanese female facial emotion (JAFFE) dataset, the effectiveness of the proposed approach is assessed. For the CK+ and JAFFE datasets, the accuracy attained across K-fold for the proposed ensemble model is $99.39 \% \pm 0.38$ and $99.06 \% \pm 1.15$, respectively. The results demonstrates that the proposed ensemble approach outperforms the state of the art methods for facial emotion recognition.

title: Optimizing Dynamic Charging Infrastructure Placement for Heavy-Duty Vehicles
authors: Pierrick Daval, Bilal Kabalan, Rochdi Trigui, Emmanuel Vinot, Mina Khalesian, Nour-Eddin El Faouzi
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper presents an optimization approach to determine the cost-effective placement of dynamic charging infrastructure in the case of a road electrification, considering road topography and truck characteristics. First, an energy model is developed for an electric truck and for the electric road systems, including conductive and inductive charging technologies. Then, the problem of charging infrastructure placement is formulated as a cost-minimization optimization model, and a dynamic programming based method is used to solve it. Finally, we illustrate our approach with a realistic use case. The study concludes with a discussion of the simulation results and their implications for the economical deployment of electric roads.

title: Thoughts on Technology and the State
authors: Nir Kshetri, Jeffrey Voas
publish: Computer
abstract: Governments attempt to regulate the technology their citizens and industries use. This article looks at how governments are attempting to keep up with the rate of technology advances.

title: SHAP-Based Feature Analysis Method for Pipeline Defect Signal Interpretation
authors: Huaijiang Wang, Wenxin Xia, Ketian Zhao, Jie You, Han Yang, Huaiwei Peng
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This study proposes a SHAP-based feature analysis method for pipeline defect signals, aiming to enhance the accuracy and reliability of defect detection and inversion. By leveraging SHAP values, the method quantifies and ranks the contributions of different defect features—such as defect length, width, and depth—to the prediction performance of inversion models. The importance, influence direction, and potential interactions of these features are visually interpreted through bar plots and SHAP summary plots. To address issues of redundancy and noise in the feature selection process, a SHAP-based feature optimization strategy is introduced, which improves computational efficiency while maintaining model accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the rational selection of high-contribution features significantly improves inversion precision, reduces overfitting, and enhances the model's generalization capability on unseen data. This approach not only improves the interpretability of the model but also provides data-driven decision support for pipeline defect detection in engineering practice.

title: Drawing Power Grid Diagrams to Explicitly Separate Different Nominal Voltage Levels
authors: Tarun Indira Kumar Babu, Paul Cuffe
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a network drawing technique for power systems that explicitly and deliberately separates different nominal voltage zones within the grid. Power grids are large, complex systems that deliver electricity from generation plants to residential, industrial, and commercial consumers. Understanding how these grids are connected and how electricity flows through them is essential for engineers to design and operate reliable power networks. Conventional schematic diagrams have long been used to show power grids; however, these often fail to convey key operational aspects such as segmentation into nominal voltage zones and the directional nature of real power flows. These limitations reduce their effectiveness for grid operators who require clarity for network monitoring and decision-making. This paper proposes a visualization method that, first, segments a network into zones based on their operating voltage levels and then diagrams constrained graph layouts that visually segregates these zones.

title: Pneumonia in Children Using Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning
authors: Ritesh Kumar, Deepak Juneja, Manu Kumari, Abduvahob Teshaboev, A. Kaliappan, G. Dharmamoorthy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Pneumonia is an important cause of childhood morbidity and mortality globally, therefore accurate and timely identification is vital. While chest X-ray imaging is still the standard diagnostic method, manual interpretation is haphazard and subjective. In recent years, advances in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) have allowed for systematic and automated processing frameworks that now show improved performance. This work investigates the comparison of four models, including: a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), an Artificial Neural Network (ANN), a model from the Gradient Boosted (GBoost) family, and a CNN with mobile net architecture (MobileNetV2) based on transfer learning using a Kaggle pediatric chest X-ray dataset containing 5,800 images labelled for pneumonia or normal. MobileNetV2 achieved the best overall classification accuracy at 90.06%, while CNN achieved 87.18%, ANN 84.46%, and GBoost 74.52%. This work demonstrates that lightweight software architectures based on efficient mobile deep learning models such as MobileNetV2 can continue to be promising in the case of pediatric pneumonia classification.

title: Analyzing the Effectiveness of Machine Learning Approaches in Sentiment Classification
authors: M. Sai Abhi Chandra, Navneet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Analyzing sentiments in reviews has become a crucial task in understanding customer feedback and reshaping product features in online retail sites. In this paper, I investigate the use of various machine learning algorithms for the sentiment analysis of Amazon's product reviews. On the side of feature construction, I have implemented CountVectorization and TF-IDF (applied to words, characters, and n-grams). The features that were created this way, I used them for training and testing of various learning algorithms like Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, K-Nearest Neighbours, Decision Tree, Naïve Bayes, Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost. After that, each model was deeply analyzed for accuracy and other metrics to determine the best combination of feature engineering and classification algorithm. The superior method achieved higher accuracy, further demonstrating machine learning's potential in the automatic sentiment classification task. The focus of this work is on utilizing intelligent techniques in opinion mining, the decision-making processes for enterprises, and in enhancing the online experience for consumers.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis of Data Driven NN Models for EMG-Based Force Estimation in Rehabilitation Robotics
authors: Lotfi Mostefai, Brahim Brahmi, Merzoug Bouhamdi, Mohamed Benouis
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This work introduces data-driven estimators to enable EMG-based control of upper-limb rehabilitation robots. Surface electromyography (EMG) signals from key arm muscles are preprocessed to extract amplitude envelopes and synchronized with force to form a structured dataset. Three neural network models—NARX, RBF, and LSTM—are trained to estimate joint position and force from EMG, with NARX and LSTM capturing temporal dependencies and RBF approximating instantaneous mappings. Hyperparameters are optimized via a focused grid search to ensure stable, efficient performance suitable for real-time control. This work highlights the potential of neural network-based EMG decoding for subject-specific, intelligent human-robot interaction in therapeutic applications. the NARX model offers a superior balance of performance and computational efficiency suitable for real-time applications, over the LSTM and RBF NN based estimators.

title: Geographically Weighted Log-Logistic 3-Parameter Regression Model for Stunting Prevalence: A Case Study on Sulawesi Island, Indonesia
authors: Nur Mawadah, Purhadi, Shofi Andari
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study proposes the Geographically Weighted Log-Logistic 3-Parameter Regression (GWLL3R) to analyze stunting prevalence data across 81 districts/cities in Sulawesi Island, utilizing the 2023 dataset obtained from the National Food Agency (BAPANAS). Addressing the limitations of global models in handling spatial heterogeneity and skewed data, the model employs a Fixed Gaussian kernel weighting function. Parameter estimation was conducted using the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) optimized with the Berndt-Hall-Hall-Hausman (BHHH) algorithm. The results demonstrate that the GWLL3R model with an optimum bandwidth of 13.1043 achieves the best fit, yielding the lowest AICc value of 582.2952 compared to other kernel functions.
