Furthermore, model comparison tests confirm that the spatial model significantly outperforms the global LL3R model. The analysis identified four distinct spatial clusters, with poverty percentage and health worker ratio emerging as the most robust determinants significantly affecting stunting across all locations, while other variables such as education showed localized effects. These quantitative findings validate the GWLL3R’s superiority in capturing location-specific factors, providing a precise basis for targeted regional health interventions.

title: Firefighter Response Training Using Real-Time Adaptive XR Scenarios
authors: Hasan Muhammed Alii, Swati Agrawal, P.B. Edwin Prabhakar, P. Kranthi Kumari, R. Nallakumar, Abdumutalliev Abdulakhad Abdusamad Ugli, M.P. ElboyevaTashkent
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The classic methods of training firefighters, which could be delivered in a physical structure or be in the form of stationary extended reality (XR) training, are very restricted in terms of realism, flexibility, as well as in terms of scale. Physical training facilities are highly costly to maintain, non-particularly readily adjustable, and can be hazardous during actual training. In the meantime, the applications of the stationary XR modules are not usually dynamically responsive to the user input and, thus, are not capable of supporting the real-time decision-making or the simulation of the realistic stress. The creation of the first adaptive XR training system specific to the readiness of the firefighters is introduced in the research. It integrates AI-based adaptation of the situation with real-time intervention by the instructor to create a high-fidelity training that reacts to trainees. The system maintains a consistent record of actions, responsiveness, and coordination of a team as trainees deal with the varying fire circumstances, and hence, balances the hazard intensity such as spread of fire, smoke density, and structural support of the edifice. The fact that there is no control in real emergencies can be simulated by instructors interjecting the scenario in real-time in order to alter, introduce new problems or offer suggestions based on their assessment, which can be guided feedback. In order to evaluate the quality of the system, the scientists compared the system with the traditional XR modules regarding the effect on the participants (60) divided equally between the control and experimental groups. Measures such as accuracy of the procedures, time of response to the hazards, consistency of decision making as well as one week retention were used. The results showed that trainees who studied adaptive system were 24 per cent faster, the error rates critical were reduced in 40 per cent and the level of retention was 19 per cent higher than those who studied fixed XR. In addition, there was a high score on the engagements with greater user immersion and the sense of realism. The results validate the adaptive XR as a game changer in educating firefighters and possibilities to scale, differentiate, and introduce a safer learning environment, one which responds to the needs of the real world.

title: Optimizing Checkout Page Performance for High-Traffic E-Commerce Platforms: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Divyanshu Abhichandani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Checkout processes for e-commerce sites are major problems to solve in terms of optimizing them to reduce cart abandonment and maximize conversion rates. This study explores the use of machine learning algorithms to predict and optimize checkout page performance with an extensive dataset of 7,400 user sessions across 16 behavioral and contextual variables. The research uses five individual classification models that are Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Machine, and K-Nearest Neighbors to forecast successful checkout achievement. The results show that Support Vector Machine has the best accuracy of 98.45% with precision and recall scores of 98.80% and 96.69% respectively. The study determines key performance features such as session length, page visits, cart value, and checkout page dwell time. Mathematical models are constructed to measure the connection between user behavior patterns and checkout success probability. Results present e-commerce platforms with actionable recommendations to deploy data-driven optimization strategies, which have the potential to decrease cart abandonment rates by as much as 15.3% according to the suggested predictive framework.

title: Optimizing Timeliness in Network Design for Electric Vehicle Battery Recycling Under Demand Uncertainty Incorporating Fourth-Party Logistics
authors: Weidong Wang, Xiaoguang Ding, Yang Cao, Qidi Ma
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the rapid growth in electric vehicle usage, retired electric vehicle batteries (EVBs) create significant recycling demands and safety challenges. Efficient and rapid recycling of EVB is a fundamental requirement for reducing storage costs and ensuring safety and stability. Network design, recognized by scholars as crucial for determining the EVB recycling process, has been extensively studied. However, previous studies rarely explore the impact of timeliness on recycling network design. From a fourth-party logistics perspective, an EVB recycling network design problem is formulated, which explicitly incorporates timeliness constraints to ensure that essential recycling phases are completed within specified durations. To effectively capture strategic network configuration choices and manage operational responses in an uncertain environment, a stochastic two-stage framework has been developed. To solve this model, Latin hypercube sampling (LHS) and sampling average approximation (SAA) are integrated to propose the LHS-SAA method. Numerical experiments and a real-world case illustrate that enforcing timeliness constraints improves recycling rates, lowers expected penalties for uncollected EVBs, and enhances network responsiveness. Based on the experimental analysis of demand uncertainty effects, design guidelines for time-sensitive recycling networks for retired EVB are provided.

title: Finite-Time Simultaneous Rest-to-Rest Setting Control for Dual Modes of a String Using Halfodd Trigonometric Functions
authors: Taichi Okamoto, Shigeo Kotake
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Distributed parameter systems, such as strings and flexible robot arms, have an infinite number of vibration modes. Consequently, achieving vibration-suppressed transport requires the simultaneous control of multiple modes. In this paper, we analytically derive a control trajectory that enables the simultaneous suppression of two vibration modes of a string during translational transport between two stationary states. The proposed trajectory is a finite-time settling function combined with half-odd-integer trigonometric functions. We evaluate the residual vibration of the string using this trajectory through numerical simulations. While the method demonstrates effectiveness in suppressing dual vibration modes simultaneously, its performance depends on the selection of the parameter p, the specific vibration modes targeted, and the operation time.

title: Structuring Secure Communication Channels Through Adaptive AI Frameworks
authors: Khaleelula Mulla Syed, Veera Talukdar, Pallikonda Priyanka, Vivek Veeraiah, Ankur Gupta, Krishna Nand Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The rapid growth of networked devices, 6G networks, and cloud-edge technologies has made modern communication systems far more complicated and open to assault. Static and reactive security solutions can't keep up with threats in dynamic network settings since they change all the time. Through this study, a framework that is referred to as UAASC is presented with the purpose of improving security, facilitating scalability, and providing real-time accessibility. Federation-based learning, decision-making based on agents, and machine learning are all used in this process. In order to safeguard data while it is being sent across various platforms, the system employs a number of different means, including encryption techniques, anomaly detection techniques, and adaptive response techniques. The results of the simulation demonstrate that this technique is superior to others in terms of locating intrusions, decreasing latency, and minimizing the number of false positives and false negatives. In order to guarantee the security of the communication networks of the future generation, the UAASC design is proactive, pays attention to the situation, and safeguards users' privacy.

title: Integrated Design and Performance Optimization of Residential PEMFC-CHP System
authors: Zishun Xu, Tiancai Ma, Shijun Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Proton exchange membrane fuel cell combined heat and power (PEMFC-CHP) system can improve energy utilization efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is an indispensable part of modern energy systems. System integration and control strategy play important roles in the efficiency, reliability, and economy of the PEMFC-CHP system. Firstly, system architecture analysis is conducted based on application scenarios and operating conditions. Secondly, the membrane humidifier is removed from the air supply subsystem. There is only an injector in the hydrogen recirculation loop. The thermal management subsystem controls the operating temperature of the stack through a three-way valve. Thirdly, the thermal storage tank stores the heat generated by the stack and supplies hot water. Finally, the electrical subsystem and energy management strategy ensure efficient and stable power supply. The results show that the PEMFC-CHP system has good steady-state and transient performance, meeting the electricity and heat needs of residential buildings. Under rated operating conditions, the hydrogen utilization efficiency is 98.66%, the electrical efficiency is 44.72%, the thermal efficiency is 47.90%, and the CHP efficiency is 92.62%. This paper provides theoretical and technical guidance for the design and application of the PEMFC-CHP system.

title: Decision Optimization for Electronic Products Based on Multi-Stage Planning and Multi-Layer Perceptron
authors: ShuDong Zhang, JiaHang Wang, Hao Zhu, Wei Wu, Biyuan Yao, Jinyue Deng
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The rising demand for high-quality electronics challenges manufacturers to minimize inspection costs while ensuring product quality. Existing methods struggle to balance inspection cost reduction, dismantling cost control, and profit maximization, limiting adaptability in complex production environments. To address this, we propose a planning-based multi-stage decision model covering inspection, dismantling, and defective product treatment across pre-production (spare parts screening), in-production (assembly), and post-production (after-sales and recycling). Firstly, an optimized parts inspection scheme based on the binomial distribution and central limit theorem determines the minimum sample size, reducing inspection costs. Then, a simulated annealing algorithm optimizes inspection and dismantling decisions to improve production efficiency. Additionally, a multilayer perceptron enhances decision-making intelligence, while a multi-stage expectation model integrates substandard product recovery. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively reduces inspection costs, enhances profitability, and adapts well to diverse production environments, providing a feasible decision optimization framework for electronic manufacturing enterprises.

title: Enhanced Spatiotemporal Coordination for Multi-Robot Systems in Smart Warehousing: A Digital Twin-Enabled Approach
authors: Changqing Ji, Songtao Jiang, Zuxu Wang, Landi Zhu, Zhe Sun, Xiaoyu Nie
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study introduces a spatiotemporal coordination framework enhanced through digital twin synchronization for robotic warehouse systems, with three conceptual advances overcoming conventional optimization bottlenecks. First, a 3D node expansion architecture using hierarchical temporal windows enables simultaneous path-temporal optimization through dynamic collision matrices, reducing spatial conflicts by 78–92% compared to single-space planning approaches. Second, our hybrid search algorithm integrates adaptive congestion models with prioritized replanning, achieving 95.3% path efficiency while the auction-based path planning reduces total travel distances by 18–25% compared to random allocation algorithms, through synergistic optimization of movement coordination and temporal sequencing. Finally, the virtual-real synchronization platform establishes a closed-loop verification system demonstrating 93% deadlock reduction in high-density operations through predictive traffic simulations, resolving a critical scalability limitation in existing multi-robot architectures. Validation across 6–20 robot scenarios confirms real-time responsiveness with 2.3s average replanning latency, while enhanced auction mechanisms improve task allocation fairness by 38–65% compared to traditional bidding systems. These innovations collectively advance both theoretical models of spatiotemporal constraints and practical implementations of digital twin verification for industrial automation.

title: BIM-Aided Digital Twin of Long-Span Pratt Truss Modeling and GNSS Displacement Monitoring for Bridge Lifecycle Management
authors: Elfrido Elias Tita, Gakuho Watanabe, Yushi Tomoeda
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Bridges are critical components of national infrastructure, enhancing connectivity, supporting economic development, and ensuring access to essential services. Globally, many countries face increasing challenges in managing aging bridge stocks, particularly those constructed during rapid economic growth. In Japan, over 50% of bridges are over 50 years old, with projections indicating that more than 75% will exceed this age within the next two decades. These trends highlight the urgent need for efficient, predictive, and cost-effective maintenance strategies. This study proposes an integrated framework that combines displacement monitoring utilizing digital twin technology based on Building Information Modeling (BIM) and the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) with the aim of improving the lifecycle management of long bridges. BIM enables detailed and data-rich modeling and promotes collaboration between multiple disciplines, while GNSS enables continuous, remote acquisition of high-precision 3D displacement data, enabling real-time structural health assessment. The current implementation supports near-real-time monitoring, future developments will incorporate edge computing and bidirectional feedback to achieve true real-time digital twin synchronization. This framework has been applied to Oshima Bridge (a long-span plate truss bridge) in Yamaguchi Prefecture, which experienced a ship collision accident in 2018. This case demonstrates the value of continuous monitoring in anomaly detection and resilience planning. Rooted in existing technologies, this research provides an operational bridge management model and outlines a path toward complete digital twin system.

title: Gain-Scheduling-Based Energy Management System for Marine Electric Propulsion System
authors: Mohammed Abu Mallouh, Ahmad Jobran Al-Mahasneh, Basel Jouda, Sarah Oudeh
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper introduces a gain-scheduling-based Energy Management System (EMS) for marine electric propulsion systems. Developed as part of the IEEE VTS Motor Vehicle Challenge 2025 (MVC), this EMS is specifically designed for tugboats utilizing hybrid battery and supercapacitor energy storage. The proposed method employs a rule-based approach to effectively manage and distribute power between the battery pack and supercapacitor module. Preliminary results demonstrate its promising capabilities in optimizing the power split for marine vessels operating in both towing and non-towing modes.

title: Exploring Colour Space Correlations for Non-Destructive Assessment of Banana Ripeness
authors: Haarshit R, Naveen Kumar C, Aakash K, Ganesan M
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Determining the ripeness of bananas is important for reducing post-harvest losses and improving supply-chain management. Since peel colour of the banana changes rapidly during ripening, this work focuses on colour-based feature extraction supported by accurate fruit segmentation. The proposed approach begins with K-means clustering on the saturation channel, followed by morphological closing and GrabCut refinement to handle common imaging and fruit surface issues like bruises, fungal spots and uneven lighting. After isolating the fruit region, colour features from HSV, LAB and YUV spaces are extracted and used to train machine-learning models for ripeness prediction. Experimental results show that certain colour channels exhibit a strong correlation with ripening stages, leading to more consistent and reliable classification. These results strengthen our claim of the creation of a non-destructive models for estimating banana ripeness, benefiting everyone involved in the supply chain.

title: Toward Secure and Scalable Access Control in IoT for Smart and Sustainable Systems: A Hybrid RBAC-ABAC Survey and Roadmap
authors: Mishra Mridul Kailashchandra, Udai Pratap Rao, Pintu Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed digital ecosystems but introduced complex security challenges that traditional access control models like Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) struggle to address independently. RBAC provides administrative simplicity, while ABAC offers fine-grained, context-aware access decisions. However, both face scalability, dynamic adaptability, and policy complexity limitations in heterogeneous and resource-constrained IoT environments. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of access control models for IoT, emphasizing the evolution and integration of hybrid RBAC-ABAC approaches. We critically evaluate recent models, including HyBACRC, HyBACAC, BlendCAC, and DHACS, and analyze them across key dimensions such as scalability, trust, delegation, and policy decision latency. Furthermore, we identify prevailing challenges and propose a forward-looking framework that incorporates emerging technologies-such as machine learning, reinforcement learning, lightweight cryptography, and edge/fog computing-to enhance adaptive security and real-time policy enforcement. Our findings underscore the potential of standardized hybrid access control paradigms as foundational components for future-proof, secure, and intelligent IoT ecosystems.

title: Analysis of Impedance Characteristics of Semi-solid Lithium Batteries
authors: Juefei Yang, Yuting Liu, Ze Mo, Liangxuan Ouyang, Yunfei Wang, Weichen Wang, Zhaoyang Zhao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Semi-solid-state lithium-ion batteries (SSSB) offer improved safety and energy density, but their impedance behaviour remains insufficiently understood, limiting accurate state estimation and practical application. Therefore, this work investigates the impedance characteristics of semi-LIBs. Aging tests under various conditions were conducted, and the effects of temperature, state of charge (SoC), and aging on impedance evolution were analysed. DRT analysis was further applied to reveal reaction mechanisms. The results show that high C-rate cycling accelerates degradation, while appropriate pressure mitigates it. SoC, temperature, and aging markedly influence the impedance response, providing useful insights for impedance modelling and state estimation.

title: IFG-Net: Channel Info Fusion Guidance for Retinal Vessel Segmentation
authors: Qixiu Li, Xiang Zhu, Xiaoyong Li, Chengcheng Shao, Xiaoli Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Retinal vessel segmentation plays a crucial role in supporting ophthalmologists with pathological analysis. Recent studies have focused on leveraging output fusion techniques and attention mechanisms to improve segmentation performance using the U-Net architecture. However, challenges remain in fusing segmentation results without information loss, as well as in capturing the relational dependencies between downsampled feature maps of different dimensions. In this paper, we propose Info Fusion Guidance U-Net (IFG-Net), which is a multi-dimensional channel-associated fusion guidance segmentation model. Specifically, in IFG-Net we first design a novel strategy called Entropy preserved Channel info Mixture (ECM) to improve the fusion of output feature maps while optimizing information utilization, which is an adaptive weight generator that preserves information entropy. Furthermore, we propose a novel mechanism called Dimension Scale Attention (DSA), which is capable of capturing long range, cross level dependencies between encoder features of varying dimensions in IFG-Net. Extensive experiments demonstrate that IFG-Net achieves superior segmentation performance across multiple datasets. Compared to the state-of-the-art EDAE-Net, IFG-Net shows improvements in all selected evaluation metrics on the DRIVE, CHASE_DB1, and STARE datasets, which may benefit for the automated diagnosis and treatment of retinal diseases.

title: Spatiotemporal Graph Neural Network for Predictive Maintenance in Wind Energy Systems Using Multi-Task Learning
authors: Deepika Nayak, Seema Singh, Nikunj Sharma, Karthik Palani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The rapid adoption of renewable energy sources has increased the complexity of infrastructure maintenance, making early fault detection and predictive analytics critical for sustainable operations. This study presents a novel spatiotemporal Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework that captures both topological and temporal dependencies in wind energy systems. Unlike conventional models, it integrates graph attention mechanisms with gated recurrent units for enhanced fault detection, Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction, and anomaly identification using multi-task learning. The methodology is validated using the CARE dataset comprising 89 years of SCADA data from 36 turbines, achieving 94.2% fault detection accuracy, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6.4\%}$</tex> MAPE for RUL prediction, and up to 8.4 weeks of early warning. The model demonstrates strong crossdomain generalization and scalability across diverse wind farm conditions. This framework enables more proactive, cost-efficient maintenance and contributes to the reliability and resilience of clean energy infrastructure, aligning with global goals for sustainable and uninterrupted power supply.

title: Integrating Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Iot, Ai, and Data Science for Future Innovations
authors: Megha, Vinod kumar Srivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: They have been united in a new era of opportunities in numerous fields, such as smart cities, healthcare, manufacturing, and agriculture, by data science, the IoT, AI, DL, and ML. The paper gives a detailed discussion of how various technologies work together to improve the position of automation, real-time decision-making, and prediction. Our multi-layer integrated platform accepts the input of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, processes this data via the most advanced ML/DL models, and then uses the artificial intelligence-based analytics to generate smart applications. Experiments indicate that the integrated effect will be much more accurate, energyefficient, and faster than stand-alone solutions. Regarding the creation of flexible, scalable, and sustainable solutions, the findings prove that AI systems can be extremely helpful. This research also offers future research the right direction by determining the major problems such as data privacy, computation complexity, system interoperability.

title: AI-Powered Multimodal Fusion Models for Lung Cancer Recurrence Prediction in Diverse Diagnostic Contexts
authors: Shivam Chaurasiya, Rohit Bajaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Lung cancer is still one of the main causes of mortality among the world population, especially due to late diagnosis and varied clinical manifestations. This paper offers a novel multimodal deep learning (DL) framework that incorporates computed tomography (CT) imaging, clinical characteristics, and genomic data in order to enhance early lung cancer recurrence prediction. The suggested hybrid architecture is composed of a Convolutional neural network (CNN), Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks, and a Seasonal-Trend decomposition by using LOESS (STL) layer to extract spatial features, learn temporal and sequential, and seasonality and long-range temporal changes in the signals of the genome, respectively. The modalities are separately preprocessed, after which they are merged at the feature level and classified using a fully connected neural network. The evaluation of experimental results on three benchmark datasets and a fused multimodal dataset indicates the ability of the proposed model (CNN+LSTM+ST <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L$</tex>) to perform better (93.61 percent and AUC of 0.948) than the other baseline CNN, LSTM, and CNN+LSTM in a fused dataset.

title: Formal Verification and Implementation of GeoFC-NIRF: Geospatial Fog-Cloud assisted Framework for SDG #4
authors: Sreeya Dash, Jnyana R. Mohanty, Ratan Lal, Rabindra K. Barik
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Introduction of a Cloud-Fog paradigm is vital to seamlessly bridge the gap between growing Geospatial data and the need for secure and scalable computing resources. In view of this, it proposes the GeoFC-NIRF, a Geospatial Fog-Cloud assisted framework for the National Institutional Ranking Framework. The framework is designed to respond in real-time for large-scale geospatial applications. The addition of a Fog layer reduces latency and speeds up processing of data from the data source. This reduces reliance on distant cloud infrastructures and enhances responsiveness for end-users. The significant contribution of the paper is the formal verification of Fog layer, that assures accuracy, consistency and robustness of the model-based analysis. Formal methods are considered in the planning process to make the system more reliable and lower the risk of errors in distributed geospatial applications. A preliminary implementation aimed at Sustainable Development Goal #4 illustrates the applicability of GeoFC-NIRF, demonstrating how the framework improves intelligent educational services, decision-making for both students and policymakers, and advances fair access to geospatial learning resources. The results show that GeoFC-NIRF provides a scalable, reliable, and useful basis for domain-specific applications. Although this study focuses on education, the framework can be applied to other important sectors.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Rotating Oil-Jet Cooling for Thermal Management in Hairpin Winding Electrical Machines
authors: Sen Zhang, Zeyuan Xu, Fengyu Zhang, Chuan Liu, Christopher Gerada, He Zhang, Xiaochen Zhang, David Gerada
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Efficient thermal management is crucial for high-performance electric machines, particularly in electric vehicle applications where both power density and reliability are critical. Among direct oil cooling strategies, oil-jet cooling provides an attractive balance between simplicity and effectiveness. This study investigates the cooling performance of an oil-jet scheme in which oil is directed toward the rotor end face and subsequently splashed onto the stator end windings. A dedicated test rig was developed, enabling independent control of oil flow rate and rotor speed. Temperature measurements were primarily obtained using a thermal imaging camera, with thermocouples employed for calibration. The corresponding heat transfer coefficients (HTC) were determined under various operating conditions. Results demonstrate that HTC increases rapidly under high oil flow rate conditions, while it remains nearly constant at low flow rates. These findings offer valuable insights into the thermal characteristics of oil-jet cooling and provide practical reference for the design of future cooling systems.

title: A Survey of Intrusion Detection Systems in Deep Learning Era: Methods and Perspectives
authors: Amira Berrezzek, Hayet Djellali, Lamia Mahnane
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: In response to the growing complexity of cyber threats, Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) serve as a foundational pillar for securing digital infrastructures. This literature review analyzes their historical transition from conventional rule-based methods to modern paradigms based on Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL), encompassing host-based IDS (HIDS), network-based IDS (NIDS), and hybrid approaches. Major innovations reviewed include detectors using DL techniques, ensemble methods, Federated Learning (FL) techniques, explainable AI (XAI), and the integration of blockchain. The discussion also focuses on model generalizability using benchmark datasets, while pointing out current limitations: managing false positives, detecting zero-day threats, and resilience against adversarial attacks. The conclusion identifies necessary orientations for developing next-generation IDS that are more intelligent, efficient, and interpretable.

title: Responsible AI for Health Governance: A Focus on Alzheimer's Patients
authors: Madhvi Garg, Akshay Juneja, Deepak Painuli, Divya Mishra, Priyanka Kumari, Vijay Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence and healthcare systems for neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease need a responsible and trustworthy framework to ensure fairness, legality, authenticity, and social welfare. This paper proposes a structured AI governance alliance in four categories namely, functional AI, legal AI, ethical AI, and philanthropic AI. These categories are analyzed in terms of their nature, evaluation metrics, and impact on healthcare stakeholders. Moreover, five essential parameters are discussed for implementation of Responsible <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> in Alzheimer's disease diagnosis. These parameters are fairness and bias mitigation, transparency, explainability, security and safety, and human-centered design. The different challenges to achieve the task are data bias, model interpretability, patient data security, and alignment with clinical workflows. These issues are categorized in practical challenge in which a small dataset is used to train the black-box nature of deep learning, and adversarial challenges. The possible solutions are diverse dataset curation, explainability tools, and robust monitoring systems. Furthermore, this paper presents measurable metrics such as accuracy disparity across subgroups, decision-making ability of model, clinical comprehension rates, and community feedback, used to enable consistent and transparent evaluation of each Responsible AI component. The ethical compliance is emphasized without compromising functionality or efficiency. The presented framework aims to develop the AI models that are transparent, secure, and socially aligned, along with high accuracy, for responsible Alzheimer's disease detection and diagnosis.

title: Big Data Visualisation Using Multimodal Learning Feedback Analysis
authors: Aakansha Soy, Chand Tandon
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The fast digitalisation of the education sector has produced tremendous amounts of heterogeneous data in online learning sources, including click stream logs and discussion forum activity, biometric data, and audio-visual signals. Traditional learning analytics dashboards often fail to utilise the richness of multimodal data, typically displaying delayed, disaggregated, and static information that cannot support timely interventions or provide helpful feedback. These constraints limit educators to the whole learning experience and prevent students from receiving practical advice, particularly in large and diverse learning settings. To fill this gap, we recommend Big Data Visualisation Using Multimodal Learning Feedback Analysis (BDV-MFLA). This advanced framework integrates multimodal data streams into a single, real-time, adaptive visualisation ecosystem. The system utilises deep multimodal fusion models to process textual, behavioural, and physiological inputs, leveraging large-scale data pipelines that offer scalability and low latency. The knowledge is translated into interactive visual dashboards that enable educators to identify engagement levels, predict performance, and offer individualised feedback in real-time. The framework was tested on three large-scale educational datasets comprising over $\mathbf{1 5, 0 0 0}$ learners across multiple domains. It achieved predictive accuracy of $87.4 \%$, precision of $89.2 \%$, recall of $85.7 \%$, and an $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of 86.5, which is better than current dashboards by more than $15 \%$ in all three measures. ANOVA and paired t-tests accepted the value of these improvements as statistically accurate ($\mathbf{p}\lt $ 0.05). In addition, six-month longitudinal research studies found that engagement and academic persistence among students with BDV-MFLA feedback remained $\mathbf{1 2 \%}$ higher than those of controls. The key value of the study is to integrate the representation of big data with multimodal learning feedback to build an intelligent and scalable, adaptable analytics system capable of not only enhancing the interpretability of the analysis but also influencing the behaviour of students over time and positively impacting their performance.

title: Analysis of CNN Model Vulnerabilities through Adversarial Attack-Based Image Generation Technique
authors: Seonyul Shin, Dongho Shin, Jeongwon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This study investigates the performance variations of deep learning classification models by combining GAN-generated images and adversarially perturbed data using the Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM) on the MNIST dataset. First, a ResNet-18 model trained on the original MNIST dataset achieved a test accuracy of 98.87%, but its performance significantly dropped to 51.59% under FGSM attacks with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}= 0.2$</tex> [1]. Next, when trained on a mixed dataset that included GAN-generated images, the model's test accuracy improved to 99.15%; however, its accuracy further decreased to 35.18% when FGSM attacks were applied to the generated images. These results indicate that although data augmentation with GAN-generated samples can enhance general classification performance, it may also exacerbate the model's susceptibility to adversarial perturbations [2]. Therefore, future deep learning frameworks that rely on generated data should incorporate robustness-enhancing defense mechanisms to mitigate adversarial vulnerabilities [3]. By quantitatively analyzing the interaction between GAN-generated data and adversarial perturbations, this study provides foundational insights for developing data augmentation and defense strategies aimed at building robust and reliable artificial intelligence systems.

title: Opt-GPTQ: An Optimized GPTQ Combining Sparse Attention and Quantization Techniques
authors: Jie Kong, Junxiang Zhang, Jiheng Xu, Yalong Li, Shouhua Zhang, Jiehan Zhou, Yuhai Liu, Peng Liang, Quan Zhang, Luohan Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In the field of deep learning, traditional attention mechanisms face significant challenges related to high computational complexity and large memory consumption when processing long sequence data. To address these limitations, we propose Opt-GPTQ, an optimized Gradient-based Post Training Quantization (GPTQ) combining the Grouped Query Attention (GQA) mechanism with paging memory management, optimizing the traditional Multi-Head Attention (MHA) mechanism by grouping query heads and sharing key-value vectors. Optimized GQA (Opt-GQA) effectively reduces computational complexity, minimizes memory fragmentation, and enhances memory utilization for large-scale models. Opt-GPTQ is optimized for Data Center Units (DCUs) and integrated into the vLLM model to maximize hardware efficiency. It customizes GPU kernels to further enhance attention computation by reducing memory access latency and boosting parallel computing capabilities. Opt-GQA integrates Attention with Linear Biases (ALiBi) to reduce overhead and enhance long-sequence processing. Experimental results show that Opt-GPTQ significantly reduces computation time and memory usage while improving model performance.

title: Bridging the Simulation-to-Real Gap in Automatic Modulation Classification for 5G/6G: A Problem-Driven Critique and a Lightweight CBAM-Transformer Continuation
authors: S. Kirubakaran, M. D. Selvaraj, Bolimera Siddharth Sekhar, A. Paventhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Fifth-and sixth-generation (5G/6G) wireless systems demand robust spectrum awareness and adaptive waveform control, where Automatic Modulation Classification (AMC) plays a pivotal role in enabling cognitive radio, interference mitigation, and non-cooperative signal identification. However, existing AMC approaches, particularly deep learning-based methods, often rely on synthetic benchmarks that fail to capture real-world complexities such as Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) effects, hardware impairments, and variable framing. This paper identifies these simulation-to-real gaps and proposes a lightweight Convolutional Block Attention Module– Transformer (CBAM–T) architecture that fuses multi-view representations—I/Q with phase pre-correction, amplitude–phase, and short-time spectrum—through attention mechanisms and a compact temporal Transformer. Using a MATLAB-generated dataset with realistic impairments, we achieve an average accuracy of 70.47% for CBAM-T, comparable to CNN-T (70.47%) and MCMBNN-T (71.07%), while maintaining low complexity (500K parameters) for edge deployment. The solution enhances robustness at mid-to-low SNRs and clarifies boundaries among high-order Quadrature Amplitude Modulations (QAMs). We provide a detailed training recipe, deployment guidelines, and actionable inferences.

title: Parkinson's Disease Prediction and Analysis Using LSTM and RNN
authors: Atharv Milind Pujari, Vedang Ashish Kane, Divija Arjunwadkar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: This paper presents a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) based approach for prediction of Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) score to analyze the Parkinson's Disease (PD) progression using voice-based features. A sliding window technique is used with the LSTM during the prediction to capture the temporal patterns to make time-aware predictions. Both the models were tested on a dataset of 42 patients with PD and demonstrated a Mean Squared Error (MSE) of less than 2.0 for 22 subjects in the case of LSTM and 18 subjects in the case of RNN. The proposed approach focuses on modeling patient specific disease progression which enables personalized and noninvasive monitoring of Parkinson's disease.

title: Obstacle Avoidance for Indoor Mobile Robots Using Multi-Sensor Fusion and Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Renpeng Cui, Yan Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end obstacle avoidance framework for indoor mobile robots based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL), developed to enhance navigation performance in unknown and dynamic environments. A frontend multi-sensor fusion architecture is introduced to address challenges caused by irregular obstacles. LiDAR is the primary perception sensor, while an RGB-D camera provides complementary visual and depth information. The fusion core integrates semantic perception and depth refinement: semantic segmentation is applied to RGB images to generate binary and human-region masks projected onto the corresponding depth images. The refined depth maps are downsampled and aligned with LiDAR data to produce pseudo-LiDAR representations, capturing essential spatial features beyond LiDAR's vertical field of view. These fused observations are then fed into a decisionmaking network. Furthermore, to enable dynamic obstacle avoidance under partial observability without relying on a global prior map, a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) is incorporated into the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) framework, allowing temporal information encoding across sequential observations. Extensive experiments conducted in both simulated and realworld environments demonstrate the effectiveness and generalization capability of the proposed approach, achieving robust performance in scenarios with irregular and dynamic obstacles.

title: A Synchronization Stability Enhancement Method for Wind Turbines Based on the Seamless Switching Between GFL and GFM
authors: Xin Ma, Zhenjun Gao, Ping Wei, Xuetao Dong, Chao Huo, Ran Cao, Bin Hu, Heng Nian
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a synchronization stability enhancement method for wind turbines with a seamless switching between Grid-Following (GFL) and Grid-Forming (GFM) control modes. Analysis reveals that GFL control exhibits strong stability under strong grid but weak stability under weak grids, while GFM control demonstrates the opposite stability characteristics. Leveraging this complementarity, the method dynamically switches control modes based on grid strength to suppress oscillation. To address power transients and waveform distortion during switching process, a seamless strategy is developed by analyzing control dominance under different time scales and implementing reference signal inheritance. Simulation results demonstrate that the approach significantly improves wind turbine adaptability to wide grid strength ranges, effectively suppresses oscillations, and eliminates power shocks during the process, enhancing equipment safety and power quality.

title: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Regression Models in EMG-Based Muscle Fatigue Prediction
authors: Md Asjad Raza, Raghuram Karthik Desu, Sreejith Mohan, S.P. Sivapirakasam, Dalley Krishnan
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Monitoring muscle fatigue progression is critical for optimizing training, preventing injury, and guiding rehabilitation. This study proposes a machine learning framework to estimate Time-To-Failure (TTF) during sustained isometric contraction using surface electromyography (sEMG) signals. Raw EMG signals were segmented into sliding windows and transformed into physiologically relevant features across time, frequency, and nonlinear domains. Four regression models—Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), Neural Network (NN), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Random Forest (RF) were trained and evaluated on their ability to predict remaining TTF in real-time. The results show that GPR outperformed other models with the lowest Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) (4.75 s), highest R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (0.92), and a relatively unbiased residual distribution. Residual analysis revealed consistent underestimation by SVR and RF, while GPR maintained symmetric residuals across fatigue stages. Statistical comparisons using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test confirmed significant differences (p < 0.05) between most model pairs, establishing the superiority of GPR over both conventional and ensemble-based approaches. The proposed framework enables interpretable and continuous fatigue estimation using minimal sensor input, highlighting its applicability in ergonomics, neurorehabilitation, and sports science. Unlike previous studies limited to fatigue classification, this regression-based TTF prediction offers finer granularity and real-time deployability, especially when integrated into wearable EMG systems. Future work will extend this approach to dynamic tasks, subject-independent generalization, and feature-level fusion with neuromechanical variables to enhance robustness and clinical translation.

title: Load Frequency Control of Diversified Power System with Improved Fruit Fly Algorithm Based Fractional Order Regulator
authors: Ch. Naga Sai Kalyan, B. Srikanth Goud, Subhashree Choudhury, Swati Shukla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This work aims to develop a soft computing methodology-tuned regulator that can ensure the power system’s dynamic stability. In this regard, an improved fruit fly algorithm (IFFA)-based tilt-integral-derivative-filter (TIDF) is presented as a frequency regulator whose functioning is tested on the dual-area, diverse-sourced power system (DADSPS). For a 10% step load perturbation (SLP), the analysis is initiated, and at the same instance, to reveal the TIDF efficacy, the comparative study is made with the other controllers in literature. Later, the DADSPS is incorporated with the supplementary control technique, and the analysis is performed under the proposed secondary control of IFFA-tuned TIDF. The superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is injected in the control areas, and the tie-line is penetrated with the Thyristor-controlled phase shifter (TCPS) to get the DADSPS stability improvement. The simulation work demonstrated the significance of employing the SMESTCPS in getting the dynamic stability enhancement. At last, the DADSPS, under the supervision of secondary and the adopted supplementary technique, is subjected to load deviations, and the analysis confirmed the ability of the suggested control mechanisms in ensuring the system’s stability even under unexpected load fluctuations.

title: Time Travel: LLM-Assisted Semantic Behavior Localization with Git Bisect
authors: Yujing Wang, Weize Hong
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: We present a novel framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) into the Git bisect process for semantic fault localization. Traditional bisect assumes deterministic predicates and binary failure states—assumptions often violated in modern software development due to flaky tests, non- monotonic regressions, and semantic divergence from upstream repositories. Our system augments bisect traversal with structured chain-of-thought reasoning, enabling commit-by-commit analysis under noisy conditions. We evaluate multiple open-source and proprietary LLMs for their suitability, and fine-tune DeepSeek- Coder-V2 using QLoRA on a curated dataset of semantically labeled diffs. We adopt a weak-supervision workflow to reduce annotation overhead, incorporating human-in-the-loop corrections and self-consistency filtering. Experiments across multiple open- source projects show a 6.4-point absolute gain in success rate (from 74.2% to 80.6%), leading to significantly fewer failed traversals and—by experiment—up to 2x reduction in average bisect time. We conclude with discussions on temporal reasoning, prompt design, and fine-tuning strategies tailored for commit-level behavior analysis.

title: Method of Moments for Optimal Ring Ratio Under Two-Ring M APSK Modulation
authors: Vincent Livudo Aquino, Peter O. Akuon, Gevira Otieno
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents an analytical framework for deriving optimal ring ratio for M-ary amplitude-phase shift keying (MAPSK) modulation scheme, which is mapped as a toroid of two rings. The theory of an electric dipole moment is used to characterize the symbol constellation for MAPSK as an analogy. Each symbol is treated as an electric charge in the configuration. The law of equilibrium is then applied on the moment of force of the inner ring and the outer ring to compute the radius ring-ratio. Since there are M points on the constellation, the amount of variance, $\sigma^{2}$ among the symbols is estimated through conventional biased variance estimated from a sample population as $\sigma^{2}=\frac{M}{M-1}$. Validation tests for different ring-ratios for the radii are carried out through the analysis of symbol error rate (SER). The two-ring constellation is implemented as a toroid for 8-, 16- and 32-APSK under Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channel. Applications for higher order PSK is found in Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB- S2) with M = 8 and Single-Carrier Frequency Division Multiple Access (SC-FDMA) in Long-Term Evolution (LTE) with $M=16$. Visible Light Communication (VLC) is another candidate for APSK system. The optimal ring-ratios are found to be $\mathbf{1. 7 5}$, $\mathbf{1. 6}$ and 1.4596, for 8-, 16- and 32-APSK, respectively.

title: Privacy-Utility Trade-offs in Federated Learning for 6G Networks: A Systematic Evaluation of Software-based Privacy Mechanisms
authors: Jawaad Ahmar, Iqra Batool, Mostafa M. Fouda, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Zubair Md Fadlullah
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enhances privacy by training models locally, but remains vulnerable to inference attacks. We systematically evaluate software-based privacy mechanisms in FL for 6G networks, comparing Homomorphic Encryption (HE), Differential Privacy (DP), and hybrid approaches. We implemented five configurations including our novel Sequential Hybrid that temporally separates DP (training phase) and HE (aggregation phase), unlike existing simultaneous methods. Evaluations on CIFAR-10 revealed clear privacy-utility trade-offs: stronger privacy mechanisms progressively reduced accuracy while improving protection. Our sequential approach outperformed simultaneous application in learning stability, while HE demonstrated superior resilience to data heterogeneity compared to hybrid methods under non-IID conditions. This systematic evaluation provides empirical guidance for privacy mechanism selection in 6G networks requiring both strong privacy and robust performance across heterogeneous devices.

title: AI-Driven Prediction of ICU Admission After Left Heart Catheterization: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Ardian Prima Atmaja, Chastine Fatichah, Ratih Nur Esti Anggraini, Wijayanti Nurul Khotimah
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study developed an AI-driven predictive model for ICU admission following Left Heart Catheterization (LHC) using the MOVER database (1,779 procedures, 1,591 patients, 2017-2022). A novel three-stage hybrid feature selection methodology—combining mutual information filtering, recursive feature elimination with cross-validation (RFECV), and Lasso L1 regularization—reduced dimensionality from 48 to 12 features (75% reduction). Eight machine learning algorithms were evaluated on ADASYN-balanced data with 10-fold stratified cross-validation, with the optimized CatBoost model achieving exceptional performance: AUROC 0.973, accuracy 93.2%, F1-score 93.2%, MCC 0.897, and false negative rate 7.14%. SHAP analysis identified disch_disp_home routine (SHAP value: 1.023) as the dominant predictor, followed by device_foley and med_beta_blocker. The three-tier risk stratification system demonstrated strong calibration with actual ICU rates of 3.1% (low risk), 9.1% (moderate risk), and 92.9% (high risk). This clinically deployable model addresses critical gaps in perioperative AI through rigorous feature selection, transparent interpretability via SHAP/LIME analysis, and reproducible methodology using open-access data, facilitating evidence-based ICU resource planning and preoperative decision support.

title: Dynamic Prognosis of Cardiovascular Disease Using Emr-Enhanced AI and Ml Models
authors: Supriya Telsang, Ragini Pawar, Samarth Pawar, Piyush Pawar, Sanika Pawar, Piyush Patne
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: CVD) continues to be a leading cause of death globally, often progressing silently until it reaches life-threatening stages. With modern sedentary lifestyles and rising risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and smoking, early detection has become a critical necessity. This research proposes a robust AI-driven fusion framework that integrates Electronic Medical Record (EMR) data with Electrocardiogram (ECG) signal predictions to assess heart disease risk more accurately and non-invasively. A machine learning model using CatBoost was trained on structured EMR features including age, sex, blood pressure, cholesterol, glucose level, and lifestyle indicators. Parallelly, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) was trained on ECG signal data to extract temporal patterns. The output probabilities from both models were then fused using a meta-classifier to deliver a final cardiovascular risk prediction. The system demonstrated promising performance across multiple train-test splits, achieving accuracy levels above 95%, with significant improvement in interpretability and real-time usability. A userfriendly web interface was also developed using Streamlit to deploy the model, enabling interactive input, real-time prediction, and downloadable health reports—making it a practical tool for both patients and medical professionals.

title: Design of an Electric Drive System Powered by Renewable Sources
authors: Toufik Roubache, Fouad Berrabah
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: The most serious disturbances to occur in electric vehicles (EVs) are the management of electric energy sources, which can affect the performance and efficiency of the EV. In this paper, various renewable sources are proposed for an electric drive system, equipped with a double stator induction motor (DSIM) connected to the EV. Overall, this study is centered on the application of multisource energy storage systems in EV drive system, mainly photovoltaic power generation system (PV), battery source (BS), and fuel cell (FC). A Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) controller for a PV system connected to BS which ensures an uninterrupted power supply of the EV, during the steady-state response as well as the temporary behavior. Simulation results are given to demonstrate the benefits of the use of various renewable sources in EVs drive.

title: SEE-FuseNet: A Stage-Enhanced Multi-Level Feature Fusion Framework for Eye Disease Classification
authors: Panigrahi Srikanth, Y. C. A. Padmanabha Reddy, Kancharagunta Kishan Babu
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Eye diseases remain a leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide, where early and accurate diagnosis is essential for effective treatment. Automated classification of fundus images, however, is challenging due to heterogeneous disease patterns, class imbalance, and limited availability of annotated datasets. To address these issues, we propose SEE-FuseNet, a Stage-Enhanced Multi-Level Feature Fusion framework for robust eye disease classification. The architecture employs EfficientNet-B4 as the backbone for hierarchical feature extraction, while a novel Multi-Level Feature Fusion (MLFF) module—comprising Stage Enhancers, Lateral Reduce, Fuse Mix, and Unify Channel operations—refines and harmonizes multi-scale representations. The fused features are further enhanced using a Transformer encoder and an MLP classifier to capture global dependencies and improve discriminative power across ten eye disease categories. Extensive experiments were conducted on both original and augmented datasets to compare SEE-FuseNet against several baseline backbones. Among the baselines, EfficientNet-B4 consistently demonstrated superior performance, validating its effectiveness as the backbone choice. SEE-FuseNet further improved upon this, achieving 0.9003 accuracy, 0.9015 F1 Score, and 0.8897 MCC on the augmented dataset, and 0.8091 accuracy on the original dataset. These results confirm that SEE-FuseNet effectively integrates spatial and semantic features with global contextual information, achieving superior robustness and generalization for automated eye disease classification.

title: DeepFake Analysis : A Review of Recent Studies, Detection Methods and Trends in Deepfake Detection
authors: Parveen Kaur, Chirag Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The fast growth of digital media and online communication tools has changed a lot about how information is made, shared, and used. As an example of how this revolution has also opened the gate to harmful uses, think about deepfake photos and videos, which are fake content made using AI methods that change people's facial expressions in videos in a way that looks real. Changes to visual content on Deepfakes can spread false information, violate privacy, and make people less likely to believe proof. The growth of deepfakes is due to the wider availability of generative models, such as autoencoders and GANs. This information has important and scary effects in the real world, ranging from political lying to following celebrities.

title: Hybrid GRU-Convolutional Neural Networks for Alzheimer’s Progression Prediction from Neuroimaging
authors: Parthasarathi Pattnayak, Tulip Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Early and accurate staging of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is crucial for timely intervention and patient care. This work proposes a GRU-CNN hybrid deep learning framework that integrates multimodal medical imaging with clinical data to classify AD’s progression. EfficientNet-B7 and 3D CNNs are employed for spatial feature extraction from 2D and volumetric scans, respectively, while Gated Recurrent Units (GRUs) capture temporal dependencies from longitudinal data. Attention-enhanced CNN modules further refine feature selection. A Softmax-based multi-class classification approach outputs stage probabilities, with performance evaluated using AUC, accuracy, F1-Score, precision and recall. Results demonstrate the model’s robustness and potential for clinical integration in aiding early AD diagnosis and progression tracking.

title: Dual-Modality Smart Shoes for Health Assessment: A Primary Study in Heart Failure using the 6-Minute Walk Test
authors: Qijun Ying, Chenghao Deng, Kangyu Chen, Yuchen Zhong, Huajun Long, Xiaohui Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Assessing exercise capacity is essential for man-aging chronic diseases like heart failure. Traditional methods, such as cardiopulmonary exercise testing, are accurate but confined to specialized settings. Recent advancements in wear-able technologies provide new opportunities for remote and continuous health monitoring. This study introduces a dual-modality smart shoe system integrating inertial and pressure sensors, designed for health assessment during the six-minute walk test. In a primary study involving 18 heart failure patients, we validated the system’s accuracy in estimating the six-minute walk distance (6MWD) using a drift-resistant foot orientation-based turn detection algorithm. The proposed system achieved a mean error of 1.36 ± 3.21 meters for 6MWD estimation. Additionally, novel plantar pressure features were developed to assess left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), a critical cardiac function indicator. Incorporating these features into a machine learning framework achieved 2.65% mean absolute error and 3.11% standard deviation error in leave-one-out cross-validation. This study demonstrates the feasibility of dual-modality smart shoes for accurate 6MWD estimation and preliminary LVEF evaluation in heart failure patients. Future research should explore the clinical scalability of this approach in larger, multi-center studies.

title: A Comprehensive Drug Classification Analysis Using Classical Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Arooj Imtiaz, Fariha Shoukat, Ahthasham Sajid, Ishu Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: From last few years almost every field has developed or designed applications of artificial intelligence on this basis those fields have received new breakthroughs. Among these all fields, designing a drug and its classification is among the most important areas in the field of medical which not only can be proved as a greatest help or a helping hand in the current era but also would be a great breakthrough in the medical field. On one hand, according to the statistics, there is a decrease in the newly listed drugs but at the same time there we can see a great hike in the production price on the development of drugs both things are in opposite direction to each other. To treat a patient with most appropriate drug on the basis of physiological and biochemical patterns suggesting a drug or classifying them are considered most critical. In this study, we classify the drugs on the basis of specific problem which can reduce the human efforts and increase the efficiency. A structured dataset of 5000 entries was used; data was preprocessed and analyzed in order to classify the appropriate the drugs. The contribution of this work is state-of-the-art in drug classification records. Personalized medicines are depending mostly on data-driven decision support systems. In this work variety of traditional machine learning models are compared to see what model performs well on the classification based data and patient level data. KNN performs better with performance metrics of 0.99.

title: Towards Adaptive and Scalable DDoS Detection in Distributed System using Tuned Hierarchical Machine Learning Techniques
authors: K Manivannan, S Jayanthi, T Kavitha, M Geetha, P Arockia Mary, S Nelson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: A DDoS attack detection system is a software that constantly monitors the network or system activities in order to identify the anomalous patterns and detect the activities that are potentially malicious or harmful in nature. In the present era, cybercriminals provide a wide range of strategies to access confidential data. With the growth of the Internet, new threats emerge -mainly viruses and worms. Most, however, exploit vulnerabilities as are exposed in discussions regarding a variety of approaches such as password-cracking and interception of unencrypted data. Thus, security measures are effected to prevent systems from unauthorized access. Firewall technology is the most popular type of the defense mechanism to try to protect private networks from other types of attacks on the outsideIDS plays a significant role in network security, healthcare applications, credit card fraud detection, and insurance sectors. The main goal of research to be conducted within this study is a comparative analysis of DDoS detection, based on the different machine learning and deep learning models described above. Some machine learning approaches, including Random Forest (RF), SVM, and Gradient Boosting (GB), are used to develop IDS with realtime datasets such as DDoS attack detection set and the UNSW datasets for attacker networks. Gradient Boosting, which is an effective classification algorithm that performs complex interactions of multiple independent variables in relation to one or several categorical target classes, mostly is the choice behind this approach. In this approach, decision nodes are assigned adaptive weights, with greater weight assigned to the attributes that highly influence a given node, whereas less impactful features exert little influence on the prediction outcomes. The accuracy and performance evaluation metrics will be the basis for validation of the proposed system, implemented in Python.

title: Plant Disease Identification based on LIME-CNN
authors: Sonali Dash, V.Keerthi Kiran, Gupteswar Sahu, Venkata Lalitha Narla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Conventional image processing techniques identify the features of the diseases manually, which demonstrate poor efficacy and poor detection rate. To solve this issue, this work has suggested an improved convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture that is utilized for multi-class recognition of plant disease images. Initially, the traditional network, such as GoogLeNet and EfficientNet, is utilized for feature extraction and categorization. Secondly, the features of the traditional network are enhanced by hybridizing with low low-light image enhancement algorithm. The experiment utilizes the sugarcane leaf disease dataset that is available on Kaggle. The results outperform the original CNN models. At the same time, the recommended techniques have converged with a faster speed than traditional approaches.

title: Analysing the Impact of Flexible Power Point Tracking in Grid-Tied PV Systems with Varying Solar Irradiance and Load Conditions
authors: Ved Pravir, Tanmoy Roy Choudhury
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Over the past decade, grid-tied solar photovoltaic (SPV) system integration has grown significantly, aiding in the global shift to renewable energy, which results in the requirement that utility operators update grid codes to maintain the grid’s quality and dependability. Several different flexible power point tracking (FPPT) techniques have been put forth in different works of literature. Enabling grid-tied solar systems to function adaptively under changing irradiance and load conditions is the main goal of the FPPT algorithm. This ensures optimal energy consumption while adhering to grid support standards. Variations from the maximum power point (MPP) could result from this interference, reducing the efficiency of the PV system. In spite of that, FPPT makes PV systems more grid-friendly and reliable. There are major technological issues brought about by the growing integration of PV generation into traditional power networks. Excessive power injection under high solar irradiation can cause unanticipated overloading and a spike in voltage in the distribution network, which could result in sensitive electrical equipment malfunctioning or being damaged. The simulation analysis presented in this paper aims at analyzing the impact of grid-tied SPV panels by evaluating the system’s overall performance in varying load and irradiation scenarios under two techniques, i.e., PV Voltage Control and Current Limiting Control (CLC) of Power Limiting Control (PLC) strategy. The study explores scenarios based on these variations and discusses their implications in detail.

title: Designing a Conversational Agent for Competence Development
authors: José Pedro Schardosim Simão, Letícia Sophia Rocha Machado, Juarez Bento Da Silva, Patrícia Alejandra Behar
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and proof-of-concept of a conversational agent integrated into a competence management system to assist students in competence development. The agent leverages Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) to provide tailored feedback and recommend learning strategies based on students’ proficiency levels. The proposed system includes a structured competence management system, a recommendation engine, and an interactive chatbot that engages users in guided learning experiences. The architecture of the system is built using Django, PostgreSQL, and OpenAI’s API, ensuring a scalable and adaptable solution for different learning contexts. The agent is designed to be integrated with Learning Management Systems (LMS) via LTI and employs the xAPI standard to track user interactions. Through a structured interaction model, students receive custom responses that foster self-regulated learning. While the application demonstrates potential for competence development, its effectiveness must be validated through real-user testing. Future research will focus on usability evaluations and refining AI-driven recommendations to enhance educational outcomes.

title: About the Institute
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)

title: IMAS 2025 TOC
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)

title: FST-SMO position observer for PMSM Sensorless Control Based on Hill Climbing Compensation
authors: Zhe Song, Weihong Zhou, Xi Xiao
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In the sensorless control system of permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM), the traditional sliding mode observer (SMO) exhibits significant estimation errors. To improve the accuracy of rotor position observation, a fast super-twisting sliding mode observer (FST-SMO) based on hill climbing method for position error compensation is proposed. First, an FST-SMO based on the d-q coordinate system is designed using an improved fast super-twisting algorithm, which enables the estimation of rotor speed and position while reducing chattering and ripples in the estimated back electromotive force (EMF). Second, to eliminate phase fluctuations and drifts in the observed position angle, a phase-locked loop (PLL) is constructed to extract estimation information, avoiding the use of low-pass filters and the reconstruction of position errors, thereby enhancing dynamic performance and observation accuracy. In response to non-ideal factors such as control delays, installation errors, and parameter variations, an intelligent hill climbing control method is employed to optimize and compensate for the observed error angle, further improving observation accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that this method achieves accurate speed and rotor position observation with excellent performance.

title: Manifold-Based Adaptive Cruise Control for Autonomous Vehicle Platoons
authors: Yuxuan Chang, Chenlei Hou, Zhiqun Yuan, Weiqiang Chen, Zhenyu Qin, Xuewu Ji, Shuiwen Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Driveability is a key criterion for vehicular longitudinal motion control. Traditional adaptive cruise control (ACC) systems employ separate speed and range control, which injects unnecessary disturbances when switching between the strategies thus degrades the driveability significantly. This paper proposes a unified manifold-based architecture that integrates two key concepts: d-field control, which generates a control action based on the state’s distance to kernel function, and a-field control, a nonlinear kinematic accelerating/braking strategy. By unifying these approaches into a single continuous control law, the proposed manifold-based ACC (mACC) eliminates the switching. This not only enhances the single-vehicle driveability but also provides an intrinsic mechanism for alleviating platoon-level disturbances. System stability is formally proven using the Lyapunov principle, and a novel phase-portrait analysis offers a holistic assessment of global performance. Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) testing further validates the controller’s superior performance as well as the real-time feasibility. This work therefore establishes a foundation of developing an unified control strategy for the robust and stable multi-vehicle systems.

title: Tendon-Actuated Galvanometer Robot (TAGR) Towards Minimally Invasive Hybrid Surgical Laser Steering
authors: Kent K. Yamamoto, Behnam Moradkhani, Tanner J. Zachem, Patrick J. Codd, Yash Chitalia
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Surgical lasers are becoming increasingly prevalent in minimally invasive procedures, as laser fibers are thin and flexible, allowing for precise targeting. The use of surgical lasers spans tissue manipulation, energy delivery (in laser interstitial thermal therapy), imaging (optical coherence tomography), and tumor identification. There are two primary methods for steering surgical lasers: fiber steering and free-beam steering using galvanometers. In practice, however, lasers must first traverse through complex anatomical structures, then the laser must be steered with high precision while the tool body avoids critical anatomy. In this paper, we develop a steerable surgical tool that combines both fiber and free-beam steering, the Tendon-Actuated Galvanometer Robot (TAGR). The proposed ball-chain (BC) robot can bend in 3D space, then utilizes a 2-DoF tendon-actuated galvanometer (TAG) at the end-effector to steer the laser on a surface while the robot body is static. Both BC kinematics and 2-DoF TAG laser kinematics models are presented and validated. Closed-loop PID control is implemented in both robot and laser steering, resulting in RMSE values of less than 2.5 mm and 3.7 mm for independent and hybrid steering, respectively. The novel hybrid laser steering system is then demonstrated within a phantom rib-cage model to showcase how novel hybrid laser steering can impact minimally invasive laser surgery.

title: Real-Time Constraint-Aware Inverse Kinematics Via Passivity-Based Dynamics Simulation
authors: Jeongseob Lee, Dongjun Lee
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: We propose a novel inverse kinematics (IK) solver based on an optimization–simulation duality, in which the conventional optimization-based IK problem is reformulated as a forward dynamics simulation of a virtual mechanical system. The IK solution emerges as the equilibrium of this system, corresponding to the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions of the original problem. To ensure the stability of the discrete-time forward simulation, we adopt the passive midpoint integrator (PMI) [1], which enforces a discrete-time passivity. This allows the proposed method to converge to an equilibrium without the need for line search. The resulting solver is lightweight, scalable, and suitable for real-time inverse kinematics computation in high-degree-of-freedom (DOF) systems, while satisfying joint limits, obstacle avoidance, and other task-specific constraints. The efficacy of the algorithm is validated and demonstrated through extensive simulations on various robotic platforms.

title: IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Society Information
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

title: An End-to-End Cost-Focused Wind Power Forecasting Framework Based on Convex Hulls
authors: Chenghan Li, Yinliang Xu, Hongbin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: The traditional prediction methods primarily emphasize accuracy. This letter presents an end-to-end training framework that integrates a convex hull support function with the Mean Squared Error (MSE) for cost-focused learning. Specifically, by introducing a convex hull loss, decision cost information is incorporated into the model's learning process, while the MSE term ensures that the predicted results align with the actual distribution. Experimental results on the IEEE-33 bus system demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a 12.4% improvement in cost reduction compared with traditional forecasting methods. Furthermore, the proposed approach significantly improves training efficiency compared with other decision-focused baselines. The proposed framework provides a generalizable paradigm for cost-aware forecasting under renewable uncertainty.

title: Optimal SCUC Considering Nodal RoCoF Security Constraints in Single Generator Trip Contingencies
authors: Licheng Wang, Xianpeng Zeng, Bomiao Liang, Yu Yang, Youbing Zhang, Fushuan Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: The rate of change of frequency (RoCoF) is a critical metric of power system frequency security. Post contingency nodal RoCoFs are not identical across a power system, with spatial characteristic significantly related to the fault size/location, network connections and parameters, as well as the system's inertia distribution state. However, most traditional security-constrained unit commitment (SCUC) strategies typically rely on aggregated frequency models, lacking necessary granularity to differentiate disparities among nodal RoCoFs. Consequently, certain generators may suffer from extremely large RoCoFs, potentially triggering unexpected pole slip protection and trip operations, even if the system's RoCoF estimated by an aggregated model remains within the allowable range. To address this issue, a nodal RoCoF security constrained unit commitment is proposed considering N-1 contingencies of any single generator trip in this letter. First, unified boundary conditions of generators are established to depict their disparate inertia response behaviors in online/offline states. Then, nodal RoCoF security constraints are further derived and embedded into an optimization problem for SCUC scheduling. Following the proposed SCUC strategy, nodal RoCoF security can always be guaranteed in any single generator trip contingencies, which is further verified by simulation results of the South East Australia Power System in different scenarios.
