title: Service Continuity for Serverless-Edge Consumer Applications: Opportunities and Issues
authors: Carlo Puliafito, Antonio Virdis, Enzo Mingozzi
publish: IEEE Consumer Electronics Magazine
abstract: Service continuity is a critical requirement for serverless systems deployed across the cloud-edge continuum, where dynamic conditions such as user mobility, network disruptions, and resource constraints are common. Serverless computing promises scalability, transparency, and efficiency, but ensuring seamless function execution across distributed and heterogeneous environments remains challenging. This article explores the functional and operational dimensions of service continuity in serverless edge computing systems. We identify core consumer scenarios and analyze challenges related to invocation routing, secure communication, and session-state management. We present recent advances and candidate solutions, including application-layer redirection, transport-layer connection migration, post-quantum cryptography, and hybrid state management. Our findings highlight the need for platform-level support and coordination between computing and networking components to achieve transparent, efficient, and secure service continuity at the serverless-operated edge. Ultimately, service-continuity mechanisms are key enablers of future consumer technologies, where always-on, latency-critical experiences depend on resilient and seamless function execution.

title: Panoramic Active Visual System for Distant Traffic Sign Recognition
authors: Xuan Yuwen, Ziwang Lu, Jicheng Chen, Long Chen, Hui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traffic sign recognition (TSR) is one of the most important visual perception tasks for autonomous vehicles. Traffic signs situated far away occupy only a few pixels in the images captured by the cameras of the autonomous vehicle, which presents a challenge for TSR methods to give accurate and reliable results. In this paper, we propose a panoramic active visual system (PAVS) for distant traffic signs recognition. It combines the advantages of the active pan-tilt-zoom(PTZ) camera for long-distance viewing and the advantage of the panoramic camera to have a large field of view. The traffic signs will be preliminarily detected and tracked in the panoramic image and the objects with confidence lower than the threshold will be further detected by the active PTZ camera to get more reliable results. The proposed PAVS are tested with different state-of-the-art (SoTA) TSR networks in real traffic scenes and the experimental results show that, compared to the passive visual system, the performances of the proposed PAVS improve 8.5% in F1-score, 5.3% in mAP, and 60.2% in mean first detection distance (mFD) in traffic sign recognition tasks.

title: SLM-VINS: Advancing Visual-Inertial SLAM via Hierarchical Spatial Line Integration and Multi-Mechanism Marginalization
authors: Xiangyu Li, Baoqi Huang, Bing Jia, Lifei Hao, Hao Gong, Zhenwei Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) has emerged as a cornerstone technology in intelligent transportation systems (ITS) and autonomous robots, finding widespread applications in various scenarios and multiple platforms autonomous driving tasks. However, in environments with weak textures and motion blur, achieving efficient and robust visual-inertial SLAM remains challenging. Current research utilizes line features to enhance SLAM performance in such environments, but incurs difficulties in line extraction, structured scene representation, and computational overheads involved in joint optimization. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a novel SLAM framework with both high pose estimation accuracy and high back-end computational efficiency. Firstly, an intelligent spatial line integration method is proposed to effectively reduce data redundancy in joint optimization by leveraging the remarkable stability of long line segments in structured scenes, thereby enhancing the spatial consistency of structural lines. Secondly, to combat low-light and high-speed motion environments, an optical flow tracking accuracy verification method is designed to bolster the system’s tracking performance and robustness in complex scenarios. Finally, to relieve the substantial computational overhead arising from high-dimensional optimization parameters in bundle adjustment (BA), a multi-mechanism marginalization strategy is presented to enhance the accuracy and computational efficiency of BA, while also preventing scale explosion. Comparative evaluations against state-of-the-art algorithms on both the EuRoC MAV and TUM VI benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly improves localization accuracy and joint optimization efficiency.

title: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics Information for Authors
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics

title: Cross-Sensor bushfire Detection Using Supervised Domain Adaptation
authors: Md. Farhan Shakib, Md. Shahid Uz Zaman, Md. Al Mamun, Md. Nahiduzzaman, Muhammad E. H. Chowdhury, Azmain Yakin Srizon, A. F. M. Minhazur Rahman
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Bushfire detection using satellite imagery plays a critical role in mitigating ecological and economic damage. Traditional deep learning models perform well on specific satellite data but often fail when applied to imagery from different satellites due to differences in resolution, spectral bands, and calibration. This study addresses these cross-sensor challenges by proposing a supervised domain adaptation framework based on Deep CORrelation ALignment (Deep CORAL). A lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is trained on Landsat-8 imagery and adapted to Sentinel-2 data by jointly optimizing source classification loss, CORAL alignment loss, and supervised classification loss on labeled target samples. Results show that baseline model performs poorly on Sentinel-2 (fire-class F1-score = 55%, overall accuracy = 49%), while the domain-adapted model achieves a F1-score of 97% and overall accuracy of 97% in initial experiments. Further experiments across six spectral band combinations revealed that SWIR inclusion enhances cross-domain performance, with R-G-B-NIR-SWIR achieving 99.29% accuracy and 99.30% F1-score on target domain. Analysis of feature distances and PCA plots demonstrates that the latent representations are well aligned across sensors. A comparison with previous studies also confirms the superiority in performance for our proposed method. The proposed framework significantly improves cross-sensor generalization, leverages labeled data from both domains, and provides a scalable, near-real-time solution for large-scale bushfire monitoring using heterogeneous satellite sources.

title: ISRITI 2025 Opinion
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)

title:
ISAC-Enabled Handover Design in LEO Satellite Networks
                    <sup/>
authors: Sovit Bhandari, Thang X. Vu, Nhan Thanh Nguyen, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Mega-constellations of low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites are envisioned to deliver global broadband and direct-to-cell services, requiring seamless handovers (HOs) to ensure uninterrupted connectivity. Conventional break-before-make HO protocols, although supported by inter-satellite links, suffer from beamforming delays due to the high orbital velocities of LEO satellites. To address these limitations, we propose an integrated sensing and communication (ISAC)-assisted HO (ISAC-HO) protocol that enables make-before-break HOs via ISAC-enabled ground terminals (GTs). A novel ISAC design capable of generating a three-dimensional (3D) beampattern under realistic conditions allows GTs to sense approaching LEO satellites without significantly compromising communication with the currently serving LEO satellite. The design problem is highly challenging due to its non-convexity and mixed-integer nature. To tackle these challenges, we propose an approach that leverages Riemannian manifold optimization and closed-form solutions. For multi-GT scenarios, we introduce a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework that mitigates sensing collisions and ensures quality-of-service under shared spectrum constraints. Numerical results confirm that the proposed ISAC design significantly improves the communication–sensing trade-off, enables smooth HO, and remains robust in the presence of imperfect channel state information.

title: Soft Label Pruning and Quantization for Large-Scale Dataset Distillation_supp1-3664488.pdf
authors: Yang He
publish: N/A
abstract: Large-scale dataset distillation requires storing auxiliary soft labels that can be 30-40× (ImageNet-1K) or 200× (ImageNet-21K) larger than the condensed images, undermining the goal of dataset compression. We identify two fundamental issues necessitating such extensive labels: (1) insufficient image diversity, where high within-class similarity in synthetic images requires extensive augmentation, and (2) insufficient supervision diversity, where limited variety in supervisory signals during training leads to performance degradation at high compression rates. To address these challenges, we propose Label Pruning and Quantization for Large-scale Distillation (LPQLD). We enhance image diversity via class-wise batching and BN supervision during synthesis. For supervision diversity, we introduce Label Pruning with Dynamic Knowledge Reuse to enhance label-per-augmentation diversity, and Label Quantization with Calibrated Student-Teacher Alignment to enhance augmentation-per-image diversity. Our approach reduces soft label storage by 78× on ImageNet-1K and 500× on ImageNet-21K while improving accuracy by up to 7.2% and 2.8%, respectively. Extensive experiments validate the superiority of LPQLD across different network architectures and other dataset distillation methods.

title: A Multimode Coupling Dispersion Model for Helically Corrugated Waveguides With Application to the Overmoded Regime
authors: Ying Xin Lai, Cheng Chen, Wei Chao Kuang, Shan Jin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Helically corrugated waveguides are critical components in many high-power microwave systems. However, theoretical analysis of their dispersion characteristics within the overmoded regime—essential for developing devices operating at high frequencies (terahertz band) or handling high power (megawatt level and beyond)—remains challenging for conventional two-mode coupling dispersion models. To address this limitation, a comprehensive multimode coupling dispersion model is developed, based on a generalized dispersion equation derived from vectorial coupled-wave equations that simultaneously account for interactions between an operating mode and multiple companion modes. The model is then applied to a fivefold helically corrugated cylindrical waveguide operating in a high-order mode. Within the target dispersion region, the multimode predictions show excellent agreement with full-wave simulations and experimental measurements, establishing the model’s validity in capturing the dispersion behavior that the two-mode model fails to reproduce. Furthermore, multimode dispersion analysis of an overmoded helically corrugated coaxial waveguide derived from the fivefold cylindrical prototype demonstrates that compressing multiple strong couplings into a narrow frequency band produces a single, sharp dispersion curve inflection. This strategy effectively overcomes the traditional “sparse mode spectrum” constraint, producing a superior monotonic group velocity profile over a wide bandwidth that significantly outperforms the original cylindrical structure. The proposed model provides both theoretical insight and a practical design tool for developing next-generation high-power microwave devices that employ overmoded helically corrugated waveguides.

title: Launch Strategy for Green Innovative Products Considering Recall Risk: Timing and Product Portfolio Decisions
authors: Chunyu Bao, Min Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: For firms committed to environmentally friendly (green) innovation, the launch strategy—particularly the choice of timing and product portfolio—critically affects both market opportunities and reliability risks. We develop a two-period model to examine how early launch decisions, mixed-product strategies, and proactive regulatory compliance interact under potential recalls. Our findings indicate that early launch is viable only when sufficient reliability is ensured, and that retaining mature products mitigates recall-related losses through a “risk-sharing effect”. Additionally, contrary to the traditional view that government regulation acts as a constraint, our study reveals that the “reliability assurance” aspect of government regulation can actually incentivise the firm to launch green innovative products earlier. Furthermore, the extension not only confirms the robustness of our model but also constructively suggests that strategic partial market withdrawal can internally motivate a firm's green innovation. These insights provide both theoretical and practical guidance for designing green product launch strategies that balance speed, performance, and risk.

title: BVRF-Net: Edge Detection Network Inspired by the Characteristics of Biological Visual Receptive Fields
authors: Zhefei Cai, Yingle Fan, Minchao Ye, Jianwei Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: As a kind of low-dimensional visual structural feature, edge helps to highlight the basic information of the image, playing the key role in the pre-processing of subsequent advanced visual tasks. Edge detection models with VGG16 as the basic framework can achieve excellent performance through transfer learning, but such models suffer from problems such as large number of parameters and high computational costs. To address the challenge of the coexistence of accuracy and lightweight, an edge detection network inspired by the characteristics of biological visual receptive fields (BVRF-Net) was proposed in the paper. In the Global Pathway, the ON/OFF type convolution kernel was constructed by simulating the ganglionic ON/OFF centroid type receptive field, initializing the convolution kernel by pixel difference value. Meanwhile, simulating the sparse suppression property of complex neurons, the sparse surround suppression convolution kernel with center periphery adjustment was constructed to suppress the texture noise. In the Local Pathway, the asymmetric orientation selectivity convolution kernel was constructed by simulating the orientation selectivity and asymmetric surround suppression characteristics of primary visual cortex neurons, which helps to quickly optimize the orientation features and enhance the contrast features by giving the convolution kernel a priori knowledge, achieving the precise extraction of local detail features. Taking BSDS500 dataset, NYUD-v2 dataset and Multicue dataset as experimental objects, BVRF-Net can achieve competitive results with only 0.358M parameters required. The excellent performance proves the effectiveness of incorporating bio-vision characteristics to construct neural network models, promoting the development of biomimetic computational vision.

title: Cascaded Symmetry-Aware Network for Component Segmentation of Satellites
authors: Yiman Zhu, Zhicai Dong, Lu Wang, Liaoxue Liu, Yu Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Visual perception of non-cooperative targets is crucial in close-range proximity operations for active debris removal and on-orbit servicing, which typically focus on box-wing satellites due to their high maintenance and recovery value. Most box-wing satellite targets are equipped with symmetrical solar pannels. Their repetitive textures and visual ambiguity pose significant challenges for local feature detectors, which is the foundation of downstream perception tasks. Additionally, constraints of computational resources remain persistent issues in this field. To address these challenges, a cascaded symmetry-aware network for component segmentation of satellites is proposed to provide semantic contexual information for local descriptor. Specifically, a two-stage learning strategy which mimics human intuition by inferring symmetric regions from asymmetric regions. To enhance regional awareness, a contrastive learning based auxiliary module is designed, enabling the network to learn spatial relationships and distinctive boundaries across images. The predicted symmetric component information is inserted to the discription vector to improve the feature matching result on box-wing satellites. In comparative experiments and application validation, our method demonstrated superior symmetry recognition capability across different targets and viewing angles and significantly improved the stability and accuracy of the 3D reconstruction.

title: Elderly FallGuard: An AI-Driven Assistive Technology for Fall Risk Prediction using Motion and Health Monitoring
authors: Harish S, Nila Bhaskar, Sivakami V, Tharuun M, Vishnu S, Vishnuvarthan Rajagopal
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Falls are the leading cause of injury, immobility, and death in elderly individuals, with one in four elderly individuals falling each year, creating enormous health, emotional, and economic consequences. While current fall detection systems are mostly reactive, only acting to respond to events after they have occurred, proactive prediction strategies are necessary. In this research, an innovative fall prediction system is introduced based on the integration of inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensors and vital monitoring technologies to predict and mitigate fall risks. The IMU placed on the foot tracks gait and movement patterns, and the wrist-worn device monitors health metrics like heart rate and oxygen saturation. The system uses a two-stage predictive framework that first analyzes data from IMU sensors and vital monitors independently to detect anomalies and combines these results using Multimodal Fall Prediction Algorithm (MFPA) to enhance accuracy. Users receive timely warnings and are alerted in real time, using a smart stick with an actuator that alerts users before they fall. The proposed system, with an accuracy of 95.2% using GRU for vitals and an accuracy of 99% using GRU for IMU, shows that integrating biomechanical and physiological data strongly improves the accuracy and reliability of fall risk prediction.

title: AI-Driven Classification of Encryption Techniques in Medical Image ROIs for Secure Transmission
authors: Diganth Vijayan R, Anindita Das Badhan, K Ashwini
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: The secure transmission of sensitive medical images is critical in modern healthcare. This paper presented an AI-driven approach for metadata-agnostic classification of encryption techniques applied to Regions of Interest (ROIs). Deep learning models were trained to identify the specific cipher used on encrypted medical image ROIs, enabling automated decryption routing without reliance on metadata. ROIs were encrypted with three chaotic map–based methods: (i) AES with Logistic Map permutation, (ii) Arnold Cat Map with Sine Map scrambling, and (iii) Sine Map with Logistic Map modification. The resulting dataset of encrypted ROIs was then used to train multiple Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), including ResNet18, VGG11, and EfficientNet-B0. Experimental results demonstrated high accuracy in distinguishing encryption techniques, validating the feasibility of AI-assisted cipher classification. The proposed framework enhanced privacy-preserving medical image communication in scenarios where metadata was unavailable or unreliable, bridging AI, cybersecurity, and healthcare.

title: The Implementation of Machine Learning and Deep Learning On Skin Tone Classification
authors: Evelyne W, Catheline D, Muhammad F.H
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Rapid advancements in technology in the modern era enabling human features analysis to improve efficiency and promoter innovation. Small improvements in digital analysis can significantly impact decision-making processes, especially in profit-driven fields like business, by helping identify trends. One feature increasingly examined is skin tone, used in medical diagnostics and personalized services like recommendation systems on e-commerce platforms. To perform effective digital analyses, various intelligent models are used. However, selecting the right model is critical due to the need for accuracy and the challenges posed by the dataset. Therefore, this study compares the performance of machine learning and deep learning models (SVM, CNN, SwinTransformer T) on a single classification task using RGB and HSV color analysis methods, providing guidance for choosing suitable models and techniques for skin tone classification. Results indicate that deep learning models perform better, with the SwinTransformer based on SwinT achieving a good recall rate (0.70). Although the HSV technique is more consistent in class separation, with a macro average score of 0.94, the RGB method excels at selecting target cases. This advantage is especially evident when facial features such as hair, eyes, and brows are removed, resulting in an over 33.57% improvement in model performance (RGB-Swin average score across four measures, estimated with a relative improvement formula).

title: Intelligent Reverse Vending Machine for Automated Collection and Shredding of PET Bottles Using YOLOv8 and ESP32
authors: Hakim Kharroubi, Mohamed Amine Ben Aissa, Ayoub Si Salah, Mohamed Islam Menaa, Hocine Moulai
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: Plastic pollution, especially from polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottles, poses a significant environmental threat. This paper presents an intelligent recycling system inspired by Reverse Vending Machines (RVMs) that automates the collection, classification, and shredding of plastic bottles. Using a YOLOv8 model for real-time PET detection and an ESP32 microcontroller for system control, the prototype achieved accurate identification and reliable shredding performance. The proposed solution offers a low-cost and eco-friendly approach to improving plastic waste management through the integration of artificial intelligence and embedded hardware.

title: A Federated Learning Approach for Personalized Online Course Recommendation Using Hybrid Recommender Strategies
authors: Raj Sinha, Vivek Jaglan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The rapid pace of growth in online learning environments has made it more difficult for learners to find courses that are tailored to their individual learning needs and goals. Typically, recommender systems rely on centralized data processing, which raises considerable concerns around user privacy and the heterogeneity of user data. This research presents a hybrid recommender system with Federated Learning (FL) characteristics to provide personalized recommendations to users while protecting their data. The recommender system creates four primary recommendation frameworks: Content-Based Filtering (CBF); Popularity-Based; Collaborative Filtering (simulated); and a novel Federated Learning approach that hybridizes on the three other recommended/first ranked approach, whose performance is evaluated with a graphical user interface (GUI) built using Tkinter that provides real-time recommendations to chosen users and comparisons amongst the four recommended approaches using multiple performance measures. The assessment of the systems' efficacy used seven typical evaluation metrics: Hit Rate, Precision@5, Recall@5, F1@5, Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR), Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain (NDCG@5), and Coverage. The bar charts demonstrated that while the Popularity-Based recommendation approach had the highest hit rate respectively and highest precision, it had very low coverage of recommending courses to learners. On the other hand, the Federated Learning-based approach produced a comparable hit rate and precision, while also achieving comparable F1 scores and coverage (86 %). This study emphasized the benefits and practicality of using Federated Learning to build contextually scalable, safe, and effective course recommender systems, and further emphasized the benefits of combining or hybridizing the two approaches for maximum robustness and quality of recommendations, especially for the educationallyfocused digital sphere.

title: AI-Powered Collaborative Robotics for Next-Gen Industrial Automation
authors: M Ramya, S. Subburam, Pushplata Patel, J. Seetaram, K. Ranjith Singh, Guma Ali, Zayd Ajzan Salami
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The runaway development of Industry 4.0 has brought very interconnected, intelligent, and automated production systems in place, but conventional robotics based on rules cannot react to dynamic production conditions, unpredictable working processes, and real-time disruptions, which tend to result in lower efficiency, time delays, and bottlenecks in the work process. Among common challenges faced by factories are inefficiencies in task allocation, the absence of collaborative coordination among robots, poor predictive maintenance, and vulnerabilities in data exchange during interactions. To address those issues, this research proposes AI-Powered Multi-Agent Collaborative Robotic System (AI-MACROS), a highly sophisticated industrial automation system integrating swarm intelligence, reinforcement learning, digital twin simulation, and blockchain-based security. AI-MACROS allows teams of robotic agents to work together, learn dynamically based on environmental interactions, optimize task distribution and deal with unexpected events in the real world. Through digital twins, it provides virtual replicas of robots and work processes, with which to monitor the system in real time, preemptive maintenance and simulate scenarios without disrupting the existing processes. Also, blockchain protocols guarantee integrity and safety of communication and data across the industrial network. Compared to a typical rulebased robotics, one may observe that AI-MACROS is executed by the high performance score (i.e. higher efficiency, accuracy, recall, and F1-scores), and the coordination and energy efficiency is additionally simplified with the help of particle swarm optimization, genetic algorithms and deep reinforcement learning. The proposed solution addresses the disadvantages of the traditional automation, making the operations more resilient in addition to improving the security and scale, not mentioning that it is deemed as not only a potential game changer but also as a next-generation smart factory solution. In a clever synergy, predictive analytics and safe decentralized information processing, AI-MACROS creates high-performance prototype of adaptable, fruitful and credible automation of production under realistic production scenarios.

title: Efficient Stochastic FP32 to INT4 Quantization in lightweight 32-bit RISC-V Processors
authors: S K Avinaash, Bharat R Patil, Aditya Chapparadahallimath, Rajeev Pankaj Nelapati
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Edge machine learning demands lightweight representations to balance accuracy with computational efficiency on resource-constrained devices. Quantization from 32-bit floating-point (FP32) to 4-bit integer (INT4) is key, but stochastic rounding (SR), which introduces randomness to reduce error accumulation, remains computationally expensive without dedicated hardware. This work introduces a compact RISC-V custom instruction extension for hardware-accelerated FP32→INT4 conversion with SR. Integrated into the PicoRV32 core via the PCPI coprocessor interface, it uses a lightweight Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) for randomness, avoiding the overhead of a full floating-point unit. Evaluated on cycle counts, hardware area, and rounding-error distributions, the extension achieves 4.2× speedup over an optimized software routine (54 cycles baseline) and 24× over full software FP emulation (316 cycles). Compared to deterministic rounding, SR improves error variance by up to 30% in simulated ML workloads. This low-overhead extension enables practical stochastic quantization on edge processors, facilitating accurate ML inference with negligible added cost. It demonstrates how targeted ISA enhancements can enable advanced ML techniques for IoT and embedded systems.

title: Application of AI in the Load Forecasting for Smart Grid
authors: Vineet Kumar Mishra, H K Verma, Arun Parikh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: For intelligent systems to be properly monitored, accurate resource projections are very important. With this knowledge, electrical system managers can predict changes in demand, make the best use of resources, and stop system overloads from happening. It is difficult to achieve adequate precision due to large flows in energy demand but the uncertainty introduced by RES makes it even more challenging. Previous efforts to address this situation have typically not been satisfactory. Our goal is to develop technology that is further advanced. This article provides research that looks at the ability of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to improve forecasting of load in smart grids. These studies include forecasting for the short term, medium term, and long term, whereas most review papers focus only on short term forecasts. AI is able to handle various types of data, perform precise calculations, and provide computational efficiency for each type of data. The Paper presents information about many current developments and innovations in the development of sustainable and reliable energy systems. This approach focuses primarily on research that has the ability to respond to instantaneously changing variables which workforce models may struggle with including economic data as well as social events, such as weather forecasting. Given the presence of uncontrolled variables their results indicate that intelligent systems may provide a more accurate prediction of energy demand. The researchers suggest that Hybrid models may improve predictive accuracy. Historically, this article drives home the work that ultimately needs to be more prevalent in the management of smart electricity systems given the adoption of AI smart grids.

title: Exploring the Influence of Technology Business Incubators on the Growth of Eco-Friendly Startups Using Green Financing Models
authors: Raminder Kaur Khattri, Vinay Kumar Jain, Prabh Deep Singh, Palki Sharma, Bhavna Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The crucial significance of technology business incubators is examined in this research which helps in fostering the scalability of sustainable startups and their growth with the help of green financing models. As the world's transition to sustainability quickens, startups put the main focus on environmental impact and green technologies which face the substantial barriers in scaling their operations and accessing capital. TBIs will help the startups by providing them resources, networks and mentorship which will help them to bridge the gaps. The study looks at how TBIs are incorporating the ideals of sustainable development into their incubation programs making access easier to various specialized green financing options like impact investing, green bonds and government incentives. Through examination of optimal practices this paper examines that how TBIs guide startups towards securing funds with the help of qualitative data and environmental, social and governance (ESG) criteria. By supporting these eco-friendly finance schemes TBIs play an evaluative role in fueling ecoinnovative success of startups and contributing to the larger circular economy. The paper also suggests that collaboration between investors, TBIs and policymakers is necessary to have a strong environment that encourages sustainable business practices.

title: Review on Optimizing Cloud Computing: Resource Allocation, Task Scheduling, and AI-Driven Enhancements
authors: Bommineni Narsimhulu, T. Sampath Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: With flexible access to computing power provided via the cloud computing, the traditional way of working with IT infrastructure has been changed. The article discusses to optimize the cloud systems from Resource Distribution, Optimization techniques and Task scheduling. Researchers have explored heuristic, metaheuristic, and AI-based approaches to reduce delays and costs.. It shows that AI driven methods can achieve $37.8 \%$ saving on energy consumption, $22 \%$ increase on SLA compliance, $30.4 \%$ on workload distribution efficiency. The deep reinforcement learning models reduce the task execution time by $31.5 \%$ and increase the CPU usage by $17 \%$. Blockchain has also been considered for multi cloud management of workload and it has resulted in a $62 \%$ decrease in unauthorized access efforts, and $57 \%$ decrease in data breach. The only troubles in introducing these capabilities are the high computational demands, security efficiency tradeoffs, and real time adaptation flaws. While the authors provide a way to improve AI heuristic models, energy aware scheduling and scalable security, this study also shows where current methods fail and how they may be strengthened. The study’s results indicate that by combining the AI and blockchain, we can build the cloud systems to be more efficient, secured and less expensive for the future

title: ResNet-Swin Transformer Fusion with Shifted Window Attention for Multi-Class Plant Disease Classification with Weighted Sampling
authors: Kishor Chettri, Biswaraj Sen, Rupert Anand Yumlembam, Palash Ghosal
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Plant diseases pose a critical challenge to global agriculture, contributing to significant crop losses and threatening food security. Conventional disease identification methods such as manual inspections and laboratory tests are often inefficient and labor intensive, prone to misdiagnosis due to the visual similarity of symptoms between different diseases. This paper introduces a hybrid deep learning model that combines the ResNet-50 and Swin Transformer architectures to improve plant disease classification by capturing localized and global contextual features. Comprehensive augmentation approaches: rotation, flipping, color jittering, resized cropping, Gaussian blur ensure robust learning across diverse datasets. Our study includes several datasets, proving the robustness of the model across largescale datasets such as PlantVillage ($99.87 \%$), real-time dataset such as PlantDoc $(81.00 \%)$, and as well as its flexibility in smaller, domain-specific datasets such as the Rice Leaf dataset $(92.00 \%)$ accuracy on the test set. A weighted cross-entropy loss along with a WeightedRandomSampler is used to reduce class imbalance, an Adam optimizer is used with a ReduceLROnPlateau scheduler to modify the learning rate dynamically, and early stopping is used to prevent overfitting. These components collectively enable the model to achieve state-of-the-art accuracy for multi-class plant disease classification on the PlantVillage dataset while maintaining competitive performance across other benchmark datasets, underscoring its potential as a scalable solution for precision agriculture and disease diagnostics.

title: Enhancing IoT-Enabled Electric Vehicle Battery Performance Monitoring and Prediction using AI Techniques
authors: Mummadi Durga Bhavani, K. Kalyan Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid adoption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) has intensified the need for efficient battery monitoring and predictive maintenance to ensure safety, longevity, and optimal performance. This study presents an advanced framework integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) with Internet of Things (IoT) technology to monitor and predict EV battery health in real time. The IoT-based system employs state-of-the-art sensors to collect key battery parameters, including temperature, voltage, current, and charge cycles. Data is analyzed using AI models such as Machine Learning and deep learning algorithms to detect anomalies, forecast degradation, and optimize energy management. The proposed approach achieves high predictive accuracy, with metrics Mean Absolute Error (MAE: 0.0790), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE: 0.1040), and $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ score (0.9900). This enables early fault detection, reduces maintenance costs, and extends battery life, while improving thermal management and charging efficiency. The results demonstrate that combining IoT data acquisition with AI analytics offers a robust, data-driven solution for proactive EV battery management, enhancing efficiency, reliability, and sustainability in modern transport systems.

title: Using Circuit Theory and Swarm Intelligence for the Design and Optimization of Energy Harvesters for Ambient Mechanical Vibrations
authors: Kailing Song, Michele Bonnin, Fabrizio Bonani, Fabio L. Traversa
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: We consider the model of a networked energy harvester for ambient dispersed vibrations, based on coupled mechanical resonators and a piezoelectric transduction mechanism. The networked harvester is equivalent to a mechanical filter that can be optimized for broadband energy harvesting. Using mechanical-to-electrical analogies, we derive an equivalent circuit model for the energy harvester, and we calculate the transfer function, output voltage, average harvested power and power efficiency in the frequency domain. We discuss the problem of the energy harvester optimization. Because analytical formulas for the objective function and its derivatives are not available, we apply a gradient-free method, based on Particle Swarm Optimization, to find the network parameters that maximize the scavenged energy. We show that, after proper optimization, the networked energy harvester collects significant more power than a single degree-of-freedom energy harvester.

title: Advancing Electric Vehicle Efficiency Forecasting: Nonlinear Battery Frameworks and Empirical City Driving Profiles
authors: Utkarsh Alset, Datta Chavan, Ashwini Pawar, Panchshila Pillewar, Snehal Andhale
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This investigation introduces an innovative approach for modeling electric vehicle (EV) operations via a detailed battery structure that integrates nonlinear discharge behaviors and thorough degradation factors. In contrast to previous analyses that mainly utilized linear discharge assumptions, this study constructs a simulation environment to evaluate EV operational distance and battery durability in a precisely formulated urban mobility pattern derived from observed data. Through MATLAB / Simulink ${ }^{\circledR}$ simulations on a representative EV model, examinations cover power usage, achievable mileage, and battery charge level in authentic urban settings. Findings indicate substantial improvements in predictive reliability relative to conventional techniques, offering essential observations that facilitate progress in EV architecture and battery control mechanisms.

title: Unlocking Player Strategy: A Visual Journey Into Players’ Problem-Solving Behaviors
authors: Zhaoqing Teng, Magy Seif El-Nasr
publish: Computer
abstract: INSPECT, an interactive visualization system, transforms messy gameplay logs into clear visual roadmaps that reveal not just what players do, but how they do it—helping developers spot where players get stuck and coaches identify winning strategies.

title: Mutual Inductance and Load Estimation in Wireless Charging Systems via Port-Impedance Analysis
authors: Yu Lan, Qinghua Zhang, Jiabao Zhang, Qingxuan Zhang, Fengshuo Yang, Jinhai Jiang, Kai Song
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Load and mutual inductance are critical parameters for ensuring optimal matching in wireless power transfer (WPT) systems. The precise identification of these parameters is fundamental for ensuring interoperability between diverse charging devices. This paper presents an online method for identifying both mutual inductance and load parameters, utilizing the port impedance of the transmitting coil in an LCC-compensated WPT system. Initially, an analysis of the WPT system's network characteristics is conducted, deriving the relationship between port impedance, load, and mutual inductance. The load and mutual inductance identification processes are then decoupled. By introducing a fictitious ratio, the complex load identification equation is simplified into a quadratic form, enabling the inverse determination of mutual inductance from the identified load. A simulation model is created at the end to verify the proposed approach. The results reveal that, under different coupling and load scenarios, the maximum errors in identifying the load and mutual inductance are 6.8% and 4.8%, respectively. Importantly, the proposed method does not depend on resonance approximations or real-time communication, showcasing its practicality and robustness for wireless charging systems.

title: Exploring the Potential of Big Data and Machine Learning for Superior Analysis and Personalization of Customer Behavior
authors: C. Anitha, D. Karunkuzhali, B R Celia, V. Samuthira Pandi, Shobana D, Sandra Johnson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) and big data have changed the game for businesses by providing more accurate insights into consumer behaviour and paving the door for more tailored experiences. This study delves into the possibilities of using big data and ML techniques to improve customer behaviour analysis, offering a thorough framework for companies to comprehend and foretell consumer behaviours. Online interactions, purchase history, and social media activity are just a few examples of the many consumer touchpoints that organisations may analyse to find trends and patterns that traditional approaches miss. Customers can be better profiled and targeted marketing campaigns can be fine-tuned with the use of machine learning algorithms, especially supervised and unsupervised learning models, which enable real-time decision-making, dynamic segmentation, and predictive analytics. Research on the use of advanced analytics to the development of tailored consumer experiences that increase happiness, devotion, and engagement over the long term is also underway. The research shows, via case studies and empirical analysis, how ML and big data may be utilised effectively across many industries. This gives practical insights for companies that want to remain competitive in a data-driven market. Before concluding with suggestions for further study and methods of application, the article delves into the difficulties and moral dilemmas that come with using big data for consumer analytics.

title: Uncovering Public Discourse on the MBG Program: A Comparison of BERTopic and Top2Vec on Indonesian Tweets
authors: Hany Wijaya, Jesslyn Hok, Messya Carment, Edy Irwansyah
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The exponential growth of social media has created exceptional opportunities to analyze public opinion via textual data, particularly in relation to contentious government policies. This research examines the perception of Indonesian citizens towards the Free Nutritious Meal (MBG) program by evaluating modern topic modeling techniques on 8,693 tweets gathered from X. Utilizing comparative analysis, this study aims to provide holistic insights on model performances and display public concerns regarding the program’s long-term sustainability. Comparing BERTopic and Top2Vec with multiple embedding models, results show that BERTopic consistently outperformed Top2Vec, achieving topic coherence scores ranging from 0.59 to 0.60 and diversity scores between 0.92 and 0.96 with DistilUSE-multilingual embeddings producing the most coherent and interpretable themes among others. It also revealed four significant themes in the collective discussion: implementation in schools, budget concerns, food quality, and political debates. These findings are anticipated to contribute by providing methodological benchmarks on modern topic modeling techniques, while also offering practical evidence to enhance the MBG program’s credibility and impact.

title: Coronary Artery Stenosis Degree Classification Model Based on Graph Neural Network
authors: Jing Qin, Baotong Liu, Xiaoyu Nie, Xin Kang, Lu Liu, Lisha Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Coronary artery disease (CAD), also known as coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, is a common cardiac pathology. Although the degree of coronary stenosis can be identified through invasive coronary angiography, it is often difficult to correctly identify many angiograms by the naked eye. Therefore, we propose a novel classification model based on graph neural network for coronary artery stenosis. The network defines multi-head attention mechanisms, residual blocks, and graph convolutional networks, which are combined with many layers. Through a series of processing input signals, the model ultimately yields classification results. We conducted experiments using a dataset provided by Zhongshan Hospital affiliated with Dalian University, achieving a recall rate of 0.806 and an F1 score of 0.754. These performances offer certain reference value for doctors in diagnosing coronary diseases, enabling better resolution of issues that are imperceptible in angiograms even to the naked eye, which significantly improves the accuracy of coronary disease recognition.

title: Estimation of Wind Power Utilization Considering Daily Average Wind Speed
authors: Yong Wei, Linlin Zhao, Bingxu Hou, Lu Gao, Ronghu Cao, Xiaoxiao Zhao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: In response to the need for analyzing wind curtailment under data-constrained conditions, an estimation method for wind power utilization rate that accounts for daily average wind speed is constructed. Firstly, on a county/district scale, the daily effective utilization hours of each wind farm within the county/district are statistically summarized across different time intervals and daily average wind speed ranges. Secondly, based on the one-sided T-test theory, a mathematical benchmark unit is established to compute the upper and lower output limits for each time interval and wind speed range. Finally, with the benchmark unit as a reference, the presence of wind curtailment in each wind farm is assessed, and further, the upper and lower limits of wind power utilization rate for each wind farm and even the entire county/district are computed. Applying the proposed method, data from 13 centralized wind farms in Y County of S Province in northwest China are selected as a demonstration case, and the lower limit of wind power utilization rate in this county for 2024 is estimated to be 91.4%.

title: A New PI and PID Controllers Using CCDDCCTA
authors: Yumnam Shantikumar Singh, PheiroijamRobin Luwang, Kiyam Babaloo Singh, Vivek Bhatt, Ashish Ranjan, Sharmila Meinam
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper illustrates a design for Electronic Proportional Integral (EPI) and Electronic Proportional Integral Derivative (EPID) controllers by utilizing Current Controlled Differential Difference Current Conveyor Transconductance Amplifier (CCDDCCTA) as an advance active block. A simple realization of controllers come with CCDDCCTA and grounded active components for passive resistor and capacitor that enables electronically tunable features. The proposed controller is very suitable to integrated circuit implementation. In addition, EPI controller uses single active element with two grounded passive elements and EPID controller uses two active elements with two grounded passive elements. This proposed controller can easily be controlled by tuning the bias current. The theoretical workability of the proposed controllers is investigated through computer simulation with 0.25µm CMOS Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) parameters.

title: Zone-Wise Deep Learning Framework for Real-Time Crowd Surge Detection via Wi-Fi Probe Analysis
authors: Aswinth Narayan A, Nikhil S, Sooraj S Kumar, Amal Anand, Partthiv Murali R P, Poornima Mohan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Crowd surges in open public spaces remain one of the most pressing safety risks, often leading to life-threatening incidents. This paper presents a zone-based real-time infrastructure for crowd forecasting and alerting, utilizing passive WiFi probe request data. Minute-level device counts are captured across three spatially distinct zones and enriched through multidimensional feature engineering-including temporal flags, lag sequences, rolling statistics, growth rates, frequency-domain attributes (FFT), and adaptive spike indicators. For each zone, deep learning models such as LSTM, GRU, and BiLSTM are trained independently to perform short-term predictions. These models maintain low prediction errors, with mean absolute errors (MAE) ranging from 6 to 7 devices and root mean square error (RMSE) between 10 and 20. The system enables timely detection of crowd surges using a dynamic thresholding approach based on rolling trends and local deviations. Once a surge is identified, real-time SMS alerts are dispatched via the Twilio API. Experimental results show that the proposed zonewise framework outperforms global forecasting baselines by 15–25% on surge detection tasks, achieving an F1 score as high as 0.90. The framework is lightweight, privacy-conscious, and scalable-making it well-suited for deployment in worship sites, transit stations, and other high-density urban environments for enhanced crowd safety.

title: Cancer Driver Gene Prediction using Gene-Level Mutation by Supervised Learning
authors: Kavitha M, Rajatharika S, Sathya Priya B, Subiksha P, Nithesh S, Sowmiya E
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Cancer is a disease that can be effectively treated when the causing genes are identified early and accurately. The prediction of the cancer driver gene involves in which mutations that are causally involved in the development of cancer and unlike that the non-driver gene mutations that don't involved in any cancer development. This paper present with a lightweight predictive framework which is used to classify the genes into the cancer driver gene or non — driver gene using the gene level mutation features. This prediction involves with the three supervised learning algorithms such as Logistic Regression, Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), XGBoost. These three model are used to balance simplicity, analyze trends in the dataset, and achieve high performance. It helps to build this predictive models to help in early detection. The dataset has been divided into train and test data. Each model is trained independently with some evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. This model provides a prediction as output and graph is represented for their performance and evaluation. Results analyses show <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5 \%} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{9 3 \%}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 1 \%}$</tex> accuracy on Logistic Regression, MLP, and XGBoost respectively. It has various application that supports cancer genomics research bioinformatics experts, and medical professionals.

title: Automated Pest Control in Agriculture Using IoT and Image Processing
authors: N. Shanmuga Priya, Harini. K, Harini. M, Haswanth S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Agriculture continues to be plagued by huge challenges of pest infestation, resulting in huge yield and economic losses in the world. Common pest control methods largely rely on workers' exhaustive visual inspection and overuse of chemicals, not only rendering them ineffective but also ecologically questionable. IoT sensors and advanced image processing techniques are proposed in an automated pest control system. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) advanced model, which incorporates multiple techniques, was designed to identify pests in real-time images with an accuracy of 93.6%, a false positive rate of 3.2%, at a processing time of 0.9 seconds. The environmental conditions are detected through fitted wireless sensor networks and through automated actuated application of the pesticides when required. The model was evaluated using a conditioned pest data set and proofs through MATLAB-Simulink and Node-RED simulations. The findings demonstrate a robust and flexible system appropriate for precision agriculture use. This method significantly reduces labor and pesticide overspray, and improves detection accuracy and comprehensive system efficiency.

title: Attention-LSTM Based Time-Series Deep Learning Model for Real-Time Exercise Posture Error Correction
authors: Kyuseung Kim, Dongho Shin, Jeongwon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Exercise form correction plays a crucial role in preventing injuries and maximizing training effectiveness [5]. Current approaches often struggle with capturing temporal dependencies in movement patterns and providing real-time feedback. This paper presents a novel deep learning architecture that combines multi-head attention mechanisms with bidirectional LSTM networks for real-time exercise form analysis. The system processes 3D skeletal data extracted from RGB video streams, focusing on temporal movement patterns rather than static postures. The attention mechanism identifies critical moments in exercise sequences, while the bidirectional LSTM captures both forward and backward temporal dependencies. Experimental results using the AI Hub Fitness Posture Image Dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves 80.21% accuracy in form classification while maintaining real-time performance on consumer-grade hardware.

title: Confronting Challenges of the Neuro-Symbolic AI (NSAI) in Human-Centered Computing (HCC), Healthcare, Education and Research, Emphasizing Ethics and Safety- an Interdisciplinary Qualitative Survey
authors: Aniqa Afzal
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Neuro-symbolic AI (NSAI) revolutionizes Human-Centered Computing (HCC), research, healthcare, education, reasoning and learning. This study focuses on the knowledge gap, ethical and safety guidelines, particularly the terminology used in NSAI literature, exploring various opportunities and challenges in the field. An interdisciplinary literature review and Thematic Analysis with survey method was used to analyze experts’ opinions from other majors, answering how we as researchers can improve the ethical guidelines for NSAI besides using NSAI-specific terminology in papers so people from diverse academic backgrounds may understand and contribute to research and NSAI model-trainings, since they may confuse NSAI’s overlapping terms with either the English vocabulary (e.g. Logic, Transfer Learning, Reasoning etc.) or those in Cognitive Psychology. Research and survey questions aimed to find and confront several underlying challenges in NSAI with simple steps that prior studies found already existed, but failed to highlight the Knowledge Representation aspect of it, or assess readers’ understandings. Results from an anonymous survey, when compared to Generative AI (GAI)’s responses, confirmed a huge knowledge gap exists, resulting from the way knowledge is represented in NSAI literature that only its research experts comprehend, but those from other majors may not as their responses were significantly different from those of GAI’s, analyzed by a qualitative Thematic Analysis. With 50% of participants unsure of NSAI terminology, further research is necessary in NSAI Knowledge Representation and Reasoning to contribute to NSAI research, model trainings, safety and ethical improvements, and publications.

title: Augmented Reality Banking: Investigating Consumer Trust, Usability, and Behavioral Intention in Immersive Financial Service Interfaces
authors: Ishwari Kamat, Shilpi Gupta, Vivek Sharma, Amit Verma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: In digital banking, the augmented reality (AR) can be used to reach clients in a way that was not possible with the current non-immersive and uneasy mobile applications. With legacy offerings, financial data is presented only in static dashboards that leaves space for problems in terms of engagement and trust. To mitigate those gaps, we developed a proof of concept (PoC) banking application utilizing Unity and ARCore/ARKit with secure banking APIs. The technical aspects of latency time, frame rate and tracking stability were measured to assess the system's capability. Trust, ease of use and behavioral intention were some of the features used to measure the adoption by user. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to explore the AR approach with present larger-scale experimental datasets (400 subjects) and task-based experiments, in combination with surveys that experimentally demonstrate its effectiveness. The results resulted in an average latency of 85 ms, a stable track, and a mean SUS score well over 80. Structural Equation Modeling confirms that usability enhances trust, and trust is an important driving factor of system adoption. The paper presents an AR bank architecture, the empirically validated one and design principles for future realisation.

title: Wideband Circularly Polarized Slot Antenna with Octagon Island for X-Band Applications
authors: Lamia Khashan, Tarek Nour, Mohamed Gamal, Youssef Gamal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: In this paper, a circular slot antenna with indirect feed is designed to operate in the X-band frequency range. The proposed antenna comprises a circular slot with an octagon island positioned inside the circle, an offset feed line, and three small stubs. The achieved axial ratio is below 3dB for the full Xband and the antenna operates between 7.07 and 13.28 GHz. The antenna has a peak gain of 5.2 dBi and total efficiency above 88%. The prototype is fabricated and measured. There is good agreement between the simulated and the measured results for both the $\boldsymbol{s}$-parameters and the axial ratio.

title: TwIndex: A Framework for Measuring the (Hidden) Value of Digital Twins by Mapping Atypical Interaction Patterns
authors: Mareike Victoria Keil, Julius Umsonst, Andrew G. Peck
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Despite the growing adoption of digital twins (DTs) across multiple domains, assessing their true value remains a complex challenge. Traditional valuation methods often focus on direct efficiency gains, overlooking potential benefits arising from diverse and atypical usage patterns. This vision paper introduces TwIndex, a conceptual framework that aims to explore new ways to quantify the value of DTs by analyzing interaction patterns beyond traditional metrics. We propose that neurodivergent and neurotypical users may engage with DTs in fundamentally different ways, revealing latent benefits that have yet to be systematically explored and mapping to vulnerabilities not apparent at the design phase. By exploring atypical interaction patterns, future research can uncover hidden dimensions of value and lead to more adaptive evaluation methods. This paper highlights the need for a paradigm shift in measuring the success of DTs and argues for a broader perspective in assessing their impact.

title: A Proposed Ultra Wide Band Low Noise Amplifier With Improved Gain Using Negative Impedance Circuit
authors: Priyanka Chaurasia, Ankita Verma, Manish Goswami, Prasanna Kumar Misra
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: In this paper, the performance of various Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) architectures is studied. The techniques like noise cancellation, gain boosting, current reuse methods, inductorless designs are explored for ultra-wideband applications. Each technique offers certain benefits and some demerits. Negative impedance based two stage LNA is designed with the help of incremental static power to provide significant improvement in power gain while maintaining the same noise figure. To validate this concept 40 nm CMOS technology is used. The small signal analysis of proposed architecture is done. The integration of negative impedance in differential outputs of the LNA can improve the gain upto 40 dB while using a power of 23.6 mW. The power addition is 1.5 mW compared to the conventional two stage LNA. This method is beneficial for battery operated devices like IoT transceiver chips required for short range wireless communication systems.

title: Software Defect Detection Using Optimized Support Vector Machine Based on RW-GWO-WOA
authors: Maulana Alirridlo, Riyanarto Sarno, Dwi Sunaryono, Abdullah Faqih Septiyanto, Irzal Ahmad Sabilla
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Software defect detection is a crucial aspect of the software engineering process because undetected defects can cause system failures and application performance degradation. The growing complexity of software makes manual detection methods less efficient and error-prone. SVM has proven to be effective in detecting defects through the classification process, but its performance is largely determined by the optimal hyperparameter settings. This study proposes a novel optimization approach by applying the Random Walk mechanism to the hybrid Grey Wolf Optimizer-Whale Optimization Algorithm (RW-GWO-WOA) to optimize SVM parameters. The main contributions of this study include: (1) replacing hold-out evaluation with k-fold cross-validation to enhance model generalization reliability; (2) developing the RW-GWO-WOA optimization method, which combines the exploratory capabilities of GWO with the local exploitation of WOA enhanced by the Random Walk mechanism; and (3) conducting a comprehensive evaluation by comparing performance without oversampling, SMOTE, and BorderlineSMOTE. Experimental results show that the RW-GWO-WOA method achieves competitive performance with the highest average accuracy of 97.86% on the PC2 dataset without using PCA or oversampling. The k-fold cross-validation was able to provide a more reliable evaluation and reduce the possibility of overfitting compared to the hold-out approach.

title: AI-Driven Green HRM: Predictive Sustainability Culture and Workforce Engagement Modeling
authors: Pallavi Priya Silveira, Naval Lawande
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This paper presents an Artificial Intelligence (AI)- based GHRM model that helps define ways to engage employees in the organization's sustainability activities. It aims to bridge this gap by using a new, proactive environmental management practice, which in turn addresses ESG compliance legislation or works towards sustainable objectives. The contributions of the framework are three-fold: Firstly, based on predictive analytics on green culture. Secondly, a behavior nudging system based on real-time information, and last, an ESG sentiment analysis which uses natural language processing(NLP). Using machine learning, environmental indicators, and HR data, the GHRM model measures sustainable workforce engagement. This means that the GHRM approach can help with positive environmental interventions by identifying sustainability champions and clarifying likely environmental interventions. It is an introductory effort towards integrating AI into green HRM and thus a strategic, holistic framework for sustainably managing human capital. Lastly, it demonstrates how AI can lead and advance the human resource area into date with people management and wind, water, and plant planetary well-being.

title: Design and Analysis of Cascaded H-Bridge Inverters for EV Applications
authors: J. N. Bhanutej, P. S. Raghavendra, S. Sanjana, K. Tara Sing, M. Pranay, Sundeep Siddula, Neelima Kalahasthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This study shows the design and testing of multilevel inverters (MLIs) for electric vehicles (EVs), with a focus on comparing 5-level, 7-level, and 9-level inverter setups using MATLAB/Simulink. MLIs are often used in EV drive systems because they can produce high-quality output voltage with reduced harmonic distortion, lower switching losses, and more efficiency. This work makes models and runs simulations of 5, 7, and 9-level cascaded H-bridge (CHB) configurations. We examine each setup’s performance for total harmonic distortion (THD), the quality of the output voltage waveform, and how well it works with EV traction systems. The results show that more levels mean less THD and a smoother output voltage. This makes motors perform better and rides more comfortable. The 9-level inverter offers the finest harmonic performance, but it is also harder to make and use. This comparison shows the pros and cons of different MLI setups, which will help you choose the optimum inverter design for future electric vehicles.

title: Advancement in Mobile Network Technology: Evolution from 4G to 7G
authors: Saurabh, Ankita Aggarwal, Neha Arya, Geetanjali Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Mobile network technology development has brought about major changes in worldwide communication systems and information retrieval methods. The paper examines mobile network development from 4G to the upcoming 7G network generation through a detailed analysis. The paper examines each network generation through its main features, which include speed enhancements and latency minimization and capacity expansion and AI and terahertz, and quantum computing system integration. The research demonstrates how 5G network capabilities through URLLC and mMTC enable fast and reliable communication, which will lead to the development of 6G networks that will achieve terabit-per-second speeds and AI-based network administration. The paper investigates 7G network possibilities through its predicted ability to link space-based networks with quantum communication systems, for instant, worldwide connectivity. The review examines mobile network development through technological progress and operational advantages and system obstacles, and future directions.

title: A SOC estimation method for flow batteries based on EIS and LSTM-TCN neural network
authors: Min Wang, Yijian Zhao, Menglian Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: In flow battery management systems, the state of charge directly affects operational safety and cycle life. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, an essential tool for characterizing internal battery states, is closely related to state of charge; however, its application in flow batteries remains limited. In this study, we propose an LSTM-TCN neural network model that accurately estimates battery state of charge using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data while accounting for varying operational conditions. Additionally, an equivalent circuit model for flow batteries is established to analyze the functional relationship between state of charge and derived impedance parameters. electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurement results reveal that ohmic resistance, charge transfer resistance, diffusion impedance, and Warburg coefficient are highly correlated with state of charge (|R| > 0.95). By incorporating ECM-derived impedance features into the neural network, high-accuracy state of charge estimation is achieved (MAE, RMSE < 0.01). This work presents a robust and stable EIS-based state of charge estimation approach for flow batteries, offering valuable insight for intelligent battery management.

title: Joint Face Completion and Super-Resolution Using Contextual Position Relation Networks
authors: Arun Kumar, Shyam Singh Rajput
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Face super-resolution (FSR), or face hallucination, is a specialised image restoration task that poses challenges due to prevalent degradations like occlusion, shadow, blur, and abnormal illumination. In real-world scenarios, low resolution often coexists with occlusion, making the recovery of such faces critical. A reasonable strategy involves initially addressing the occluded areas, followed by the use of super-resolution techniques to the restored low-resolution images. We propose Face Completion Super Resolution utilizing Contextual Position Relation Networks (CPRNet), a two-stage framework consisting of face completion followed by face super-resolution. In the face completion stage, global facial priors guide the reconstruction of degraded patches by adaptively retrieving substitute information from structurally correlated regions. This non-local modeling enables the recovery of missing details and produces an unoccluded LR face. Subsequently, in the following stage, a super-resolution module improves the unoclluded LR image, generating a high resolution (HR) Reconstruction with greater structural fidelity and perceptual distinctiveness quality. Detailed investigations conducted on the CAS-PEAL-R1 validate the efficiency of FCSRCPRNet, with distinct algorithms surpassing a number of recent-state-of-the-art.

title: HybridLog: LLM-Powered Log Anomaly Analysis with Heterogeneous Semantic Collaboration Training
authors: Hongwei Zuo, Fengxiao Tang, Yangfan Li, Ming Zhao, Rui Wang, Jinke Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Log anomaly detection is a critical technology for ensuring reliability and operational efficiency in software systems. Traditional methods often face challenges, particularly those related to log parsing complexities that can lead to information loss and consequently high false positive rates. While detection identifies issues, understanding them is also vital. Existing workflow-based approaches offer some explanation by comparing anomalous sequences against normal patterns. There is also a lack of semantic-level anomaly diagnosis capabilities. In this paper, we propose a novel approach named HybirdLog, which focuses on the detection and diagnosis of log anomalies. It introduces heterogeneous semantic collaborative training, integrating anomaly features extracted by LLMs, jointly encoding semantic information and anomaly tendencies. Our approach achieves low-resource cross-domain anomaly detection and interpretability of anomalies. Experimental validation on two public datasets demonstrates the leading performance of our proposed method, offering an efficient and interpretable solution for analyzing logs from software systems.

title: Voltage Ride Through Parameter Optimization of Wind Turbines in the Sending-end System for Transient Overvoltage Mitigation
authors: Zhuyi Peng, Xingning Han, Shan Song, Quanquan Wang, Wenjia Zhang, Wentao Sun, Wanchun Qi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Owing to the development of renewable energies, the proportion of wind power in the power system is gradually increased. However, if commutation failure or even blocking of HVDC occurs, the wind turbine in the sending-end system would suffer risk of overvoltage, which then affects the stable operation of power system. To solve the problem, the regularity of voltage at the rectifier during the commutation failure is analyzed. Then based on the grid-connected control strategy and output power expression of wind turbine, the key parameters of voltage ride through control that affect the voltage state are identified. Finally, a key control parameter optimization model with the objection of minimizing the voltage fluctuation at the grid-connected point of wind turbine is proposed, the effectiveness of which on mitigating the overvoltage is validated by the simple and actual system based on the electromechanical transient simulation platform.

title: Cyber-Enhanced Dynamic VAR Management in Single-Phase Grids via an IoT-Based Control Loop
authors: Subhajit Roy, Shrayam Sarmah, Ashmita Sutradhar, Dulal Chandra Das, Nidul Sinha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In modern power distribution networks, especially at the single-phase level, inductive loads introduce significant reactive power demand, leading to poor power factor (PF) and increased transmission losses. Traditional fixed or semi-automatic capacitor-based compensation systems often fail to maintain PF under dynamic loading conditions. This paper presents a cyber-enhanced, Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled Automatic Power Factor Correction (APFC) system that dynamically manages VAR compensation using a modular capacitor bank and a cloud-hosted logic engine. The proposed architecture employs a discrete set of six 500 VAR capacitors, each selectively switched based on real-time PF measurements computed within a MATLAB Simulink environment. These measurements-voltage, current, real power, and PF-are transmitted to a ThingSpeak IoT platform at 0.5 -second intervals. A cloud-hosted logic engine evaluates the incoming data and responds with optimized capacitor-switching commands via a feedback channel, thereby ensuring responsive and minimal-reactive-error compensation. Three models are evaluated to validate the system’s performance: (1) a fixed-load model with static compensation, (2) a variable-load model with static capacitors, and (3) a dynamic, IoT-integrated model with adaptive capacitor control. Results demonstrate that while fixed methods can offer PF improvements from 0.80 to 0.95, the IoTenabled system consistently maintains PF above 0.97 under varying loads. Real power remains stable, and the system dynamically adjusts apparent and reactive power with minimal overshoot or delay. Additionally, the IoT integration enables remote visualization, event logging, and scalability toward predictive and AI-enhanced control strategies. This work illustrates a low-cost, modular, and cyber-resilient solution for improving grid power quality and efficiency, particularly relevant for residential, commercial, and microgrid applications.

title: Repurposing Generative AI for Learning A Topic Modeling Approach Beyond EdTech
authors: Saeed Saffari, Michael Pin-Chuan Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study explores how current generative AI tools, originally developed for content creation, productivity, marketing, and coding, can be repurposed for education. Using a dataset of over 4,600 publicly available tools, we applied stratified topic modeling to uncover functional patterns across different popularity levels. Our analysis identified three key meta-themes: generative media tools, interactive agents and assistive systems, and utility and personalization tools. Although only a small fraction was designed for educational use, many tools offer features that align with teaching and learning goals. The results highlight how general-purpose AI tools can inform classroom innovation. This research provides practical insights for educators and designers aiming to adapt AI technologies for inclusive and engaging learning experiences.

title: Smart Monitoring and Control of Solar Panel Cooling System Using IoT-Integrated Wiper Mechanism
authors: Ajeng Bening Kusumaningtyas, Ikhsan Kamil, Adnan Afriadi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The efficiency of solar panels decreases as surface temperature rises, especially in tropical country Indonesia. Automatic cooling system in solar panel was designed using a wiper mechanism based on the Internet of Things (IoT), utilizing an ESP32 microcontroller. This system is equipped with temperature, voltage, and current sensors that monitor panel conditions in real-time via an I2C LCD display and the Blynk application, while also recording data to Google Spreadsheet. The cooling motor activates automatically when the temperature reaches 42°C and stops when it falls below 37°C, with movement direction controlled by an infrared sensor. The system features two operation modes—manual and automatic—which can be controlled either conventionally or via a smartphone. Data transmission and control are implemented without using delay functions, ensuring the system remains responsive and continuously connected to the Blynk server. Testing results show that the voltage sensor has an average accuracy of 98.76–99.29%, the current sensor achieves 87.80% accuracy at medium current levels, and the temperature sensor ranges from 97.26–98.92% accuracy. The system also successfully executes motor control logic according to the programmed schedule, with minimal actual time deviation. With accurate sensor performance and a responsive control system, this tool proves to be reliable for automatic and remote temperature monitoring of solar panels. Additionally, the system supports the principles of energy efficiency and automation in the application of IoT technology, making it suitable for optimizing the performance of solar power systems.
