title: PIMA Diabetes Dataset Classification Using AI Optimization Techniques
authors: Neha Katiyar, Hardeo Kumar Thakur, Anindya Ghatak
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Rapid advancements in healthcare devices generate huge amounts of data. These datasets are utilized for different purposes, consist of disease prediction, identification, and analysis. The central aim of this paper is to develop a novel analysis for diabetes detection using Artificial Intelligence (AI) optimization techniques. Recognizing the current demands to address the constraint of the latest diabetes prediction methods, this study makes a unique benefactions by seamlessly combining advanced AI optimization algorithms, thereby exceeding old methods and paving the way for more reliable early diagnosis. These AI techniques are applied to the PIMA diabetes dataset. The overall diabetes prediction process consists of several steps, including training and testing the PIDD dataset, evaluating and optimizing the model, making predictions, and providing the prediction results. This optimization and classification process is performed with AI algorithms such as Hill Climbing Algorithm, Hill Climbing Algorithm with Hyperparameters, Expected Maximization, Simulated Annealing, Local Beam Search, Tabu Search, Genetic Algorithms, and a Hybrid Algorithm combining Tabu Search and Simulated Annealing, as well as Tabu Search with Hyperparameter tuning. The implementation process was carried out on the PIMA Indian Diabetes Dataset with iterations of 50, 100, and 150 epochs. Among all iterations, the Tabu Search with Hyperparameter tuning provides the best accuracy of 77 %, an F1 score of 71 %, a Precision of 76 %, and a Recall of 69 %, with a total estimated time to the result of 48 seconds. This optimized classification process validates the prediction rate of diabetes.

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Atypical Speech Recognition
authors: Rachna Mohapatra, Vedant Singh, Anisha Natarajan
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Atypical speech, that is, dysarthric or slurred speech, is a challenging task for mainstream automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems that are mostly designed and trained on standard datasets. In this paper, the authors examine the application of lightweight large language models (LLMs) as post-processing correction layers to enhance the accuracy of recognition in atypical speech contexts. Some of the models like Phi-2, TinyLLaMA, Mistral-7B, and Gemma-2B are compared in terms of how well they can improve noisy transcriptions from speech-to-text systems. For checking performance, parameters such as BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BERTScore are evaluated together. Experimental findings point to an accuracy vs. computational tractability trade-off, especially when the hardware used is consumer-grade with limited GPU memory. Smaller instruction-tuned models like Flan-T5 and Phi-2 are able to achieve real-world efficiency without sacrificing competitive correction quality, while larger models become increasingly accurate but require hybrid GPU–CPU execution strategies. The results show that LLM-enabled correction is a highly efficient method for improving ASR for atypical speech, enabling more inclusive and accessible speech technology.

title: Context-Aware Voltage Balancing Control for MMCs Using Dynamic Operating Condition Index
authors: Pingping Wen, Gaoyong Wang, Chong Zhang, Junchuan Zhou
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Capacitor voltage sorting of submodules is essential for voltage balancing and stable modulation in modular multilevel converters (MMCs), yet its computational latency under high submodule counts (N≥200) has become a critical bottleneck for real-time control. Conventional bubble sort, with O(N<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) complexity, can exceed 150 μs for N=300—far beyond the typical 50 μs PWM period. This paper proposes an adaptive sorting framework that integrates non-recursive merge sort (NRMS), guaranteeing strict O(NlogN) complexity, with a dual-threshold triggering mechanism based on voltage variation rate (dV/dt) and bridge-arm energy deviation. This approach dynamically relaxes the sorting execution frequency: during steady-state operation, sorting is performed only once every several PWM cycles; during transients, it reverts to highfrequency activation. By decoupling sorting from the fixed control cycle, the method maintains effective voltage balancing performance without compromising control accuracy, while reducing the average computational overhead by 20 to 50 times, depending on submodule count and operating conditions. This significant efficiency gain liberates substantial processing resources for advanced functionalities such as grid-forming control and multi-terminal coordination. Simulations across 240– 400 SM configurations demonstrate the proposed framework’s scalability, real-time feasibility, and compatibility with highperformance MMC applications.

title: AI-Driven Root Cause Analysis of Project Failures: A Machine Learning Implementation Study
authors: Rasik Borkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This paper introduces a complete realization of AI-based root cause analysis of project failure through machine learning methods. The study uses a dataset of 7,200 project instances with 12 feature variables to make predictions on failure results. Among the six machine learning models tested, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) recorded the best performance with 98.51% accuracy, 98.25% precision, and 98.77% recall. The deployment meets the essential requirement for automated failure analysis in project management, with conventional approaches usually failing to cope with intricate, multi-faceted data. The results prove that AI-based methods can greatly enhance the accuracy and efficiency of root cause analysis with the potential to lower project failure rates by facilitating preemptive intervention measures. The research adds to the existing literature in intelligent project management systems and offers real-world advice to organizations aiming to adopt AI-based failure prediction systems.

title: Beamforming and Performance Analysis for Interference Systems with UAV and Ground Users
authors: Azar Hakimi, Yindi Jing, Xinwei Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In this work, we explore the downlink of an interference system where two base stations (BSs) with uniform linear antenna arrays serve both unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) and ground users over shared resources. UAV channels are modeled as line-of-sight (LOS) while ground user channels follow Rayleigh fading. We introduce a transmit beamforming design to eliminate interference to UAV users while maximizing signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratios (SINRs) for all users. Analytical expressions for achievable UAV rates and average achievable ground user rates are derived, and the average achievable rate region is studied. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed design and validate analytical accuracy.

title: A Hybrid Quantum-Classical Approach for Solving QUBO Models in Blockchain-Enabled Supply Chain Inventory Management
authors: L Sherin Beevi, Ponsy R K Sathia Bhama, Joe Prathap P. M., Mosses A, W Vinil Dani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Managing inventory in large-scale supply chains necessitates quick, cost-effective decisions that adhere to constraints such as storage limits and variable demand. This paper describes a novel hybrid approach that uses both quantum and classical computers to tackle inventory problems structured as Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO). Each choice variable, such as restocking a product, is represented in binary form, with related costs and penalties built into the objective function. Business constraints are communicated indirectly using adjustable weights, allowing the model to remain unconstrained while discouraging unrealistic conclusions. Optimization is carried out using both classical methods like simulated annealing and quantum solvers such as D-Wave and QAOA, where a hybrid strategy selects the most viable solution. The results indicate that the hybrid system consistently produces lower total costs and better constraint compliance compared to individual solvers, especially for complex, high-dimensional datasets. To ensure secure, automated execution of these optimized decisions, a blockchain layer is introduced. Inventory actions—such as placing orders or updating stock—are carried out through smart contracts that provide tamper-proof, verifiable enforcement. By employing a lightweight Proof of Authority (PoA) mechanism, transaction validation remains fast while maintaining transparency across all nodes in the network. This integration of quantum optimization with blockchain automation enables a responsive and trustworthy framework for modern inventory management.

title: Analysis and Implementation of a Non-Isolated DC-DC Converter with High Voltage Gain for DC Microgrid Applications
authors: Karvala Yogesh, Harish Sudhakaran Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In DC microgrid applications, DC-DC converters with high voltage gain find extensive use. Due to various challenges such as the diode reverse recovery issues, the series resistances of the inductor and capacitor, and the fact that the voltage stress on the switching device is equal to the voltage at the output, a conventional boost converter is not suited for providing high voltage gain. In this paper, a DC-DC converter topology with features of high gain, high efficiency, and lower voltage stress is analysed. An output voltage of (1+D) times that of the conventional boost converter is attained from the designed converter. A 50 W, 20 V/80 V hardware circuit of the high voltage gain DC-DC converter has been designed, simulated and experimental findings for both open-loop and closed-loop hardware implementations are used to validate its performance.

title: Phasor Measurement Integration in Wireless Power Transfer Systems for Grid Applications
authors: Chisom Ogbogu, Kipngeno Koech, Jesse Thornburg
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents a phasor estimation framework tailored for high-frequency Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) systems, with a focus on integrating Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) to enhance monitoring, control, and stability. As WPT emerges as a viable solution for contactless energy delivery in microgrids and renewable-powered infrastructures, ensuring power quality and system observability becomes critical. The proposed model, developed in MATLAB/Simulink, simulates a three-phase inductive WPT system with embedded PMU tracking of voltage and current phasors at the secondary coil. Using an algorithm based on the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) and synchronized to a 60 Hz reference, the PMU enables real-time extraction of phase angle, frequency, and magnitude, even in the presence of harmonic distortion and switching transients. Simulation results demonstrate minimal ripple in DC output and accurate phasor tracking, validating the feasibility of PMU-assisted regulation. Furthermore, phasor data can be used for dynamic compensation, grid stabilization, and input to maximum power point tracking (MPPT) in PV systems. The study concludes that phasor-aware WPT architectures offer a promising approach to enhancing efficiency, controllability, and sustainability in distributed energy networks. Future extensions will explore adaptive compensation strategies and wide-area PMU coordination for next-generation smart grids.

title: Evaluation of Nested Sequential Feed-Forward Neural Network For Crop Yield Prediction: A Case Study Using Irrigated Paddy Crop Yield
authors: N Andy Kundang Chang, Shouvik Dey
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Climate and weather extremes remain a major challenge for crop yield prediction modeling. Accurately capturing the complex interactions between climatic variability and stress conditions such as drought continues to be an active research focus. A cumulative neural network architecture called Nested Sequential Feed-Forward Neural Network (NSFFNet) was recently proposed to model the cumulative effects of climatic factors on crop yield. This approach has demonstrated strong capability in learning long term climate impacts and improving prediction accuracy. However, modern crop production introduces mediating factors, particularly irrigation, that influence stress responses by reducing drought intensity and regulating temperature. To investigate these effects, this study evaluates the performance of NSFFNet using irrigated paddy yield data. The temporal yield analysis revealed substantial variability in responses during drought years, where one drought affected year resulted in very low yield while another drought year produced comparatively high yield. This variability significantly affected the model’s generalization ability, particularly when drought-affected samples appeared only in the test set but were underrepresented in the training set. Cross-validation confirmed this limitation, and comparative analysis against benchmark models including RNN, 1D CNN, LSTM, GRU, and Transformer architectures showed the same generalization pattern. These findings indicate that while cumulative modeling approaches are essential for capturing long term climatic impacts, they must also account for mediating factors that modify the impact of climate on crop yield.

title: A Hybrid Active Damping Strategy in LCL-Type Grid-Connected Inverter
authors: Andong Wang, Zhikang Guo, Zhaoxun Li, Guojun Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: In active damping (AD) strategies, both the capacitor current feedback approach and the capacitor voltage feedforward approach are extensively used to suppress LCL resonance. In this article, two proposed AD strategies are combined to constitute a hybrid active damping (HAD) strategy in order to enhance the degree of freedom in the selection of the AD coefficient. However, the complexity of the HAD coefficients tuning and the issue of introducing the non-minimum phase system by digital delay are the deficiencies in the HAD strategy. To solve the proposed deficiencies, a method of the HAD coefficients tuning is put forward based on the minimum phase system. Finally, the proposed HAD strategy and the capacitor voltage feedforward approach are compared through simulation, and the results verify the feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Metaheuristic-Optimized ConvNeXt Architecture for Ultrasound-Based Liver Diseases Classification
authors: Tanzilal Mustaqim, Sri Hidayati, Dyah Putri Rahmawati
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Ultrasound imaging serves as the primary screening tool due to its non-invasiveness and cost-effectiveness, yet manual interpretation introduces subjectivity and inter- observer variability, while image quality is compromised by speckle noise, acoustic shadowing, and machine-specific variations that undermine diagnostic reliability. Current deep learning approaches for liver ultrasound analysis face significant limitations including overfitting on limited datasets, poor cross-device generalizability, and suboptimal hyperparameter tuning processes that hinder clinical deployment. This study addresses these challenges through a novel integration of ConvNeXt Small architecture with Whale Optimization Algorithm (ConvNeXt-S + WOA), specifically designed for liver diseases classification. Evaluated on a publicly available dataset of 735 ultrasound images (435 malignant, 200 benign, 100 normal), our framework employs a tailored preprocessing pipeline for speckle reduction and acoustic shadowing simulation, coupled with WOA-driven hyperparameter optimization to maximize feature extraction efficiency. The ConvNeXt S+WOA model achieves best performance with better metric evaluation, significantly outperforming standalone ConvNeXt Small, EfficientNet B0, and other benchmark architectures while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: GSA-Based MPPT Enhancement for Solar Water Pumping Systems under Variable Conditions
authors: Mekhalfia Ramadhan, Abdelkarim Ammar, Aissa Kheldoun, Telli Abderrahim
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper analyzes the performance of a photovoltaic (PV) system designed for standalone solar water pumping applications based on a permanent-magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drive. PV energy is recognized as one of the most sustainable renewable energy sources, particularly for water pumping applications. The principal aim of this investigation is to enhance power extraction from PV panels for efficient operation in a water pumping system (WPS) the boost converter is employed to implement maximum power point tracking (MPPT), while the PMSM ensures optimal utilization of the power produced by the PV modules, consequently enhancing the system's reliability. Furthermore, a novel MPPT control strategy, leveraging the Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA), is proposed to achieve robust performance under varying operating conditions. Comprehensive simulation in MATLAB/Simulink is employed to validate the system's effectiveness.

title: State of Charge Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries under Vehicle Operating Conditions
authors: XiFeng Guo, YanFeng Xia, FengZhong Zhang, LingYan Li, DongWei Zhang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries have become the dominant energy storage technology in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. However, as the usage time increases, the performance of lithium-ion batteries significantly declines, which may indirectly lead to equipment performance degradation or failure. Accurate estimation of the state of charge (SOC) is essential for effective battery management. In this study, a novel SOC estimation approach is developed by integrating the pied kingfisher optimizer (PKO) algorithm with the hybrid kernel extreme learning machine (HKELM) to enhance the estimation accuracy of lithium-ion batteries under diverse operating conditions. The PKO-HKELM method is verified using the University of Maryland A123 battery dataset under DST, FUDS, and US06 conditions, and compared with the HKELM, KELM, and ELM methods. The experimental results show that the PKO-HKELM method outperforms traditional SOC estimation methods under different working conditions.

title: SPEAR: Soft Prompt Enhanced Anomaly Recognition for Time Series Data
authors: Hanzhe Wei, Jiajun Wu, Jialin Yang, Henry Leung, Steve Drew
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Time series anomaly detection plays a crucial role in a wide range of fields, such as healthcare and internet traffic monitoring. The emergence of large language models (LLMs) offers new opportunities for detecting anomalies in the ubiquitous time series data. Traditional approaches struggle with variable-length time series sequences and context-based anomalies. We propose Soft Prompt Enhanced Anomaly Recognition (SPEAR), a novel approach to leverage LLMs for anomaly detection with soft prompts and quantization. Our methodology involves quantizing and transforming the time series data into input embeddings and combining them with learnable soft prompt embeddings. These combined embeddings are then fed into a frozen LLM. The soft prompts are updated iteratively based on a cross-entropy loss, allowing the model to adapt to time series anomaly detection. The use of soft prompts helps adapt LLMs effectively to time series tasks, while quantization ensures optimal handling of sequences, as LLMs are designed to handle discrete sequences. Our experimental results demonstrate that soft prompts effectively increase LLMs’ performance in downstream tasks regarding time series anomaly detection.

title: Real Time Transit Tracking for Public Transportation
authors: Gajanan Ghuge, Anvay Sinkar, Sneha Patil, Snehal Sagar
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Urban public transportation systems in developing nations, particularly in India, are grappling with a systemic crisis characterized by chronic overcrowding, fleet insufficiency, and operational unpredictability. This paper presents a novel system designed to address these issues. The Real Time Transit Tracking (RTTT) framework comprises two key components. First, an affordable, privacy-preserving Internet of Things (IoT) device that utilizes a fusion of a pressure mat and infrared (IR) sensors to achieve high-accuracy passenger counting. Experimental validation of the hardware prototype demonstrates an overall counting accuracy of 90.4% with robust performance across real-world scenarios. Second, we architect a hybrid SARIMA–LSTM forecasting model to leverage seasonal structure and non-linear exogenous effects (weather, holidays, events). Implementation and empirical evaluation of the forecasting model are reserved for future work. The developed hardware and proposed framework offer a viable and powerful tool for transit authorities to optimize fleet deployment, mitigate overcrowding, and enhance service reliability.

title: Specific Formation Large-diameter Spiral Drill Hole Construction Method
authors: Zitong Huang, Zhurong Cheng, Zhihua Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a "Large-Diameter Spiral Drilling Construction Method for Specific Strata" aimed at addressing the challenges of constructing large-diameter pile foundations under complex geological conditions. The method is an improved and innovative spiral drilling technique characterized by high-efficiency slag discharge. Through the rotary cutting action of the spiral drill rod, it enables stable drilling in soft soils without collapse or in strongly weathered strata, and in unstable geological environments with a construction slope of less than 25°. This technique significantly improves borehole quality and reduces the risk of collapse. Compared with traditional drilling methods, it offers greater adaptability—particularly advantageous in special construction environments such as mountainous power grid projects and urban confined spaces. The equipment features a compact structure and flexible operation, effectively minimizing construction vibration and impact on surrounding facilities, thereby enhancing construction safety. Moreover, by replacing manual excavation piles with mechanized operations, it greatly reduces safety risks and labor costs while shortening the construction period and improving project efficiency. The method has demonstrated excellent economic and operational performance in multiple engineering applications and is suitable for foundation construction in wind power, photovoltaics, power transmission, and bridge projects. Experimental results show that this method effectively enhances construction quality, safety, and efficiency, indicating broad application prospects.

title: Performance Analysis of a Standalone DC Source Integrated with Electric Vehicle Charging System
authors: Pranay S. Shete, R. M. Moharil
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The growing use of electric vehicles (EVs) has increased the need for efficient and reliable charging infrastructure, especially in areas where grid connectivity is weak or unstable. This paper presents a performance analysis of a standalone DC source used with an electric vehicle charging system. The study explores the possibility of using isolated renewable energy-based DC sources, such as solar photo-voltaic (PV) systems or rechargeable Li-ion batteries with series-parallel combination, to power EV chargers without relying on the utility grid. A detailed system model is created, which includes a standalone DC source, a DC-DC converter design, and a battery charge controller. Simulation results show that the dedicated DC bus charging system is able to achieve $\boldsymbol{\gt} \mathbf{9 0 \%}$ charging efficiency with negligible voltage and current ripple, even down to varying solar illuminance. These results demonstrate the system ability to ensure a safe battery operation, since the control action on battery charging and discharging is stable and robust. This article demonstrates the technical viability as well as the economic benefits of adopting independent DC power sources for EV charging, providing a scalable, green approach in case of off-board or supplemental charging infrastructure. The results in this paper align with the trend of demonstrating the feasibility of renewable-integrated, decentralized Electric Vehicles Charging Station (EVCS).

title: ZenIA: An Artificial Intelligence-Based Robotic System for Elderly Healthcare Assistance
authors: Armando Guevara, Irene López, Fernando Chávez, Bryan Vásquez-Pineda, Manuel Cardona
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: This paper presents ZenIA, a low-cost, AI-enabled assistive robot designed to support elderly individuals in home settings with medication adherence, basic companionship, and responsive interaction. ZenIA integrates on-device face recognition, 360-degree LiDAR-based navigation, and an automated medication dispensing mechanism, coupled with a lightweight software stack that prioritizes privacy through local data storage and offline operation. The mechanical design emphasizes safety and ergonomics (rounded geometries) for domestic environments, while the human–robot interaction (HRI) layer combines synthesized speech and a 7-inch touch GUI to improve usability for older adults and caregivers. We detail the hardware–software architecture, including Raspberry Pi 5, Arduino, HuskyLens AI camera, LD-19 LiDAR, and a servo-based carousel dispenser. Technical validation shows 87% face-recognition accuracy in a small cohort, reliable obstacle avoidance in mixed indoor layouts, and synchronized medication dispensing. A preliminary user session with a 70-year-old participant validated task completion and acceptability. We discuss cost/robustness/privacy trade-offs, limitations (lighting sensitivity, lack of global SLAM, minimal user sample), and future steps toward multimodal fall detection, human-aware navigation, and broader living-lab trials in Latin America.

title: Data Analytics in Smart Grids: Implications for Privacy and Information Security
authors: Neeraj Kumar, Keshav Kumar Tiwari, Umesh Pathak, I. B. Lal, Manish Kumar, Nitesh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The integration of data analytics wi thin s mart grid systems has revolutionized the management and optimization of energy distribution, enabling real-time monitoring, predicti ve maintenance, and improved efficiency across the energy network. Howe ver, as the smart grid becomes increasingly reliant on vast volumes of consumer and operational data, concerns about privacy and information security have grown significantly. This paper explores the dual-edged nature of data analytics in smart grids, highlighting both the transformati ve benefits and the emerging risks associated with data-dri ve n energy infrastructures. It investigates how granular data collection, such as smart meter readings and usage patterns, may inadvertently expose sensitive personal and operational information. Key challenges addressed include data anonymization, unauthorized data access, cyber vulnerabilities, and regulatory compliance. Furthermore, the paper e valuates existing security fr ameworks and privacy-preser ving technologies such as differential privacy, encryption, and secure multi -party computation. By assessing current practices and proposing a roadmap for balancing innovation wi th privacy safeguards, this study provi des a comprehensive over vie w of the implications of data analytics on privacy and security wi thin the evolving landscape of the Energy Internet.

title: Understanding Inconsistent State Update Vulnerabilities in Smart Contracts
authors: Lantian Li, Yuyu Chen, Jingwen Wu, Yue Pan, Zhongxing Yu
publish: ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology
abstract: None

title: Force-centric Bidirectional Cross-domain Interpretation between Soft-body Simulation and Piezoresistive E-skin_supp1-3666454.mp4
authors: Ziya Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cutaneous tactile feedback is essential for robotic manipulation, particularly when interacting with deformable objects with limited visual sensing. Learning-based approaches are increasingly adopted but rely on large volumes of tactile data. To meet this demand, Sim-to-Real strategies are widely used to generate synthetic high-resolution tactile images. However, in many tactile servo tasks, force information is more critical than the tactile image. Electronic skins (e-skins) offer direct force sensing, but remain underutilized in Sim-to-Real approaches due to the difficulty of simulating their output signals. Force-centric interpretations across real and simulation domains can facilitate the application of learning-based methods to e-skin sensing. We propose a framework that combines a soft-body simulator with a 10×10 piezoresistive e-skin. A shared feature encoder and dual-headed decoder enable bidirectional interpretation between e-skin normal force mapping readings and simulation normal stress fields. This framework supports both high-resolution stress field reconstruction and virtual tactile sensing data generation. Experiments show that the framework reduces the spatial discrepancy between real and simulated data, enhances multi-frame gradient consistency, and reconstructs edge and feature details, achieving an SSIM of 0.79 in cross-domain interpretation.

title: Human-in-the-loop Capacitive Microphone Sensors-Based Muscle Sensing System for Predictive and Adaptive Exoskeleton Assistance_supp1-3666391.mp4
authors: Zhenhua Yu
publish: N/A
abstract: Mobility impairments among older adults and individuals with neuromuscular weakness motivate the need for timely and adaptive exoskeleton assistance. This paper presents a human-in-the-loop muscle sensing and control system based on capacitive microphone sensors (CMS) that capture subtle mechanical muscle vibrations preceding observable motion. CMS signals were shown to occur 20–30 ms earlier than IMU-based kinematics, enabling anticipatory intent detection and feedforward assistive control. A five-sensor CMS array positioned over major thigh muscles is combined with a two-stage control strategy that integrates threshold-based pre-assist triggering and machine-learning-based torque refinement. Experiments across walking, stair ascent, sitting, and standing achieved over 90% classification accuracy under both non-fatigued and fatigued conditions with low latency. Robustness evaluations demonstrate stable CMS performance under realistic wearable perturbations, including perspiration and attachment variation. Extended experimental sessions (1-2 h) and preliminary feedback from five participants indicate comfortable wear and natural interaction. These results highlight the potential of CMS-based anticipatory sensing for practical wearable exoskeleton deployment in daily scenarios.

title: MgSAN: Multi-graph Semantic-aware Adaptive Graph Convolutional Network for Fake News Detection
authors: Linlin Zhu, Liang He, Heli Sun, Qi Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: The widespread dissemination and misleading impact of fake news on the web have become a significant concern for the public and the government. Discovering fake news is crucial for ensuring that users receive authentic information and maintaining social harmony. However, most existing entity-based fake news detection methods have two issues: i) methods for acquiring additional information through entities lack flexibility and real-time capabilities. ii) approaches using entities to capture news semantics have not adequately revealed the interactions between words in the text. To address these issues, we propose a Multi-graph Semantic-aware Adaptive Graph Convolutional Network (MgSAN), which comprehensively captures the semantic information of news texts by constructing multiple semantic graphs and learns the features from these graph structures using an adaptive graph convolutional network (SwiGCN). Specifically, we design a global semantic interaction graph to capture the complex interactions between words, generating a comprehensive textual semantic representation. We also employ an entity-noun relationship graph to mine deep semantic associations, enhancing the model's understanding of fine-grained textual deep meanings. Additionally, we develop an adaptive graph convolutional network to effectively extract and aggregate feature information from different graph structures. Finally, we introduce a fusion module to integrate both global and local fine-grained semantic information, forming a rich composite semantic representation, thereby improving the effectiveness of fake news detection. Extensive experimental results on three public benchmark datasets verify the effectiveness and superior performance of MgSAN, outperforming state-of-the-art detection models.

title: Diverse Subset Selection Via Norm-Based Sampling and Orthogonality
authors: Noga Bar, Raja Giryes
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: Large annotated datasets are crucial for the success of deep learning, but labeling data can be prohibitively expensive in domains such as medical imaging. This work tackles the subset selection problem: selecting a small set of the most informative examples from a large unlabeled pool for annotation. We propose a simple and effective method that combines feature norms, randomization, and orthogonality (via the Gram–Schmidt process) to select diverse and informative samples. Feature norms serve as a proxy for informativeness, while randomization and orthogonalization reduce redundancy and encourage coverage of the feature space. Extensive experiments on image and text benchmarks, including CIFAR-10/100, Tiny ImageNet, ImageNet, OrganAMNIST, and Yelp, show that our method consistently improves subset selection performance, both as a standalone approach and when integrated with existing techniques.

title: Robust Beamforming for STAR-RIS aided Hybrid-Field ISAC Systems
authors: Xintong Zhou, Feng Ke, Chunyue Wu, Xiu Yin Zhang, Derrick Wing Kwan Ng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a joint beamforming design for optimizing integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems under imperfect channel state information (CSI), leveraging a simultaneous transmission and reflection reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS). Owing to the deployment of large-scale antenna arrays and high carrier frequencies, the Rayleigh distance can extend to tens or even hundreds of meters. This expansion leads to a fundamental paradigm shift in electromagnetic field characteristics, transitioning from the conventional far-field regime to the emerging near-field regime. As a result, the propagation characteristics experienced by users and the target may differ. Accordingly, we consider a practical scenario in which users and the target are situated in distinct fields. However, this hybrid-field model increases the system’s sensitivity to channel estimation errors (CEE). To this end, we propose a robust design that jointly optimizes beamforming for base station (BS) and STAR-RIS, aiming to maximize the achievable sum-rate of the nodes while satisfying the constraint of sensing requirements. Under a statistical CEE model, we derive the interference covariance matrix and reformulate the maximization problem as an equivalent weighted mean square error (MSE) minimization problem. Subsequently, the transformed problem is decoupled into multiple sub-problems using a block coordinate descent (BCD)-based algorithm. The algorithm capitalizes on semidefinite relaxation and Gaussian randomization to obtain an effective solution. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed robust design. Compared with the baseline schemes, the proposed algorithm achieves a higher communication sum-rate and illustrates how various parameters affect the performance.

title: Digital Technology for Delivery Strategies in a Supply Chain: Platform's Expansion with Value-Added Processing Centers_supp1-3665646.pdf
authors: Jun Pei
publish: N/A
abstract: E-commerce platforms adopt differentiated delivery strategies for various products, where the application and investment of digital technologies play a vital role in shaping delivery services. We consider a hybrid product market in which the platform sells standard products and competes with manufacturers of augmented products that require value-added processing, such as engraving or printing. The platform may provide only basic delivery services for augmented products while applying digital technologies to enhance the delivery of standard products. Alternatively, it may establish value-added processing centers to support a unified delivery strategy and adjust its digital investment accordingly. Counterintuitively, our analysis shows that even when product value and service fees are high, the platform may still refrain from establishing value-added processing centers. Moreover, the adoption of these centers can stimulate further digital investment and enhance coordination, benefiting manufacturers through improved delivery and wider market reach. While customer surplus may decline due to weakened competition, overall welfare can increase through better alignment of processing and delivery decisions. We further demonstrate the robustness of these findings through two model extensions (i.e., asymmetric processing costs and heterogeneous product valuation) as well as numerical verification of the analytical results. This study contributes to the engineering management literature by explaining how platforms align digital technology investment with the establishment of value-added processing centers and how this alignment reshapes delivery strategy, platform-manufacturer interaction, and market outcomes. —

title: Edge-Intelligent Finance: Evaluating the Efficiency of Edge AI in Decentralized Credit Risk Assessment and Real-Time Lending Decisions
authors: Shiva Johri, Amit Verma, Megha Sharma, N. Deepalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Cloud-based centralized credit scoring is accurate but suffers from network delays, high bandwidth costs, privacy concerns, and non-transparent decision-making processes. We present an edge intelligent finance framework that combines shallow neural models with symbolic, rule-based reasoning to make real-time, transparent loan decisions in the wild over low-cost edge devices. Trained via federated learning on popular benchmarks (German Credit, LendingClub, FICO), the framework achieves competitive discrimination performance (AUC ≈ 0.83) while reducing inference latency to 50ms and energy use to 0.3J/inference compared to their centralized deep models. An interpretable validation layer is proposed to encode fairness constraints and regulation rules, which outputs the interpretable rationales and group-gap metrics (<0.05). Under bandwidth constraints, stress tests indicate that accuracy and response times remain stable, as inference is performed locally. Our results demonstrate that under edge AI, efficient lending workflows and peer-to-peer ecosystems can be enhanced with privacy, fairness, and compliance through a series of information yellow-red-green cycles. We also address scalability, rule complexity, and deployment recommendations for financial institutions and regulators.

title: Exploring the Digital Thread: A Comprehensive State of the Art Review
authors: Clarissa Gregory, Souad Rabah, Vincent Chapurlat
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The Digital Thread is becoming increasingly important in Industry 4.0 by facilitating the management of data throughout the system lifecycle. However, definitions of the DTh vary widely in scientific literature. This study proposes a systematic review that analyses the research works available in the Scopus, IEEE and Web of Science article databases to establish a consolidated definition of the DTh. Within this framework, this article explores the definitions, properties, use cases and implementation methods of the DTh. Interoperability is often an obstacle to DTh implementation. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to characterize the interoperability problems associated with DThs in the light of interoperability frameworks and to study the approaches proposed by the methodological and theoretical framework of Systems Engineering for the practical implementation of DTh, leading to Digital Twin engineering.

title: DSPViT: An FPGA-based Vision Transformer Accelerator with Dynamic Semantic-aware Pruning
authors: Xiaobin Zhuang, Cen Chen, Xiaofeng Zou, Minaer Yeerlan, Huiping Zhuang, Gang Liu, Ziqian Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In recent years, vision transformers (ViTs) have demonstrated excellent performance in computer vision tasks, but their large computational complexity and memory overhead seriously hinder efficient deployment on resource-constrained edge devices. Although researchers have conducted studies to optimize ViT through sparsification, existing methods often rely on static pruning or artificially predefined sparse patterns, and lack the ability to adaptively sense the input semantics, resulting in loss of accuracy or limited hardware efficiency. To this end, we propose a semantic-aware mixed-granularity dynamic pruning co-design architecture—DSPViT for efficient acceleration of ViT inference. We first adopt a semantic-aware dynamic grouping approach to group tokens and evaluate group importance before the attention module; then we use token-wise, block-wise, and element-wise pruning within different groups, which adequately removes redundant tokens as well as redundant connections between tokens in ViT. In addition, we implement token grouping unit on FPGA through counters, adder trees, and DSPs, and we implement row-configurable PE arrays through customized selectors. Compared with existing ViT pruning studies, DSPViT can improve the accuracy of ImageNet dataset by 0.3%-0.5% at lower computational cost; for various widely used ViTs such as DeiT-T, DeiT-S, and DeiT-B, DSPViT can achieve 30%-65% computational reduction. Compared to the baseline hardware accelerators, our DSPViT implementation on U250 achieves an end-to-end acceleration ratio improvement of 3.58×-61.9× and an energy efficiency ratio improvement of 3.15×-36.73×.

title: Foundation Models Meet Spatial Representations: Advancing Zero-Shot Navigation for Embodied AI
authors: Zhou Zhou, Wenlong Chen, Hua Xia, Zhen Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Zero-shot navigation enables embodied agents to perform tasks in unfamiliar environments without specific training by integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) and Vision-Language Models (VLMs) with structured spatial representations. This approach effectively addresses the semantic limitations of traditional methods like Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM). While LLMs provide generalized knowledge, translating this into actionable perception and path planning relies on suitable spatial representations. Current challenges include knowledge transfer, perceptual uncertainty, multimodal fusion, and decision interpretability. Our contributions include: (1) a systematic analysis of LLM applications in zero-shot navigation; (2) a comparative evaluation of spatial representation techniques; and (3) a novel hybrid paradigm integrating universal spatial representations with continual learning and human-robot collaboration for improved generalization in real-world scenarios.

title: Performance Analysis of BPSK and DPSK Modulation Schemes with Hybrid Analog-Digital Transmission Framework in MATLAB
authors: R Abila, G Manoj, P R Harry
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Digital overlays in composite baseband systems provide a means to integrate new services while maintaining compatibility with existing structures. This paper presents a comparative study of Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK) and Differential Phase Shift Keying (DPSK) when used as digital subchannels at 57 kHz within a four-component composite framework. The system study is done using MATLAB simulations. The composite signal consists of (i) an analog baseband signal, (ii) a 19 kHz pilot tone, (iii) 38 kHz sin/cos subcarriers, and (iv) a 57 kHz digital channel carrying random binary data. The design and evaluation of a digital transmission system inspired by the FM stereo Radio Data System (RDS) architecture is used here. Unlike the traditional RDS protocol, which follows fixed group structures, our study focuses on transmitting arbitrary digital data using an FM stereo-like multiplexing framework. The composite signal is modeled with additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel. At the receiver, the composite is bandpass-filtered around 57 kHz, down-converted to baseband, and digital demodulation is done. Analytical and simulation results confirm that BPSK outperforming DPSK at low error rates, while DPSK offers reduced synchronization requirements at the expense of error performance. The study demonstrates the feasibility of extending the FM stereo framework for arbitrary digital communication in broadcast.

title: Power Quality Enhancement of Hybrid PV-Wind-Battery-FCS-AE Based Standalone Microgrid under the Operation with Various Loads
authors: Karanam Deepak, Ajesh, Muhammad Hammad Saeed, Ch. Srinivasa Rao, Ankita Nainwal, T. Saravanan, N. Srinivas, Kandi Bhanu Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Power supply systems especially standalone Microgrids that relies on hybrid renewable sources are more viable solutions for many problems. Hybrid system consisting of Photovoltaic (PV), PMSG based wind conversion system, Aqua-Electrolyzer (AE), Fuel Cell Stack (FCS), battery bank is developed in this paper for supplying AC power to various loads through an inverter. All components of PV, wind system, FCS, AE, battery banks are integrated to a common point through required dc/dc converters to establish a stable dc-link. Different loads such are constant current, impedance, power loads are operated from dc-link through an inverter. Novel control methods are developed on all dc/dc converters to make power flow between respective component and dc-link as well as to maintain a stable voltage at dc-link ($\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{dc}}$). In order to supply a stable voltage to various loads, a novel inverter controller is also implemented in this paper. An efficient energy management system is also developed among all components involved in the Standalone Microgrid System (SMS). Various responses of the system are presented through Simulink on MATLAB platform to validate the proposed method.

title: Masking-Augmentation on Mel-Spectrogram and MFCC for White-crowned Sparrow Vocalization Variants Classification
authors: Abdurrahman Zufar, Sari Widya Sihwi, Herdito Ibnu Dewangkoro
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the application of masking augmentation techniques on the frequency and time axis of Mel-spectrogram and MFCC features for classifying vocalization variants of the White-crowned Sparrow using MobileNetV3. The dataset consists of 860 audio recordings of nine variation groups recorded in California, USA. The study explores the impact of different masking parameters on model performance, evaluated using aggregated F1-score metrics across ten cross-validation folds. The results indicate that applying masking augmentation on Mel-spectrogram features yields the highest F1-score of 98%, outperforming MFCC features and non-augmented data. However, the study also finds several things that can lead to performance degradation attributed to low and high ranges of certain parameters, such as the number of mels or coefficients used to generate the features and the masking coverage on the augmented data.

title: Forecasting Road Traffic Accidents in the Caraga Region Using Comparative Clustering Techniques: Basis for a Data-Driven Road Safety Intervention Program
authors: Imee U. Anton, Cristopher C. Abalorio
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Road traffic accidents remain a persistent public safety concern in the Caraga Region. This study analyzes and forecasts road traffic accidents in the Caraga Region by integrating dimensionality reduction, comparative clustering, and seasonal time-series modeling. A dataset of 18,568 incidents (2019–2024) from the Philippine National Police Caraga was preprocessed and transformed using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), retaining ≈100% of variance (PC1 = 51.80%, PC2 = 48.20%). Four clustering algorithms, The Divisive Analysis (DIANA), Agglomerative Nesting (AGNES), K-Means, and Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) were compared using the Silhouette Score and Davies–Bouldin Index (DBI). DBSCAN achieved the highest Silhouette Score, while K-Means obtained the lowest DBI (0.813) with competitive cohesion, and was selected for downstream forecasting due to its balanced performance and interpretable severity-based clusters (Low, Moderate, High). Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) models were trained on 2019–2024 data to generate a five-year outlook (2024–2029). Forecast accuracy, measured by Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), was 41.37 for Low, 48.97 for Moderate, and 65.75 for High severity clusters. Results reveal seasonal peaks holidays and rainy months, persistent high-volume low-severity incidents, and volatile high-severity spikes. These findings inform a cluster-specific intervention program combining targeted enforcement, seasonal operations, and infrastructure upgrades. This work constitutes the first documented application of comparative clustering techniques integrated with SARIMA-based forecasting in the Caraga Region, establishing a novel, data-driven framework for localized accident prediction and the formulation of evidence-based road safety interventions.

title: Enhanced Conformational Clustering Evaluation Using the RMSD Distance Function in K-Means Method
authors: Dwi Taufik Hidayat, Ira Puspitasari, Febdian Rusydi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: K-Means is a widely used clustering algorithm; however, its application to molecular conformers often suffers from low silhouette scores, significant cluster overlap, and sensitivity to initialization. This study proposes the integration of the Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) distance function into the K-Means algorithm for conformational clustering. Using a dataset of 54 flexible conformers, we conducted a comparative analysis between atom-based geometry clustering and RMSD-based clustering. Evaluation was performed using the silhouette score, visualization, and computation time, implemented in Python (utilizing scikit-learn and RDKit libraries). The results demonstrate that incorporating RMSD significantly improves clustering quality, effectively doubling the silhouette score from 0.3 to 0.6 and reducing misclassification by 40%. While computation time increased by 15%, the precision achieved was twofold higher. Consequently, RMSD-based K-Means offers a more stable and accurate solution for molecular systems comprising fewer than 500 atoms, presenting strong implications for fields such as drug discovery and molecular simulations.

title: Control System Design of a Stacked-Interleaved Buck Converter for Electrolysers
authors: Francesco Cherchi, Mario Porru, Alessandro Serpi
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The design of a multi-loop control system for a Stacked Interleaved Buck Converter (SIBC) is presented in this paper. Starting from the SIBC model, which reveals a significant coupling among the several voltage and current variables, a nested control loop structure has been defined to regulate the SIBC output voltage, branch currents and voltages simultaneously. The proposed design approach is based on the dynamic decoupling between the different control loops, which has been achieved by an appropriate management of SIBC model, as well as by introducing suitable auxiliary variables. The effectiveness of the proposed control system has been verified in simulations, which regards the tracking of a given reference output voltage profile in case of different and variable output currents.

title: Medium-Molecular-Weight Chitosan Derived NDoped Carbon Quantum Dots as a Selective Fluorescent Probe for $\text{Fe}^{3+}$ via a Dual-Mechanism Quenching Process
authors: Lulu Feng, Hainan Li, Zishuai Zhang, Shuang Pang, Zhiyu Liu, Jiahao Lin, Bo Wang, Xuemei Lu, Shiyu Wang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Carbon quantum dots (CQDs), as zerodimensional carbon-based fluorescent nanomaterials, have garnered significant attention in environmental and biological monitoring due to their low toxicity, high stability, and tunable synthesis. This study presents a green synthesis route for nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (N-CQDs) using medium-molecular-weight chitosan as a single precursor via a one-step hydrothermal method <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(190^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 24 \mathrm{h})$</tex>. The resulting NCQDs exhibit uniform spherical morphology (typical diameter: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim {3} \text{ nm}$</tex>) with amorphous carbon cores and abundant surface functional groups, including amino, hydroxyl, and pyrrolic groups (elemental composition <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C} / \mathbf{N} / \mathbf{O}=64: 4: 32$</tex>). These structural attributes enable strong blue fluorescence <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\lambda_{\text{ex }} / \lambda_{\text{em }}=\right. 330 \text{nm} / 402 \text{nm}$</tex>) and selective <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Fe}^{3+}$</tex> detection through a dualmechanism process: (i) coordination binding between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Fe}^{3+}$</tex> and surface functional groups, and (ii) photoinduced electron transfer (PET) facilitated by the high redox potential of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Fe}^{3+}$</tex> (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{E}^{\mathbf{0}}=+\mathbf{0. 7 7} \mathrm{V}$</tex> vs. SHE). The N-CQDs achieve a detection limit of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.72 \mu \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{S} / \mathrm{N}=3)$</tex> for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Fe}^{3+}$</tex> with excellent selectivity against 15 interfering ions (including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al}^{3+}, \text{Cu}^{2+}$</tex>, etc.) and demonstrate validated performance in tap and lake water samples (recoveries: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 9 8}-\mathbf{1 0 0. 0 4 \%}$</tex>). This work highlights the potential of biopolysaccharide-derived nanomaterials in environmental analysis and offers a rapid detection method for trace <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Fe}^{3+}$</tex>.

title: Adaptive Energy Dissipation Device Control for MMC-HVDC Based on Critical Fault Clearing Time
authors: Jiyu Chen, Jinxin Ouyang, Baixiang Huangfu, Taiyu Xiao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: DC overvoltage of the modular multilevel converter-based high voltage direct current (MMC-HVDC) caused by grid faults can lead to itself blocking and compromise AC system stability. Existing methods typically activate the energy dissipation device (EDD) based solely on the DC voltage level, without considering the fault duration, which may result in unnecessary EDD operations. Such unnecessary activations impose additional stress on the AC/DC system and lead to excessive energy waste. In this paper, a security region for the inverter is established, and its contraction characteristics are analyzed. Furthermore, the concept of the critical fault clearing time (CFCT) and its calculation method are introduced. By comparing the main protection operating time with the CFCT, an adaptive EDD control strategy is designed. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively ensures both AC current and DC voltage security while minimizing unnecessary EDD.

title: Evaluating Hybrid Feature Selection Quality and Efficiency Trade-Off in DRL-Based Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Satriadi Putra Santika, Ford Lumban Gaol, Yulyani Arifin, Haryono Soeparno
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern network traffic and the growing sophistication of cyberattacks demand Intrusion Detection System (IDS) that are both accurate and efficient. This study proposes an integrated Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)–based IDS framework that combines feature selection (FS), data imbalance handling, and efficient learning design to enhance detection capability and adaptability. The hybrid Information Gain (IG), Chi-Square (CS), and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) methods were employed for FS, while K-Means SMOTE was applied to address class imbalance in the CSE-CIC-IDS2018 dataset. A stacked LSTM-based DRL model was then trained to learn sequential network behaviors and optimize detection policies. Experimental results show that the PSO-based feature selection achieved the best trade-off between detection performance and computational efficiency, reaching a macro-F1 score of 91.62% with stable convergence. The K-Means SMOTE technique yielded the most balanced data distribution, improving overall generalization and stability. The confusion matrix revealed minor misclassifications between Bruteforce and Benign classes, attributed to their similar network traffic patterns. Although the hybrid IG + CS + PSO configuration achieved the lowest computational cost across all efficiency metrics, it reduced accuracy to 89.20%. In contrast, the PSO + K-Means SMOTE combination provided the most reliable balance, maintaining high detection capability with reasonable complexity. These findings highlight the potential of the proposed DRL-based framework as a foundation for developing adaptive and efficient IDS models suitable for real-time deployment.

title: A comprehensive review of the integration of electric vehicles into the smart grid
authors: D Sarathkumar, Raymon Antony Raj, Sampath Kumar Venkatachary, Leo John Baptist Andrews, Annamalai Alagappan, G Guna, V Anusharani, Murugesan Manivel, B.K. Parrthipan, Sabarish Ponnusamy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into the smart grid presents both significant opportunities and complex challenges. This comprehensive review explores the multifaceted aspects of this integration, encompassing technical, economic, and regulatory perspectives. Key topics include the impact of EV charging on grid stability, demand response strategies, vehicle-togrid (V2G) technologies, and the role of renewable energy sources in supporting a sustainable EV ecosystem. The review also examines the advancements in communication protocols and smart charging infrastructures necessary for seamless integration. Additionally, it addresses the challenges associated with cybersecurity, data privacy, and the regulatory frameworks required to facilitate the widespread adoption of EVs within the smart grid. By synthesizing current research and industry practices, this paper aims to provide a holistic understanding of how EVs can be effectively integrated into the smart grid, highlighting potential solutions and future research directions.

title: Stochastic Streets: A Walk Through Random LLM Address Generation in Four European Cities
authors: Tairan Fu, David Nazareno-Campo, Javier Coronado-Blázquez, Javier Conde, Pedro Reviriego, Fabrizio Lombardi
publish: Computer
abstract: Large language models are capable of solving complex math problems or answering difficult questions on almost any topic, but can they generate random street addresses for European cities?

title: Improved Grid Performance using Novel Control Technique under G2V and V2G Operation
authors: N Venkata Koteswara Rao, K. Bala Krishna
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: A significant power strength in an advanced grid system is an energy storage system for electric vehicles. Sustainable energy management is complete possible with the integration of electric automobiles into a micro-grid strategy, which also rallies stability and power control capabilities. This work presents the execution of V2G integration in a modelled micro-grid (addressing power fluctuation problems due to recurrent power generation) using rapid off-board Level-3 bidirectional charging circuitry with one converter DC-DC Converter along with battery voltage and SOC based (BVSOC) controller is used to change the mode of current direction (V2G or G2V) using bidirectional converter switches and here BVSOCC is the novel control technique used in entire model to obtain the MATLAB/Simulink model. A simulation investigation is led to measure the stability and dynamic sensitivity of V2G and G2V operations. The assessment results demonstrate how critical V2G integration is for sustaining rated values for DC bus voltage and Grid power in failures. During the alternating periods of, the vehicles provide and achieve the flow of active electricity into the grid. Improved dynamic stability and the least amount of harmonic distortion of injected grid current are definite by the converters, controllers, and filters.

title: Edge Computing for Real-Time Crop Health Monitoring in Precision Agriculture
authors: T. Suresh, Mohammed H. Fallah, Utkarsh Anand, G. Satyanarayana, Shermatov Abdukodir Obidjon Ugli, D. Anandhasilambarasan, D.E. Kholdarov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The autonomous and edge agricultural systems are providing a refreshing change in precision farming. The old methodologies of smart farming have paid a lot of attention to the real-time streaming and responsive processes such as pesticide spraying or irrigation of a certain specific process. However, these approaches disregard the higher order biotic news ones, and are more likely to disregard deep, interplay, the implications of which biotic interactions could have on the health of the plant, particularly dynamic interactions between the plants and the microbiome that surrounds them. The article provides a novel, real-time plant health optimization engine that has been designed to execute fully at the edge. Unlike those that are dependent on clouds, the root-zone microbial community will automatically be adapted to local and multiparametric data of biosensors in the proposed system. The system can detect both biotic and abiotic stress earlier on set and this has been possible by being able to gain insight into some plant physiology, alterations in soil chemical conditions and activity of the microbes. Once identified, it offers particular biological healing, in lure of the discharge of probiotic microorganisms, or pH; by a progressing situation of the plant. As it is a closed-loop feedback system, one can continuously learn and optimize decisions and therefore can respond to change in crop health condition or a change of the environment in real-time. It is important to note that the system will not need the common cloud infrastructure, thereby, making it to be exceptionally reliable and responsive, even in an area of the globe, where connection is limited. The performance of clustering-based intervention in terms of stress detection, time and energy efficiency, and yield are considerably improved compared to the performance of conventional systems through experimental evaluation in a wide variety of agricultural settings. The biological smart farming development will commence with the framework. It can support scalable, sustainable and autonomously operated precision agriculture ecosystem, which is founded on edge intelligence and microbiome-guided intervention.

title: AI-Integrated Demand Response with Dynamic Pricing in Prosumer-Driven Renewable Microgrids
authors: RVS Praveen, Zaid Alsalami, Neeraj Varshney, B. Rajalakshmi, Kashi Sai Prasad, Nandini Shirish Boob
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The increasing penetration of prosumers in renewable-energy-based microgrids is transforming energy systems into decentralized, participatory, and intelligent networks. This paper investigates an AI-integrated demand response (DR) framework coupled with dynamic pricing strategies to optimize energy management in prosumer-driven renewable microgrids. By leveraging machine learning for load forecasting, optimization, and adaptive pricing, the proposed approach aligns consumer demand with variable renewable generation, enhancing grid reliability and economic efficiency. The study develops a comprehensive model integrating prosumer behavior, renewable variability, and AI-based dynamic pricing to facilitate real-time, automated DR. Simulation results demonstrate significant peak-load reduction, improved renewable utilization, and cost savings for both utilities and prosumers. Additionally, the analysis highlights the potential of AI to address operational challenges such as demand uncertainty and price volatility through predictive control and reinforcement learning. The paper concludes by discussing the practical implementation challenges, including data privacy, infrastructure requirements, and regulatory considerations, while outlining future research directions for scalable, interoperable, and equitable AI-DR systems in renewable microgrids. This research contributes to advancing smart-grid design by demonstrating how AI can foster an adaptive, resilient, and sustainable energy ecosystem driven by active prosumer participation.

title: Autonomous Real-Time Fault Detection in Commercial Spacecraft Systems
authors: P. K. Chidambaram, Hassan MuhamedAle, Sonam Dubey, V. Suresh, N. V. Dhandapani, Sharipov Dilshodbek Shodmonjon ugli, Mardon Rakhmatov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: A fault detection on systems in commercial spacecrafts requires autonomy in real time in order to be able to safely, reliably and effectively see the missions through. The dynamic nature and multifaceted ness of space vehicles also leads to the large volumes of telemetry created as the space vehicles are operating through the interaction of different sub systems. Rigorous fault detection techniques such as model-based and classical machine learning-based have very low scalability and cross-subsystem dependency modelling problems and are not sensitive to the changes in the type of faults. It is on such weaknesses that they cannot be feasible in real-time applications in the environment in the onboard setting that will require fast and precise fault prognostic responses to outlaw cascade-like failures and the reality that autonomous remedial measures can be executed without the assistance before ground before ground. This system suggest of such a solution to such issues a Hybrid Adaptive Transformer-Graph Neural Network model (HAT-GNN) that is capable of identifying and localising faults in commercial spacecraft systems in real-time by itself. We have a research advantage which consists of an advantage called Interdependencies are expressly represented in our solution which means that it considers the spacecraft subsystems and sensors as a grab base system with dynamic edge connection implying dependencies. The trends in technical sensor telemetry amongst timeseries are detected timely by a lightweight Transformer encoder with the ability to identify temporal abnormalities. The Graph neural Network module condenses and disperses explicitly the information amongst the adjacent subsystem nodes and thereby allows fault localization and inter-subsystem diagnosis to be perfect.

title: Modeling and Control of a Rope-Driven Continuum Robot Based on Cosserat Beam Theory
authors: Fanxi Zeng, Minglei Zhu, Jilie Zhang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Rope-driven continuum robots are an advanced class of flexible bionic robots designed for operation in complex environments. These robots are capable of navigating confined and intricate spaces; however, their control remains challenging due to the nonlinear nature and infinite degrees of freedom inherent in their design. This paper introduces a hydrostatic modeling approach based on Cosserat beam theory, which discretizes the continuum and enables the numerical solution of the driving forces. The model's validity is confirmed through the calculation of the translational relationship of the continuum's position. This work provides a novel theoretical framework for the motion control and mechanical analysis of rope-driven continuum robots, facilitating more precise control in practical applications.

title: Medium and Long Term Load Forecasting Based on Data-Driven Method
authors: Xinying Zhao, Hua Li, Changchun Wang, Dongxue Li, Ruixue Hu, Keke Ding
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Improving the prediction accuracy is of great significance for enhancing the economic benefits of the power system. Smart grids are confronted with problems such as extremely large data volume, differences in statistical standards, and complex data structures. Meanwhile, the factors influencing power load are numerous, diverse, and changeable, and the data of these factors are dispersed across varying temporal scales. When making predictions, it is essential to consider the interdependencies among multi-scale data. Only by comprehensively and fully utilizing data from different time scales can achieve accurate, stable, and dependable medium and long term load prediction. This study introduces a multi-layer recurrent neural network architecture based on LSTM units, which integrates climate data from different time dimensions, historical load data, and regional economic data into the prediction model. A case study utilizing actual operational data demonstrates that the proposed stacked long short-term memory recurrent neural network model achieves no less accuracy than single neural network architectures and outperforms stacked support vector machine models in load forecasting precision.

title: Performance Analysis of Parabolic Solar Cooker with Bayonet Tube Receiver
authors: Abhishek Raj, Kunal Singh, Satish Kumar, R. V. Sharma, Shalendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive CFD analysis of fluid flow and heat transfer in a bayonet tube, simulating the operational conditions of a receiver tube in solar parabolic trough collector system. The investigation considers fragmented heat flux condition, where the upper half tube surface is exposed to global radiation $I_{g}=800 \mathrm{Wm}^{-2}$ while the lower half is subjected to concentrated beam radiation $I_{b} \times C R$ with $I_{b}=600 \mathrm{Wm}^{-2}$ and $C R=8.6$; The analysis is performed for Reynolds numbers under laminar, transition and turbulent regimes (inlet velocities $0.054-0.92 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$) using laminar, transition-SST and $\boldsymbol{k}-\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}$ models. Rise in temperature at low flow rate $(\operatorname{Re} \approx 750)$ is 8 K and at high flow rate $(\operatorname{Re} \approx 4350)$ is about 1 K. The influence of varying flow rates and thermal boundary conditions on the heat transfer characteristics, particularly the Nusselt number show that the average Nusselt number sharply increases from 12 at $\mathbf{R e} \boldsymbol{\approx} \mathbf{2 6 5 0}$ to $\mathbf{3 3}$ at $\mathbf{R e} \boldsymbol{\approx} \mathbf{5 9 5 0}$ with a diminishing slope once turbulent mixing is established.

title: Optimizing Activation Sparsity in Vision Transformers (ViTs) for Edge Devices
authors: Smitha Gladius T S, Siva priya. M S, Jeipratha P N, Omana J
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Despite achieving state-of-the-art performance on numerous computer vision applications, Vision Transformers (ViTs) are challenging to implement on edge devices with limited resources due to their high computational complexity and memory requirements. In order to overcome this difficulty, this work presents the Dynamic Activation Sparsity Mechanism (DASM), whose main goal is to lower memory and computational expenses without appreciably sacrificing accuracy. This approach dynamically reduces the number of activated neurons during inference to maximize activation sparsity. This method, when tested on benchmark datasets such as CIFAR-10, results in over 40% memory and computational cost savings with only a slight loss in accuracy. This development opens the door for the use of potent ViTs in low-power, real-time applications on edge devices.

title: Investigating the Effects of Age and Treatment on Sleep Quality in Breast Cancer Patients
authors: Swati Singh, Sonal Sharma, Dharmendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Research studies indicate that women aged between 18-49 years are often diagnosed with advanced stages of breast cancer, necessitating intensive treatments that leads to multiples physical and behavioral issues among which sleep disturbances hold a dominant position. The study aims to assess sleep quality and the key factors impacts the sleep quality of women in India diagnosed with breast cancer disease. Total 156 women enrolled in the study among which 73% reported poor sleep quality (PSQI>5) and 35% women experienced severely reduced sleep duration (24 hours per night). Findings revealed that sleep disturbances (SD), prolonged sleep latency (SL), and subjective sleep quality (SSQ)are interconnected issues with factors such as age, surgery, and chemotherapy further exacerbating sleep problems.

title: Impact of Latency on User Experience in Immersive Teleoperation: A Study with Motion Capture Gloves and Dexterous Robotic Hand
authors: Shravan Kumar Pattiwar, Myrthe E. J. Tilleman, Konstantinos Kousias, Paresh Saxena, Özgü Alay, Carsten Griwodz
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Understanding latency tolerance in teleoperated systems is crucial to ensure smooth human-robot interaction (HRI). In this study, we investigate the effects of network-induced delays on teleoperation using a controlled setup featuring a Rokoko Smartglove and a Shadow Robot Dexterous Hand. Through our experiments, users control the robotic hand in real-time while receiving visual feedback either directly or via a VR headset, delivering an immersive, metaverse-oriented experience. To introduce controlled delays, we utilize an Ingress Delay Mechanism for precise latency application. A user study involving 33 participants was organized to evaluate the impact of latency on user experience in terms of responsiveness, naturalness, control, and level of frustration. Results show that VR-based teleoperation is more sensitive to delays than direct HRI. In particular, perceived responsiveness decreased significantly with an additional 200 ms of delay, while frustration levels showed a significant increase with 150 ms of additional delay. These findings provide valuable insights towards optimizing future immersive teleoperation systems.

title: Real-Time Blockchain Identity Verification for Borderless Travel
authors: Rajesh Sehgal, Anish Gupta, G. Premananthan, Ahmed Anwer Jaafa, Ergashev Rasulbek Sokhib Ugli, Chidanand T
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Due to increased globalization and international travel, there is a growing demand for secure and private identity verification systems at border entries. Reliance on databases controlled by only a few hinders quick, safe, and easy border crossings for travelers. The paper proposes a system utilizing blockchain technology that would enable individuals to verify their identities in real-time when traveling internationally. The system suggested for travelers utilizes selfsovereign identity technology, allowing them to manage their verified IDs on their devices through wallets based on blockchain technology.
