Once biometric details, such as facial recognition, fingerprints, and iris scans, are collected from each individual, they are linked together on the identical federated, permissioned blockchain by the nation's and border agencies. With the help of smart contracts, it is possible to control entry such that only approved agencies verify traveler documents, and zero-knowledge proofs ensure that only essential attributes about a person's identity are disclosed. Simulations prove that the system reduces verification time to under two seconds, significantly outperforming traditional systems, and prevents nearly 90% more identity fraud. Additionally, since blockchain is decentralized and secure, it ensures that audit records are transparent and there are no single points of failure. The work introduces a manageable and compatible system that enables people to travel more efficiently while facilitating collaboration between border officials and countries. The next step is to do significant pilot deployments, connect to current travel technology, and face rules and differences among countries and regions to make sure air (/land) mobility grows for everyone.

title: Variable Gain Robust Formation Control with Disturbance Attenuation Performance for Uncertain Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Takuma Kawakami, Hayate Sawato, Kouki Shibuya, Haruto Takahashi, Yoshikatsu Hoshi, Hidetoshi Oya
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper proposes a design method of a variable gain robust formation controller with disturbance attenuation performance for uncertain multi-agent systems (MASs). The proposed robust controller consists of stabilizing state feedback laws, state feedback inputs for consensus, and compensation inputs with adjustable parameters, and can achieve both consensus and relative positions between it. In this paper, it is shown that sufficient conditions for the existence of the proposed formation controller which guarantees disturbance attenuation performance can be reduced to solvability of the linear matrix inequalities (LMIs).

title: Novel Attention Feature Modeling for Knowledge Fusion in Power Systems Based on Hierarchical Embeddings
authors: Sai Zhang, Ying Liu, Xiao Liang, Xiaoxuan Fan, Qiang Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: As the digitalization and intelligent transformation of power systems continues to advance, power knowledge exhibits characteristics such as multi-source heterogeneity, semantic complexity, and structural coupling. Traditional models struggle to balance accuracy and generalization in knowledge fusion and semantic representation. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Hierarchical Embedding-Based Attention Framework (HEAF) for power system knowledge fusion. This model constructs a multi-layer semantic embedding framework, categorizing power knowledge into entity, relationship, and scenario layers to achieve hierarchical semantic representation. It introduces a cross-layer attention mechanism to dynamically allocate feature weights, thereby strengthening structural associations and semantic consistency. Experiments conducted on multi-source power knowledge datasets encompassing dispatch, operation and maintenance, and safety supervision data demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms mainstream methods in accuracy, semantic consistency, and robustness, achieving an overall performance improvement of approximately 6%–10%. The findings indicate that integrating hierarchical embedding with attention mechanisms effectively enhances power knowledge understanding and intelligent reasoning capabilities, providing novel technical pathways and theoretical support for operational analysis, risk early warning, and knowledge-driven decision-making in power systems.

title: FPGA Implementation of Programmable LFSR
authors: Sambhav Langote, Sakshi Cholli, Suhas Shirol, Rajeshwari M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: As the complexity of IC increases with advances in VLSI, efficient and flexible testing methods are essential. Linear Feedback Shift Registers (LFSRs) are widely used in BIST systems for their simplicity and ability to generate pseudorandom patterns. This work proposes a reconfigurable LFSR (R-LFSR) architecture that allows for the dynamic modification of bit width and feedback polynomial at runtime, enabling the generation of tailored or maximum-length sequences without requiring hardware changes. This adaptability makes it ideal for multi-mode and adaptive testing environments. The R-LFSR is implemented on an FPGA, enabling rapid prototyping and flexibility. Analysis of resource usage, reconfiguration latency, and pattern quality confirms the design's efficiency. The proposed architecture supports diverse testing needs, reduces design costs, and improves reusability, making it well-suited for modern VLSI testing applications.

title: A Weighted Ensemble of Multi-Scale Fusion CNNs for Melanoma Classification
authors: Yanal Idrees, Heba Abdel-Nabi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The early and accurate diagnosis of malignant melanoma remains a significant challenge in dermatology, largely due to the high visual similarity between malignant and benign skin lesions. This paper introduces a novel classification methodology tested on the challenging and highly imbalanced ISIC 2017 dataset. A custom multi-scale feature fusion head was designed to improve the feature extraction capabilities of standard Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) backbones. Through systematic evaluation, an EfficientNetB6 model equipped with this fusion head was identified as the most effective single-model architecture. To further boost the performance, a weighted ensemble was developed that combines the outputs of our two best fusion models: EfficientNetB6 and DenseNet201. The final proposed model, utilizing a 90/10 weighting scheme, achieved an F1-score of 0.5517, an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.8174, and a clinically significant recall of 75.2%. The experimental results demonstrated that this weighted ensemble of multi-scale fusion models offers a superior balance between precision and recall, establishing an effective strategy for this complex classification task.

title: Switching Angle and PWM Controls of Three-Phase Three-Level Multilevel Inverter Permanent Magnet Motor Drives for Variable Speed/Frequency Applications
authors: Olusegun Solomon
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: A three-phase multilevel inverter was previously introduced and proposed with a generalized formula of output voltage to establish the conditions for reduction or elimination of specific harmonics. This multilevel inverter was particularly suitable for fixed speed/frequency applications, significantly reducing switching losses by having inverter switching devices operate at only a single line frequency. However, many applications benefit from variable speed/frequency operation, necessitating switching at much higher frequencies and multiples of the fundamental line frequency. This study extends previous work by analyzing the performance of the three-phase three-level multilevel inverter for variable speed control. The switching scheme of the previously proposed fixed-speed inverter is also modified to enable pulse-width modulated variable speed/frequency control. The performances of the multilevel inverters connected to permanent magnet motor machines are examined through simulation to demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed concepts. The proposed control schemes do not necessarily require the use of rectifier front end to supply DC bus voltage to the inverter, thereby eliminating the need for capacitors and capacitor voltage balancing used in some conventional drives. The proposed concepts can offer additional benefits for enabling compact designs and capabilities for standalone operation. The proposed inverter-motor drives are very suitable for Renewable Energy (RE) and Electric Vehicle (EV) power systems supplied from an array of dc voltage sources.

title: Development of a Compact Hybrid Energy Storage System for Pulsed Load Applications in Unmanned Ground Vehicles
authors: Palande Sunil Pandurang, Rohan Kumar, Kunwar Aditya
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs) are increasingly deployed in applications demanding high reliability and efficient energy utilization under pulsed and transient operating conditions. Conventional lithium-ion battery power systems, while offering high energy density, suffer rapid degradation and diminished performance when exposed to high-rate, repetitive loads. This study presents the development and experimental validation of a compact Hybrid Energy Storage System (HESS) for UGVs, integrating a 24 V lithium-ion battery pack with a 16.2 V high-capacitance ultracapacitor module via a bidirectional buck-boost converter managed by embedded controls. The system's architecture enables dynamic power sharing, markedly reducing battery current ripples and improving response to abrupt load pulses up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 0}$</tex> A. MATLAB/Simulink simulations and hardware tests confirm significant improvements in system efficiency, thermal management, and battery lifespan, demonstrating the suitability of the HESS approach for enhancing UGV operational endurance and resilience under severe field conditions.

title: Enhancing Model Reliability through GAN-Augmented Data: A Case Study on Real vs. Fake Detection
authors: Harshita Mishra, Ashwani Kumar, Ishant, Kumud Sachdeva, Bharti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: As the degree of misinformation and fake media increases, has become a critical challenge to be able to differentiate between authentic and synthetic data. In this study, we examine how Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) can be deployed to augment datasets and increase reliability in real-vs- fake detection tasks by use of Machine Learning (ML) models. GANs are useful in balancing the classes, improving the diversity of features, and the capability to generalize due to the production of high quality fake data. The current paper provides a case study, in which the GAN-enhanced datasets were employed to train classification models that identify fake instances of various domains. The relative findings indicate that GAN-based augmentation increased the model accuracy by 85.4 per cent to 92.7, precision by 82.1 per cent to 90.3, and error rates by 11 per cent, hence greatly strengthening the detection system.

title: AI Enabled Approach for Nutrition Analysis and Ingredient Substitution
authors: Akashdeep Singh, Raj Kumar, Neetu Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) and its implementation in various fields has revolutionized many industries, particularly food and nutrition, in a huge way. The following paper credits the development of a web application in terms of the utilization of AI technologies, such as OpenAI's GPT and Stable Diffusion, to assist users in designing customized recipes based on the ingredients they have available. The application enables users to input a list of ingredients, and the program generates a complete recipe in terms of the provided ingredients, along with suggestions for further ingredients required to complete the meal. Apart from this, the system also provides nutritional information relevant to the developed recipe, giving users valuable insights into their nutritional intake. The web application uses JavaScript, CSS, and other web technologies to create a responsive and user-friendly interface, with the use of AI models in the application of the recipe development and the nutritional analysis functions. This paper elaborates on the procedure involved in developing the application, technical integration of AI, and the likely impact of such technology on modern-day cooking habits, nutritional monitoring, and personalized meal planning. It concludes with mention of difficulties encountered during development and suggesting areas of future development to improve the functionality of the system and interface.

title: A Study on an Intelligent Error Prevention System for Relay Protection Voltage Plates Based on Lightweight ResNet-FPN Fusion Models
authors: Sun Fucheng, Yin Zhipeng, Li Chenming, Cui Zhaolong, Wang Baosen, Wang Weiquan, Yuan Yi
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Aiming at the risk of human error casting and stopping in relay protection pressure plate operation, this paper proposes an intelligent error prevention method based on lightweight AI. By constructing a multi-vendor pressure plate feature database and designing an improved ResNet-18+ simplified FPN fusion model, it realizes the real-time recognition of pressure plate state on the mobile end (accuracy rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geqslant 99.2 \%$</tex>). The system establishes a bimodal error prevention mechanism: the error prevention logic is previewed by the database before operation, and the results are automatically verified by image sequence comparison after operation. Practical application shows that this method reduces the error rate of manual operation to less than 0.8%, improves the efficiency of instruction execution by 40%, and provides technical support for the construction of the intrinsic safety system of relay protection, which is based on the principle of “operation rehearsal-process guidance-results traceability”.

title: Multi-Step Compensation-Based Dynamic Optimization for Ethylene Cracking Furnace
authors: Qiming Ding, Chuang Wang, Huiyuan Shi
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Complex industrial processes often require the implementation of hierarchical control architectures to seamlessly integrate loop control and operational optimization across different time scales. However, the inherent complexity of multi-time-scale structures, coupled with the presence of unknown dynamic disturbances and uncertainties, poses significant challenges for achieving coordinated control and dynamic optimization. This study introduces a real-time optimization method based on robust predictive control and multi-step signal compensation, designed to address the multi-time-scale characteristics of complex industrial processes while dynamically optimizing economic performance objectives. By constructing a composite state-space model incorporating unmodeled dynamics and designing a multi-step signal compensation controller, the proposed approach effectively enhances the system's robustness and adaptability. Furthermore, the dual-layer control framework facilitates efficient coordination between upper-layer operational optimization and lower-layer loop tracking, ensuring that the system consistently operates near its economic optimum under dynamic conditions. The proposed method is validated through simulations of a diesel hydrotreating process, demonstrating its potential to improve control performance and economic efficiency in complex industrial applications.

title: Enhancing Overload Capability of Electric Truck Inverters via Active Thermal Control
authors: Eneko Agirrezabala, Yoann Pascal, Karthik Debbadi, Marco Liserre, Iosu Aizpuru, David Garrido
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Electric trucks are subject to demanding overload events during operations such as kerbstone climbing, where the inverter operates at low output frequency and high current, leading to significant thermal stress on power semiconductors. To prevent exceeding the junction temperature limits, standard practice often involves limiting torque output or oversizing the power stage, resulting in reduced acceleration performance or increased system cost. This study investigates the use of Active Thermal Control (ATC) to improve inverter operation during such overload conditions, enhancing performance without exceeding thermal limits. Three ATC strategies are evaluated: increase of gate voltage, reduction of switching frequency, and the application of Discontinuous PWM, as well as selected combinations of these strategies. The study quantifies the thermal, lifetime, and waveform quality impact when applying these ATC strategies. Results demonstrate that the junction-to-ambient temperature difference can be reduced by up to 26%, and the number of safe mission repetitions can increase by a factor of five. Alternatively, for a fixed thermal limit, the deliverable output current can be raised by approximately 20%, enhancing acceleration capability without requiring converter oversizing. These findings confirm the potential of individual ATC strategies to enhance inverter robustness and dynamic performance, while showing that their combination enables even greater improvements in demanding electric drive applications.

title: A Data-Driven Scenario Construction Based Probabilistic Assessment Method for Electrical Power and Energy Balance
authors: Junjie Zhao, Bo Jia, Zhikai Wu, Ziru Wang, Lin Ji, Pingyu Shan
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Aiming at the multi-timescale uncertainty challenges faced by the power balance of the power system under a high proportion of new energy grid-connectedness, this paper proposes a data-driven operation scenario-based power balance assessment method. First, a multi-timescale source-load probability distribution model is constructed by combining a variational encoder (VAE) and a Gaussian mixture model (GMM); second, a data-driven operation scenario-based approach is proposed to evaluate the power balance. Finally, a constrained scenario screening algorithm based on source-load characteristic indicators is proposed to efficiently locate the risk scenarios of insufficient peaking/backup and to reduce the evaluation calculation volume. The results show that the error of power shortage probability assessment is less than 0.01%, and the calculation accuracy of new energy abandonment rate is 15% higher than that of the traditional time series simulation, which provides an effective technological support for the new type of power balance planning of the new power system.

title: State-of-Charge Estimation for Battery Based on Integrated Incremental Capacity Analysis and Dual Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Binjie Liao, Yang Liu, Yiming Gong, Yuhao Wu, Jinlei Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: With the rapid development of the new energy vehicle industry, lithium-ion batteries have become its mainstream power source, and accurate estimation of the State of Charge (SOC) is crucial for the lifecycle management of power batteries. For the traditional Dual Extended Kalman Filter (DEKF) algorithm, the challenge of correcting SOC estimation errors caused by capacity degradation has long been a focal point of industry research, particularly evident when the battery charge is low. To address this, this paper proposes a battery SOC estimation method that integrates Incremental Capacity Analysis (ICA) with DEKF. Firstly, an equivalent circuit model of the battery is constructed, and a dual-time-scale DEKF algorithm is employed to estimate the available capacity on a macroscopic time scale and the SOC on a microscopic time scale. Subsequently, an ICA-DEKF interactive updating mechanism is established, leveraging the coupling relationship between ICA characteristics and available capacity to create a numerical linkage, thereby providing the DEKF algorithm with initial values for the available capacity. The results indicate that the combined ICA-DEKF algorithm achieves an average SOC estimation error of 1.01% under the UDDS driving cycle, and the SOC estimation error is 0.83% under low SOC conditions. This provides a novel approach to solving the state estimation challenges associated with the aging of power batteries.

title: Improving Intrusion Detection in IoT Networks Using Tree-Based Ensemble Methods and Mutual Information Feature Selection
authors: Abdelkader Hadj-Attou, Yacine Kabir, Farid Ykhlef
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: The inherent limitations in processing power and resources of Internet of Things (IoT) devices increase their susceptibility to malicious intrusions. This research aims to address the intrusion detection problem in IoT systems through a comparative analysis of three tree-based ensemble learning algorithms, namely XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost, on the BoT-IoT dataset. Furthermore, we examine the influence of Mutual Information (MI)-based feature selection on enhancing detection performance. The experimental results indicate that XGBoost combined with MI demonstrates the highest reliability, as they maintain consistent performance regardless of the selected feature subsets.

title: Research on dynamic filtering SLAM based on 3D optical flow error model and deep learning features
authors: Jiajing Su, Yuan Zhu, Ke Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Dynamic vehicles and pedestrians, as well as motion-blurred scenes, pose challenges to the localization accuracy and mapping stability of traditional Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM). To this end, this paper proposes a real-time dynamic filtering SLAM algorithm that combines a 3D optical flow error model with deep learning features. The algorithm takes stereo or RGB-D images and IMU data as input, extracts SuperPoint feature points, limits the optical flow tracking range within the target semantic area through instance priors, and accurately identifies potential motion features based on the 3D optical flow error model. In the localization stage, static features are retained for pose estimation and optimization. In the mapping stage, potential motion features are removed to ensure that a purely static point cloud map is generated to support loop closure and relocation. Verified by multiple datasets, the algorithm is superior to existing mainstream methods in terms of real-time performance and localization accuracy. In particular, the localization accuracy of the real vehicle experiment is improved by 96.68% compared with the basic algorithm.

title: Visual language models and generative artificial intelligence for smart workplace safety: a comparative study
authors: Pasquale Molinaro, Luca Turconi, Marco Giannotti, Francesco Pupo, Giancarlo Fortino
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Workplace accidents often lead to fatal or serious injuries if workers don’t wear personal protection equipment (PPE) in a proper way. In the very recent years, the deployment of object detection systems has seen a great improvement in different domains. In particular, many of these systems are being applied in dangerous workplaces, used to detect PPEs worn by workers. Although many studies have reached good results with classical techniques such as YOLO or Faster R-CNN, the usage of Large Language Models (LLM), more specifically the Vision Language Models (VLM), are increasingly recognised as a viable alternative. VLMs are gaining interest due to their flexibility and adaptability to different scenarios. These are models that integrate both visual and textual information. They can perform different tasks such as extracting features from images and elaborating them to give a proper answer to specific questions, using the power of the most recent LLMs integrated in them. The focus of this study is to analyse and compare these two paradigms: on one side a classic algorithm like YOLO, while on the other side different VLM models. The purpose is to use them to perform an object detection task on different kinds of PPEs. Furthermore, the objective is to improve the detection of PPEs through testing models on specific datasets. Results show that while working with restricted computational capacity, classic techniques, like YOLO, maintain their leading position in terms of speed and efficiency. Although with the proper computational power, generative models show great scalability and versatility. Moreover, these models can analyse complex scenarios without task-specific fine-tuning, thanks to their ability to extract features from the textual part.

title: NH SwiftPass
authors: Georgy K Jayee, Ginu Mariya George, Hima Mariya, Minnuja Shelly, Anusree K
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: This project aims to reduce highway toll booth delays by introducing a smart toll pre-booking system with dedicated express lanes. Over three months, a mobile/web app will be developed to let users pre-book tolls within a 5–20 km radius, with a time-bound entry window. AI cameras will verify vehicle numbers using OpenCV with YOLO or OCR or Google Gemini API, detecting violations and enabling automatic fine or refund processing. The backend will manage bookings, enforce rules, and provide an admin dashboard, while the frontend shows booking status, fines, and history. The system prototype will be tested and optimized before final submission, ensuring faster toll access, reduced congestion, and improved user convenience.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Tea Plant Disease Identification Based on Similar Visual Characteristics
authors: Johan Muliadi Kerta, Abdul Haris Rangkuti, Jajat Sudrajat, Siti Hajar Mohamad, Raiza Rahman, Kenrick Panca Dewanto
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Research on Tea plant disease is critically important in the face of serious agricultural challenges and evolving global consumer preferences, as exemplified by the significant decline of the Indonesian tea industry and the pressing need to adapt to new market demands. To address issues of crop loss and quality control, this study investigates the application of advanced deep learning methodologies to automate the detection and classification of tea plant diseases. An extensive dataset of 5,445 images was utilized, divided into 2,777 training images (51%), 820 validation images (15%), and 1,848 test images (34%). Seven distinct Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models were rigorously evaluated. The experiments demonstrated highly promising results, with models such as Inception V4, DenseNet169 and YoloV11 achieving peak accuracies of between 97%, 96% and 95%. respectively. Most of the other models also yielded robust average accuracy above 90%. While classification performance varied for specific diseases, particularly Red Spider Infestation and Red Rust, the study conclusively shows that these deep learning models can provide a highly effective and accurate means of automated disease identification. This work establishes a strong foundation for future research, which could expand to include a wider variety of more diverse and complex plant diseases to further enhance agricultural resilience

title: Impact Assessment of Multiple PV-DG & DSTATCOM Allocation in Reconfigured RDN using a novel hybrid Approach
authors: Pragya Guru, Shradha Singh Parihar, Saurav Raj
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources in modern distribution system necessitates intelligent optimization strategies to ensure operational efficiency, voltage stability and power quality. This article presents an assessment study to determine the impact of optimal allocation of multiple photovoltaic distributed generation (PV-DG) and DSTATCOM in a reconfigured radial power distribution network. To determine ideal feeder reconfigured network and multiple PVDG & DSTATCOM unit allocation under deterministic load conditions, a novel hybrid Marine Predator-Jellyfish Search optimization algorithm (MPJSA) is suggested. The method maximizes the net economic gain from enhanced voltage regulation and loss reductions while minimizing real power losses and voltage variations. Here, results of IEEE 118-bus radial distribution network under various constraints are used to validate the methodology after comparing it with the published results. The analysis clearly reflects that coordinated optimization greatly enhances the voltage profile and reduces active power losses with improvement in technical performance and financial gains. The study offers an economical method for raising operational profitability and distribution network efficiency.

title: Trustworthy and Privacy-Enhanced Financial Portfolio Management Using Federated Learning on Blockchain Networks
authors: Munnangi Suresh, Meena G, Vishwa Priya V, G. Manikandan, Chandan Bandyopadhyay, B J Ananya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The centralized data processing, high vulnerability to data breaches, and lack of transparency in existing financial portfolio management systems are serious flaws that erode participant trust. It indicates an integrated system that combines Blockchain technology and Federated Learning (FL) to address these issues. FL allows for decentralized model training, protecting sensitive data locally and just exchanging updates to the model. Security and efficiency are improved by methods including adaptive learning rates, homomorphic encryption, and differential privacy. Smart contracts automate compliance, while blockchain provides a transparent record for model modifications, guaranteeing data integrity and participant trust. In comparison to existing systems that have larger overheads and accuracies of 75% and 77%, the results show an increased communication efficiency at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 0 ~ M B}$</tex>, faster convergence at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0}$</tex> epochs, and an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 2. 1 \%}$</tex> for the model. The proposed system maximizes collaborative financial decision-making while also improving data security and privacy.

title: Performance Realization of Multiple Inductive Active-Cell Balancing Technique for EV Applications
authors: G Vijayakumar, A Saranya, R Sundar, C Ramkumar, P Rajakumar, Pranav Kumar Rowlo
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are a crucial component of electric vehicles. It is widely used due to its high energy density and long lifespan. Cell balancing is the process of maintaining uniform voltage levels in each cell of a battery pack to maximize the battery pack’s efficiency. This research paper proposes a multi-inductor-based active cell modelling in which a shared inductor is used for redistributing the energy among cells actively within a battery pack. A 48 V battery consisting of 13 Li-ion cells connected in series, each rated at a nominal voltage of 3.7 V, is to be employed. The imbalances in the voltages of the 13 cells are to be ascertained and rectified using inductor-based active cell balancing. The simulation is demonstrated in MATLAB software, and the simulations were carried out for different State of Charge (SoC) to study the time frame of the cell balancing. The inductor configuration reduces component count, contributing to a simplified, faster, and cost-effective design.

title: Navigational Aid for Submerged Underwater Vessels using Obstacle Detection Sonar and Open Source GIS Systems
authors: M.S Fathima, Sumi A. Samad
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Underwater navigation becomes a critical challenge, where conventional systems such as satellite communication, or network connectivity are unreliable. Integration of obstacle detection SONAR and pre-loaded geospatial data using open source Geographic Information System tool offering mariners a two-dimensional visualization of in-water hazards and geographic features in the vessel’s projected path. This approach allows loading nautical charts which enables the detection and representation of obstacles at navigational significant ranges, providing a real-time, context-aware decision-support offline. Such a system not only advances navigational safety but also aligns with the growing demand for intelligent marine technologies that support autonomous and semi-autonomous vessel operations.

title: Optimized Ensembled Model for Water Toxicity Prediction Using Machine Learning Approach
authors: Deepak Rawat, Ankita Aggarwal, Saurabh, Geetanjali Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The underwater aquatic life is highly impacted by the toxicity. The presented paper proposes an optimized ensemble to predict the toxicity effects of water on aquatic life. Although the traditional machine learning algorithms predict the toxicity level but shows the accuracy may be increased by extending the machine learning approaches. Linear regression performs well further the performance of proposed model is quite satisfactory. As the performance of optimized Ensemble model is better than traditional applied machine learning models so to validating and strengthen the proposed model multidisciplinary domain named operational research is applied where W-Saw and Balanced error are calculated which further leads to the deployment of model in real life synerios.

title: A Fuzzy-Based Clustering and Routing Protocol for Enhancing the Lifetime of Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Simanta Das, Ripudaman Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a fuzzy-based clustering and routing (FBCR) protocol to enhance the lifetime of wireless sensor networks (WSNs). FBCR protocol uses a fuzzy-based technique to compute the optimum number of CHs in a round. In this technique, the input is the average residual energy of alive SNs. Further, the FBCR protocol ensures that each round has the optimum number of CHs. Furthermore, FBCR protocol uses the hyper round technique (HRT) to reduce the energy consumption of SNs in clustering. We compare the performance of the FBCR protocol with the EDFIKM, FR-LEACH and LEACH protocols. Results show that the FBCR protocol provides 10.0%, 14.0%, and 22.0% higher network lifetime than EDFIKM, FR-LEACH and LEACH protocols, respectively.

title: Structured Controller Design in Grid Following Converters for Guaranteed Performance and Robustness Against Weak Grids. An LMI Approach
authors: G. Navarro-Patrón, C. Diaz-Sanahuja, A. Ordono, M. Guillamon-Ferrer, R. Ortiz-Cardenas, I. Peñarrocha-Alós
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a discrete-time multivariable controller design method for grid-connected power converters interfaced with LCL filters operating in grid-following mode. The approach is meant to handle different grid conditions as well as inherent computational and PWM delays, and also avoiding hidden oscillations typical of discrete implementations. Additionally, it considers the regulation of converter output currents under varying grid scenarios and uncertainties introduced by auxiliary components. The controllers are implemented as a structured state-feedback scheme. Its design balances robustness, by minimizing the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H_{\infty}$</tex> norm of the sensitivity function, dynamic response, by imposing a given dominant pole, and noise effect limitation, by constraining the range of gain values the controllers can take. Controller gains are obtained by solving an optimization problem described by a sequence of Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI) combined with the inclusion of the Completion of Squares technique to improve the problem computation. Simulation studies are included to compare the proposed method with conventional PI controllers augmented with decoupling and feedforward structures. These demonstrate a better performance in different grid scenarios, showing the method's success in enhancing stability, robustness, and overall dynamic behavior.

title: EV Charging Infrastructure Development in Smart Grids
authors: D Sarathkumar, Raymon Antony Raj, Sampath Kumar Venkatachary Grant, Leo John Baptist Andrews, Annamalai Alagappan, Guna G, Anusharani V, Murugesan Manivel, B.K. Parrthipan, Sabarish Ponnusamy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has driven the need for a robust and scalable charging infrastructure, integrated seamlessly with smart grids. This paper explores the key challenges and opportunities in the development of EV charging infrastructure within the framework of smart grids. It highlights the critical role of smart grids in optimizing energy distribution, managing peak loads, and integrating renewable energy sources for sustainable EV charging. The paper addresses various technological advancements, including Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) systems, bi-directional charging, and demand-side management, which enhance the efficiency and reliability of EV charging networks. Furthermore, the paper discusses the impact of grid modernization, smart metering, and advanced communication technologies in facilitating real-time monitoring and control of charging stations. Key challenges such as grid capacity constraints, interoperability issues, and regulatory policies are also examined. By analyzing existing case studies and pilot projects, this study offers insights into best practices and strategic approaches for developing future-proof EV charging infrastructure, aiming for a sustainable and energy-efficient transportation ecosystem.

title: Imbalanced Data Handling for Stroke Prediction Using Oversampling and Cost-Sensitive Learning
authors: Triyan Agung Laksono, Widyastuti Andriyani
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Class imbalance is a major challenge in medical predictive modeling, especially in stroke risk identification, where minority cases represent only a small fraction of the available clinical data. This study compares the effectiveness of two imbalance handling techniques, SMOTE oversampling and cost-sensitive learning, applied to Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and XGBoost using the public Kaggle stroke dataset. Three experimental scenarios were evaluated: baseline, SMOTE, and cost-sensitive learning. The results show a significant improvement in minority class recall, especially for SVM, although this improvement is accompanied by a decrease in overall precision and accuracy. Evaluation using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC shows that cost-sensitive learning provides the best balance between sensitivity and discrimination performance. Further SHAP analysis revealed that age and hypertension were the most influential predictors. Although these findings are promising, limitations related to dataset size and the risk of overfitting remain. Further research should explore hybrid imbalance handling methods and validation on larger and more diverse datasets to improve clinical applicability.

title: Electric Field Emissions from Laptop Computers: A Quantitative Study of User Exposure During Charging and Non-Charging Operations
authors: Charles Nnamdi Udekwe, Ajibike Eunice Akin-Ponnle, Hope Arosoye, Akinlolu Adediran Ponnle
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper evaluates electric field (EF) emissions from commonly used HP laptops under realistic operational conditions, with an emphasis on charging states and user proximity in relation to international exposure limits. Five HP laptop models were tested using the TriField TF2 EMF meter, with measurements recorded at fixed distances ranging from 0 to 25 cm under two power conditions (charging and noncharging) and three usage modes (airplane, browsing, and video playback). A total of 30 test scenarios were analyzed. EF intensity was plotted and fitted to theoretical decay modelsnamely inverse-square and exponential functions-with goodness of fit assessed via $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ and RMSE metrics. Results show that EF emissions decrease with distance, generally following exponential attenuation. Charging consistently resulted in higher EF values, with several models reaching or exceeding the TF2’s upper detection limit of $1000 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$ at $0-2 \mathrm{~cm}$, whereas noncharging emissions remained below $20 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$ across all modes. Among the laptop tested, the EliteBook Folio 9480m exhibited the highest emissions, attributed to its compact design and legacy power architecture. Curve fitting demonstrated strong model alignment, particularly under browsing mode ($\mathrm{R}^{2} \geq 0.99$). While all observed values fall within ICNIRP and IEEE C95.1 public exposure guidelines, the elevated emissions during charging raise ergonomic concerns for close-contact users. The study recommends maintaining a minimum distance of $20- \mathbf{2 5 ~ c m}$ during laptop charging to mitigate near-field EF exposure. These findings contribute to EMF safety discourse and support the development of informed usage practices and shielding-conscious device designs

title: Methodology for an Analysis of Influencing Factors on 3D Object Detection Performance
authors: Anton Kuznietsov, Dirk Schweickard, Steven Peters
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In automated driving, object detection is crucial for perceiving the environment. Although deep learning-based detectors offer high performance, their black-box nature complicates safety assurance. We propose a novel methodology to analyze how object- and environment-related factors affect LiDAR- and camera-based 3D object detectors. A statistical univariate analysis relates each factor to pedestrian detection errors. Additionally, a Random Forest (RF) model predicts errors from meta-information, with Shapley Values interpreting feature importance. By capturing feature dependencies, the RF enables a nuanced analysis of detection errors. Understanding these factors reveals detector performance gaps and supports safer object detection system development.

title: Term Deposit Customer Prediction: Leveraging Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM) with Bank Marketing Data
authors: Rahul Prasad, Mohit Choubey, Praveen Kumar Tyagi, Ajay Sharma, Ebtasam Ahmad Siddiqui, Swati Gautam
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The global COVID-19 pandemic led to a sharp economic downturn, disrupting economies and financial systems worldwide. Lockdowns and travel restrictions severely affected supply chains, forced businesses to close, and caused widespread job losses, underscoring the importance of sound financial planning. Term deposits have so become relatively common as effective ways to lower financial risk. As marketing moves to contact potential consumers, direct communication techniques are used more and more over traditional middlemen. This paper investigates consumer term deposit subscription using information from a Portuguese bank. Using machine learning methods such Support Vector Machine (SVM), Gaussian Naïve Bayes, Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM), Bagging, and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGI), these potential customers are categorized and projected. Results reveal that bagging methods most predict client behavior, which provides valuable information to enhance targeted marketing strategies.

title: Optimization and Integration of Low-Area Low-Energy and High-SQNR FFT Accelerators in ULP MCUs
authors: Pol Maistriaux, Jérôme Louveaux, David Bol
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Power-constrained embedded applications often execute Fast Fourier Transforms (FFT) on ultra-low-power microcontrollers (ULP MCUs). They can integrate memory-based hardware (HW) FFT accelerators, with additional silicon area being traded for energy and latency improvements. This trade-off is modulated by the radix of the FFT accelerator. Moreover, a fixed-point representation with a fixed wordlength is generally used, which limits the signal-to-quantization-noise ratio (SQNR) and requires a data scaling method to avoid overflows. Higher accelerator radices reduce the scaling method SQNR and increase its area overhead. In this work, we explore the trade-offs between energy, area, latency and SQNR in FFT accelerators integrated within ULP MCUs. An in-depth analysis is conducted based on design implementations in a 65-nm LP CMOS technology with a configurable radix from 2 to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2^{4}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. Energy and latency improvements of radix-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2^{4}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> reach a factor <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.83\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3.98\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula>, respectively. However, the logic area increases by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.14\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula>. We also propose a new scaling method, called index-encoded hierarchical block floating-point (IH-BFP). It provides the high SQNR of existing methods and relies on the deterministic access pattern of the FFT to achieve energy savings of 9.7 % and logic area savings of 32.7 %.

title: Consistent Soil Moisture and Vegetation Optical Depth from Relatively Calibrated SMOS Brightness Temperatures with SMAP
authors: Julian Chaubell, Simon Yueh, Andreas Colliander, Akiko Hayashi, Rajat Bindlish, Scott Dunbar, Dara Entekhabi, Jun Asanuma, Aaron Berg, Alisa Coffin, Michael Cosh, Gerald Flerchinger, Ann Fortuna, Chandra Holifield Collins, Taras Lychuk, José Martínez-Fernández, Kayla Moore, Zhongbo Su, Jeffrey Walker
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Soil Moisture Active Passive mission (SMAP, since 2015) from The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) and Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity mission (SMOS, since 2009) from The European Space Agency's (ESA) measure polarimetric brightness temperature (TB) at L-band (1.4 GHz). They provide estimates of surface soil moisture (SM) and L-band vegetation optical depth (L-VOD) approximately every 2-3 days at the equator, with a spatial resolution of ∼40 km for a local overpass time of 6 AM/PM. Integrating the AM and PM TB observations from SMAP and SMOS satellite missions can reduce the revisit time to about 1 day over the equator, thus helping to address fast-response hydrologic processes that cannot be addressed with the 2-3 day revisits. This will allow the capture of the SM conditions more often and hence capture the rate of decline due to drainage and recharge to groundwater. This occurs early during dry down after storms. The integration of SMOS measurements also works to fill temporal gaps caused by missing data due to SMAP instrument outages. This paper details the integration of the SMAP and SMOS observations to achieve a combined SM and L-VOD product. The SMOS TB observations interpolated to 40° incidence angle were first relatively calibrated (RC) to generate SMAP-like SMOS TB (RCTB), making the combined TB records consistent spatially and temporally. The SMAP baseline SM and L-VOD retrieval algorithm was then applied to the RCTB records. We showed that after relative calibration (ARC), the bias between the SMAP and SMOS TBs was reduced from 0.5 K to -0.03 K for TB H and from 2.6 K to 0.014 K for TB V in the AM cases. For the PM cases the mean value of differences was reduced from 0.82 K to 0.27 K and from 2.88 K to 0.19 K for TB H and TB V respectively. The comparison of the core validation sites (CVS) in-situ SM to the retrieved SM from the combined TB record showed an unbiased root-mean-square-difference of 0.039 m3/m3 for both AM and PM cases and the retrieved L-VOD demonstrated consistency with independent biomass and tree height estimates. We also showed an improvement in temporal coverage and that the global mean number of visits to each grid went up from 283 (SMAP only) to 446 (SMAP+SMOS) when both AM and PM overpasses are considered.

title: Getting Acquainted with Your LLMs: Are They Aware of Smelly Code?
authors: Zhengyi Zhuo, Yan Liu, Xindi Yang
publish: IEEE Software
abstract: Generative AI has become a new software development role, helping human developers in designing, coding, and reviewing. However, LLMs do make mistakes, and worse, they make mistakes confidently. In this article, we take a close-up examination of LLMs with symptoms of code smells. Enlightened by the data-driven approach and observable software engineering, we provide supplementary evidence and practical takeaways to help practitioners know their LLMs. Our reminder is simple: manage your context, log the AI-usage traces, and engineer observations for LLMs—because software quality rarely speaks for itself.

title: Single-Step Hardware-Aware Neural Network Quantization with Mixed Precision
authors: Jie Hu, Zhihan Zhang, Zhan Li, Qunkang Meng, Xingyu Shi, Qijun Huang, Hao Wang, Sheng Chang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: Quantization is a neural network compression technique that effectively improves the deployment performance on inference hardware. Fixed-point quantization methods use the same bit-width for all layers in the network, which leads to difficulties in balancing compression rate and accuracy loss. Therefore, mixed-precision quantization has recently been proposed. The major challenge of the mixed-precision quantization is to select the quantization bit-widths of each layer in network to simultaneously meet the requirements of minimizing accuracy loss and hardware resource consumption. In this paper, we present a Single-Step Hardware-Aware Quantization (SHQ) method. It can calculate the resource consumption of hardware such as Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) before actual deployment and find effective quantization schemes by just single step, different from common software-hardware two-step approaches with large workload and time-consuming. Genetic algorithm is combined with SHQ to search quantization schemes with low hardware resource usage and high accuracy. In addition, the correlation between hardware resource cost and qualitative indicators of proxy signal has been analyzed to bring computer-aided design insights of neural network accelerators. Experiments of full-pipeline accelerator deployment on FPGAs platforms show that our approach saves 39% of Digital Signal Processors (DSP) and 59% of Block Random Access Memory (BRAM) usage on MobileNet compared to full 8-bit quantization, while the accuracy drops by only 0.56%. The source code about our method can be found at this link: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/hujie369/SHQ</uri>.

title: Enhancing Adversarial Transferability with Cost-efficient Landscape Flattening_supp1-3664421.pdf
authors: Jingjing Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: The transferability of adversarial examples across different models has drawn considerable attention recently, particularly in targeted transferability. Prior research has empirically shown that optimizing adversarial perturbations at neighboring points with the highest loss value improves transferability. While effective, such a method requires multiple iterations to reach the local maxima and disregards the local minima of the input loss landscape. In this paper, we theoretically show that enhancing adversarial transferability is attainable by flattening the input loss landscape. This is accomplished through the perturbation optimization at both local maxima and minima. Moreover, we propose the Cost-efficient LandscapE Flattening (CLEF) attack to consider local maxima and minima around current inputs in a cost-efficient way to flatten the loss landscape and improve adversarial transferability. Specifically, we reuse the gradients of the previous attack step to assist current inputs in reaching local maxima, and employ probabilistic modeling to learn the distributional representations of perturbations that assist current inputs in reaching local minima. This probabilistic modeling can be pre-trained on dozens of images from other domains, enabling us to directly sample this type of perturbation from the pre-trained distribution when attacking. Experimental results demonstrate that integrating local maxima and minima into targeted transferable attacks can significantly flatten the loss landscape of the crafted adversarial examples, resulting in improved adversarial transferability.

title: Human or Machine? A Survey on Machine-Generated Text Detection
authors: Zainab Ahmad, Miguel Torres-Ruiz, Ahmad Mahmood, Rolando Quintero, Iqra Ameer, Necva Bölücü
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: As generative AI advances rapidly across education, research, medicine, and journalism, machine-generated text (MGT) raises questions about authenticity, ethics, and social impact. To ground this discussion, we conducted a linguistic analysis, covering phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, lexicon, and pragmatics, which uncovers robust MGT signatures, such as lower perplexity and simpler morphology. We then consolidate the state-of-the-art by reviewing 30 benchmark corpora, totaling over 4 million text samples, and 44 empirical studies, including outcomes from six major shared tasks. Detection approaches are grouped into five broad classes: classical machine learning, deep learning, transformer-based architectures, commercial AI detectors, and statistical tools. Transformer models achieve near-perfect accuracy (≈100%), while human evaluators peak at ≈77% accuracy. This survey also highlights common evaluation setups and the core performance measures used to assess model effectiveness. Future MGT detectors can become truly fair, scalable, and effective across languages and domains by expanding corpus diversity and innovating resource-efficient, adversarially robust methods.

title: IoT-Enabled Hierarchical Energy Trading for Multi-Community Sharing in the Internet of Energy
authors: Chun-Cheng Lin, Shi-Yu Zhang, Jie Lian, Der-Jiunn Deng
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the rapid advancement of the Internet of Energy (IoE), peer-to-peer energy trading has become an important mechanism for decentralized energy balancing and distribution-network relief. However, prior works have focused mainly on single platforms or isolated communities, offering limited insight into coordinated operation across multiple communities within a unified IoE ecosystem. This work proposes an IoT-enabled hierarchical trading framework that manages both intra- and inter-community energy transactions through decentralized area platforms and a central coordinating platform. A mixed-integer programming model is formulated to maximize the daily profit of energy-trading operators by optimizing household charging and discharging decisions, supported by distributed renewable generation and battery storage. The framework incorporates a dynamic IoT-driven pricing mechanism that adapts buying and selling prices using real-time measurements from smart meters and local IoE communication networks, ensuring responsive and data-driven market operation under varying conditions. Because the optimization problem is NP-complete, a simplified harmony search (SHS) algorithm is adopted to efficiently generate high-quality solutions. Experiments across 20 system configurations show that SHS outperforms several widely used metaheuristic baselines in both solution quality and run-to-run stability. Results further indicate that larger communities yield higher profits, with the maximum observed when each community contains 25 households. Eliminating the central trading platform causes a drastic reduction in operator profit, confirming its essential role in enabling scalable coordination and equitable energy allocation across heterogeneous communities. These findings highlight the effectiveness of the proposed hierarchical IoE architecture and underscore the importance of centralized coordination in next-generation smart energy systems.

title: Joint Semantic Compression and Massive MIMO Transmission for Edge Video Analytics
authors: Peng Cui, Shujun Han, Ze Liu, Yunfei Luo, Xiaodong Xu, Xiaoyu Chi, Bingxuan Xu, Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies has catalyzed widespread deployment of emerging video analytics applications, particularly in edge computing environments requiring real-time processing capabilities. However, achieving optimal trade-off between analytical accuracy and real-time performance for edge video analytics in bandwidth-constrained conditions poses a critical challenge. To address this problem, this paper proposes a joint semantic compression and massive multiple-input and multiple-output (massive-MIMO) transmission scheme for edge video analytics. Specifically, we design a task-oriented performance metric named task reliability, jointly evaluating the stochastic delay bound of intelligent task transmission and the accuracy of intelligent task execution. By optimizing pilot sequence length, pilot power, data power, and semantic compression ratio jointly, we maximize the weighted sum task reliability. Furthermore, we propose a power and semantic compression ratio allocation (PSCRA) algorithm, which utilizes maximum entropy multi-agent reinforcement learning to balance exploration and exploitation. Numerical results demonstrate that our resource allocation scheme achieves superior system utility compared to baseline methods, while the PSCRA algorithm outperforms conventional multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithms.

title: A Multi-World Synthetic Benchmark for Evaluating RSCE in Clinical Machine Learning
authors: Nattakitti Piyavechvirat, Yi-Jheng Huang, Qazi Mazhar Ul Haq
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Clinical machine learning (ML) models often achieve strong performance on clean test sets yet remain fragile at deployment, where measurement noise, hospital-specific distribution shift, surrogate-feature drift, label noise, and unstable explanations can lead to silent failure. Existing clinical ML benchmarks provide limited ability to probe these failure modes in a controlled, reproducible, and clinically interpretable manner. In particular, domain-style benchmarks (e.g., WILDS-like multi-environment evaluations) largely rely on pre-collected environments without mechanism-level control, while prior synthetic stress tests typically target only a narrow subset of stressors. We present a synthetic-first, perturbation-aware benchmarking framework that evaluates deployment-relevant model integrity along four complementary dimensions: Reliability (R), Robustness under shift (S), Calibration Stability (C), and Explainability Stability (E), combined into a composite RSCE index. The benchmark comprises seven analytically specified synthetic clinical “worlds” that emulate common deployment scenarios, ranging from clean in-distribution evaluation to hospital skew, measurement noise and missingness, surrogate corruption, strong nonlinearity, and label noise. These worlds are constructed via explicit perturbation operators with tunable severity ranges under a known structural data-generating process that inject controlled distortions while preserving an underlying physiological structure, enabling mechanism-isolating stress tests beyond domain labels alone. Using this testbed, we evaluate a diverse set of linear, tree-based, kernel, neural, and ensemble models across more than 15,000 model–world–perturbation configurations, and conduct external stress tests on NHANES and a MIMIC-IV hospital mortality cohort. The results reveal systematic trade-offs between discrimination, calibration, robustness, and explanation stability: models with similar AUROC on clean data can differ markedly in their behavior under realistic perturbations. Tree-based ensembles form a consistent integrity frontier, whereas several widely used models degrade sharply in calibration or attribution stability despite strong in-distribution performance. Integrity patterns learned from synthetic worlds transfer qualitatively to NHANES and MIMIC-IV, supporting RSCE as a practical pre-deployment screening and diagnostic tool. The proposed framework is fully reproducible and extensible, and is intended to serve as a synthetic-first reference benchmark for developing and vetting clinically trustworthy ML systems prior to large-scale real-world deployment.

title: Fashion Recommendation System Using Vision Transformers (ViT) and Graph Neural Networks (GNN)
authors: P. Srinath, P. Shilpa, P. Sarika, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Since there is a growing demand for tailored online shopping experiences, it is expected that fashion recommendation systems become indispensable for customers to be able to choose clothes that are in accordance with their style preferences. This article introduces a high-level fashion recommendation system, which uses graph neural networks (GNNs) and vision transformers (ViT) to provide recommendations, that are visually as well as contextually relevant. Vision Transformers are employed to gain the highest visual level that is deep in the clothing objects, thus they gather the intricate design elements going beyond the capability of the traditional CNN. These features are then used to establish a similarity graph where the nodes stand for the items and the edges correspond to the feature-based cosine similarity. The graph is first converted to a graph neural network, then the GNN learns the associations and the co-relations of the objects in order to give accurate recommendations. Experimental results show that the model can provide an accuracy of 92.4% in diverse fashion recommendations, thus the advantage of combining ViT and GNNs in recommendation tasks is emphasized.

title: Scaling MADDPG for Enhanced Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Arth Singh, Dhruv Dixit, Aditya Verma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Addressing multi-agent scenarios is a challenging task for traditional reinforcement learning algorithms due to the environments' dynamic nature from each agent's perspective. In this research, we delve into the performance of multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradients (MAD-DPG), a tailored algorithm for multi-agent scenarios, in the context of a cooperative navigation OpenAI environment involving three agents. Through extensive experimentation, we investigate the impact of various hyperparameters and action exploration strategies on MADDPG's performance. Moreover, we propose enhancements to MAD-DPG to overcome its main weakness, which lies in its limited scalability to more significant numbers of agents. Our findings demonstrate that MAD-DPG outperforms singleagent policy gradient approaches significantly. Furthermore, our innovative improvements to MAD-DPG effectively tackle its primary limitation, allowing the algorithm to scale more efficiently to accommodate larger numbers of agents while only minimally impacting its overall performance.

title: Blocking Analysis in Multi-Server Queues for Computer Network Performance
authors: Savita
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The paper provides a comprehensive performance analysis of a non-cyclic queuing network model with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{K}$</tex> service stations with a number of parallel servers at each. The model addresses the transfer blocking, the one that happens when a job completes its service in a particular station and tries to move to the different station only to find that it is already occupied. Here, the job remains in the home station until there is space in this case, which shows that a major impact on the functioning of the system and needs a keen modelling in order to establish an exact picture of the performance of the system. In order to address the issues that blocking generates, approximation method is applied to achieve impossible states in underlying state space to be normal. The method allows you to estimate the transfer blocking probabilities without listing all the possible system configurations. This technique allows us to estimate that such significant network performance measures as the average number of jobs at each station, the average station occupancy and the total network throughput. Different numerical tests are done on systems employing three and four service stations respectively. These case studies provide a numerical demonstration of the influence of routing probabilities, server multiplicity and network size on system performance. The findings indicate that the proposed approximation procedure is effective and also provides valuable recommendations in the design and testing of computer communication systems as well as distributed service infrastructures with a large number of multiserver queueing and blocking.

title: Attention-Based Deep Learning for Retail Sales Forecasting: A TabNet Framework with Store-Level Clustering
authors: Sachin Singh, Ikrama Dayyabu Hayatu, Utpal Dhar Das, Surya Kant Pal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Forecasting sales accurately in the retail sector still represents a tough problem because demand is complex, not linear, seasonal and promotional. This paper applied two new state-of-the-art Artificial Intelligence (AI) models, Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) and TabNet to improve daily sales forecasts using the Rossmann Store Sales datasets. Traditional models such as Decision Tree, Linear Regression, Exponential Smoothing (ETS), and SARIMAX were applied as benchmark models. A feature-engineered framework was created to include time-related, promotion-related, and competition-related variables, as well as K-Means store clustering, to capture heterogeneity at the store level. Results show that the tuned TabNet model achieved top performance (RMSE = 746.54, MAE = 524.11 and R2 = 0.94), achieving a greater prediction accuracy than all benchmark models. TabNet's attention mechanism improved interpretability by indicating which predictors are most important including variable Promo, Month, Competition Distance, and Store Cluster. Overall, we find that attention-based deep learning can provide superior predictability and interpretability with structured retail data. This research shows that TabNet could potentially be an interpretable AI forecasting framework to help improve data-driven decision-making in the retail sector.

title: Enhancing Cloud Computing Load Balancing: A Review of Machine Learning Approaches, Open Challenges, and Proposed Architecture
authors: Swetha. G, Md Oqail Ahmad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Cloud computing has emerged as an important technology. to offer scalable and flexible computing infrastructure. A distribution is the major challenge in cloud environments. is known to workloads efficiently on several servers. As load balancing. In this paper, the use of machine is analyzed learning as one of the potential solutions to this challenge by permitting. to adaptive, predictive and data-driven load management. The article proposes a model that integrates real-time. Workload forecasting, smart resource and monitoring Allocation. The model involves machine learning to help. it has dynamic task scheduling, resource allocation and. workload estimation. Despite the fact that the framework is discussed at a hypothetical level and has not yet been completely put into action, it lays. the preparation of solutions to problems such as variation of resources, equity, and overhead in the system. This research paper will be of support in the future. Studies in developing and experimental machine learning-based load. Tradeoffs that may be made to enhance the efficiency and scaling of cloud computing systems.

title: Machine Learning and NLP-Enabled Talent Recruitment and Retention Framework for Financial HR Optimization
authors: Revati Ramrao Rautrao, Suheel, Tharini Rajasingam, K. Shyam Kumar, M.R. Prakash, Patri Vasundhara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is changing talent optimization in financial Human Resources (HR), having a powerful effect on industries on a very large scale by promoting workforce efficiency, recruiting accuracy, and staff engagement. This paper introduces a new AI-based framework that combines machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and predictive analytics to automate HR processes, maximize talent recruitment, and enhance workforce planning. With the help of AI, financial HR departments can screen resumes automatically, forecast employee performance, improve retention initiatives, and offer customized career development plans. Real-time monitoring of performance and sentiment analysis also support proactive decision-making and enhanced employee satisfaction. Experimental outcomes show a 40% decrease in recruitment time, a 25% reduction in turnover, and a 30% boost in workforce productivity. The suggested AI-based system guarantees strategic talent management, allowing financial businesses to keep themselves ahead of the curve in a fast-changing digital economy. Future studies will investigate integration of AI with blockchain to offer greater transparency and security in HR functions. The model achieved an accuracy value of 90% after using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex>.

title: Student Grades Prediction and Forecast Using the Linear Regression
authors: Hardeep Singh Dhillon, Sandeep Bhatia, Jatinder Kaur, Kuldip Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: A machine learning-based model for student grade prediction employs the above-stated data, the student's current performance, and variables like attendance, study hours, homework submission, and sleep duration. Technologies that are emerging make things simple and effective by facilitating correct predictions. Since educational institutions want to enhance student scores and aid high performers to achieve their goal results, our model makes grade predictions based on essential factors like past grades, attendance, and study hours. Using the Linear Regression method, the model predicts the value of one variable from another with a model accuracy of 90.55 %. For example, the model predicted the final grade of 84.24 % for a student who studies for 6 hours a day, has a previous grade of 78 %, has completed 80 % of homework, and sleeps for 8 hours. With this model, students are able to see their predicted scores and areas for improvement, e.g., study longer hours or be regular in attending classes. We used the Linear Regression model because it is simple to implement and extensively used in business and science for forecasting and data analysis. The test data set (20 % of the data) tests the model after the training data set (80 % of the data). Observations show high precision for low to mid-range scores, although there are minor variations at the upper end, as with a student's actual grade of 100 % predicted as 90 %. The general aim is to enhance student success rates for both teachers and students.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Movie Reviews Using DistilBERT
authors: Charis Berlian, Joseph B. Adiputra, Nikita Ananda Putri Masaling, Andry Chowanda
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Sentiment analysis is a notable direction of research in natural language processing (NLP), and an extremely broad field of study that includes social media monitoring and product review classification in a wide variety of forms and models of variables. This paper discusses how modern machine-learning advances can be combined with sentiment analysis of movie reviews. Using the IMDb corpus (50,000 annotated reviews), we compare traditional machine-learning methods ( including logistic regression and support vector machines, SVMs) and more advanced transformer-based models, including DistilBERT. We use contextual embeddings, and optimise the pre-trained language models to achieve the highest possible sentiment categorisation accuracy. In our approach, we use feature-engineering aspects, such as length of review and punctuation, to increase the effectiveness of the model. The results indicate that the use of transformer-based architectures outperforms traditional ones with an accuracy of 93 % on IMDb data. This study shows the value of recent NLP methods in sentiment analysis, and it highlights the challenges involved in textual information processing with real-life textual information.

title: NLP and Explainable AI for Clinical Decision Support: A Comprehensive Review with Emerging Quantum Perspectives
authors: Dattatray Raghunath Kale, Swati Shirke-Deshmukh, Sandeep Gajanan Sutar, Abhijeet Sanjay Tadasare
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Clinical Decision Support (CDS) systems play a fundamental role in increasing healthcare distribution by providing clinicians with evidence-based perceptions for timely and precise decision-making. As healthcare data grows progressively formless and huge, Natural Language Processing (NLP) has appeared as a critical tool for extracting meaningful clinical information from electronic health records, medical literature, and patient accounts. However, the black-box nature of many NLP-driven systems increases concerns about transparency, trust, and interpretability, making Explainable AI (XAI) important for developing clinician confidence and regulatory compliance. This review provides a comprehensive investigation of the current landscape of NLP and XAI techniques in the context of Clinical Decision Support (CDS), examining their methodologies, applications, and limitations. Also, it introduces the emerging possibility of quantum computing to address the computational and scalability contests of clinical NLP, highlighting current quantum-enhanced approaches. The review also classifies noteworthy research gaps, counting the need for clinically relevant explainability, standardized evaluation frameworks, and the practical mixing of quantum tools. By creating insights across these domains, the paper summarizes a roadmap for the next generation of brainy, transparent, and scalable clinical decision support systems.

title: A Hierarchical DWD-PLRM Framework for Real-Time Autonomous Navigation in Dynamic Environments
authors: Mohammed Fallah, Lalit Sachdeva, Makhmudov Nurilla Normirza Ugli, M. Jasmin, D. Navya Narayana Kumari, A. Pushpalatha, Sh. A. Sultonova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Planning of autonomous mobile robots in unpredictable and dynamic environments in real time is a significant challenge. Conventional techniques, including A, DLite, RRT and Velocity Obstacle (VO) techniques, either assume the world is statically known or are reactive in nature. Global planners can be effective in constant conditions, but not able to preserve their approach in the shifting ones, whereas reactive local strategies such as Dynamic Window Approach (DWA) and Artificial Potential Fields (APF) are quicker but tend to create unstable or oscillating paths. Such computationally intense control methods as Model Predictive Control (MPC) also increase the load on onboard processing, restricting speed and safety. In order to overcome these drawbacks, a hierarchical hybrid path planning algorithm based on Dynamic Wavefront Decomposition (DWD), and Predictive Local Replanning Module (PLRM) is presented. DWD actively separates the environment, and calculates parallel costmaps to ensure continuity of world paths, whereas PLRM anticipates motion of obstacles, to produce smoother and adaptive local paths. Experimental findings indicate that DWD-PLRM framework decreases the time of replanning by 65.9 percent over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D^{*}$</tex>-Lite and 66 percent over A+ and still ensures latencies of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ m s}$</tex>. It has a 92 % obstacle avoidance success rate which is more than 10 times better than the existing methods. The suggested solution provides the computational efficiency, predictive, and adaptability to realtime autonomous navigation and manages the global optimality of structured planners and the flexibility of reactive systems to guarantee reliable multi-robot operations.

title: Smart Logistics Management for Electric Motorcycles
authors: David Dias, Ana Vigário, Tiago Pinto, Arsénio Reis, João Barroso
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
