abstract: The growing adoption of electric two-wheeled vehicles in urban environments demands robust digital solutions that ensure efficient, sustainable, and safe management. This work presents a digital platform designed for the logistics management of electric motorcycles in urban settings, integrating features such as real-time monitoring, task planning, preventive maintenance, and communication with riders. The solution is built on a modular and scalable architecture, featuring an adaptive, user-centered frontend, a RESTful API-based backend, and a web-based management interface. The frontend, implemented on the motorcycles’ displays, presents only essential information, promoting safer and more effective riding. The management interface encompasses a wide range of functionalities necessary to ensure service efficiency and effectiveness, as well as the optimal preservation of the vehicles, without neglecting the well-being of the drivers. Integration with IoT technologies allows for failure prediction and proactive intervention. Developed within the scope of the A-MoVeR Agenda, the platform addresses the challenges of urban electric mobility by enabling smarter, more efficient, and more sustainable operations, directly impacting operational cost reduction and enhancing the overall user experience.

title: Stability Assessment of HVDC Transmission System Utilizing Hybrid DR-MMC Converter in Sending-Terminal
authors: Yuechao Jin, Li Xiong, Qi Zhang, Xudong Huang, Bin Hu, Heng Nian
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The hybrid converter consisting of diode rectifier and modular multilevel converter (DR-MMC) offers cost-effective integration for offshore wind farm (OWF) in High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) transmission system, and requires a comprehensive stability assessment. Therefore, this paper establishes the impedance model to assess the stability of the sending-terminal while the receiving-terminal converter is simplified as a constant DC voltage source. The frequency sweep verification shows excellent agreement with impedance derivation, validating modeling accuracy. Based on the impedance model, the sub/super-synchronous oscillations (SSSOs) in sending-terminal are studied and the calculated oscillation frequencies are corroborated by time-domain simulation analysis. Moreover, the simplified impedance model which disregards MMC’s DC dynamics is compared with the comprehensive impedance model, indictaing the simplified model may lead to erroneous stability assessment for the sending-terminal system.

title: Counterfactual Adversarial Learning for Fair LLM Recommenders
authors: Xiangwei Wang, Haolong Xiang, Hongsheng Dong, Xiaolong Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have driven transformative advancements in recommender systems through their superior semantic understanding and logical reasoning capabilities. However, the fairness risks embedded in implicit feedback within LLM-based Recommender Systems (LRS) remain understudied—recommendation homogeneity induced by similar behavioral patterns may amplify societal biases, leading to systematic marginalization of disadvantaged groups. To address this challenge, we propose a fairness enhancement framework integrating counterfactual reasoning and dynamic adversarial learning. By constructing counterfactual text intervention scenarios, we uncover implicit causal dependencies between user-sensitive attributes and recommendation decisions. Furthermore, we design a hierarchical gradient blocking mechanism that adaptively suppresses sensitive information propagation pathways during adversarial training, achieving balanced optimization between recommendation fairness and utility. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework effectively mitigates implicit feedback bias at both group and individual levels across multiple benchmarks, significantly improving recommendation equity while maintaining personalized recommendation quality. This study establishes a novel paradigm for LRS that harmonizes semantic understanding with fairness constraints, paving new avenues for ethical alignment in generative recommendation system.

title: The Dual-System Hierarchical Architecture: A Future Paradigm for Vision-Language-Action Models
authors: Wenlong Chen, Zhen Tian, Zhou Zhou, Youhua Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: With the breakthroughs of deep learning and large-scale pre-trained models in the fields of natural language processing (NLP) and computer vision (CV), Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have opened up new opportunities for the development of embodied intelligence. This paper first reviews the limitations of traditional robotic manipulation methods—specifically, their heavy reliance on precise environmental modeling and the scarcity of training data—and explores the potential advantages of end-to-end large models for robotic control. We systematically categorize existing VLA approaches into four major classes: classic Transformer-based architectures, diffusion model-based methods, autoregressive prediction methods leveraging pre-trained large language models (LLM) or vision-language models (VLM), and hierarchical hybrid architectures that integrate LLM with specialized action experts. We highlight the architectural characteristics, strengths, and limitations of each category, trace the trend from monolithic end-to-end systems to layered dual-system designs, and propose key future research directions, including multimodal integration, expert routing mechanisms, and adaptive subtask decomposition for open-world scenarios.

title: FDTD Electromagnetic Simulation of Electrically Steerable Phased Patch Antenna Array
authors: Tangus Koech
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: An Electrically Steerable Passive Array Radiator (ESPAR) is presented. Passive patch antennas are reactively loaded using varactor diodes and the phase shift induced by the change in the varactor capacitance causes a shift in the directivity of the main lobe of the antenna array. The steering effect is induced electrically and the increase in directivity is caused by the mutual coupling of the microstrip patch antennas. A nine ($3 \times 3$ cell) patch antenna array is simulated and the far field radiation pattern and directivity is shown. A Chebyshev steppedimpedance feedline is presented to provide sidelobe suppression for multi-antenna patch arrays. The use of microstrip enables the ESPAR antenna to be easily manufactured using a PCB etching process, incorporated into a PCB Surface Mount Technology (SMT) assembly, and easily miniaturized into an embedded system. Microstrip fabricated ESPARs present a low-to-medium microwave frequency alternative to Antenna-in-Package (AiP) antennas - the latter of which requires a semiconductor lithographic and packaging process but is more suited to higher microwave and terahertz frequencies. The antenna array presented operates in the ISM band with a center frequency of 2.436 GHz.

title: Explainable Machine Learning for Preoperative Prediction of Tumor Focality in Thyroid Cancer Using Lifestyle and Clinical Examination Data
authors: Hasan Ahamed Alif, Md. Jisan Mashrafi, Sebagat Selim, Urmi Haldar, Ahsan Ullah, Rana Das
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Multifocal thyroid carcinoma is tougher to anticipate before surgery, especially in regions with low resources, even though it is more likely to recur and needs more competent surgical planning. In order to tackle this problem, the proposed research would construct an interpretable machine learning model that could predict tumor focality (unifocal vs. multifocal) using only non-invasive preoperative clinical and lifestyle data. Three hundred eighty-three patients were employed as a balanced sample set for training the classifiers XGBoost, Random Forest, and Logistic Regression. Logistic Regression was the best model when compared to other models, with the most excellent recall (70.4) and ROC-AUC (0.726), both of which were substantially different (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}<0.05$</tex>). The HAP-based analysis found that the most relevant predictors were age, smoking history, and physical examination. The concept may be applied in outpatient clinical settings as it is straightforward to learn, particularly in institutions without access to histology or imaging. This paper indicates that tumor focality is foreseeable using easily accessible data, enabling a trustworthy decision-support tool for early treatment planning in the treatment of thyroid cancer.

title: Lifetime Prediction of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell System Under Integration of Gaussian Process Regression with Bayesian Optimization
authors: Shuangfei Xie, Wang Han, Zhicheng Qi, Jingjia Hu, Hongmin Liu, Xiting Yuan, Erting Wu, Zhiguang Hua
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Predicting the remaining useful life (RUL) of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is critical for their stable operation and industrial application. However, due to the strong nonlinearity of the aging process and complex operating conditions, traditional life prediction methods struggle to balance prediction accuracy with computational real-time performance. To address the issues of PEMFCs lifespan prediction, this paper proposes an aging prediction model based on a Gaussian Process Regression (GPR)-enhanced Bayesian Optimization (GPR+BO). Experimental results under different training set ratios (400h, 450h, 500h, 550h, 600h, 650h, 700h, 750h and 750h) using datasets from various operating conditions demonstrate that the GPR+BO model can accurately track aging trends under both steady-state and dynamic conditions, exhibiting good prediction accuracy and robustness. Compared to the traditional Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) model, in steady-state conditions, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) is reduced by up to 48.06%, and the Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) is reduced by up to 46.22%. Compared to the traditional GPR model, in steady-state conditions, the RMSE of GPR+BO is reduced by up to 53.36%, and the MAPE is reduced by up to 32.68%. Compared to the traditional LSTM model, in quasi-dynamic-state conditions, the RMSE is reduced by up to 28.95%, and the MAPE is reduced by up to 36.66%. Compared to the traditional GPR model, in quasi-dynamic-state conditions, the RMSE is reduced by up to 30.33%, and the MAPE is reduced by up to 33.54%.

title: Controlling the Attenuation Slope in a Rectangular Waveguide Partially Filled with an Absorber: Application to the Design of Attenuators
authors: Mohammad Kahtany, Gaëtan Michot, Norbert Parker, Vincent Laur
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper aims to show how attenuation slope can be controlled in a rectangular waveguide partially filled with an absorber. The physical principle is based on the excitation of longitudinal section magnetic modes in waveguides containing H-plane slabs of lossy dielectrics that gives rise to non-monotonic evolution of attenuation as a function of the filling factor. In this paper, it will be shown that the attenuation frequency slope over the frequency band can be controlled (positive, null or negative) as a function of the filling factor. This phenomenon will be applied to design a 10 dB attenuator in the X-band.

title: AI-powered Muscle Tracking Genie
authors: Vanchhit Khare, Sujay Shrivastava
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This work presents an artificial intelligence-based muscle tracking system that measures and visualizes muscle changes both before and after training sessions. To record photos of certain muscle groups both before and after exercise, the technology uses a mesh grid and a smart mirror with computer vision. Then, with an eye toward the degree of stretching and contraction, it evaluates every grid cell for changes in the muscle. The ensuing visual feedback lets users clearly see which muscles have been used and how they have responded to the workout, helping them to track their development over time and modify their training plans.

title: AI-Powered Data Analytics for IoT Systems: A Review on Efficient Processing at the Edge and Beyond
authors: Vivek Lakshman Bhargav Sunkara
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies has led to a surge in real-time data generation across diverse sectors, including smart cities, healthcare, and industrial automation. This continuous influx of data demands low-latency, energy-efficient, and context-aware analytics, which traditional cloud-centric approaches struggle to deliver due to bandwidth, privacy, and responsiveness limitations. To address these challenges, the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) at the edge and near-edge layers has emerged as a transformative solution. This paper presents a comprehensive review of AI-powered data analytics architectures for IoT systems, focusing on efficient processing strategies at the edge, fog, and hybrid layers. The study evaluates various AI techniques, such as TinyML, federated learning (FL), and collaborative inference, and compares architectural paradigms in terms of latency, energy consumption, scalability, and model adaptability. Experimental insights, algorithmic models, and visual comparisons are used to highlight trade-offs and deployment scenarios. The review concludes by identifying open challenges and proposing future research directions aimed at enhancing the robustness, interoperability, and sustainability of AI-driven IoT analytics.

title: Autonomous Security Orchestration for Cloud-Native Environments Using Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Venkata Thej Deep Jakkaraju, Naga Subrahmanyam Cherukupalle, Vijay Mane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: With cloud-native settings becoming more complicated due to microservices and using multiple clouds, organizations now need security solutions that can work smartly, independently and grow as needed. This paper introduces a new way of using MAS and DRL to allow autonomous security orchestration in cloud-native architectures. Dynamic access graph and agent-based architecture in the proposed system make threat detection, policy adjustments and searching for secure services possible. We tested out many agent ideas in multiple cloud environments by monitoring results using accuracy in detection, response time, consistent policies and false alerts. MAS-based security orchestration performs better than old methods of security, increasing detection success by 12% and lowering average response time by 58%. This design approach helps the system grow, withstand different issues and cope smoothly with moving threats. Besides offering a detailed security model, this paper prepares the way for future cloud-native defense systems to include federated learning, distributed trust models and hybrid DRL strategies. It shows that autonomous multi-agent orchestration has the ability to influence cloud security methods in the AI-driven age of cyber threat.

title: Design and Implementation of an AI-Based Automatic Plastic Waste Sorting System
authors: M. A. BEN Aissa, H. Kharroubi, S. Boukara, I. Aitigrine, H. Moulai
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an intelligent plastic waste sorting system that integrates computer vision, robotics, and a graphical user interface (GUI) for real-time supervision. The system employs the YOLOv8 (You Only Look Once) deep learning model for the detection and classification of seven plastic categories: PET, HDPE, single-use plastics, single-layer plastics, multi-layer plastics, squeeze tubes, and UHT boxes. A robotic manipulator (EEZYbotARM Mk2), controlled by an STM32F446RE microcontroller, performs automated pick-and-place operations based on the detection results. A custom PyQt5 GUI provides live video streaming, detection zones and results, category counters, and features such as counter reset, detection filtering, and export of detection history to Excel. The system was validated on a conveyor-based setup, demonstrating accurate detection, reliable robotic sorting and an intuitive user interface. This work addresses the limited development of plastic recycling in emerging countries, highlighting a feasible and efficient solution to improve plastic waste management.

title: Toward Emotion-Aware and Personality-Driven Mental Health Chatbots Using Large Language Models
authors: Fina Keiza Arismana, Rizka Wakhidatus Sholikah, Raden Venantius Hari Ginardi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Mental health issues have become a major global concern, with reports from the World Health Organization (WHO) indicating a significant rise in mental disorder cases, particularly among university students. Stigma, financial limitations, and lack of information are key barriers to accessing professional mental health services. This research proposes the development of a mental health chatbot based on a Large Language Model (LLM) capable of providing empathetic responses by considering users’ emotions and personality types. The system integrates LLaMA 3 for conversational capabilities, RoBERTa for emotion detection, and a rule-based MBTI test using the Forward Chaining approach. The chatbot is session-based, capable of saving conversation histories and automatically generating conversation summaries to support professional counseling sessions. Results indicate that the system can generate contextually appropriate responses, with an emotion detection accuracy of 97% and an average accuracy BERTScore-F1 for model chatbot of 87%.

title: Four Spiral Resonator Compact Diplexer with Improved Out-of-Band Rejection for the Coexistence of 5G Applications
authors: Stefano Maddio, Giacomo Giannetti, Giovanni Lasagni, Marco Badii, Monica Righini, Stefano Selleri, Giovanni Collodi, Alessandro Cidronali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: A diplexer with two channels and two resonators per channel is presented. A new arrangement for the resonators is proposed. The geometry of the resonators is based on two kinds of spiral shapes corresponding to two different filtering behaviors: open spirals (low pass) and etched spirals (high pass). To show the effectiveness of the design, a prototype is realized for $\mathbf{5 G}$ applications. The prototype works at $2.26 \mathbf{~ G H z}$ and $3.59 \mathbf{~ G H z}$ and at the lower [higher] frequency channel is characterized by a return loss of $13.4 \mathbf{d B}[15.0 \mathbf{d B}]$, an IL of $1.1 \mathbf{d B}[1.2 \mathbf{~ d B}]$, an isolation of $34.2 \mathbf{~ d B}$ [$38.2 \mathbf{~ d B}$], and a fractional bandwidth of 39.7% [7.5%]. The active area is $19.5 \mathrm{~mm} \times 25 \mathrm{~mm}$. Out-of-band rejection is $-41 \mathbf{d B}$ and $-37 \mathbf{~ d B}$ for the lower and higher channels, respectively. The ratio between out-of-band rejection and occupied area is one of the highest among previously published diplexers using the same technology.

title: Deep Learning-Based Sign Language Communication System with Multi-Language Support
authors: Pranathi Hegde, Sanjana N, Nidhi N P, Bhanu M, Sahana P Shankar
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Speech impairment is regarded as one of the significant disabilities. When it comes to communicating with others, people with this limitation employ sign language. However, individuals with speech disabilities are unable to communicate with those who do not understand sign language. Therefore, our initiative aims to bridge this communication gap. The primary goal of this work is to develop a vision-based system that can recognise sign language motions in real-time and provide translation in multiple languages. We trained a CNN model on both spatial and temporal features present in real-time video sequences, achieving an accuracy of 97.5%. For multilingual translation, we employed the T5 transformer, achieving an average BLEU score of 0.193, ROUGE-L score of 0.038, and 0.224 seconds per sentence for English-to-Hindi, and a BLEU score of 0.048, ROUGE-L score of 0.022, and 0.434 seconds per sentence for English-to-Kannada translation.

title: Benefit Allocation Method for Integrated Energy System Alliances Based on Alternating Bidding Game
authors: Yubo Fan, Shi Yan, Jing Liu, Jie Xu, Chen Ren, Yuchen Wang, Runyang Wang, Daogang Peng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Within the master-slave game framework, operators can optimize system economics through rational guidance. However, as the autonomy of diverse entities in energy markets grows, the traditional "leader-follower" relationship increasingly struggles to fully unleash the potential of all participants. It may even trigger cooperative conflicts due to uneven benefit distribution. To address this, this paper constructs a system-wide cooperative alliance encompassing the Integrated energy system Operator (IESO), Integrated energy system Aggregator (IESA), and diverse user loads. It introduces a dynamic alternating bidding game mechanism based on peer-to-peer (P2P) architecture. Within this framework, the game dynamics undergo a fundamental shift: participants engage in multiple rounds of bidding and response on an equal footing, gradually converging toward optimal allocation strategies through bilateral negotiations. This process ultimately achieves equilibrium between individual rationality and collective optimality, maximizing the system's total surplus. To validate the proposed model's effectiveness, this chapter conducts a case study based on real-world energy system data. Simulation results demonstrate that the constructed P2P dynamic game mechanism not only enhances overall system economic efficiency but also effectively stimulates participation enthusiasm among diverse entities while ensuring allocation fairness. This provides theoretical foundations and methodological support for the collaborative optimization of new energy systems.

title: InterQ: a Job Interview Training Platform Using Facial Expression Detection and Answer Scoring
authors: Yoshiven Boer, Amelia Cantika Permatasari, Kevin Kevin, Gabriel Asael Tarigan, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Unemployment in Indonesia remains a pressing issue, with 7.86 million individuals recorded as unemployed in 2023, including 5.32 percent in the open unemployment category. Many fresh graduates fail at the interview stage due to low confidence and limited preparation. Existing training tools provide general practice but lack integrated, data-driven feedback on both verbal and non-verbal performance. This study introduces InterQ, a web-based platform that combines facial expression analysis using ResEmoteNet and Haar Cascade with automated answer grading through Whisper transcription and E5-small embeddings. The models were validated on FER-2013 and synthetic Q&A datasets, achieving average F1-scores of 0.747 and 0.706. A usability study with 50 participants using a validated questionnaire showed that 80.4 percent felt more confident and better prepared for real interviews. These findings highlight InterQ’s novelty as a multi-modal AI simulator and its potential to address interview challenges faced by Indonesian job seekers.

title: Active Probe Based NTP Vulnerability Detection
authors: Weiping Zhu, Yilun Liu, Xuanbing Li, Xianfeng Dai, Chao Ma, Chuanhe Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Reliable network time synchronization supports many critical applications such as finance, telecommunications, and distributed computing. Yet, the widely deployed Network Time Protocol (NTP) still contains vulnerabilities that enable reflection-amplification attacks, timestamp manipulation, and daemon-level denial of service. This paper presents an active detection approach leveraging high-concurrency scanning and cloud load balancing to evaluate these vulnerabilities across the entire public IPv4 address space.Our results indicate thousands of vulnerable NTP servers exposed to DDoS amplification and time integrity risks. Finally, we analyze operational impacts and highlight effective mitigation strategies, including restrictive ACL configurations, timely software updates, and broader adoption of Network Time Security (NTS).

title: Heart Attack and Cardiac Arrest Predictor: Data-Driven Approach
authors: Shivam Mani Tripathi, Shivank Kushwaha, Shubhra Divyadarshini, Shreyash Srivastava
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease remains one of the major causes of death worldwide, and recognising early signs of cardiac weakness is still a difficult task for doctors and patients alike. In this project, health information from individuals is collected to estimate the probability of a heart attack or cardiac arrest. The data is processed through supervised learning techniques, which include cleaning and preprocessing to ensure reliable input for the prediction model. Among the tested algorithms, Gradient Boosting offered the most balanced performance in terms of accuracy and recall on the selected dataset. To protect sensitive medical information during deployment, secure access control is used so that patient records can be viewed only by authorised users. The system generates both a risk score and a confidence score, helping in the early identification of high-risk cases and supporting timely medical intervention.

title: Solving Optimal Power Flow Using Enhanced Dung Beetle Optimization Algorithm
authors: Ravi Kumar Avvari, Lakshminarayana Gadupudi, Anil Kumar Annamraju, Nareddy Nageswara Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In this paper, an enhanced dung beetle optimization (EDBO) method is suggested for the solution of optimal power flow (OPF) problem. The EDBO method draws inspiration from the reproductive, ball-rolling, dancing, foraging, and thieving behaviours exhibited by dung beetles. By considering both local and global exploitation, the proposed method possesses the qualities of a rapid convergence rate and adequate solution precision. Along with equality and inequality constraints, the total generation cost, emission, active power loss, and magnitude of voltage deviation are considered as objectives in this paper. The efficacy of the proposed method is evaluated utilising the IEEE 30bus system. This paper employs a penalty-based constraint handling approach to effectively handle equality and inequality constraints inherent in the OPF issue. The outcomes obtained by the EDBO are contrasted with the basic dung beetle optimization (DBO), artificial hummingbird algorithm (AHA), and grey wolf optimization (GWO) algorithms. From results it is evident that the EDBO exhibits superior performance with regard to convergence rate, solution accuracy, and stability as compared to other algorithms.

title: Automated Preprocessing and Deep Learning for Non-Invasive Anemia Estimation Using Conjunctival Images
authors: AparnaRajesh Atmakuri, G.Siprarani Patra, Gayatri Sahu, Ashutosh Tripathy, Trilochan Rout, Sunita Padhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Anemia remains a major global health challenge, particularly in under-resourced settings where access to laboratory testing is limited. Non-invasive detection methods using computer vision provide a scalable alternative, but many existing approaches either rely on full-face analysis, require manual preprocessing, or depend on computationally heavy architectures unsuitable for real-world deployment. In this work, we propose ConjAnNet, a two-stage deep learning framework that combines U-Net-based segmentation of the conjunctiva with MobileViT for anemia classification. This end-to-end pipeline ensures clinically guided feature extraction and enables deployment on mobile and edge devices. Experimental evaluation on a balanced dataset of conjunctival images from Kaggle demonstrates strong performance, achieving a Dice coefficient of 0.8612 and IoU of 0.7815 for segmentation, and $96.5 \%$ accuracy with an ROC-AUC of 0.987 for classification outperforming baseline CNN and MobileNet models. While these results highlight the potential of conjunctiva-specific analysis for automated anemia screening, the dataset’s lack of demographic diversity and acquisition details represents a limitation. Future work will focus on validation with clinically acquired, diverse datasets and extension toward multiclass anemia grading.

title: Enhancing Autonomous Vehicle Security: An Adaptive CAN Bus Testbed Architecture
authors: Bastien Morantin, Robin Hatier, Tarek Ould-Bachir, Nora Boulahia-Cuppens, Frédéric Cuppens
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper introduces a versatile CAN Bus testbed to enhance autonomous vehicle security. Our testbed offers significant flexibility by easily creating new datasets from DBC files through random value generation, supporting diverse usage scenarios beyond pre-established logs. The automatic API generation from DBC files allows quick adaptations for different vehicles, while our system supports comprehensive CAN Bus protocols, including Extended IDs, with minimal delay and packet loss. The testbed stands out with its low deployment cost, using an inexpensive USB CAN interface. Our innovative approach also facilitates the integration of various attack scenarios, such as DoS, Flooding, Fuzzing, Replay, and Suspension, without additional hardware costs. With up to eleven nodes in simulation, the testbed effectively supports comprehensive research without constraints from physical transmission arbitration. This work highlights the feasibility and benefits of a low-cost, flexible, and adaptive CAN Bus testbed for advancing autonomous vehicle security research.

title: Accelerating Arithmetic: A Novel Approach to Ladner-Fischer Adder Design
authors: Sornalakshmi M, Sakthimohan M, M. Thenmozhi, Elizabeth Rani G, Karthigadevi K, Sanjeevi Kumar V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The given research paper presents a new paradigm in the implementation of a 32-bit Ladner-Fischer adder, aimed at achieving the best results regarding performance parameters. A 32 -bit Ladner-Fischer adder was synthesized and implemented with Xilinx ISE tool with a Spartan 3 family FPGA (xc3s1000) in mind. The resultant implementation provided a highly reduced propagation delay which is crucial in high-speed arithmetic operations. The design reflected an overall delay of 25.627 ns, of which 12.870 ns and 12.757 ns was the logic and the routing delay respectively. The use of hardware adoption made use of minimal target device footprint. The architecture used only 95 slices or 7680 and 1674 input LUTs or 15360, or 1% of each. Power consumption of the design also was a first order consideration. The total electric power load on-chip was measured to be 0.098 W, most of which is the static (quiescent) power and the dynamic power consumption was insignificant. The sparseness of the resources used and the little value of power consumption together with the speed at which it works renders this new-fangled way of the Ladner-Fischer adder design very efficient. The study offers a good reference point on further studies in optimizing high-speed arithmetic circuits in resource-constrained embedded systems.

title: Hybrid Pinching Antenna Systems: Architecture and Beamforming Design
authors: Kangjian Chen, Chenhao Qi, Octavia A. Dobre, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Pinching antennas (PAs), a special class of leaky-wave antennas (LWAs), have recently emerged as a promising technology to mitigate blockage and reduce large-scale path loss. However, PAs suffer from performance limitations due to their passive radiation characteristics and mechanical actuation. To overcome these limitations, we introduce reconfigurable LWAs (RLWAs), which enable RLWA beamforming through electronic control of both radiation amplitudes and phases. By integrating RLWAs into the existing PA systems (PASS), we propose a hybrid PASS (H-PASS) architecture, which combines mechanically reconfigurable PA beamforming with electronically reconfigurable RLWA beamforming. Given that PAs in H-PASS can be deployed in discrete-position or continuous-position manners, H-PASS comes in two variants accordingly, and we formulate weighted sum-rate maximization problems for them, respectively. For the discrete-position case, we propose a penalty-based two-loop joint analog and digital beamforming algorithm. For the continuous-position case, we propose an alternating-minimization-based joint position optimization and beamforming algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that H-PASS can increase the sum-rate of the existing PASS by up to 33%, reduce the performance loss caused by phase quantization in discrete-position PAs by up to 69%, and mitigate the performance loss caused by position errors in continuous-position PAs by up to 90%. Overall, H-PASS significantly improves the performance of existing PASS by leveraging the strengths of RLWAs while mitigating the limitations of PAs.

title: A Systematic Analysis of Object Detection Approaches in Images: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Nishu Bansal, Sonali Dash, Kushwant Kaur, Deepanshu Garg
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Object detection is considered as detection of an object that appears in an image or video. This system helps in identifying and classifying the objects present, such as whether the object is a car, person, dog, etc. A human brain can efficiently perform this task and does not require much time and processing, but it is not the same case for a machine. A machine requires much time and data processing to identify what object is present. In order to detect an object inside the image, there are various ways to achieve using computer vision techniques. Although there have been a large number of studies that thoroughly explored various types of methods for object detection. Here, this article compares four mainstream object detection models to detect objects inside an image tracing the evolution from traditional machine learning-based methods to contemporary deep learningdriven approaches. The analysis is drawn based on different published literature for machine learning and deep learning based techniques. This review attempts to assist academics and practitioners in choosing and developing object detection methods for various application domains by providing critical analysis and comparative insights.

title: A Novel Multifunctional Filtering Leaky Wave Antenna in Substrate Integrated Waveguide Technology
authors: Neema S. Joseph, Gowrish Basavarajappa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel multifunctional filtering leaky wave antenna implemented in substrate integrated waveguide technology. In-addition to filtering response, the proposed antenna exhibits a beam scanning range of 60 degrees from broadside to end-fire direction over a frequency range from 3.4 GHz to 3.6 GHz. The proposed filtering antenna basically incorporates periodic longitudinal slots on the broad wall of each resonator in an iris coupled bandpass filter. Transition to microstrip technology is adopted at the input and output ports. To verify the proposed concept, a filtering leaky wave antenna is designed, simulated and fabricated at a center frequency of 3.5 GHz. The measured return loss is better than 15 dB in the entire frequency range with a peak realized gain of 7.5 dBi. The scanning rate of the proposed filtering leaky wave antenna is 10.5 degree per percentage which is considerably higher than conventional SIW based leaky wave antenna.

title: Cross-Modal Mixup Enhance Foundation Model Adaptation for Few-Shot Learning
authors: Jiuqian Dai, Zhenyan Ji, Zechang Xiong, Jiqiang Liu, Shen Yin, Huihui Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In few-shot learning, adapting foundation models has emerged as a powerful approach to bridge the gap between limited task-specific data and the rich knowledge encoded in pre-trained models. Existing adaptation methods based on CLIP primarily focus on improving the network architecture to enhance the learning ability, which has been proven to cause overfitting and reduce generalizability, but overlook the influence of data augmentation. In this work, we first analyze the differences between our work and previous work from the perspective of probability theory. Then, we concentrate on data augmentation and propose innovative Cross-Modal Mixup methods designed to enhance the model's cross-modal reasoning and classification capabilities, as well as its overall generalization. Specifically, based on dimensions match or not, the Cross-Modal Mixup methods comprise two forms: Cross Mixup (CM) for data augmentation with features of the same dimension, and Cross Expand Mixup (CEM) with features of different dimensions. Extensive experiments have demonstrated the effectiveness of our CM and CEM.

title: A Power System Operating State Prediction Model Integrating Big Data Analytics
authors: Qiuchen Li, Zhongyu Ma, Zhaoxing Chen, Yisheng Fang, Yanan Meng, Yu Yin
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the integration of renewable energy sources (RES), electric vehicles (EVs), and smart loads, modern power systems are evolving into complex, multi-source data-driven systems. Accurate prediction of operating states (e.g., voltage magnitude, frequency, active/reactive power flow) is critical for ensuring grid stability, optimizing dispatch, and reducing outage risks. However, traditional prediction models (e.g., ARIMA, support vector machines) struggle to handle the high-dimensional, time-varying, and heterogeneous nature of big data generated by smart meters, phasor measurement units (PMUs), and RES. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Hybrid Big Data-Driven Prediction Model (HBDPM) that integrates Spark-based big data preprocessing, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) with an Attention Mechanism (AM) for feature extraction and prediction, and a Bayesian Optimization (BO) module for hyperparameter tuning. The HBDPM first processes multi-source data (including historical operating data, meteorological data, and RES output data) via Spark to eliminate noise, fill missing values, and normalize features. Then, the CNN layer captures spatial correlations between grid nodes, while the GRU layer models temporal dependencies of time-series data; the AM adaptively emphasizes critical features (e.g., peak load periods, sudden RES fluctuations). Finally, BO optimizes key hyperparameters (e.g., CNN filter size, GRU hidden units) to enhance model generalization. Experimental validation is conducted on two datasets: the IEEE 30-bus system (simulated data) and real-world data from a 110 kV regional grid in Jiangsu, China. Compared with benchmark models (ARIMA, single LSTM, CNN-GRU without AM), the HBDPM reduces the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 8. 2 \%} - \text{3 2. 7 \%}$</tex> and the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 9. 5 \% - 3 4. 1 \%}$</tex> for voltage and frequency prediction. The results demonstrate that the proposed model effectively leverages big data analytics to improve prediction accuracy and robustness, providing a reliable tool for power system dispatch and stability control.

title: Enhancing Wind Speed and Power Forecasting Accuracy Using Machine Learning Techniques: A Case Study of Jaisalmer Wind Park, India
authors: Raja Owais Ahmad, Aparna Unni, Manjeet Singh, Ravi Sharma, Mohd Abuzar Sayeed, Sunil K Singla
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a detailed investigation into the effectiveness of various machine learning (ML) techniques for forecasting wind speed and power, specifically focusing on the Jaisalmer Wind Park located in Rajasthan, India. The study evaluates linear regression (LR), decision tree regression (DTR), Gaussian process regression (GPR), and artificial neural networks (ANNs) using data from January 2018 to April 2024. The methodologies applied include comprehensive data preprocessing, parameter optimization, and performance evaluation metrics such as mean absolute percentage error and coefficient of determination. The findings aim to enhance the predictive accuracy of wind speed and power forecasts, thereby supporting the integration of renewable energy into the power grid and advancing sustainable energy practices. The research utilizes MATLAB's regression tools for analysis, emphasizing the potential of ML techniques to improve the operational efficiency of wind farms and facilitate a transition towards more sustainable energy systems

title: Comparative Analysis of Energy Storage Revenues in Provincial and Regional Electricity Markets
authors: Fei Guo, Wei Liu, Guangde Dong, Qiangqiang Liu, Pei Yong, Juan Yu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The uncertainty and volatility of renewable energy sources have intensified the demand for operational flexibility of power systems. Energy storage systems (ESS) have become vital in addressing these challenges due to their rapid response capabilities. However, their high capital costs and uncertain profitability necessitate a deeper understanding of their economic behavior under different coordination frameworks. The coordinated optimization models are developed to investigate the impact of the ESS operational revenues under provincial and regional electricity markets. The results indicate that regional coordination enhances overall power system flexibility but simultaneously reduces the scarcity of flexibility resources. This reduction in scarcity decreases the marginal value of flexibility services, leading to lower ESS revenues relative to localized operation. Therefore, price signals reflecting flexibility contribution should be designed to maintain investment incentives for the ESS.

title: Comparative Analysis of Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Processing Methods for Eye Color Prediction
authors: Anggun Winursito, Risanuri Hidayat, Igi Ardiyanto
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Significant challenges in genotype-based phenotype prediction systems remain because the relationship between Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) and phenotypes (especially eye color) is highly complex and polygenic. The success of eye color prediction from genomic data is strongly influenced by the choice of algorithms and how the genotypes are encoded. This study was conducted by comparing six classification algorithms (Histogram Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Machine, Extra Trees, Random Forest, and Logistic Regression K-Nearest Neighbors) and five SNP encoding schemes (additive, dominant, recessive, additive+dominant, and one-hot genotyping). The dataset used was obtained from a source validated in related studies and consisted of 456 multipopulation subjects. The dataset used 17 SNP features with three eye color phenotype classes (blue, brown, and intermediate). The main metrics used were balanced accuracy and macro F1, as well as accuracy and ROC-AUC OvR. To ensure biological consistency, features were restricted to a specific panel of SNPs associated with eye color. This study contributes to the selection of classification algorithms and encoding methods that have varying degrees of suitability in predicting eye color. Histogram Gradient Boosting showed the best accuracy with a value of 0.913. Analysis of the encoder methods showed that the additive, dominant, and additive+dominance methods performed well and consistently in predicting eye color. Meanwhile, the one-hot recessive and genotype methods showed low performance (accuracy ~0.42–0.46) due to overly stringent assumptions and dimensionality jumps. Feature/coefficient importance analysis aligned with known pigment loci associated with eye color.

title: Transaction fraud detection algorithm based on graph neural network and user behavior
authors: Yu Zhang, Li Ruan, Limin Xiao, Jianyu Qu, Cong Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: With the diversity of transaction forms continue to rise, and transaction fraud is increasingly widespread. The traditional way to deal with transaction fraud depends on the rule system and manual verification, which is not only inefficient, but also difficult to cope with complex and changeable fraud routines.This paper proposes an improved GraphSAGE network based on multilateral types, integrating the attention mechanism of multilateral types and high-order graph convolution. The multi-head edge type attention mechanism can dynamically adjust the aggregate weight of neighbor node information according to the edge type, so as to capture the differential contribution of different edge types to the node representation. The higher-order graph convolution operation can capture more distant dependencies in the graph. In order to enhance the interpretability of the model, this paper also introduces the SHAP value analysis method to explain the basis of the model prediction results. Experimental data show that the improved GraphSAGE network has excellent performance and higher AUC than the traditional method.The research results of this paper are expected to be promoted and applied in more fields, such as the access scenario of aggregation chain.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Scheduling Method for Power Systems Considering Transmission Limits and Transient Security Constraints
authors: Xinwei Li, Qiang Zhang, Qi Jia, Jifeng Cheng, Xiangxu Wang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: To address the challenges of transient security and transmission corridor overload in large-scale power system dispatch, this paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning-based scheduling method that integrates critical corridor constraints with transient security constraints. The proposed method incorporates a fast-converging twin-delayed deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm for transient security optimal dispatch (DDPG-TSOD) to enhance training efficiency and policy stability. By embedding critical corridor flow rewards and overload penalties into the scheduling objective function, the agent can actively recognize and avoid the risk of corridor flow violations during the learning process. Moreover, prioritized replay of failure samples and a two-stage training strategy are employed to improve sample utilization, thereby accelerating convergence and reducing reward fluctuations. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, comparative experiments with different ablation configurations were conducted on the IEEE-39 standard test system under a three-phase short-circuit fault. The results demonstrate that the combination of DDPG-TSOD with corridor rewards achieves a 100<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> control success rate within fewer training steps, and outperforms other schemes in terms of convergence speed and reward stability. This study ensures transient security while simultaneously considering economic efficiency, thereby providing a feasible intelligent scheduling solution for secure and economic dispatch of large-scale power systems.

title: Performance Evaluation of PSO-Based MPPT Algorithm for PV Systems Under Partial Shading
authors: Amel Smaili, El Ghalia Boudissa
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: Photovoltaic solar energy is the most sought-after renewable energy to replace fossil fuels, reduce pollution, and protect the ecosystem. It works via a Photovoltaic technology that directly transforms the energy from sunlight into electrical energy using PV panels. The Electricity obtained from this source can be available anywhere in the world, depending on the temperature and the sunlight available. Factors such as shading will affect the sunlight's amount reaching the PV panels, which will reduce the overall system's efficiency. Conventional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms, such as the perturb and observe algorithm, have addressed this challenge. However, they show limitations such as low convergence speed and sensitivity to shading conditions. This paper introduces a particle swarm optimization (PSO) based MPPT method to increase the total system performance of solar photovoltaic panels across different shading conditions and overcome the limitations presented by the other algorithms. The simulations were undertaken using MATLAB/Simulink with 4 “Tata Power Solar Systems TP250MBZ” modules connected in series; the results obtained from the comparative analysis between the PSO and the P&O algorithms are satisfactory and showcase the efficacy of the proposed approach.

title: Advancing Multivariate Time Series Forecasting with the HybridTST-Transformer Model
authors: Xiaolong Niu, Yang Li, Qizhou Huang, Gongju Wang, Ye Chen, Long Yan, Yulun Song
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This paper introduces the HybridTST-Transformer model, an innovative framework designed to enhance multivariate time series forecasting and self-supervised representation learning. The HybridTST-Transformer combines the strengths of transformer architectures with cross-channel attention mechanisms to effectively capture both local dependencies and global pat-terns in time series data. By integrating the self-attention mechanism with advanced feature extraction techniques, the model can handle diverse data types, including temporal features and external variables such as macroeconomic indicators. The model leverages shared parameter mechanisms and self-supervised pre-training to optimize performance and improve training efficiency. Through extensive experiments on datasets such as Weather, Huangshan Scenic Area, Traffic, and Electricity, the HybridTST-Transformer consistently outperforms existing models in predictive accuracy and generalization. Notably, the model achieves over 90% accuracy in forecasting potential traffic congestion in the Huangshan Scenic Area, highlighting its practical relevance and robustness. The HybridTST-Transformer offers a versatile and interpretable approach to time series forecasting, demonstrating promising applications across a wide range of domains, from traffic management to energy demand forecasting.

title: Hybrid CNN-Transformer Model for Scalable and Robust Phishing URL Detection
authors: Kamaljeet Kaur, Ankit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Phishing attacks remain a significant cybersecurity threat, targeting individuals and organizations by exploiting deceptive URLs to steal sensitive information. This paper presents a hybrid approach to phishing URL detection, combining convolutional neural networks (CNN) for local pattern extraction with Transformer models for capturing global relationships among URL features. The proposed architecture utilizes an optimized preprocessing pipeline, addressing categorical and numerical data, standardization, and feature encoding, ensuring the model is scalable and robust. Evaluation on a diverse dataset demonstrates an accuracy of 97.31%, outperforming traditional methods while maintaining computational efficiency. Additionally, the model leverages a novel layered structure, incorporating GlobalMaxPooling1D and self-attention mechanisms to enhance detection accuracy and reduce false positives. The study also explores real-world challenges, such as zero-day phishing URLs and dataset imbalance, and provides insights into potential improvements by integrating additional contextual features. This research contributes significantly to phishing detection, paving the way for efficient and scalable cybersecurity solutions.

title: Kullback–Leibler Divergence–Driven Cooperative Asynchronous Compressive Spectrum Sensing for Cognitive Radio Networks
authors: Hadj Abdelkader Benzater, Nacerredine Lassami, Djamal Teguig, Hamza Zeraoula, Abdellatif Rouabah, Redouane Kaibou
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This work introduces a selective cooperation strategy for compressed spectrum sensing in cognitive radio networks, where the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence serves as a channel quality metric. The recovered spectra of multiple secondary users are compared against a cooperative reference spectrum, and users are dynamically ranked according to their KL divergence. Since KL divergence acts as a surrogate for effective signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), users with large divergence values—indicative of poor channel quality—are excluded from cooperation. This selective participation mitigates the impact of noisy contributors (which arise from the erroneous bin positions) and strengthens detection reliability. Simulation and software-defined radio (SDR) experiments confirm that the proposed approach yields substantial gains in sparse signal recovery for small-scale networks, particularly under adverse noise and interference conditions.

title: Computing the Load Margin of Power Systems Using Birds of Prey-Based Optimization Algorithm
authors: Murilo E. C. Bento
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: The Load Margin (LM) of power systems indicates the maximum system load level that does not cause system instability. Most methods consider a single direction of load growth to calculate the Load Margin. However, different load growth directions can yield different LMs. This paper proposes an optimization model to identify the LM, considering a degree of variability in the load growth direction. The Birds of Prey-Based Optimization Algorithm is applied to the proposed optimization problem to identify the LM.

title: Multi-Model Disagreement Active Learning for N-1 Stability Constraint Construction in Optimal Power Flow
authors: Jianshu Yu, Diwen Zheng, Tao Chen, Guangde Dong, Zihan Lin, Pei Yong, Juan Yu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an efficient three-stage framework for N-1 Stability-Constrained Optimal Power Flow (SCOPF), focusing on the effective generation of dynamic stability constraints. First, an unconstrained Optimal Power Flow (OPF) identifies an economic optimum. Second, a gradient-based search strategy efficiently guides the system from potential instability to a critical stable operating point that is close to the stability boundary. Third, we introduce the Multi-Model Disagreement Active Learning (MMDAL) strategy, which leverages the predictive disagreement among heterogeneous models to strategically select the most informative samples, thereby minimizing costly dynamic simulations. These samples are used to train a high-fidelity linear Support Vector Machine (SVM), whose decision boundary serves as a surrogate constraint for integration into the final OPF. Validation on the IEEE-39 system demonstrates MMDAL’s superiority, achieving a fully feasible and economic solution at a modest 1.5% operational cost increase.

title: Low-Frequency NILM via Deep Dictionary Learning and Compressed Sensing
authors: Yu Wu, Yiling Tan, Han Xie, Jian Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The growing demand for fine-grained appliance-level energy monitoring has attracted considerable attention from both research and industry communities. While existing Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) methods have achieved substantial performance improvements, their effectiveness often degrades under real-world low-frequency sampling conditions. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a novel compressed sensing-assisted NILM framework for low-frequency environments. The approach incorporates an analog-to-information converter into smart metering infrastructure, facilitating compressed data acquisition and transmission via compressive sampling principles. A deep dictionary learning mechanism is subsequently employed to extract appliance operational states from the compressed measurements. Experimental findings verify the feasibility and efficacy of the suggested methodology, exhibiting promising performance in scenarios with low sampling rates.

title: Research on Early Insulation Fault Detection and Location in Distribution Power Cables
authors: Youbo Jia, Chao Dong, Jingying Zou, Wenzhou Liu, Xiangping Meng
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Early-stage insulation faults in distribution power cables exhibit faint and intermittent transient signatures that conventional monitoring techniques struggle to detect and localize. Such incipient degradation is a precursor to catastrophic failures and constitutes a significant threat to power system stability. Because transients are sporadic and low in magnitude, traditional schemes often fail to provide timely warning or accurate fault location, making the development of reliable early-stage detection and localization methods essential for preventing fault escalation, shortening outage durations, and enhancing supply reliability. This paper reviews the state of the art in early insulation fault detection and location for distribution cables, critically analyzing the strengths and limitations of existing approaches. Building on this analysis, a novel method that integrates multi-source information, including high-frequency partial-discharge signals, synchronized transient earth-voltage/current waveforms, and distributed temperature data, is proposed. Laboratory and field experiments demonstrate that the proposed fusion framework detects incipient faults at their emergence stage and pinpoints their positions with sub-meter accuracy. The results provide a practical and effective tool for condition assessment and intelligent O&M of distribution cable networks.

title: Examining Opportunities, Challenges, and Strategic Integration in AI-Driven Corporate Communication
authors: Shivani Kapoor, Madhu Jasola
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been presented as a key component of corporate communication, initiating the requalification of organizations in terms of services and creating a range of strategic opportunities and some associated threats. In this paper, a structured review of the literature is done to analyze how AI is integrated in corporate communication, the opportunities it provides, challenges it presents, and the strategies that can be used to support effective integration. Drawing on the contributions of antecedents in relation to AI in business communication-based functions, the study compares the existent strategies and maps the gaps in research. It lists key opportunities and challenges and offers strategic suggestions specific integration strategies to particular problems. Experimental applications of AI, like natural language processing, chatbots, predictive analytics and automated content generation, supplement operational and stakeholder interactions and decision making on data. However, organizations face high costs of implementation, lack of skills, ethics and governance issues, resistance to change and uncertainty about the regulations as well as integration challenges. The results highlight the notion that AI-inspired business communication should be theorized as a socio technical system whereby technology, individuals and institutional background are harmonized. The paper ends on practical implications to the practitioners and the direction of the future research.

title: Compact Dual Band Substrate Integrated Waveguide Cavity Backed Patch Antenna with Hybrid Pattern
authors: Neema S. Joseph, Gowrish Basavarajappa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents a dual band cavity backed patch antenna in substrate integrated waveguide technology. A square substrate integrated waveguide cavity is designed using a single layer substrate with a square shaped patch on the top layer which serves as a radiating element and is fed using coax probe. The dual band antenna produces the two types of radiation pattern due to the square slot dual resonance. The prototype is simulated, fabricated and measured for return loss, and radiation pattern, where two operational bands with omnidirectional and directional radiation along the broadside direction are realized at 2.23 GHz and 4.45 GHz with fractional bandwidth of 1.34% and 3.37%. The antenna offers multifunctionality with two independent operating bands having different radiation patterns.

title: MediAid: Automated Healthcare and Smart Medicine Dispenser
authors: Ravichandran M, Anusri S, Madhunisha M V, Simhadri Ravishankar
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Elderly individuals often experience serious health issues that need ongoing monitoring of their health and prompt administration of medication to avoid complications. This work introduces an IoT-based Elderly Health Monitoring and Robust Care System which combines biomedical sensors such as an MAX30102 sensor for heart rate and SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> monitoring, an ECG sensor to analyze cardiac activity, and an NTC thermistor to measure body temperature with an ESP32 microcontroller, coupled with a servo motor-controlled automatic medicine dispenser for precise administration of drugs. The system transmits collected health data to the cloud for real-time storage, visualization, and anomaly detection, while incorporating an intelligent alert mechanism to immediately notify caregivers or medical professionals when abnormalities are detected. Additionally, a mobile application has been developed to provide an intuitive interface for doctors, caregivers, and patients to view health records and manage prescriptions. The solution presented provides a low-cost, scalable, and secure method of remote care for the elderly through the integration of real-time health tracking with autonomous medication management, hence enhancing early abnormality detection, drug compliance, and healthcare accessibility for the elderly population.

title: Median Frequency Inflation Rate (MFIR): A Novel Time–Frequency Method for Rapid P and S–Wave Detection in EEW Systems
authors: Siddhartha Sarkar, Anubrata Roy, Satish Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Earthquake Early Warning (EEW) systems are vital for reducing the damage caused by earthquakes by providing seconds of warning before strong shaking begins. A key challenge in EEW is the rapid and accurate detection of seismic waves, particularly the initial P-wave, along with precise identification of P and S-wave arrival times. This study presents a novel time-frequency based signal processing method termed the Median Frequency Inflation Rate (MFIR) technique for improved real-time seismic event detection and phase picking. Utilising a large, strong-motion accelerogram dataset from Japan’s K-NET seismic network and non-earthquake data from NCR, India, the MFIR approach examines spectral density changes across multiple frequency bins in earthquake accelerograms. MFIR effectively detects sudden changes in median frequency that correspond closely with P and S wave arrivals. By tuning detection thresholds, the method achieves a high true positive rate (TPR) of approximately 98% for P-wave events with a threshold of 0.7, while maintaining a low false alarm rate of 5% on non-earthquake data. Additionally, the S-wave detection TPR exceeds 90%. Additionally, MFIR offers low latency, with median phase arrival detection delays under one second for both P and S-waves, demonstrating its capability for real-time applications.

title: Research On Temperature Error Compensation Technology of Pillar Optical Fiber Current Transformer
authors: Lin Cheng, Jianyong Luo, Weibin Si, Yanhua Han, Kun Zuo, Haitao Sun, Bo Niu, Shuangzan Ren
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: In order to solve the problem of ratio accuracy drift with temperature in engineering application of pillar type fiber optical current transformer (FOCT), the structure and temperature error influencing factors of pillar FOCT are analyzed, and the temperature error sources of signal unit, modulation and demodulation unit, transmission unit and sensing unit are discussed. The temperature performance improvement method of "component optimization and system compensation" is proposed. The feasible method of restraining temperature error is discussed from the system point of view. A FOCT engineering prototype is developed. The results of full temperature test show that the total temperature error can be within ± 0.1% after optimization design and temperature compensation, which is better than the application requirement of ± 0.2%.

title: Research and Application of Regulatory Safety Management Underthe New Situation
authors: Xiaoqin He, Yang Lei, Chong Li, Yizhi Tian, Jianfeng Guo, Rui Wang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: In the new era, with the rapid development of the economy, the demand for electrical energy in various industries has increased significantly, and the power industry has become a key driver of industrial development. The power industry has promoted the transformation of energy structure and the upgrading of power systems. The advent of the new power system has brought new challenges to risk prevention and control as well as safety management.

title: Motorcycle Exhaust Gas Emission and Noise Measurement and Classification System Using ESP32 and IoT Sensor
authors: Farhan Syah, Nurul Ilmi, Demi Adidrana
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: In Indonesia, certified motorcycle emission testing equipment costs IDR 40–80 million, creating accessibility barriers for individual owners and small workshops. Existing IoT monitoring systems typically address gas emissions or noise separately without regulatory classification capability. This study presents an integrated portable system combining MQ-7, MQ-135, MAX4466 sensors with ESP32 microcontroller and deterministic classification based on Indonesian Ministry of Environment regulations No. 8/2023 & No. 07/2009. The device simultaneously measures CO, HC, and exhaust noise, classifying results as Safe, Needs Attention, or Dangerous. Validation against government-certified analyzers (baseline: 0.28% CO, 194 ppm HC, 73 dB(A)) through five calibration iterations achieved 21% CO error (0.06% absolute deviation) and 85% classification accuracy in the final iteration. The embedded classification executes under 5ms without cloud dependency, contrasting with computationally intensive ML approaches. However, MQ sensors exhibit humidity-induced cross-sensitivity (±15% at 60-90% RH) and temperature drift (±0.5%/°C), while MAX4466 lacks IEC 61672-compliant A-weighting, causing ±3 dB deviations. Combined with 10-15% annual sensitivity degradation, these limitations position the device as a screening tool rather than regulatory-grade equipment. At IDR 500,000 (~$32)—1% of certified equipment cost—the system maintains functional accuracy for pre-inspection diagnostics. Key contributions include synchronized emission-noise sensing, on-device classification eliminating network latency, and validated cost-effectiveness under resource constraints, supporting Indonesia's SDG 11 and 13 objectives through democratized emission monitoring access.

title: A Rule-based Energy Management System for a Marine Electric Propulsion System
authors: Nicola Corona, Mario Porru, Alessandro Serpi
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a rule-based Energy Management System (EMS) for the marine electric propulsion system presented by the IEEE Motor Vehicle Challenge (MVC) 2025. The system integrates a Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine (DTP-PMSM), whose three-phase windings are supplied by a battery pack and a supercapacitor module, respectively. The proposed EMS optimizes the DTP-PMSM power flow by utilizing the supercapacitor module to compensate for sudden power variation, by providing peak shaving during towing operations as well. Simulations based on the IEEE MVC 2025 reference cycles demonstrate effective power distribution and reduced battery current fluctuations achievable by the proposed EMS compared to the MVC 2025 baseline EMS.

title: Dual-layer Integrated MPC and SMC-based Energy Management Strategies for Hybrid Electric Vehicles
authors: Swathi Lavudya, Sachidananda Sen, Basetti Vedik, Chandan Kumar Shiva
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper addresses the key issue of energy management in Fuel Cell-Battery Hybrid Electric Vehicles (HEVs) to improve efficiency, performance, and component lifespan. In real-world driving, inefficient energy distribution increases fuel cell tension and impulsive battery degradation. Conventional strategies, such as the PI (Proportional and Integral), frequently struggle with the complex, nonlinear energy interactions. To overcome these limitations, the study proposes an advanced dual-layer Energy Management System (EMS) integrating Model Predictive Control (MPC) and Sliding Mode Control (SMC). MPC provides robust predictive optimization for global energy management under future load conditions. To minimize state of charge (SOC) limitations, maintain smoother conversions, and reduce energy loss. SMC, chosen for its adaptability to system disturbances, improves the performance of MPC by allowing real-time correction of the state of charge (SOC), thereby improving overall system stability and maintaining flexible tracking of energy requirements. To improve system flexibility under dynamic driving conditions, establishing better performance compared to conventional methods, the integrated MPC-SMC is proposed. MATLAB Simulink results show the MPC-SMC maintains the DC link voltage at desired voltage level improving the battery SOC slew rate. A comparative analysis between the PI and MPC-SMC control is presented with measured parameters comparison.

title: Innovative Charging and Discharging Policies for EV Battery Management: Leveraging Reinforcement Learning for Elongation and Efficiency
authors: Jishor Erat Krishnankutty, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, Bhukya Balakrishna, M. Dinesh, A. Rajalingam, Abner Ferdinand J
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Electric vehicles are a cornerstone of the world transition to green transportation. Yet the capacity and lifetime of their battery solutions are the most critical obstacles in terms of user adoption and satisfaction and environmental impact. conventional BMS Control strategies according to rule-based and model-based approaches, which are lacking the ability of dynamic adaptation to real-world uncertainties including changing driving schedule, environment temperature and grid loads. This work examines a novel method for battery charge and discharge management based on Reinforcement Learning (RL) which is a branch of machine learning able to learn through interaction with the environment. The studies aim to apply state-of-the-art RL methods, such as DQN and PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization), to online learning of adaptive SoC stabilized charging policies with the objectives of minimizing SoC deviation, maximizing the cycle life of a battery, and maximizing power efficiency when being charged. The RL agent is developed within a simulated EV environment that is representative of real-world driving conditions, energy consumption behavior and grid interaction. The reward function has been formulated to compromise between then trade-offs of battery health, energy usage and operation readiness. Experiments show that the battery management system that is based on RL has better performance results when it adjusts the charging and discharging level, the operating threshold dynamically to the un anti-reset windup scheme basing on the input. The most important parameters, such as charge cycle life, thermal behavior and SoH retention is much better. And without damaging battery life it allows V2G (vehicle-to-grid) integration, which will provide great value for the smart grid. This research also serves as a proof point to the general intelligent transport systems field of showing that Adaptive AI can be leveraged to tackle complexity in the context of EV battery dynamics. The new approach not only prolongs battery life and enhances performance, but also paves the way for smarter, energy-efficient mobility services. The effects are immense, ranging from bringing down the total cost of ownership (TCO) of EVs to negatively impacting their environmental footprint.

title: Predicting the Clear-Sky and Clearness Indices for GHI Estimation Under Two Algerian Climate
authors: Chennoufi Souad, Nacer Tarek, Nadjemi Omar, Ykhlef Farid
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: Solar radiation variability represents a major challenge to the optimal utilization of solar energy. This study focuses on predicting the clear sky index <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{t}})$</tex> and the clearness index <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{d}})$</tex> in two climatically different regions of Algeria: In Salah (Warm desert climate) and Souk Ahras in Oued el Kebrit (cold semi-arid climate steppe cold), according to the Koppen-Geiger climate classification. These will then be used to estimate horizontal solar radiation (GHI) using time series models. The National Solar Radiation Database (NSRDB) was used as the database for the period January 1 to December 31, 2022, with an hourly time resolution. The results indicate that both indices provide accurate and reliable forecasts in regions with stable climatic conditions, such as In Salah. However, the prediction accuracy decreases in regions with high climatic variability, such as Souk Ahras. Furthermore, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{t}}$</tex> index demonstrated superior performance compared to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{d}}$</tex> index. The main contribution of this research lies in first forecasting the indices <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K_{d}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K_{t}$</tex>, and then using them subsequently to estimate GHI, Unlike previous studies that directly predict GHI using time series models. This approach improves data stationarity and significantly contributes to enhancing forecasting accuracy.

title: Interpretable Healthcare Cost Prediction Using XGBoost with Dual Explainable AI Framework
authors: Ammar Pavel Zamora Siregar, Achmad Udin Zailani, Nurul Ilmi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Healthcare cost transparency is critical for patient empowerment, yet 92% of patients lack access to accurate cost estimates before treatment, contributing to medical debt for 41% of U.S. adults. Traditional statistical methods achieve limited accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.75) in modeling complex relationships between patient factors and healthcare costs. Machine learning models like XGBoost offer superior performance but lack interpretability, a critical issue when algorithmic decisions impact patient lives. This research proposes an interpretable healthcare cost prediction system using XGBoost with dual Explainable AI (XAI) framework: SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) for global model understanding and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) for patient-facing explanations. The Kaggle Insurance Cost dataset (1,338 records) was processed with domain-informed feature engineering based on WHO medical standards. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms other well-known ML techniques and XGBoost without optimization. The final ensemble model achieved R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.8770, RMSE = $4,320, and MAE = $2,440, exceeding the project’s performance target (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ≥ 0.87) with excellent generalization (overfitting gap = 0.0102).
