SHAP analysis identified smoker_bmi_interaction as the dominant cost driver ($6,397.52 mean impact), while LIME local surrogate models achieved average R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.829 when approximating individual XGBoost predictions, with 8-second computation time per patient. The deployed interactive dashboard at healthcare-cost-predictor.streamlit.app quantifies actionable savings potential ($8,000–$45,200 annually) from lifestyle interventions. This framework enables transparent, evidence-based healthcare cost awareness supporting informed patient decisions.

title: Design of Dynamic Prediction System for Electricity Heterogeneous Data Based on Deep Neural Network
authors: Lalit Sachdeva, Azimjanov Nazirbek, R. Gunasundari, Haeedir Mohameed, Saurabh, P Priyadharsini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Electricity pricing and incentive mechanisms play an important role in consumer usage pattern development in a Smart Grid (SG) ecosystem. Variations in these patterns have a direct effect on the fluctuation in prices as well as the overall demand. For that reason, reliable and timely forecasting of electricity prices and consumption demand is necessary to ensure SG reliability, stability, and effective maintenance. With the proliferation of smart meters, sensors and monitoring systems, the SG environment is now providing huge volumes of heterogeneous data and big-data driven forecasting is a rapidly advancing area of research. Empowering the consumers of power with accurate knowledge of prices and demands allows the ability to manage the load efficiently, which could be one of the factors in improving energy efficiency and cutting down operational costs.

title: Comparative Analysis of Clustering Algorithms for Identifying Wind Turbine Operating Regimes from SCADA Data
authors: A K Prajwal, Ahamed Sarfraz, S Sridhar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Wind turbine operational behavior is complex, influenced by dynamic weather conditions and internal control strategies, making performance monitoring and fault detection challenging. While traditional power curve analysis provides a baseline, it often fails to capture nuanced operational modes. This study conducts a comparative analysis of three unsupervised clustering algorithms—K-Means, Agglomerative Clustering, and Fuzzy C-Means (FCM)-to automatically identify distinct operating regimes from wind turbine SCADA data. Using measurements of wind speed, active power, and theoretical power of 10-minute intervals, we evaluate the algorithms based on silhouette scores and the Fuzzy Partition Coefficient (FPC) for FCM. K-Means and FCM (with m=1.5) demonstrate strong performance (Silhouette Scores of 0.560 and 0.559, FPC of 0.906 for FCM, respectively), effectively partitioning the data into four interpretable clusters representing states such as low-wind standby, ramp-up, rated power operation, and potential underperformance. Agglomerative clustering also identified similar regimes, albeit with a slightly lower silhouette score (0.514). Principal Component Analysis (PCA) projections and feature-pair scatter plots provide clear visual separation of these modes for each algorithm. This research underscores the utility of applying and comparing multiple clustering techniques to enhance the understanding of turbine behavior, offering a robust approach for advanced condition monitoring and operational analysis beyond conventional methods.

title: A Method for Locating High-Resistance Ground Faults in Low-Resistance Grounded Systems Based on Zero-Sequence Current-Voltage Characteristics and Matrix Algorithms
authors: Yu-Ting Wang, Dan Zhou, Hui Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To address the challenges of zero-sequence overcurrent protection failing to operate and lacking selectivity during high-resistance ground faults in low-resistance grounded systems, this study proposes a fault section localization method based on zero-sequence current-voltage characteristics and matrix algorithms. By extracting the normalized difference amplitude between zero-sequence current and zero-sequence voltage derivatives as a fault feature, it effectively distinguishes between upstream and downstream fault locations as well as branch line electrical characteristics. By integrating the network description matrix with the fault information matrix, precise fault section localization is achieved. PSCAD simulation results demonstrate that this method reliably selects and locates faults even under transition resistances as high as 2000 ohms. With clear principles, simple criteria, and low requirements for device sophistication, this method exhibits excellent engineering applicability.

title: Analysis of a Variable Region Size in Regional Voting
authors: Jared Hirt, Liang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Choosing the wrong region size in a regional election can result in electing a candidate that is not preferred by the majority of the population. We propose a method of conducting regional elections where the election is conducted several times on the same sample, but with different region sizes considered. A candidate is then elected if more than half of the regions vote for them. This approach has the benefit of increased stability present in regional elections, but also mitigates the chance of choosing an inappropriate region size. Our proposed model offers a formula for calculating the stability of an election with multiple region sizes, and with a set amount of blocks of concentrated noise of different sizes.

title: Real-Time Educational Personalization Using Fine-Tuned LLMs and Learner Behavior Analytics
authors: Suhail. T, K. Rajakumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This research introduces a new way to personalize education in real time by combining fine-tuned large language models (LLMs) with dynamic learner behavior analytics. The suggested method uses data from ongoing user interactions, such how accurate their answers are, how long they take to think about something, their patterns of engagement, and their content preferences, to adaptively fine-tune LLMs so they can provide individualized learning material and assistance. Our technology changes learning pathways in real time based on behavioral signals, which is different from standard static recommendation systems or rule-based adaptive learning platforms. This makes sure that training is both contextually relevant and cognitively aligned. This provides a unified architecture that takes in real-time behavior cues and sends them to a lightweight fine-tuning pipeline to adjust the model's outputs on the fly. The system has been tested with both simulated and actual learners, and it has been shown to greatly enhance learning speed, user happiness, and retention rates. This research sets a new standard for scalable, smart, and context-aware educational systems that change as the student does, laying the groundwork for future uses in customized digital education.

title: Comparative Study of Circular and Rectangular MPA Using HFSS Tool (Wi-Fi Applications)
authors: Srinivas Yerram, Chandupriya Thumma, Bhanu Yugendar Racherla, Manideep Racha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: In this paper, circular microstrip patch antenna (MPA) and rectangular microstrip patch antenna (MPA) designed to work at the frequencies of the Wi-Fi, in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2. 4 - 2. 4 8 3 5 ~ GHz$</tex> (ISM band) are comparatively analyzed. On account of Ansys HFSS simulation software, both antennas geometries are designed and analyzed according to main elemental performance parameters i.e. return loss, gain, bandwidth, and radiation pattern. The objective is to come up with the most efficient antenna structure in size, performance and best fit to the compact wireless communication systems. In the simulation results, there have been clear advantages and tradeoffs between the two designs in terms of impedance matching better in circular as compared to rectangular and Omnidirectional radiation characteristics better in circular as compared to rectangular. The research offers practical guidelines when it comes to choosing the best MPA set-ups to use on the latest Wi-Fi-supporting devices.

title: Research on Switching-Period-Based Loss Balancing Technology for All-SiC Active NPC Inverters
authors: Xinpeng Zhang, Wenxi Yao, Huan Yang, Rongxiang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The three-level active neutral point-clamped (3L-ANPC) inverter is used in fields such as photovoltaic power generation, new energy vehicles, and electric aircraft due to its advantages of low harmonics, high efficiency, and low voltage stress. However, uneven power loss among power devices leads to inconsistent junction temperatures, making high-temperature devices more prone to failure. By analyzing the loss distribution under different operating conditions, a switching period-based loss balancing strategy is proposed. This strategy switches between different commutation schemes on a per-switching-period basis. Results show that it not only achieves effective loss balancing but also reduces junction temperature fluctuations.

title: AZTEM: A Self-Evolving Zero-Trust Model for Adaptive Cloud Security Using AI-Driven Threat Mitigation and Quantum-Resilient Encryption
authors: Ikhar Avinash Khemraj, A. Buckshumiyan, Zayd Balassem, A. Shekar, B. Arunkumar, Guma Ali, Nurboy Jabborov
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The new digital ecosystems are being based on cloud environments but they are highly vulnerable to the shifts in cyber threat, which can take advantage of the stationary trust models, loose access rules and encryption functions that hangs in the air with the advent of quantum computing. The traditional models of perimeter based security fail to operate in highly dynamic cloud environments with insider based mauling, cross-lateral mauling and the zero day mauling bypassing the traditional security models. In this work, A Self-evolving Zero-Trust Model of Adaptive Cloud security with AI-based Threat Mitigation and Quantumresilient Encryption is introduced and is capable of addressing these emerging problems. AZTEM eliminates the implicit trust, validating and permitting all user, device, and microservice relations through the utilization of a contextsensitive trust engine that is reinforced by reinforcement learning algorithms. To counter the rapid adaptations of attack vectors, the system relies on the deep-learning-based anomaly detection methods such as LSTM-based sequence classifiers on cloud workload telemetry, network flow logs, and publicly accessible datasets (UNSW-NB15 and CICIDS2018). An adaptive policy controller is the basis of dynamic orchestration of mitigation strategies and uses AI-based response mechanisms to quarantine, reroute, or restrict malicious sessions in real time. Besides, the model includes quantum-resilient encryption that extends the protection of both data-at-rest and data-in-transit by using lattice cryptography to secure quantum decryption threats where confidentiality is ensured at the long-term scale. An initial deployment of AWS on Kubernetes clusters demonstrated that threat detection accuracy and false positives decreased by 27 percent and 34 percent respectively over a baseline zero-trust deployment, and performance overhead is less than 8 percent. Its application in adversarial context was assessed through measures such as precision, recall, F1-score and confidence intervals and proved it to be qualified. The architecture is not only making the cloud more resilient to the present, and the infrastructures of the quantum age impervious to the threats of the quantum age, but it is also providing businesses, governments and hard-to-secure areas in need of cloud security without a trade-off an ethical and scaleable and deployment-ready path.

title: A Method for Enhanced Depth Detection in Underwater Navigation: Implementation and Comparative Study
authors: S M Annapurna, R Sarath Chandran, T P Haneesh Sankar, K R Rajesh
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Accurate depth detection is crucial for underwater navigation systems such as Doppler Velocity Logs, echo sounders, and autonomous underwater vehicle guidance systems. Traditional envelope-based technique detects the arrival time of the echo by extracting the signal envelope. Although this method is simple to compute, it often lacks accuracy and results in more false echo detections at low Signal-to-Noise Ratios, especially in conditions of high signal attenuation. Correlation-based processing assesses the similarity between transmitted and received signals. However, this method can be complicated and sensitive to frequency shifts in the received waveform caused by the relative motion between the transducer and the target. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a Correlation-based Time Delay estimation technique that combines frequencydomain information with a two-stage cross-correlation approach to provide accurate and efficient depth estimation. The proposed method reduces noise and frequency mismatch effects by correlating the received signal with simulated reference waveforms. This improves robustness in low-Signal-to-Noise Ratio conditions. A systematic comparison between the Echo Envelope Thresholding method and Correlation-based Time Delay estimation technique is conducted using a laboratory setup that includes a waveform generator, signal attenuator, receiver module, data acquisition system, and Graphical User Interface to simulate a realistic acoustic channel. Simulation, laboratory experiments, and field trial results show that the Correlation-based Time Delay estimation technique consistently performs better than the Echo Envelope Thresholding method in challenging underwater situations, offering high depth accuracy, and stable performance while maintaining an acceptable computational load.

title: Logic Functional Scaling in the Angstrom Era: From Generic CMOS to Function-Specific Optimization
authors: Anabela Veloso, Julien Ryckaert, Srikanth B. Samavedam
publish: IEEE Electron Devices Magazine
abstract: We review several of the key elements responsible for driving advanced logic CMOS scaling. At the transistor level, we are entering the nanosheet (NS)-based device era with the focus first placed on single-level NS field-effect-transistors (FETs) consisting of several vertically stacked NS per device. These can evolve into 3D stacked configurations like the so-called complementary FET (CFET) with potentially different materials/crystal orientations used for the stacked channels. The trend toward using both wafer sides, triggered by the move of on-chip power distribution to the wafer’s backside (BS), enables new connectivity schemes and also opens up new opportunities for further BS functionalization, e.g., using 2D materials and oxide semiconductors. Together with advances in 3D interconnect technologies, this is paving the way for CMOS 2.0. The latter allows functional partitioning of the system-on-chip (SoC) by stacking multiple technology layers on top of each other, with the devices and interconnect schemes used in each layer optimized for a given, targeted application. The paradigm shift from CMOS to CMOS 2.0 offers great potential, but it is also a complex technological change, a de facto revolution, requiring innovations at various levels and increased interdisciplinary synergies.

title: A Low-Latency Post-Quantum Group Authentication Framework for VANETs
authors: Ashutosh Kumar, Manik Malhotra, A. Anjali, Amrendra Singh Yadav
publish: IEEE Networking Letters
abstract: Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) require ultra-low-latency authentication in high-mobility scenarios, decentralized trust, and emerging post-quantum security threats. This paper proposes a lightweight blockchain-assisted group authentication framework that integrates post-quantum cryptography with decentralized trust management. The scheme leverages CRYSTALS-Kyber for secure group key distribution, CRYSTALS-Dilithium for message authentication, and zero-knowledge proofs to achieve conditional anonymity and unlinkability. A permissioned Hyperledger Besu blockchain logs encrypted group keys and dynamically updated roadside unit reputation scores, enabling scalable and accountable authentication without monetary transaction overhead. Formal security analysis under the Dolev–Yao adversary model demonstrates confidentiality, authentication, replay resistance, and unlinkability based on standard post-quantum assumptions. Performance evaluation using OMNeT++ and SUMO shows up to 52.7% reduction in communication overhead and a group key update latency of 1.2 ms in dense traffic scenarios, while maintaining high throughput and effective Sybil attack detection. These results highlight the practicality of the proposed framework for post-quantum secure VANET authentication.

title: Revolutionizing Turn-by-Turn Navigation With Cloud-Edge Deep Learning
authors: Yiming Yang, Hao Fu, Fanxiang Zeng, Xikai Yang, Yue Liu, Ning Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Turn-by-turn (TBT) navigation systems are integral to modern driving experiences, providing real-time audio instructions to guide drivers safely to destinations. However, existing audio instruction policy often relies on rule-based approaches that struggle to balance informational content with cognitive load, potentially leading to driver confusion or missed turns in complex environments. To overcome these difficulties, we first model the generation of navigation instructions as a multi-task learning problem by decomposing the audio content into combinations of modular elements. Then, we propose a novel deep learning framework that leverages the powerful spatiotemporal information processing capabilities of Transformers and the strong multi-task learning abilities of Mixture of Experts (MoE) to generate real-time, context-aware audio instructions for TBT driving navigation. A cloud-edge collaborative architecture is implemented to handle the computational demands of the model, ensuring scalability and real-time performance for practical applications. Experimental results in the real world demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces the yaw rate (the proportion of vehicles deviating from navigation routes) compared to traditional methods, delivering clearer and more effective audio instructions. This is the first large-scale application of deep learning in driving audio navigation, marking a substantial advancement in intelligent transportation and driving assistance technologies.

title: Detecting inline code comment smells leveraging CodeBERT Model
authors: Sajjad Mahmood
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Inline code comments provide contextual information within source code, potentially enhancing readability and maintainability. However, suboptimal commenting practices, commonly referred to as comment smells, can obscure code intent, reduce maintainability, and increase the likelihood of defects. Automated detection of these smells remains challenging due to their diverse manifestations and the interplay between code and natural language. In this paper, we present a model that leverages CodeBERT embeddings to detect and classify multiple types of inline comment smells. The method incorporates systematic preprocessing of code comment pairs, class balancing to mitigate skewed label distributions, and contextual representation learning to capture semantic and syntactic aspects of the code. The proposed approach is evaluated on a publicly available benchmark dataset comprising 2,189 manually annotated code–comment pairs extracted from open-source Java and Python projects. Evaluation on a benchmark dataset shows that CodeBERT consistently outperforms traditional machine/deep learning classifiers in accuracy and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), establishing a new state-of-the-art for multi-class comment-smell detection. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of pre-trained, code-aware language models for detecting inline comment smells in a software project. These findings highlight the promise of code-aware transformer models for automated assessment of inline comment quality in real-world software systems.

title: Gain Self-Adjustment Observation and Guaranteed Performance for Faulty Industrial Process System: A Performance Self-Recovery Approach
authors: Peihao Du, Yan Lei, Hongyi Li, Weimin Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article formulates a gain self-adjustment state observer-based performance self-recovery control (GASO-based PSrC) strategy for the industrial process system subject to actuator faults, and the main contributions of the GASO-based PSrC strategy can be summarized as its adaptability to external environmental variations, its capability to suppress faulty performance, and its plasticity in the postfault operation scenario, manifested in adjustable convergence rate and regulation precision for damaged process performance. Therein, a novel gain self-adjustment state observer (GASO) is constructed for estimating the disturbance and process states, thereby completing GASO gain update and maintenance as well as the accommodation of environment variation. To constrain sustained performance decay and steady-state evolution performance, a two-stage performance function with transient response and steady-state convergence is developed. An activation instruction based on the correntropy criterion is designed to detect faults and enable the guaranteed performance control scheme in the postfault operation scenario. Then, the proposed GASO-based PSrC framework is established to realize the scheduled process regulation level. Extensive experiment validations are accomplished on a micro-wastewater treatment process, and the regulation results on the dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration illustrate that the proposed control strategy can guarantee the user-defined performance requirement while mitigating the detriment of faults and disturbance.

title: Health Monitoring of Inductor Based on the Thermal Time Constant
authors: Jun Zhang, Zhihuan Wang, Jiaxin Wu, Yi Zheng, Xiong Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Inductors are essential components in power converters, and their health monitoring is critical for preventing unscheduled downtime due to failures. This article proposes a novel inductor health monitoring method based on the thermal time constant. Results show that the inductor health can be monitored by detecting the increase in the thermal time constant. Compared to existing methods, the proposed technique achieves electrothermal decoupling, eliminating the influence of current and frequency on the results. Furthermore, it is a cost-effective and onboard method for inductor health assessment. Simulations in COMSOL and experimental tests on a PWM bridge with an inductive load were performed to verify the proposed approach. Detailed analyses were also conducted on the influences of current, frequency, ambient temperature, sensor position, and the inductor structure.

title: Edge-Optimized Agentic AI for Stochastic Communication Modeling in Digital Systems
authors: Jagjit Singh Dhatterwal, Dipesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: A conventional modeling fall short due to latency, scalability, and resource limitations, modern digital systems confront formidable hurdles in controlling intrinsically unpredictable communication patterns (traffic bursts, delays, losses). In order to understand and govern real-time stochastic communication, this research suggests a novel Edge-Optimized Agentic AI framework. Using a distributed Multi-Agent System (MAS) architecture, we present autonomous decision-making, lightweight stochastic inference (using Markov/Poisson processes), and localized sensing carried out by specialized agents placed on edge devices. The integration of TinyML techniques (quantization, pruning) for on-device stochastic model execution under extreme computational constraints, communication-efficient agent coordination protocols that minimize overhead, and agent-driven adaptive tuning of model parameters to handle non-stationarity are some of the major innovations. Tested using an NS-3-based edge emulator, our approach outperforms cloud-based AI in terms of decision latency by 42% and resource use by 35%, while retaining <90% prediction accuracy in the face of stochastic bursts and network dynamics. The results validate enhanced fault tolerance, scalability, and flexibility, allowing for autonomous optimization in dynamic edge contexts such as industrial networks and the Internet of Things.

title: A Low-Pass Filtering Wilkinson Power Divider with Wide Harmonic Suppression
authors: Benbachir Maroua Nour El Houda, Amrani Fayçal
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This work reports the design of a wideband filtering power divider with enhanced harmonic suppression for radio-frequency applications. The proposed structure integrates a Wilkinson power divider with a low-pass filter to achieve both power division and filtering within a single structure. An elliptic resonator along with suppression cells is used to realize the low-pass response, effectively eliminating unwanted harmonics and extending the stopband from 2.3 GHz to 20 GHz achieving an attenuation of −20 dB. At the operating frequency of 2.1 GHz, the power divider exhibits good performance, with an in-band isolation of −43 dB, a return loss of −36 dB, and an insertion loss of −3.2 dB. The suggested design is well suited for modern communication systems, where compact size and effective harmonic suppression are critical requirements.

title: DPCC for Winding Segmented Permanent Magnet Linear Synchronous Motor with Sliding Mode Disturbance Observer
authors: Qingbin Geng, Yanxin Li, Qinfen Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a deadbeat predictive current control (DPCC) method for winding-segmented permanent magnet linear synchronous motors (WS-PMLSM). Due to the segmented winding structure of the WS-PMLSM, variations in inductance and permanent magnet flux linkage occur as the mover traverses different segmented winding, which leads to performance degradation in traditional DPCC. To address this issue, a novel control algorithm integrating DPCC with a sliding mode observer is designed. The algorithm estimates the system perturbations in real time and compensates the estimation results in predicted currents and voltages generated by DPCC. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared with conventional control algorithms, the proposed method achieves superior robustness and control effectiveness during motor switching process.

title: Solving Inverse Kinematics for Quantised Joint Manipulators Using Metaheuristics and Discrete Gradient Descent
authors: Rhiddhi Prasad Das, Junali Jasmine Jena, Suresh Chandra Satapathy
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Inverse Kinematics (IK) is a core problem in robotics, typically solved using continuous methods that assume differentiable joint spaces. However, many real-world systems, such as stepper motor-driven arms and embedded manipulators, exhibit discrete or quantized joint behaviour, where classical IK solvers often fail or produce unstable, jittering outputs. To address this, we formalise the Inverse Discrete Kinematics (IDK) problem and propose a hybrid solution combining discrete metaheuristic search with a local refinement step using Discrete Gradient Descent (DGD). The method optimises joint configurations within a quantised space to minimise end-effector error while maintaining energy efficiency. Experiments on 5-DOF and 6-DOF manipulators demonstrate sub-millimetre accuracy and improved robustness over brute-force and naive rounding approaches, establishing IDK as both tractable and practically significant. Statistical analysis was performed on each of the runs to determine significant differences and equivalence before and after the DGD process.

title: Breakdown Characteristics of Fluorocarbon Dielectric for HV High Power Electronic Device Phase Change Cooling System
authors: Lejia Song, Shilin Shi, Fengshun Jiao, Liming Wang, Fanghui Yin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The thermal losses of high-voltage and high-power power electronic devices are gradually increasing, thus requiring more advanced cooling technologies. Phase change cooling is a relatively popular heat dissipation technology in recent years. Among them, fluorocarbon compounds are used as phase change cooling materials, and their breakdown characteristics under high voltage need to be studied. This article explores the influence of various factors on the breakdown characteristics of fluorocarbons, providing a reference for the application of this substance in phase change cooling technology.

title: Solar Photovoltaic Panels Tilt Angle Optimization using Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Vima Mali, Pankaj Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The photovoltaic panels-based power generation system is a very common and well adopted technology. The installed capacity of these systems is growing very fast. However, the accurate estimation of tilt and azimuth angles for these systems is very crucial, else, this may lead to decrease in the harnessed energy. Therefore, in this work, two artificial neural networks are trained to predict the optimal solar panel tilt and azimuth angles. The models are trained using the solar elevation and azimuth angle data of Gandhinagar, Gujarat $\left(23.2156^{\circ} \mathrm{N}, 72.6369^{\circ} \mathrm{E}\right)$. The input neurons of the model are activated with two inputs; month of the year and hour of the day. The trained artificial neural network models are tested under two cases, in the first case, the predicted values of the neurons are compared with the actual values (for entire data). In second case, predictions of the model are extrapolated by extending the inputs beyond the training values.

title: Design and Implementation of a Smart Contract Integrity Verification Framework for API
authors: Thanikaivel. B, Vishnupriyan. J, Dharma Sastha. B, Naveen Akash. V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This paper presents a Smart Contract Based Integrity Verifier framework for web security in APIs. This framework utilizes blockchain technology in order to design a secure mechanism that makes use of cryptographic hashes to verify the credibility of API responses. Smart contracts ensure transparent and tamper-proof scoring while automating security enforcement The approach is relevant because it covers the weaknesses existing in the existing Oauth 2.0 APIs and provides a strong mechanism for data tampering detection and prevention. This is achieved through the implementation of the system on Python Framework and blockchain simulation, hence enabling users to interact with the system and send API responses validated for credibility. The framework ensures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8 \%}$</tex> verification accuracy rates as compared to the existing security mechanisms for API Credibility Verification. Future work is in integrating into various domains, such as healthcare, finance, supply chain, and IoT.

title: Analysis of Electromagnetic Characteristics of Magnetic - Latching Relays and Optimization Design Based on Multiple Factors
authors: Min Zhang, Chenyang Gu, Hangxin Wei, Yong Peng, Xubin Zheng, Jianguo Sang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: With the development of modern technology, electromagnetic relays are widely used. The traditional ones consume high energy, while magnetic latching relays are favored for their energy - saving feature. This paper focuses on magnetic latching relays. Considering the influence of coil parameters on magnetic field distribution and the inadequacies of existing research, simulation - based analysis is conducted. It is found that by changing the frequency of the rectangular pulse current input, the coil magnetic field changes slowly in a rectangular - pulse shape at low frequencies, and oscillates with a relatively stable peak value at high frequencies. Through multi - factor optimized design, this study enhances their performance and reliability, providing support and guarantee for their application in electrical fields such as smart grids.

title: Multi-View Feature Fusion with Cross-Attention for Robust Leukemia Detection in Microscopic Imaging
authors: Jagan Mohan Dudala, Anmol Bhatnagar
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Automated leukemia detection from microscopic blood cell images plays a crucial role in hematological diagnostics, enabling early and accurate disease identification. Traditional deep learning (DL) models primarily rely on single-view feature extraction, making them susceptible to variations in staining intensity, illumination, and imaging artifacts. These limitations hinder classification robustness and generalization, posing challenges in real-world clinical applications. To address these issues, this work introduces a multi-view feature fusion framework that integrates raw images, optical density (OD) transformed images, and anisotropically diffused images to enhance feature representation. A cross-attention mechanism is incorporated to adaptively refine salient features while suppressing redundant information across views. Experimental results on a high-resolution leukemia dataset demonstrate that the proposed model achieves a test accuracy of 97.90%, significantly outperforming single-view approaches. Furthermore, an ablation study confirms the impact of OD transformation and anisotropic diffusion in improving classification robustness. The confusion matrix and ROC analysis validate the model’s effectiveness, while LIME-based visual explanations enhance interpretability. These findings highlight the potential of multi-view learning in hematopathology, paving the way for more reliable AI-assisted leukemia diagnostics.

title: Performance Analysis of UAV Communication Using Scaled Selection Combining
authors: Jency J, M.D. Selvaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), being deployed as aerial relays are gaining momentum in communication, to enhance coverage, handle sudden surges in connectivity demand, and improve reliability in wireless communication systems. This makes them a promising component of next-generation networks. In this work, we study a cooperative communication model where a base station transmits M-ary Phase-Shift Keying symbols to a destination, both directly and via a UAV aerial relay. At the user end in the destination, the received signals are com-bined using a low-complexity scaled selection combining (SSC) scheme. A closed-form expression of Symbol Error Probability (SEP) has been analytically derived, for the considered system assuming Rayleigh fading channel conditions. The simulation results demonstrate that UAV-assisted relay communication with SSC outperforms both conventional selection combining and direct transmission.

title: YOLO-PetX: Enhanced YOLO-Based Recognition of Abnormal Dog Behaviors in Intelligent Pet Care Applications
authors: Chunlong Xu, Xiaofei Liao, Xi Cheng, Bohang Chao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: With the rapid growth of the global pet industry, intelligent behavior monitoring has become increasingly important for animal welfare and early health management. Abnormal canine behaviors—such as limping, vomiting, or bleeding—often indicate potential health issues but remain difficult to detect accurately and efficiently on resource-limited devices. To address this challenge, we propose YOLO-PetX, a lightweight YOLOv11-based framework for abnormal dog behavior recognition in intelligent pet care. YOLO-PetX replaces the original YOLOv11n backbone with the EfficientViT-SAM architecture to enhance global-local feature extraction and contextual awareness, and introduces a Decoupled Head and MPDIoU loss to improve task separation and bounding-box regression. Experiments on a self-constructed dataset of ten normal and abnormal behaviors show that YOLO-PetX achieves a mAP50-95 of 72.3%, exceeding the YOLOv11n baseline by 3.9 percentage points while maintaining a compact size (2.74M parameters) and fast inference speed (1.86 ms per image). These results confirm the effectiveness of YOLO-PetX for real-time embedded deployment, offering a practical solution for intelligent pet monitoring and early anomaly detection.

title: A Knowledge Graph Approach with Graph Data Science and Hybrid Filtering for Personalized Learning Recommendation System
authors: Nurul Arina, Indriana Hidayah, Noor Akhmad Setiawan
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The rapid growth of educational data has created a critical need for personalized learning recommendation systems. This study proposes a novel approach that integrates the Curriculum Knowledge Graph with a hybrid filtering algorithm to provide more adaptive and personalized course recommendation. Additionally, rule-based filtering is also applied to ensure compliance with academic regulation, including the amount of credit limits and prerequisite requirements. This experiment used an undergraduate Information Technology curriculum data that successfully demonstrated the recommendation outputs aligned with student profiles and academic context. The results are the list of recommended courses that obtained an average expert relevance score of 4,63/5. That highlights a strong potential to implement Knowledge Graph in education domain particularly integrating it with other recommendation methods. However, the study still lacks of incorporating the students’ preferences such as their field of interest and career paths. Therefore, these limitations could be a potential for the future research.

title: Graph partitioning for accuracy and scalability in training GNN-based traffic prediction models for Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Ashish Agnihotri, Bao Ngo, Khuc Nguyen, Aniket Mahanti, Ying Ying Liu, Parimala Thulasiraman
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: As urban areas grow and transportation networks become increasingly complex, accurate large-scale traffic forecasting is essential for Intelligent Transportation Systems. Graph Neural Networks-based traffic prediction models, such as the Diffusion Convolutional Recurrent Neural Networks (DCRNN) model, treat the traffic flow as a diffusion process on the graph, effectively capturing the propagation of the traffic conditions through the network. Unlike linear statistical models, GNNs inherently capture non-Euclidean spatial dependencies via graph structures. However, training GNNs on large-scale graphs is resource-intensive and time-consuming. This paper aims to study the impact of graph partitioning tools on accuracy and scalability in training GNN-based traffic prediction models. This paper integrates the Adaptive Graph Convolutional Recurrent Network (AGCRN) with a domain-specific graph partitioning tool for transportation networks—the Buffoon-optimized Karlsruhe High-Quality Partitioning (KaHIP). The partitions are trained on an NVIDIA A100 Tensor Core GPU. Tests on the California highway network dataset show that the Buffoon-optimized KaHIP framework produces higher-quality partitions, resulting in higher forecasting accuracy. We also show that the AGCRN-KaHIP integration outperforms DCRNN-METIS and baseline statistical methods. The integration achieves lower prediction errors and more stable forecasts.

title: Secure Fog-Edge and 5G-Enabled Architecture for AI-Driven Mobility, Real-Time Traffic Analytics, and Accessibility in Aging-Focused Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Victor Balogun, Sayed Saminur Rahman, William Kai Watt
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: With the global population aged 65 and older expected to double by 2050, ensuring equitable access to safe, efficient, and responsive transportation systems has become a pressing societal imperative. This paper introduces a secure fog-edge and 5G-enabled architecture designed to enhance the safety and accessibility of aging populations within next-generation Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS). The proposed framework integrates AI-powered elderly vehicle monitoring for proactive risk detection, real-time traffic analytics through decentralized edge-fog computing, and adaptive intelligent traffic lights that respond dynamically to the mobility needs of older drivers and pedestrians.Leveraging decentralized edge intelligence, blockchain-enhanced privacy safeguards, wearable health-monitoring integration, and AI-driven analytics, the system provides ultra-low-latency, resilient, and adaptive mobility services. The architecture emphasizes latency mitigation, human-centered interface design, dynamic risk evaluation, and policy-aligned cybersecurity strategies. Analytical comparisons demonstrate that local data processing combined with predictive threat modeling can substantially reduce transportation-related health risks, improve decision-making efficiency, and foster inclusive urban mobility. A novel architectural model is presented to inform the design of secure, accessible, and aging-centric ITS infrastructures.

title: Practical Visualization of Learning and Teaching Behaviour Patterns Using Moodle Blocks
authors: Angela Smith, Sabine Graf
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Dashboards that illustrate the behaviour patterns of students and/or instructors can be enormously valuable for students and instructors. They can be used to promote self-reflection or support monitoring student activity. However, many dashboards simply display available data without considering whether this data is useful or supports learning success. In contrast, this research established useful visualizations based on underlying behavioural theories, developing three Moodle blocks as dashboards to explore the question: How to provide useful and understandable information about student and instructor behaviours in the form of instructor and student dashboards? While the focus of this paper is on the dashboard designs, this research is part of a larger project that uses artificial intelligence to (1) verify and depict the usefulness of the information presented with respect to its impact on student success, failure or dropout likelihood and (2) recommend alternative behaviour patterns for students and instructors to increase student success. The resulting dashboards are useful tools that allow students and instructors to self-monitor, encouraging behaviour changes that could lead to greater learning success.

title: 5G-Enabled Edge Intelligence for Hybrid Inverters with Smart Solar Battery Charging
authors: Sasikala. A, Harish. V, Jaswanth. J, Ganeshram. D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The growing popularity of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems that use hybrid inverters and battery backup demonstrates the importance of productive, reliable, and safe energy control. Nevertheless, the current research, however, has limitations in terms of conversion efficiency, latency, flexibility, and cybersecurity, especially when putting active load and dynamic solar conditions. To overcome such problems, this paper suggests a 5G-interconnected edge intelligence architecture of hybrid inverters and smart solar battery charging. It involves deep learning-based adaptive control in controlling the inverter, edge computing in the realtime decision-making process, and cybersecurity-minded anomaly detection to defend the threats. The system model utilizes 5G ultra-reliable low latency communication (URLLC) to maintain an uninterrupted interaction among PV modules, hybrid inverters and storages. Experimental testing revealed efficiency of the inverters of maximum 97%, battery charging/discharging efficiency of 94% and a significant lower latency of 30-55 ms compared to conventional schemes. The suggested system offers a flexible, smart, and robust kind of next generation smart energy infrastructures.

title: Improving Stock Price Prediction Utilizing Anomaly Detection and Handling for Top 3 LQ45 Financial Company in Indonesia
authors: Nicholas Irvin Suhendi, Lili Ayu Wulandhari
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study tries to explore how anomaly detection and handling affect model performance on stock price prediction. The tickers used in this study is BBCA, BBRI, and BMRI, the top three financial companies in the LQ45 index. To mark anomalies, LSTM and CNN autoencoders were fitted and is tasked to predict the to-be-marked subset of data. Percentile-based thresholds of reconstruction errors from when the model predicts the subset is then used to mark anomalies. Following the detection phase, we correct the marked anomalies using two approaches: linear interpolation and rolling median. Evaluation shows that rolling median provides stable improvements on most percentiles while linear interpolation, especially on lower thresholds, becomes too aggresive when correcting the anomalies. Thus, degrading the predictive model performance. To help validate the tests performed, we used statistical validations such as paired t-tests, Wilcoxon tests, Cohen’s d, and bootstrap confidence intervals. These tests help confirm that mild, structure-preserving correction methods such as rolling median provide the most stable and reliable improvements. These findings show the importance and the potential improvements anomaly handling is able to provide for stock price forecasting.

title: Empirical Analysis of AI Methods of Forecasting financial Times Series: A Research on LSTM and ML models in Indian Stock, Commodity and Energy Prices
authors: Suresh Kumar, Pardeep Kumar, Renu Sidhu, Neha Kumari, Swapandeep Kaur, Kawal Nain Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The present paper provides an empirical analysis of the methods of Artificial Intelligence (AI) predicting the financial time series data in the Indian context, namely the use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network, Random Forest Regression, and Support Vector Machines (SVM). There are four main variables of the study that are the NIFTY 50 stock index, the historical gold price, the price of crude oil and the price of natural gas which represent important sectors of the Indian economy. The paper demonstrates that the AI models outperform the conventional econometric models (such as ARIMA and Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression), significantly in terms of accuracy of predictions, sensitivity to volatility, and the ability to fit non-linearity in the actions of variables. LSTM reduced the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) by more than 50 percent in stock market forecasts when compared to ARIMA and the machine learning model improved the prediction performance of credit default by 17 percent compared to the logistic regression model. This research uses a mixed methods design, an Integrative survey, blending model-based performance evaluation with the qualitative contributions of 100 stakeholders in the Indian financial institutions, fintech affiliates, and regulatory authority. These findings reveal a wide optimism in terms of AI to enhance risk management and make the operations more efficient and also highlight the consistent concerns about data protection, clean governance and institutional readiness. The paper concludes by calling on the urgency of explainable AI systems (XAI), effective regulatory strategies, and industry synergies so that ethically and sustainably AI should be applied in the financial sector of forecasting, particularly in the emerging economies, such as India.

title: Gain-Scheduled-PID Controller design for Anti-Lock Braking System of Automobile
authors: Srinjoy Paul, Rajeeb Dey
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Brake systems are crucial for ensuring the reliability of automobiles. In modern automobiles Antilock braking systems (ABS) is employed to improve vehicle stability and safety by mitigating wheel lockup during braking. The objective of the research is to improve ABS functionality and reduce the likelihood of accidents resulting from skidding under uncertain road conditions. To accomplish this, an open-loop adaptive gain-scheduled PID control is designed for ABS to control the wheel slip so as to achieve optimal stopping distance while preserving steering control and minimizing wheel lock-up.The novelty of the proposed control design is validated through various performance metrics introduced here and further compared with traditional control for ABS.

title: Cross-Market Collaborative Trading Strategy for Virtual Power Plants: A Hierarchical Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Liang Cheng, Huannian Jiao, Pengyang Duan, Jianying Sun, Zheng Dai, Xiaoxuan Qi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To address the challenges of difficult coordination and low profitability for a Virtual Power Plant (VPP) participating in multiple electricity markets, which arise from rule discrepancies, resource fluctuations, and coupled decisions, a hierarchical multi-agent deep reinforcement learning strategy for cross-market trading is proposed. First, a two-level collaborative framework that integrates bidding prices and declared quantities is constructed. In this framework, each resource aggregation unit of the VPP is treated as an agent. The revenues from multiple markets, such as spot, ancillary services, and demand response, are integrated with factors like network security and operational stability into a unified reward function, forming a two-level finite Markov Decision Process (FMDP). In this process, the upper-level agents cooperate within the reward mechanism to recommend an optimal bidding price strategy. Simultaneously, the action-decision output from the upper-level network is incorporated into the state considerations of the <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>lower-level multi-agents. Based on the updated state information, the lower-level agents devise the multi-market declared quantity allocation. Furthermore, the Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MADDPG) algorithm is introduced to achieve collaborative and game-theoretic optimization for the multi-agents in cross-market trading. Finally, the proposed strategy is validated through simulations. The case study results indicate that the proposed method significantly improves the matching degree of declarations, thereby enhancing the cross-market profitability and flexible regulation capabilities of the VPP.

title: Research on Short-term Line Loss Rate Prediction Method of Distribution Network Based on RF-CNN-SVM
authors: Lin Jiang, Canbin Wang, Wei Qiu, Jiawei Yang, Zhenzhen Xu, Caili Xiang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Accurate prediction of line loss rate enables more economical and efficient decision-making in the power sector. This paper presents a short-term line loss rate forecasting method for distribution networks based on an integrated RF-CNN-SVM approach. Given the high-dimensional time-series characteristics of line loss data, the random forest algorithm is first applied to evaluate and rank the importance of multiple feature variables. A combined convolutional neural network and support vector machine (CNN-SVM) model is then constructed to perform the prediction. To demonstrate the superiority of the proposed model, comparative experiments are conducted against the CNN-SVM and standalone SVM models, without feature selection via random forest. The results confirm that the RF-CNN-SVM model achieves superior predictive performance.

title: The Deepfake Governance Gap: Navigating Global Regulation in an Age of Synthetic Realitiess
authors: Nir Kshetri, Jeffrey Voas
publish: Computer
abstract: This article examines the global struggle to regulate deepfake technology amid its rapid proliferation. It argues that effective governance requires agile, nuanced frameworks that curb harms while safeguarding free expression, innovation, and individual rights.

title: Assistive Wearable for Real-Time Posture Monitoring and Correction in Elderly Using Using Inertial Sensing
authors: Tresa Joseph, Nandhana T S, Rithika Ramesh, Rudra Sudheesh, Sona Savy
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Poor posture among elderly individuals contributes significantly to musculoskeletal disorders, chronic pain, and reduced mobility. Existing posture correction solutions suffer from high costs, bulky designs, and lack of real-time feedback mechanisms. This paper presents a cost-effective, lightweight wearable device that provides real-time posture monitoring and correction using an MPU9250 inertial measurement unit and ESP32 microcontroller. The system continuously monitors trunk angle deviations and provides immediate haptic feedback through a vibration motor when posture falls outside the optimal range of 70° to 110°. Additionally, the device integrates with the Blynk cloud platform to deliver real-time alerts to mobile applications. Experimental validation demonstrates accurate posture detection with response times less than one second and sustained operation exceeding eight hours on a single battery charge. The proposed system offers a practical alternative to traditional posture correction methods with applications in healthcare, office ergonomics, and elderly care.

title: Machine Learning-Assisted Screening of Pyrimidine-Pyrazole Derivatives as Steel Corrosion Inhibitors in Hydrochloric Solution
authors: Jaka Fajar Fatriansyah, Muhammad Ali Yafi Rizky, Rio Sudwitama Persadanta Kaban, Muhammad Rakha Alfarabi, Sharen Ardyana Khintani, Rayhan Hagel Safa
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Industrial corrosion poses significant economic and safety risks. This study evaluates the performance of pyrimidine-pyrazole derivatives as corrosion inhibitors for steel in hydrochloric acid. Various machine learning algorithms, including K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), Support Vector Regression (SVR), eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGB), Gradient Boosting (GB), Extra Trees (ET), and Artificial Neural Network (ANN), were trained on molecular descriptors from AlvaDesc to predict the inhibitor efficiency based on the electronic features. Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) was used to optimize model performance. Model accuracy was assessed using the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score, with XGB achieving the highest precision (96.50%). Further analysis using SHAP and Pearson Correlation identified the F02{N-N} descriptor as the most significant feature influencing EHOMO energy. The findings validate that machine learning, particularly the XGB model, provides an accurate and cost-effective approach for screening potential corrosion inhibitors.

title: Impact of Meta-Heuristic Hyper-Parameter Tuning in AI Based Fault Classification in a Grid Connected PV System
authors: Areeb Ahmed, Jatin Yadav, Gurpreet Singh, Rahul Virmani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive study on machine learning model based fault classification in grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) system. The study focuses on identifying six types of faults, including inverter faults, feedback sensor faults, PV array mismatches, and controller faults. Further, meta heuristic (Bio Inspired) hyper-parameter tuning a recent trend in Machine learning has also been addressed by implementing an approach based on Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and the results have been compared with the conventional techniques such as Grid Search and Random Search. The results demonstrate that the optimized KNN model achieves an accuracy of nearly 95% with the best hyper-parameters. The paper also compares the performance of different tuning methods on the performance metrics. This presented work intends to open a new approach to the area of hyper-parameter tuning.

title: AI-Powered Glasses for Visually Impaired
authors: Meena Kumari, Dhanshri Parihar, Anubhav Bewarwal, Gaurav Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Individuals who are visually impaired will utilize all of their remaining sensory capabilities to perform daily necessities, such as; navigation, identification of objects or individuals, recognition of people and/or printed material. This dependence on their other senses can negatively impact people's independence and their quality of life. For many, switching to alternative assistive devices such as walking canes or guide dogs provide some assistance, but fail to be real-time with their contextual information. This paper describes an artificial intelligent-powered set of smart glasses developed to be a personal assistant to visually impaired people. The glasses apply the latest machine learning algorithms to recognize objects, identify people by name, identify currency, read text, and give spatial information. The smart glasses operate using voice commands and provide a 180-degree view along with personalized sound feedback delivered stereo through a discreet speaker for ease of use and privacy as they navigate their environment. This work reflects a creative conception of how artificial intelligence can lead to versatile, multi-dimensional assistive devices that can enable greater independence and promote more inclusion for disabilities in our technologically advancing society. Future work will focus on expanding to a 360-degree view and improving environmental adaptation

title: Magnetic Transmission Performance Evaluation of Magnetic Gear and Magnetic Lead Screw
authors: Zhijian Ling, Jintuo Zheng, Meimei Xu, Hao Qin, Wenxiang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The magnetic transmission actuators have attracted increasing attention due to the advantages of high reliability and good converting performance. This paper investigates general magnetic field modulation theory for different kinds of magnetic transmission actuators. The coaxial magnetic gear (CMG) can transmit torque and rotary speed according to the magnetic field modulation. Extending this idea to linear topology, the concept of magnetic lead screw (MLS) is proposed. It can convert rotational motion into linear motion and vice versa, by helical magnetic field, and significantly improve thrust force. The capability of energy conversion is a key part of the magnetic transmission. To achieve better energy conversion, the magnetic field modulation theory is investigated. Afterwards, the electromagnetic performance, such as magnetic field modulation effect, and torque/thrust characteristic are analyzed. Finally, in order to facilitate manufacturing, a segmented manufacturing method is proposed.

title: Bio-Inspired Optimization for Channel Equalization: A Study on the African Vultures Algorithm
authors: Yashpal Singh, Suman Kumar Saha, Lakshminarayana Janjanam
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: In this paper, a Finite Impulse Response (FIR) designed for channel equalization, optimized by newly developed African Vultures Optimization Algorithm (AVOA), inspired by foraging behavior of African Vultures. Typically, FIR structure suffers from tuning of its parameter. Addressing channel distortion and non-linearities in high data rates wireless communication. This study demands advance equalization for Inter Symbolic Interference (ISI) reduction. The AVOA demonstrate a proper balance between the exploration and exploitation phase enhance the global searching capabilities preventing premature convergence. Also, through comparative study evaluates AVOA against Particle swarm optimization (PSO) and Sine cosine Algorithm (CeA) algorithm considering comprehending aspect of diverse channel model and non-linearities Bit Error Rate (BER) and Mean Square Error (MSE).

title: Sequence-Domain Impedance Model of Grid-Following VSCs with DC-Side Impedance Coupling
authors: Zhiwu Fang, Weiyu Wang, Ye Cai, Junyue Dou, Xiaoxing Lu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Most existing studies on grid-connected converters (GCCs) ignore the coupling effect introduced by the DC-side impedance and typically assume an ideal DC voltage source, which limits the accuracy of small-signal stability analysis. This paper develops a comprehensive full-sequence impedance model for three-phase voltage source converters (VSCs) that explicitly incorporates the coupling between the AC and DC sides. First, unified small-signal linearized models of the current inner loop, DC-link voltage outer loop, and phase-locked loop (PLL)) are established. Based on a two-port network representation, nine associated transfer functions are derived. Subsequently, DC-side small-signal models under constant-power source (CPS) and constant-current source (CCS) conditions are formulated and embedded into the impedance-coupling framework, resulting in complete sequence-domain impedance expressions that fully reflect AC–DC interaction. Finally, a frequency-sweep simulation platform is constructed in MATLAB/Simulink to validate the proposed model under three scenarios: ideal DC source, CPS, and CCS. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed model exhibits strong agreement with frequency-sweep responses and accurately reveals the impact of DC-side dynamics on the AC-side impedance characteristics of the VSC.

title: IndoBERT and IndoBERT-Lite Models in YouTube Comment Sentiment Analysis to Assess All-Age Viewing Suitability
authors: Muhammad Genta Syamsutizar, Deny Haryadi, Rana Zaini Fathiyana
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: YouTube is one of the most widely used digital platforms in Indonesia, attracting users of all ages, including children. This study aims to analyze public sentiment toward gaming content from the Windah Basudara and MiawAug channels to evaluate its suitability for young audiences. A total of 9,221 YouTube comments were collected using the YouTube Data API and preprocessed through case folding, stopword removal, and tokenizing. Using a lexicon of 1,996 Indonesian profanity words, each comment was labeled as "Friendly" or "Unfriendly," resulting in a highly imbalanced dataset (8,983 friendly and 238 unfriendly). Two transformer-based models, IndoBERT and IndoBERT-Lite, were fine-tuned for sentiment classification and evaluated using Accuracy, Precision, Recall, and F1-Score. IndoBERT achieved superior performance with 99.55% accuracy and an F1-Score of 95.88%, while IndoBERT-Lite achieved 99.27% accuracy and an F1-Score of 93.74%. These results indicate that both models effectively identify child-friendly and unfriendly comments, with IndoBERT offering higher precision and IndoBERT-Lite providing a more efficient alternative for real-time or resource-limited applications.

title: Impact of Mesh Density and Time-Step Variation on Losses and Torque Characteristics in 3D and 2D FEM Models of an Axial Flux Machine
authors: Vineetha Puttaraj, Sonja Tidblad Lundmark, Torbjörn Thiringer
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: The Finite Element Method (FEM) is a useful numerical tool for evaluating the electrical machine performance in two and three dimensions (2D and 3D), such as for the Axial Flux Machine (AFM), where the magnetic flux paths are distributed in 3D. However, as is well known, FEM is sensitive to the chosen space and time resolution (choice of mesh density and time step), and the sensitivity is highly dependent on the calculated parameters. This paper aims to quantify the considerations needed specifically when calculating the loss in Permanent Magnet (PM)s, the loss in the stator core, and the characteristics of the torque. The results show the threshold levels of mesh density and time resolution beyond which further refinement has an insignificant impact. Furthermore, this study demonstrates the selection of mesh density and time step resolution in electromagnetic transient simulations during the early stage modelling of AFMs. To validate these selections, a detailed analysis of losses and torque was conducted for a 2D, extruded 2D, and a 3D model. It was found that at no-load, the (cogging) torque in the 3D model is very sensitive to the mesh density, while at rated conditions, all models show less than 5% deviation of the average torque compared to the results with mesh and time discretization of a chosen trade-off point. Average core loss sensitivity to mesh is less than 1% when improving the mesh from medium to fine, for the 2D and 3D models, and sensitivity to time-steps is below 7% in 3D and 1% in the 2D AFM models. Magnet losses are sensitive to varying mesh density and time steps with a difference of 10% in 2D models and up to 3% for 3D models.

title: Vision-Based Adaptive Signal Control: A Comparative Study of YOLOv9, SSD, and Faster R-CNN
authors: Jovinto Ferdinand Kusniawan, Jeremy Ardhito Sulle, Nicholas Tjandra, Fiqri Ramadhan Tambunan, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Traffic jam is a serious and ongoing issue in Indonesia's big cities caused primarily by the utilization of fixed traffic light systems that cannot adapt to dynamic patterns of vehicle flow. This study presents a comparison of three object detectors—YOLOv9, SSD, and Faster R-CNN—for computer vision-based adaptive traffic light control, followed by operational simulations that translate visual counts into dynamic green durations. The models are trained/validated on a public vehicle dataset and evaluated using CCTV footage of Jakarta intersections. Accuracy is measured with mAP@0.50 on the held-out set: YOLOv9 achieves 0.6310 (LR=1e−2), SSD 0.7531 (LR=1e−3), and Faster R-CNN 0.7776 (LR=1e−4). The best model (Faster R-CNN) is then applied to a decision window approximately 5 seconds before the end of the red phase to count the number of vehicles per class in the count zone, which is then mapped to an adaptive green duration with minimum–maximum operational limits. Day–night testing highlighted the challenges of occlusion, motorcycle crowding, and low-light/glare conditions, yet the dynamic policy consistently improved performance: vehicles served increased from 291 to 313 per cycle (≈7%). These findings demonstrate that the off-the-shelf detector-based green detection, count and scheduling pipeline is capable of delivering measurable throughput improvements without the need for additional roadside sensors.

title: A Privacy-Preserving AI-Blockchain Framework for End-to-End Supply Chain Traceability
authors: Hayder Muhamed Abas, Priya Vij, Kurbonova Marguba Yuldashevna, T. Suresh, G Prema Swathi, D. Aarthi, Z.Y. Shukurova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Global supply chains deal with large volumes of essential products, and failure to track them back, whether in fake ingredients and slow recall, or faked records of certification, represents a huge challenge to the finances, policies, and even personal safety. The inability to provide real time checks between distributed stakeholders is characterized by fragmented systems, poor interoperability, and a failure to ensure scan-free audit trails on scale. The available strategies seek to fill these gaps but fail in critical aspects. The centralized ERP/MES systems do not enhance the entire visibility but introduce one-point systems of failure and poor data provenance. Public blockchains are not only immutable, but also have the disadvantage of having high transaction costs, high response time, and no data privacy. There is a better permission control, but there is no smooth fusion of the heterogeneous networks by Consortium blockchains. In the meantime, separate AI-powered risk detection systems are able to anticipate abnormalities, but are not incorporated into the execution layer to promptly institute remedial measures into the supply chain process. This paper proposes a privacy-preserving AI-integrated Layer-2 blockchain traceability framework that leverages Layer-2 rollups for scalable, low-cost event validation and AI-powered smart contracts for autonomous compliance and anomaly response. The design integrates IPFS-based off-chain storage, cross-chain interoperability, and decentralized identity verification (DID) to ensure privacy, scalability, and trust. Results demonstrate a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>99 \%$</tex> reduction in transaction cost and sub-minute counterfeit detection, establishing a scalable model for global, high-value supply chains. Smart contracts that use AI carry out compliance through automatic performance in case of risk identification. Constant retraining pipelines and sharding-based scaling also ensure more flexibility of the system and its ability to fasten over the long term. Product traceability is brought out as scalable, auditable and privacy intended with this integrated design. It shows an innovative architecture that minimizes verification latency, enhances detection of frauds and does not have single point of failure. Combining real-time risk analytics with fully automated, completely independent enforcement, the proposed framework will provide end-to-end visibility needed in global, high-value, and safety-sensitive supply chains.

title: Karana: A Post-Quantum Secure AI Surveillance System for Autonomous Multimodal Threat Detection
authors: Satyander Kaushik, Ravneet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Karana is a surveillance system driven by artificial intelligence (AI) that can identify threats instantly and react safely in ever-more complicated settings. Designed for industrial facilities, smart cities, and defense zones, Karana integrates edge AI, multimodal sensing, and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) into a single, intelligent platform. Because they rely on manual oversight, cloud inference, and monomodal inputs, traditional surveillance infrastructures are susceptible to cyberphysical breaches, spoofing, and lax reaction times. Even while AI-based systems improve visual analytics, many of them are still only capable of single-sensor streams and lack reliable, on-device decision-making, which makes them useless against threats from autonomous drones, GNSS jamming, and encrypted RF spoofing. By combining radio frequency (RF), infrared (IR), radar, and red-green-blue (RGB) video data, Karana fills in these gaps. An edge AI engine that runs Swin Transformer, You Only Look Once version 8 (YOLOv8), and a suggested quantum-inspired classifier processes these. Rapid, context-aware threat mitigation is made possible by this approach, which also removes reliance on external processing. CRYSTALS-Kyber and Dilithium2, two PQC protocols that comply with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), are used to strengthen security. A policydriven rule engine automatically chooses graded non- lethal actions, including alarm broadcasts, lockdowns, or signal jamming, based on the type and origin of the threat. Karana maintained an average inference latency of 52.9 milliseconds across multimodal inputs and obtained an F1 score of 90.0 when validated with simulation workflows. These findings validate realtime performance in hostile, low-light, and spoofing scenarios. Future stages will include adversarial robustness testing and hardware optimization.

title: Digital Twin and Machine Learning-Enabled Reliability Assessment for Distribution Networks: a Hybrid Framework
authors: Zhaoxing Chen, Qiuchen Li, Zhongyu Ma, Yanan Meng, Yu Yin
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the integration of distributed generation (DG), electric vehicles (EVs), and smart loads, modern distribution networks (DNs) exhibit high complexity and dynamic uncertainty, posing significant challenges to traditional reliability assessment (RA) methods. This paper proposes a hybrid RA framework fusing Digital Twin (DT) and Machine Learning (ML) to address the trade-off between assessment accuracy and computational efficiency. First, a high-fidelity DT model of the DN is constructed to realize real-time mapping of physical system states (e.g., load fluctuations, DG output, and equipment health) via 5G-edge computing. Second, a long short-term memory-gated recurrent unit (LSTM-GRU) hybrid model is designed to predict key fault parameters (fault duration, affected range) by leveraging historical fault data and real-time DT feedback. Third, an improved Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) algorithm is proposed to prune low-probability fault scenarios based on DT-realized system states, reducing computational redundancy while ensuring assessment precision. The framework is validated on IEEE 33-bus and 123 -bus test systems, with results showing that compared to traditional MCS and single ML methods, the proposed approach reduces SAIDI (System Average Interruption Duration Index) and SAIFI (System Average Interruption Frequency Index) prediction errors by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 2 \% - 2 0. 3 \%}$</tex> and shortens computational time by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 2. 6 \% - 4 1. 8 \%}$</tex>. This work provides a practical tool for DN operators to optimize maintenance strategies and enhance power supply reliability.

title: Thermal Compatibility of Immersion Phase Change Cooling System Medium with High Power IGBT Material
authors: Lejia Song, Shilin Shi, Fengshun Jiao, Liming Wang, Fanghui Yin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The immersion phase change cooling technology is one of the effective methods to address the high heat dissipation requirements of high-power IGBTs. However, the compatibility between the phase change cooling medium and the materials of IGBT devices has not been studied yet. This paper conducts a compatibility study of the typical phase change cooling medium perfluorohexane (PFH) with the materials of IGBT devices. The results show that PFH has good compatibility with single-crystal silicon, PCB boards, and bakelite, and the fluorine content will decrease after compatibility with fluorine-containing substances such as fluoroceramic rings. The research results provide a reference for the selection of the immersion phase change cooling system medium for IGBTs.

title: A Cost-Aware Retraining Recalibration Strategy in Communication Network
authors: Akanksha Singh, Ratneshwer
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Concept drift refers to the change in the statistical distribution of data over time such that the relationship between input features and target output no longer remains stable [1]. It is a phenomenon that machine learning models deployed in communication networks generally face. However, frequent retraining is one solution that can help resolve this problem, but it also incurs high costs and consumes high resources when deployed to large-scale real-world networks. To address this problem, this paper proposes two complementary approaches: a cost-aware retraining strategy and a few-shot retraining strategy, which enable machine learning models to stay accurate even if applied to a highly dynamic environment. The proposed approaches are applied and tested on the SOFI dataset [4]. Additionally, a comparative analysis is conducted with a baseline method. Experimental results demonstrated that our proposed models maintain a competitive accuracy under drift while reducing the frequency of retraining and adapt effectively in the scenario of limited data.

title: Design and Simulation of Software Defined Radar
authors: Dubasi Jhansi, Shaik Karishma, P M Menghal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: In This paper focuses on the design and simulation of a Software-Defined Radar (SDR) system using MATLAB Simulink, integrated with a Graphical User Interface (GUI) for real-time control and visualization. The system leverages SDR technology to enable dynamic configuration of radar parameters such as waveform selection, pulse width, modulation, and gain control. The radar model incorporates range and doppler processing, time-varying gain, and pulse integration, enhancing detection performance for high-range applications. The simulation-based approach ensures flexibility, cost-effectiveness, and scalability, making the system suitable for applications in defence, surveillance, automotive radar, and remote sensing.
