This work highlights the potential of SDR technology in radar systems by offering a reconfigurable, software-driven approach to high-performance radar signal processing.

title: A Gated Fusion Framework for Multimodal Urdu Named Entity Recognition
authors: Eihab Zaidi, Md. Shah Fahad, Saurabh Sharma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Named Entity Recognition is an integral part of Natural Language Processing. However, there are several chal-lenges associated with low-resource languages like Urdu, the key being data scarcity and the complex syntactic nature. The study explores the usage of speech as an additional modality to overcome the challenges posed and enhance the performance of NER models by providing prosodic and acoustic cues that help in the disambiguation of the entities. A robust aligned data pipeline is first prepared by converting an existing text only dataset to a text and speech dataset and extracting the desired features. These along with the textual features are then fed to the model encompassing layers involving a Bidirectional - Long Short Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) - Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) encoder and a gated fusion mechanism that dynamically blends the two modalities together to produce the result. The results revealed a 2.36% relative improvement of the F1-score over the text-based baseline model. These findings validate the idea of the efficacy of a multimodal NER model involving textual and acoustic features and allow for the exploration of the technique in future research avenues.

title: Enhancing Industrial Productivity through Integrated Automation Control Systems Using Edge-Based Smart Digitization Techniques
authors: Ruchi Sharma, Sreeja Rashmitha Duvvada, S. Suma Christal Mary, G Sajiv, Manoranjan Dash, I Infant Raj
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Thing demands real-time, reliable, and efficient automation control systems to enhance productivity. Existing methods often suffer from high latency, limited local processing capabilities, and inefficient resource allocation, resulting in delayed responses and increased maintenance costs. This study proposes an Adaptive Edge-Driven Control Optimization framework that integrates lightweight predictive models deployed at edge nodes with advanced sensor fusion techniques to enable real-time data analysis and decision-making. The main goal is to bring messages across as fast as possible, ensure accurate predictions, improve constant operation and do so with as little upkeep cost as possible. AEDCO is unique because it uses a flexible way to assign resources at the edges combined with effective controls, allowing reliable and efficient operations in factories. The experiment has shown that these innovations result in a latency of 35 ms, high accuracy in predictions at $96.4 \%, 98.5 \%$ of system uptime and a $32 \%$ cut in maintenance costs compared to traditional cloud solutions. Thanks to LSTM for forecasting and MQTT for live data transmission, the overall system can work with large amounts of data while being robust to errors. On the whole, using the method proposes a useful method for efficient and inexpensive smart industry automation with the help of intelligent edge-based processing.

title: Neuromorphic Architectures for Real-Time Speech Processing in Noisy Environments
authors: Jyotsna Dwivedi, V. Mangaiyarkarasi, Ramy R. Hussein, Pitta Geetha Bhavani, N. V. Balaji, Saodat Kambarova, Azizov Marufkhuja Ahmatkhonovich
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The processing of speech in acoustic cluttered environments (such as the cocktail party problem) continues to be an extremely difficult problem to the artificial auditory system. In this case, the human listeners excel at isolating and parsing speech through the use of biologically efficient neural networks, as opposed to conventional digital signal processing systems which are characterized by latency, energy dissipation and poor performance in multitalking or noisy conditions. In order to overcome these inadequacies, neuromorphic computing has emerged as one of the new radiant approaches by simulating the biological auditory pathway with respect to its structure and functionality. The framework that integrates a biologically-inspired cochlear front-end, attentional spiking neural units, and attention-directed temporal fidelity that has recently been proposed in this paper is called the Attention-Gated Spiking-FullSubNet (AGS-FSN). To achieve localization and separation of sounds, Cochlear unit performs this frequency decomposition in a neuromorphic filter bank whose phase and timing representations are crucial to sound localization and separation. Events Implemented and Gated spiking neuron, event-driven paradigm reduces computational cost and is very energy-efficient. FullSubNet-Like attention mechanism permits the selective amplification of the pertinent parts of the speech of the background speech interference to the side. Extensive experiments on noisy real world datasets reveal that AGS-FSN demonstrates state-of-the-art hearing enhancement and recognition capability, easily surpassing the conventional deep learning models by a large margin in terms of accuracies, and power consumption. The design is aimed at the neuromorphic hardware devices such as field-programmable gate arrays and event-based silicon processors, which offers a reasonable path to low-power and real-time edge AI via audition. AGS-FSN is a new milestone of robust/scalable and biologically-inspired speech processing in diverse acoustic conditions.

title: Low-Cost Portable Digital Shadow for Radiative WPT Systems
authors: Henrique Figueiredo Chaves, Helena Ribeiro, Amit Baghel, Nuno Borges Carvalho
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost and portable digital shadow architecture for radiative wireless power transmission systems, combining off-the-shelf RF hardware, ESP32-based telemetry nodes, and live MATLAB analytics. The platform achieves continuous performance monitoring with negligible sensing overhead, while evaluating a Power Amplifier operating directly from a standard Li-Po battery. Supercapacitor energy storage supports controlled high-current bursts under live supervision, all delivered at a fraction of the cost of traditional bench instrumentation. Providing real-time insights in lab and field, this digital shadow enables closed-loop digital twins with adaptive power control and multi-harvester aggregation.

title: Resilient-Sustainable Winner Determination for Raw Material Procurement Auctions of Electric Vehicle Batteries
authors: Jinman Tong, Xiaohong Wang, Ce Gao, Yang Cao
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the increasing geopolitical instability and supply chain risks, the procurement of raw materials for electric vehicle batteries (EVBs) faces frequent disruptions. Although existing studies have explored the issue of EVB raw material procurement from various aspects, the impact of disruptions from cross-border material suppliers on procurement decisions is rarely analyzed. In this paper, a new stochastic resilience and sustainability winner determination model is proposed, aimed at solving the supplier selection problem in EVB raw material procurement, and integrates risk mitigation strategies such as multi-source procurement, fortification, reservation, and emergency procurement. To enhance the efficiency of solving the model, a heuristic algorithm based on reduced scenario and relaxation technique is developed. Numerical experiments based on problem analysis are carried out to confirm the validity of the designed model and algorithm. Results show that the designed algorithm achieves better performance than traditional solving methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. Sensitivity analysis reveals that the maximum fortification investment budget and key parameters for emergency procurement significantly influence the selection of disruption mitigation strategies. The research results, which provide a theoretical basis and managerial insights for the sustainability and resilience of global EVB raw material procurement, especially in high-risk environments where energy supply fluctuates significantly.

title: Information Extraction and Standardization from Scanned Medical Reports using Vision Language Models
authors: Mohamed Mehfoud Bouh, Abdullah Al Noman, Prajat Paul, Forhad Hossain, Ashir Ahmed
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Most clinical data remain unstructured in the form of scanned laboratory reports, which hinders retrieval, integration, and analysis. This unstructured nature also increases physicians’ workload by requiring extensive manual review, thereby reducing efficiency and delaying decision-making. This paper presents a pipeline that extracts structured content from hematology and hemogram scanned medical reports using vision–language models (VLMs) and standardizes outputs into HL7 FHIR for interoperable exchange. A task-specific flat JSON schema and a standardized prompt guided three state-of-the-art VLMs (Qwen2.5–VL–72B, Gemini 2.5 Pro, GPT–5), each evaluated across three independent trials per report. Extraction performance was measured using Micro-Accuracy, F1-score, Per-Type Accuracy, and Latency under both Strict and Loose normalization modes. On hematology, Qwen2.5–VL–72B achieved the highest MicroAcc (0.83 Strict, 0.89 Loose) and F1 (0.79, 0.88); Gemini was competitive and fastest (46–56s), while GPT–5 exhibited slower processing (170–189s). On hemogram, Qwen reached the highest MicroAcc (0.92 Strict/Loose) and Gemini achieved the top F1 (0.93). Loose normalization improved accuracy by +0.05–+0.08 over Strict, demonstrating robustness to typographic variation. The best-performing outputs were mapped into HL7 FHIR R5 Bundles with integrated LOINC terminology and validated using the official FHIR Validator, confirming semantic and structural compliance. These results demonstrate that VLMs can effectively transform scanned laboratory reports into validated, machine-readable FHIR resources with minimal post-processing, providing a foundation for interoperable medical data digitization. Future work should address generalizability across diverse report formats and privacy considerations through on-premise deployment of open-source models.

title: Temperature Field Characteristic Analysis Based on Dynamometer Measurements of a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor
authors: Yuyang Liu, Li Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: To analyze the temperature field characteristics of permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM) under realistic and diverse operating conditions, a dynamometer-based measurement framework is established. A statistical analysis of axial, radial, and circumferential temperature distributions is conducted based on measured data. The results show that the windings exhibit the largest axial temperature difference, reaching up to 48.6 °C, with hotspots typically located at the end windings. In addition, radial and circumferential gradients can reach up to 114.7 °C and 41.1 °C, respectively. This study provides practical guidance for both the design of dynamometer experiments and the development of more accurate and physically meaningful thermal models.

title: Continuous Power Flow-Based Cooperative Optimization of Multiple SVGs in a Looped Power Network in Xinjiang
authors: Lei Yang, Tian Yizhi, Wu Guanyu, Luo Peng, Sun Zhiyong
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of voltage regulation in a long-chain looped network in a certain region of Xinjiang, where the grid is predominantly integrated with renewable energy and lacks stable power sources. In such a network, the multi-path characteristics of power flow frequently lead to issues such as voltage limit violations, reverse reactive power flow, and line overloads. Although the Static Var Generator (SVG) can serve as a dynamic reactive power compensation device to effectively support node voltage, multiple SVGs operating independently based solely on local information are prone to reactive power compensation conflicts and voltage fluctuations, making global optimization difficult. To tackle this issue, this paper establishes a multi-objective optimization function based on the continuous power flow algorithm, taking into account the stochastic nature of renewable energy generation. A coordinated operation strategy for three SVGs is proposed to achieve optimal allocation of reactive power resources and coordinated voltage control, thereby enhancing the stability and economic efficiency of system operation.

title: Potato Leaf Disease Classification Using Vision Transformers
authors: V. Meghana, S. Akanksha, P. Kaushik Reddy, M. A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Deep learning has completely transformed plant disease detection by making it possible to classify leaf conditions automatically, accurately, and efficiently. CNNs have been the most common approach to this problem so far, but they can be restricted by their local feature extraction in capturing the global contextual information of an image. This current study looks into the potential of Vision Transformers (ViTs) in classifying potato leaf diseases to go beyond these limitations. ViTs use the self-attention mechanism on images by considering them as rows of fixed-size patches. This makes the model able to learn global relations throughout the whole image, thus increasing its capability to recognize the faint and scattered patterns that are symptomatic of the various diseases. Here, the ViT model is being re-trained on a multi-class classification task of potato leaf conditions. The architecture based on the transformer model enables it to place its focus on the most suitable sections of the image in a flexible manner; hence, the model is more interpretable, and robustness is increased. ViTs, which have less reliance on inductive biases as compared to CNNs, are capable of generalizing better if they are fed with enough training data. The model set a new record by achieving a test accuracy of 99.82%. These results indicate that Vision Transformers can act as an impactful aid for plant disease classification and, therefore, are the initial phase towards more reliable and extensible solutions in precision agriculture.

title: AquaFed: Leveraging Federated Learning for Real-Time Schistosomiasis Prevention Through Water Quality Monitoring
authors: Mohamed Mohsen, Hamada Rizk, Moustafa Youssef
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Schistosomiasis, a waterborne parasitic disease caused by trematode flatworms of the genus Schistosoma, transmitted through skin contact with freshwater containing infectious larvae released by specific snail hosts, remains a critical public health concern in endemic regions, where early detection and intervention are vital for effective disease prevention. This work presents AquaFed, a decentralized system for real-time monitoring and forecasting of water quality parameters and freshwater snail populations—key indicators in schistosomiasis transmission. AquaFed leverages Federated Learning (FL) in combination with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to enable predictive modeling across distributed IoT sensor kits. By training models locally and sharing only model updates, AquaFed significantly reduces communication bandwidth during both training and inference, while stabilizing local updates and accelerating global convergence, in addition to enabling scalable deployment in resource-constrained environments. Experimental evaluations conducted in a schistosomiasis-endemic region of Burkina Faso demonstrate that AquaFed achieves forecasting performance on par with traditional centralized learning approaches, while reducing the utilization of the communication bandwidth. These findings underscore the potential of AquaFed as a robust, communication-efficient platform for real-time risk assessment and proactive schistosomiasis control.

title: A Systematic Review of Flood and Landslide Prediction Using Deep Learning
authors: Lalit Verma, Kuldeep Kumar Kushwaha, Sukhwinder Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Floods and landslides are increasingly frequent natural disasters with devastating social and economic impacts. this project presents a deep learning-based approach leveraging convolutional neural networks(cnns) for spatial feature extraction from satellite and sensor data, and recurrent neural networks specifically, long short-term memory (lstm) models, and(rnns) for capturing temporal dependencies in weather and environmental patterns. by integrating multimodal data sources—such as remote sensing, telemetry, and social media—into a unified predictive framework, the system enhances real-time detection and early warning capabilities. with optimized accuracy exceeding 90% for critical risk classifications and minimal mean absolute percentage error in forecasting key variables, the model aims to support timely decision-making in disaster-prone regions.

title: Review of Indian and Global Electric Vehicle Charging Standards: Opportunities and Challenges for Emerging Economies
authors: Meet Parab, Het Bhalja, Amit V. Sant, Nirav Karelia
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: India's unique electric mobility transition, dominated by two-wheelers and constrained by its distribution grid, requires a tailored charging ecosystem to sustain market growth. This paper reviews India's charging infrastructure, focusing on connector standards and their technical implications compared to global electric vehicle standards. It evaluates indigenous protocols like Bharat AC-001 and Bharat DC-001 against global systems such as the Combined Charging System (CCS), comparing operating voltages, power levels, and interoperability. While Bharat standards offer low-cost, gridsensitive solutions for light EVs, CCS provides scalability for high-power fast charging. The study also examines India's current EV market, highlighting the coexistence of diverse standards, battery types, ratings and emerging capabilities like Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G). A key opportunity lies in V2G, where an aggregated fleet of enabled vehicles could function as a distributed energy resource, providing crucial grid stabilization services and helping to cater to peak demand, thereby mitigating stress on the distribution network. The paper concludes that aligning domestic standards with international protocols, while considering local constraints, is critical for building a robust, future-ready charging infrastructure that can fully leverage these advanced V2G capabilities for India's EV ecosystem.

title: Deep Learning Framework for Secure and Revocable Face Template Protection
authors: Pritam Kumar Raul, Mulagala Sandhya, Bala Prakasa Rao Killi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Because biometric templates kept in databases can be stolen and misused, Face Recognition technologies now have significant security vulnerabilities. Accurate recognition is often compromised by traditional template protection techniques. Strong solutions that maintain high efficiency while guaranteeing template security are required due to the increasing use of face authentication. This study proposes a deep learning-based architecture that uses InsightFace and ResNet100 to extract features while safeguarding cryptographic templates. To protect biometric data, the system employs revocable transformations, random projection, and dynamic salting. L2 normalization standardizes feature magnitudes, enabling consistent similarity comparison while maintaining the irreversibility of transformed templates. After MTCNN based face identification, the pipeline extracts 512-dimensional embeddings and performs L2 normalization. AES-256 encryption and XOR-based revocation are used to protect the features after they are projected into a 400-dimensional space and binarized using a median threshold. The protected templates are matched using cosine similarity. With EERs of 0.00% and 6.80%, respectively, the evaluation reveals with VGGFace2 and LFW datasets 99.98% and 93. 23%, respectively. The method outperforms BioHashing with an accuracy of 11.5% in VGGFace2 and offers reversible templates. It achieves 400-bit security with less than 2% FRR in a spoken dataset, which is very viable in the real world and offers a better balance between security and performance than existing methods.

title: Model-Free Adaptive Predictive Speed Control for PMSM Based on Dynamic Linearization
authors: Anqi Situ, Xiaojun Zhang, Weiqiang Sun, Jiaqiang Yang, Ruoyu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The conventional speed loop PI control for PMSM requires motor parameters such as rotational inertia and flux linkage, which are often difficult to adjust, especially when there is a mismatch in motor parameters, the control performance will be greatly deteriorated. To solve this problem, a model-free adaptive predictive speed control method based on dynamic linearization is proposed. More specifically, the proposed method introduces a real-time updating parameter, transforming the nonlinear motor system into an equivalent incremental linear system, which achieves the adaptive control effect and only requires the input and output of the control system. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed control method has fast convergence ability, bounded input-output stability, and has great advantages over traditional PI controllers.

title: IoT-Enabled Nanogrid System for Real-Time Energy Data Monitoring and Analysis
authors: V S B Chaitanya Duvvury, Samala Richender Reddy, Mohammed Naheem Basha, Koppula Anusha, Gaini Ramani
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper examines the feasibility of integrating cost-effective IoT technology into a Nanogrid system for real-time energy data analysis. A nanogrid installed at the BVRIT academic campus in Narsapur, India, can support a load of approximately 300 watts independently from the utility grid. The system comprises six LED lamps, a streetlight, and a ceiling fan, powered by two 12V, 150 Ah batteries and a 24 V, 1500 VA, 1200 W inverter. A timer controls the operation of the loads, switching them ON at 6 PM and OFF at 5 AM. Initially, two IoT modules, each equipped with a Pzem004T and a NodeMCU, were deployed to conduct a feasibility study on real-time energy data extraction. The collected data was automatically logged into a Google spreadsheet. Over three days, the energy data was collected under varying load conditions, and battery voltages were recorded manually before and after load disconnection. The inverter efficiency was evaluated under three distinct loading conditions, yielding values of 51.72%, 43.22%, and 51.90% respectively. Future work aims to expand the Nanogrid system on campus, contributing to sustainable development goals.

title: Dialogue Policy Learning: Reinforcement Learning Strategies for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems in Customer Service
authors: Gaddam Prathik Kumar, Pratiksha Katyayni, Namratha D P, Aryan Saxena, Niteesh Kumar S, Jyoti Parashar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Reinforcement learning provides a dynamic framework where systems can learn and enhance dialogue strategies with feedback and user experience. The problem stated in this paper is the challenge of finding an effective dialogue policy that reflects efficiency, accuracy, and user satisfaction for task-oriented dialogue systems. This paper provides an analysis on the use of reinforcement learning techniques for dialogue policy learning for customer service applications. For taskoriented dialog systems, particularly customer service, learning a dialogue policy is crucial for creating natural and efficient interactions between human users and automated agents. Rule-based systems do not have the ability to cope with the complexity and variability of customer interaction and tend to introduce stiff and non-optimal conversations. The purpose of the study is to explore and implement advanced reinforcement learning methods for dialogue policy learning with a purpose of improving customer service dialogues in terms of responsiveness, personalization, and user experience. Based on comparative analysis and experiments, the paper compares the performance of numerous reinforcement learning methods, including policy gradient methods & deep Q-learning, in real-world customer service scenarios. The results project the potential of these methods to enhance dialogue systems to be more natural, efficient, and user-focused conversations. This paper aims to bring about the enhancement of intelligent customer service solutions prioritizing user satisfaction and interaction.

title: Detecting and Counting Human Presence using Device Free Wi-Fi Channel State Information
authors: Udayveer Singh, Sudhir Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This work introduces a method for human presence detection and counting based on Channel State Information (CSI). We address the problem of noisy CSI data by applying a Hampel and Savitzky-Golay filter as pre-processing, followed by segmentation of data to extract significant features. The segmented data are classified with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Residual-CNN networks. The results from the experiments exhibit high accuracy classification of 98.75% for human presence detection and 97.78% for crowd counting in differentiating between 0–5 persons. Notably, for presence detection and crowd counting experiment, the data is obtained from three rooms of varying occupancy loads and different transmitter–receiver distances, and the models performed equally well in these varied test settings. Further, The model is tested on an external dataset not used during training and 95.60% accuracy proves its robustness and generalizability across different device placements and environmental conditions. After classification the output is sent via UDP from PC to IoT device which then sends the message to authorized user devices for notification or control. This shows the capability of combining signal processing and deep learning for human presence detection and counting in real world scenarios.

title: Iterative Learning Robust Security Predictive Control for Batch Process Subject to Deception Attacks
authors: Baishuang Song, Shiqi Wang, Hui Li, Huiyuan Shi, Ping Li
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the increasing integration of network control technology in batch processes, the need for robust security control has become more critical. To address the challenges posed by deception attacks in small time delay batch processes, prior studies on iterative learning control have overlooked the possibility that the successive characteristics of batch processes might obscure the patterns of deceptive attacks. Moreover, relying on offline iterative learning control gains leads to significant system state deviations over time. To overcome these limitations, we propose an iterative learning robust security predictive control approach, which introduces robust security set to constrain the system state within a safe range and enhance robustness. Meanwhile, the iterative learning controller integrates deception- attack related data from previous batches, which can continuous optimization and improve control performance. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Sepsis Risk Prediction Using Temporal Convolutional Networks Applied to Time-Series Health Monitoring Data
authors: I.S. Chakrapani, Rahul Pradhan, Manivannan Govindasamy, Dr Anita Pradhan, Dr Ajmeera Kiran, M Ponni Valavan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Sepsis is a critical disease that can be diagnosed and, thereby, lead to a decrease in death, and better outcomes. The conventional SIRS and SOFA score systems cannot reflect the pattern of sepsis development, and thus they lead to delays. Although LSTM and GRU are sequential and treat sequential health data, they are computationally cost-prohibitive. The authors have presented a time-series-based TCN approach to early sepsis using EHR, which can demonstrate good performance on long-range dependencies with a parallel workflow and hence can be used in the real-time clinical setting. Model, LSTM, GRU, XGBoost, and Logistic Regression are tested basing on AUC-ROC, accuracy, precision, and recall. Essential risk indicators that SHAP analysis emphasizes are vital signs including heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate. SMOTE and weighted loss are used against class imbalance. The studied TCN has the accuracy of 88% and 0.92 AUC-ROC, demonstrating its usefulness in early detection of sepsis in tertiary care.

title: Telemedicine Access for Rural Healthcare in Nabha
authors: Mathivanan P, Rajadurai R, Prakash B, Chandran M
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Digital technologies have transformed the global healthcare systems in several ways. In spite of this, there is still a huge disparity between urban and rural regions in terms of access to health care in India. It is also mostly because of the lack of qualified medical personnel, inadequate infrastructure, and bad connectivity. This paper proposes a telemedicine platform named MediLink that would address these problems in such rural areas as Nabha. MediLink enables consultation within a low-bandwidth setting through integrated secure electronic health record (EHR) administration in the setting of adaptive streaming and artificial intelligence (AI) syndromic analysis. It involves the continuous use of care and offline synchronization frequents to be certain the safety of patient data by means of AES-256 encryption. The platform creates awareness on preventative healthcare and enhances cooperation between tertiary institutions and the Primary Health Centres (PHCs). MediLink has been experimentally demonstrated to be effective, reliable, and safe in supplying healthcare in different connectivity environments. The technology facilitates the National Digital Health Mission in India and aids in reducing the healthcare disparities between urban and rural regions.

title: Autonomous Vehicle For A Smart And Safer Mobility
authors: K Uma Rani, M U Anusha, Y P Tharun Gowda, K G Manu, P Kushal, Maanya S Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper presents a cost-efficient autonomous vehicle prototype aimed at improving road safety and mobility through embedded hardware and computer vision. The system employs a dual-controller design using Raspberry Pi 5 and Pico W boards in coordination with onboard cameras. YOLOv11 is used for lane segmentation, and YOLOv8 for pothole detection, enabling real-time perception with OpenCV support. Accident detection is achieved using accelerometer and vibration sensors, while GPS and GSM modules transmit emergency alerts with precise location data. In addition, adaptive headlight control automatically adjusts illumination according to environmental conditions. Experimental evaluation shows $99 \%$ accuracy in lane detection and $85 \%$ accuracy in pothole detection. The integration of vision-based perception, sensor-driven accident recognition, and adaptive lighting into a unified low-cost platform highlights the potential of embedded AI to enhance the safety and practicality of autonomous driving systems.

title: GAN-Empowered Parasitic Covert Communication: Data Privacy in Next-Generation Networks
authors: Pengcheng Guo, Zhi Lin, Haotong Cao, Yifu Sun, Kuljeet Kaur, Sherif Moussa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The widespread integration of artificial intelligence (AI) in next-generation communication networks poses a serious threat to data privacy while achieving advanced signal processing. Eavesdroppers can use AI-based analysis to detect and reconstruct transmitted signals, leading to serious leakage of confidential information. In order to protect data privacy at the physical layer, we redefine covert communication as an active data protection mechanism. We propose a new parasitic covert communication framework in which communication signals are embedded into dynamically generated interference by generative adversarial networks (GANs). This method is implemented by our CDGUBSS (complex double generator unsupervised blind source separation) system. The system is explicitly designed to prevent unauthorized AI-based strategies from analyzing and compromising signals. For the intended recipient, the pretrained generator acts as a trusted key and can perfectly recover the original data. Extensive experiments have shown that our framework achieves powerful covert communication, and more importantly, it provides strong defense against data reconstruction attacks, ensuring excellent data privacy in next-generation wireless systems.

title: Dual-Transduction MEMS Gas Sensor for H and CO Identification Across Humidity_supp1-3660610.docx
authors: Wenjun Yan
publish: N/A
abstract: Selective discrimination between explosive H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> and CO gases while preserving moisture resistance is of paramount importance. Conventional metal–oxide–semiconductor (MOS) gas sensors suffer from poor selectivity, and reliable multigas identification with a single device remains challenging. Here, we report a microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) gas sensor that integrates two transduction mechanisms, enabling single-sensor gas identification. We demonstrate this innovative approach through the simultaneous measurement of chemiresistive response and temperature change of the sensing layer. Due to gas-specific catalytic exothermic reaction and distinct redox rates on the MOS surface, and maintaining stability under humidity, the relatively independent resistive and calorimetric signals allow robust classifications of H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> and CO gases across humidity conditions using linear discriminant analysis (LDA). We hope our work could resolve the key bottleneck in multigas identification via a single device and offer guidance for intelligent gas sensor technology with compact MEMS platforms.

title: Defending Backdoor Attacks in Task-Oriented Multi-User Semantic Communication: A Contrastive Training Approach
authors: Jincheng Peng, Huanlai Xing, Lexi Xu, Shouxi Luo, Penglin Dai, Li Feng, Laha Ale, Bowen Zhao, Zhiwen Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Multi-user semantic communication enables multiple users (such as mobile devices) to collaborate on intelligent tasks, reducing communication load while enhancing efficiency. However, it is vulnerable to backdoor attacks due to the absence of auditing mechanisms for mobile users. In such attacks, malicious attackers can inject carefully crafted samples to implant backdoor neurons into the target model, which can be triggered to mispredict the target class based on the attacker's intent. Most existing defense methods for backdoor attacks are inadaptable to semantic communication systems, post-analysis, and are unable to respond timely. To address these challenges, we propose Reject-BD, a contrastive training-based defense mechanism tailored for multi-user semantic communication systems. Firstly, Reject-BD can actively apply test gradients to local semantic encoders. Then, contrastive training is used to amplify the differences in the updated test gradients of different clients to predict the credence degree of each client. Finally, the global semantic decoder is dynamically updated according to each client's credence degree. Experimental results demonstrate that Reject-BD effectively reduces the success rate of backdoor attacks while maintaining relatively high classification accuracy of the semantic decoder compared to five baseline methods.

title: Simplified Ultra-Wideband Tightly Coupled Antenna (SUTCA) Array with Improved Bandwidth and Superior Performance
authors: Hong Tang, S. M. Rakibul Hasan Shawon, Boyang Xiang, Yunxi Dong, Yi Huang, Huan Zhao, Bowen Zheng, Hualiang Zhang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents a simplified ultra-wideband tightly coupled antenna (SUTCA) array that achieves unprecedented bandwidth without lossy materials or frequency selective surfaces. The proposed design features a remarkably streamlined architecture comprising only four components: a monopole‑type radiator, a tapered balun, a ground plane, and a PTFE superstrate. A key innovation lies in directly connecting the balun ground line to the coupling plate rather than to radiator ground arms, a fundamental departure from conventional tightly coupled dipole arrays (TCDAs). This new scheme eliminates the low-frequency loop resonance that has historically limited TCDA bandwidth, enabling ultra-wideband operation while maintaining structural simplicity. The superstrate serves as a quarter-wavelength transformer, optimizing impedance matching at lower frequencies. The simulated array unit-cell can achieve a bandwidth of 12.13:1, from 0.75 GHz to 9.10 GHz, with simulated active VSWR less than 2.64 across the whole band. Since neither lossy materials nor lossless frequency selective surfaces are employed, the proposed array radiating element maintains high radiation efficiency (>98%) and excellent co/cross polarization ratio (>52 dB) across the whole band when scanning to the broadside. The array profile remains low at 0.40λhigh without the superstrate (0.97λhigh including the superstrate). To validate the proposed design concept, a 10×10 antenna array prototype was fabricated and tested. Comprehensive measurements, including active VSWRs, radiation patterns, and realized gain, validate the simulated performance. Measured active VSWR is less than 2.82 at broadside and less than 3.46 when scanning to 45° in E-, H-, and D-planes. The synthesized array realized gain implies total efficiency higher than 80% and co/cross polarization ratio higher than 20 dB across most of the band. Simulated and measured patterns agree well for broadside and 45° scanning. This work represents the first reported tightly coupled array achieving bandwidth exceeding 10:1 while simultaneously maintaining high efficiency and good polarization purity.

title: From Prediction to Prescription: A Causal-AI for Personalized Learning Path Optimization in MOOCs
authors: Chukwuemeka Paul Isiwu, Leonard Chukwualuka Nnadi, Yutaka Watanobe
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) generate vast amounts of learner interaction data, enabling predictive models to identify at-risk students. However, most existing approaches stop at prediction, offering limited guidance on which interventions should be applied to improve outcomes. This paper proposes a Causal-AI–driven reinforcement learning (RL) framework that transitions from prediction to prescription by integrating causal effect estimation with policy optimization. Specifically, uplift modeling is employed to estimate heterogeneous treatment effects of candidate learning actions, and these causal signals are embedded into an Actor–Critic RL agent through causal regularization. The resulting framework prescribes adaptive intervention policies that are both data-driven and causally grounded. We evaluate the approach on the OULAD dataset. Baseline predictive models achieve strong accuracy (AUC = 0.795) and calibration, while uplift distributions reveal heavy-tailed heterogeneity across learners. Off-policy evaluation demonstrates that the causal-RL policy consistently outperforms the observed behavior and standard RL baselines (Greedy Uplift SNIPS ≈ 0.619 vs. baseline 0.589). Subgroup analysis highlights disparities across age and gender, motivating fairness-aware extensions. A case study further illustrates how adaptive recommendations can redirect learner trajectories toward success. These findings demonstrate that causal-RL integration enables prescriptive, interpretable, and equitable personalization in MOOCs.

title: A Microgrid-Based Self-Healing Control Strategy for Active Distribution Networks
authors: Peng Cao, Yier Ba, Liangsong Guo, Haoxuan Huang, Zhiwei Liu, Changhong Deng
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the continuous increase in energy consumption and ongoing optimization of energy structure, the penetration rate of distributed generation (DG) in distribution networks continues to rise, making issues related to the security and reliability of power systems increasingly prominent. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a self-healing scheme tailored for distribution networks integrated with DG, based on the self-healing capabilities of microgrids. For the off-grid islanded operation scenario of a microgrid, an optimal configuration model for microgrid energy storage is established, considering both load outage losses and the cost of additional energy storage allocation. Furthermore, an improved dung beetle optimization algorithm incorporating chaotic initialization and a variable spiral strategy is proposed to solve the model efficiently. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method enhances the utilization efficiency of energy storage resources and the economic performance of microgrid off-grid operations, while effectively reducing the overall loss during the distribution network's self-healing process.

title: TRAIL-D: Ternary Restoring Array Integrated Logic – Division
authors: Karthik R Varma, Rishi Agrawal, Sreehari Veeramachaneni, Syed Ershad Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Division is widely used in digital signal processing tasks, such as calculating filter coefficients, normalizing signals, and scaling data, which are key steps in improving audio quality or processing images. By allowing accurate adjustments and fine-tuning of signal values, division helps ensure that processed signals closely match the original, reducing errors and maintaining quality. Despite growing advancements in ternary logic implementations using carbon nanotube field-effect transistors (CNTFETs), ternary restoring division lacks systematic exploration. This work advances the field by proposing a ternary restoring division algorithm and a novel designed circuit architecture, adapting binary division principles to ternary logic. Novel modules for division specific subtraction and control logic are introduced, complemented by optimized reuse of existing ternary combinational circuits. The proposed architecture demonstrates inherent scalability for 2n/n digit divisions through modular replication. Functional correctness of the circuit is verified via exhaustive HSPICE simulations for 6/3 and 8/4 division operations.

title: DynPrice-MG: Trajectory Privacy Protection Based on Dynamic Pricing with Mamba-GAN
authors: Shoukai Liao, Suiming Guo, Chen Chao
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In recent years, ride-on-demand (RoD) services, such as Uber and DiDi, have experienced a surge in popularity. Dynamic pricing, a core feature of RoD services, has received substantial attention for its role in demand management and its influence on travel behavior. Although GPS data and dynamic pricing in RoD services offer valuable insights for urban application research, their public release poses privacy concerns. In this paper, we introduce DynPrice-MG, an innovative framework designed to examine the influence of dynamic pricing on GPS data synthesis and to generate high quality synthetic dynamic pricing. By integrating the Mamba-2 network, which employs a selective SSM mechanism for dynamic data weighting, with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), the proposed method generates high-quality synthetic GPS data and dynamic pricing. Experimental evaluations on real-world urban datasets demonstrate that dynamic pricing is essential for synthesizing high-fidelity trajectory data. Moreover, DynPrice-MG outperforms existing approaches in generating trajectory datasets that support urban data mining tasks while preserving data privacy.

title: A Comprehensive Evaluation of State-of-the-Art Deep Learning Object Detection Frameworks for Crown-of-Thorns Starfish in Coral Reef Monitoring
authors: Sadaf Ansari, Akaash Samson Anand Gudlangari, Pratik Khirod Nayak
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Coral reefs are hubs of marine biodiversity and are vital for human livelihoods. However, they are increasingly threatened by Crown-of-Thorns Starfish (COTS) outbreaks—an invasive species capable of devastating large areas of coral and severely disrupting reef ecosystems. Conventional monitoring approaches, while effective, are slow, labour-intensive, and unsuitable for large-scale surveillance. With the rapid progress of deep learning, real-time object detection models now offer a promising alternative. In this paper, we present an extensive comparative evaluation of nine state-of-the-art YOLO object detection models, from YOLOv5 to the latest YOLOv13. The models are benchmarked across Precision, Recall, F1-score, mAP, Inference Speed, and Model Size. The results provide comprehensive insights into the trade-offs among different YOLO versions, offering practical guidance for selecting models suited for scalable, real-time COTS detection – contributing to enhanced coral reef monitoring, protection, and conservation.

title: Point-of-Care Breast Cancer-on-Chip Diagnosis Using Linear SVM Model
authors: Tanushree Bhowmik, Dev Gupta, Ananya Sharma, Anil Kumar Rajput, Pradyut Kumar Sanki, Manisha Pattnaik, Biswabandhu Jana
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Breast cancer is the second-leading cause of cancer worldwide. Researchers have utilized machine learning classifiers on FPGA to increase the effectiveness of breast cancer diagnosis. The proposed approach features an optimized real-time breast cancer detection system utilizing a Support Vector Machine (SVM) linear classifier for point of care. To minimize hardware complexity, this method incorporates a wrapper-based feature selection technique, identifying the most significant features, and utilizes an approximated adder design. The system achieves an accuracy of 96% while employing a reduced feature subset. FPGA implementation demonstrates a 14% reduction in hardware requirements compared to existing methods. For a single-chip solution in 45nm technology, the system achieves an area of 63,903 µm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, power consumption of 43 mW, and a delay of 6.6 ns. Overall, the proposed system integrates high accuracy with reduced hardware requirements, enabling efficient real-time diagnostics in resource-constrained environments with a target of point-of-care diagnostic tools.

title: Impact Analysis and Settlement Mechanism Effect Evaluation for the Full Market Integration of New Energy in Anhui's Electricity Trading Market
authors: Honghu Cheng, Changchun Dai, Yongbo Li, Qiang Li, Chenyao Hou, Xin Du
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: With the national "Document No. 136" promoting the full integration of new energy generation into the power market, China's electricity market reform has entered a new phase. However, the randomness and volatility of new energy output pose severe challenges to provincial power markets designed around traditional thermal power generation, with issues such as market price failure and supply-demand imbalances becoming increasingly prominent. This study aims to conduct an in-depth analysis of the impacts of full new energy market entry on supply-demand dynamics and price formation within Anhui's provincial power market. It specifically evaluates the economic effects of the "differential settlement mechanism" designed to safeguard new energy enterprises' revenues, with the goal of providing decision support for optimizing market rules and promoting the efficient integration of new energy into the power system.

title: High-Performance Network Virtualization with Safety for Automotive Virtualization OS
authors: Jianguang Zhou, Wenji Han, Tianran Zhuang, Jun Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The development of intelligent and connected vehicles places higher demands on the performance, security, and flexible deployment of vehicle network virtualization. Existing studies have integrated vehicle operating systems through virtualization technology, but they mostly focus on a single platform or functional module. Such a solution struggles to balance cross-platform network transmission efficiency, security isolation, and system scalability. This paper proposes a hierarchical virtualization architecture based on a hypervisor to achieve the integration of multi-platform vehicle network functions. Specifically, a network function abstraction layer across different virtual machines is constructed using hardware-assisted virtualization technologies (VirtIO/SR-IOV), and the security boundary is strengthened by combining the dynamic packet filtering of virtual switches with VLAN isolation policies. Experimental verification demonstrates the comprehensive advantages of the framework in terms of low communication latency, high throughput, and security protection, providing a scalable technical path for the evolution of intelligent vehicle systems.

title: Human-Centered Building Energy Modeling and Simulation for Retrofit
authors: Wenbing Zhao, Yongxin Tao
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In the US, buildings account for about 40% of total energy consumption. Hence, we have seen numerous policies being enacted at different corporate and governmental levels with the promise to improve the energy efficiency of the buildings. Unfortunately, the actual energy and financial savings of the implemented policies are substantially lower than what was anticipated. Although this is a complex issue, the major root cause is the lack of considering human factors, which has been pointed out in several previous studies. In this paper, we provide an overview of existing studies on occupant energy behaviors and how to incorporate such behaviors in building energy modeling in the context of retrofit. Furthermore, we propose a data-driven surrogate-based approach to developing optimal retrofit policies. We also go over current machine learning models that have been used as surrogate models, state-of-the-art sampling method for generating training data for surrogate models, as well as the wellbeing metrics that could be used for human-centered building energy modeling.

title: Reconfigurable FPGA-Based Framework for Power-Efficient Signal Processing in AI-Assisted IoT Gateways
authors: Janga Prasad, M. Sirin Kumari, G. Srikanth, A Gopi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce ANEMIA, a novel reconfigurable FPGA framework aimed at power-efficient signal processing in AI-assisted IoT gateways. With the increase in the reliance of IoT ecosystems on real-time edge intelligence data processing, the static traditional architectures are challenged immensely in terms of energy costs, latency, and flexibility. ANEMIA overcome these constraints by using a flexible, aware context model that combines neuromorphic processing and pipeline modules of signals. It has five key elements such as a Neuromorphic Signal Encoder (NSE) where spiking neural networks extract features in an energy-efficient manner; Modular Power-Aware Pipelines (MPAP) that activate only the signal processing units needed by the workload; an AI-Driven Reconfiguration Agent (AIRA) which optimizes hardware configurations using in real-time a lightweight meta-learning framework; an Edge-Aware Quantized Learning Core (EQL-Core) that supports low-power AI inferences by enabling ultra-low precision models; and an Hybrid Data Compression It has been experimentally demonstrated that ANEMIA is capable of saving a significant amount of power, as much as 43 percent when compared to state-of-the-art methods with competitive accuracy, latency and throughput. Its framework is also typified by the great scalability and flexibility of the heterogeneous IoT settings. The ANCEMIA is developed by reconfiguring hardware dynamically at the border, controlled by AI, hence it is an important step to create intelligent edge computing systems to be sustainable. The contributions made by this work are a new architectural paradigm of the next-generation AIoT systems that are to be energy-efficient and there is a high level of performance demanded in resource-constrained conditions.

title: Hybrid Quantum Key Distribution for Secure Open Banking Platforms
authors: Rabiya Naushad Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Open Banking exposes regulated financial capabilities through standardized open APIs to third-party providers (TPPs). While the ecosystem is protected today by TLS, mutual TLS (mTLS), OAuth 2.0/OIDC, JWT, and the FAPI profiles, the emergence of cryptographically relevant quantum computers (CRQC) introduces a "harvest-now, decrypt-later" risk that threatens long-lived financial confidentiality, non-repudiation, and systemic integrity. This paper proposes a hybrid security architecture that fuses Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) with Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) to secure inter-organizational open-banking communications across data centers, metro fiber, and cloud backbones. We map each integration point in an end-to-end Open Banking flow—PSU device, TPP platform, ASPSP/bank API gateway, consent management, clearing/settlement rails, observability, and audit—to concrete cryptographic mechanisms, define deterministic fallback behavior, and present deployable key-management patterns. We provide a threat model, protocol bindings to FAPI 1.0/2.0, performance and cost models, and a migration blueprint that preserves compliance while enabling quantum-safe resilience.

title: Research on Current Limiting Characteristics of Shipboard Low-Voltage Hybrid DC Current Limiter
authors: Duoning Yuan, Zhendong Peng, Kuan Qiao, Xinle Sha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The integrated solution of "current limiter + circuit breaker" is an effective technical means to address short-circuit fault interruption in high-capacity DC power systems. In response to the current issues of large size and high cost of superconducting current limiters, as well as severe losses and the need for additional cooling devices in solid-state current limiters, this paper innovatively proposes a hybrid DC current limiter that combines the advantages of low power loss in the rated current-carrying state of mechanical switches and the fast action speed of solid-state current limiters. This article first conducts theoretical and simulation analysis of the current limiting process under fault conditions, sequentially simulating and analyzing the impact of parameters such as current limiting inductance, time constant, and fast mechanical switch breaking time on current limiting characteristics.Subsequently, based on the simulation results and combined with the circuit results, various components of the current limiter were designed, and a prototype of a DC900V/1000A hybrid DC current limiter was developed. Finally, a test circuit was set up to conduct a test on the fault current limiting characteristics with a DC voltage of 900V, a time constant of 1ms, and an expected peak value of 13kA. The fault current was quickly limited to approximately 7kA within 1ms, and the current value after steady-state limiting was about 6.2kA. The test results showed that the designed DC limiter can quickly and effectively limit the fault current to the set value required by the system, providing a new technical solution for rapid protection of DC system faults.

title: Conversion-Invariant and Quantum-Secure Image Steganography Using YCgCo-R Transformation and DWT-Based Hybrid Encryption
authors: Kiran Malik, Ravinder M, Gaurav Indra
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of quantum computing technology poses a formidable threat to existing cryptographic and steganographic methodologies, which have been designed to depend upon computational difficulty assumptions, many of which will not remain secure in light of the developments in efficient quantum algorithms, such as those discovered by Shor and Grover. In this paper, we present a post-quantum framework for steganography which is resilient to conversion, ensuring imperceptible and secure data-embedding which is invariant to conversions within a digital environment. The framework outlined here utilises a reversible color-space transformation (YCgCo-R) in order to maintain pixel consistency during format conversion, DWT (Discrete Wavelet Transform) for fast multiresolution compression and a hybrid Mceliece + AES encryption scheme, which ensures both quantum resistant and fast symmetric security. Further adaptive deep embedding is performed using a 3D-RCNN-based hiding and revealing network designed for spatiotemporal feature preservation. This enhances plate capacity and imperceptibility. In addition, a novel index will be suggested, the Conversion Robustness Index (CRI), which will provide a numerical value for the recovery characteristics of image data over the recovery of colour space and compression indices. The framework demonstrates its performance on COCO and DIV2K benchmark datasets, yielding PSNR > 57 dB, SSIM ~ 0.999 and a Conversion Robustness Index (CRI) > 0.98, showing significantly enhanced robustness with color-space and format conversions. The proposed system offers a strong launch point for future secure multimedia communications in the quantum age.

title: Co-Regulating Intelligence: Designing Emotionally-Responsive Human-AI Collaboration Models for K-12 Classrooms
authors: Rouhi Faisal, Azza Mohamed, Mohammed Ghazal
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly present in K-12 classrooms, yet its integration often prioritizes efficiency over emotional awareness or teacher agency. This study introduces an emotionally responsive co-regulation framework that positions AI as a collaborative partner to support student engagement, emotional well-being, and teacher decision-making. Drawing on socially shared regulation of learning (SSRL), the framework reconceptualizes AI not as a replacement for instruction, but as a tool to aid real-time reflection and emotional co-regulation. Using a Design-Based Research (DBR) approach, the study engaged 12 teachers and 240 students across two urban K-12 schools to co-design, implement, and refine an AI-supported instructional model. A custom dashboard captured engagement signals and emotion-based cues, offering real-time feedback to teachers. Mixed-methods data, interviews, observations, system logs, guided iterative refinement of both the model and the AI tool. Findings suggest that emotionally aware AI systems can enhance teacher reflexivity and student agency when designed transparently and ethically. The study proposes design principles for affect-sensitive AI tools and provides policy recommendations for ethical classroom integration. Ultimately, this research contributes to a more human-centered vision of AI in education, where collaborative intelligence enhances, not displaces, relational learning practices.

title: Synergistic Multi-Station PV Generation Forecasting with Correlation Orthogonalization
authors: Zixin Wang, Dazhong Ma
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: In multi-site collaborative photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting, a central challenge is posed by the modeling and exploitation of cross-site correlations. Conventional approaches typically rely on graph structures, such as the construction or learning of adjacency matrices and message-passing aggregation. however, these approaches are sensitive to topology design and noise coupling, often leading to over-smoothing and amplification of spurious correlations. To address these limitations, a unified framework termed COD-TCNet (Correlation Orthogonal Decomposition based Trend–Cycle Network) is introduced for multi-site PV forecasting. First, eigen-orthogonal decomposition is applied to the inter-site correlation matrix, yielding a set of mutually uncorrelated cooperative modes that project the original cross-site coupling into an orthogonal mode space for effective decoupling. Then, dedicated subnetworks are employed to model slow-varying trends and intra-day cycles/fast disturbances separately. A composite loss function, incorporating energy preservation, frequency consistency, and reconstruction error, is optimized in an end-to-end manner. Finally, site-level predictions are reconstructed through inverse projection. Experimental results demonstrate that, in comparison with representative graph neural networks and Transformer-based baselines, the proposed framework consistently achieves lower forecasting errors across diverse scenarios while exhibiting enhanced robustness to variations in site number and meteorological perturbations.

title: Smart Energy Monitoring & Appliance Level Power Consumption Analysis: An Integrated Approach for Residential Energy Efficiency
authors: Deepshikha Shrivastava, Atharva Khabale, Utkarsh Kashid
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Households and buildings consume more than 40% of total global energy-yet most users have no idea which of their devices are the biggest culprits. In an era of rising energy demands, climate concerns, and increasing electricity costs, understanding real-time power consumption is more critical than ever. However, traditional energy meters lack the granularity to provide device-level insights.This paper introduces a Smart Electricity Monitoring System powered by Internet of Things IoT and cloud analytics that allows users to monitor, track, and control energy usage per appliance in real time. Our solution helps users make datadriven decisions to conserve energy, reduce bills, and identify faulty appliances. By bridging the gap between awareness and action, the system not only promotes sustainability but also enhances convenience through remote monitoring and control. Our solution helps users make data-driven decisions to conserve energy, reduce bills, and identify faulty appliances. Upon deployment, the system has demonstrated its effectiveness, enabling users to save $\mathbf{2 0 - 2 5 \%}$ on their electricity consumption and associated costs. By bridging the gap between awareness and action, the system not only promotes sustainability but also enhances convenience through remote monitoring and control.

title: A Study on the Economic Benefits of Energy-Efficient Retrofitting of Building Envelopes in Existing Residential Buildings in Severe Cold Regions
authors: Jiajia Teng, Lei Zhang, Yameng Gao, Weipeng Yin, Chong Li
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Building energy consumption in severe cold regions, particularly in Northeast China, is a significant concern. Existing residential buildings often exhibit poor thermal performance in their building envelopes, with long heating seasons and high energy consumption for heating. This study addresses these issues by selecting a typical non-energy-efficient residential building from the 1990s in Changchun, Jilin Province as a case study. Using the building energy simulation software BESI, a physical model of the building was constructed to identify key envelope material parameters influencing energy consumption. Based on this model, the optimal economic thickness of insulation materials was determined, and a balance between retrofit investment and operational energy cost was analyzed. The findings aim to provide technical support for the energy-efficient renovation of existing residential buildings in the severe cold regions of Northeast China.

title: A New Space Distribution Method for Autonomous Vehicles at Lane-Drop Bottlenecks on Multi-Lane Freeways
authors: Thanh Tung Phan, Trung-Dung Le, Duc Duong Nguyen, Manh Hung Do, Ngoc Thanh Pham, Minh C. Ta
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) represent a ground-breaking technology poised to revolutionize transportation. Their impact spans various domains, with particular promise evident in their deployment on multi-lane freeways to address dynamics at lane-drop bottlenecks. This paper introduces the New Space Distribution Method (NSDM), aimed at optimizing AV coordination upstream of lane-drop bottlenecks in multi-lane freeways to enhance throughput. The proposed NSDM leverages an innovative imagination variable to simplify multi-variable problems, facilitating the calculation of optimal AV positions prior to lane changes. Subsequently, the framework guides AV trajectories to maximize speed and minimize gaps, facilitating efficient passage through bottlenecks. Simulation results prove the efficacy of the proposed method in substantially reducing average travel time for all vehicles.

title: Physics-Constrained CNN-GNN Framework for Power System Transient Stability Assessment with Causal Interpretability
authors: Hangyuan Du, Xuguang Hu, Yongzhi Ji, Run Song, Jiance Zhao, Hui Dong
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: A novel physics-constrained deep learning framework integrating convolutional neural networks with graph neural networks is proposed to address the critical challenges of transient stability assessment in modern power systems. This method introduces physics-informed convolutional layers that embed power system governing equations directly into the CNN architecture, enabling the model to learn both data-driven patterns and physical constraints simultaneously. The proposed CNN-GNN hybrid architecture leverages the spatial-temporal feature extraction capabilities of CNNs while incorporating the topological awareness of GNNs to capture complex power grid interconnections. Furthermore, a causal attention mechanism is integrated to identify critical system variables and their causal relationships during transient events, providing unprecedented interpretability beyond traditional visualization approaches. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach not only improves transient stability assessment (TSA) accuracy and real-time performance, but also enhances model generalization and transparency, thereby providing a robust and practical solution for deploying deep learning in safety-critical power grid applications.

title: Integration of AI and ML for Anomaly Detection in SSD Validation Logs
authors: Ritesh Deshmukh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The explosive growth of data-intensive workloads has made solid-state drives (SSDs) a critical infrastructure building block that requires unprecedented monitoring for reliability. This work proposes SMART (SSD Monitoring and Anomaly Recognition Technology), an end-to-end AI-based system that achieves 96.7 % detection accuracy with 4.2 % false positive, far superior to prior threshold-based schemes. Our ensemble system combines gradient boosting machines, isolation forests, and deep neural networks with explainable AI features for real-time anomaly detection across heterogeneous SSD populations. Scalable validation across <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5, 0 0 0}$</tex> production validation logs results in 35% reduced surprise failures, 28% in maintenance cost, and 23 % system availability gain. The adaptive learning and distributed design enable scalable monitoring of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5, 0 0 0}$</tex> SSDs in parallel with sub-second response time.

title: Development and Simulation of a 5-Stage Constant Current Control Battery Management System
authors: Sweety Kumari, Khushboo Bharti, Supriyo Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Renewable energy and electric car systems have made extensive use of energy storage technologies. Lithium-ion battery is most efficient for electric vehicle due to its high specific power and high energy density. Among the many popular forms of energy storage devices are lithium-ion batteries. This paper presents a battery management system (BMS) simulation utilizing a constant current control method for efficient charging and discharging of lithium-ion(Li-ion)batteries. State of charge (SoC), load voltage, battery current, and operational modes (charging/discharging) were among the critical performance metrics that were assessed. The results demonstrate the system’s stability, control accuracy, and safe operational limits, which are critical for applications in renewable energy storage and electric vehicles. Modeled using MATLAB/Simulink, the system ensures optimal performance and safety for a 7 -cell Li-ion battery pack. The simulation results validate the system’s ability to improve battery lifespan and safety by preventing overcharging and deep discharging. An accurate battery model in simulation platform is very useful to design and develop an efficient battery-management system.

title: On the Derivation of the Globally Optimal Efficiency Maps in Hybrid and Full Electric Vehicles
authors: Davide Tebaldi
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: In this paper, the derivation of the globally optimal efficiency map, and of the corresponding globally optimal speed and torque maps of the power sources, is addressed for a class of hybrid and full electric vehicles. The problem is formulated and solved using two algorithms for two case studies, accounting for the power sources efficiency maps and for the gears dissipation. The considered case studies for the derivation of the globally optimal efficiency maps are: the recharge of the energy storage system in a series hybrid electric vehicle, and a power-split full electric vehicle equipped with a single-stage planetary gear set.

title: Modeling and Control of a CLLLC Resonant Converter for a Battery Charger
authors: Sadegh Baghaei, Zohra Kader, Maurice Fadel, Jerome Lachaize
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper addresses modeling and control of a CLLLC converter using a first-order Linear-Parameter-Varying (LPV) representation, where the static gain and time constant vary with switching frequency. The time constant is identified via Least-Squares in small-signal conditions, while the gain is derived analytically. A Proportional-Integral (PI) controller is designed with gain compensation achieved by applying the analytical inverse of the static gain. A Monte Carlo analysis evaluates robustness under parameter variation. MATLAB/Simulink simulations confirm the accuracy of the model and the effectiveness of the control strategy for embedded battery charger applications.

title: Stress Analysis and Long-Term Performance of Vacuum Tube Operating Mechanism in Power Equipment
authors: Weizhao Huang, Yingjie Yan, Chuanyu Gu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Mechanical failure of the moving and fixed contacts is a critical factor constraining the operational reliability of Vacuum Circuit Breakers (VCBs). Addressing the issues of closing collision characteristics and mechanical fatigue life in high-voltage vacuum circuit breaker contact systems, this paper establishes a numerical dynamic solver model based on multi-rigid-body dynamics theory to analyze the velocity characteristics and bounce patterns during the contact closing process. On this basis, the collision velocity derived from the dynamic calculation is utilized as the initial boundary condition to establish a refined contact model in ANSYS Workbench, allowing for the numerical solution of the transient stress field distribution at the instant of collision. Furthermore, combining this with Miner's linear cumulative damage theory, the mechanical fatigue life of the CuCr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">25</inf> contact material and the conductive rod is quantitatively evaluated. Simulation results indicate that: under rated closing conditions, the contact rigid closing velocity calculated by the dynamic model is 0.82 m/s; the maximum contact stress generated by the collision is 134 MPa, which is lower than the material's yield strength, indicating that the mechanism operates within the elastic working region; and the predicted mechanical life of the contact system is approximately 65,000 operations. This study verifies the rationality of the contact system design for this type of circuit breaker and identifies the critical weak links affecting its service life.

title: Designing Resilient Integrated Systems Engineering Architectures for Robust Cybersecurity Against Emerging Threats
authors: Ashish Avasthi, S.Suma Christal Mary, Ajmeera Kiran, Bvn Prasad Paruchuri, Jyothi Preshiya, Dhaaraani R
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Modern Industrial Control Systems in Industry 4.0 environments face unprecedented cybersecurity challenges due to increasing interconnectivity and digitalization which making critical infrastructure vulnerable to sophisticated cyber threats that can cause significant operational and economic disruption. Traditional cybersecurity approaches rely primarily on reactive perimeter defenses and lack standardized methodologies for implementing cyber-resilience engineering within systems engineering lifecycles, creating critical gaps in protecting mission-critical infrastructures against advanced persistent threats. This study develops the CRISEA Framework that integrates Model-Based Systems Engineering, Zero Trust Architecture, Threat-Informed Design using MITRE ATT and CK framework, AI-based anomaly detection and Digital Twin environments for comprehensive cyber-resilience. The framework incorporates the Cyber-Resilient Architecture Maturity Evaluation methodology for systematic assessment of architectural resilience across multiple system layers. Evaluation using the Edge-IIoTset dataset with over 20 million records demonstrates superior performance achieving 93.7% accuracy, 93.1% precision, 94.4% recall and 93.7% F1-score, significantly outperforming traditional methods like Logistic Regression at $\mathbf{8 5. 9 \%}$ accuracy and Decision Tree at $\mathbf{8 8. 1 \%}$ accuracy.

title: FPGA Based Neural Networks for Ultrasound Muscle Pathology Classification
authors: Suchit Tilak, Prasad Joshi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Effecting pathological diagnosis involving muscle scans is a challenge especially in remote geographies as well as demands an additional challenge of requiring specialty and specific imaging facilities. Making available AI assisted diagnostic tools which can effectively be used on portable devices can largely help access deprivation as well as permit in point of care diagnosis in urban as well as rural settings. Deep learning classification models in medical imaging often require significant computational power and hence face a stiff challenge to be deployed on resource constrained edge devices for point of care diagnosis. The present study uses a methodology that involves extracting domain specific features with use of lightweight neural networks for ultrasound-based muscle pathology detection. We extract 12 texture and statistical features (GLCM, GLRLM, LBP, wavelet energy, and Nakagami parameters) from 1,830 ultrasound images and evaluate them using three classification models like the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1D CNN) and XGBoost. XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy at 88.0%, followed by the 1D CNN at 87.7% and the MLP at 87.4%. We validated the MLP implementation on Zynq-7020 FPGA, achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.4\mu\mathrm{s}$</tex> inference latency with efficient post-implementation place and route resource utilization of 110 DSPs (50%) and 6,280 LUTs (11.8%). The proposed combination approach shall help in real-time ultrasound image classification using FPGA with the AI assisted diagnosis being carried out on a hand-held portable device.

title: Performance Analysis of Li-Fi Under Cryogenic Temperature Conditions
authors: Ritesh Kumar Kushwaha, Rajeev Ranjan, Pratham Vinayak Sharma, Sukhjot Singh, Vansh Chhabra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This paper presents performance evaluations of a Light Fidelity (Li-Fi) communication system under cryogenic conditions by modeling LEDs, avalanche photodiodes (APDs), and free-space optical (FSO) links in OptiSystem.
