Performance metrics: Bit Error Rate (BER), Q-factor, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), were evaluated at different LED quantum efficiencies (0.5, .7) with FSO attenuation and APD gains (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-20$</tex>), in terms of different combinations, which provided diverse results. For example, at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 0 ~ K}$</tex>, LED quantum efficiency improved from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 5}$</tex> to 0.7 which produced an improved Q-factor of 7.4% and reduced the BER from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 10^{-35}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 10^{-40}$</tex>. Tuning the gains of the APD (3–5) with a decrease in the ionization ratio also increased responsivity and decreased the excessive noise levels of the photodetector. Collectively, these outcomes have confirmed that cryogenic operation provides significant increases in performance to Li-Fi systems for use in deep-space, superconducting, and quantum communication.

title: A Carbon Emission Estimation Method Based on Convolutional Neural Networks and Lightweight Gradient Boosting Trees
authors: Fan Cheng, Chen Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To address the urgent need for low-carbon operation of power systems under high penetration of renewable energy, achieving precise and efficient short-term carbon emission estimation is crucial. Addressing the limitations of current methods in the power sector — including insufficient accuracy, data barriers, and inadequate model adaptability — this paper proposes a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with LightGBM. Leveraging CNN’s robust automatic feature extraction capabilities, the model extracts deep features from limited raw power data. Combined with LightGBM’s efficient regression advantages in handling high-dimensional features and nonlinear relationships, it constructs a data-driven carbon emission estimation framework. Experiments demonstrate that the CNN-LightGBM model outperforms both single models and traditional regression models in evaluation metrics such as the coefficient of determination and root mean square error at both daily and hourly time scales. This effectively validates the method’s efficacy and practicality in enhancing estimation accuracy, robustness, and enabling low-cost "electricity-to-carbon" monitoring, providing robust technical support for low-carbon intelligent decision-making in power grid enterprises.

title: Efficient and Representative Mission profiles generation from Historical Field Data
authors: Xiao Ma, Niels Divens, Koen Laurijssen, Jan Stroobants
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Accurate product validation and performance estimation require representative usage data, as real-world conditions differ from laboratory settings. This paper proposes an efficient heuristic greedy-based algorithm that combines self-weighted Monte Carlo simulation with KL divergence to generate mission profiles from historical field data. Validated through industrial case studies, the method significantly reduces data volume while preserving key operational features. It enables the creation of effective, representative inputs for Digital Twin applications and virtual testing, enhancing the utility and efficiency of existing field data.

title: Additively Manufactured Millimeter-Wave Waveguides with Optimized RF Choke Structures for Screwless Split-Block Integration
authors: Emre Uzundurukan, Serioja Ovidiu Tatu, Tarek Djerafi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost and efficient method for fabricating WR-28 millimeter-wave waveguide components using stereolithography apparatus (SLA)-based additive manufacturing combined with a simple silver-paint metallization process. To mitigate performance degradation caused by assembly-induced gaps in conventional split-block waveguide structures, a comprehensive parametric study of RF choke configurations was conducted. Three choke designs straight, single-fold, and double-fold were evaluated under varying gap conditions, focusing on minimizing insertion loss while accommodating SLA fabrication constraints. Simulation results indicate that the optimized screwless double-fold choke, with optimized segment lengths achieves a transmission loss as low as $0.21 \mathrm{~dB} / \mathrm{mm}$ at 30 GHz under a large gap of 0.5 mm. The proposed approach significantly simplifies fabrication and reduces cost, offering a practical solution for rapid prototyping and low-cost production of high-frequency waveguide components.

title: Sparse Design of Navigation Conformal Array and Its Beamforming
authors: Tian Lan, Jun OuYang, Kedi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Microwave and Antenna Symposium (IMAS)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a sphericalcylindrical conformal phased array for navigation applications, addressing the critical challenges of achieving wide-angle coverage with reduced hardware complexity and computational cost. A comprehensive design methodology is proposed, integrating conformalization, sparsification, and fast beam synthesis. This study addresses the design of sparse arrays for large curved surfaces and develops a fast adaptive beamforming algorithm. By employing compressive sensing techniques, the number of antenna elements is reduced by 46.5% and 28.9% in two respective case studies, while maintaining beamforming performance. The proposed Linear Constrained Sector Suppression (LCSS) algorithm demonstrates effective anti-jamming capabilities with widened nulling sectors. The results indicate that the proposed methods can significantly reduce the physical and computational cost of conformal arrays without substantial performance degradation, making them suitable for practical navigation systems.

title: Multi-Channel 1D-CNN Architecture for Drone vs Bird Classification Using mmWave Radar ADC Data
authors: Sacharitha Sirisilla, Ankit Kumar, Bethi Pardhasaradhi, Linga Reddy Cenkeramaddi
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Reliable discrimination between drones and birds is essential for secure airspace monitoring. Traditionally, image-based approaches struggle under poor lighting or weather conditions. However, radar-based classification has emerged as a promising alternative by observing drone and bird RCS and Doppler signatures. In this work, we explore raw 60 GHz millimeter-wave radar analog-to-digital converter (ADC) signals for binary aerial target classification using multi-input one-dimensional convolutional neural networks (1D-CNNs). In this paper, three architectures are designed and evaluated on the ADC data: a 2-input CNN (amplitude + phase), a 3-input CNN (amplitude + real + imaginary), and a 4-input CNN (amplitude + phase + real + imaginary). Each proposed model employs parallel convolutional streams for feature extraction and then feature-level fusion to capture complementary signal characteristics. Experimental results show that the 3-input 1D-CNN achieves the best performance with an accuracy of 96% when trained on longer sequences. Moreover, the 2-input 1D-CNN provides stable and computationally efficient performance. Finally, the 4-input 1D-CNN suffers from reduced generalization due to redundancy despite incorporating richer modalities. These findings demonstrate the potential of raw radar signal learning for robust drone-versus-bird classification and provide practical insights for developing accurate and efficient real-time airspace surveillance systems.

title: Sustainable Nanocomposites for Energy Storage and Intelligent Computing in Eco-Efficient Systems
authors: Rajesh Kumar, Roop Lal, Bhupinder Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The further development of intelligent computing, as well as sustainable energy systems, demands new materials that should be high-performance and environmentally friendly. This is because this research is dedicated to the production and study of the properties of the graphene-zinc oxide-silica (GZS) nanocomposites as eco-friendly materials in the next-generation energy storage applications and low-power intelligent electronic devices. It consisted of a distinctive synthesis strategy to maximize electrical conductivity and charge storage capacity and showed a great prospect of application in smart sensors, embedded systems of the internet of things, and energy-efficient devices with artificial intelligence. Structural stability and electrochemical behavior were elucidated using advanced material characterization methods such as XRD, SEM and TEM. Optimized nanocomposite especially sample Rk-6 had the lowest impedance value, which implies that it could be applicable in energy storage devices and power flow control. This contribution is to scalable, sustainable technologies encompassing intelligent computing and environmental responsibility - essential in future smart energy systems, and smart mobility.

title: AI-Powered Handwritten Signature Verification Using Siamese Neural Networks for Forgery Detection
authors: Mohd. Haris, Kalika Pokhriyal, Yashnandini Minhas, Japneet Kaur Ahuja, Aaskaran Bishnoi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: One of the key biometrics technique for legal technique, financial systems, documentation, and secure access is Signature Verification. Handcrafted features extraction methods used earlier have been discovered to be restricted, especially when there are variations in classes and professional forgeries. With the current developments in deep learning, another possible option is the Siamese Neural Networks (SNNs), which can learn directly good feature representations of raw signatures data. We train and design a convolutional SNN in offline handwritten signatures, and compare its performance, on three publicly made available Kaggle datasets, namely, CEDAR, Handwritten Signatures and Signature Verification. The preprocessing steps included: conversion to grayscale, normalization and equal-factored production of genuine-forged samples. The proposed system had a high degree of accuracy on the CEDAR and Signature Verification data (over 90<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>) and rather poor performance on Handwritten Signatures (47%) and emphasizing the impact of dataset quality and structure on the performance of the models. These results both affirm the relevance of SNNs to offline signature verification and show that standardized, high quality data are necessary in order to achieve generalizable results.

title: Operation Optimization Strategy for User Flexible Load Participation in Demand Response Based on Naive Bayes Classification Algorithm
authors: Liu Liu, Qiong Wu, Xincheng Gong, Qi Li, Anxin Shen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Since the proposal of the "dual carbon" goals, the accelerated energy transition has boosted renewable energy grid integration while exacerbating supply-demand imbalances in the energy system. Demand response, recognized as an effective mechanism for balancing energy supply and demand, is expected to become a crucial regulatory resource for power systems as residential electricity demand surges. This study develops operational characteristic models for transferable, curable, and energy storage loads based on diversified residential load categories. Using Naive Bayes classification algorithm, we screen eligible users for demand response programs and obtain aggregated load curves for selected participants. By positioning load aggregators as information intermediaries between grid and users, we establish an operational optimization model with maximum economic efficiency as the objective, implemented through CPLEX solver. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed model effectively reduces peak-valley load curve differences and lowers aggregator operating costs, providing cost-effective support for large-scale residential flexible loads to participate in real-time grid interaction services.

title: Efficient Three-Level CLLC Converter for DC Microgrid-Based EV Charging
authors: G. Srikanth, G. Sravanthi, N. Madhu, M. Sreeja, P. Nikhil, B. Manikanta Goud
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The recent development rate of electric vehicles (EV s) and their penetration into renewable-driven smart grids has posed a high need of efficient and variable power conversion systems. This proj ect presents three levels of CLLC resonant bidirectional DC-DC converter that can help in the reliable transfer of energy between EV batteries and DC microgrids. The system has a large voltage window of 100 V to 700 V and can therefore support the various EV battery capacities and dynamic grid conditions. In contrast with the classical unidirectional converters, the suggested system will allow grid-to-vehicle (G2V) and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) operation. The converter in G2V mode provides charging power in the microgrid in a regulated manner and at high efficiency to the EV battery. On the other hand, during V2G working, it allows feeding the battery energy to the grid, thereby assisting in the peak load regulation and the power balance of renewable energy. It is a two-way functionality that can improve the role of EV s as active participants of the contemporary energy systems instead of passive loads. It is a converter topology that relies on two three-level full-bridge circuits in conjunction with CLLC resonant components. This arrangement guarantees a soft-switching operation through the large range of load and voltage values, and this greatly minimizes switching losses and electromagnetic interference (EMI). Following this, the converter is more efficient, attains a long life of the component and lower thermal stress as compared to traditional hard-switching converters. Further improvement of system functionality is done by the use of Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC). The FLC is dynamic and adaptive as opposed to a classical Proportional-Integral (PI) controller, which uses constant tuning parameters. This is improved voltage regulation, faster transient response to power outage, more stable power trade in rapid changing micro grid or EV charging environments. Besides, FLC will contribute to the development of a more elegant silhouette of a battery charging and the efficient and productive state-of-charge (SoC) development that will prolong the battery life and enhance the content of a user

title: Statistical Validation of Metaheuristic-Guided Multi-Backbone Fusion: A Comprehensive Analysis for Rice Leaf Disease Detection
authors: Subarna Das, Sukanya Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Rice leaf diseases are a persistent challenge to crop productivity, and early detection is vital for preventing severe yield losses. Manual diagnosis by experts, although effective, is time-consuming, subjective, and difficult to scale in field conditions. This work introduces a Harmony Search-guided multi-backbone ensemble framework for automated rice disease recognition. The framework combines three complementary deep networks - ResNet50V2, ConvNeXt-Small, and Xception, through a two-stage fusion strategy. At the intra-architecture level, predictions from different optimizers are aggregated to stabilize backbone performance, while at the inter-architecture level, Harmony Search adaptively determines fusion weights, leading to more reliable ensembles than simple averaging. The method was evaluated on three standard rice disease datasets covering diverse disease categories and imaging conditions. Using 10-fold cross-validation, rigorous statistical tests including Friedman, Nemenyi post-hoc, Wilcoxon signed-rank, and Cliff’s delta confirmed the significance and stability of the observed improvements. These results demonstrate that adaptive fusion can enhance both accuracy and consistency, offering a robust approach for practical deployment in precision agriculture.

title: A Hybrid Approch for Accurate SoC Estimation of Li-ion Battery by Using CCM and CC, CV Control of EV Applications
authors: Rajeev Ranjan, Umesh Kumar Sinha, Ravikant Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The parameters of the li-ion battery under running conditions are discussed in this article. Accurate state-of-charge (SoC) of a battery needs to be determined. Coulomb counting is prone to additive error over time, despite the fact that it allows high-resolution, real-time SoC measurement. We try to find out exactly what is the rate of discharge for a Li-ion battery. Constant current (CC) control, however, is still unable to track changing load conditions even though it is accurately calibrated. This study presents a hybrid method in which in combination of CC control and CV approaches, the precision and reliability of SoC calculation are closely monitored by coulomb counting and accumulated errors are corrected from time to time by CC control for lithium-ion batteries. Our simulation results indicate that the hybrid strategy reduces the prediction errors and improves the system robustness, thus being ideal for implementation on applications such as electric vehicles.

title: Milk Product Recommendation through CatBoostRanker on Tesseract OCR(Optical Character Recognition)-Extracted Nutrition Facts
authors: Samuel Ady Sanjaya, Nur Hayati, George Kerry Wijaya, Annabelle Chloe, Yohanes Vincentius, Jansen Wiratama
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Choosing healthier milk products is challenging because labels vary widely and marketing can be misleading. Many items sold to the public as milk are actually dairy-flavored beverages with little real milk content, and a substantial share contain high levels of added sugar. These factors are linked to obesity and a higher risk of early-onset type 2 diabetes in children. To solve this problem, we propose a recommendation algorithm that formulates milk selection as a learning to rank task and employs CatBoostRanker to prioritize lower sugar while preserving beneficial nutrient composition using OCR-extracted, open, and scraped label data, so it can help parents choose suitable products for their children. The data was collected from three resources: (1) images of real packages via OCR(Optical Character Recognition) using Tesseract, (2) open data, and (3)web scraping. A comprehensive dataset of 11,318 milk products from 65 brands, compiled from OCR, open data, and web scraping, and standardized. The process includes unit standardization between per 100 g and per serving, text standardization, and plausibility checks so that products can be compared fairly. We then pose product selection as a learning to rank task that prioritizes lower sugar while preserving beneficial composition, such as adequate protein with controlled saturated fat and salt. An optimized CatBoostRanker learns preferences within relevant groups, such as brand or category. The model was evaluated using ranking metrics NDCG@k, which achieved 99.66% on the 355<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> iteration. The system consistently surfaces lower sugar items without sacrificing desirable nutrient profiles. In future research, we will explore personalization and preference learning for different age and health profiles and extend the approach to other nutrition-sensitive product categories.

title: Multi-Class Sentiment Analysis with Fine-Tuned Transformer Models
authors: Jayapal Reddy Vummadi, Suresh Dodda, Navin Kamuni, Pavan Nutalapati
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a multi class sentiment analysis framework to classify user’s text as positive, negative and neutral category. Naturally, it uses NLP, ML and DL techniques that help it capture lexical and contextual cues from user generated content. Normalization, stemming, and noise reduction steps are applied to preprocessed semantics for consistency. We use its features (TF-IDF) along with baselines such as Logistic Regression, Random Forest, or LightGBM, and try to extract local semantic features with CNN. The central contribution is to fine tune a transformer-based model on DistilBERT which uses selfattention to understand contextual relationships. The experimental results show that DistilBERT performs well in terms of precision and recall compared to classical models and brings scalable performance for the tasks like sentiment analysis in the areas of customer feedback systems, social media monitoring, and opinion tracking.

title: A Hybrid Model for Detecting Lung Cancer
authors: Yashwanth Adimulam, Rohit Agudu, Harshith Amanchi, Shyam Sunder, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Lung cancer is among the leading causes of cancer related deaths, mostly stemming from being poorly detected and diagnosed in the early and treatable stages. Conventional techniques, including X-rays, CTs, and biopsies, tend to result in late stage detection with poor prognosis. This study proposes an integrated approach to the early diagnosis of lung cancer using image processing and machine learning techniques. This paper investigated several classification algorithms such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM) optimized through Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) applied on CT and MRI imaging modalities. Publicly accessible datasets, namely the TCIA PET-CT-Dx collection and Kaggle's MRI dataset, have been utilized for evaluation. Experimental results showed that deep learning models like CNN in particular were not superior to classical machine learning algorithms for classification when used with advanced preprocessing and optimization. Random Forest reached an accuracy of 88.17%, whereas the SVM-PSO reached 87.80%. The CNN, conversely, did have great generalization and robustness across different imaging modalities, with an accuracy slightly lower than 86%. These conclusions may indicate, probably depending on some particular AI algorithms, on how an AI driven diagnostic system can help the radiologist to improve accuracy and timing of lung cancer diagnosis in the clinical setup. However, some other challenges are still hindering its large scale deployment, such as data highly varying in nature, model overfitting, a limited number of annotated samples.

title: A Transformer-Based Intrusion Detection System with Attention-Driven Feature Selection for Network Traffic Classification
authors: Toralkar Pawan, Shridhar Allagi, Saritha Kamatham, Shilpa Chinnakkagari, Vijeeta Patil, Balachandra Chikkoppa, Prassana Bammigatti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: As cyber threats advance, conventional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) frequently face challenges in identifying emerging attacks owing to their dependence on manual feature extraction. The envisioned work enforces an enhanced transformer-based intrusion detection system with an attentiondriven feature selection. The Transformer Encoder uses a multi-head self-attention mechanism to capture intricate dependencies in network traffic competently. After that, a lightweight classifier is used to detect intrusions using the cultivated representations. The implemented model demonstrates outstanding performance on the UNSW-NB15 dataset, effectively addressing class imbalance and accurately identifying attacks, achieving an accuracy of 95.68%, precision of 96.42%, recall of 95.70%, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 96.06%. The two preprocessing strategies, i.e., Z -score normalisation and categorical encoding, are utilised to upgrade detection competence and model sturdiness.

title: Can LLMs Aid Expert Elicitation for Causal Modeling?
authors: Olha Shaposhnyk, Daria Zahorska, Svetlana Yanushkevich
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study investigates the potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) as a support in expert elicitation for extracting structured causal knowledge and facilitating causal modeling in biometric and healthcare applications. LLM-generated causal structures, specifically Bayesian networks (BNs), were benchmarked against traditional statistical methods (e.g., Bayesian Information Criterion) using healthcare datasets. Validation techniques included structural equation modeling (SEM) to verify relationships and measures such as entropy, predictive accuracy, and robustness to compare network structures. LLM-generated BNs demonstrated lower entropy than expert-elicited and statistically generated BNs, suggesting higher confidence and precision in predictions. However, limitations such as contextual constraints, hallucinated dependencies, and potential biases inherited from training data require further investigation.

title: From Mental Models to Data-Enriched Knowledge Graphs as a Basis for Operator Assistance
authors: Josua Höfgen, Birgit Vogel-Heuser, Fan Ji, Dorothea Pantförder
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Through experience, operators and engineers obtain mental models of the technical processes and systems under their control. These mental models can be made explicit using, e.g., concept maps or graph representations. Aligning these representations with data analysis is challenging due to the disparity in formal rigor required for representing mental models compared to mathematical data analysis models. Data analysis is, however, considered a key enabler to improve production processes. The integration of ever more sensing capabilities in manufacturing processes may further complicate the alignment of mental models and data analysis results. This requires robust frameworks to integrate operator knowledge and data analysis with an explicit focus on application in an assistance system. We propose one such framework that centers around a three-layered knowledge graph that captures the structure of mental models, enriches it with data analysis results, and incorporates information required for the presentation to the operator in a graph-based assistant system. The approach is evaluated using cause-effect graphs and data analysis models that have been developed for quality prediction in an industrial stretch foil production use case. Using the proposed framework, all aspects are brought together in a single, systematically structured knowledge graph that is visualized in an assistance system for product quality monitoring.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning Techniques for Intrusion Detection System Using UNSW-NB15 Dataset
authors: V.S.R. Pavan Kumar Neeli, Venkata Ramana Gupta Nallagattla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The rapid evolution of cyber-attacks has heightened the need for advanced Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) capable of detecting a wide range of network-based threats. This paper investigates the effectiveness of three machine learning algorithms—Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine (SVM)—for identifying network intrusions using the UNSW-NB15 dataset. The dataset, rich in both normal and attack traffic instances, is used to train and test each model. The models are evaluated based on performance metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Among the three algorithms, Random Forest demonstrates superior performance, showing the highest accuracy, precision, and recall. This paper contributes to the IDS research by providing a comparative analysis of these machine learning models on a modern and diverse dataset, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of each approach for practical intrusion detection.

title: Deep Learning-Based Classification of Diabetic Retinopathy Using Fundus Images and Transfer Learning
authors: Uma Yadav, Palavi Meshram, Shweta Bondre, Vipin Bondre, Priya Dasarwar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is still a major factor that leads to vision loss all over the world, especially among people who have had diabetes for a long time. Detecting diabetic retinopathy at an early stage and identifying its severity levels are crucial to intervene in time and prevent damage that cannot be reversed. This research introduces a decision support system based on deep learning that classifies diabetic retinopathy into five different levels of severity from retinal fundus images. We built and experimented a tailor-made Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) along with sophisticated pretrained architectures like EfficientNetB0 and DenseNet121. We used the Kaggle EyePACS dataset for training and testing the model. We also measured its accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score to evaluate its performance. The DenseNet121 model was the closest to the real situation in the classification of instances with a classification rate of 83%. The EfficientNetB0 model (81%) and the custom CNN model (76%) were not as accurate. A confusion matrix and accuracy/loss charts gave us further information about how the model worked and where it went wrong. To make it easier for doctors to understand and trust, explainable AI features like heatmaps that show important parts of the retina were added. Streamlit was used to set up the system, which made it possible for people to interact with the model in real time using a web browser. This methodology shows a dependable, scalable, and clinically relevant way to automate DR screening, and it could perform well in healthcare locations that are far away or don't have many resources.

title: CNN-Based Feature Learning and Logistic Regression for 5-Level Car Dent Categorization
authors: Raghavendra Sridhar, Deepak Banerjee, Rashi Nimesh Kumar Dhenia, Ishva Jitendrakumar Kanani, Jyoti Bhola, Gaurav Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: To classify and predict the severity of dents in a car, the paper suggests a unified approach, that is, a combination of CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks) with the Logistic Regression. According to picture analysis, the system will categorize dents in five levels (Level Dent 1 to Level Dent 5). Although the Logistic Regression ensures effective and accurate classification, CNN is applied to deep extract features, and detect complex visual patterns in car photos. The proposed model works well based on significant metrics, such as accuracy, recall, and the F1 score of all levels of the dent, and its overall accuracy is excellent (98). Experimental results show how the system has the ability to minimize false detections and correctly distinguish between small changes in dents. Experimental results show how the system has the ability to minimize false detections and correctly distinguish between small changes in dents. There is a significant potential in applications of this automated approach in auto repair shops, insurance claim processes as well as auto damage assessment. The proposed architecture enhances smart damage detection systems by reducing the number of human errors and shortening the assessment time.

title: Fully Unrolled Two-Stage Pipelined AES-128 Hardware IP for High-Speed Encryption/Decryption on FPGA
authors: Aditya Antil, Raghul C J, Malay Choudhary, Manish Goswami, Kavindra Kandpal
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This paper presents a high-speed and area-efficient AES-128 hardware accelerator implemented on the Zynq UltraScale+ ZCU104 FPGA platform. The proposed design employs a fully unrolled two-stage pipelined architecture, integrating both encryption and decryption into a unified module for flexible mode switching. The pipeline is partitioned into an S-box transformation stage and a combined MixColumns, ShiftRows, and AddRoundKey stage. Operating at 170.1 MHz, the design achieves a throughput of 21.77 Gbps with a latency of 11.76 ns, producing 128-bit output per clock cycle. Resource utilization is limited to 7409 LUTs, 9653 flip-flops, and 51 BRAMs, with a power consumption of 3.462 W, resulting in an efficiency of 2.94 Mbps/LUT. AXI DMA-based communication between PS and PL ensures seamless high-speed data transfer. Compared with existing AES architectures, the proposed accelerator demonstrates superior throughput, latency, and resource efficiency. This makes it highly suitable for real-time encryption in embedded security systems and IoT devices that demand both high performance and optimized hardware footprint.

title: Research on Electric Vehicle Charging Simultaneity Factor Prediction Algorithm Integrating Multi-Source Features and Federated Learning
authors: Kong Lingda, Zhang Bo, Zhang Yuhao, Fan Min, He Lianjie, Yang Honglei
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Growing proliferation of electric vehicles poses significant challenges to the stability of distribution networks, the charging simultaneity factor, as a critical metric reflecting the concurrent operation of charging stations,plays a pivotal role in enabling accurate grid load forecasting and optimal scheduling. Existing research primarily focuses on charging load prediction but encounters limitations, including inadequate representation of multi-source data and potential privacy risks associated with multi-site data collaboration. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel prediction model for the electric vehicle charging simultaneity factor that integrates multi-source features within a federated learning framework. This proposed approach leverages federated learning to safeguard data privacy and enable collaborative model training across distributed sites. It employs the sparrow search algorithm to optimize the parameters of variational mode decomposition , which effectively decomposes complex simultaneity factor time series and mitigates nonlinear interferences. Furthermore, the model integrates multi-source features including temporal, meteorological, and historical simultaneity factors data, into a Transformer-based architecture to capture long-term temporal dependencies and cross-modal correlations.Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed model.

title: Live Workplace Mirror: Seamless XR-Driven Soft Skills Development in the Flow of Work
authors: Rame Riadhusin, Ashutosh Pandey, T. Saravanan, N. Chandra Shekhar Reddy, P. Mayilvel Kumar, Najmitdinov Akhadkhon Khamitdkhanovich, D.U. Ashurova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In contrast to a scholarly setting, soft skills are not developed and polished in a vacuum, but are also shaped through real-time interactions. However, the overwhelming majority of training systems designed with XR and VR are restricted to artificial, time-bounded simulations that fail to reflect the dynamics of communication in its everyday form. In the paper, the author introduces the Live Workplace Mirror, a next-generation XR-powered platform that integrates continuous skills enhancement into the natural workflow. By combining real-time AI, speech and sentiment analysis, and wearable XR devices, the system will enable capturing the team's dynamics at a given moment and providing subtle, personalised micro-coaching without interfering with the work process. It acknowledges the communication, emotion, gesture, and cooperation models and makes immediate and contingent individualised statements to foster empathy, individuation, and interpersonal performance. The platform is based on the principles of cognitive-behavioural learning and organisational psychology. It shifts the traditional post-modern vision of training in soft skills into a continuous learning and development framework. We present the theoretical framework, technical design, educational strategy, and implementation plan for the system, which demonstrate how the Live Workplace Mirror helps close the gap between remote training and real-world application. The creation of human-centred competence in the present-day organisation, which is both scaling and transformative, is the approach offered by its learning system as part of daily cooperation.

title: An Approach for Testing Rural LOS V2X Minimum Communication Processing Distance
authors: Zhanle Zhao, Yuen Kwan Mo, Xizhe Zhang, Siddartha Khastgir, Matthew D. Higgins
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: The safety performance of braking systems within connected and autonomous vehicles can be improved via introducing V2X communications. This paper proposes a methodology for an optimisation analysis on transmitter power and channel delay under DSRC V2V and 5G V2I to determine the minimum required V2V and V2I communication processing distance in a rural LOS driving scenario. The methodology has been built up via simulating the maximum delay from respective Packet Error Rates between DSRC and 5G to analyse the minimum Communication Processing Distance under the worst case scenario. From the analysis, it is demonstrated that 5G V2I exhibits a lower Packet Error Rate and delay which allows for a shorter communication processing distance than DSRC V2V. This shorter communication processing distance determines that 5G V2I requires lower transmitter power than DSRC V2V for processing a safe and smooth connected braking in rural LOS scenarios.

title: 5G-Enabled IoT with Machine Learning Approach for Predictive Surface Mining and Environmental Safety
authors: Voore Subrahmanyam, K. Nagaiah, Mulagundla Sridevi, Shailaja Voore
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The cross-section of the 5G technology and the Internet of Things (IoT) is changing the work of the surface mining, creating a new system of intelligent and real-time monitoring, focusing on safety of workers, the sustainability of the work, and environmental preservation. In this paper, the authors will comment on how 5G-enabled IoT forms, such as wearable sensors and autonomous machinery, and environmental monitors enable people to transmit data immediately and make a decision in hazardous mining conditions. Proactive precautionary measures, such as health of workers monitoring and location tracking, detection of the toxic gases, and automated handling of the emergency can be taken using such technologies. Meanwhile, Internet of Things systems are also used to make mining sustainable by optimizing the resources, reducing emissions, and following environmental policies. The fact that edge computing is combined with predictive analytics also adds to the fact that the operations become more efficient and helps to make the ecological effect less significant. The switch to more intelligent, safer, and greener future with the use of 5G-enabled IoT may make industrial development consistent with the environmental duty and human comfort.

title: Smarter Healthcare: Assessing Nurse Workload using Wearable Sensors and Machine Learning
authors: Viet-Hoan Bui, Duc-Nghia Tran, Hoang Trong Minh, Ngoc-Anh Dinh, Minh La Tuan, To-Hieu Dao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
abstract: Nursing care activity recognition is vital for optimizing workflows and reducing documentation burden in elderly care. The SONAR dataset, recently released as a benchmark for nursing activities and recorded with wearable inertial sensors in a clinical environment, poses unique challenges due to noise, class imbalance, and fine-grained activity definitions. This study presents a systematic evaluation of classical ensemble learning methods on SONAR under deployment-oriented constraints for resource-limited microcontrollers. We assess the impact of sensor placement and model configuration on recognition performance. Among the evaluated algorithms, XGBoost consistently outperformed Extra Trees, LightGBM, and Random Forest, achieving 64.01 % accuracy and 61.21 % weighted F1. These findings highlight both the potential and the remaining challenges in developing reliable and resource-efficient nursing activity recognition systems.

title: MDFL: A Machine Decision Method for Intelligent Manufacturing Based on Vertical Federated Learning
authors: Xiaolong Jin, Bo Hou, Hongyi Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The expansion of the industrial internet necessitates advanced machine learning (ML) for automated decision-making. However, its deployment is hindered by data privacy limitations and insufficient training data, which result in reduced accuracy. This paper introduces MDFL, a four-layer decision model that leverages Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) to enable collaborative model constructing across multiple parties for diverse classification tasks while preserving data privacy. Furthermore, a VFL data synthesis method is proposed to generate semi-real data from misaligned samples, thereby augmenting datasets for model training under privacy protection. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy and practicality of the proposed framework in constructing accurate decision models while adhering to privacy constraints.

title: Cognitive-Inspired Lightweight Semantic Mapping in Weak Texture Environments
authors: Shiqi Liu, Bin Guo, Yasan Ding, Zhaotie Hao, Tingting Gao, Linwei Li, Haoyu Li, Sicong Liu, Zhiwen Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In Internet of Things (IoT) systems, embodied intelligent agents serve as a crucial bridge between the physical environment and digital services. In environments with weak textures, agents are unable to extract rich features through visual means. Additionally, traditional methods for creating high-precision maps result in significant storage overhead, which is unsuitable for agents with limited storage capacity, thereby affecting navigation tasks. Inspired by human cognitive mechanisms that leverage reasoning and selective information retention for environmental understanding, this paper proposes CogMap, a cognitive mapping strategy. By integrating topological structures with semantic information, the environment is categorized into corridors and rooms, with corresponding nodes created in real-time. These nodes, combined with odometry, enable localization and the construction of a occupancy map, thereby facilitating the development of CogMap. Leveraging the constructed map, we further design a room-to-room navigation method for validation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms mainstream topological maps in storage efficiency, navigation performance, and node sparsity, confirming its effectiveness as a lightweight semantic mapping solution for agents in weak texture environments.

title: Learning a Unified Risk Map for Autonomous Driving in Partially Observable Environments_supp1-3666393.mp4
authors: Wenchao Ding
publish: N/A
abstract: Occlusion-aware prediction remains a critical challenge in autonomous driving due to the inherent uncertainty of unobserved regions. Existing approaches either overestimate risk based on reachable states or struggle to predict accurate trajectories under high occlusion uncertainty. To address these limitations, we propose a unified risk map modeling and learning framework for partially observable environments. Our method integrates traffic flow risk and collision risk through spatiotemporal modeling, enabling fine-grained assessment of occlusion-induced hazards. To address the scarcity of scenarios involving occluded interactions, we introduce a diffusion-based scenario generation framework that produces realistic yet adversarial scenarios. We integrate the modeling and learning of a unified risk map into a framework that supports risk-aware planning under partial observability. Experiments on the Waymo Open Motion Dataset show that our method significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art occlusion-aware baseline, improving minimum time-to-collision by 0.78 times and average time-to-collision by 1.67 times. The proposed framework offers a comprehensive and practical solution for risk-aware planning in partially observable environments.

title: OFDR Machine Learning Approach with Principal Components Analysis and AutoGluon AutoML Framework for High-Precision Distributed Strain Sensing
authors: Haomao Wang, Zhiguo Zhang, Yifan Wang, Ziyang Xiao, Luming Li, Rui Zhou
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Optical Frequency Domain Reflectometry (OFDR) has extensive application prospects in structural health monitoring, but faces technical challenges in simultaneously achieving high-precision continuous strain monitoring and large strain monitoring capabilities. This study proposes a novel OFDR machine learning approach targeting the requirements of structural health monitoring, aiming to develop a model with high-precision capabilities for both continuous strain and large strain demodulation. Based on the characteristics of OFDR local spectra, the proposed sequence exchange augmentation and coefficient scaling augmentation methods help the model focus on intrinsic spectral variation patterns rather than surface intensity fluctuations, enhancing generalization capability and prediction stability. The PCA dimensionality reduction method provides a novel interpretive perspective for spectral data, abstracting time-correlated spectral data into principal component feature information and extracting novel spectral features and variation patterns. This method achieves a 90% reduction in dimensions while preserving over 99% of the cumulative explained variance, providing machine learning models with a more structured and information-dense feature space. The weighted ensemble capability of the AutoGluon framework can integrate different high-performance models, maintaining excellent demodulation performance in both continuous strain and large strain scenarios by synthesizing the predictive capabilities of various models. Furthermore, the framework’s automated processing and multi-layer stacking architecture efficiently explore model combinations, significantly improving training efficiency and providing researchers with more comprehensive model performance perspectives and data evidence. The trained weighted ensemble model achieved a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 2.4 in continuous strain measurement and an MAE of 16.4 under 3000μϵ large strain conditions, simultaneously possessing high-precision demodulation capabilities for both continuous varying strain and large strain scenarios. This study provides a new technical paradigm for the deep integration of OFDR with high-performance machine learning algorithms, offering efficient and effective solutions for the entire OFDR machine learning pipeline from data augmentation to data processing, model training and optimization. The approach meets structural health monitoring application requirements and provides technical support for OFDR system applications in this field.

title: Machine-Learning Classification of Reactive Power Capability Compliance in Wind Power Plants
authors: Ali Ozan, Mustafa Bagriyanik
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Modern grid codes require wind power plants to provide sufficient reactive-power capability at the point of common coupling (PCC) to maintain voltage security. Meeting these provisions is challenging because plant-level reactive support depends on converter limits, operating voltage, and network constraints. This paper proposes a two-part approach: a multi-objective genetic algorithm co-optimizes the placement and MVAr ratings of shunt capacitor and reactor banks in the collector system, and a supervised classifier enables rapid compliance screening without solving a power-flow problem for every new operating point. Candidate designs are assessed by AC power-flow analysis under turbine voltage-dependent P–Q limits, bus-voltage bounds, and branch-loading limits; a reactive power deviation metric quantifies how closely the PCC envelope tracks the required curve across voltage and active-power levels, and a knee solution is selected to balance low losses with near-boundary compliance. Using labels derived from these evaluations—infeasible, feasible with increased losses, and feasible with reduced losses—classifiers (artificial neural network, support vector machine, decision tree, bagged trees, k-nearest neighbors) are trained on only the operating condition and compact device descriptors. The classifier provides near-instant compliance screening without per-case power flow and achieves 98.7% accuracy on a stratified holdout, with residual errors concentrated near class boundaries. A case study aligned with Turkish grid-code practice shows that minimally compliant device sizes can satisfy the PCC capability curve while keeping losses low, enabling fast pre-selection of feasible operating scenarios and informed siting/sizing of reactive support.

title: Partially Supervised Compositional Zero-Shot Learning by Class-Balanced Distribution Alignment
authors: Aditya Panda, Dipti Prasad Mukherjee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: The partially supervised Compositional Zero-Shot Learning (pCZSL) recognizes new compositions of states and objects, where for every image in the training set either the state or the object annotation is available. In pCZSL, features of a state vary depending on the object in the composition (e.g. the features of state ripe are different for ripe banana and ripe apple). Understanding the variation in features across scales of objects is also a key challenge. In the proposed architecture, a swin transformer based Hierarchical Feature Extractor (HFE) captures the large range of semantic interactions between state and object features. The Discriminative Context Aggregation module utilizes features from the intermediate layers of the HFE to understand the features of object at their corresponding scales. To leverage the partially labeled data in pCZSL, we pass strongly and weakly augmented versions of the input image to the proposed architecture. The predicted class probabilities for strongly and weakly augmented images are encouraged to be similar, minimizing a distribution alignment loss. This loss incorporates class specific re-weighting approach to alleviate the effect of data imbalance for pCZSL. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of the proposed approach.

title: A Snapback-Free MOS-Triggered Thyristor with Modulated Thyristor Ratio for Ultra-High Pulsed Current Capability
authors: Xuanyi Huo, Limei Song, Xiaowu Cai, Jiang Lu, Longli Pan, Jian Lu, Lei Wang, Bo Li
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: A snapback-free MOS-triggered thyristor with modulated thyristor ratio (SFMR-MCT) has been developed for high-current pulsed power applications. The proposed device integrates a large-area N⁺ emitter and a compact P⁺ turn-off region within a single P-Well to achieve a high thyristor area ratio. And a carrier storage (CS) layer is introduced beneath the P⁺ region to accelerate regenerative triggering and eliminate forward snapback. These two features jointly enhance the pulse performance. Experimental results show that the SFMR-MCT delivers a peak current (IPEAK) of 4.28 kA and a di/dt capability of 94.06 kA/μs at 1600 V, representing improvements of 67% and 34% over the conventional device, respectively. The device maintains stable performance under repetitive pulsed conditions, demonstrating strong potential for reliable high-voltage switching systems.

title: Hybrid Active-Passive RIS-Enhanced Physical Layer Security for MIMO Communications
authors: Shady A Deraz, Rugui Yao, Xi Nan, Wanying Su, Ye Fan, Tamer Mekkawy
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) critically enhance physical layer security (PLS), safeguarding next-generation MIMO communications against eavesdropping. Passive RIS are limited by multiplicative path loss, while active RIS implementations introduce uncontrolled noise amplification and significant power consumption. To overcome these dual constraints, we propose a hybrid active-passive RIS (HRIS) architecture. The proposed design synergistically incorporates a minimal number of active amplifying elements within a passive structure to maximize the secrecy rate (SR). The problem of SR maximization is tackled by jointly optimizing the base station beamforming vectors and the HRIS reflection coefficients. To address the non-convexity of the optimization problem, we decompose it into three subproblems of optimizing the transmitter beamforming, phase shift coefficient and amplification coefficient. These sub-problems are solved iteratively within an alternating optimization framework. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed design effectively balances secrecy performance and power consumption, providing a resource-efficient solution for secure MIMO communications.

title: Degradation Mechanism in Aged SiC MOSFETs Under Repetitive Short-Circuit
authors: Xuan Li, Ze Zhao, Hanqing Zhao, Xiaochuan Deng, Min Ren, Yi Wen, Zekun Zhou, Bo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: The robustness of silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFETs against repetitive short-circuit (RSC) events is a critical reliability concern for automotive electric drivetrain converters. In this article, gate switching instability (GSI) followed by RSC test is carried out to find the new degradation phenomenon of aged devices (after GSI stress). The threshold voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {th}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> increases first and then decreases after a certain number of RSC cycles. Furthermore, the degradation mechanism is revealed that injected charge type is transitioned by originally injected charges. Based on the mechanism, we propose the charge injection barrier modulation (CIBM) effect, which provides universal application to explain nonmonotonic gate-related parameters change under varied stress conditions. To sum up, this study gains key theoretical insights for developing accurate lifetime models and comprehensive health monitoring strategies for aged SiC MOSFETs.

title: PLNK: Prompt Learning with Neutral Knowledge for Few-Shot Out-of-Distribution Detection
authors: Xinhua Lu, Runhe Lai, Yanqi Wu, Kanghao Chen, Zhiming Dai, Wei-Shi Zheng, Ruixuan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Recent developments in few-shot out-of-distribution (OOD) detection have yielded remarkable performance, benefiting from large pre-trained vision-language models (VLMs). Our prior work focuses on using in-distribution (ID) knowledge as references to learn richer knowledge beyond the textual semantics of class labels, which is prone to cause the model overconfidence and results in a limited score gap between ID and OOD data. In this paper, rather than treating ID knowledge as references, we propose Prompt Learning with Neutral Knowledge (PLNK) to better differentiate ID from OOD data. Our key insight lies in leveraging diverse neutral knowledge to improve ID discrimination while alleviating the inherent model overconfidence on OOD data induced by ID knowledge, thereby capturing the notable discrepancy between ID and OOD data. By introducing neutral knowledge with a balanced degree of similarity to both ID and OOD data, we amplify the discrepancy between the learnable prompt and the references (i.e., diverse neutral knowledge) for ID data, while reducing it for OOD data. In this way, the simple yet effective PLNK framework brings a notable score gap between ID and OOD data, thereby improving OOD detection. Moreover, we incorporate the visual neutral prompt with richer semantics alongside the original text-only reference. Comprehensive experiments show that our method consistently surpasses current state-of-the-art methods. The codes will be released publicly.

title: Pandora: A Large Language Model-Driven Self-Evolving Agent for On-Campus Task Execution
authors: Wenting Zeng, Xiuhuai Xie, Xianyi Yan, Zhengquan Li, Yufei Wang, Guofeng Luo, Cheng Wang, Longbiao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In dynamic and complex campus environments, robot agents face challenges in providing efficient and accurate services due to their limited ability to learn and adapt to unforeseen situations. To address these issues, we propose Pandora, a large language model (LLM)-driven robot agent framework that enhances task execution through a structured approach of planning collection, insight extraction, and evolutionary inference. Specifically, the agent systematically collects and stores task planning using a task planning tree, extracts high-level insights to guide future actions, and integrates these insights and successful planning with supervised fine-tuning to achieve self-evolution. Evaluations on a digital twin platform and benchmark datasets demonstrate that Pandora significantly improves task success rate and task efficiency, offering a robust solution to develop adaptable and intelligent robot agents in campus settings.

title: RailDefect-MPL: Multimodal Prompt Learning for Railway Defect Detection
authors: Zhongchuan Wang, Weiwei Xing, Guanjia Zhang, Wei Lu, Zhengyang Zhao, Cheng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Recent advances in large multimodal models (LMMs) demonstrated remarkable capabilities in handling complex multimodal tasks. However, The applications of LMMs to railway defect detection remains challenging due to domain-specific knowledge gaps and limitations in fine-grained visual reasoning. To address the above challenges, we propose an innovative multimodal prompt learning approach for railway defect detection, named RailDefect-MPL, which generates detailed textual descriptions of exceptions based on LLM and replaces generic exception labels with specific prompts. The descriptions are embedded into text templates to enhance text-image alignment. For localization, Grounding DINO provides preliminary location and a Split Resize Module (SRM) to refine high-resolution anomaly regions. The fused visual-textual features enable the LLMs to generate accurate anomaly detection and support dialogue. Extensive experimental results on a real-world railway dataset demonstrate that the proposed RailDefect-MPL achieves state-of-the-art performance with 93.1% AUC in image-level defect detection, while maintaining robust performance in few-shot scenarios. Our approach pioneers the application of LMMs in railway safety, offering a more accurate solution for railway infrastructure inspection.

title: GPT-Based Conversational Agents for L2 Speaking Development: A Feedback-Optimized Task Design Framework
authors: Jiyoung Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Existing artificial intelligence-powered agents in language education often lack principled feedback differentiation, limiting opportunities for targeted speaking development. This study proposes a structured framework for designing generative pre-training transformer (GPT)-based conversational agents to optimize the delivery of corrective feedback in second-language (L2) speaking tasks. The proposed framework addresses this gap by outlining the design principles for implementing three evidence-based feedback types (i.e., recasts, clarification requests, and metalinguistic feedback) in GPT-powered task environments. The framework specifies prompt engineering strategies, error detection mechanisms, and task sequencing protocols grounded in L2 acquisition theory while acknowledging the current limitations of GPT technology in educational contexts. Unlike existing generic chatbot approaches, the proposed framework (1) provides systematic feedback differentiation based on the error characteristics and learner proficiency levels, (2) outlines realistic implementation scenarios specifically tailored for language education, though it has yet to be tested with actual learners, and (3) offers concrete implementation guidelines, including robust prompt templates; evaluation metrics for complexity, accuracy, and fluency; and ethical protocols for learner data protection. This study may provide actionable guidance for developers and educators aiming to build pedagogically grounded, GPT-based speaking practice systems.

title: Bi-Level Optimal Scheduling of Multi-Regional Integrated Energy Systems Considering Integrated Demand Response and Carbon Emission
authors: Hexuan Yin, Changjun Jin, Chao Wang, Yifan Liu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This paper proposes a bi-level optimal scheduling framework for multi-regional integrated energy systems (MRIES), considering integrated demand response (IDR) and carbon emission management. The upper level models the energy service operator (ESO) who sets energy and carbon trading prices to maximize profit, while the lower level consists of user aggregators that adjust their energy consumption to minimize costs and reduce emissions. A Stackelberg game formulation is used to model the interaction between the ESO and user aggregators. The framework incorporates renewable energy uncertainty modeling using Markov Monte Carlo (MMC) and hierarchical clustering, detailed equipment modeling for energy production, conversion, and storage, as well as incentive-based demand response and a tiered carbon trading mechanism. Case studies on a three-region system demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly reduces both operational costs and carbon emissions-by 29.0 % and 31.8 %, respectively-compared to the baseline scenario, validating the effectiveness of the bi-level coordination mechanism.

title: Neuromorphic Spiking Neural Network-Based Explainable AI for Energy-Efficient, Quantum-Resistant Dynamic Access Control Systems with Temporal Causal Traceability
authors: Vishnukumar A, Dinesh B, Harini Pachaiyappan, Govarthan V, Lakshmi Priya V, Suvathika K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Traditional access control systems face unprecedented challenges from quantum computing threats, opaque AI decision-making, and stringent energy constraints. We propose a novel interdisciplinary framework that unifies neuromorphic computing with explainable AI (XAI) and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) to create a secure, interpretable, and energyefficient access control system. Our architecture employs Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neurons organized in Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) trained via Spike-Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP), inherently mimicking the brain's energy-efficient information processing. This neuromorphic foundation is augmented with a symbolic surrogate model that provides temporal-causal traceability of access decisions through interpretable causal graphs. To safeguard against quantum threats, we integrate lattice-based cryptography for credential exchange and authentication, ensuring long-term security. Experimental evaluation demonstrates an 87% reduction in energy consumption compared to conventional deep learning approaches while maintaining 94% access decision accuracy and providing complete decision justification trails. The modular design enables seamless integration with existing infrastructure, offering quantum-resistant security guarantees and human-interpretable access reasoning, thereby establishing a new paradigm for next-generation access control systems.

title: Blockchain-Driven Mitigation of Security Vulnerabilities in Software-Defined Networks Through a Systematic Review
authors: Mohit Marwaha, Rajeev Kumar Bedi, Sunil Kumar Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) is a new network architecture that decouples control plane (decision-making) from data plane (traffic handling). Though SDNs provide flexibility, scalability, and better network administration, it also presents new security threats such as attacks on control plane, switch-based attacks, and trust management among network entities. Blockchain with its distributed, tamper-proof record keeping can be able to enhance the security of SDNs by offering secure authorization, tamper-proof logging, and decentralized control thereby guaranteeing enhanced trust and accountability. In this paper, we have examined how Blockchain can be incorporated to improve SDN security by carrying out systematic literature review and suggesting a formal threat taxonomy and categorizing various SDN vulnerabilities with potential blockchain-based solutions.

title: Comparative Analysis of Vgg19 and Efficientnet-B3 for Automated Bird Species Classification Using Deep Learning
authors: Putumbaka Sravya, Khushi Vishwakarma, Ashutosh Sahu, Amit Panwar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Bird species identification is a prerequisite to biodiversity tracking, ecological studies, and wildlife conservation. Clearly identifying the species of birds enables researchers to monitor populations, detect changes in habitats, and inform effective conservation measures. However, the classification carried out traditionally by bird experts is usually time-consuming, laborious, and subject to human error, necessitating the use of strong automated mechanisms. In this research, we present a framework based on the use of deep learning techniques to classify bird species based on convolutional neural networks (CNN). VGG19 and EfficientNet-B3 were used, implemented, and analyzed on a dataset comprising 200 bird species with diverse visual features, totaling 2,400 images. Detailed experiments were conducted to determine the output of the competing models based on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. VGG19 achieved an accuracy of approximately 79.70 percent, while EfficientNet-B3 delivered superior performance with 98 percent accuracy, demonstrating the benefit of optimized compound scaling and efficient feature extraction. Our results indicate that birds can be automatically recognized very effectively based on the use of deep CNN-based models, representing important instruments used in ecological research as well as biodiversity conservation. This framework is capable of being used to support the conduct of largescale monitoring programs as part of developing smart wildlife management systems. The significant performance gap between the two architectures highlights the importance of model selection in fine-grained classification tasks. Both VGG19 and EfficientNetB3 were fine-tuned using ImageNet pre-trained weights, so as to leverage the transfer learning for better performance on the bird dataset. Such initialization helped the models to retain rich low-level visual features learned from large-scale natural images and accelerated the convergence on our limited dataset. By transferring these generalized representations, the networks required less training samples and resulted in significantly higher accuracy on fine-grained bird species recognition.

title: A Buck Power Factor Corrector Circuit with Reduced DC Bus Capacitor
authors: Hari Venkata Sai Kishore Pabbisetty, Arnab Kumar Pal, Snehamoy Patra, Amit Kumar Singha
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Powering a DC load from a single-phase system requires a cascaded two-stage configuration, which includes a Power Factor Correction (PFC) front-end, typically a boost PFC, followed by a point-of-load (POL) DC-DC converter. Elevated boost PFC output voltage increases the voltage stress of the POL converter. Moreover, the PFC DC-link voltage exhibits second harmonic voltage ripples, which are filtered out by bulky electrolytic capacitors. This requires a huge space and results in compromising with the power density. The use of electrolytic capacitors increases the hold-up time and energy support; however, the overall system life expectancy of the system is shortened. To address these issues, this paper proposes a structure by integrating a buck PFC with a shunt ripple cancellation converter (RCC). The inherent step-down capability of the buck PFC eliminates the high stress on POL, whereas RCC significantly absorbs the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{1 2 0 ~ H z}$</tex> load voltage ripple with a reduced amount of bus capacitance. Moreover, to control the RCC, a simple control structure is proposed, which consists of a single PI controller and a feedforward DC bus voltage sensing loop. Simulation and experimental results indicate that the proposed structure and the control mechanism significantly reduce the DC-link voltage ripple and effectively minimize the output capacitor size by a factor of five.

title: AUDRON: A Deep Learning Framework with Fused Acoustic Signatures for Drone Type Recognition
authors: Rajdeep Chatterjee, Sudip Chakrabarty, Trishaani Acharjee, Deepanjali Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), commonly known as drones, are increasingly used across diverse domains, including logistics, agriculture, surveillance, and defense. While these systems provide numerous benefits, their misuse raises safety and security concerns, making effective detection mechanisms essential. Acoustic sensing offers a low-cost and non-intrusive alternative to vision or radar-based detection, as drone propellers generate distinctive sound patterns. This study introduces AUDRON (AUdio-based Drone Recognition Network), a hybrid deep learning framework for drone sound detection, employing a combination of Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) spectrograms processed with convolutional neural networks (CNNs), recurrent layers for temporal modeling, and autoencoder-based representations. Feature-level fusion integrates complementary information before classification. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that AUDRON effectively differentiates drone acoustic signatures from background noise, achieving high accuracy while maintaining generalizability across varying conditions. AUDRON achieves 98.51% and 97.11% accuracy in binary and multiclass classification. The results highlight the advantage of combining multiple feature representations with deep learning for reliable acoustic drone detection, suggesting the framework’s potential for deployment in security and surveillance applications where visual or radar sensing may be limited.

title: Efficient Symmetric Key Based Fully Homomorphic Encryption Scheme
authors: Vinay Kumar Devara, Anshul Mishra, D. Ramesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In the age of cloud computing and big data analytics, how to protect the privacy of sensitive information in the computation is a severe problem. Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) is an interesting proposal to this problem as it allows performing computations on encrypted data without the need to decrypt it. Most known FHE schemes to date are however public key based and have a prohibitive computational and storage overhead, thus not useful in practice. In this paper, we propose efficient symmetric key based fully homomorphic encryption scheme which reduces computation complexity drastically without compromising the high level of security. The proposed scheme has its advantages of faster encryption, decryption, and evaluation time than the conventional public-key FHE systems by using lightweight symmetric key primitives and optimizations of homomorphic operations. The scheme can support additive and multiplicative homomorphism and therefore well-suited to many privacy-preserving tasks, such as secure cloud computation, encrypted data search, and private machine learning. The discussed symmetric FHE model is a good candidate to be used in practice in the cases when it is required to provide security and efficiency in computations.

title: Deep Multimodal Representation Learning for Social Media Based Depression Detection
authors: Ishu Mehra, Vandana Sharma, Geeta Sikka
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Social media platforms like Twitter generate massive amounts of multimodal content, such as text and images, which makes them a great source for learning about people's mental health. If we can detect signs of depression early from what users share online, it could help support timely interventions and assist clinical screening. Social media analysis provides useful opportunities for early depression detection. This work evaluates multimodal architectures that utilise various BERT text encoders with CNN image encoders to detect depressive expression in tweets. Our dataset consists of manually collected Twitter posts that were labeled by experts and crowd annotators. The best-performing model, RoBERTa+ResNet50, as per the accuracy, F1-score, and ROC-AUC. These results either match or surpass the performance of recent multimodal approaches. Our contributions include a newly labeled multimodal Twitter dataset, a thorough evaluation across transformer-CNN pairings for depression detection and a thorough analysis of model performance.

title: Design and Analysis of Dual Permanent Magnet Linear Machine with a Primary-Side Halbach Array
authors: Yiming Shen, Shengdao Zhu, Yanxin Li, Qinfen Lu, Christopher H. T. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual permanent magnet linear machine (DPMLM) with primary-side halbach array to minimize rare-earth PM usage while enhancing the thrust force density for long-distance applications. The proposed topology introduces asymmetric dual PM excitation, which simultaneously generates both second-order harmonic magnetomotive force (MMF) in the primary excitation (PE) and second-order harmonic permeance in the secondary excitation (SE). The paper first outlines the machine topology and operating principles under dual PM excitation. The main working principle is analyzed based on analytical modeling and further validated through finite element analysis (FEA). Finally, the electromagnetic performance of the DPMLM is evaluated and compared with other PMLMs. It is shown that the proposed DPMLM can achieve approximately 138% of the conventional PMLM's thrust force density while using merely 71% of the rare-earth PM volume over a 10-meter travel distance.

title: Principled Cyber–Physical System Design: From Foundations and Models to Practical Engineering
authors: Manfred Broy, Harald Ruess
publish: Computer
abstract: We present a principled approach to engineering cyber–physical systems (CPS) based on a semantically coherent framework of models for specifying, abstracting, designing, refining, and implementing software-intensive CPS. This framework supports essential systems and software engineering principles, such as encapsulation, information hiding, modular composition, and traceability.

title: Early Stage Detection of Knee Osteoporosis through X-Ray Imaging with Fine-Tuned VGG19
authors: Raghavendra Sridhar, Pratick Mondal, Rashi Nimesh Kumar Dhenia, Ishva Jitendrakumar Kanani, Ajay Khajuria, Gaurav Sharma, Deepak Banerjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Knee osteoporosis (KO) is a painful condition that is often associated with significant mobility issues and is a typical complication that undermines the strength of bones and increases the chances of fractures. Treatment requires early diagnosis; however, normal methods involve a physical examination and bone mineral density tests may overlook early bone defects. It is a customized VGG19 deep learning model that predicts knee osteoporosis with X-ray images. The VGG19 model that has a high performance in the image classification was altered into binary (healthy versus osteoporotic) classification with the help of the transfer learning. The model with both the Healthy and Osteoporosis category was trained and tested on a dataset of knee X-rays consisting of 1,258 training images, 315 validation images, and 472 testing images. The model performed excellent with a high level of recall, F1-scores, and accuracy of 97.5, which is extremely good with a high level of precision of 0.97. The general training and good generalization were observed in the generalization and confusion matrix with only 12 false negative and no false positives with the confusion matrix reveling the true validation loss although sporadic variations were observed in the training and validation loss. The document confirms the capability of deep learning models particularly VGG19 to automatize the detection of knee osteoporosis and, therefore, improve diagnostics accuracy. This plan can significantly enhance patient outcome since it provides physicians with a powerful tool of early diagnosis.

title: A Robust and Interpretable Deep Learning-Based System for Multi-Category Skin Cancer Categorization on Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
authors: Vinitha G, Rajakumar B, Nagakishore Bhavanam S, Surendran R, R. Rajalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Skin cancer remains one of the most common and potentially fatal malignancies worldwide, particularly in regions with limited access to dermatological expertise and advanced diagnostic tools.
