While deep learning has shown promise in improving diagnostic accuracy, its deployment on low-power edge devices remains a significant challenge due to computational constraints and interpretability issues. In this study, we propose a robust and interpretable deep learning framework for multiclass skin cancer detection, specifically optimized for resource-constrained environments such as rural clinics. The framework leverages an ensemble of lightweight CNN architectures-MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, and DenseNet121—combined via a feature fusion strategy to enhance classification performance. Advanced preprocessing, data augmentation, and class-balancing techniques are applied to improve generalizability on the HAM10000 dataset. Grad-CAM is integrated to provide visual explanations of model decisions, enhancing clinical trust. The proposed model achieves an accuracy of 98.25% with an inference time of 0.01 seconds on Raspberry Pi 5, demonstrating its feasibility for real-time, portable, and reliable skin cancer screening. This approach holds promise for democratizing dermatological diagnostics and improving early detection outcomes in underserved healthcare settings.

title: Improved Linear Estimation of Battery Open-Circuit Voltage and RC Model Parameters from Pulse-Relaxation Data
authors: Sooraj Sunil, Krishna R. Pattipati, Balakumar Balasingam
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Equivalent-circuit models (ECMs) are widely used to represent the electrical behavior of Li-ion batteries in battery management tasks for state estimation and control. A common approach for parameterizing an ECM is to perform pulse-relaxation tests and estimate model parameters from the recorded current-voltage data. This paper presents an improved two-stage least-squares (LS) estimation framework for estimating the ECM parameters of a battery, along with the open-circuit voltage, from such data. In the proposed method, the time constants are first estimated using a LS formulation, followed by a second LS step to determine the remaining circuit parameters. Compared to nonlinear LS techniques, the two-stage linear LS approach offers several advantages: it requires no initial guess, guarantees global convergence, simplifies stability analysis, enables experiment-design optimization, and achieves high computational efficiency due to its non-iterative structure. Experimental validation using data from four cylindrical Li-ion cells demonstrates the accuracy of the proposed method, achieving voltage-prediction errors below 1 mV across the battery operating range, making it a suitable choice for on-board battery management tasks.

title: Hybrid Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) for Patient-Centric EHR
authors: Edy Prayitno, Noor Alis Setiyadi, Erma Sofiani, Edi Iskandar, Basuki Heri Winarno, Sri Setyowati
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Securing Electronic Health Records (EHRs) in cloud and Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) environments requires cryptography that remains resilient against quantum-capable adversaries while preserving patient-centric consent and auditability. This study assesses the feasibility of a Hybrid Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) approach for patient-controlled EHR access, focusing on performance, cost, security, and usability. The proposed design integrates TLS 1.3 with hybrid key encapsulation (X25519+ML-KEM-768) and ML-DSA, Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) R4 off-chain storage, Ethereum Proof-of-Authority smart contracts for grant/revoke operations and on-chain indices, and IPFS for large objects. Synthetic EHR workloads generated by Synthea were tested under realistic network impairments, with handshake latency, end-to-end read/write latency, throughput, revocation latency, and gas units as primary endpoints, and attack resilience and usability scores as secondary endpoints. Results show that Hybrid PQC increases TLS handshake latency by about 25% compared with ECC-only, while maintaining approximately 91% of baseline throughput. Revocation latency averaged 1.84 seconds and consent transactions consumed about 85k gas units, while attacks such as man-in-the-middle, downgrade, and replay were fully prevented under policy. Usability testing indicated acceptable performance with a System Usability Scale score of 78.5. These findings suggest that Hybrid PQC enables quantum-ready, auditable, and patient-centric EHR access with bounded overhead and minimal impact on clinical throughput, while also highlighting the need for multi-site validation and further optimization of PQC performance in healthcare contexts.

title: Adaptive Real-Time Meta-Learning Framework with Hybrid AI Classifiers for Live Detection and Mitigation of DDoS Attacks
authors: Anita Sofia Liz. D.R., Rame Riadhusin, Akash Bhattacharya, Khusainov Ilyos Jamoliddin ugli, J. Santhosh Kumar, S. Kannimuthu, Shuhrat Sirojiddinov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks remain one of the most critical and persistent threats to network security, causing severe service disruptions and economic losses by overwhelming network infrastructures with malicious traffic. Traditional detection frameworks, which rely on static or pre-trained AI classifiers, often fail to identify newly emerging or stealth attack variants due to their limited adaptability and lack of real-time learning capability. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an Adaptive Meta-Learning Framework integrated with Hybrid AI Classifiers for intelligent, real-time DDoS detection and mitigation. The proposed framework employs meta-learning to rapidly adapt to novel attack scenarios using minimal data, thereby enhancing model generalization and resilience to zero-day threats. A hybrid ensemble architecture combining Graph Neural Networks (GNN), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), and Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) is developed to capture spatial, temporal, and topological characteristics of network traffic. To strengthen robustness, an adversarial training module based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) is incorporated, enabling resistance against evasion and adversarial attacks. For dynamic response, a reinforcement learning-based mitigation agent autonomously selects optimal countermeasures-such as IP blocking and rate limiting-balancing network performance and service continuity. Furthermore, an edge-cloud collaborative processing layer distributes computational tasks efficiently, ensuring low latency at the edge and scalability in the cloud. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets (CICIDS2017, CICDDoS2019) and adversarially generated data demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves superior detection accuracy (85.7%), faster adaptation speed, and improved mitigation effectiveness compared with state-of-the-art baselines. The research establishes a comprehensive, intelligent, and scalable defense mechanism capable of maintaining network integrity in evolving threat environments. This work contributes a novel synthesis of meta-learning, hybrid ensemble intelligence, and reinforcement-based mitigation for real-time, adaptive DDoS protection.

title: Development of Dependable Systems Using Constrained Colored Petri Nets
authors: Carolina Lagartinho-Oliveira, Filipe Moutinho, Luís Gomes
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper introduces constrained colored Petri nets (CCP-nets), a high-level Petri net formalism that facilitates the creation and deployment of dependable systems. CCP-nets employ abstraction mechanisms such as colors, colored tokens, and variables, which are subject to explicit constraints. This enables compact modeling of complex behaviors, simplifying design, and ensures compatibility with unfolding techniques, allowing models to be integrated with verification and implementation tools. Here, we define the syntax and semantics of CCP-nets and clarify their role within the adopted model-driven development approach. Through an example, we discuss how CCP-nets' highlevel features reduce design effort while supporting state-space analysis and code generation for target platforms.

title: Evaluating the Efficiency and Fidelity of Image Compression Methods: From Classical Codecs to Deep Learning Approaches
authors: Poonam Rani, Rounak Gupta, Mehul Raj, Palak, Kritika Tanwar, Tushar Dahiya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: This study uses the BSDS500 dataset, which consists of 500 natural images with different textures and illuminating conditions and then applied different image compression techniques such as Autoencoder, LZMA, JPEG, and JPEG2000. To compare these methods, we use performance metrics such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), Compression Ratio (CR), Compression Factor (CF), Bits per Pixel (BPP), and Space Savings (SSs%). The study shows that JPEG2000 outputs the best image quality in terms of MSE, PSNR, and SSIM, while JPEG is the most efficient method, as it saves the most space in compressing the image. The Autoencoder, which is based on deep learning, can handle complex images, but its high computing cost and long training time make it less suitable for everyday image compression tasks.

title: CardioRiskMapper: A Predictive Model for Assessing Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Clinical Decision Making
authors: Murugan Ramu, Srinidhi P C, Subhalakshmi A, Vandana B, Amritha C
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: CardioRiskMapper is a predictive deep learning framework designed to assess cardiovascular risk factors and enhance clinical decision-making using multi-source clinical data. The model combines the strong ensemble architecture made up of Gradient Boosted Decision Trees (XGBoost), support vector machines (SVM) and deep neural networks (DNN) with attention mechanism to highlight the high impact risk variables. Clinical data extracted from benchmark datasets such as the UCI Heart Disease dataset and institutional Electronic Health Records (EHRs) were utilized in training and validation of the model. Data preprocessing received Z-score normalization, MICE-based imputation, one-hot encoding and outlier filtering as preprocessing techniques while feature selection received statistical testing and PCA-based dimensionality reduction. ACC/AHA thresholds and Framingham Risk Scores were used in stratifying risk. Performance of CardioRiskMapper across 5 key evaluation metrics including Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1 Score and AUC-ROC vindicates superior ability of CardioRiskMapper. The developed model performed relatively well with an accuracy of 93.6% which is much better than baseline models which include Logistic Regression 83.2%, and Random Forest of 87.1 %. The proposed model also was able to deliver an AUC-ROC value of 96.1%, demonstrating robust classification ability to differentiate between low-, medium-, and high-risk patients. Representing a clinically actionable tool for early cardiovascular risk prediction and planning patient-specific interventions with high interpretability through SHAP and LIME and an easy integration to EHR, CardioRiskMapper is one of the proposed technologies.

title: A Multi-Modal Quantification of Parkinson’s Medication Response Using Kinematic Rigidity Profiling and Acoustic Feature Regression: A Proof-of-Concept Study
authors: Abhishriya Mahanta, Dhruv Kansal, Daksh, Shubhajit Roy Chowdhury
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: PD affects over 60% of people above 50, and its UPDRS-based monitoring demands clinical visits and lengthy evaluations, making monitoring costly and inconvenient. This paper presents a first integrated multi-modal telemonitoring system for Parkinson’s disease, combining kinematic rigidity profiling with speech-based regression modelling to estimate medication response severity in Parkinson. Wrist rigidity is quantified using synchronized Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs), while acoustic features extracted from sustained phonation are used to predict UPDRS scores via an XGBoost regression model. Both modalities are fused to generate a unified Medication Response Score (MRS), providing a continuous estimation of patient state rather than categorical ON/OFF detection. This multi-modal fusion will be performed using an application-based system responsible for all data processing and user interaction. For the speech part, we used the largest known PD speech database, comprising nearly 6,000 recordings from 42 patients, gathered over a six-month, multi-centre trial. Preliminary prototyping, hardware validation and algorithm of our regression model achieved R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> 0.887 and MSE 11.49, demonstrating strong alignment with clinician-rated UPDRS. A Bland–Altman analysis confirmed minimal bias acceptable agreement limits. These results highlight the feasibility of a non-invasive, low-cost, portable system for remote UPDRS tracking in Parkinson’s telemonitoring. Future work will integrate full sensor–speech processing on-device with clinical-grade validation.

title: Employing random forest regression and oceanic factors to predict the occurrence of marine heatwaves
authors: S. Arockia Jayadhas
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Marine heat waves are occurring with increased frequency and severity, posing a significant hazard to global marine ecosystems. They induce coral bleaching, species displacement, and the decline of marine biodiversity. Predictive models of maritime climate are crucial for marine conservation and the development of early warning systems. This study employed random forest regression utilizing significant oceanographic and ecological variables, including sea surface temperature (SST), pH, latitude, longitude, location, bleaching rate, and observed species, to develop a data-driven methodology for predicting marine heat waves. The collection includes temporal and spatial characteristics, such as date and geographic coordinates, which provide precise pattern identification in the environment. We employed GridSearchCV to refine the model’s hyper parameters for enhanced accuracy. The model proposed has achieved an impressive $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ score of 0.89 and a minimal mean square error, indicating its suitability for simulating intricate situations. Furthermore, the study of feature importance indicated that SST and pH serve as effective predictors. The proposed method demonstrates the efficacy of ensemble learning in forecasting marine climate and supports proactive ecological management in response to climate change.

title: Intelligence Shoes with Live Tracking and Health Analytics
authors: Sanjana Prasad, N. Bhanupriya, K.C. Meghana, Monika. S, Syed Ameena Ruman, Ishu Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: This study introduces a novel smart shoe platform that combines real-time physiological monitoring, location tracking and sustainable power generation in a single, user-friendly design. Outfitted with heartbeat, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SpO}_{2}$</tex> and skin-temperature sensors alongside a GPS module, the footwear continuously captures vital signs and positional data, transmitting encrypted readings over a cloud-enabled Wi-Fi link to a dedicated mobile application for remote caregiver oversight. Unlike existing wearable systems that depend on frequent recharging and often compromise comfort or aesthetics, our prototype employs embedded kinetic-energy harvesters to achieve self-sustaining operation, and is engineered with durable, water-resistant materials to withstand daily wear. By integrating advanced health-tracking features, seamless device interoperability and robust energy management, this eco-conscious Internet-of-Things solution addresses limitations in battery life, bulkiness and cost-offering an affordable, discreet and secure tool for continuous wellness assessment and personal safety.

title: YOLOv5-WMA: Improved YOLOv5 with Windowed Multi-Head Attention for Infrared Welding Anomaly Detection
authors: Zhen Ding, Jie Zhou, Xueli Feng, Heping Huang, Hui Chen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: In this work, an enhanced YOLOv5-based model, termed YOLOv5-WMA (Windowed Multi-Head Attention), is proposed to address the challenges of detecting subtle anomalies within complex infrared backgrounds. The model incorporates the core module of the Swin Transformer—Shifted Window Multi-Head Self-Attention (SW-MSA)—into the backbone to facilitate cross-window feature interaction and improve global context modeling in weak-texture regions. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv5-WMA achieves an mAP of 87.1% on a self-constructed dataset, surpassing the baseline YOLOv5 by 1.5% and enhancing precision by 4%. This approach provides a high-precision, real-time solution with strong applicability in industrial non-destructive testing scenarios.

title: Techno Economic and ML Optimization of IOE Integrated Hybrid Solar-Wind-Biomass Microgrid in Remote Kerala Village, India - A Case Study
authors: Renugadevi P, Sudha Anbalagan, Srimathi R
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: This study presents a new framework for rural electrification in village, Kerala, India, that utilizes machine learning (ML) and IoE (Internet of everything) to improve techno-economic performance. The framework is IoE integrated and hybrid solar-wind-biomass. Using the IoE platform, data is collected in real-time via Message queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) protocols from a variety of distributed energy resources, including 50 kW of PV, 20 kW of wind, 30 kW of biomass, 100 kWh of Li-ion storage, and an 800 kWh/day load. While ML algorithms such as Long short-term memory (LSTM) for forecasting and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for dispatch then optimize system sizing and operation under Kerala's monsoonal climate, HOMER (Hybrid Optimization of Multiple Energy Resources) Pro (v3.16) conducts techno-economic analysis. The results show that compared to diesel baselines, there is a 25 % reduction in Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE) (from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\$ 0.12 / \text{kWh}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\$ 0. 0 9 / k W h}$</tex>), 99.5% continuity of supply (LPSP <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<\mathbf{0. 5 \%}$</tex>), and 150 tons/year abatement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>. With LCOE increasing by only 5 % for every 10 % increase in biomass price, sensitivity analysis verifies resilience. The suggested system outperforms non-ML hybrids and achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 - 3 0 \%}$</tex> more cost efficiency and superior dependability via ML-IoE synergy, in comparison to previous research (such as solar-biomass LCOE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\$ 0.15 / \text{kWh}$</tex> in Bihar and biomass-based hybrid renewable energy systems (HRES) in Kerala, which range from $0.08 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\$ 0.12 / \text{kWh}$</tex>. This reproducible concept provides a framework for rural Indian villages to become energy independent for long run, by reducing fossil fuels and expensive grid upgrades and shown in a graphical abstract “Fig 1”.

title: Transfer Learning for Survival Analysis with Application to Breast Cancer Risk Prediction
authors: Houtian Yi, Xin Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Our research applies the new algorithm, Trans-Cox algorithm, to the real datasets about the breast cancer. Trans-Cox algorithm hopes to borrow information from source datasets in order to improve the estimation based on the target datasets. We also compare the variance of the estimator and risk prediction performance in Trans-Cox algorithm to those in some traditional methods, such as fitting the cox model directly based on the target datasets. The results are much similar to those in the paper which proposed the Trans-Cox algorithm. We also give some thinkings about the real data analysis with the application of the Trans-Cox algorithm.

title: Deploying Context-Aware AI Tools for Internal Organizational Communication
authors: Lavanya Morasani, Mamatha G, Badana Upendra, Vivek Veeraiah, Ankur Gupta, Krishna Nand Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: As the use of hybrid workplaces and digital transformation becomes more widespread, organizations are in need of intelligent technologies that are able to collaborate in ways that traditional artificial intelligence is unable to. The purpose of this study is to analyze the approach that context-aware artificial intelligence systems use to evaluate user roles, activities, locations, task statuses, and interaction histories in order to revolutionize interpersonal communication. With the purpose of determining the most successful methods in which context-aware artificial intelligence improves communication via enhanced customization, efficiency, and appropriateness, this study conducts an analysis of twenty-five current research originating from academic and industrial sources. We want a multi-level system that merges machine learning, natural language processing, and semantic reasoning in order to achieve better and more real-time communication. It has been shown by the results of the review that there have been significant shifts in the amount of time required to complete tasks, the level of contentment experienced by users, and the degree of discomfort experienced by users when conversing with other individuals. The study investigates the safety of data, the degree to which individuals have faith in the system, the way in which the system functions as whole, and the methods for dealing with ambiguity. By doing a substantial amount of research and putting prototypes through rigorous testing, businesses have the potential to design communication systems that are honest, adaptable, and ready to expand. In this study, we present novel approaches to learning that safeguard individuals' privacy, provide light on artificial intelligence, and include multi-modal context modeling.

title: Intra-Lead ECG Analysis for Deepfake Detection Using Temporal Neural Networks
authors: Mallikarjun Yeshlur, Manthan B T, Ammaar Mohammed Faiz, Rashmi Ugarakhod
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Recent advancements in Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have made it possible to produce very realistic deepfake electrocardiogram (ECG) signals, posing serious threats to data integrity, clinical decision-making, and biometric security. This work presents use of Temporal convolutional networks (TCN) which enables simultaneous capture of local waveform characteristics and global temporal patterns, ensuring comprehensive signal representation for distinguishing deepfake from authentic ECG signals. Our approach emphasizes Intra-lead analysis, where models are trained to learn temporal patterns within individual ECG leads, rather than relying on interlead correlations. This helps the models focus on lead-specific morphological cues that may be subtly distorted in synthetic ECGs, avoiding artifact-based learning. We test the approach on a collection of 10-second ECG records at 500 Hz sampling rate, which is evenly split between authentic and artificially generated signals. With early stopping and learning rate tuning, the proposed TCN model attained accuracy of 98.58% at a learning rate of 0.001. Results reflect the susceptibility of AI-based healthcare systems to adversarial-generated physiological signals and the necessity for secure frameworks to guarantee the authenticity of ECG data.

title: Enhanced Plant Leaf Disease Detection Using Optimized Machine Learning Models
authors: Akshaya Kubba, Vikas Wasson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Plant diseases present one of the greatest challenges for global agriculture, particularly in areas where a swift response to disease is crucial to avoid widespread crop damage. Manual traditional methods of inspection are time-consuming, error-prone and do not scale. In this paper, we propose a machine learning-based model for real-time plant leaf disease identification using a new lightweight convolutional network (AgroNet-Light) optimized in relation to edge computing. Different from previous methods like entropy- aware data sampling, interpretability via Grad-CAM and adaptive feedback for model evolution in their own way, our work combines them with each other. Quantitative experiments on joint datasets, which contain field-captured images, show that the proposed model is robust under diverse visual conditions and capable of generalizing across crops and regions. Additionally, we demonstrate how the optimization techniques such as quantization and pruning enable integration with mobile and IoT devices without compromising prediction accuracy. Our work provides a deployment-ready farmercentred initiative, that not only diagnoses the disease, but also educates the user thereby paving the path toward a participatory and smart farming future.

title: A Pattern-Based Predictive Optimization of E-Shape Antenna Design Using Pre-Simulated Data
authors: Yulindon Yulindon, Noor Azah Samsudin, Riswan Efendi
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Full-wave simulation–based optimization of antennas is computationally expensive because methods such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) require repeated iterations of full-wave analysis. The core innovation of this work is the reuse of pre-simulated optimization data to develop a fast and reusable predictive model, thereby eliminating the need for new simulations in Computer Simulation Technology (CST) Studio Suite during the design phase. The proposed Pattern-Based Predictive Optimization (PBPO) framework transforms a compact set of PSO/GA optimization results into regression-based equations that map the operating frequency directly to the dominant antenna dimensions (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> and W<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>). We demonstrate this framework through the design of an E-shape microstrip patch antenna, where the predictive model efficiently generates geometry without iterative full-wave computation. The results show that PBPO significantly reduces design time while maintaining dimensional consistency with conventional optimization methods. This approach offers substantial benefits for rapid prototyping, educational applications, and computationally efficient antenna design.

title: An Integrated Framework for Real-Time Crime Prediction and Trend Analysis Using Crime Cast-AI
authors: Chitra S, Kanishka S M, Gayathri S, Jagadeesh P M, Ajay Kumar M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Crime poses a significant public safety concern in rapidly growing urban areas. Conventional machine learning and time series methods tend to find it difficult to manage intricate patterns over space and time, particularly when facing large amounts of data and multiple types of data. To this, the Crime Pattern Analyzer makes use of advanced AI technologies to categorize crimes, forecast future cases, and ascertain where crimes occur more efficiently. The system uses CatBoost, a robust algorithm capable of processing categorical and imbalanced data. It achieved over 90% F1-score in identifying crimes like burglary and theft, and improved classification accuracy by 13-15% compared to older models like Logistic Regression and Random Forest. To comprehend how crimes occur over time, a GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) network was employed, which achieved 87% accuracy for recording weekly and monthly trends and minimized over fitting by 20%. For predictive purposes of trend in future crime, the Prophet model identified seasonal peaks, as denoted by thefts and assaults increasing by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18-22 \%$</tex> in months like March and October. Geographically, Folium was employed to create interactive heat maps, determining that 25% of the crime was concentrated in only 12% of the Indian city area. Together, the system enhanced analysis by 38%, providing an accurate and scalable system that enables police to plan more effectively, utilize resources in a more suitable manner, and control city crime more efficiently.

title: A Data-Based Digital Twin Model for Distributed Systems in the Field
authors: Atefeh Gooran Orimi, Rayen Hamlaoui, Christian Backe, Veit Briken, Roland Lachmayer
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Digital Twin Models (DTMs) have received significant interest in recent years, particularly in industrial and engineering fields. While current models, especially those developed based on the concept of Digital Master (DM) and Digital Shadows (DSs), have proven effective in various industrial domains, their extension to field-related distributed systems remains underexplored. This paper proposes a data-based DTM tailored for such systems, incorporating humans, cyber-physical systems, and the environment operating under real-world conditions. The model emphasizes robust data management in alignment with FAIR principles to enhance data reusability. We present the details of the model and discuss its various characteristics, using a practical use-case from the GOLO archetype within the NFDI4Ing consortium. The investigated use-case includes a sensor-equipped vehicle operating in urban environments, which demonstrates the applicability of the proposed model.

title: M3ET: Efficient Vision-Language Learning for Robotics based on Multimodal Mamba-Enhanced Transformer
authors: Yanxin Zhang, Liang He, Zeyi Kang, Zuheng Ming, Kaixing Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In recent years, multimodal learning has become essential in robotic vision and information fusion, especially for understanding human behavior in complex environments. However, current methods struggle to fully leverage the textual modality, relying on supervised pretrained models, which limits semantic extraction in unsupervised robotic environments—particularly with significant modality loss. These methods also tend to be computationally intensive, leading to high resource consumption in real-world applications. To address these challenges, we propose the Multi-Modal Mamba-Enhanced Transformer (M3ET), a lightweight model designed for efficient multimodal learning, particularly on mobile platforms. By incorporating the Mamba module and a semantic-based adaptive attention mechanism, M3ET optimizes feature fusion, alignment, and modality reconstruction. Our experiments show that M3ET improves cross-task performance, with a 2.3 times increase in pre-training inference speed. Particularly, the core VQA task accuracy of M3ET remains at 74.18%, while the model’s parameter count is reduced by 66.63%. Although performance on the EQA task is limited, M3ET’s lightweight design makes it well-suited for deployment on resource-constrained robotic platforms.

title: Novel 9-Level Switched Capacitor Inverter with Reduced Components and Variable Frequency PWM
authors: Geno Peter, Albert Alexander Stonier, Vijayakumar Arun, Samat Iderus
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: The primary objective of this research is to develop Minimal Component Switched Capacitor High-Gain 9-Level Inverter (MCSCHG9LI), which has a Unipolar Trapezoidal Variable Frequency Pulse Width Modulation (UTVFPWM) control. The key objective of this study is to overcome the constraints of typical multilayer inverters (MLIs), which include the need of bigger switches, sources, diodes, and capacitors. The proposed MCSCHG9LI comprises a single DC supply, two capacitors, eight switches, and a pair of diodes to provide nine distinct levels of output. When contrasted to other relevant inverter systems, the MCSCHG9LI requires the minimum possible of components. Additionally, employing a Unipolar variable frequency multi-carrier modulation technique with a Trapezoidal reference enhances the quality of the waveforms developed. The results of MATLAB simulations are used to assess the MCSCHG9LI’s overall functionality. This assessment relies upon the relatively low total harmonic distortion and high DC bus utilization achieved by successful utilization of a variety of UTVFPWM controls and modulation indices.

title: Integrated Electrical and Thermal Model of Li-ion Batteries for Accurate SOC, Core Temperature, and Internal Resistance Estimation
authors: Omid Rezaei, Majid Gharebaghi, Masoud Dahmardeh, Zhanle Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: State of charge (SOC) estimation and thermal management are the key components of electric vehicle (EV) management systems (BMSs). However, accurate estimation is challenging, and battery temperature has a great impact on SOC estimation and battery thermal management. To address these challenges, the proposed model integrates the equivalent circuit model (ECM) and thermal dynamic equations. This model can accurately estimate SOC, terminal voltage, surface and core temperatures, and internal resistance of Li-ion batteries. Experiments are conducted using a battery cell under the Hybrid Pulse Power Characterization (HPPC) test method and a Fiat 500e 2020 electric vehicle battery pack under the Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Cycle (WLTC) signals. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves an SOC estimation error of less than 1%. Additionally, the model can provide an estimate of internal resistance and core temperature, which can be utilized in state of health (SOH) estimation and thermal management. The application of the proposed model can significantly enhance battery safety, efficiency, and extend the life of EV batteries.

title: Explainable AI for Deep Gait-based Fall Detection Models: Smartphone vs. Wearable Inertial Sensors
authors: Jayeeta Chakraborty, Vedant Kumar, Vishal Singh, Shilpa Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Explainable AI for gait assessment is an emerging approach that combines the capabilities of artificial intelligence with the interpretability of automated gait assessment systems. Gait-based fall prediction generally uses motion data captured using wearable inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensors, vision sensors, and pressure sensors. Despite growing interest in Smartphone-based fall prediction, these systems often face distrust among clinicians, questioning its clinical reliability. In this experimental study, we present a comparison of the interpretability and trustworthiness of automated fall prediction models trained on mobile IMU data and wearable IMU data. For this purpose, a bidirectional Long Short-term Memory model is trained on two standard datasets - MobiFall and KFall. The MobiFall dataset incorporates data from a smartphone of participants engaging in various activities and a range of falls. The KFall dataset includes falls and daily activities of individuals, collected using waist-worn IMUs. We utilize SHapley (SHAP) Additive exPlanations and Layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP) approach to explain the model’s predictions for both datasets. The predictor variables are analyzed for their contribution to the performance of the prediction models. The interpretability of the variables derived from smartphone and wearable IMU devices is compared to validate the applicability of mobile sensors for fall prediction. The maximum SHAP values reported for the MobiFall and the KFall datasets are 0.01877 and 0.0202, respectively. The visualization of the LRP relevance score demonstrates a deeper understanding of the features in the deep learning model that enhance the trustworthiness of systems designed to predict falls, enabling clinicians to provide more informed patient care, treatment plans, and interventions.

title: Comparative Analysis and Final Selection of the Best Reference Frame for MTPA Control Implementation in DI-WRIM Drives
authors: Cheshta Jain, Abhishek Shaw, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of different reference frames for implementing Maximum Torque per Volt (MTPV) control in Doubly Fed Induction Wound-Rotor Induction Motor (DI-WRIM) drives and identifies the most suitable one for practical realization. The design of voltage controllers required for MTPV operation is examined in three reference frames: rotor flux, air-gap flux, and current-oriented. While MTPV control in the rotor flux-oriented frame is established in literature, this work extends the analysis to air-gap flux and current-oriented reference frames as well. Based on comparative assessment, the most appropriate reference frame is selected for implementation. The simulation and experimental results corresponding to the final selected reference frame are presented to validate the effectiveness of the proposed MTPV control approach. This study provides valuable insights into reference frame selected for efficient MTPV operation in DI-WRIM drives.

title: Deep Learning Model Development Using a Super-Resolution Approach for Age and Gender Recognition in Low-Resolution Facial Images
authors: Jonathan Adrian, Gede Putra Kusuma, Ariadi Nugroho
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study evaluates the effectiveness of using super resolution (SR) techniques as a preprocessing step to improve age and gender recognition from severely low resolution (LR) facial images. Three SR models, SFMNet, FishFSRNet, and MAIC, were trained to upscale 8×8 LR facial images from the UTKFace dataset to 128×128 pixels (16× SR). All experiments used a stratified 80:10:10 train, validation, and test split. The SR models were trained with the Adam optimizer for 50 to 100 epochs with early stopping, while the recognition models, GRA_Net, XceptionAG, and a modified CNN, were trained using Adam or SGD under the same early stopping technique. Results show that deep learning recognition models perform poorly when directly applied to 8×8 images. FishFSRNet was identified as the strongest SR model in reconstruction quality, achieving an SSIM of 0.7598 and a PSNR of 25.28 dB on the test set. Across all SR and recognition model combinations, SR consistently improved recognition-stage performance. The best overall results were obtained by combining the XceptionAG recognition model with the SFMNet SR model, producing the lowest Mean Absolute Error of 6.3956 years for age estimation and the highest gender classification accuracy of 0.8880. These findings demonstrate that a two stage SR enhanced pipeline provides a reliable and effective approach for recognition tasks in severe low resolution scenarios.

title: Integrating BFV Homomorphic Encryption and BB84 QKD: A Simulation Study of Quantum-Resilient Encrypted Computation
authors: Chitra M, Aditya N, Dhruv Shankar, Devarajan A N, Aaryan Singh Sunil
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: In order to investigate quantum-resilient encrypted computation, we create and assess a prototype framework that combines a simulated BB84 quantum key distribution (QKD) protocol with the Brakerski–Fan–Vercauteren (BFV) homomorphic encryption scheme. We benchmark encrypted polynomial evaluations under identical parameter settings using Qiskit-based BB84 simulation and Microsoft SEAL for BFV, contrasting a pure-BFV baseline with the integrated BFV+QKD workflow. The hybrid design achieves comparable end-to-end latency, stable ciphertext sizes, and correct decryption across all tested parameter sets in our experiments on a single commodity server, suggesting that it is possible to integrate QKD-derived session keys for evaluation-key protection in this setting without incurring prohibitive overhead. These findings are restricted to single-node experiments and idealized QKD simulation; they do not account for physical quantum channels, network latency, or large-scale multi-tenant deployments, which are left for future research. The evaluation is conducted under an honest-but-curious server model and an idealized BB84 simulation, and does not provide a composable security proof of the integrated QKD–HE workflow.

title: Greedy Adaptive Critics and Integral Reinforcement Learning: Convergence and Optimal Control for Constrained-Input Systems
authors: Fengyu Geng, Shuanghe Yu, Menghan Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Reinforcement learning has been successfully applied to continuous state space problems, with neural networks widely employed for adaptive evaluator research. It has also been utilised for solving the Hamilton-Jacobi Bellman equation in online learning for partially constrained input systems. Theoretical proofs in this field remain largely confined to specific scenarios such as linear-quadratic (LQ) systems, with limitations including the inability to guarantee optimal policy discovery or demonstrate narrow scope. This paper therefore proposes an integral reinforcement learning (IRL) algorithm based on an actor-critic architecture to address these challenges. The IRLbased controller design analyses the implementation of four adaptive critic variants within LQR, integrating actor-critic and experience replay online learning algorithms to address optimal control for partially unknown continuous-time systems subject to input constraints. The Linear Quadratic Regulation (LQR) optimal controller utilises the Integral Reinforcement Learning (IRL) algorithm to update critic network weights, providing an online adaptive solution for partially unknown systems. This experiment demonstrates that the IRL algorithm, based on an Actor-Critic architecture, converges to theoretically optimal solutions without relying on system dynamics models. The stable convergence of the weight vector yields results that closely match the theoretical optimum. This work not only resolves optimal control problems for partially unknown continuous-time systems subject to input constraints but also designs controllers that are more intelligent, reliable, and adaptable, bridging control theory and reinforcement learning.

title: Doppler-Robust Zero-Crossing Deep Autoencoder Vocoder for Secure and Efficient Underwater Acoustic Speech Communication
authors: R K Sunil Kumar, Ebin Antony, V V Sameer, K V Aljinu Khadar
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Ocean Technology (SYMPOL)
abstract: Underwater speech communication suffers from bandwidth limits, multipath fading, and Doppler distortions that degrade intelligibility. Conventional vocoders transmit spectral features that are highly Doppler-sensitive. This paper proposes a Zero-Crossing Deep Autoencoder Vocoder (ZC-DAEV) that exploits the Doppler-robustness of inter–zero-crossing intervals (IZCI) and compresses them with deep autoencoders. Mathematical analysis shows that normalized IZCIs are invariant up to a global scaling factor, and become exactly invariant after normalization, enabling stable feature extraction. Global median and sliding-window correction further address constant and time-varying Doppler effects. The IZCI–sign sequences are encoded into low-dimensional latent codes, combined with encrypted auxiliary parameters, and reconstructed securely at the receiver. Experiments on clean and simulated underwater speech demonstrate that ZC-DAEV achieves intelligible reconstruction at 800 bps, improving STOI scores over LPC-10 (0.81 to 0.85 in clean speech, 0.65 to 0.75 at 3 dB SNR, and 0.58 to 0.64 with Doppler, α ≈ 1.05). Security tests confirm that intercepted features alone remain unintelligible without the encrypted key. These results highlight ZC-DAEV as a robust, low-bitrate, and secure solution for underwater acoustic speech communication.

title: Using an Immersive Virtual Reality Game Guided by Generative AI for Fifth-Grade Science Learning
authors: Vivien Lin, Cheng-Ji Lai, Kim Koh
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Scientific concept learning poses challenges for English language learners with issues related to not only language but also content difficulties. This study attempts to address existing problems related to scientific learning among fifth-grade English-Mandarin bilingual learners via the implementation an immersive virtual reality (IVR) game supported by generative AI. The game aimed to enhance scientific vocabulary and concept learning through game mechanisms combined with Gen-AI feedback and guidance. The researchers adopted quasi-experimental design and conducted a pilot test that compared outcomes between the Treatment (IVR game with GenAI Guidance) and Comparison (IVR game with Pre-programmed Guidance) Groups. The pilot test results showed that while the two groups did not show significant difference in terms of vocabulary acquisition, students in the Treatment Group outperformed those in the Comparison group for concept acquisition. Based on this positive finding on enhancing scientific learning, the researchers made recommendations about adopting Gen-AI-guided IVR games as a complementary learning mode to typical instruction for science learning among English language learners in elementary school settings.

title: Comparative Machine Learning Analysis for Predicting Container Turnaround Time in ESG-Driven Port Marine Systems
authors: Sucianna Ghadati Rabiha, Fajar Kurniawan, Fauzi Khair, Amir Tjolleng, Siti Nurmaya Musa, Muhamad Qosim, Afifah Nur Fadiyah
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Sustainable port operations and efficient container handling are essential components of competitiveness in modern maritime logistics. Although machine learning (ML) has been widely applied to port operations, particularly for berth scheduling, crane allocation, and yard optimization, current approaches generally emphasize operational efficiency and rarely integrate sustainability requirements. This gap limits the capacity of predictive systems to support emerging Smart Port environments, where performance must align with Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) principles. To address this need, this study develops an ESG-driven predictive framework for estimating container turnaround time using six ML algorithms: Generalized Linear Model (GLM), Deep Learning, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosted Trees, and Support Vector Machine. Historical operational characteristics, such as berth time, crane efficiency, loading and unloading rates, and delay factors, were analyzed utilizing RapidMiner. Experimental results indicate that GLM attains the lowest Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.175, while providing the fastest runtime of 7 seconds, surpassing more complex ensemble methods and neural network models. These findings demonstrate that operational variables display strong linear correlations with turnaround efficiency, thereby rendering GLM appropriate for real-time decision support. By integrating ESG considerations into the predictive process, the proposed model improves environmental performance, reinforces governance coordination, and promotes social workload equilibrium. This study presents a computationally effective methodology for the sustainability-oriented transformation of smart ports.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization Method of Distribution Network Outage Planning Based on Interpretable Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Wang Guangming, Xue Hanjin, Li Zhi, Zheng Fangfang, Wu Yonghui, Cheng Siqi
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the access of large-scale renewable energy and the increasing uncertainty of both sources and loads, the power grid presents high-dimensional and strong nonlinear characteristics, which makes it difficult for traditional scheduling optimization algorithms to give consideration to both computational efficiency and dynamic adaptability. The deep reinforcement learning algorithm can deal with high-dimensional dynamic characteristics and uncertainties, and can be used to solve the above problems. However, due to its “black box” characteristics, the decision-making is poorly interpretable and easily deviates from the scheduling rules, so it has not been effectively applied in engineering practice. In order to solve this problem, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization method of distribution network outage planning based on interpretable deep reinforcement learning. Firstly, the equivalent aggregation strategy of nodes in each time period is designed, and the secondary nodes are aggregated based on the load influence threshold to reduce the state space dimension. Secondly, a multi-objective optimization model including power outage loss load, workload balance and power outage cost is constructed and solved by deep reinforcement learning. Then, an interpretability enhancement mechanism based on expert experience and scheduling rules is proposed, which directly transforms key expert experience such as equipment health threshold and load peak threshold into state space characteristics and action space constraints, making the decision-making process transparent and traceable, enhancing the interpretability and engineering credibility of DRL, and solving the “black box” problem. Finally, the near-end strategy optimization algorithm is used to train the model, and the trained model is used to make optimization decisions. The example shows that this method can not only ensure the economy and reliability of power grid, but also significantly improve the calculation efficiency and interpretability of the algorithm.

title: Performance Evaluation and Optimization of Energy Storage in Renewable-Powered Nanogrid Systems
authors: Saher Javaid, Iacovos I. Ioannou, Yuto Lim, Yasuo Tan, Jahangir Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: As the energy sector transitions towards greener solutions, energy storage systems (ESSs) become increasingly vital in managing power fluctuations arising from renewable energy sources (RESs). The intermittent nature of RESs, combined with seasonal variations in power demand, presents significant challenges for system balancing and operational stability. This paper proposes a novel optimization framework for determining the optimal sizing of ESSs, explicitly considering constraints to maintain safe operational limits and prevent overcharging or over-discharging. The study further investigates the impacts of various connectivity arrangements and energy management strategies among system components, analyzing their trade-offs in terms of energy balancing, flexibility in meeting user demands, and efficient storage allocation. The proposed methodology is validated through simulations using real-world generation and consumption data from a smart home environment (iHouse), capturing seasonal variations across summer, winter, spring, and autumn. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ESS design in mitigating power fluctuations, significantly reducing the required storage capacity while ensuring robust, reliable, and safe system operation. These findings underscore the critical role of optimal ESS sizing and connectivity management in enhancing the efficiency and reliability of renewable energy-powered nanogrids.

title: A Steel Industry Smoke Feature Extraction Method Based on Variable Selective Convolution
authors: Fan Zhou, Jiyuan Li, Zhongyang Han, Tianyu Wang, Jun Zhao, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: To address the challenges in smoke identification within the steel industry, e.g. variable scales, limited feature distinctness, and susceptibility to background interference, this paper proposes an efficient smoke feature extraction network-Efficient Smoke Net (ESNet), which is based on Variable Selective Convolution (VSConv). The VSConv module combines Constrained Variable Convolution (CVC) and Context Self-Attention Based Proposal Module (CSAPM) to enhance feature representation. CVC introduces controlled local deformation to better capture scale variations in smoke. CSAPM dynamically defines the deformation region to reduce information loss caused by excessive deformation and repeated sampling. To improve computational efficiency, ESNet applies partial channel features during the deformation process. Experimental results show the proposed method achieves superior smoke identification performance compared with other identification methods, e.g. YOLOX and Cascade R-CNN in steel industrial environments.

title: A Comparative Analysis of AI-Based Predictive Models for NIFTY50 Index Forecasting
authors: Meghna Mankotia, Ekta Gandotra, Deepak Gupta, Mehak Singhal, Naina Jain, Raghav Singh Thakur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Stock market price prediction remains one of the challenges as it depends on a large number of factors that influence each other and are hard to predict. These factors include economic indicators, global events, investor sentiment, and policy changes. AI and machine learning techniques have a potential in pattern recognition and in generating insights that lead to informed decision-making by traders and investors. This work compares the performance of various AI-based predictive modelling approaches in forecasting the NIFTY50 index. The models are trained using the historical Open, High, Low, Close, and Volume data, collectively known as OHCLV data. The results of the experiments show that the extreme gradient boosting model yields the lowest mean squared error of about 16,692 and a coefficient of determination of 0.999. The hybrid model combining long short-term memory and convolutional neural network, has a significantly lower coefficient of determination of 0.961. However, the hybrid model is more robust in new market scenarios as it can capture both temporal dependencies and localized patterns. This study conducts a comprehensive review of predictive modelling techniques and realizes their practical relevance in facilitating data-driven investment strategies, which is one of the most important aspects of AI's revolutionary role in financial forecasting.

title: Enhancing Startup Support in TBIs through AI and IoT-Enabled Decision Systems
authors: Mohd Tabrej Alam
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper presents a proposal of an AI-IoT-based Decision Support System (DSS) that improves decision-making in Technology Business Incubators (TBIs) and industrial processes. Conventional DSS have a static database and centralized architecture that translates to latency, inefficiencies, and lack of flexibility. The suggested architecture combines real-time monitoring based on IoT with distributed Edge AI and cloudbased analytics, which allow making predictive and prescriptive decisions. The empirical validation in the manufacturing, healthcare, supply chain, and smart city spheres has shown that it has resulted in a substantial improvement in performance: the decrease in the decision latency by up to 69%, the improvement in the accuracy of decisions by $7-16$ percent, and the reduced operational expenses by $\mathbf{1 8}-\mathbf{2 5}$ percent. Additionally, the integration of Explainable AI (XAI) features like LIME and SHAP enhanced the level of trust of the stakeholders by around 30% and usability by around 25%. In the case of TBIs and startups, such capabilities allow pivoting more rapidly, allocating resources more efficiently, and conducting an open review of entrepreneurial projects. These findings create a scalable and sustainable model through which incubators can reinforce entrepreneurial ecosystems by using AI-IoT-based decision support.

title: SE-FedMLP: A Federated Learning Approach with Squeeze-and-Excitation MLP for Crop Recommendation
authors: Harinder Kaur, Sarabjit Kaur, Gyana Ranjana Panigrahi, Chaitanya Singla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Crop recommendation helps farmers to decide which crop should grow depending on the factors like soil nutrients, weather, and environmental conditions. The checking of all these parameters manually is difficult and time-consuming. Traditional machine learning models require collecting all data in one place, which raises privacy problems. This paper introduces a secure and effective solution called SE-FedMLP, which combines Federated Learning (FL) with a Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) enhanced Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) model. FL allows different clients (like farms) to train the model locally without sharing data, hence keeping the data private. SE blocks improve the model to extract the important features from the input data. Experiments were done using a synthetic crop dataset with 7 features and 22 crop labels. We have also created a synthetic dataset to simulate real agricultural scenarios, including data variations across different regions The model was trained across 3 clients using the FedProx algorithm, and the results show high accuracy (97.85%) and strong F1-score (96.16%), proving the effectiveness of the proposed approach. This approach proves that FL can be a effectively used for crop recommendation while keeping data private.

title: The Indian Agriculture System's Implementation of Diverse Agriculture Techniques and Technologies to Promote Sustainable Farming
authors: Sonika Tyagi, Yogesh Kumar Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Around 9000 B.C., India's agricultural system was started [2] and it is one of the top producer of the agricultural products [1]. Since the start of the Agriculture, various technologies and methods have been developed and implemented by the Indian Agriculture System regularly upon demand. Indian agriculture has advanced tremendously from wheat domestication to become the world's leading rice exporter and one of the top agricultural commodity producers. India's agricultural technology has evolved, moving from traditional harvesting equipment such as axes and stone sickles to toward the application of digital farming, smart farming, and various supply chain management approaches. This article discusses the various tactics & innovations that the Indian agriculture system has been adopting to improve itself for fulfilling the ever-increasing demand of agricultural produce and also discuss the most recent agricultural technique i.e. Digital Farming, Smart Farming, also the future technologies of Indian Agriculture.

title: Human Behavior as a Key: An Innovative Fusion of AI and MFA
authors: Sumesh Mohan, V Sheeja Kumari, Akshara, S. Vidhya, S. P. Santhoshkumar, A. Chitra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Strong authentication methods are now essential due to the growing dependence on digital platforms. Static passwords and other conventional techniques are inadequate because they are susceptible to phishing and brute force attacks. Despite adding a physical authentication component to improve security, USB token-based multi-factor authentication (MFA) systems are still vulnerable to compromise when both the password and the token are stolen. This paper suggests a sophisticated authentication framework that combines behavioral anomaly detection powered by artificial intelligence with USB token-based protocols. By examining user-specific behavioral patterns, such as keystroke dynamics, mouse movements, and login session characteristics, the suggested system adds an adaptive, context-aware security layer. Experiments on publicly accessible keystroke datasets show anomaly detection accuracy of over 90%, highlighting the approach's viability and resilience. The foundation for creating intelligent authentication systems that can withstand complex cyberthreats is laid by this work.

title: Advanced Packed U-Cell Inverter Topology for High-Efficiency Power Conversion
authors: Aliya Zahoor, Neeraj Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In this paper, a small Packed U-Cell (PUC) inverter topology is proposed that produces a five-level symmetric output from a single DC source and a floating capacitor. The structure minimizes the number of switches and eliminates the need for feedback sensors or sophisticated control strategies. Simulation and experimental data validate that the proposed inverter offers low switching losses, a constant capacitor voltage, and a rapid dynamic response during changing load conditions. The results show that the PUC topology provides a low-loss and cost-effective solution for renewable energy and other high-performance power conversion applications.

title: Enhancing Anemia Detection with Histogram-Based Gradient Boosting and SMOTE Integration
authors: Dimas Chaerul Ekty Saputra, Ighfir Maulana, Pima Hani Safitri, Tri Ratnaningsih, Irianna Futri, Alfian Ma’arif
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Anemia remains a major global health challenge, with conventional diagnostic methods often being invasive, costly, and inaccessible in low-resource settings. Existing AI-based anemia studies primarily rely on large datasets, image modalities, or single-model approaches, yet lack a unified comparative framework using structured hematological data. To address this gap, this study proposes an AI-driven anemia classification framework evaluating five ensemble models, such as Histogram-based Gradient Boosting (HGB), AdaBoost, XGBoost, CatBoost, and Bagging on clinically validated complete blood count (CBC) datasets. The dataset consists of 128 clinically validated CBC samples from Yogyakarta (2020– 2021), comprising BTT and IDA cases confirmed via ferritin tests and hemoglobin electrophoresis. Class imbalance was handled using SMOTE, improving model stability and predictive performance. HGB achieved the best results on the anemia dataset after SMOTE (accuracy 0.985, F1-score 0.988, AUC 0.999) and demonstrated strong generalizability on diabetes and heart disease datasets. Its performance benefits from histogram-based binning and robust regularization, enabling efficient training with limited samples. The findings show that integrating HGB with SMOTE provides an accurate, interpretable, and computationally efficient solution for AI-assisted diagnosis, particularly suited for resource-constrained healthcare environments.

title: Impact of tilt angle on bifacial power gain of a bifacial solar photovoltaic (PV) module: A comparative study with monofacial (rear side covered) module
authors: Achintya Basak, Suprava Chakraborty, Aruna Kumar Behura
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This study represents a comparative analysis of performance of a monofacial (rear side covered) and bifacial solar photovoltaic (PV) module under different tilt angles such as 0°, $13^{\circ}, 25^{\circ}, 30^{\circ}, 35^{\circ}, 40^{\circ}, 45^{\circ}, 90^{\circ}$ based on power output, and solar radiation. Experimental data were collected for each angle under real operating conditions. Bifacial module shows a consistent increase in performance compared to monofacial module. The highest bifacial gain of 13.20% was observed at 90° tilt angle when rear radiation reached at $174 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and measured irradiation ratio was 0.28. The optimum electrical power output of bifacial module of 392.88 W was recorded at 30° tilt angle and in case of monofacial module it was 341.82 W at 35° tilt angle. The findings show that rear radiation and albedo hugely affect the bifacial gain at higher tilt angle whereas optimal power output is achieved at moderate tilt angle in between 30° to 35°. These results signify the importance of adjusting tilt angles in a specific location to maximize the energy output of the bifacial solar PVmodule.

title: Performance Degradation of Deep and Traditional Machine Learning Models Under Market Volatility: An Inter-Day Stock Trend Comparison
authors: Kanuru Eshwar Venkat Venu Sai, Harthik Manichandra Vanumu, Soumyashree M. Panchal, Y.V. Srinivasa Murthy
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This paper presents an empirical analysis of how deep and traditional machine learning models degrade under market volatility in the Indian stock market. Using inter-day data from 2015–2025 covering key events such as the COVID-19 crash, 2022 rate hikes, and the 2023 AI surge, we evaluate Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Dense Neural Network (DNN), Gradient Boosting Classifier (GBC), and ensemble variants across stable (HDFC, Infosys, Reliance) and volatile (BHEL, Adani Ports, IFCI) equities. A time-aware five-fold cross-validation ensures chronological integrity and prevents look-ahead bias. Results show an average accuracy decline exceeding 20% and F1-score degradation above 0.18 under high volatility. The findings highlight that even advanced ensembles remain sensitive to non-stationarity, emphasizing the need for adaptive, regime-aware frameworks to maintain robustness under structural market shifts.

title: NB-IoT over Non-Terrestrial Networks: Performance Evaluation for MT & MO scenarios
authors: Gabriel Miranda Rodrigues, Vivianne de Aquino Rodrigues, Luan Rocha Lopes, Thiago P. de Souza, Bruna Maira Da S. Fonseca, Vanessa R. de Amorim, Edilson Ribeiro S.
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: With the continuous evolution of mobile networks, connectivity has become as critical as performance, especially in remote regions where geographic limitations, infrastructure scarcity, or high costs hinder access. In this scenario, satellite communication and Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) emerge as promising solutions to overcome global communications bottlenecks. This work presents test scenarios for Short Message Service (SMS) over NTN using NB-IoT (Narrowband Internet of Things). Two cases are evaluated: MT (Mobile Terminated) and MO (Mobile Originated), focusing on sending and receiving SMS under challenging conditions. The proposed test scripts demonstrate the robustness of NTN-based SMS, achieving successful message exchange even with severe RSRP (Reference Signal Received Power) degradation down to -134 dBm-levels practically unattainable in conventional terrestrial systems. These results highlight the stability and feasibility of NTN technology for reliable communication.

title: Performance of ZP-OTFS Communication System Over Transmission Channel
authors: Ahcene Alibey, Ahmed Krobba, Mohamed Debyeche, Lallouani Bouchakour, Roubehie Fissa Nihad, Zoulikha Loubna
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: The Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation technique has emerged as a promising approach for next-generation wireless communication, particularly in the 5G. In this paper, we study the ZP-OTFS (Zero-Padding Orthogonal Time Frequency Space) system, an emerging modulation technique designed to overcome the limitations of conventional systems in highly dispersive propagation environments. The main objective is to evaluate the performance of ZP-OTFS under challenging 5G scenarios, with a particular focus on its robustness to frequency-selective fading channels such as Rayleigh and Rician channels, which fully exploit the diversity of the delay-Doppler domain. Experimental results show that that ZP-OTFS significantly improves the bit error rate (BER) performance and ensures more reliable data transmission. These results confirm that ZP-OTFS is a reliable and effective technology in the devices without 5G.

title: Comparative Analysis of CNN and Transformer Models for Cigarette and E-Cigarette Detection
authors: Tiara Sabrina, Imelda Damayanti, Izzulhaq Mahardika, Muhammad Rafly Arjasubrata, Mahmud Dwi Sulistiyo
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Widespread tobacco and e-cigarette content on social media risks influencing young people by normalizing smoking behaviors and encouraging use. Moderating this content is a significant technical challenge, requiring automated systems that can detect both cigarettes and e-cigarettes across diverse, real-world scenarios. Unfortunately, no prior research has developed a single model to detect both cigarettes and e-cigarettes for social media moderation, a gap largely attributed to the lack of dataset for a unified detection model. To address these limitations, this study compares CNN-based YOLOv12 architecture with the Transformer-based RF-DETR, training on a novel CORTEX dataset to evaluate their ability to simultaneously detect both product types across diverse media content. A key trade-off between the models was revealed by the experimental results. The highest precision and accuracy were achieved by the YOLOv12m model, which obtained a mAP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</inf> of 0.841. In contrast, superior recall of 0.822 along with more consistent performance across varied scenes was demonstrated by the RF-DETR model. Although effective performance on static images was observed, detection flickering in video frames was identified as a key limitation. Therefore, the future work of this research is to integrate object tracking algorithms to enable robust, real-time analysis.

title: Fault Location in Intelligent Substations Based on Multimodal Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks
authors: Wang Dingjun, Wu Jinyuan, Zhang Li, Liao Xiaojun, Wang Lina, Ye Junjun
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To address the challenges of high feature dimensionality, complex topological relationships, and difficulty in identifying multiple faults in secondary circuit fault location within intelligent substations, this paper proposes a fault location method based on a Multimodal Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Network (MST-GNN). The method employs a multimodal feature extractor to separately learn feature representations from device status, communication traffic, and alarm signals. It utilizes an adaptive graph structure learning module to dynamically construct the association relationships between devices. Furthermore, it integrates a spatio-temporal attention mechanism to capture the spatio-temporal characteristics of fault propagation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits superior performance in environments with single faults, multiple faults, and interfering signals, achieving an average location accuracy of 97.78%. This represents improvements of 1.9% and 0.7% over traditional Deep Neural Network (DNN) and Graph Neural Network (GNN) methods, respectively, demonstrating strong robustness and generalization capability.

title: Receiver Algorithms for Satellite-Terrestrial ISAC-RIS Systems
authors: Nathanael Danso-Ntiamoah, Aseni Jayarathne, Ibrahim Al-Nahhal, Octavia A. Dobre
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The concept of integrating satellite and terrestrial wireless networks has emerged in recent years as one of the focal points for addressing the high demand for global connectivity. Meanwhile, integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) and reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) have been studied to enable some of the applications future wireless networks are envisioned to support. To reflect these recent research directions, this paper proposes a satellite-terrestrial integrated network (STIN) model, which comprises an uplink terrestrial ISAC-RIS scenario and a downlink satellite transmission to the ISAC base station. Based on the system model, a mathematical formulation is provided to characterize the communication symbol detection and target estimation problems. Further, the maximum likelihood (ML) detection algorithm is proposed to jointly detect the symbols transmitted by the terrestrial user equipment and satellite. In an interference cancellation scheme, the reflection coefficients of the ISAC target are estimated after symbol detection using the minimum mean-squared error estimation (MMSE) method. The computational complexities of ML and MMSE algorithms are analyzed in terms of the number of real additions and real multiplications involved in their operations. Finally, Monte Carlo simulations are presented to support the findings.

title: Sugarcane Disease Classification Using MobileNetV3
authors: Justine David B. Cadacio, Gabriel A. Ferrer, Ernesto M. Vergara
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Sugarcane production is a leading aspect of agriculture in the Philippines, driving high economic values in the industry. However, sugarcane diseases pose major issues with production rates. Such prevalent diseases in the country are Red Rot, Smut, and Pokkah Boeng, leading to worrying yield losses. Detecting these diseases using traditional laboratory methods consumes a lot of time. With the use of the MobileNetV3 Convolutional Neural Network architecture and a Raspberry Pi 4 Model B, this study seeks to create a system capable of detecting the stated widespread diseases on sugarcanes. The researchers were able to successfully develop a system with an overall accuracy of 91.33% through transfer learning. Improvements to the system can be explored by increasing the dataset size and variance, and implementations of agricultural classification systems on other diseases may be targeted for future research.

title: Multi-Layered Cybersecurity for Smart Power Grids Using AI and Machine Learning for Real-Time Threat Detection and Prevention
authors: Saket Kumar Mishra, Krishna Bihari Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Smart power grids, as the backbone of contemporary electrical power distribution systems, are more vulnerable to cyberattacks with their interconnectedness and reliance on a communication network. Distributed nature and complexity of the grids make them vulnerable to cyberattacks that can lead to disruption of power supply and compromise of critical infrastructure. In this paper, we introduce a multilayered cybersecurity framework that will improve the security of smart grids through Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) mechanisms. The framework includes physical, network, and application-layer security controls, along with real-time anomaly detection and predictive threat prevention by ML-driven algorithms. We simulate a variety of cyberattacks, such as Denial of Service (DoS), Man-in-the-Middle (MITM), and data injection attacks, to test the performance of the proposed framework. Experimental results indicate that the framework detects and mitigates cyber threats with an accuracy of 98.5% with low latency and false positives. The proposed solution demonstrates significant improvement in the resilience and reliability of smart grids against emerging cyber risks.

title: Forest Fire Prediction using One Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Rani Rotul Muhima, Ira Puspitasari, Aditya Prana Iswara
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Forest fires have caused a critical threat, leading to severe environmental degradation, economic losses and serious consequences for human life. Prediction, prevention, and control to handle forest fires become important. Several studies have applied machine learning for forest fire prediction. In this study, one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D CNN) was implemented to forest fire prediction using the UCI Algerian forest fire dataset. This dataset contains 12 features and 244 instances. The proposed model was measured using standard metrics—accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score—and its performance is compared with baseline algorithms including SVM, Random Forest and XG-Boost. Based this experiment, 1D CNN achieves higher performance than existing traditional models, although its performance remains slightly below that of optimized model in previous studies. These findings indicate that 1D CNN offers a competitive deep-learning method for forest fire prediction and provides a useful benchmark for future research.

title: TabNet-Based Deep Transfer Learning Approach to Predict Anxiety Disorder over Obsessive Compulsive Disorder Dataset
authors: Ashish Nema, Rahul Kumar Chaurasiya, Lakshya Chouhan, Mukul Mandrai, Manas Gupta, Pilli Srichand Aniketh
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Very often the obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) co-exists with anxiety disorders (AD).
