This study investigates and compares the use of deep transfer learning (DTL) model (TabNet) over primitive machine learning (ML) models (viz. logistic regression, random forest, XG-boost) to predict anxiety diagnosis on the basis of patient demographics and clinical features such as Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) score. During the course of this study, we applied extensive data processing techniques along with k-fold cross validation process. The experimental results performed on clinical dataset demonstrate that TabNet-based DTL model outperformed in terms of accuracy and reliability than the primitive ML models. The study highlights the potential for early diagnosis support systems.

title: Cloudless Intelligence: Building Autonomous AI Agents on Edge Fabric
authors: Rajesh Kumar Kanji, Ramesh Krishna Mahimalur, Kapil Kumar Sharma, Sai Tejaswi Bellapukonda, Naveen Sri Harsha Rellu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: With the blistering development of edge computing, new horizons have opened in the field of the implementation of AI systems directly on edge devices without the need to rely on centralized cloud environments. This paper introduces the Cloudless Intelligence paradigm which is centred on creating autonomous AI agents that could operate fully within decentralized edge fabrics. We discuss the architecture blueprint of edge-native agents which utilises local computation, federated learning and lightweight inference models to support real-time decision-making, privacy friendliness and context sensing. Our suggestion of a framework combines decentralized communication technology, energy-efficient AI algorithms, and dynamic resource orchestration strategies to achieve self-guiding conduct that is independent of cloud connections. Such experimental performance characteristics on various IoT and edge use case are recorded to justify the viability and practical benefits of our cloudless agents in the aspects of latency, resilience, and energy. This study establishes the design foundation of next-generation AI systems which are self-sustaining, privacy-conscious, and are designed to run in an intermittently connected distributed environment.

title: Integrating Human Factors into Insider Threat Detection – A Systematic Review
authors: Nadeeka Pathirana, Ruby Roberts, Harsha Kalutarage, Christopher McDermott
publish: ACM Computing Surveys
abstract: None

title: Benchmarking Subjective Quality Assessment Methodologies for Light Field Compression_supp1-3661409.pdf
authors: Saeed Mahmoudpour
publish: N/A
abstract: This study benchmarks the effectiveness of multiple subjective quality assessment (QA) methods for evaluating the perceptual quality of light field (LF) content in the context of image coding applications. A passive visualization approach is adopted, where LF data are rendered as pseudo-video sequences and assessed on calibrated 4K 2D displays under controlled laboratory conditions. Three subjective test protocols, including two rating-based and a pairwise comparison (ranking-based) method, are evaluated through six experimental configurations, incorporating different viewing trajectories and interaction modes. This setup, together with our proposals for deploying inter-rater consistency criteria (e.g., error consistency), enables a comprehensive evaluation of the reliability and suitability of different subjective experiments for LF QA. The results confirm the superior discriminability of the pairwise comparison tests over the rating-based methods. Among the rating-based approaches, the method employing a comparative scale scoring outperformed the one based on an impairment scale. Moreover, the performance of several objective QA metrics was evaluated by comparing their scores against the subjective scores obtained from the three test protocols. The outcomes of this study provide methodological guidance for designing subjective LF quality experiments, highlighting the trade-offs between reliability, sensitivity, and experimental cost, and offer insights relevant to future standardization efforts in LF coding.

title: Sea Surface Elevation Retrieval From Synthetic Aperture Radar During Tropical Cyclones
authors: Mengyu Hao, Weizeng Shao, Maurizio Migliaccio, Xingwei Jiang, Lei Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: Storm surges triggered by tropical cyclones (TC) in coastal regions, which refer to an abnormal rise in sea surface elevation, represent a severe hazardous phenomenon. The novelty of this study is to test the applicability of sea surface elevation retrieval from synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image under TCs based on wave dispersion relation at nearshore. There are 36 dual-polarized [vertical-vertical (VV) and vertical-horizontal (VH)] Sentinel-1 (S-1) images acquired in interferometric wide and extra wide mode in the Northwest Pacific Ocean. In addition, these images are collocated with sea surface elevation simulated by a couple atmospheric–oceanic numerical model, namely Weather Research and Forecasting−Finite-Volume Community Ocean Model (FVCOM)−Simulating Waves Nearshore. Three wave parameters, including significant wave height, cross-zero wave period, and mean wavelength were inverted from VV-polarized S-1 imagery using a trained eXtreme Gradient Boosting model. Under TC conditions, the comparison of sea surface elevations from SAR and the FVCOM model yielded a root mean squared error (RMSE) of 0.26 m, whereas validation against tide gauge observations achieved an RMSE of 0.42 m. The observed bias exhibited a nonlinear correlation with water depth rather than dynamic processes, originating from a systematic overestimation by FVCOM in shallow nearshore areas. Collectively, our work advances the retrieval of sea surface elevation from SAR during TCs.

title: Path-Specific Beamforming and Nonuniform Doppler Compensation for Underwater Acoustic Communications
authors: Diego A. Cuji, Milica Stojanovic
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: This article introduces methods for path-specific beamforming and adaptive compensation of nonuniform Doppler drifts in single-carrier broadband underwater acoustic communications. We focus on scenarios where different propagation paths experience varying Doppler drifts, which can significantly degrade conventional receivers. The proposed method employs broadband beamforming to separate the multipath components. Each path is then individually time-aligned and Doppler-synchronized before being processed by a multichannel fractionally spaced decision-feedback equalizer (DFE). By time-aligning the signals before equalization, the DFE filters need only cover the dispersion of each isolated path rather than the entire multipath spread, which leads to an overall reduction in the equalizer size. To account for time compression and dilation, we incorporate a delay-locked loop alongside a phase-locked loop to perform adaptive online resampling or delay tracking, thus eliminating the need for front-end resampling even in high-Doppler scenarios. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach operates successfully under conditions that cause conventional receivers to fail. In cases where the conventional receiver performs well, our proposed algorithm achieves comparable performance with significantly fewer training symbols, yielding excellent performance in terms of data detection mean squared error and bit error rate.

title: Random Access for Semantic Transmission under Finite Buffer and Retransmission in Vehicular Networks
authors: Yuyi Sun, Tingting Xiao, Fangyuan Xing, Shibo He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: The rapid advancement of autonomous driving brings large amount of data to transmit in vehicular networks, which increases the burden of channels. While semantic communication (SemCom) can alleviate bandwidth pressure by transmitting semantics rather than raw data, random access (RA) for SemCom may still suffer from collisions and delays due to resource competition. This indicates that, in current vehicular networks, a unified modeling and analysis framework integrating SemCom and access schemes is supposed to be designed and explored. In this correspondence, we propose a RA scheme named SVRA under the buffer and retransmission constraints, where the state characterizations are determined using Markov chain. Furthermore, we introduce the age of incorrect information (AoII) by considering the structure similarity index measure (SSIM). We compare SVRA with existing schemes, the results of which validate that SVRA has a better performance.

title: ATRMME: A Tensor Ring-based Feature Extraction Method for Hyperspectral Remote Sensing Image Classification under Noisy Labels
authors: Tong Gao, Hongwei Dong, Lingyu Si, Zhuxin Zhao, Yongqiang Sun, Bin Bai, Yanbo Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The extraction of concise and discriminative features from hyperspectral remote sensing images (HSIs) holds great significance for land cover classification tasks. Nevertheless, the intricate spatial-spectral tensor structure and inaccurate class labels undermine the performance of existing vector-based or Tucker tensor-based feature dimensionality reduction (DR) approaches. To tackle this problem, we propose an Adaptive Tensor-Ring Manifold Maintaining Embedding (ATRMME) approach for HSI feature DR in the presence of noisy labels. Firstly, a tensor-ring subspace representation theory is established to characterize the low-dimensional hyperspectral tensor subspace. To mine concise features from complex spatial-spectral data, differing from existing Tucker-based DR methods that involve exorbitant parameter overheads, a nuclear norm-constrained Tensor-Ring (TR) feature representation term is designed. This term enables the compression of key features within the low-dimensional subspace with a linear parameter cost. For the adaptive perception and capture of the manifold structure under noisy labels, an adaptive adjacency matrix is constructed, and the adjacency relationships are reorganized based on the TR feature distribution. To guarantee the effective execution of model training, an alternating optimization algorithm is developed for parameter estimation. Experimental results on multiple hyperspectral datasets verify that the ATRMME approach exhibits strong robustness against noisy labels, outperforms conventional vector-based and Tucker tensor-based methods, and has lower parameter requirements.

title: Adaptive Finite Time Command Filtered Backstepping Control for Optimal Oxygen Excess Ratio of Hydrogen Fuel Cells With Unknown Air Compressor Faults
authors: Anguo Zhang, Chenglong Hu, Qing Chen, Chaoxu Mu, Yongduan Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Proton exchange membrane fuel cells are a core pillar of the clean energy transition, drawing widespread attention for their high efficiency and eco-friendly energy conversion. Maintaining an optimal oxygen excess ratio (OER) is critical to balancing the efficiency, durability, and dynamic performance of PEMFC systems, but this task faces inherent nonlinearities, external disturbances, and unpredictable concurrent air compressor faults—challenges that traditional control strategies struggle to address simultaneously. Its core innovations are reflected in three aspects. First, it establishes a unified adaptive control architecture to address the performance limitations of existing command-filtered backstepping frameworks under air compressor fault conditions. Rigorous Lyapunov stability analysis verifies the closed-loop stability under parameter perturbations. Second, it develops a new fault-tolerant control paradigm to ensure the finite-time convergence of the OER under multiple concurrent unknown faults of the air compressor, without relying on external fault diagnosis modules. Third, its practical feasibility is verified through controller-hardware-in-the-loop (C-HIL) experiments. Compared with mainstream methods, the adaptive finite-time command-filtered backstepping (AFTCFB) controller exhibits better tracking accuracy, smaller overshoot, and faster fault recovery speed.

title: Advances in Laser-Generated Ultrasound for Biomedical Applications
authors: Ziqi Li, Peng Chen, Xinyun Li, Xiaoning Jiang, Chang Peng
publish: IEEE Nanotechnology Magazine
abstract: Laser-generated ultrasound (LGU) has emerged as a transformative technology in biomedicine, offering unique advantages over conventional ultrasound, including non-contact operation, high spatial resolution, and broadband frequency spectra. This review synthesizes two decades of advancements in LGU, highlighting its pivotal role in biomedical imaging, tissue characterization, and therapeutic applications. In imaging, LGU integrates seamlessly with modalities like photoacoustics to enhance diagnostic precision, as demonstrated by studies combining laser-induced ultrasound with classical techniques to improve vascular contrast and subsurface tissue visualization. Innovations such as fiber-optic transducers and carbon nanotube composites have enabled further miniaturization and optimization of LGU systems for clinical uses, resulting in high-resolution intravascular and endoscopic imaging. Beyond diagnostics, LGU excels in tissue characterization, providing non-invasive insights into biomechanical properties through techniques like laser-guided focused ultrasound and quantitative ultrasound visualization. These methods have proven invaluable for assessing bone health and detecting microstructural anomalies without ionizing radiation. Therapeutically, LGU enables precision interventions, such as microbubbles and nanodroplets-mediated thrombolysis, targeted drug delivery, and noninvasive surgery, with minimal collateral damages. Recent developments, including optically generated focused ultrasound for neuromodulation, underscore its potential in neurosurgery and regenerative medicine. Despite its promise, challenges like signal attenuation and clinical scalability persist. However, solutions such as AI-driven image reconstruction and robotic-assisted systems are poised to overcome some existing barriers. By bridging technological innovation with clinical needs, LGU is redefining precision medicine, offering safer, more effective alternatives to traditional ultrasound-based diagnostics and therapeutics.

title: Evaluation of Pedestrian Future Conflict at Non-Signalized Intersections Based on Probabilistic Trajectory Prediction
authors: Tengfeng Lin, Zhixiong Jin, Hwasoo Yeo, Inhi Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Recent advances in sensing and artificial intelligence technologies have laid the foundation for proactive pedestrian safety at non-signalized intersections. These technologies enable the prediction of future pedestrian-vehicle conflicts, allowing for timely intervention. Existing studies, however, overlook the uncertainty inherent in future prediction, which mainly stems from behavioral variability and observational inaccuracies. Probabilistic trajectory prediction can capture these uncertainties, yet it has rarely been applied to future conflict evaluation. To improve future conflict evaluation by accounting for uncertainty, this study introduces a novel method that integrates probabilistic trajectory prediction with a newly designed surrogate safety measure, Stochastic Predicted Time to Collision (SPTTC). SPTTC enables accurate conflict prediction, reliable scenario classification and evaluation of conflict severity progression, as demonstrated in quantitative results and case studies. Across different types of non-signalized intersections, SPTTC was separately integrated with four probabilistic trajectory prediction models, achieving F1 scores of 0.77–0.84 and consistently outperforming baseline methods. The proposed method also exhibits strong robustness under high-uncertainty conditions, such as unpredictable pedestrian behavior (e.g., children), low visibility (e.g., nighttime), and missing data. This proposed method can be integrated into proactive pedestrian protection systems, enhancing safety by providing timely alerts to pedestrians or activating vehicle brakes at critical moments.

title: HeightFormer: Learning Height Prediction in Voxel Features for Roadside Vision Centric 3D Object Detection via Transformer
authors: Zhang Zhang, Chao Sun, Chao Yue, Da Wen, Yujie Chen, Tianze Wang, Jianghao Leng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Roadside vision centric 3D object detection has received increasing attention in recent years. It expands the perception range of autonomous vehicles, enhances the road safety. Previous methods focused on predicting per-pixel height rather than depth, making significant gains in roadside visual perception. While it is limited by the perspective property of near-large and far-small on image features, making it difficult for network to understand real dimension of objects in the 3D world. Bird’s Eye View (BEV) features and voxel features present the real distribution of objects in 3D world compared to the image features. However, BEV features tend to lose details due to the lack of explicit height information, and voxel features are computationally expensive. Inspired by this insight, an efficient framework learning height prediction in voxel features via transformer is proposed, dubbed HeightFormer. It groups the voxel features into local height sequences, and utilize attention mechanism to obtain height distribution prediction. Subsequently, the local height sequences are reassembled to generate accurate voxel features. The proposed method is applied to two large-scale roadside benchmarks, DAIR-V2X-I and Rope3D. Extensive experiments are performed and the HeightFormer outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in roadside vision centric 3D object detection task. Code will be at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/zhangzhang2024/HeightFormer</uri>

title: Parkinson's Disease Identification with Antenna and Shallow Hybrid Network
authors: Subham Ghosh, Banani Basu, Arnab Nandi, Marami Das
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD), a prevalent neurodegenerative disorder that is frequently misdiagnosed with similar symptoms. This study investigates the feasibility of a wrist-worn wearable antenna for identifying actual PD from false PD (essential and physiological tremors). Antenna sensitivity was measured with the biological tis sues. Reflection properties were measured while patients performed four motor activities. To overcome class imbalance, a GAN was used for data augmentation. Signals were normalized and converted into 2-D representations using the Gaussian-windowed Gabor wavelet transform (Gw-GWT) and the short-time Fourier synchrosqueezed transform (ST-FSST). A deep-learning model (DLM) shallow hybrid CNN-transformer network (SHCT-Net) is utilized for obtaining local and global features, with benchmark DLMs serving as comparisons. The original and enhanced datasets were trained and evaluated using 5-fold subject-wise cross-validation (5-FSWCV). The suggested model, with only 0.7 million parameters, obtained 93.22% precision, 91.12% accuracy and 91.12% F1-score.

title: Measurement and Analysis of Induced Voltage in a Rotating Coordinate System of a 1 kW-class High Temperature Superconducting Squirrel-Cage Rotor Winding
authors: C. N. D'Azevedo, T. Nakamura
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: This work presents a simple and direct measurement method for rotor bar voltages in the rotating coordinate system of a high temperature superconducting induction/synchronous motor (HTS-ISM). The arrangement consists of soldering copper wires to the opposing ends of the rotor bars and routing them through a spinning reel to avoid entanglement, thereby providing a continuous electrical connection between the rotating quantities of the rotor and the stationary measurement instruments. Experiments with both ramped and stepped stator voltage inputs under no-load conditions revealed markedly different dynamic behaviors, including rapid acceleration, hunting torque, and current distortion. A recurring component at ≈1.05 Hz was consistently identified on the rotor bar voltages across independent tests, including at different input frequencies, suggesting the presence of an intrinsic oscillation under low excitation. The proposed measurement approach provides new experimental access to the flux-flow and synchronous regimes of HTS machines and establishes a foundation for future studies under load and with varied rotor designs.

title: Small Language Models for Emergency Departments Decision Support: A Benchmark Study
authors: Zirui Wang, Jiajun Wu, Braden Teitge, Jessalyn Holodinsky, Steve Drew
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have become increasingly popular in medical domains to assist physicians with a variety of clinical and operational tasks. Given the fast-paced and high-stakes environment of emergency departments (EDs), small language models (SLMs), characterized by a reduction in parameter count compared to LLMs, offer significant potential due to their inherent reasoning capability and efficient performance. This enables SLMs to support physicians by providing timely and accurate information synthesis, thereby improving clinical decision-making and workflow efficiency. In this paper, we present a comprehensive benchmark designed to identify SLMs suited for ED decision support, taking into account both specialized medical expertise and broad general problem-solving capabilities. In our evaluations, we focus on SLMs that have been trained on a mixture of general-domain and medical corpora. A key motivation for emphasizing SLMs is the practical hardware limitations, operational cost constraints, and privacy concerns in the typical real-world deployments. Our benchmark datasets include MedMCQA, MedQA-4Options, and PubMedQA, with the medical abstracts dataset emulating tasks aligned with real ED physicians’ daily tasks. Experimental results reveal that general-domain SLMs surprisingly outperform their medically fine-tuned counterparts across these diverse benchmarks for ED. This indicates that for ED, specialized medical fine-tuning of the model may not be required.

title: Evaluation of Low-Cost Pressure Sensors for IoT and ML-based Water Flow Estimation
authors: M. Gandhi, T. Bhatt, S. Chaudhari, A. Vattem
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Water scarcity and inefficient resource management present critical challenges, with conventional flow measurement techniques often relying on expensive and invasive methods. This work evaluates the performance of three low-cost pressure sensors (HK3022, MBS3000, and Series 21Y) for internet of things (IoT) and machine learning (ML) based water flow estimation. Tests were conducted in a closed-loop experimental setup across pressure ranges from 1.0 to 2.0 bar, generating over 8,640 pressure readings and 2,160 flow measurements. Sensor performance was assessed through pressure measurement accuracy metrics (RMSE and CV), and flow estimation reliability was assessed using five ML algorithms. Results demonstrate that all sensors achieve comparable flow estimation accuracy. While calibration improves absolute pressure measurement accuracy, it provides minimal advantage for flow estimation tasks. This low-cost, non-invasive approach offers a promising water monitoring solution that is accessible and economically viable.

title: A Survey on Speech Emotion Recognition Datasets: Research Challenges, Issues and Opportunities
authors: Narottam Chaubey, Lovejit Singh, Himanshu Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Speech Emotion Recognition (SER)has attracted a lot of interest due to its uses in emotional computing, education, healthcare, and human-computer interaction. However, the constraints of accessible audio datasets severely limit the advancement of SER. Model generalization is constrained by the majority of extant corpora, short sample sizes, lack of speaker diversity, class imbalance, and language or cultural bias. The resilience of trained models in practical situations is further affected by environmental variables such as channel fluctuation, recording quality, and background noise. These issues show how urgently large scale, balanced, multilingual datasets, as well as consistent labeling systems and evaluation processes, are needed. This paper presents a survey of speech emotion recognition datasets along with research challenges and issues. Speech data sets are taxonomized according to how emotional expressions are obtained, mainly into four categories: simulated data set, prompted data set, unprompted data set, and natural dataset. Moreover, it describes various research challenges and issues that need attention to develop precise, reliable, and broadly applicable SER systems. Data set-related problems can be facilitated via data augmentation, cross corpus learning, multi-modal integration, and transfer learning.

title: Enhancement of PV Panel Efficiency Using Reflection of Light Technique
authors: M. Leela Venkata Pavan Chandu, M.Raja Nayak, Badham DivyaVani, Kompalli Susmitha, Tammisetty Sivaram, T. Nagaraju
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This study explores the application of light reflection technique to exploit the space usage and lift photovoltaic (PV) panel efficiency. Light reflective materials such as mirrors are arranged to capture additional light intensities and were directed onto the PV panel alongside direct sunlight, offers enhanced power generation from panel. To maximize efficiency, various mirror angles were tested, and an optimal panel angle was identified that significantly boosted performance. High-reflectivity materials such as mirrors and aluminum foil were used to enhance light redirection. Experimental validation on compact PV panels demonstrated an impressive solar panel efficacy enhancement of $\mathbf{1 3 1. 2 \%}$ under space-constrained conditions, showcasing the immense potential of proposed innovative reflection of light strategy. The enhanced efficiency was calculated based on solar panel ratings. This key investigation may be adapted for larger commercial PV installations, leading to substantial efficiency gains with an initial investment only.

title: Next-Gen AI Decision Support in Software Engineering: Leveraging Complexity with Quantum Computing, DevOps Automation, and Responsible Machine Learning
authors: Paramjot Kaur Sarao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: The future will feature the use of next-generation AI decision support systems powered by quantum computing, DevOps automation, and machine learning with responsibility to accommodate mounting complexity in software engineering. Quantum computing provides a solution that allows breaking the current limits of computation and solving complex algorithms and huge quantities of data rather fast. DevOps automation is a complete incorporation of AI to eliminate bottlenecks and add efficiency in the process of staging seamless cooperation. Essentially, responsible machine learning serves as their moral guide that ensures that AI decisions are transparent, accountable, and within social conformities. Upon the convergence of these three concepts, a radical change is made in software development and management. They deal with challenges of modern software as they enhance the speed and reliability through decision making streamlining. This study presents a framework for Next-Generation AI Decision Support in Software Engineering, resulting in an AI driven “software engineer” capable of managing the difficulties of modern development. This intelligent system uses quantum computing to solve complicated software design difficulties with its improved processing capabilities. Integrating DevOps automation to speed up continuous integration, delivery, and deployment ensures agile, real-time responsiveness to changing needs. Through case studies and performance evaluations, this AI-driven software engineer has proven to optimize resources, reduce development timelines, and improve software quality, laying the groundwork for future autonomous engineering systems that support complex decision making and operational efficacy.

title: Ensemble Strategy for Road Network Extraction in Satellite Imageries
authors: Harshita Sharma, Muskan Chaneja, Mukesh Kumar Verma
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Intelligent systems and AI-driven analytics are reshaping smart cities by enabling accurate, large-scale mapping of transportation infrastructure, where reliable road network extraction from satellite imagery is critical for navigation, traffic optimization, and emergency response. A ma-jor limitation of existing approaches is the vulnerability of single-model deep learning methods to noise, occlusions, and diverse urban-rural contexts. To overcome this, seven complementary DeepLabV3+ networks-efficientnet-b3, resnet50, resnext50_32x4d, densenet169, mobilenet_v3 _large,regnetx_032, and efficientnet-b0-were independently trained on bootstrap samples of the DeepGlobe road dataset with varied augmentations and optimization schedules to maximize representational diversity. Their predictions were fused using probability averaging and an alternative spatial interleaving strategy enhanced by seam smoothing and conditional random field refinement to improve boundary continuity. The ensemble delivered consistent gains in intersection-over-union, Fl-score, and boundary accuracy compared to the strongest individual model, reducing false positives and capturing fine-grained road structures. These findings demonstrate that leveraging encoder diversity and structured fusion significantly strengthens road network extraction, offering a scalable and robust foundation for autonomous navigation, urban planning, and disaster management in smart city applications.

title: Impact of Multiple Types of Regulation Resources on Primary and Secondary Frequency Regulation Capability in Modern Power Systems
authors: Cijian Xie, Xintong Ma, Junjie Sun, Mingzhu Li, Shubo Hu, Haoqi Liang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This paper establishes frequency response models for thermal power, hydropower, wind power, and energy storage systems to investigate their impact on secondary frequency regulation capability in power grids. The study analyzes the response characteristics of these resources when participating in frequency regulation individually and collectively. Findings indicate that thermal power units offer stable and continuous support, hydropower units exhibit rapid and substantial response, wind power units demonstrate swift response under appropriate control, and energy storage systems exhibit the fastest response time and highest flexibility. Collaborative frequency modulation involving multiple types of regulation resources can notably reduce frequency fluctuation amplitude, expedite frequency recovery, and enhance the frequency stability of the power system.

title: Integrated Segmentation and Classification Framework for Neonatal HIE Using SegResNet and XGBoost
authors: Athira Chandran, Lekshmi Reghunath
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Neonatal Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE) is a major brain injury in newborns resulting from insufficient supply of oxygen during the perinatal period, often leading to long-term neurological dysfunctions and delayed development . Timely and accurate diagnosis is essential for enhancing clinical outcomes. In this work, we propose a multimodal approach for automatically segmenting HIE lesions and severity classification using MRI scans. A SegResNet architecture was employed to segment lesions from Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC) and Z-scored ADC (Z-ADC) maps. In the following stage, features derived from predicted lesion masks and clinical meta data were combined using an early fusion approach. The fused feature set was used for classifying the HIE lesions according to severity as mild, moderate and severe. Experiments were conducted on the Boston Neonatal Brain Injury Dataset (BONBID-HIE). The segmentation model achieved a Dice score of 0.749, while the severity classification obtained an accuracy of 88.64%. These findings show the effectiveness of the proposed structure in both clinically relevant severity classification and accurate lesion spot identification, indicating its ability to support early clinical decision-making in neonatal clinical care..

title: Control Allocation for Electric Vehicles with Brake-by-Wire to Optimise Safety and Energy Efficiency Across Full Envelope of Operation*
authors: Yi-Yuan Li, Efstathios Siampis
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: To enhance vehicle stability and maximise energy efficiency, this paper presents a novel control allocation strategy for electric vehicles (EVs) equipped with a brake-by-wire system, which can independently allocate tractive and brake torques on 4 in-wheel motors and friction brakes. The proposed approach integrates a real-time optimisation algorithm that dynamically allocates torques to individual motors/brakes by considering the tyre, motor and friction brake dynamic limits. It also employs an asymmetrical cost function, penalising positive and negative motor torques differently to maximise regenerative braking energy recovery. Simulation results using a high-fidelity vehicle model demonstrate significant improvements in vehicle handling and energy efficiency performances compared to the traditional control allocation method. This paper therefore showcases how to construct a global optimal wheel torque strategy considering both performance-oriented and energy-efficient EV applications.

title: Efficient Reconstruction of High-Resolution Human Avatars from Monocular Videos via a Hybrid Representation
authors: Jiaang Wu, Yuhui Wen, Weibin Liu, Weiwei Xing, Liping Jing
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: In this paper, we address the challenge of reconstructing high-resolution human avatars from monocular videos with both efficiency and high quality. While existing methods such as the fast NeRF variant based on hash grid representation can achieve efficient reconstruction of low-resolution human avatars, they need to increase the hash grid resolution when reconstructing high-resolution human avatars, which leads to a dramatic increase in network parameters. To solve the problem, a hybrid representation that combines multi-resolution hash grid features and tri-plane features is proposed. Based on this representation, we propose a novel reconstruction method that can provide higher rendering quality while maintaining a compact model size compared to the baseline methods. In addition, we introduce a training strategy from coarse to fine, using patch-level supervision to encourage the network to acquire clear appearance details. The proposed method demonstrates its superior performance in terms of appearance quality based on extensive experiments.

title: Explore the Dynamics of Mobile Social Networking
authors: Himanshi Dhamija, Manju Bagga, Surbhi Dhiman, Rubika Walia, Ritu Mishra, Ravi Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The sharp increase in the productivity of mobile devices and wireless technologies has brought a drastic change in the landscape of social interaction, giving rise to mobile social networking as a prevailing form of online communication. this paper is regarding the dynamics of mobile social networking by looking into technological enablers, user behavior, and the socio-cultural impact of these platforms. use of qualitative methods along with quantitative methods, we deeply analyze patterns of user engagement, the influence of real-time or live connectivity, and the role of location-based services in framing social interactions. there are so many challenges addressed by us like security concerns, information overload, and internet addiction. this study aims to advise the design of more user-centric, secure, and inclusive msn platforms by providing insights into the evolving nature of social connections in mobile contexts. the results focus on a deeper understanding that how mobile technologies are continuing to redefine the boundaries of community, identity, and social participation.

title: Broadband High Power High Efficiency Pulsed VHF SSPA For Ground Penetrating RADAR Applications
authors: Nishant Jaiswal, Gautam Kumar, Samriti Kumar Garg
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This paper describes the methodology involved in the design, development and measured performance of broadband high efficiency 100 W pulsed solid state power amplifier (SSPA). The SSPA design consists of three amplifier stages to provide 100W output power, namely driver amplifier (DA) stage realized using TO-8 packaged device, medium power amplifier (MPA) stage using diffused metal-oxide-semiconductor (DMOS) and high power amplifier (HPA) stage using DMOS in push-pull configuration. The matching circuits of the amplifier stages used lumped components where the input matching network (IMN) or output-matching network (OMN) of HPA uses semi-rigid (SR) cables balanced to unbalanced (BalUn) impedance transformer. The achieved measured performance of the SSPA in class AB mode provides 50 dBm peak output power, overall minimum gain of 48 dB with flatness below 0.5 dB and drain efficiency better than 47% at 45 MHz having bandwidth of 22.22%. This SSPA is highly suitable for satellite based ground penetrating radio detection and ranging (GPR) applications.

title: An Active Power Enhancement Method for Renewable Energy Source under Voltage Faults
authors: Zhenjun Gao, Ping Wei, Xuetao Dong, Chao Huo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Conventional low voltage ride-through strategies, which prioritize reactive current injection for voltage support, often lead to a significant curtailment of active power, thereby jeopardizing system frequency stability. To address this issue, this paper proposes an active power enhancement method for renewable energy source during voltage faults. The method determines the optimal current angle for active power output while considering practical active power limits. It is capable of adjusting the output current angle, adaptively switching between the optimal angle for active power output and the optimal angle for voltage support. This enables the full utilization of both active power and current capacities to achieve effective active power support and voltage support simultaneously. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulations.

title: Fault Detection Using Kernel Nonnegative Matrix Factorization
authors: Amir Khurshid, Azeez Mohammed Ali, Ajaya Kumar Pani
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Fault detection in modern industrial processes has grown increasingly complex due to nonlinear dynamics and high-dimensional data. Traditional linear approaches such as PCA and standard NMF often fail to adequately capture the nonlinearities present in real-world systems. This paper introduces a nonlinear process monitoring framework based on Kernel Nonnegative Matrix Factorization (KNMF), which integrates kernel mapping techniques with the nonnegativity constraints of NMF to preserve interpretability and enhance detection sensitivity. By projecting process data into a high-dimensional feature space and applying NMF, the method successfully captures nonlinear patterns while maintaining the physical meaning of nonnegative components. Validation on benchmark datasets demonstrates that KNMF performs well, as it gives high fault detection rates and low false alarm rates.

title: Teaching Transformed: Integrating YOLOv11, GroundingDINO, and SSDMobileNetV3 for Enhanced Monitoring in Video-Based Classrooms
authors: Ivan Afrizal, Azani Cempaka Sari
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: In online and hybrid learning environments, video recordings often face challenges such as static camera angles, obscured whiteboards, and the need for manual adjustments. This paper investigates three object detection models—YOLOv11, GroundingDINO, and SSD MobileNet-v3—for automated lecture monitoring using a classroom dataset annotated based on person presence. Both balanced and imbalanced datasets were evaluated using standard classification metrics. GroundingDINO achieved perfect precision but had the lowest accuracy, making it less practical for real-time applications due to its reliance on AWS Lambda and S3, which require significant computational resources. YOLOv11 offered a good balance of speed and precision, making it suitable for real-time use. SSD MobileNet-v3 provided high efficiency with minimal resource requirements, making it ideal for edge devices. Considering their performance and efficiency trade-offs, YOLOv11 and SSD MobileNet-v3 are both suitable for responsive and practical lecture monitoring systems, depending on the specific hardware and performance requirements.

title: Emerging AI Technology in Cloud Doctor Machine: A Paradigm Shift in Digital Healthcare
authors: Puneet, Subhash Manohar Choudhary, Lalit Kr Tyagi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The combination of cloud computing and AI (artificial intelligent) technology combines to a newgeneration digital healthcare system, called Cloud Doctor Machine. This novel model provides automated diagnosis, online monitoring of patients and personalized treatment plans with the support of AI based cloud technology. By embedding wearable devices, biomedical sensors and machine learning models, the Cloud Doctor Machine optimizes healthcheck parameters for specific people, predicts diseases before happening and bridges the gap between patients and doctors. This paper reviews system architecture design, AI underpinning mechanisms, pros, and cons of the proposed work and its implementation challenges and emphasizes the importance of this system in relation to improving telemedicine, chronic disease management as well as achieving universal access to global health care services.

title: Development and Application of an Auxiliary Device for 10kV Live-Line Installation of C-Type Clamps
authors: ZHOU ZhaoNan, WANG ZiGe, WANG MengYu, WANG ZhongXiang, LIU WeiJie, QIN HongMing
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems existing in the installation of C-type clamps in 10kV live-line connection operations, such as complex operation, high safety risks, and reliance on multi-person coordination, this paper develops an auxiliary device for 10kV live-line installation of C-type clamps. The device consists of an insulated integrated clamp fixture, a locking mechanism, an insulated buckle, a spring mechanism, an insulated pin, and an adjustment mechanism. It achieves safety protection through insulation design, ensures stable fixation of the clamp by means of spring elasticity and mechanical locking, and is compatible with various types of C-type clamps and conductors. Practice shows that the device enables single-operator installation, effectively reduces the risks of electric shock and arc burns, improves operation efficiency, and has high application and promotion value.

title: Autonomous Underwater Robots for Live Environmental Monitoring
authors: Haydeer MohamadAbbas, Shilpi Nishant Tanwani, S. Kanmani Jebaseeli, D. Ajay Kumar, R. Krishnan, Umida Rasulova, Rashidkhon Uulu Atabek
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Real-time monitoring of underwater ecosystems is crucial for maintaining healthy marine environments increasingly affected by human activity and climate change. Existing AUVs, however, exhibit limited adaptability to fluctuating underwater conditions, short operational lifespans due to restricted energy resources, and low spatial-temporal coverage. To address these limitations, this paper introduces EcoSwarm, a distributed autonomous underwater robot swarm that uniquely integrates adaptive sensing and bio-inspired manipulation for real-time environmental monitoring and interaction. Each miniature AUV is equipped with multi-modal sensors for chemical, biological, and physical data collection, coupled with an AI-driven adaptive sensing framework that dynamically adjusts sensing strategies in response to environmental changes. A decentralized communication system, combining acoustic and optical channels, enables robust coordination and data fusion across the swarm. Additionally, bio-inspired compliant robotic arms empower EcoSwarm to perform cooperative environmental interventions such as microplastic collection and habitat restoration. The system's hybrid energy-harvesting and docking architecture extends operational endurance, while prototype testing demonstrates superior adaptability, fault tolerance, and real-time responsiveness compared to conventional AUVs. EcoSwarm thus establishes a transformative paradigm in underwater robotics, combining swarm intelligence, adaptive sensing, and manipulative interaction to achieve sustainable marine ecosystem management.

title: Boosting Automated Urine Sediment Classification via Data Scaling
authors: Satyendra Yadav, Isha Saini, Vidushi Sharma, Rajiv Ratn Shah
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Urine sediment analysis plays a critical role in diagnosing the kidney related diseases, urinary tract infections and many related disorders. Historically, the urine sediment microscopic image samples were manually examined under a microscope by the clinical experts and trained professionals. This traditional manual analysis is slow, time consuming, labor intensive and prone to variability and errors. In recent times, computer vision models have been extensively used in automated urine sediment analysis but they often struggle in accurately locating and identifying smaller and irregular shaped urine sediments. In order to overcome these challenges we have worked with two distinct approaches to improve the performance of computer vision models in urine sediment analysis. In this work, we have used two state-of-the-art computer vision models YOLOv12 and RT-DETR in our experimental results on the publicly available datasets. The experimental results confirms that the proposed merging method improves the overall accuracy of YOLOv12 and RT-DETR by 4.14% and 9.45% respectively. However, the augmentation method declines the performance of these models and a decrease in the accuracy is observed with this approach. This study further concludes that YOLOv12 outperforms RT-DETR when trained on a smaller dataset but this trend gets reversed when trained with more comprehensive merged dataset.

title: An Innovative Machine Learning Framework for Classification of Natural Events and Cyber Attacks in PMU-Based Power Transmission System
authors: Nikhil B Sardar, Priyanshi Agarwal, Anjali Dhakad, Shubham Kumar, Gaurav Vinod Patil, Ram Singh, Manoj Tripathy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: As modern power systems grow more complex, protecting these critical infrastructures from natural faults and advanced cyber attacks has become increasingly essential. This research proposes an Innovative Machine Learning (ML) Model-Based Feature Improvisation to enhance anomaly detection through machine learning techniques. The framework is specifically designed to accurately identify and classify three key system conditions: normal operations (no event), disruptions resulting from physical faults (natural conditions), and cyber-attacks engineered to mislead operators. The proposed approach has been applied to a distance protection set-up within a transmission network that incorporates four interconnected intelligent electronic devices (IEDs). By coupling an Innovative Machine Learning model- based feature selector with multiple machine learning algorithms, the inclusion of the framework in Principal Component Analysis (PCA) improves the accuracy and performance of the abnormal detection system. Support vector machine(SVM), Gradient boosters, k-nearest neighbors (KNN), random forest (RM), and decision tree (DT) classifiers are evaluated to determine the most suitable models to detect and distinguish between normal operations, natural disturbances, and cyber attacks within transmission networks. Among these models, random forest along with PCA demonstrated with best accuracy and F1-Score indicating its strong potential as an effective solution for anomaly detection in such systems.

title: LSF Integrated Hippopotamus Optimizer Algorithm for Single DG Optimization in Radial Distribution Power Network
authors: R Vinay, Sundar R, M Selvakumari, A Sakthidasan, P Saravanakumar, P Rajakumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Distributed generation (DG) allocation provides significant benefits to radial distribution power networks (RDPN) when its size and location are optimally determined. This paper proposes a novel and efficient integrated approach for optimizing the site and rating of a single DG unit to minimize the total real power losses (TRPL) of the RDPN. The proposed method combines the loss sensitivity factor (LSF) with an advanced metaheuristic technique, the Hippopotamus Optimizer Algorithm (HOA). The LSF is first computed to identify a set of potential locations for DG placement, while HOA leverages the unique defense mechanisms and evasion strategies of hippopotamuses to optimize the DG capacity. The effectiveness of the proposed integrated approach is validated on the balanced IEEE 33-bus benchmark RDPN under both nominal and peak load conditions. To further assess robustness, type I and type III DG unit placements are considered.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Secure Federated Learning for Electronic Medical Records: A Scalable and Privacy-Preserving Framework
authors: Indra Yatini B., Kuindra Iriyanta, Hendra, B.T. Sutrisno. SP., Heri Muhrial, Edy Prayitno
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The rapid digital transformation in healthcare has accelerated the adoption of Electronic Medical Records (EMRs), yet concerns about privacy, interoperability, and security remain major challenges. Centralized learning models expose data to leakage and adversarial attacks, reducing clinical reliability. To address these issues, this study proposes a Secure Federated Learning (FL) framework integrated with Blockchain to enable scalable, privacy-preserving, and trustworthy EMR management. A quantitative experimental design was conducted using the publicly available MIMIC-III dataset in a simulated multi-institutional environment. Federated learning enabled local model training across distributed nodes, while blockchain served as a permissioned ledger for update verification, node authentication, and access control. Homomorphic encryption and differential privacy were incorporated to enhance confidentiality. System performance was evaluated in terms of predictive accuracy, calibration, communication efficiency, and security resilience. The proposed framework achieved an average prediction accuracy of 94.7%, with balanced precision (93%) and recall (92%), and an AUROC of 0.97. Calibration also improved, yielding lower Brier and ECE values compared with baselines. Communication latency remained practical at 210 ms per iteration, while bandwidth consumption decreased by 18% relative to vanilla FL. Security analysis showed that the system detected anomalous updates under poisoning attacks with an 87% success rate, while differential privacy reduced membership-inference risk toward chance levels. The blockchain layer further ensured transparency and auditability of all transactions without degrading predictive utility. In conclusion, integrating federated learning with blockchain provides a scalable, auditable, and privacy-preserving solution for EMR management. This framework advances secure digital healthcare infrastructures and establishes a foundation for real-world deployment in hospital ecosystems.

title: A Novel Gradient Boosting Model for Effort Estimation in Scrum Projects
authors: Mohit Arora, Shivali Chopra, Premananda Sahu, Bhupinder Singh, Manish Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Software Effort Estimation has a lot of significance in Scrum project management because it enables the teams to manage resources in addition to organizing the development cycles. Planning Poker and expert decision models in the traditional approaches have scalability, subjectivity, and inconsistency that render the method inaccurate and cause project overruns most of the time. In this research work, it is suggested to use a CatBoost Regressor to improve the estimation of efforts in Scrum projects. The method proposed in this paper can solve some of the hardest estimation tasks such as the ability to deal with categorical variables and minimize the bias of prediction. In contrast to other traditional models of machine learning, CatBoost works with high dimensionality and learning results optimization using historical data of Scrum projects. Catboost model is better than traditional regression models since it has better MSE, RMSE by getting an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9872, which is a particular improvement to the best baseline model. In this piece of research, we conclude that our model improves the estimation of Scrum efforts, which results in a solid and effective agile project management solution through the combination of risk-based adjustments and sophisticated features.

title: A Hierarchical Intelligent Design Approach for Frontal Collision Vehicle Structures Based on Machine Learning
authors: Shijie Zhu, Yejie Jiang, Baogong Liu, Chunyu Zhang, Xiangzheng Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a hierarchical intelligent design approach for vehicle frontal collision vehicle body structures. It involves constructing system-level decision-tree models for each body performance requirement, where body performance requirements (e.g., Occupant Load Criterion (OLC)) are leaf nodes and component performance (e.g., component average stiffness) are decision nodes. Then, component-level decision-tree models are built for each component's performance requirements, with component performance (e.g., component average stiffness) as leaf nodes and design parameters (e.g., beam design parameters) as decision nodes. Using these models enables rapid intelligent design of body components. Initially, determine vehicle-level performance requirements and use the system-level model to identify key component performance requirements. Next, apply the component-level model to design parameters for each key component based on its performance requirements. This approach significantly diminishes repetitive iterations in traditional optimization, reducing necessary simulation and testing rounds in body structure optimization for similar vehicles. Consequently, it conserves computational resources, cuts development costs, and enhances design efficiency.

title: Experimental Investigation of Mode Switching in Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer System Integrated Onboard Auxiliary Battery Charger
authors: Zi Wang, Ryosuke Ota
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: In dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) systems, converters require high-performance power devices; however, their utilization is limited, leading to low device utilization. As a solution, the authors previously proposed a multiport onboard AC–DC converter that integrates an auxiliary battery charging function, whose fundamental characteristics have been clarified. In this paper, this multiport converter is experimentally investigated with respect to mode switching under DWPT conditions. The experimental results confirm that mode switching can be achieved without chattering, thereby demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed system.

title: Revolutionizing Brain Tumor Detection with Deep Learning: Enhancing Accuracy and Enabling Early Diagnosis
authors: Priyanshu Singh, Reshma, Shikha Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This study attempts to improve brain detection and therapy to reduce suffering. The term “cancer” refers to malignant tumors, which are characterized by aberrant cell development and are brain tumors. Traditionally, to locate malignant areas within the brain, medical experts have relied on CT and MRI images. However, in this study, we focus on processing MRI scan pictures to identify illness status. These are the purposes of this study: i) the identification of abnormal image features and ii) the precise segmentation of tumor regions. By creating segmented masks, we can estimate tumor density, which holds crucial implications for therapeutic interventions. Our study employs deep learning techniques to detect abnormalities within MRI images to achieve these objectives. Tumor region segmentation is achieved by applying a multi-level thresholding technique. The segmented region's quantity of cancerous pixels is a vital indicator of the affected area's density.

title: Enhancing Cryptographic Security Using Pseudoprimes: A Novel Encryption-Decryption Algorithm
authors: Bhawana Fulara, Arvind Bhatt, Shubham Agarwal, Deepak Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The present study proposes a novel cryptographic algorithm using pseudoprimes to augment secure communication systems. Unlike algorithms based on RSA, which rely on large prime numbers, the proposed approach rests on the application of strong pseudoprimes crucial for improving key masking and protecting against exposure to factorization attack in bases 2 and 3. The results from this study provide better encryption and decryption capabilities, resilience of keys, improvement of algorithms, and execution in Python, and a profound security analysis and investigation. This research presents a comparative analysis that determines how systems enhanced with pseudoprimes offer distinct advantages over traditional encryption methods.

title: Optimal Operation Strategy for VPP Considering Chp Flexibility Enhancement and Deep Peak Regulation
authors: Tianfang Zhang, Danfeng Zhang, Qiaosheng Deng, Yunlong Qiu, Bing Xu, Jiaqi Zhao
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: To address the challenge of peak-shaving demands in power systems under high renewable energy penetration, this paper proposes an optimal operational strategy for virtual power plants (VPPs), specifically targeting the constraints on combined heat and power (CHP) units' peakshaving capabilities imposed by the “heat-driven power generation” mode. Initially, a collaborative architecture integrating carbon capture systems and electric boilers is constructed within the virtual power plant, followed by the development of an economic dispatch model embedded with a deep peak-shaving compensation mechanism. Subsequently, a coordinated optimization strategy is proposed, which unlocks the deep peak-shaving potential of CHP units through the incorporation of electric boilers and peak-shaving compensation mechanisms. Meanwhile, the carbon capture system is treated as a dispatchable load, with its capture energy consumption flexibly adjusted to synergistically enhance system operational flexibility and renewable energy accommodation capacity. Moreover, an improved multi-genetic algorithm is introduced to efficiently solve this high-dimensional nonlinear optimization model. Finally, simulation analyses validate the effectiveness of the proposed model and strategy in enhancing the economic benefits of the virtual power plant and strengthening its peakshaving capabilities.

title: Utility-Driven Selective Memory for Reinforcement Learning: A Biologically Inspired Replay Framework
authors: Vidhya Lavanya Ramachandran, Kondru Charwick Hamesh, Yamavarapu Bhanodai Yadav, Sumesh E P
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Agentic AI needs strong long-term memory to reason over long horizons and adapt. Standard reinforcement learning (RL) replay buffers use static retention, wasting capacity on low-value experiences and slowing learning. We introduce a utility-driven memory curation framework that scores each transition by a weighted combination of immediate reward magnitude and temporal-difference (TD) error, capturing both episodic importance and training informativeness. A Deep Q-Network (DQN) agent with our adaptive buffer keeps high-utility transitions and evicts low-utility ones under capacity pressure, emulating selective consolidation and relevance-based forgetting. Sampling remains uniform over the retained set, preserving simplicity, while logs of utility and evictions provide transparent, interpretable memory decisions. On CartPole-v1 and Acrobot-v1, Utility-Driven Replay learns faster than FIFO and Prioritized Experience Replay (PER) on CartPole-vl and achieves higher final returns on Acrobot-v1 by preserving informative swing-up experiences. Utility-driven agents match or slightly outperform PER in final returns on CartPole-v1 and converge faster; on Acrobot-v1, they reach superior asymptotic performance. Baselines include Uniform Replay (FIFO), PER with FIFO eviction, and Random Eviction, averaged over multiple seeds. Beyond performance gains, the approach is easy to implement with minimal DQN changes and clarifies memory dynamics over training, pointing toward lifelong learning, self-regulated memory, and ethical, explainable agent behavior.

title: Stability Analysis of Double Reference P&O and ANN MPPT in PV Systems
authors: Jayanta Kumar Sahu, Shreyansi Nanda, Sampad Kumar Pradhan, Chittaranjan Swain, Dipika Debasmita Panda, Jyoti Prasad Patra
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper compares the Maximum Power Point Tracking methods for photovoltaic systems based on Artificial Neural Networks and Double Reference Perturb and Observe. The performance of both approaches is assessed in the paper under various environmental circumstances, with an emphasis on important parameters including stability, tracking speed, and power loss. The comparison is based on key performance characteristics, such as power loss and stability during temperature and irradiance changes. The results demonstrate that while the DR-P&O method provides faster initial tracking with moderate stability, the ANN-based MPPT significantly reduces power loss and provides better stability during dynamic changes. For PV systems, this paper provides useful information on how to select optimal MPPT strategies to optimize energy harvesting.

title: AI-Driven Fault Diagnosis and Health Management for Power Equipment Using a Hybrid Deep Learning Framework
authors: Caolu Shi, Yisheng Fang, Hongbo Zhang, Sihan Du
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: The growing complexity of modern power systems necessitates intelligent and automated solutions for fault diagnosis and health management (FDHM) of critical power equipment. This paper proposes a novel AI-driven framework that integrates multi-modal sensor data, deep learning models, and digital twin technology to achieve accurate fault detection, health assessment, and remaining useful life (RUL) prediction. The proposed system employs a hybrid CNN-LSTM architecture for spatiotemporal feature extraction, an improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm for model tuning, and a physics-informed digital twin for simulation and prediction. Validated on real-world datasets from 500 kV transformers and GIS switchgear, the system achieves 98.7% fault classification accuracy, 95.3% RUL prediction precision, and reduces false alarms by 87%. The framework enables proactive maintenance and is estimated to save up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\dollar 2. 3}$</tex> million annually per substation.

title: Performance Evaluation of Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithms for Transient Stability Assessment Using Synchrophasor Data
authors: Sharmila Devakumar, Prabhakar Karthikeyan Shanmugam
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: This work explores how Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) techniques can be employed to evaluate transient stability in power systems by utilizing synchrophasor measurements as the primary data source. Traditional approaches depend on numerical simulations or machine learning; however, these methods face challenges in real-time deployment and generalization. To overcome these limitations, this work applies DRL for TSA using phasor measurement unit (PMU) data. Specifically, five DRL models like Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), Deep Q-Network (DQN), Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C), Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) are applied to a well-known benchmark dataset. The dataset comprises of 3,120 simulation cases with 354 features that are generated from transient stability studies of the IEEE 39-bus New England test system. The models are employed to classify operating conditions as either stable or unstable under a range of fault disturbances. In these five DRL Model results, DQN achieved the highest accuracy by outperforming PPO, SAC, DDPG, and A2C. These findings demonstrate the robustness of the DQN for real-time TSA and highlight its potential for integration into wide-area monitoring systems.

title: Early Detection of Autism Spectrum Disorder in Toddlers Based on XGBoost and SHAP
authors: Yenny Margareta Wijaya, Nurul Ilmi, Hertanto Suryoprayogo
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) during the early stages of development continues to play an important role in helping to provide necessary intervention during the critical stages of development. In the classical approach for the diagnosis of ASD, there are often instances where the diagnosis is based on the expert opinion of the clinician, which often leads to inconsistent diagnosis and delays. In light of the above-discussed limitations, the following study proposes an understandable approach for the diagnosis of ASD by combining the Extreme Gradient Boosting algorithm and SHAP. This study uses an independent evaluation approach for the XGBoost model and carries out the experiment on three separate ASD datasets available to the general public. After pre-processing the data, the study uses accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.The experimental study reveals that the XGBoost model performs well on the first and third dataset, which confirms the presence of reliable and distinct behavioral cues. However, the suboptimal performance on the second dataset confirms the challenges faced due to the presence of noise and inconsistent features. The result obtained from the SHAP study confirms that the behavioral questionnaire items and the array of features, specifically A6 to A9, play the most significant role, and the characteristics are less important. These experimentally supported facts and study analyses verify that the novel XGBoost-SHAP model not only delivers optimal accuracy but also provides clarity and meaningful information for toddlers suffering from ASD. Keywords—Autism Spectrum Disorder, Explainable AI, SHAP, XGBoost, Early Detection, Machine Learning.

title: Control Strategy For Virtual Synchronous Generator Based on Adaptive Sliding Mode Control
authors: Xiuren Du, Xuhong Yang, Xiaofang Zhu, Shun Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To enhance system robustness and grid recovery, an Adaptive Sliding Mode Control strategy based on Virtual Synchronous Generator (ASMC-VSG) is proposed. This method incorporates Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) to control the output voltage reference within the Adaptive Sliding Mode Control (ASMC) framework. A simulation model was built using Matlab, and comparative analysis was conducted with the traditional ASMC method. Simulation results demonstrate that when system parameters change, the ASMC-VSG strategy can enhance system stability and improve the transient process.

title: Classifying Indonesian Tweet Virality with Machine and Deep Learning
authors: Jeffrey Junior Tedjasulaksana, Andien Dwi Novika, Almuzhidul Mujhid, Ricky Reynardo Siswanto, Willy Kristian, Constantine Amadio Widjaya
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The rapid growth of social media platforms, particularly Twitter, has facilitated the widespread dissemination of information in Indonesia. Predicting tweet virality can support effective strategies in digital marketing, public communication, and online engagement. This study classifies Indonesian tweet virality into three categories—low, medium, and high—based on retweet counts, using textual and numerical features. Textual features are represented through IndoBERT embeddings, complemented by sentiment, emotion, and tweet metadata. To address class imbalance, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) were applied alongside cost-sensitive learning, while Genetic Algorithm (GA) was employed for hyperparameter tuning. Experimental results show that XGBoost with cost-sensitive learning achieved perfect metrics (F1 = 1.00), while PCA + SMOTE + XGBoost also performed strongly (F1 = 0.94). In contrast, Deep Neural Networks (DNN) struggled to capture minority classes, resulting in lower F1-scores despite relatively high accuracy. These findings highlight the robustness of XGBoost, though perfect performance should be interpreted with caution as further validation on larger and more diverse datasets is needed. Beyond methodological contributions, this study also fills a gap in non-English NLP research by demonstrating effective virality prediction for Indonesian tweets.

title: A Novel Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm With Adaptive Parameter Tuning
authors: Jinze Liu, Jun Zhao, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is an optimization algorithm that allows particles to find the optimal solution in the search space by simulating the foraging behavior of a flock of birds. Improvement of the PSO algorithm mainly consists of adaptively adjusting the inertia weights and learning factors, as well as constraining the processing particles' positions and velocities, so as to improve the convergence speed, accuracy, diversity and feasibility of the algorithm. We adaptively adjust the parameters in PSO by designing new inertia weights and learning factors, so that it can better balance local and global search. We conducted comparative experiments with three different optimization algorithms in 20 different standard test functions. The results show that adaptive particle swarm optimization (APSO) has excellent performance.

title: Machine Learning Based Water Quality Assessment of the Krishna River: A Data-Driven Approach for Environmental Monitoring
authors: Pranita P. Bhor, Pradnya R. Valvi, Radhika J. Thale, Janhvi R. Mishra, Vikas Kolekar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Water quality is crucial to preserving human health and the sustainability of the ecosystem. Even if traditional techniques of assessing water quality are efficient, they can be expensive in terms of time and resources. The water quality of the Krishna River, one of India's most well-known rivers, was investigated in this study using machine learning methods, including Random Forest and CatBoost. The application of these algorithms yielded an accuracy of approximately 100% for Random Forest and 87.5% for CatBoost. The findings highlight Maharashtra as the region with the highest count of good water quality instances, while Andhra Pradesh faces significant challenges with pollution. Our findings show that machine learning may greatly improve the precision and effectiveness of water quality evaluation, offering a reliable tool for real-time observation and decision-making. This strategy provides a scalable and affordable way to guarantee the safety of water supplies, with possible uses in public health and environmental management.

title: Intelligent Anti-Proxy and Performance Framework for Employee Management using Transfer Learning
authors: Neeraj Gautam, Vivek Yadav
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Presently, Indian organisation facing big challenge in form of employee's attendance and employee's authentication Problem. To avoid the future loss to the employees in form financial burden this is not good for future growth and development of that particular organisation. To come out this problem organisation will look it seriously otherwise employees will make organisation underdeveloped which is not desirable by any of the owner or entrepreneur who invested such a large chunk of money on welfare of employees by providing salary. Every problem has solution, in era of digitalization we have to take the help of information technology management system. In this research paper we developed a system which is based on deep learning for secure employee's verification which is combination of facial recognition with likeness detection to prevent fake or proxy login attempts. This system is being capable of identification of real users and rejects photos which are not present in database. This system has feature of accurate and reliable authentication while employees login for his her attendance. This model also monitors employee's login behaviour Pattern and duplicate proxy. This findings support management in better performance of employees in form of employee engagement. The system has 98% of accuracy. At last this framework enhances transparency and productivity of the industry. This system has feature of accurate and reliable authentication while employees login for his her attendance. This model also monitors employee's login behaviour Pattern and duplicate proxy. This findings support management in better performance of employees in form of employee engagement. The system has 98% of accuracy. At last this framework enhances transparency and productivity of the industry.

title: Matched Filtering and Adaptive Energy for Efficient Pulse Detection in Time-Hopping Pseudolite
authors: Ayoub Bengherabi, Mustapha Flissi, Khaled Rouabah
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: The detection of pulse positions in pseudorandom time-hopping (TH) pseudolite (PL) signals is essential for their integration into participative Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receivers. Conventional approaches rely on computationally intensive exhaustive searches of TH intervals, which often yield a low detection probability and may fail under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces a robust four-stage pulseposition detection methodology that significantly improves TH signal acquisition compared to conventional approaches. The core innovation is the sequential integration of coarse acquisition for fractional alignment, matched filtering, and a novel adaptive energy detection scheme. This adaptive process reliably converts noisy correlation peaks into a clean binary pulse sequence, which is then efficiently compared against the TH table using circular correlation to identify the correct slot sequence and phase. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method consistently detects the correct TH slot indices and initial phases across varying duty cycles and SNR levels while achieving higher detection probability and substantially reducing computational complexity compared to conventional exhaustive search (ES) approaches. This methodology improves the reliability of PL-based positioning and supports practical real-time implementation in participative GNSS receivers.

title: Real-Time Robotic Painting and Surface Finishing in Automotive Manufacturing
authors: Mohammed H.F, Saurabh Banwar, S Sivasubramanian, A. Satyendra Goud, P. S. Pilomina, Sharustam Shomusarov, Sobirjonov Khumoyun Boburjon Ugli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The surface finishing and robotic painting processes in automotive manufacturing are critical determinants of vehicle exterior quality and production efficiency. Despite considerable progress in automation, real-time correction of paint irregularities remains a major challenge due to the absence of continuous, adaptive feedback mechanisms. Conventional vision-based inspection systems primarily detect defects post-application, leading to increased rework, material wastage, and production downtime. To overcome these constraints, this paper proposes the Real-Time Adaptive Aeroacoustic Robotic Painting and Finishing System (RAARPS)-a novel intelligent framework that integrates aeroacoustic sensing and deep learning-driven adaptive control for instant defect detection and correction.
