The RAARPS system utilizes an array of miniature directional microphones and airflow sensors strategically positioned on robotic arms and within the paint booth to capture high-frequency acoustic and aerodynamic signals generated during spray atomization and surface wetting. These signals are processed by a hybrid convolutional and recurrent neural network model, which interprets subtle variations in sound and airflow patterns to identify turbulence, overspray, or non-uniform atomization within milliseconds. The inference model then autonomously adjusts spray parameters, such as paint flow rate, electrostatic charge, and arm motion trajectory, ensuring consistent coating thickness and finish quality. Experimental validation demonstrates that RAARPS achieves a 6% improvement in defect detection accuracy and enhances first-pass yield compared to existing vision-based systems. Furthermore, the system reduces paint waste by approximately 12% and lowers volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions by about 8%, contributing significantly to sustainable and eco-efficient manufacturing. The results confirm that RAARPS provides a transformative advancement in intelligent robotic painting, offering real-time, data-driven adaptability that enhances surface precision, operational reliability, and environmental compliance.

title: Autonomous Edge Intelligence for Real-Time Inventory Management an Adaptive Zone-Aware IoT Mesh Framework
authors: Hyba AbdulJaleel, Ashu Nayak, Bakhriddinov Makhamadali Madaminjon ugli, K. Kumararaja, D Leela Durga, S. Kannimuthu, D.G. Tolipova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Modern intelligent factories are struggling to achieve real time visibility of the inventory because of the latency, flaws in the human intervention, and bottlenecks in the verticality of the traditional systems that encompass RFID-ERP integrations, barcode-MES models and manual periodical stock valuations. Such constraints cause poor decision making, poor stock control and insufficiency in regard to responsiveness to changing production requirements. To meet the issues described above, though, the application of Adaptive Zone-Aware IoT Mesh equipped with Autonomous Inventory Decision Agents (AZA-IMAD) can be proposed on this paper; it is a full edge-centric inventory control framework. AZA-IMAD implements the IoT sensor nodes in a truly dynamic form of zoning that are governed with autonomous decision agents that have the capability to perform real time sensor fusion, anomaly detection as well as reconstruction of replenishment at the edge itself. A zone-aware communication protocol will further ensure the vital changes will be transmitted to the network to reduce network congestion but a lightweight blockchain ledger will provide auditing to diverse changes that are decentralized as well as tamper-resistant and will not need web connectivity on an ongoing basis. The overall evaluation in a virtual smart manufacturing arrangement reveals AZA-IMAD achieves an desired inventory monitoring of an 91.75 that is above the conventional process of 65% - 85%. Also, specifically, the framework recognizes stock change at a rate of 93,90 and induces timely replenishment decision at 91 of the stock at 93% accuracy. In addition, AZA-IMAD saves on 38 percent of bandwidth in addition to activation response of decisions in milliseconds since the centralized processing bypasses are eliminated. AZA-IMAD introduces two core innovations: (1) a dynamic zoning mechanism that adapts sensor clusters based on real-time inventory density and flow, and (2) autonomous decision agents (AIDAs) operating at the network edge, enabling immediate anomaly detection and replenishment without central dependence. These innovations jointly deliver over 10% higher accuracy and 38% bandwidth savings compared to RFID-ERP systems.

title: Fpga Implementation of Radio and Video Composite Data Transmission for Signal Detection Applications Using Petalinux in Hardware/Software Co-Design Approach
authors: Redouane Kaibou, Mohamed Salah Azzaz, Bachir Madani, Hadj Abdelkader Benzater
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper presents an FPGA-based embedded platform for real-time composite transmission of video and radio signals in energy detection applications. Built on a Zynq-7000 SoC using Vivado HLS and PetaLinux, the system integrates a hardware/software co-design to fuse heterogeneous streams: OV7670 video via custom VideoCapture IP and RTL-SDR I/Q samples via HLS FFT IP for spectral analysis. A HackRF One generates different analog and digital modulated signals for loopback validation. The platform achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 5. 1} \pm \mathbf{0. 8}$</tex> FPS at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 8. 1} \pm$</tex> 1.3 ms latency under PetaLinux, 3.2 times faster than Windows while using only 2.44 % LUTs. Live RF tests with Keysight FieldFox confirm SNR 40-51 dB across 8 FM stations. Applications include UAV telemetry, cognitive radio, and edge surveillance. The work advances embedded digital signal processing through reusable IP cores and validated multi-modal fusion.

title: SAP System Optimization Using AI-Driven Process Automation and Predictive Modeling Maintenance for Enhanced Business Efficiency
authors: Kiran Kumar Reddy, Kamalakar Gunupati, Manish Kumar, Pell Reddy Rajender Reddy, Ramesh Julakanti, Ram Reddy Jonnalagadda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Companies that use SAP systems continue facing increasing pressure to become more operationally efficient while minimizing cost and driving innovation at the rapidly evolving digital world today. This research provides a new approach to optimizing SAP systems by integrating AI-enabled automation of process and predictive maintenance. Common procedures such as data entry, invoice processing, and inventory control get automated by applying artificial intelligence to SAP workflows, which significantly reduces manual work and error level by human. In additions, based on the operational data and system logs analyzed by the machine learning algorithms-powered predictive maintenance, it is possible to predict probable problems and be proactive in the treatments, minimizing the downtime and ensuring the continuity of business. Through real-time monitoring and sophisticated analysis, the proposed architecture, not only makes the system effective and reliable, yet represents helpful insight. Case studies and simulated deployments show quantitatively significant improvements for critical KPIs, i.e., processing speed, the usage of resources and service availability. This strategy supports a proactive, data-oriented approach into the IT-infrastructure, which is capable of making agile corporate decisions, and complies with the goals of digital transformation. Being a revolutionary step in an intelligent enterprise resource planning, the integration of AI technology in SAP systems offers the scalable solutions for businesses that want to stay competitive on the changing market.

title: Regional Medium-Term Load Forecasting Based on Multi-Stage Residual Decomposition and BiLSTM
authors: Xifeng Guo, Zeyu Shen, Fenglong Kan, Guojiang Fu, Jiuyi Lv
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: Medium-term electric load forecasting plays a vital role in ensuring stable system dispatch and optimizing power resource allocation. However, existing models often fail to fully exploit the valuable information embedded in the residual components produced by variational mode decomposition (VMD). To address this limitation, we propose a parameter optimization strategy based on the rime optimization algorithm (RIME) to improve the VMD process. Subsequently, the original load sequence and its residual components are further decomposed and reconstructed, which enhances forecasting accuracy. Experimental results show that, in a 5-day medium-term forecasting task, the proposed model reduces the root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), and mean absolute error (MAE) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$47.7 \%, 36.4 \%$</tex>, and 29.1%, respectively, thereby confirming its advantages in both forecasting accuracy and stability.

title: A Comparative Study of Transformer-Based Models for Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis on Indonesian Hotel Reviews
authors: Rifqi Alfinnur Charisma, Nikita Ananda Putri Masaling, Ayu Maulina, Fiqri Ramadhan Tambunan, Leo Andri Yulius Caesar, Roderich Cavine Chow
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Analyzing unstructured customer feedback, such as Indonesian hotel reviews, presents significant challenges, particularly with class imbalance and the limitations of general sentiment analysis, which often fails to capture opinions on specific service aspects. This study aims to conduct a comparative performance analysis of several Transformer-based models, such as IndoBERTweet, BERT, and DeBERTa, for Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) on this type of data. In contrast to other studies, this one provides a more accurate evaluation, particularly for minority classes, by methodically testing these models on a homogeneous dataset and including the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to rectify class imbalance. Micro F1-score, precision, and recall were used to assess the models' performance after they were trained on a pre-processed and balanced dataset of hotel reviews from Indonesia. Due in great part to its pre-training on informal social media language that closely resembles the review content, IndoBERTweet demonstrated outstanding performance with a micro F1-score of 96.36%. In conclusion, IndoBERTweet and the SMOTE balancing approach work well together to provide a reliable and accurate ABSA system for hotel reviews in Indonesia.

title: Leader-Follower Game Optimization of Microgrid Operation Considering Wind Power Uncertainty
authors: Heqing Jiang, Haiming Niu, Shida Xu, Shuang Song, Shichao Jiang, Shengquan Jin, Zhiwei Li
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: To address wind power uncertainty, a microgrid leader-follower game model is constructed, in which the integrated energy retailer acts as the leader, while energy suppliers and load alliances serve as the followers. A bilevel optimization framework is employed to identify the worst-case wind power scenario, and the problem is solved in a distributed manner using a GA-QP algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach enhances economic efficiency and risk resilience, while facilitating peak shaving, valley filling, and multi-party equilibrium.

title: Clustering and Profiling Student Study Behaviors and Interactions with an AI Coding Assistant
authors: Eric Poitras, Jeffry Paul Suresh Durai, Jonathan Boisvert, Keaton Doucette, Michael Pin-Chuan Lin, Marta Kryven, Raghav Sampangi
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: This study examines how undergraduate students spaced and interleaved their practice while learning introductory programming, with support from an AI coding assistant. The assistant was designed to provide guidance without revealing the complete solution to problems, aiming to foster independent learning rather than promoting over-reliance that could hinder skill development. Over a five-week period, students solved up to 350 formative practice problems and completed summative assessments. Analysis of their interactions revealed three distinct profiles of study behavior, each associated with distinct learning outcomes. The most proficient learners practiced more extensively and diversely, becoming more fluent in completing code writing tasks. Notably, these high-performing students also made the most frequent use of the AI assistant, especially for interpreting error messages and requesting context-sensitive hints.

title: Sustainable Agriculture Through Solar-Powered IoT-Based Crop Monitoring
authors: Sanjana Prasad, Sunil M C, Sumanth Gowda, Sumukha C R, Srinivas S C, Ishu Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The main challenges present in today's modern agriculture are sustainability and efficacy which necessitates the combination of various technologies like renewable energy with Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. A Solar-Powered IoT-Based Smart Crop Monitoring System proposed in this work automates irrigation process, helps in the choosing crops and monitors various key environmental factors. Multiple parameters like soil moisture, temperature, humidity, light intensity, and gas sensors are put together with an Arduino-based controller. Data collection process is done with the help of various sensors, processed and communicated through an LCD display and Bluetooth interface, The merging of solar power with IoT-driven multi-sensor monitoring, inclusion of gas detection for environmental safety, intelligent crop recommendation based on the soil and climate conditions, and a dual communication mechanism for improved accessibility makes it unique from the existing systems. The existing current systems in the literature focus either on irrigation or monitoring fields. This work delivers a holistic, sustainable, and cost-effective framework that is designed for remote and off-grid farming. Results demonstrated dependable operation when the soil moisture ranges from 3% to 62%, temperature from 29° C to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$41{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, and humidity from 58% to 68%. Crops recommended based on the soil and weather conditions were rice, wheat, maize, ragi, and cactus. The proposed work confirms its effectiveness in conservation of water, thereby supporting informed decisions, and promotes precision agriculture.

title: State-of-the-Art Antenna Innovations for Effective RF Energy Harvesting-A Review
authors: Pandit T. Yewale, Abhay N. Gaikwad
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Novel antennas are designed for effective RF energy harvesting that requires innovative engineering and optimization techniques. Low-profile and multi-band antennas are a significant step forward in creating efficient energyharvesting solutions that adapt to diverse frequency bands and operational conditions. The design of antenna structures for effective RF energy harvesting is fundamentally tied to mathematics governing electromagnetic principles and materials science. As research advances, the future holds promise for innovative solutions that enhance the potential of RF energy harvesting in powering a wide array of wireless devices and systems. As technology progresses and the demand for sustainable energy solutions rises, these optimized antenna designs play a crucial role in powering innovative wireless devices and systems in the future.

title: A Deep Learning System using MobileNetV3 to Identify Facial Emotion for Supporting in Mental Health Monitoring
authors: Baby K, Bindhuja R, Indhiresh V, Jeeviga B, Nimish Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Facial expressions are essential indicators of a emotions of the and psychological state. Accurate recognition of these expressions can support early detection of mental health conditions. This proposes a lightweight, facial expression analysis framework in a real time leveraging Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), MobileNetV3, transfer learning. This model extracts feature of facial through pretrained CNN layers and classify the emotions fully connected with SoftMax layers. Evaluation can be conducted using the dataset, a recent and diverse benchmark for studying facial emotions in mental health application. The proposed CNN-based model demonstrates a high classification accuracy of 92.5%, efficient model with shorter execution time. Compared to traditional and quantum convolutional models, this technique provides an improved compromise between performance and efficiency. Its low computational cost and high accuracy make it well-suited for mobile and embedded healthcare applications aimed at real-time mental health monitoring.

title: Practical Method for Estimating Energy Consumption Model of Electric Vehicles Using Real-World Driving Data
authors: Yuki Hosomi, Alessandro Correa Victorino, Binh-Minh Nguyen, Hiroshi Fujimoto
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: To enhance the environment-friendly performance of electric vehicles (EVs), maximizing energy efficiency remains a critical challenge. Achieving this objective requires highly accurate vehicle dynamics and energy models tailored to the target EV. This study proposes a cost-effective parameter estimation method based on real driving data, eliminating the need for conventional motor bench testing. By collecting motion and energy-related measurements directly from the vehicle during actual driving, the method formulates an optimization problem that minimizes the discrepancy between measured and calculated values to identify model parameters. The proposed approach enables parameter estimation on each driving occasion, allowing it to adapt dynamically to variations in vehicle characteristics and road conditions. As a result, the obtained model closely reflects the actual energy consumption, leading to a reduction in the root mean square error.

title: Reliability Investigation of High Performance Nanoscale Dual Edge Triggered (DET) TSPC-D-Flip Flops for Future Low Power Electronics
authors: Md. Badhesha, Motla Sathwika, J. Ajayan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: In the digital world, DET flip-flops provide an ingenious method of balancing performance and power efficiency. DET FFs are essential elements in contemporary VLSI designs due to their ability to function on both clock edges. DET-FF (Dual Edge Triggered Flip-Flop) can lower the power dissipation of synchronous logic circuits by achieving the same data rate as SET FFs (Single Edge Triggered) at half the clock frequency. According to a hypothesis, DET-FFs use less power than SET FFs in situations where glitches are infrequent; however, to achieve the most beneficial design choices, a wide range of perceptions is required. In FN_C-DET, when the supply voltage varies from 0.7 V to 1.2 V, the delay is reduced by 66.1% at a temperature of 300 K and 65.75% at 380 K. In contemporary electronic systems, energy- and power-efficient designs are becoming increasingly crucial. Systems that maintain high performance while consuming less power are necessary for both current and future applications. The impact of temperature, voltage, and process fluctuations on system performance is a significant problem.

title: Point–Line Pose Estimation With a Known Direction by Branch-and-Bound Optimization
authors: Cuicui Jiang, Qinglei Hu, Dongyu Li, Chengrong Long, Yanmei Jiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In this article, we present a branch-and-bound (BnB) optimization framework for camera pose estimation that jointly exploits point and line features under a known direction constraint. By leveraging the known direction, the original six-degree-of-freedom point–line pose problem is reduced to the 4-D formulation. This reduced problem is further decoupled into two subproblems: global translation estimation and 1-D attitude estimation. Subsequently, the BnB optimization algorithm is used to estimate the global translation. We solve the translation globally using a BnB scheme, for which we derive tight upper and lower bounds for both point and line measurements based on two complementary geometric constraints. The remaining rotational component is then recovered via 1-D global voting followed by singular value decomposition. We show that the proposed method is robust to outliers in both point and line sets, yielding accurate and reliable pose estimates. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real data validate the effectiveness and accuracy of the approach. Source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/cc2jiang</uri>

title: Optimal Design of High-Voltage Flameproof Induction Motors Through Active Materials Mass Reduction
authors: Cecilia Pagnozzi do Nascimento, Bruno Baptista, Thiago de Paula Machado Bazzo, Ângela Ferreira
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Sustainability has become a pivotal factor in industrial equipment's appliances. Electric machines are designed not only for good operational performance but also for reduced resource consumption and waste of materials. This study focuses on optimizing high-voltage flameproof induction motors to minimize their active material mass. The process was implemented through an analytical optimization procedure, using a direct search method, the Nelder-Mead Simplex algorithm. Key design variables, such as slot dimensions, core length, and stator windings parameters, were carefully set during optimization due to their substantial impact on the volume of active materials, specifically aluminum, copper, and electrical steel. Regarding constraints, particular emphasis was placed on factors such as starting current, efficiency, and maximum magnetic flux density so as not to compromise the motors' operational performance. In addition, mechanical and manufacturing constraints were also considered. The results obtained from the optimization process were validated through finite element analysis using Ansys Maxwell software. The comprehensive results of the entire procedure revealed a significant reduction in the active material mass in all the motors analyzed, always respecting the imposed restrictions and manufacturing limits. Additionally, two other benefits were observed: improved machine efficiency and reduced harmonic content in most cases.

title: Embedded C Code Safety Analysis with Automated Fault Tree Synthesis for Automotive Virtualization Systems
authors: Yikun Yang, Jie Xu, Yongping Huang, Junqun Xiong
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: With the evolution of automotive E/E architectures toward centralized designs, virtualization systems for intelligent cockpits impose higher demands on the security and reliability of hypervisors. Traditional Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) methods suffer from dual bottlenecks: poor model-code consistency and low verification efficiency. Current research primarily relies on manual fault tree construction and code-level verification, leading to logical redundancy and insufficient coverage. To address the issues of logical redundancy and critical path omission, this paper proposes an automated fault tree generation framework based on program analysis and symbolic execution, enabling automated extraction of code-level critical paths and precise mapping of fault logic. Specifically, it achieves comprehensive variable-level dependency tracking through backward program slicing on Low Level Virtual Machine (LLVM) intermediate representation, resolves multipath events using an enhanced symbolic execution-based SMT solver, and optimizes minimal cut set generation via the Quine-McCluskey algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can automatically generate fault trees from source code effectively, maintain high consistency with traditional FTA from design models, and uncover additional critical fault paths while dramatically reducing manual effort.

title: Smart Driver Assistance System Using AI
authors: P A Abirajah, A Sam Good Win, A. Praisy Evangelin
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Road accidents have been a thorn in the flesh of the world, and most of these accidents are related to human factors that include distracted drivers, drowsiness, and illegally entering a vehicle. Conventional safety systems, such as seatbelt alerts, lane departure warning systems, and alcohol ignition interlocks, are effective in specific contexts but cannot respond to multiple factors that lead to driver-related accidents in real-time in a holistic manner. Equally, with more sophisticated technologies like adaptive cruise control and blind-spot detection, there is enhanced situational awareness; however, this is limited to the vehicle’s surroundings and provides little control over driver actions. These gaps serve as an indication of the urgency of a more detailed and innovative driver assistance solution. To overcome this difficulty, we introduce the Smart Driver Assistance System (SDAS). This holistic, AI-based platform utilises a single front-facing camera and integrates various safety features into a cohesive platform. The system also features secure face verification based on MTCNN and FaceNet models to limit unauthorised vehicle access; therefore, only authenticated users will be able to manage the vehicle. Ingestion of main media is only achievable via a gesture control module powered by MediaPipe Hands, which facilitates distraction-free management of infotainment; consequently, less cognitive load is applied6 to the drivers. A YOLOv8-based object detection model, which detects cases of mobile phone use during driving and provides real-time auditory and visual feedback, is used to reduce unsafe behaviour. Moreover, the constant tracking of the Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) enables the identification of drowsiness and microsleep instances beforehand, providing a warning to avert fatigue-related accidents. Installed on a conventional computing platform, SDAS demonstrates strong performance, achieving authentication accuracy of over 98%, gesture recognition of over 95%, and driver monitoring of over 90%. This system will also help bridge the gap between conventional driver assistance technology and the latest autonomous driving technology, thereby providing a unified solution that enhances safety levels, reduces the number of accidents, and makes the driving experience more enjoyable. Finally, SDAS highlights the potential of AI-driven multimodal monitoring to pave the way for more innovative and safer cars in the future.

title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Disturbance Rejection Synchronous Tracking for Marine Vessels with Prescribed Performance*
authors: Haipeng Fan, Xiuchen Fan, Xin Hu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This paper presents a dynamic event-triggered enhanced adaptive synchronous tracking control strategy for intelligent vessels under time-varying disturbances. By integrating prescribed performance constraints (PPC) with disturbance observer-based compensation, the transient overshoot and steady-state tracking error are explicitly bounded. A disturbance observer estimates environmental disturbances online, while a dynamic event-triggered system mitigates actuator saturation effects. The error transformation technique maps constrained tracking errors into unconstrained variables, enabling systematic controller design. Simulations on a 1:70 scaled Cyber Ship II model demonstrate reduction in overshoot and superior disturbance rejection compared to baseline methods. The results validate the proposed method's potential for real-world maritime applications.

title: A Hybrid Approach for Detection of Skin Diseases Using Deep Learning
authors: Krutika k. Chhajed, Ajay B. Gadicha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Skin disease diagnosis is a critical aspect of dermatology, yet traditional methods often suffer from subjectivity, variability, and limited accessibility to dermatologists, particularly in developing regions. To address these challenges, this study presents a hybrid deep learning model that integrates ResUNet++ for lesion segmentation and AlexNet-Random Forest for classification, leveraging their strengths for accurate skin disease detection. The HAM10000 dataset, containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1, 5 5 0}$</tex> images across seven skin disease categories, is used for model training and evaluation over 35 epochs. The ResUNet++ model effectively segments skin lesions, ensuring that only the affected regions contribute to classification, thereby improving accuracy. AlexNet, coupled with Random Forest, extracts robust features for classification, achieving a balanced performance between deep learning and machine learning techniques. The model's performance is assessed using a confusion matrix, ROC curve, and training loss and accuracy graphs, which demonstrate its effectiveness in distinguishing between different skin diseases. Results indicate a significant improvement in diagnostic accuracy compared to traditional approaches, suggesting the hybrid model's potential for clinical implementation. This research contributes to the ongoing advancements in AI-driven dermatological diagnostics and highlights the importance of integrating segmentation and classification techniques for enhanced skin disease detection

title: Improving Food Security: A Novel Approach for Rice Leaf Disease Detection using Dynamic Mode Decomposition and DenseNet
authors: Afsa Mailmuri, Manohar Madgi, Vishwanath P Baligar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: Rice cultivation Plays a vital role in India in ensuring global food security however, its productivity is greatly impacted by several foliar diseases. Accurate and early detection is crucial for reducing crop loss and improving disease management. Conventional approaches rely on visual inspection and are prone to error, also labor -intensive and can lead to inaccuracies. The research tackles these issues using a deep learning approach that combines DensNet 121 with Dynamic Mode decomposition (DMD) which is used to improve disease identification and classification. DMD serves as a preprocessing technique that minimizes the background noise and emphasizes areas affected by disease which allows accurate feature extraction. A dataset of 9607 labeled images is used for training and evaluation with an 80-20 split for model validation.in the research conducted the DensNet 121 model is fine-tuned through transfer learning and achieved training accuracy of 93.32% and validation and test accuracies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2. 5 0 \%}$</tex> and 91.59. Experimental results show that using DMD in enhancing model interpretability, classification, and prediction, by generating attention-driven feature improvements is also able to localize the infected regions. Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score are used for performance evaluation.

title: Design of Fully Automatic Pulverizing Plant using PLC Logic and HMI Graphics
authors: Jheel Dayalani, Sarika S. Kanojia
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Pulverization plays a vital role in grinding raw materials, particularly in the food processing industry. Pulverizing plants can function in manual, semi-automatic, or fully automatic modes, with automation achieved through the integration of components such as capacitor duty contactors, changeover relays, and Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs). This paper presents the implementation of a DVP12SE 11R PLC, programmed using Delta ISP-Soft software, with COMMGR utilized for communication. In manual mode, operation is controlled through digital inputs, start/stop latches, and output ladder logic. The semi-automatic mode incorporates essential safety interlocks, while the automatic mode integrates both primary and safety interlocks for reliable operation. Additionally, the analog module ladder logic is designed as a closed-loop system employing a potentiometer, Variable Frequency Drive (VFD), and the PLC CPU’s analog module. Human-Machine Interface (HMI) graphics provide real-time visualization of key process parameters, including frequency, current, and system indicators. The proposed approach demonstrates a flexible and efficient control framework for pulverizing plant automation.

title: Optimizing Plant Disease Resistance Through Cloud-Enabled Microbiome Analysis Using Logistic Regression
authors: V. Vaidehi, R. Hema, C Srinivasan, P S V Surya Kumar, M. Ruba, Vivek V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This work investigates the enhancement of plant disease resistance by cloud-based microbiome analysis, using Logistic Regression (LR) to identify significant correlations between microbial populations and plant health. The increasing danger of plant diseases demands creative strategies to enhance resistance, and comprehending the microbiome provides a potential opportunity. It gathered microbiome samples from several plant species and used high-throughput sequencing to analyze microbial diversity. Quickly processed extensive datasets using cloud computing capabilities, facilitating thorough analysis. LR was used to analyze the relationship between microbiome composition and disease resistance traits, uncovering crucial microbial taxa that improve plant immunity. The results indicate that certain microbial profiles are associated with enhanced disease resistance, providing prospective avenues for microbiome modification in agricultural operations. This study enhances our comprehension of plant-microbe interactions and underscores the need to use cloud technology for extensive data analysis in agricultural microbiology. This initiative seeks to enhance sustainable farming methods and bolster crop resistance against pathogenic threats.

title: Harnessing Metaverse Technologies for Sustainable Healthcare: An Integrative Approach to Medical Education and Practice
authors: Ray Al-Barazie, Imen Zalila-Kolsi, Azza Mohamed
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The sustainability of the healthcare sector is increasingly recognized as a crucial goal, aided by novel ideas and technologies. This study investigates the transformative potential of metaverse technologies, namely virtual laboratory simulations (VLS), in promoting sustainable healthcare practices through medical education. Our research focuses on the use of VLS in medical professional training, particularly in the field of medical virology. Our findings show that VLS has considerable advantages in teaching practical skills required for identifying and managing viral infections, resulting in a deeper knowledge among students. However, we discovered issues, such as technological difficulties encountered by users, that could impede effective deployment. This study emphasizes the metaverse's function as a sustainable practice with the potential to influence the future of medical education and healthcare services. We make specific recommendations for maximizing the integration of metaverse technology to optimize their educational benefits. Finally, the incorporation of developing metaverse technologies opens significant prospects for boosting healthcare sustainability by effectively reducing existing restrictions while improving healthcare delivery and education.

title: I/Q Imbalance Fingerprinting for Identifying Counterfeit Wireless COTS Transceivers
authors: Quy Ton Le, Wesam Al Amiri, Terry N. Guo, Syed Rafay Hasan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Counterfeits in commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) devices pose significant security risks to supply chains, emphasizing the need for robust authentication methods. As the Internet of Things (IoT) continues to expand across various domains, such as autonomous vehicles (AVs), smart homes, and industrial automation, IoT devices have become ubiquitous. Many of these devices are equipped with wireless transceivers, enabling the use of radio frequency fingerprinting (RFF) for device authentication. One of the common RFF techniques is to extract unique features from in-phase and quadrature (I/Q) imbalance measurements. However, existing RFF techniques often rely on the use of a common test receiver, which limits their applicability in real world deployments. In this work, we propose a novel RFF technique independent of a common test receiver that leverages the crosstalk effect in the transceiver. An individual I/Q imbalance measurement is converted into an abstract data point that can be a vector value or, more generally, a probability density function (PDF). Our approach employs a statistical modeling framework that is lightweight and computationally efficient, eliminating the need for large labeled datasets or frequent model retraining. This makes the method well suited to real time implementation on platforms with limited computation and memory, since constellation gating, I/Q imbalance estimation, and PDF comparison can be implemented with simple streaming updates and a single distance check per recording. To examine the feasibility of the proposed method, we conducted extensive experiments using software-defined radios (SDRs) in different environments. Statistical analysis of the extracted fingerprints reveals that for a given device, the maximum measurement deviation (MMD) between a measured data point and the center of multiple measured points remains consistently smaller than the minimum inter-device distance, suggesting that it is feasible to generate stable and discriminative RFFs to authenticate COTS devices with transceivers in the supply chain.

title: On the Robustness of RSMA to Adversarial BD-RIS-Induced Interference
authors: Arthur S. de Sena, Jacek Kibiłda, Nurul H. Mahmood, André Gomes, Luiz A. DaSilva, Matti Latva-aho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: This article investigates the robustness of ratesplitting multiple access (RSMA) in multi-user multiple-input single-output (MISO) systems to interference attacks against channel acquisition induced by beyond-diagonal RISs (BD-RISs). Two primary attack strategies, random and aligned interference, are proposed for fully connected and group-connected reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) architectures. Valid random reflection coefficients are generated exploiting the Takagi factorization, while potent aligned interference attacks are achieved through optimization strategies based on a quadratically constrained quadratic program (QCQP) reformulation followed by projections onto the unitary manifold. Our numerical findings reveal that, when perfect channel state information (CSI) is available, RSMA behaves similarly to space-division multiple access (SDMA) and thus is highly susceptible to the attack, with BD-RIS inducing severe performance loss and significantly outperforming diagonal RIS. However, under imperfect CSI, RSMA consistently demonstrates significantly greater robustness than SDMA, particularly as the system's transmit power increases.

title: Optimal Batch-Size Control for Low-Latency Federated Learning with Device Heterogeneity
authors: Huiling Yang, Zhanwei Wang, Kaibin Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a popular approach for collaborative machine learning in sixth-generation (6G) networks, primarily due to its privacy-preserving capabilities. The deployment of FL algorithms is expected to empower a wide range of Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications, e.g., autonomous driving, augmented reality, and healthcare. The mission-critical and time-sensitive nature of these applications necessitates the design of low-latency FL frameworks that guarantee high learning performance. In practice, achieving low-latency FL faces two challenges: the overhead of computing and transmitting high-dimensional model updates, and the heterogeneity in communication-and-computation (C2) capabilities across devices. To address these challenges, we propose a novel-aware framework for optimal batch-size control that minimizes end-to-end (E2E) learning latency while ensuring convergence. The framework is designed to balance a fundamental C2 tradeoff as revealed through convergence analysis. Specifically, increasing batch sizes improves the accuracy of gradient estimation in FL and thus reduces the number of communication rounds required for convergence, but results in higher per-round latency, and vice versa. The associated problem of latency minimization is intractable; however, we solve it by designing an accurate and tractable surrogate for convergence speed, with parameters fitted to real data. This approach yields two batch-size control strategies tailored to scenarios with slow and fast fading, while also accommodating device heterogeneity. Extensive experiments using real datasets demonstrate that the proposed strategies outperform conventional batch-size adaptation schemes that do not consider the C2 tradeoff or device heterogeneity.

title: Carrier-Aided Intensity Modulation Direct Detection with Half-Bandwidth Field Recovery
authors: Yimin Hu, Yixiao Zhu, Ziheng Zhang, Weisheng Hu
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Large-scale generative artificial intelligence (AI) models are requiring massive optical interconnects to implement distributed training. However, intensity modulation direct detection (IM-DD) optics falls short in transmission distance due to dispersion-induce power fading. We propose a cost-effective carrier-assisted IM-DD (CA-IM-DD) scheme enabling single-lane >200 Gb/s transmission up to 75 km for scale-across applications. By adding a dedicated optical carrier, a single-sideband (SSB) signal is constructed with intensity modulation. To overcome the destruction of the Kramers-Kronig (KK) relation caused by receiver bandwidth limitation, two half-bandwidth field recovery (HB-FR) schemes, HB-KK and HB iteration cancellation (HB-IC), are implemented, which efficiently recovers the original SSB signal from received incomplete signal and eliminates signal-signal beating interference (SSBI) distortions. To estimate and remove the introduced phase noise, the residual carrier is adopted to accurately track the phase noise between two individual lasers. Experimentally, we transmit 45-Gbaud subcarrier modulation probabilistically-shaped 64-QAM across a standard single-mode fiber (SSMF) link. The measured normalized generalized mutual information (NGMI) meets the threshold of 0.857 after transmission, achieving gross data rates of 211.5 Gb/s (75 km) and 265.5 Gb/s (0 km). Meanwhile, the feasibility of residual carrier-based CPR is investigated. Several combinations with 1-MHz and 100-kHz linewidths lasers are employed, showing consistency on NGMI performance. The demonstrated CA-IM-DD system offers a distance-extended, power-efficient and cost-effective solution for next-generation 200 G datacenter interconnects.

title: Robust Optimization Localization via Ellipsoidal Uncertainty Sets for NLOS Errors Learned from CIR-Based Range Error Prediction
authors: Wenqi Shui, Rui Cheng, Xiangxing Zhu, Fading Zhao, Shuang Qin
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In wireless localization, non-line-of-sight (NLOS) propagation in complex environments significantly degrades the time-of-arrival (TOA) positioning accuracy of ultra-wideband (UWB) systems. However, existing robust optimization methods mainly rely on interval uncertainty set modeling for NLOS errors, which inherently neglects the non-uniformity and correlation of NLOS errors, with these interval set bounds often being conservatively predefined. To address these issues, this paper proposes replacing interval sets with ellipsoidal uncertainty sets for a more accurate characterization of the statistical properties of NLOS errors. In particular, the ellipsoidal uncertainty set is constructed based on the mean vector and covariance matrix of NLOS errors predicted by a deep learning model. Since ellip-soidal uncertainty sets inherently lead to nonconvex formulations, we introduce auxiliary variables for reparameterization and apply the S-lemma, thereby reformulating the original problem into a tractable convex optimization problem. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that, compared with existing methods, our ellipsoidal set-based approach, which accounts for the non-uniformity and correlation of NLOS errors, significantly improves localization accuracy and robustness across various complex environments.

title: EeveeDark: A Binary Neural Framework for Low-Light Video Enhancement via Event-Guided Sensor-Level Fusion_supp1-3666388.mp4
authors: Onur Eker
publish: N/A
abstract: Enhancing videos under extreme low-light conditions remains challenging due to the difficulty of balancing restoration quality and computational efficiency in resource-constrained settings. This paper introduces EeveeDark, a low-light video enhancement framework that combines the spatial richness of sensor-level RAW data with the temporal precision of event streams. Central to our model is a Binary Neural Network (BNN) architecture that reduces computational overhead by quantizing weights and activations while preserving detail. EeveeDark incorporates (i) modality-specific binary encoders for processing RAW frames and event data, (ii) a lightweight fusion block for integrating spatial and temporal cues, and (iii) an event-guided skip gating mechanism for dynamic spatiotemporal refinement. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets show that EeveeDark outperforms prior BNN-based methods and offers a favorable performance-efficiency trade-off compared to full-precision models.

title: Disease Prediction in Plants and Recommendations Fertilizer Using Deep Learning
authors: Amit Kumar Jaiswal, Urvi Jindal, Hitesh Kumar, Aryan, Pawan Singh, Deeksha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The factory conditions are known to enhance agriculture productivity tremendously causing drastic yields losses and profit lapses among the farmers across the world. Prior and precise finding of complaint as well as relevant proposals of toxin would be an essential role in perfection husbandry. This endeavour suggests an extensive literacy- based pattern of automated factory complaints vaticination and toxin recommendation. The ideas of the proposed system leverage the use of image datasets containing factory leaves that can be used to classify high-delicacy complaint-affected crops. When the name of a crop and complaint are interconnected, the system suggests accurate diseases adapted to the definite condition hence assisting the grower to make sound decision making. Combined complaints bracket and toxin suggestion, this strategy would offer an increased crop working, a decline in homemade dependence and ease of harvest loss. As it is proved experimentally, deep literacy is useful in providing reliable forecasts that can be scaled across and intelligent output provision of in-smarts husbandry processes[1], [2].

title: Analogue Signal Computing Architecture for Real-Time Environmental Intelligence in Resource-Limited Wearable Electronics
authors: P. Anusha, Abdul Subhani Shaik, B. Thanuja, Biroju Papachary
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In this paper, a novel computing architecture for analogue signals is proposed to meet the specifications of real-time thermal environments and wearable electronics with resource constraints. The proposed architecture differs from prior art digital signal processing systems, which dissipate considerable power and computational resources. The proposed architecture utilises ultra-low-power analogue circuits to directly operate on environmental signals, such as temperature, humidity, gas concentrations, and light intensity, in the analogue domain. The system implements efficient signal conditioning, feature extraction, and anomaly detection using core building blocks, such as operational transconductance amplifiers (OTAs), analogue integrators, floating-gate MOSFETs, and event-driven ADCs, without requiring constant digital sampling. An adaptive thresholding and choice are made possible by a neuromorphic analogue processing core and are responsive in real-time. It is built using 0.18 μm lithography CMOS and optimised for wearable platforms in terms of area-efficient layout and energy-conscious operation, utilising tiny energy harvesters. Experimental simulations and prototype measurements have proven that the analogue system is significantly more energy-efficient than its digital equivalents, with a processing energy consumption of less than 50 mW per module and an accuracy range of 8,592 per cent, making it suitable for monitoring environmental conditions. The system is capable of resisting noisy input very well, which means it can be applied in the real world, where power and reliability are essential limitations. The proposed architecture extends battery life and facilitates easy integration into flexible, skin-compatible wearable devices, as it alleviates the demand for complex digital processing and information transmission. The foundation for future research on bio-inspired analogue signal processing for edge intelligence in energy-constrained systems has been established in this work, which may be considered a breakthrough in self-powered, intelligent wearable devices for energy and health monitoring technologies.

title: Causality-Aware LLM-Enhanced Graph Representation Learning for Adaptive Power System Control
authors: Fang Yao, Jizhe Liu, Yuechuan Tao, Jing Qiu, Herbert Ho-Ching Iu, Guo Chen, Zhao Yang Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: High renewable penetration and reduced system inertia introduce significant challenges for transient stability assessment and control. This article proposes a causality-aware, large language model–enhanced distribution-preserving graph representation learning framework (LLM-DP-GRL) for fast and accurate stability prediction and decision-making. The DP-GRL model captures both structural and distributional properties of network states, whereas large language models provide physics-informed priors that improve data efficiency and generalization under multicontingency and out-of-distribution scenarios. A causal intervention module further quantifies bus-level influence on stability margins, offering interpretable insights consistent with system dynamics. The learned surrogate model is integrated into a cooperative preventive–emergency control strategy, enabling real-time stability margin evaluation and optimization. Tests on the IEEE 39-bus and 118-bus systems show that LLM-DP-GRL achieves higher accuracy, faster convergence, and improved robustness compared with conventional machine learning, LSTM, and GNN-based methods. The proposed approach reduces online control computation from over 35 min (TDS-based) to 39 s while maintaining inference latency below 30 ms. These results demonstrate that combining graph learning, LLM-guided priors, and causal analysis provides an effective and scalable solution for stability assessment and emergency control in low-inertia, high-renewable power systems.

title: Thermal Saliency-Based Spatial Weighting With Nonlinear Enhancement for Principal Component Thermography in ECPT
authors: Tengyan Xi, Ping Wang, Yan Shi, Yuan Zhang, Weihu Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: The detection of weak defects in eddy current pulsed thermography is hampered by nonuniform heating and thermal diffusion, which cause low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). While conventional principal component thermography (PCT) is widely used for data reduction, its nature as a “blind” statistical tool often fails to separate these subtle defect signatures from the dominant background noise. To address this, we adapt conventional PCT by introducing a saliency-based spatial weighting strategy. The core innovation is a weighting scheme where a spatial saliency map, derived from time-integrated thermal energy, is nonlinearly enhanced via a gamma transformation. Integrating this high-contrast weight map into the PCT algorithm transforms it from a blind statistical tool into a targeted, guided analysis. Validated on six diverse metallic specimens, the proposed spatially weighted PCT (SW-PCT) significantly outperforms traditional PCT and other representative methods in SNR, especially for enhancing weak defects. An optimized vectorized implementation ensures high computational efficiency, establishing SW-PCT as a robust solution that balances detection accuracy and processing speed for industrial nondestructive testing applications.

title: An Artificial Intelligence Enabled Approach to Plan and Find Recipe
authors: Chitresh Malhan, Raj Kumar, Neetu Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) gave such impressive solutions to various spheres and also to the culinary and nutrition industries. The suggested AI-based web application will provide its users with powerful recipe creation, automated ingredient alternatives, and nutritional knowledge based on the ingredients that the users provide. The system used does not rely on merely a set of static databases, but employs natural language processing and generative models to present context-sensitive and culturally diverse suggestions of recipes. It also is able to respond to limitations in diets whilst considering the availability of ingredients by proposing desirable surrogates that do not affect the taste or maintain the nutritive budget. The application integrates a modular architecture with AI API SaaS such as OpenAI GPT and Stable Diffusion, and offers an easy to understand web interface built in with modern web technologies. The paper presents the design approach, combined with AI modules, as well as the performance evaluation criteria that the system will perform effectively in contributing to healthy eating and food waste reduction through rational use of available products. The article also mentions limitations and gives opportunities to enhance contextual and personalized assistance in AI apps in relation to the culinary area.

title: Integrated Multi-Purpose Algae-Based Bioenergy System
authors: T. Rama Subba Reddy, Srikant Ganji, B. Venugopal, G. Shivakumar, G. Anu, M. Ganesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Environmental issues require some sustainable alternatives to fossil fuel. The paper introduces a bioenergy system utilizing microalgae to help achieve a photosynthetic microalgae-microbial fuel cell (MFC) as a system that provides electricity with other advantages which include carbon capture, the release of oxygen and the utilization of waste water. Chosen algal strains also emit electrons during photosynthesis that are harnessed over an effective MFC circuit using nanostructured electrodes to allow supplies of electrons into the MFC. The effects of the intensity of light, the availability of nutrients, the density of algae on the performance of the system are studied. The results indicate that the prototype can provide the consistent voltages up to 7 V, which can be used to drive lowvoltage gadgets and sensors, especially in a setting without an electric grid or off-grid settings. In addition to energy generation the system has other benefits in ecological values and cost-effective implementation. This study identifies algae as a potentially scalable, renewable source of energy and the technology as a potential future avenue in the development of decentralized, eco-friendly power generation in line with the worldwide sustainable clean energy objectives.

title: Decision Models for Marketing Strategies in Engineering Industries: An Autoencoder-Based Deep Learning Approach for Customer Behavioral Segmentation
authors: Said Almaqbali, Asmaa H. Marhoubi, Oualid Ali
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This work provides a light-weight deep-learning customer segmentation pipeline in engineering-based retail settings. The proposed work uses an autoencoder-based latent feature extraction alongside unsupervised clustering. The data consists of 15,079 customer records, which have five basic behavioral and demographic characteristics. In order to have a reproducible assessment benchmark, the data were treated via a stratified 80/20 train-test divide; the auto-coder was furnished with the training data to train as a non-linear latent representation. The best combination of clusters was obtained through the silhouette analysis and the elbow method, where a better silhouette score was attained at k = 2 (0.56). Other measures, such as Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) and Normalised Mutual Information (NMI), were also calculated to ensure stability of the clusters. To compare the latent embeddings of the autoencoder to the benchmark, representations of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and t-Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) were compared to the latent embeddings of the autoencoder. The autoencoder proved to have a better ability to discover concealed segments of behaviour in micro-dimensions that were not reflected in the conventional dimensionality reduction. The findings revealed that, although demographic variations across clusters were not significant, there was a significant variance in spending behaviour, which is critical in targeted marketing, personalized recommendations, optimisation of loyalty programmes, and strategic pricing. The contribution of this work is that it provides a resource-efficient neural framework, which combines both feature learning and unsupervised clustering in aiding marketing decision-making. The implications of the results are widely applicable in the retail, engineering, and customer analytics sectors, in which behavioural insights can be used to develop personalised engagement tactics.

title: WAC-YOLO: A Novel Lightweight Detection Algorithm for Safety Equipment on Construction Sites
authors: Xi Cheng, Xiaofei Liao, Chunlong Xu, Bohang Chao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: To tackle the challenges of small-object detection in construction site safety monitoring, this paper presents a lightweight model named WAC-YOLO, specifically designed to overcome the deployment limitations of edge devices caused by the large number of parameters and high computational cost of existing algorithms (e.g., YOLOv11n with 2.59M parameters and 6.6 GFLOPs). The proposed model incorporates three key optimizations: (1) a multi-level wavelet convolution (WTConv) to enhance small-object feature extraction, (2) a dual-path ADown module to reduce the computational burden of single-layer operations, and (3) a CCFF neck network to decrease the non-maximum suppression (NMS) overhead. Experimental results show that WAC-YOLO achieves 73.6% mAP50 with only 1.40M parameters and 4.3 GFLOPs, representing 46% fewer parameters and a 34.8% reduction in computational cost compared with the baseline model.

title: Phylo-Spatial Graph Neural Networks for Autism: Integrating Evolutionary, Genetic, and Functional Connectivity
authors: Rakshan N, Jeetashree Aparajeeta
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) involves complex disruptions in large-scale brain connectivity, which vary across individuals and are rooted in both neurodevelopmental and genetic factors. To better model this variability, we introduce a biologically informed Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework that integrates insights from evolutionary biology, gene expression, spatial neuroanatomy, and functional brain dynamics. By embedding these priors into brain graph representations derived from resting-state fMRI, our framework captures both individualized connectivity patterns and biologically conserved relationships. A dual-stage GNN is then trained for ASD classification and emotional state decoding. Experimental results demonstrate improved performance (87% Accuracy) and interpretability, highlighting the promise of biologically enriched graph learning in advancing precision modeling of neurodevelopmental conditions.

title: Optimization of Meteorological Data Retrieval Based on Spatial Grid Encoding
authors: Zhiang Zhu, Boyang Gao, Zhuoran Li, Shaohui Yang, Xiang Zuo, Xiaoli Ren, Xiaoyong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: With the continuous development of meteorological observation and detection means as well as numerical forecasting technology, meteorological data have seen a huge growth in terms of types, forms, and volume, which has brought great challenges to the retrieval of meteorological data. In order to alleviate this problem, in this paper, we propose a method named GeoMet, which is based on the Geohash encoding algorithm. Specifically, it firstly decodes meteorological data by the NetCDF library, then employs the Geohash algorithm to spatially encode data. This process transforms the two-dimensional latitude and longitude spatial ranges into comparable one-dimensional strings. Thirdly, according to the characteristics of meteorological data access, we store the processed data in a columnar database, with spatial indexes constructed by the one-dimensional geohash strings. Finally, we conduct experiments on real ERA5 meteorological reanalysis datasets to evaluate the performance of our method. The experimental results demonstrate that for different data query scenarios, the efficiency of retrievals based on GeoMet improved by at least 81.7% compared to traditional spatial range-based retrievals.

title: IoT Network Design and Simulation for Smart Agriculture: A Performance and Security Analysis
authors: Jyoteesh Malhotra, Mohd Muddassir
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The IoT network has become one of the major technical advancements in terms of current agriculture practices. This study evaluates the key significance of IoT and its simulation process NetSim Internetworks v14.2.18 used for developing its sustainable performance. The utility of CBR, HTTP, and FTP as well as custom traffic are also concluded to analysis their performance metric of this technology in modern agriculture. The security measure could be considered as an important factor of this advanced digitalization in agriculture, which could foster the competitiveness and scalability of IoT for developing proper communication, optimizing the supply chain management and consistent navigation of agricultural venture.

title: Federated and Homomorphic Encryption-Enabled Lightweight Cryptography for Secure IoT Environments
authors: Pravina K. Parmar, Ramesh T. Prajapati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems in domains such as healthcare, transportation, industrial automation, and smart cities has created an urgent need for secure, efficient, and privacy-preserving communication methods. Conventional cryptographic techniques impose excessive computational, memory, and energy overhead on resource-constrained IoT devices, limiting their practical adoption. This paper presents a hybrid security framework that integrates Federated Learning (FL), Homomorphic Encryption (HE), and Lightweight Cryptography (LWC) into a unified pipeline for privacy-preserving IoT environments. FL enables decentralized training without exposing raw data, HE allows secure computation over encrypted updates, and LWC ensures low-complexity cryptographic operations suitable for constrained devices. Experimental evaluation using the NSL-KDD dataset shows that the proposed FL+HE+LWC framework achieves 91.63% accuracy, an F1-score of 92.72%, and reduces privacy risk to 0.08, with minimal overhead in communication and latency compared to existing solutions. Preliminary validation on the UNSW-NB15 dataset further demonstrates adaptability across diverse IoT benchmarks. The results confirm that combining FL, HE, and LWC enhances communication security, efficiency, and attack resistance, making the framework a novel and practical solution for scalable and privacy-preserving IoT deployments.

title: A Review of Contingency Assessment and Response Methods in Evolving Power Grids
authors: Saqib Asgar Kanth, Neeraj Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Contingency analysis is a key tool for enhancing the reliability and stability of modern power systems by identifying and addressing potential failures in advance. This paper reviews state-of-the-art techniques for line, generator, microgrid, smart grid, and probabilistic contingencies, highlighting their scope, benefits, and limitations. Recent advances incorporating machine learning, optimization, and probabilistic modeling are discussed with emphasis on their role in improving accuracy, computational efficiency, and resilience. The review provides a critical perspective on current approaches and outlines directions for developing robust contingency management strategies in renewable-integrated and evolving power grids.

title: Oscillation Stability of Grid-Connected Concentrated Solar Power Plant
authors: Rui Song, Shengliang Cai, Xuebin Wang, Guobin Fu, Haibin Sun, Zhihang Xue, Zhihao Zhang, Peng Kou
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Concentrated solar power (CSP) has experienced rapid development in recent years due to its inertia and energy storage characteristics. Compared to traditional thermal power units, CSP systems typically have a smaller unit capacity and lower inertia. Furthermore, CSP plants are generally located in remote desert areas, far from load centers. When active power is transmitted over long-distance lines, oscillations may be triggered due to mismatches in the unit parameters, excitation parameters, and line parameters. Therefore, this paper investigates the oscillation stability of the grid-connected CSP plant. To this end, a comprehensive system model is first established, which includes the dynamic models of the solar concentrator heating system, the thermal energy storage system, and the power generation system. Based on the small-signal model, the oscillation modes of the system are obtained through modal analysis. The oscillation modes related to the excitation system shift to the right as the excitation system parameters increase, indicating that excessively large excitation parameters could pose a risk of oscillation in the system. The results of time-domain simulation analysis also confirm this conclusion.

title: A mm Wave Radar Based System for Fine-Grained Sleep Postures Monitoring Under Blanket
authors: Baoqi Zhou, Kaiquan Zhou, Wei Feng, Weiping Zhu, Xianlong Jiao
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Accurately and continuously monitoring sleep posture is crucial for assessing sleep quality and addressing health issues such as obstructive sleep apnea, periodic limb movement disorder, and pressure ulcers. Wireless sensing technology has garnered attention due to its non-invasive nature and privacy protection benefits. However, current solutions face numerous challenges, such as a gradual decline in detection accuracy under blanket coverage, overly coarse posture classification, and difficulty in continuously tracking changes in sleep posture. This study presents a millimeter-wave radar-based sleep posture classification system that functions effectively even under blanket coverage and continuously monitors 14 sleep postures and 28 posture transitions. Experimental results demonstrate that the system maintains an accuracy of approximately 95% for classifying 6 sleep postures, even with blanket coverage, which is significantly higher than other methods. In the framework of classifying 14 sleep postures and 28 posture transitions, the system achieves over 85% classification accuracy and shows excellent robustness in real-world scenarios.

title: Energy Efficient Wireless Sensor Network Optimization Techniques: A Review
authors: Richa Mehta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In recent times, Wireless-Sensor-Networks (WSNs) are very important in various applications such as Healthcare, Environmental monitoring, Industry automation and Military vigilance. There are different optimization techniques in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) which improve and intensify the various parameters such as routing, lifetime, data transmission and energy consumption. In this paper, different WSN's optimization techniques are inspected focusing on data aggregation, energy efficiency, security and routing protocols. Additionally, different optimization techniques are studied and comparison has been done on the basis of node deployment, process control parameters, advantages and disadvantages.

title: Thermal Dynamics of Aggressively Scaled Redundant Free Robust D Flip-Flop for Next Generation AI and IoT Applications
authors: Syeda Hurmath Juveria, J. Ajayan, Shashank Rebelli
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This brief presents a Redundant-free robust D Flip-Flop (R2FF) architecture implemented using advanced 7nm FinFET technology, at a broad range of operating temperatures and supply voltages (Vdd). In contrast to traditional CMOS designs, temperature study at operational voltages shows a reverse trend. As the temperature increases, power rises from $1.1 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ to $2.9 \mu \mathrm{~W}$, latency declines from 18.16 pS to 14.56 pS, and the power-delay product (PDP) rises by $1.89 \times$. To evaluate robustness and reliability, gate-length ($\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{G}}$) scaling is carried out using $16 \mathrm{~nm}, 14 \mathrm{~nm}, 10 \mathrm{~nm}$, and 7nm FinFET nodes at nominal Vdd levels. These results show significant improvement when scaled down to 7 nm. Power consumption improved by $71 \%$ when scaled down from 16nm to $\mathbf{7 n m}, 64.7 \%$ when L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</inf> shrinks from 14nm to 7 nm, and $56.7 \%$ when $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{G}}$ reduced from 10nm to 7 nm. Delay analysis shows that as the $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{G}}$ shrinks from 16nm to 7 nm, it shows an improvement of $\mathbf{3 7. 3 \%} \boldsymbol{.} \mathbf{2 0. 5 \%}$ improvement when L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</inf> shrinks from $\mathbf{1 4 n m}$ to 7 nm, and $9.8 \%$ of improvement when $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{G}}$ shrinks from 10nm to 7 nm. These results highlight the efficiency and scalability of the proposed FF, which are crucial for AI and IoT devices, where real-time computing and edge devices require low power consumption and high performance.

title: PRIMAD: Building Digital Twins for Software Development Lifecycle within an Evolutionary Architecture
authors: Miguel Ángel Guinea-Cabrera, Juan Antonio Holgado-Terriza, Pablo A. Pico-Valencia
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Current Digital Twin (DT) adoption in the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) faces significant hurdles, including a lack of standardized methods, limited research, and isolated use cases. Optimizing value streams is crucial for modern software organizations, which are increasingly characterized by diverse and evolving roles. Implementing a digital twin in this context can significantly enhance the ability to identify opportunities for improvement and explore potential change scenarios. To overcome these adoption barriers, we propose PRIMAD, a progressive methodology for building an SDLC DT that delivers incremental benefits by leveraging existing empirical data from issue-tracking systems, such as JIRA. This approach resolves the "cold start" problem, enabling simulations to emerge directly from real-world behavior. Our methodology integrates a Python-based simulation core with an Akka actor system for modeling issues and resources, enriched by supervised machine learning for context-aware predictions. Preliminary results validating PRIMAD components independently (using pm4py, Akka, and LightGBM) show promising outcomes. This paper details our methodology, presents preliminary component-wise results, and outlines future work.

title: Intelligent Multi-Drone Detection Using 5G Wireless Sensing
authors: Rakshith Ravisankar, Vidya Rao, Sreenivasa Reddy Yeduri, Linga Reddy Cenkeramaddi
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: The detection and classification of drones using wireless signal characteristics has become an important area of research, particularly with the increasing use of drones in civilian and restricted zones. In this study, we investigate the effectiveness of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models for classifying the number of drones based on Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) values from fifth-generation (5G) wireless communication. An experimental setup comprising a 5G transmitter and receiver is established using Ettus E312 software-defined radios. Then, multiple drones were allowed to fly between this transceiver pair and collect the RSSI values at the receiver. A balanced dataset comprised of continuous RSSI samples is prepared, which is then segmented into windows for training and evaluation. These RSSI samples are trained using various deep learning architectures, including LSTM, GRU, BiLSTM, BiGRU, and their hybrid models with CNN, alongside traditional machine learning models such as Logistic Regression, KNN, Decision Tree, Random Forest, and XGBoost. The performance of these models is evaluated using several metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and area under the curve (AUC). The results showed that XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy of 89.72% and a macro-average AUC of 0.9923, while CNN reached an accuracy of 89.38% and a macro-average AUC of 0.9937. Experimental results show that simpler models like XGBoost and CNN outperform more complex DL architectures in terms of both accuracy and AUC.

title: Multi-Process Impact Electric Load Forecasting in Steel Industry Based on Hierarchical Multi-Head Attention Mechanism
authors: Chenhui Zhang, Tianyu Wang, J. Zhao, W. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: By accurately predicting electricity load in the steel industry, enterprises can be enabled to gain a more precise understanding of power operation conditions and to make reasonable dispatching decisions accordingly, thus enhancing production efficiency. Due to the complex processes and multiple load categories in the steel industry, among which the fluctuations of impact loads are particularly intense, forecasting impact loads in the steel industry has always been a research hotspot for researchers. A hierarchical multi-head attention mechanism model integrating production scheduling data is proposed to achieve refined modeling and forecasting of multi-process load fluctuations, employing a three-layer attention architecture to parse complex correlations between processes in a layer-by-layer fashion: bottom-layer intra-process attention highlights key operations within each process; middle-layer inter-process attention captures collaborative effects and differentiated relationships across processes; top-layer global attention fuses process correlation features and load temporal features, adjusts temporal weights, and enables future load forecasting. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with traditional forecasting models and single-attention architectures, significant improvements in load forecasting accuracy are achieved by the proposed model, thereby providing a "data-driven + process-aware" approach for load forecasting in the steel industry, facilitating power grid load balancing and energy consumption optimization, and realizing substantial engineering application value.

title: Optimizing Microgrid Efficiency through Edge Computing: A Comparative Analysis with IoT Technologies
authors: Shruthi Devadhas, R. Rengaraj, M. Supriya, C Bastin Rogers, D Preethi, Rathi Abeth
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Microgrids are considered one of the technologies capable of promoting energy sustainability and resilience. Related Work Microgrid systems are widely monitored and managed based on IoT. Despite this fact, IoT-based solutions are also getting restricted more and more with high latency and restricted processing power as the microgrid becomes more complex. This paper aims to circumvent these computational inefficiencies and maximize the overall system efficiency. This paper examines the use of Edge computing in the microgrid. The study measures and compares the latency, data rate, and energy efficiency between Edge computing and IoT via a microgrid testbed. As observed in the actual experiment, the latency can be significantly reduced and the data processing efficiency significantly enhanced by edge computing compared with the traditional way of IoT. Through the support for flexible and efficient microgrid operation, edge computing contributes to the optimal utilization of resources and the stability of the grid. The findings of the study indicate that edge computing offers a promising alternative to address the limitations of classic IoT to deliver more advanced and intelligent microgrid management strategies. Accordingly, this paper provides useful insights for researchers, practitioners, policy makers, and planners to enhance the performance and penetration of a microgrid with advanced technology.

title: Comparison of small object detection approaches in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) images
authors: Mahdi SadeghiBakhi, Ali Adib Arnab, King Fai Ma, Xin Wang, Henry Leung
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
