abstract: Accurate detection of small objects remains a challenge in computer vision, especially in the context of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery, where objects often appear at low resolutions in complex backgrounds. In this paper, we review the limitations of current deep learning-based object detection algorithms and analyze the performance of recent architectures including YOLO, Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (MRCNN) and adaptations for small object detection in aerial scenarios. We highlight key architectural strategies such as Keypoint (Keypoint MRCNN) and multi-task learning (Hydra MRCNN) that have been developed to address the few-pixel feature limitations inherent in detecting objects such as cars in aerial datasets. Through comparative experiments on benchmark UAV datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness of selected techniques in improving detection accuracy for small targets and assess the generalization performance. Our findings indicate that while Keypoint MRCNN enhances recall by incorporating scale-invariant structural cues, Hydra MRCNN excels at capturing fine-grained features through dynamic multi-branch learning. We further evaluate cross-dataset generalization and discuss how inconsistent labeling—such as the presence or absence of ignore regions—impacts performance. This work contributes insights into robust small object detection under real-world UAV conditions and highlights the need for tailored dataset design and adaptive architectures.

title: Physics-Integrated Hybrid Modelling of GaN HEMTs Using PFNN and RLC-Based Circuit CoSimulation for Accurate Switching Dynamics
authors: Vikram Kumar Saxena, Kundan Kumar, Benjamin A Shimray
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid modelling approach for GaN HEMTs by integrating physics-informed neural networks (PFNN) with an RLC-based circuit model. Unlike conventional models that either lack physical insight or require extensive datasets, this framework achieves accurate prediction of nonlinear, temperature-sensitive switching behaviour with improved generalizability. A space mapping mechanism aligns PFNN outputs with analytical circuit responses to ensure physical consistency. Simulations performed in MATLAB and LTspice validate the model across varied gate voltages, thermal conditions, and load inductances. Simulations performed in MATLAB and LTspice validate the model across varied gate voltages, thermal conditions, and load inductances. The proposed method reduces voltage overshoot by 18%, shortens rise time by 8.1%, and maintains drain current prediction error below 3.5%, thereby ensuring physically consistent switching dynamics suitable for GaN-based converter design.

title: Design and Implementation of a Prototype Experimental Platform for Green Hydrogen Production via Water Electrolysis
authors: Mohamed Amine Ben Aissa, Hakim Kharroubi, Mahmoud Taleb, Abdenour Ferhaoui, Hocine Moulai
publish: 2025 2nd International conference on Advances in Electronics, Control and Communication Systems (ICAECCS)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a prototype experimental platform based on an alkaline electrolyzer for green hydrogen production. The system is built using affordable components, with a Raspberry Pi Pico employed to monitor key operating parameters in real time. A dedicated PC interface provides live data visualization, enabling efficient performance assessment. Prototype testing confirms stable operation and the generation of high-purity hydrogen. The modular design further supports research into pulsed operating regimes and offers a clear pathway toward scalable green hydrogen production.

title: Few-Shot Bird Sound Classification with Advanced Inference Methods and Enhanced PANN Selection
authors: Nikunj Dalsaniya, Sapan H. Mankad
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) has emerged as a powerful approach for learning representations from unlabeled audio data, particularly in domains like bioacoustics where labeled data is scarce. While recent work has demonstrated the effectiveness of SSL for bird sound classification in few-shot learning scenarios, most approaches rely on simple nearest prototype classifiers for inference. In this paper, we extend the state-of-the-art SSL framework for bird sound classification by implementing and evaluating three advanced few-shot inference methods combined with enhanced pre-trained audio neural network (PANN) selection strategies. Using extended training (300 epochs), enhanced data augmentation, and multi-stage PANN filtering on the BirdCLEF 2020 dataset with 10,000 evaluation tasks, we achieve adequate performance improvements over previous work. Our enhancement to Barlow Twins model with smart segment selection achieves 62.72% accuracy in 5-way 1-shot classification, representing a 10.77% improvement over baseline methods and approaching the base paper’s performance of 64.19%. With the implementation of enhanced PANN selection, we achieve 65.18% accuracy, exceeding the original benchmark. We demonstrate that the combination of extended SSL training, enhanced PANN selection, and advanced inference methods can substantially bridge and exceed the performance gap in few-shot bioacoustics classification.

title: PHSFF: Parkinson’s Diagnosis via Heterogeneous Stream Fusion with Spiking-GAT Framework
authors: Jing Qin, Boao Wang, Zumin Wang, Ming Cai, Qiang Ma, Qiufeng Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Clinical diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease(PD) is highly dependent on subjective assessment by experts, which suffers from resource scarcity and outcome heterogeneity. Existing unimodal based machine learning methods are difficult to comprehensively capture the complex motor symptoms of PD due to modal homogeneity and spatio-temporal alignment challenges of heterogeneous data. In this paper, we propose Parkinson’s Heterogeneous Stream Fusion Framework (PHSFF), which for the first time unites event camera gait data and RGB hand video data to achieve high-precision assisted diagnosis through dual-stream network architecture and dynamic decision-level fusion. PHSFF innovatively designs: Firstly, for event stream gait data, a feature extraction module is constructed based on the Spiking Neural Network (SNN) with Temporal-Channel Joint Attention (TCJA). This module utilizes the bio-temporal coding properties of spiking neurons to enhance the gait phase modeling capability. Secondly, for RGB hand videos, a cascade architecture of Graph Attention Network variant 2 (GATv2) with BiLSTM is proposed, which is derived from the spatial relationships of hand joint points and temporal motion to extract tremor and bradykinesia features; Thirdly, a dynamic weighted fusion strategy is designed to integrate complementary information from heterogeneous modalities at the decision-level to avoid the temporal alignment problem. A series of experiments on the self- constructed multimodal dataset PHG-MD have shown that PHSFF is able to achieve better performance.

title: Predicting Stroke Disease Factors with Stacking Classifier: Leveraging Ensemble Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Randi Rizal, Mochamad Renaldi, Widyastuti Andriyani, Alam Rahmatulloh, Erna Haerani, Irfan Darmawan
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Health issues worldwide are always a major topic, including in our beloved country, Indonesia. In Indonesia itself, it is often not free from attacks of dangerous diseases that can affect health issues in society in the future, one of which is "Stroke." Stroke ranked second in the world as a cause of death after ischemic heart disease in 2019. However, in Indonesia, this disease ranked first as the leading cause of death in the same year, with recorded data of 131.8 deaths per 100,000 population. There are several risk factors that can increase a person's potential to suffer from a stroke, including three main factors: health factors, lifestyle factors, and other factors. Other factors include age and hereditary factors. Therefore, in relation to this, a machine was created and programmed to identify the factors of stroke disease. The machine has obtained prediction results using several algorithms, including KNN which achieved an accuracy of 98%, Decision Tree which achieved an accuracy of 98%, SVM which achieved an accuracy of 81%, and Logistic Regression which achieved an accuracy of 76%. These four algorithms will be combined with one of the algorithms from the ensemble machine learning method, namely the stacking classifier, which results in an accuracy improvement to 99.35. This can prove the hypothesis regarding the indication of 3 stroke-causing factors based on three factors: age, blood sugar, and weight. Next, the recommendation for future research is to focus on experimenting with other meta-models of ensemble machine learning methods, such as bagging or voting. Additionally, it can also focus on other base models of the four algorithms used in this study to be further improved through ensemble machine learning method.

title: Using MobileNetV2 in the Real World: Classifying Animal Images Effectively
authors: Ajay Khajuria, Raghavendra Sridhar, Rashi Nimesh Kumar Dhenia, Ishva Jitendrakumar Kanani, Deepak Banerjee, Vatsala Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Research activities are also done in a similar manner in the case of classification of animal images due to their crucial applications in wildlife surveillance and security and agriculture output regimes. The paper develops an effective system where an architecture labelled as MobileNetV2 is used to determine dog, butterfly, chicken, cow, cat, horse, elephant, sheep, and spider species as well as squirrel species. Kaggle offers 26,179 animal images and these are categorized into ten classes. The technique consists of four different stages that begin with data preparation followed by preprocessing and the model development and finally a performance evaluation. MobileNetV2 is an advanced architecture that functions as a mobile as well as embedded systems operating model with its light-weight architecture that ensures accuracy and performance in minimal compute requirements. Evaluation of the performance of the model is based on a classification report and a confusion matrix and an analysis of the accuracy of the training and validation. The model proposed overall accuracy of 95 percent with very good precision and recall and F1 scores across all classes of classification. The model is very robust since the confusion matrix indicates few figures comprising of misclassifications. As of the system implementation, MobileNetV2 proves to be efficient in bringing accuracy in classifying animal images, thus rendering itself useful in animal conservation efforts and livestock applications on management and commercial automation processes.

title: Biogas to Hydrogen: A Comprehensive Analysis of Fuel Cell Efficiency and its Role in generating power and reducing Battery Usage
authors: Shashank Bhaskar, Om Hari Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: This paper analyses hydrogen-reforming techniques from biogas and its application in different types of fuel cells to generate efficient electricity. This study explores the different techniques to extract hydrogen from biogas, offering a renewable alternative to conventional hydrogen sources like fossil fuels. Comparative study of different fuel cells through examination of their temperature range, electrolytic nature, fuels required (including direct biogas or pure hydrogen), waste products, and their pros and cons. Further calculated the overall efficiency of biogas-to-fuel-cell power generation by incorporating combined heat and power (CHP) methods to enhance energy utilization and performance. The use of hydrogen produced from biogas in fuel cell power generation effectively produces less pollution and serves as an alternative to standard battery systems in sectors such as grid power management and the transportation sector.

title: Exploring the Psychological Landscape of Intelligent Machines: Consumer Technology Vulnerability, Affordances and Adoption Dynamics of Agentic AI
authors: Pardeep Kumar, Richa Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: Human race is continually evolving with latest advancements in technology. Humans and beautifully mastered the art and science of living with machines. Artificial intelligence has greatly enhanced the human intelligence with machine learning, neural networking, deep-learning etc. The world of finance is also witnessing the rise in efficiency, effectiveness and productivity with deployment of such innovations & techniques. The financial ecosystem has started exploring the usage of one of the latest development in this area, Agentic-AI. This is providing a competitive edge through hyperpersonalizing the experience of users while providing the power of autonomous decision-making. Despite of these advantages, agentic-AI systems have yet to be seen with widespread adoption in the global financial world. This poses for a great case of examining the different relevant psychological and perceptual factors influencing Agentic-AI adoption intentions in the financial advisory services. Grounded in the Technology Affordances and Constraints Theory (TACT) & technology acceptance framework (TAM), this study explores a multidimensional model investigating role of consumers' perceptions and technological affordances. Further, the impact of Consumer Technology Vulnerability (CTV) is investigated as a mediator in these relationships. To achieve this the survey results of 213 users of Agentic-AI enabled financial services in India are analyzed using PLS-SEM. The findings conclude CTV as a partial mediator in this relationship.

title: Improved GAN Based Operating Scenario Generation of Power System Under Persistent Extreme Weather
authors: Guolong Chen, Ji Zhang, Youhui Chen, Qiang Ma, Zikai Jin, Shuai Zhu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This Amid worsening climate change, frequent extreme weather events are causing large-scale blackouts and electricity curtailments. Power systems with high renewable penetration face significant uncertainties in both generation and load, challenging secure operation. Accurate generation of extreme supply-demand scenarios is thus essential for reliability assessment. Existing methods, however, often overlook the complex correlations between wind, solar, and load. This paper employs an Information Maximizing Generative Adversarial Network (InfoGAN) to model renewable output and evaluate system resilience. Case studies show the method effectively captures historical correlations and improves extreme scenario accuracy, supporting more secure power system planning.

title: Applicability of Permanent Magnet Flux Switching Machines for Electric Bicycle Mid-Drive Application
authors: Enlong Wang, Bowei Chen, Huan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper investigates the applicability of permanent magnet flux switching machines for electric bicycle mid-drive application as potential alternatives to the popular fractional-slot concentrated-winding permanent magnet synchronous machines. Based on the stringent space envelope and performance requirements from the application, two candidate versions of such machine with the same stator outer diameter, rotor inner diameter, permanent magnet volume, air gap length, and axial stack length, have been proposed. The response surface method is implemented to carry out optimization of the two machine configurations based on two-dimensional parametric finite element analysis. The optimal designs of the machines are comprehensively compared with a conventional fractional-slot concentrated-winding permanent magnet synchronous machine with spoke-type rotor. Additionally, three-dimensional finite element analysis is employed to reveal the end effect from the peculiar stator topology. The conclusive results further underpin the viability of the proposed permanent magnet flux switching machines with appropriate optimizations as an appealing contender for electric bicycle mid-drive application.

title: Operation Optimization for Coordinated Control System of Coal-Fired Units Based on Background Knowledge Graph
authors: Shuxian Peng, Xinyu Zhang, Zhongyang Han, Jun Zhao, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: The coordinated control system (CCS) of coal-fired unit is crucial for their stable and economical operation. However, existing methods struggle to adapt to the variable operating conditions of the unit, particularly in dynamically matching the main steam pressure with load setpoints, resulting in suboptimal control performance. To address this challenge, a dual-layer collaborative optimization approach is proposed in this study. In the optimization layer, a Background Knowledge Graph (BKG) for CCS is constructed to effectively integrate historical operational data and expert knowledge, identifying the complex coupling relationship between load and main steam pressure, thereby generating an optimal operating setpoint curve that balances both economic efficiency and operation stability. In the control layer, the Data-Driven Predictive Control (DDPC) algorithm is employed to overcome the limitations of model-dependent control algorithms, which tends to deliver unsatisfactory control performance with low model accuracy. Experimental results based on real data of a 300MW subcritical coal-fired unit in a power plant in China demonstrate that the proposed method reduces operational costs and improves control accuracy compared to other state-of-the-art methods.

title: Classification and Prediction for Autism Spectrum Disorder affected Subjects: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models and Optimizers
authors: Prashant K. Gupta, Bireshwar Dass Mazumdar, Shallu Sharma, Gurlal Singh
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurological disorder that affects a subject's growth and development in the formative years. This can have a life-long impact on the quality of life, as it influences the way individuals interact, communicate, and behave. With advancements in deep learning (DL) approaches, it has been possible to detect ASD as early as at the age of one and half years. DL models generate quick and automated classifications and predictions using facial image data, about a subject being autistic or otherwise. A lot of work has been done in this direction. However, in most of these works, the DL models generate outputs as either as classifications or predictions. Generally, no one DL model is generally best for both tasks. Also, there can be huge impact of the optimizers, early stopping, etc. on the outcomes of the DL models. To demonstrate this, we therefore, compare the performances of state-of-art DL models: ResNet152, MobileNet, VGG16, Xception and Vision Transformer (ViT); two optimizers Adam's and Lion; as well as two stopping criteria: early stopping and without. All the tests were performed on the publicly available dataset of children facial images: divided as autistic and non autistic. Our results show that ViT combined with Adam's optimizer, outperformed other DL models by generating a 91.88% accuracy without early stopping as well as 91.88% classification score. On the other hand, VGG16 gave the best performance when combined with Lion's optimizer with an accuracy of 90.36% and classification score of 90.35%, without early stopping. On the contrary, the performances of all the models and optimizers were quite poor with early stopping. We feel that our work is first of its kind to perform such comparison and provide a line of research for interested researchers.

title: Disturbance Observer Control to Face Delays and Hidden Dynamics in Grid Connected VSCs
authors: C. Diaz-Sanahuja, A. Ordono, M. Guillamon-Ferrer, R. Ortiz-Cardenas, G. Navarro-Patrón, I. Peñarrocha-Alós
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a Disturbance Observer (DOB)based control strategy for grid-connected converters and evaluates its performance against the conventional PI plus decoupling approach. The proposed structure is formulated as a direct modification of traditional decoupling mechanisms, allowing unmodelled dynamics and delays to be interpreted as input disturbances that can be estimated and compensated. The observer relies on a single tuning parameter which simultaneously determines both robustness and dynamic performance, inherently leading to design trade-offs. The main properties of the strategy are analysed, and its behaviour is assessed through time-domain simulations under different operating conditions, including parameter mismatches, weak grid scenarios and control-input delays. The results show that the DOB preserves the nominal performance of the conventional approach when no uncertainties are present. In addition, in non-nominal conditions, it provides a superior disturbance rejection and reduces cross-coupling effects at the cost of a more oscillatory transient, and a lower sensitivity margin as the observer bandwidth grows. Overall, the DOB-based proposed controller appears as a robust alternative to classical decoupling schemes.

title: Implementation of a Workplace Charging Facilities: Sizing and Preliminary Data Collection
authors: Niccolò Nicodemo, Roberto Di Rienzo, Federico Baronti, Roberto Roncella, Roberto Saletti
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: The increasing adoption of electric vehicles is a key element in fighting climate change. Unfortunately, charging operations significantly stress the existing energy infrastructure. For this reason, low-power charging approaches that leverage user working hours to charge the electric vehicles are gaining attention. Realistic usage data are essential for the effective sizing of low-power charging facilities and designing their power flow management algorithms. Unfortunately, available datasets only provide aggregate quantities but do not offer detailed information on the charging facility. This paper aims to fill this research gap by presenting a dataset of real usage data collected in two pilot charging facilities developed at the University of Pisa, Italy. One simple facility consisting of three EV chargers directly connected to the electric grid, while the second one is based on the microgrid concept. The detailed information on charging events, anonymous user data, PV production, and battery usage is collected in the proposed dataset. The database is provided freely to the scientific community as a benchmark for the sizing, development, and validation of workplace charging facilities. It currently contains the data collected during the first 16 months of activity, but it will continue to be updated.

title: Hoot:Nurturing Inclusivity by Transforming Sound Waves to Visual Gestures
authors: Ajitha Gloria A, Jeya Sri S, Varshini E, Latha B
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: A speech-to-sign language translation system for video conferencing applications is developed and shown in real time in this study. The technology interprets spoken language using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and translates it into sign language, which is subsequently shown on a 3D avatar. The video call component of the program is made with Agora, and the backend is built with Django. The objective is to improve accessibility for people who have hearing loss so that they can communicate more easily in virtual settings. After testing, the system proved to be effective in real-time translation, with an accuracy rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 5 \%}$</tex>. This offers a workable alternative for inclusive communication.

title: Application and Benefit Analysis of Distributed Photovoltaic Systems in WWTPs: A Case Study of Changchun Southeast WWTP
authors: Yu Zhao, Xuesong Wang, Yuan Wang, Nitong Yu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: This study presents the design, deployment, and performance evaluation of a 3011.43 kWp distributed photovoltaic (PV) system integrated into the Southeast Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) in Changchun, China. Tailored to the plant's electrical demand and site constraints, the system employs monocrystalline silicon PV modules coupled with string inverters and connects at 380 V via eight point-of-commoncoupling (PCC) nodes to the plant's distribution network, operating under a self-consumption regime. The paper details the system architecture, component sizing, construction methodology, and grid-tie technical measures, followed by a comprehensive assessment of energy yield, energy-saving potential, and economic viability. Annual generation is projected at 3.37 GWh, meeting approximately 15% of the WWTP's electricity demand. This output corresponds to an annual reduction of 1078.88 tonnes of standard coal. The project achieves a payback period of 10.88 years, demonstrating significant environmental benefits and economic feasibility. The findings provide a replicable engineering reference for distributed energy integration in energy-intensive industrial facilities, particularly WWTPs.

title: Impact of Digital Infrastructure on Supply Chain Robustness: The Mediating Role of Risk Mitigation
authors: Hari Prasath Jothiswaran
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: The study examines how digital infrastructure and the management information system and digital supply chain strengthens the supply chain management, particularly as it regards to risk mitigation. Team of experts examined the data of 360 employees of textile firms in Saudi Arabia. According to the findings, firms with digital infrastructure capabilities can reduce the probability of supply chain disruption. As a result, systems gets more robust and vice versa. The moderating effect of supply chain risk mitigation on resilience partially mediates an influence from digital infrastructure on supply chain robustness. The report further claims that enhancing supply chain operations will need investments in digital infrastructure and strengthening risk mitigation measures.

title: Enhancing Bone Fracture Detection in X-ray Images Using Faster R-CNN with EfficientNetV2
authors: Gading Aditya Perdana, Maulin Nasari, Muhammad Alfhi Saputra, Rico Halim, Kelvin Asclepius Minor
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Bone fracture detection from X-ray images remains a challenging diagnostic task, particularly for subtle or hairline fractures that are often missed in clinical practice. This study explores the use of Faster R-CNN with an EfficientNetV2 backbone for automatic fracture detection and investigates enhancements through feature aggregation and cost-sensitive optimization. Using the FracAtlas dataset (4,083 images with 717 fracture annotations), we evaluated baseline and enhanced models with standardized preprocessing, augmentation, and training strategies. The proposed configuration with Path Aggregation FPN and cost-sensitive loss achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.50:0.95) of 0.2016, representing a 21.6% relative improvement over the baseline Faster R-CNN with EfficientNetV2-S. Results indicate that reweighting errors on small fracture regions and strengthening bidirectional feature fusion can provide more reliable detection, though challenges remain in achieving precise bounding-box localization at stricter IoU thresholds. This suggests that the approach has potential as a supportive tool in computer-aided diagnosis, contributing incremental improvements to bone fracture detection workflows.

title: Dual Attention Guided Wavelet Domain ISTA-Net for Noise-Resilient Underwater Passive Sonar Detection and Classification
authors: Riya Rani S S, Sumit Datta
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: A narrow band of spectral lines observed in the low-frequency analysis and recording (LOFAR) of the underwater acoustic signal received by the passive sonar indicates the presence of underwater targets. However, low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions degrade the quality of the LOFAR spectrum, causing these spectral lines to become weak or buried in ambient noise. Traditional line enhancing often struggle to suppress residual noise effectively due to weighted noise in adaptation. This paper presents a robust spectral enhancement framework that integrates frequency domain ALE preprocessing with an dual attention guided iterative shrinkage thresholding algorithm (ISTA) in the wavelet domain. The ALE stage effectively reduces broadband noise and preserves spectral line structure. The subsequent ISTA block utilizes the wavelet transform’s multiresolution and localized time-frequency analysis capabilities and incorporates a learnable attention mechanism that adaptively weights wavelet coefficients to perform enhancement by preserving spectral features and promoting sparsity. Experimental evaluations show that the proposed method, namely dual attention guided wavelet domain ISTA-Net spectral line enhancer achieves an SNR improvement of 4.45 dB over fast block-processed sparsity-based ALE and 6.37 dB over conventional frequency-domain ALE. To further study the recognition accuracy of the proposed method, a ResNet-based classifier is used. The proposed method attains a classification accuracy of 96.32% outperforming existing state-of-the-art techniques. These results confirm the method’s effectiveness in enhancing target detection and recognition in underwater environments.

title: An Encoder-Only Transformer with Features-as-Tokens for Robust Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Mohaned Mohammed Naji Hider, Fayruz Rahma, Arrie Kurniawardhani
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Modern intrusion detection systems increasingly rely on machine learning models that can handle heterogeneous flow features, severe class imbalance, and evolving network traffic. While prior Transformer-based IDS approaches have shown promise, many suffer from evaluation issues such as temporal leakage and insufficient handling of extreme class imbalance. This work introduces a comprehensive framework that combines a strictly leak-free evaluation protocol with an encoder-only Transformer that treats flow features as tokens, enabling the model to capture cross-feature interactions while remaining lightweight and deployment-friendly. The architecture incorporates a learnable feature-gating tokenizer and attention-based pooling, trained within a pipeline that uses time-aware splits, train-only preprocessing, robust imputation, outlier handling, and quantile-based scaling. Training stability and generalization are further improved through mixup regularization, a One-Cycle learning-rate schedule, stochastic weight averaging, and a focal-style loss for imbalanced data.On the CICIDS2017 benchmark, the proposed Transformer achieves an AUC-ROC of 0.99986, a PR-AUC of 0.99944, an accuracy of 0.9978, and an F1-score of 0.9943 for binary intrusion detection. In the more challenging 15-class setting, it attains an accuracy of 0.9977 and a macro F1-score of 0.6939, with strong performance on frequent attack categories. The model demonstrates competitive performance compared to traditional tree-based methods while maintaining exceptional computational efficiency with only 354K parameters and 0.0087ms inference latency per flow. An ablation study confirms the contribution of each pipeline component to overall robustness.

title: Cyberattack Detection via Kalman Filter-Based Dynamic State Estimation in DC Microgrids
authors: Siyu Chen, Hung D. Nguyen, Changyun Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: Distributed secondary control improves the operational performance of DC microgrids but also increases cyberattack threats in the presence of tight communication between distributed generators. This paper presents a cyberattack detection method using state residuals and Kalman filter-based dynamic state estimation (KDSE) to identify false-data injection (FDI), denial-of-service (DoS) and communication delay attacks. The DC microgrid is linearized to obtain a compact linearized statespace model, in which the attack effects are represented in the measurement channels. The KDSE innovation is used to quantify the discrepancies between predicted and measured signals, and its normalized innovation energy enables <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\chi^{2}$</tex> hypothesis tests for attack detection. Simulation studies and OPAL-RT realtime experiments demonstrate reliable detection of FDI and DoS attacks, while delay attacks produce weaker statistical characteristics and remain more difficult to identify.

title: An Integrated Sensor-Based Machine Learning System for Predicting Crops and Fertilizers
authors: Sumaiya MN, Vinu.R, Srilatha Y, Syed Ateequr Rehman, Sindu K, Kavyashri G, Sai Meghana Y, Shashidhar S Mannapur
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Selecting suitable crops based on soil nutrient composition, including nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), and other essential elements, is a significant challenge for farmers. Traditional soil testing methods are time-consuming, requiring several weeks for laboratory results, and often do not include crop recommendations. To address this issue, we propose a system integrating sensor technology with machine learning algorithms such as Random Forest, Naïve Bayes, and KNN classifiers to analyse soil properties in real time. Sensors measure key soil parameters such as N, P, K, pH, temperature, and humidity, transmitting real time data to three machine learning models implemented in Python. The proposed system then predicts three optimal fertilizer and crop choices, enhancing both yield and soil sustainability. Instead of suggesting generic fertilizers, the model detects nutrient deficiencies and recommends only the necessary supplements. Using multiple algorithms, it generates three crop and fertilizer options, giving farmers the flexibility to choose the best fit for their needs. For random data samples collected from nearby our areas, proposed method predicts Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Potassium and pH with the accuracy of 95.24%, 97.96%, 97.23% and 100% respectively.

title: Scene Chinese Recognition with Mix Attention and LLM
authors: Xiahan Yang, Hui Zheng, Yinting Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Scene text recognition is a challenging task due to the inter-class similarity and intra-class variations of Chinese characters. To address these issues, this paper proposes the MANet model, which consists of a mixed attention mechanism and GPT. The model first extracts features using Local Attention (LA) and Global Attention (GA), where LA focuses on local information and GA captures long-range dependencies. Then, an encoder-decoder structure is used for text encoding, followed by GPT for semantic refinement, optimizing the recognition of characters with hierarchical relationships. Experimental results on the Chinese Scene dataset show that MANet achieves an accuracy of 77.92%, demonstrating its effectiveness and advantage in scene text recognition.

title: Context-Aware Detection of Malicious Social Media Accounts Using BERT-Driven Language Representation and User Behavior Profiling
authors: Asha Kurian, Darshit Sheth, Vrushil Shah, Namya Shah, Deepika Nayak, Tina Babu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Communications (COMPUTINGCON)
abstract: This study introduces a hybrid deep learning framework for the detection of fake social media accounts by integrating textual and behavioral data. We leverage BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) to generate rich contextual embeddings from user-generated text, such as profile descriptions and posts. Concurrently, we engineer a set of numerical features from account metadata, including follower-to-following ratios and activity patterns, to profile user behavior. These multimodal inputs are then processed through a unified neural network with dense layers to classify accounts as either genuine or fake. The model was trained and evaluated on a synthetic dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2, 0 0 0}$</tex> accounts designed to mirror real-world user behaviors. While our approach achieved exceptionally high performance on this dataset, with an accuracy of 99.7 %, we recognize that these results reflect performance on synthetic data and highlight the model's potential. This work demonstrates that combining transformer-based language understanding with behavioral feature analysis provides a powerful and robust methodology for fake account detection, laying the groundwork for future testing on real-world, uncurated data.

title: Optimal Selection Method of Setting Starting Point Based on Importance of Protection Coordination Relationship
authors: Qian He, Dongzan Yang, Xiaoyong Sun, Tingbai Zhang, Ling Luo, Kai Guan, Gong He, Fuke He
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: The setting of relay protection in power system refers to setting appropriate setting values for the protection devices of the system to ensure coordination between protection devices when a fault occurs, thereby avoiding the expansion of the scope of the accident. Due to the complex topological structure of the power network, some protections may have the same-segment cyclic coordination during setting, resulting in the inability to set. This paper focuses on the problem of selecting the ring network starting point in relay protection setting, comprehensively considering the number and importance of mismatch relationships, studies the optimization method of power grid relay protection setting, and proposes a setting starting point optimization selection method based on the importance of protection coordination relationships, solves it through genetic algorithms, and generates protection setting starting points based on the minimum mismatch relationship set obtained by optimization.

title: Lokachakra's Decentralized AI-Driven Matchmaking: A Microservices Architecture for Distributed Stakeholder Engagement
authors: Nataraj Donthula, Shweta Surbhi, Akshit Jain, Sameer, Akshita
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Mostly matchmaking solutions are based on centralised architectures, which result in issues such as low transparency, biasness, single points of failure, and control. In this paper, we built a decentralized matchmaking platform based on microservices, blockchain, and multi-agent AI systems, which interconnected various factors of a match in a system. Our matchmaking platform integrates components such as Inter-planetary File System (IPFS) for distributed and decentralized content storage, Solana blockchain for immutable record (provides better security), RabbitMQ for message queuing for efficient load balancing and asynchronous processing, and multi-agent architecture based on deep learning models. Through experimental evaluation, we demonstrate 15.5% improvements in the precision of the matches, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.5\times$</tex> throughput improvement to centralized approaches, and 99.94% availability with fault tolerance. Our work contributes to decentralized AI systems and serves as a prototype for building a transparent, secure and robust matchmaking platform.

title: TriStack: A Hybrid Machine Learning Model for Phishing Detection
authors: Nikita Nikita, Gabriel Gavin Geraldo, Said Achmad, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: Phishing remains a persistent and rapidly evolving cybersecurity challenge, with adversaries leveraging advanced tactics such as zero-day exploits, code obfuscation, and misleading URLs. Traditional detection methods, including blacklist-based methods and heuristic methods, often have trouble identifying recently emerging or highly advanced phishing patterns. To transcend these limitations, this research presents TriStack, a stacking ensemble hybrid framework aimed at improving detection accuracy without compromising interpretability. The model we propose integrates Random Forest and XGBoost as base learners, with a Decision Tree as the meta-classifier. Unlike most of the previous works that work with imbalanced data, this research employs a well-structured dataset containing 11,430 URLs, distributed evenly between phishing and legitimate samples with 87 extracted features. Model performance is assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Experimental analysis shows that TriStack achieves accuracy of 0.9624, precision of 0.9603, recall of 0.9637, and F1 score of 0.9620. These findings demonstrate that the proposed approach offers strong predictive capability and the ability for light-weight deployment, making it a viable option for incorporation into real-world security frameworks. The method’s equilibrium between accuracy and explainability emphasizes its promise as a viable protection approach against phishing threats.

title: Performance Analysis of MariaDB Galera Cluster with Synchronous Multi-Master Replication on Hybrid Cloud Computing Platform
authors: Muhammad Ananta Faturrahman, Muhammad Agung Nugroho, Aulia Desy Nur Utomo
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: This study evaluates the performance of a synchronous MariaDB Galera Cluster deployed across homogeneous (AWS-only, Proxmox-only) and hybrid (AWS-Proxmox) cloud configurations. Benchmarking with SysBench under OLTP workloads reveals that the homogeneous AWS deployment delivers superior performance, achieving an average throughput of 2,131.92 TPS for read-only and 104.42 TPS for write-only operations. This represents a 63.5% and 36.9% performance advantage over the Proxmox-only cluster for read and write operations, respectively. The hybrid configuration provides a balanced compromise, delivering intermediate performance at 1,203.06 TPS (read-only) and 91.74 TPS (write-only), which is 43.6% lower in read throughput and 12.1% lower in write throughput compared to the AWS-only setup. The Proxmox-only cluster yields the lowest average throughput. The results quantify the inherent performance-resilience trade-off, demonstrating that while a unified public cloud offers optimal performance, the hybrid model is a viable alternative for read-intensive, high-availability applications. A universal limitation is identified: synchronous replication imposes a severe write-scalability bottleneck, with 95th percentile latency exceeding 1,200 ms beyond 64 concurrent threads across all deployments. This work provides crucial empirical benchmarks and architectural guidance for deploying stateful database services in hybrid cloud environments.

title: A Multi-Modal Edge Inference Processor with Memory-In-Logic for Real-Time Emotion and Health State Detection
authors: K Mounika, S Krishnaveni, Renuka N, G Kalpana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In this paper, a new Multi-Modal Edge Inference Processor that incorporates Memory-In-Logic (MiL) architecture is introduced to be used in real-time detection of emotions and health states; it is targeted at wearable and mobile health devices. The proposed system addresses the shortcoming of traditional von Neumann architectures in which processing is embedded into the memory fabric via ReRAM-based in-memory computing to greatly decrease the latency and energy overheads associated with frequent memory access. The processor will process heterogeneous sensor inputs, such as face expression data (low power cameras), voice (on-chip microphone arrays) and physiological vitals like ECG and PPG (analog front-ends). A cross-modal attention module is conducted to unite these heterogeneous information flows to perform robust and context-aware inference. Inference of lightweight neural network models (e.g. quantized transformers and GRUs) is supported on-chip with 4-bit and 8-bit arithmetic to enable efficient inference at the edge with stringent area and power budgets. The simulation outcomes show the “0.8 ms average latency, 4.2 mW at 1.2 V” response time and power consumption of less than 5 mW, and detection accuracy varying between 85 and 92 percent across all the emotion and health state classes. The proposed solution ascends up to 40 percent better energy efficiency and 30 percent lesser inference latency compared to the traditional edge processors. Also, the architecture can do adaptive learning, with incremental updates to the memory with gated logic circuits in the MiL array, allowing to refine the model continuously on-device. The processor is scalable, reconfigurable, and very much fit in real-time processing in personalized healthcare, emotion-aware systems, and constant physiological monitoring, thereby extending the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A I}$</tex> processing capabilities to the extreme edge.

title: A Speed Range Expansion Scheme for Direct Torque Controlled Dual-Inverter Fed IM Drives Fed with a Single DC Power Source
authors: Anjuna K P, Roshan Jabeen K, Rajeevan P P
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Industrial Electronics Society Annual On-Line Conference (ONCON)
abstract: This paper presents a novel strategy for speed range expansion of direct torque controlled (DTC) open end winding induction motor drives powered from two inverters with a common DC supply. The problem of using common DC supply for an open end winding configuration is the flow of high circulating current because of the common mode voltage generated across the windings. Therefore, the scheme proposed in this paper for speed range extension, also incorporate a switching method to eliminate common mode voltage. For operating the motor at higher speed in the constant torque operating area, more fundamental voltage should be applied at the motor windings. So to get increased fundamental voltage across the windings without increasing the DC link voltage, this paper proposes a modified DTC scheme in which both the inverters are controlled based on the desired flux trajectory while operating from a single DC source. This scheme thus facilitates extension of the speed range in the constant torque region and delay the onset of the flux weakening. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme is verified using PLECS simulation software.

title: Distributed Robust Economic Dispatch for Microgrids Based on Trusted Subnetwork Monitoring Under FDI Attacks
authors: Zhuolin Liu, Yuhan Yin, Haoming Zhang, Dongyang Liu, Bonan Huang
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber-Energy Systems and Intelligent Energy (ICCSIE)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of smart grid intelligence, distributed dispatch strategies characterized by high flexibility and strong robustness are regarded as one of the primary dispatch approaches adaptable to future new power systems. However, the introduction of distributed frameworks and increased networking of information transmission have also significantly heightened the risk of cyberattacks on power dispatch systems. To address this gap, a novel dispatch framework is proposed to ensure the economical and secure operation of microgrids amidst FDI attacks on communication links. in communication networks. We propose an attack detection mechanism based on trust subnetwork observation and an attack isolation mechanism based on dynamic reputation value updates. These mechanisms enable the effective isolation of malicious nodes in microgrids through a fully distributed approach, ensuring both system security and economic operation. Through comprehensive simulations and comparative studies on a standard IEEE 39-node system, the proposed method is verified to be both correct and effective.

title: SimNet: A Knowledge Graph for Assisting Various NLP Systems
authors: Jyotsna Parmar, Manjeet Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Innovations and Emerging Technologies In AI &amp; Communication Systems (IETACS)
abstract: In the contemporary realm of artificial intelligence, natural language processing has an important role in facilitating communication between machines and people. There are numerous problems that necessitate the computation of semantic similarity, which is then calculated using word similarity, such as question answering systems, machine translation, text summarization, recommendation systems, etc. Recent trends in word similarity calculation include the use of encoder-decoder-based systems, LLMs, and other techniques. Deep learning-based word similarity algorithms need a huge amount of training data as well as a highly accurate model. This paper proposes a knowledge graph called SimNet, which can be used for the calculation of concept similarity, for the creation of encoded knowledge bases, as an extension for creating other major knowledge bases, and can be converted to a training dataset for deep learning models. SimNet is evaluated by a dataset containing various types of terms such as synonyms, antonyms, hypernyms/hyponyms, related words, and unrelated words. Different state-of-the-art models like BERTScore, Word2Vec, GloVe, Elmo, along with SimNet, are evaluated on the basis of precision, recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score and accuracy measures. The results are presented in the form of tabular as well as graphical formats.

title: IoT-Based Pedestrian Flow Monitoring for Smart Crosswalks
authors: Vishal Sharma, Shivanshu Yadav, Anshika Srivastava, Mohd Akif
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: With rapid urbanization continuing and traffic density rises daily, pedestrian safety at road crossings has quickly become a serious concern. Most conventional crosswalk systems use fixed time periods which cannot adjust to pedestrian flow on a real-time basis and can cause unnecessary waiting periods, increased pedestrian accident and congestion risk. The new capabilities of the Internet of Things (IoT) allow for the implementation of adaptive, intelligent crosswalk systems to enhance pedestrian safety and operations of the road system. We show IoT-based pedestrian movement monitoring framework, including distributed sensing, soft real-time data processing and analytics, and intelligent traffic signal control. The method utilizes a series of connected sensors to monitor pedestrian density and movement; the information (and available meta-information) from the sensors is processed at the edge, or in the cloud, to control traffic signals reactively in real-time, which limits congestion and anomalous behaviors. A simulation of a prototype was designed, and tested, or assessed, to evaluate the possible usefulness and effectiveness of the approach; simulation results indicated that the method produced a lesser increase in average pedestrian waiting time while producing an increased vehicle volume, and a significant increase in the validity of safety compared to fixed-time signal methods. These results demonstrate possible implications for IoT-centered crosswalk systems in the context of improved aide for pedestrian operating at crossings.

title: Multi-Stage Deep Learning Framework Using Stacked YOLOv8 Variants and MLP Meta-Classifier for Lung Disease Detection
authors: Neha Sehgal, Md. Arquam
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: Lung diseases continues to be one of the top causes of health burden in the world causing over 1.8 million new cases and as well as more than 1.6 million deaths annually. This early diagnosis and timely treatment are important to the success of the treatment and survival enhancement. However, most imaging-based systems are traditional with too many false-positives and low interpretability. We suggest a deep learning pipeline that can be interpreted and directly applied to X-ray lung diseases classification. It would be aimed to improve the accuracy of diagnosis, interpretability, and computation speed of the stacked ensemble of YOLOv8 models attached to a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) meta-classifier. To form a balanced dataset of 800 chest x-ray images on Roboflow, five classes were used i.e. bacterial pneumonia, viral pneumonia, tuberculosis, coronavirus infection and normal lung. Preprocessing included image resizing (224224), partition of data (train, validation, and test) and split of images (95) by at least 3 percent with respect to the model accuracy, which was (Nano: 85% and Small: 88% and Medium: 88% and Large: 86percent) image. The stacked ensemble classifier was observed to be with an overall accuracy of 89 per cent and AUCs of between 0.95 to 1.00. The next step is to increase the information and multi-modality imaging with a purpose of real-time and clinical relevant lung disease diagnosis.

title: Comparison of Machine Learning Methods for Classifying Graduates’ Waiting Time to Obtain Employment
authors: Rizkysari Meimaharani, Widowati, Ahmad Abdul Chamid
publish: 2025 8th International Seminar on Research of Information Technology and Intelligent Systems (ISRITI)
abstract: The waiting time for graduates to secure employment is an important indicator of higher education achievement, as it significantly influences prospective students’ interest in enrolling. Alumni tracking is conducted to determine the length of time graduates require to obtain a job. Predictive models for graduates’ waiting time are essential in assessing the urgency of addressing this issue. This study compares several machine learning methods—Support Vector Machine (SVM), Decision Tree, Naïve Bayes and K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), for this purpose. The dataset, comprising 500 records obtained from tracer studies (alumni tracking) and student records, underwent preprocessing, cleaning, and normalization. The attributes used in the classification included student ID (NIM), GPA, study duration, organizational involvement, competition achievements, competency certifications, scholarships, and waiting time. Waiting time was categorized into two groups: less than six months (considered "good") and more than six months (considered "less good"). Model performance was evaluated using confusion matrix, accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The results show that the KNN model achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 0.8625 . This research can assist higher education institutions in predicting graduates’ waiting time for employment and in improving institutional quality. It can develop a predictive model of students’ waiting time to obtain employment and develop an evaluation framework for measuring the performance of waiting time in securing a job.

title: AgentSME for Simulating Diverse Communication Modes in Smart Education
authors: Wen-Xi Yang, Tian-Fang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
abstract: Generative agent models specifically tailored for smart education are critical, yet remain relatively underdeveloped. A key challenge stems from the inherent complexity of educational contexts: learners are human beings with various cognitive behaviors, and pedagogy is fundamentally centered on personalized human-to-human communication. To address this issue, this paper proposes AgentSME, a unified generative agent framework powered by LLM. Three directional communication modes are considered in the models, namely Solo, Mono, and Echo, reflecting different types of agency autonomy and communicative reciprocity. Accuracy is adopted as the primary evaluation metric, complemented by three diversity indices designed to assess the diversity of reasoning contents. Six widely used LLMs are tested to validate the robustness of communication modes across different model tiers, which are equally divided into base-capacity and high-capacity configurations. The results show that generative agents that employ the Echo communication mode achieve the highest accuracy scores, while DeepSeek exhibits the greatest diversity. This study provides valuable information to improve agent learning capabilities and inspire smart education models.

title: Hyper tuning of Multi-Layer Perceptron Model to detect shunt faults in single line Power Transmission System
authors: Koyi Kotaiah Chowdary, L. Vamsi Narasimharao, M. Sunil Kumar, M. Vijaya Raghvendra, J. Ayyappa, Karishma Nalla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Green Industrial Electronics and Sustainable Technologies (GIEST)
abstract: Electrical faults occur very frequently in all power transmission lines due to various internal and external problems. It is very important to detect these faults quickly and resolve them as soon as possible to improve the reliability of the electrical supply, to protect the equipment from higher voltages and higher currents during fault conditions. In this work a multilayer perceptron model with hyper-parameter tuning is designed to detect the shunt faults in the single line power transmission system. The proposed work randomly develops a set of MLP models with different combinations of hyper parameters. All these models are carefully evaluated and selected a best MLP model with the best hyper parameters. The performance of MLP model-3 is good and has a training precision of $84 \%$ and a validation accuracy value of $86 \%$. The training and testing accuracies of the sleeted model is also mapping with slit differences. This model detects electrical shunt faults and gives information to the protection system. The protection system may clear faults or disconnect the fault part of the system to prevent damage.

title: Approx-Ch: An Approximate Chameleon Clustering for Large-Scale and High-Dimensional Data
authors: Priyanshu Singh, Kapil Ahuja, Soumyendu Raha
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd India Council International Conference (INDICON)
abstract: Hierarchical clustering remains a fundamental challenge in data mining, particularly when dealing with real-world datasets. Here, traditional approaches fail to scale effectively when the datasets are large-scale and high-dimensional. Recent Chameleon clustering algorithms – Chameleon2, M-Chameleon, and INNGS-Chameleon – have proposed advanced strategies that try to address this challenge. However, they still suffer from O(n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) computational complexity. We address this challenge here by introducing Approximate-Chameleon (Approx-Ch) that has O(n log n) complexity.Our algorithm has three parts. First, Graph Generation — here we use approximate k-NN search instead of an exact one, as used by earlier three algorithms. This results in fast nearest-neighbor computation, significantly reducing the graph generation time. Second, Graph Partitioning — here we use a multi-level partitioning approach as compared to a single-level one, mostly used by the prior three works. This change ensures that graph partitioning is robust to the errors introduced by approximate graph generation. This also facilitates minimal configuration requirements. Third, Merging — here we follow Chameleon2 by retaining its flood-fill heuristic and its merging criteria since it is the cheapest among the earlier three algorithms.On real-world benchmark datasets used in former three works, Approx-Ch delivers an average improvement of 5% in clustering quality and reduces total run-time by 86%. This demonstrates that algorithmic efficiency and clustering quality can co-exist in large-scale hierarchical clustering.

title: Multi-Objective Energy Management Strategy with Trade-Off Analysis for Marine Electric Propulsion Systems
authors: Dongjun Li, Haoxuan Dong, Liangcai Xu, Ziyou Song
publish: 2025 IEEE Vehicle Power and Propulsion Conference (VPPC)
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive Energy Management Strategy (EMS) for a marine Electric Propulsion System (EPS) featuring a Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine (DTP-PMSM) supplied by a Hybrid Energy Storage System (HESS) composed of a Battery Pack (BP) and a Supercapacitor Module (SM). The EMS aims to minimize a multi-objective cost function encompassing BP current fluctuations, overall energy consumption, DTP-PMSM winding loading, and winding exploitation. To address this challenge caused by unknown future information, an adaptive low-pass filtering-based EMS is proposed to dynamically adjust its time constant based on the SM’s State-of-Energy. This strategy effectively allocates high-frequency power transients to the SM while the BP handles sustained loads. The design rationale focuses on mitigating operational trade-offs, particularly protecting the BP from excessive current fluctuations and ensuring robust SM operation even with uncertain future power demands. Comparative simulation results across various operational cycles demonstrate that the proposed EMS significantly reduces the overall cost function—achieving improvements of up to 21.53%—when benchmarked against a baseline EMS. This performance enhancement is attributed to smoother BP power profiles, more efficient SM utilization, and better overall energy management.

title: Byzantine Resilient Multi Criteria Leader Election in Quantum Communication Networks Using VIKOR
authors: Suresh Kumar Jha, Ketan Anand, Aditya Narayan Hati
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Pioneering Developments in Computer Science &amp; Digital Technologies (IC2SDT)
abstract: In developing quantum-classical network infrastructures, where coordination, entanglement distribution, and time-sensitive control rely on a stable and reliable coordinator, reliable leader election is crucial. In this work, we present VIKOR-BFT, a leader election scheme that integrates a lightweight data-sanitization stage with the VIKOR multi-criteria ranking mechanism to improve resilience against Byzantine behaviour. To understand its practical behaviour, we developed a Python-based prototype and evaluated the protocol under a range of adversarial and high-load scenarios. The study indicates that VIKOR-BFT keeps latency growth moderate even as the network scales and sustains throughput values above 100 tx/s in networks of roughly 500 nodes. In comparison with PBFT and an optimized PBFT variant, the proposed method reduces message complexity by almost two orders of magnitude without compromising the correctness of leader selection. Under 15% and 25% Byzantine participation, the protocol continues to select an honest leader in more than 90% and 75% of the trials, respectively. Overall, the findings suggest that VIKOR-BFT provides a scalable and practically viable option for secure leader election in hybrid quantum-classical communication environments.

title: Feasibility Analyses for Shared Energy Storage Participating in Full Timescales Active Power Regulation of Modern Power Systems
authors: Rui Zhang, Mingke Ye, Haomin Li, Ruiheng Zhang, Weizhao Chen, Mingze Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Technologies (CEECT)
abstract: Shared energy storage has been widely recognized as an effective approach for active power regulation in power systems. However, its feasibility for participating in active power regulation across the full timescales has not yet been systematically demonstrated. Therefore, this paper evaluates such feasibility from both technical and economic perspectives. This paper first elaborates on the dynamic response process of frequency after the power system is disturbed, points out the characteristics of shared energy storage and its advantages in participating in active power regulation, and constructs control models for shared energy storage to participate in inertial frequency response (IFR), primary frequency response (PFR), secondary frequency regulation (SFR), and peak regulation (PR) respectively. Furthermore, this paper analyzes the economic benefits of shared energy storage at different timescales. Through these researches, the paper demonstrates that shared energy storage possesses both the technical and economic feasibility to participate in active power regulation across the full timescales.

title: Athermalization design for SOI waveguide Bragg grating photonic blood glucose sensors
authors: Hongqiang Li, Junqu Zhang, Xiaolin Li, Ming Han, Lizhen Zhang, Yueting Yang, Kangming Xu, Lu Cao, Enbang Li
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Accurate monitoring of the blood glucose concentration is critically important for the diagnosis, treatment, and long-term management of diabetes. In this paper， an optical blood glucose sensing method is proposed on the basis of silicon-based waveguide Bragg grating (WBG). This method involves the reaction between glucose oxidase fixed on the cladding of the waveguide and glucose, which causes a local refractive index change, resulting in a shift in the WBG reflection center wavelength, enabling the quantitative detection of blood glucose concentration. Nevertheless, during measurement, optical blood glucose sensors are susceptible to spectral drifts caused by environmental temperature variations, leading to a decrease in sensing accuracy. To address this issue, a silicon-on-insulator (SOI) WBG sensor for glucose concentration measurement is proposed and implemented. Two types of WBG blood glucose sensors, namely, bilateral and slit sensors, are designed, incorporating an athermalization design to enhance system stability and environmental robustness. By employing a compensating material with a negative thermo-optic coefficient (TOC) and optimizing various waveguide structural parameters, temperature-induced drift is effectively suppressed, which enables the design of bilateral and slit WBG glucose sensors with both glucose sensing and temperature compensation capabilities. The experimental results show that the bilateral WBG glucose sensor exhibits a refractive index sensitivity of 161 nm/refractive index unit (RIU) and a temperature sensitivity of 7.27 pm/°C within a glucose concentration range of 0–2.6 mg/mL. The slit WBG glucose sensor has a refractive index sensitivity of 242.3 nm/RIU and a temperature sensitivity of 2.37 pm/°C within the 0–2.8 mg/mL glucose concentration range.

title: State-Space Model-Based Digital Twin With Real-Time Parameter Optimization Using MDA-EFO for Grid-Connected PV Inverter Systems
authors: Rituvic Pandey, Nishant Kumar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper proposes a Digital Twin (DT) framework for a single-stage, three-phase grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) inverter system, leveraging discrete-time state-space modelling in frequency domain for accurate dynamic representation under all switching conditions. The DT integrates a novel CSTOGI-NSB-CGI (Cascaded Second and Third-Order Generalized Integrator, Noise Suppression Block, Compact Generalized Integrator) filter for robust extraction of the fundamental grid voltage, even during voltage unbalance, distortion, and harmonic conditions. To maintain precise current regulation and consistent switching frequency, an Adaptive Hysteresis Band Current Controller (AHBCC) is implemented. For real-time tuning of inverter parameters, a Magnetic-Domain Alignment Electromagnetic Field Optimization (MDA-EFO) algorithm is introduced, offering fast convergence through dual-force interaction involving global best and peer alignment. MDA-EFO is deployed on an OPAL-RT HIL platform for real-time experiments; the algorithm is platform-agnostic and can also be implemented in MATLAB/Simulink or other real-time environments. The DT framework accurately estimates internal system parameters, such as inductances, resistances, and filter capacitances, without relying on external training data. Experimental validation using real-time hardware measurements confirms the DT’s high-fidelity performance, as supported by the Digital Twin Fidelity Score (DTFS) metric. The results demonstrate the DT’s capability for real-time monitoring, adaptive optimization, and predictive diagnostics in grid-connected PV applications.
